column2: The military hearing against Pfc. Bradley Manning closed with military lawyers portraying him as a premeditated traitor, and the defense calling him an emotionally troubled whistle-blower.

The planned deployment of outside observers is aimed at making sure the government of President Bashar al-Assad withdraws heavy military weapons from Syria’s cities and starts a dialogue with opponents.
Republican leaders bowed to intense pressure from members of their party to end a politically damaging impasse, agreeing to accept a two-month extension of a payroll tax holiday.
The game-day uniforms of the Giants, the Jets and the Eagles owe their brightness to Barry Barone of Park Cleaners in Rutherford, N.J.
The N.B.A. has returned with the gift of a shorter season — and a lot of good teams (the Clippers, Bulls and Thunder among them).
Identifying mourners and absentees in North Korean photographs is one of the few ways for outsiders to make sense of the unfolding succession.
India’s government introduced long-awaited legislation on Thursday to create an independent, anti-corruption agency, provoking a loud outcry from opposition parties.
Positive economic data spurs a rise in the stock indexes.
A weekly unemployment figure suggested that the labor market recovery was gaining speed, but economic growth in the third quarter was revised downward.
“War Horse,” set in World War I and directed by Steven Spielberg, pays tribute to a tradition of honest, emotionally direct storytelling.
The changes sought by Dmitri A. Medvedev in his final state-of-the-nation address as president would begin to deconstruct Russia’s heavily centralized government.
A United States military inquiry concluded that mistakes by both American and Pakistani troops led to airstrikes against two Pakistani posts on the Afghanistan border.
A series of explosions ripped through Iraq’s capital, an ominous turn for a country reeling from political and sectarian turmoil that erupted after the departure of the American military.
This filling turns a typical Mexican condiment into the piquant star of the meal.

SOBEL--Alvin, in his 80th year, died on Sunday, December 18, 2011 surrounded by his family and friends. He will be sorely missed by his wife Judy, his children Susan, Jerome, Scott and Alla, sister Sylvia Katkin, adored grandchildren Max, Olivia, Joseph, Greg, Alexa, Miles and Billy as well as his extended families the Stricoffs, Pallys, Linksmans and Goldsteins. Alvin treasured his years as an attorney and lived life to the fullest. We will miss his guidance, laughter, beautiful singing voice and dynamic presence. His love embraced us all.

MCPHILLIAMY--Fred. Helen Keller Services for the Blind mourns the passing of its former Board Chairman and President, Fred McPhilliamy. For over 30 years Mr. McPhilliamy strengthened the mission of HKSB within the community as a pioneer in the field of blindness rehabilitation. Our heartfelt condolences to Vivian, his children and five grand children. The Staff and Board of Trustees of Helen Keller Services for the Blind

Brian Bassett is the founder of SNY's The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at @Brian--Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday. The Jets have always been nomads. From the Polo Grounds to Shea Stadium to Giants Stadium.

CATTO--Henry, Jr. My deepest condolences to the Catto family on the passing of my longtime friend and colleague, Henry Catto. A distinguished public servant, respected diplomat, passionate environmentalist and beloved vice chairman of The Aspen Institute, Henry dedicated his life to furthering the principles of true leadership. He was a natural teacher, and the world will continue to learn through the example of his great life. His tremendous wit, intellectual curiosity and unwavering spirit will be missed by all who knew and loved him. My heartfelt sympathies to Henry's four children and 11 grandchildren. Leonard A. Lauder Chairman Emeritus and Trustee, The Aspen Institute Chairman, The Aspen Institute International Committee

10 P.M. (TLC) TOP 10 WEDDINGS OF 2011 Randy Fenoli, the bridal gown guru of ''Say Yes to the Dress'' and the fashion director at Kleinfeld Bridal in Manhattan, looks back at the year's most memorable weddings, including the ceremony of Prince William and Kate Middleton, above, in April in London. The program will also revisit Nick Lachey and Vanessa Minnillo's wedding. Commentators include Kate Coyne of People magazine and Joe Zee of Elle. 2:15 P.M. (IFC) THE CUP (2000) Young monks from Tibet arrive at a placid Buddhist monastery in India with an all-consuming passion for soccer. The newcomer Orgyen (Jamyang Lodro) is a die-hard fan who has his heart set on watching the World Cup. He tries to watch the match in a local village, but when he is thwarted he hatches a plan to rent a television for the monastery. The boy's nontraditional ideas and modern influences at first find resistance from Geko (Orgyen Tobgyal), an elder monk who prefers to keep the outside world outside. The film's director, Khyentse Norbu, has a lot to say about spiritualism and globalization in this, his first feature, which he also wrote. '' 'The Cup' has a quiet political urgency, as well as a luminous air of religious conviction,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It is also a very funny movie, alive with a sense of absurdity and human foible.''

LEVINE--Gladys, 86, of Tamarac, Florida, passed away December 19. She was predeceased by her husband Al, and daughters Marilyn Varon and Dorothy Ellenberg. She is survived by her sons Michael, Joel and Lenny Levine, and daughter Sherry Berger. She was an owner of the Glory Hotel in Woodridge, NY, and was the office manager at Artistic Desk Pad. She will be greatly missed by her children, grandchildren, great- grandchildren, family members and friends.

Jacob E. Goldman, a physicist who as Xerox's chief scientist founded the company's vaunted Palo Alto Research Center, which invented the modern personal computer, died on Tuesday in Westport, Conn. He was 90. The cause was congestive heart failure, his son Melvin said.

BERRY--Rynn. 96, of Manhattan. Died peacefully in his sleep on December 20, 2011. Beloved husband of Nancy for 64 years; father of their children, Charles, Peter and the late Eliot, and of Rynn, Jr. by a previous marriage; and grandfather of Christopher, James, Nicholas, Peter, Samuel and Shirley. Rynn was one of the leading patent and trademark litigators in the country and a longtime partner of Fish & Neave (formerly Fish, Richardson & Neave and now merged with Ropes & Gray). He joined in 1941 and, after service as an officer in the Army Air Corps in the Pacific during World War II, returned and spent his career at the firm. He served as a managing partner and helped corporate clients protect their crucial intellectual property. A keen and skillful squash and tennis player, he was a national squash doubles champion and instilled in his family a great love of racket sports. He graduated from Yale College in 1937 and Yale Law School in 1941. He was president of Yale's chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, the last surviving member of his class in his beloved senior society, Berzelius, and a member of a renowned class of the Corby Court law fraternity. For more than 30 years he was secretary of Yale's Class of 1937, maintaining his skills as a clear and effective writer and his close ties to the Yale community, for which he had great affection. Services will be private. Contributions in Rynn's memory may be made to Yale University Skillman Associates, c/o Friends of Yale Squash, Box 208216, New Haven, CT 06520.

Ed Valentine is the editor of Big Blue View, a Giants blog. He and Brian Bassett of The Jets blog will write in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday. As a Giants fan I hate the idea that my team shares a stadium with the Jets.

CHAMBERLAIN--John. April 16, 1927 - December 21, 2011. With tremendous sadness, Gagosian Gallery announces that John Chamberlain has died on December 21, 2011, in Manhattan. Brandishing a wicked sense of humor and notoriously ornery, Chamberlain was a larger-than-life personality who was as bold and expressive as his sculptures, photographs, paintings, and films. Larry Gagosian said John Chamberlain made an indelible mark on the history of art in the twentieth century. He was a spectacular, roaring figure who embodied the fierceness of mid-century American art and who was unparalleled in his adaptation of unlikely materials for his sculptures. His influence will be long reaching, and his death is a great loss. Our condolences go out to his family and friends. Larry Gagosian

The turmoil in Iraq after the United States troop withdrawal is extending to its vital petroleum industry. The American oil giant Exxon Mobil and its partners are embroiled in a $50 million payment dispute with the Iraqi government over an oil field in southeastern Iraq that the companies are upgrading and modernizing. The Shiite-led government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is also unhappy with Exxon over a separate development deal the company has struck with the leaders of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region in northern Iraq.

Thieves entered Dulwich Park in south London on Monday night and stole a large bronze sculpture by one of Britain's much-loved artists. The sculpture, ''Two Forms (Divided Circle),'' by Barbara Hepworth, had been a familiar sight since it was installed in the park more than 40 years ago. A spokesman for the neighborhood council said it was insured for nearly $800,000. According to The Associated Press, the incident happened within hours after Scotland Yard officially dedicated a unit to investigate the theft of steel cables and metal car parts, which have become an increasing target for thieves as the price of copper, lead and bronze continues to rise.
Outdoor performances can be the worst. For this one, a jackhammer almost drowned out Jerry Stiller's opening lines: I think that I shall never see A poem lovely as a tree.

Steven P. Jobs was not a musician, and opinions are mixed about whether the invention of iTunes will be good for the recording industry in the long run, but his mark on how music is distributed appears indelible, and so the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has decided to give him a Grammy award in February. Jobs, who died on Oct. 5, will be given a Trustees Award, which honors ''outstanding contributions to the industry in a nonperforming capacity.'' The academy's national board of trustees decided to honor Jobs because he ''helped create products and technology that transformed the way we consume music, TV, movies, and books,'' the announcement said.

PINCUS--David. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the passing of David Pincus, our dear colleague since 1995. He was a thoroughly engaged philanthropist, humanitarian and staunch believer in the cause of refugees, particularly refugee children, and he traveled extensively to the world's crisis zones on aid missions. We extend heart-felt sympathies to his wife, Geraldine; his children, Wendy, Nathan and Leslie; and his five grandchildren. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board Glenda Burkhart and Scott Pelley, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers George Rupp, President

CHAMBERLAIN--John. Dia Art Foundation staff and trustees mourn the loss of John Chamberlain, a visionary artist. Embracing the use of common materials, he created distinctive and lyrical sculptures that will be remembered among the great artworks of our time. His way through life was exemplary, and his voice, sharp and humorous, will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to Prudence Fairweather and the Chamberlain family. Nathalie de Gunzburg, Chairman, and Philippe Vergne, Director
12:49 p.m. | Updated Vulcan Materials officially rejected Martin Marietta Materials' unsolicited $4.9 billion takeover bid on Thursday, urging its shareholders to refuse the offer.

An article on Thursday about the changing political landscape in Hawaii misstated the surname of one of the state's Democratic United States representatives at two points. As the article noted, she is Mazie K. Hirono, and in subsequent references should have been identified as Ms. Hirono, not Ms. Mazie.

CLOUD PURCHASE Akamai Technologies made its first cloud services acquisition, agreeing on Thursday to buy a three-year-old company, Contendo, for about $268 million in cash. Akamai, run by Paul Sagan, left, its chief executive, is in the business of speeding up the delivery of Web content. In Contendo it will acquire technology aimed at speeding up delivery of online content using so-called cloud computing. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

SIEGEL--R. Robert, of Chestnut Hill, MA, formerly of New York City on Thursday December 22, 2011. Devoted father of Jonathan Siegel, Thomas Siegel, and Lisa Siegel Horne. Loving grandfather of Emily, Maggie, Amanda, Elliot, David, Sam, and Josiah. Brother of the late Jimmy and Joseph Peter. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Central Park Conservancy 14 E. 60th St., New York, NY 10022. www.centralparknyc.org.

LONDON - Turkey's split personality has often left it caught between two worlds. Some European nations have vocally opposed the country's attempts to build closer ties with the West. And many of its Middle Eastern neighbors have been wary of the avidly secular state. Now, the country's identity is an advantage for deal makers. Turkey doesn't have the economic baggage of its European neighbors, which are dealing with the sovereign debt crisis. With a relatively stable government, it has also angled for a more prominent role in the Middle East, as countries like Syria and Libya continue to face turmoil.

GOETTEL--Gerard L.,83, retired U.S. District Judge, on December 19, 2011. Judge Goettel's law clerks mourn the passing of a dedicated servant of justice who was our mentor and role model. Our deepest sympathies to his dear wife of 60 years, Elinor, and their children Glenn, Jimmy and Sheryl. The Judge treated us like family. A man of wisdom and humor, he had a lasting impact on us all. We will miss him. The Clerks

In the Iowa caucus, expectations have historically mattered almost as much as actual results. Candidates like Pat Buchanan and Gary Hart who do better than the polls indicated have often received a big lift going into other states, even if they did not win Iowa. With this year's pre-caucus polls already having been volatile and a large chunk of Iowans still saying they are undecided, it is worth asking whether there are any patterns in the candidates who have tended to beat the polls in the past.

CHAMBERLAIN--John. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. For half a century, he worked to change our sense of art's possibilities. His exuberant sculpture was made less of common material than of memories of the American dream.

The former Notre Dame quarterback Dayne Crist announced on Twitter Thursday that he would be playing his final college season for Charlie Weis at Kansas, an unlikely reunion of two men attempting to resuscitate their once high-profile careers. Weis, the former Notre Dame coach, had recruited Crist to South Bend, Ind., under remarkably different circumstances. When Crist committed in the spring of 2007, Weis was coming off a Sugar Bowl appearance with the Fighting Irish and maintained his reputation as one of the country's top quarterback gurus. As an assistant with the New England Patriots, he had helped Tom Brady become one of the N.F.L.'s top quarterbacks, and he molded Brady Quinn into a first-round draft pick while at Notre Dame.

ISTANBUL -- Turkey halted diplomatic consultations and military dealings in a major rupture with France on Thursday after the lower house of the French Parliament approved legislation making it a crime to deny that the Turkish Army committed genocide against Armenians in the early 20th century. ''It is impossible for us to remain silent in face of this extremely intentional decision taken on false motives,'' Turkey's prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, said in a televised statement. ''We halt all kinds of political dialogue with France, cancel bilateral military functions and joint exercises as of now.''

EDERSHEIM--Hans S. Died at home on December 21, 2011. Officer in the Order of Orange-Nassau. Admired and beloved husband of Helen, father of Katherine, Bruce, and the late Elizabeth, grandfather of Teddy and P.J. Son of Samuel and Ella, and brother of the late Maurits, he was born in Amsterdam, Netherlands, on February 11, 1923. A WWII veteran, he thoroughly enjoyed his career as a stockbroker and was loved and respected as a man of outstanding integrity and sense of responsibility. Family will receive friends on Thursday 5-7pm at Frank E. Campbell. Funeral services Friday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

SAVADA--Lila. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Lila Savada, whose commitment to philanthropy has touched the Jewish community in New York, Israel, and around the world. We extend our condolences to her children, grandchildren, and entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

ARTUSIO--Joseph F. Jr.,M.D. We mourn the passing of Dr. Joseph F. Artusio Jr., founding chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology and anesthesiologist-in-chief at the present-day Weill Cornell Medical College and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. Dr. Artusio was an integral member of the Medical Center community and its highest ranking anesthesiologist for 42 years, from 1947 until 1989. He made major contributions to the field, including the development of anesthetic techniques for early surgery on the heart and research into non-flammable anesthetic agents. He was selected to be the first chairman of the Medical Colleges Department of Anesthesiology, established in 1967, and is remembered through a professorship in his name that is currently held by his successor, Dr. John Joseph Savarese. In 1988, he was given the Maurice Greenberg Distinguished Service Award, the Medical Center's highest honor. Beloved by colleagues, students and patients, he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughters Marianne, Suzanne and Evelyn; and sons Joseph F. III, Mark and Douglas. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Steven J. Corwin, M.D. CEO, NewYork- Presbyterian Hospital Robert E. Kelly, M.D. President, NewYork- Presbyterian Hospital John Joseph Savarese, M.D. Chairman of Anesthesiology NewYork-Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell

A new study suggests that the recent technology for artificial hips and knees did not perform any better than older, less expensive designs. The study, which draws on data from Australia's orthopedic registry, covered implants introduced from 2003 to 2007 and was published this week. The findings are significant for patients in the United States because many of the new designs, like so-called metal-on-metal hips, are widely used here. Those implants, which have both a ball and cup made of metal, are expected to fail prematurely in tens of thousands of patients rather than lasting 15 years or more as artificial joints are supposed to do.

PICKMAN--Morton. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of our dear friend and Trustee, Morton Mac Pickman. Mac was an energetic, frequent, and generous supporter of our work and a real mensch. We shall miss him greatly. Our condolences go out to Gladys and their large and loving family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair David G. Marwell, Dir

PARIS - British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia beat out Virgin Atlantic on Thursday in the bidding for British Midland International, the unprofitable airline being sold by Lufthansa of Germany. The International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways and Iberia, will pay 172.5 million (about $270 million) for the airline, known as B.M.I. That topped a competing bid from Virgin Atlantic Airways.

An obituary last Friday about the writer Christopher Hitchens referred incorrectly to the Falkland Islands war of 1982, in which he supported Britain. Britain responded to Argentine military action in the Falklands; Britain did not invade the Falklands.

GOETTEL--Gerard L. The judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York are deeply saddened by the death of our colleague, Judge Goettel, and extend our sympathy to his family. Loretta A. Preska, Chief Judge.

SONNABEND--Joan. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend who we both loved very much. She will live forever in our hearts and through the beauty in our home that she surrounded us with. Our condolences to her granddaughter, Jenna Norton and to all of those who loved her. Larry Rivero and Steven Neckman

More than 36 years after it was recorded, Zappa Records is finally releasing Captain Beefheart's album ''Bat Chain Puller,'' Billboard and The Wire report. The album has been widely bootlegged and has become something of a legend among fans of Captain Beefheart, the avant-garde rocker whose real name was Don Van Vliet. The project was reportedly shelved because of a disagreement between Frank Zappa, who produced the record, and a business partner, Herb Cohen. Alternate versions of some of the songs appeared on Captain Beefheart's 1978 album ''Shiny Beast (Bat Chain Puller),'' but the original tapes have been gathering dust in the vaults at Zappa Records.
International TURKEY DENOUNCES FRANCE

A New York City law that limits campaign contributions from individuals and entities that have business dealings with the city survived another legal challenge on Wednesday, when a federal appeals panel ruled that the law did not violate the free-speech and equal-protection provisions of the United States Constitution. Several plaintiffs had challenged the city's ''pay to play'' regulations in a lawsuit filed in federal court in Manhattan in 2008. A district court judge upheld the constitutionality of the law in February 2009.

CHAMBERLAIN--John, was a giant of 20th-century art. His pioneering work as an Abstract-Expressionist sculptor forever influenced the landscape of art history. We were privileged to represent him for over 20 years and were honored to have worked with him when the gallery was first established in Boston over 50 years ago. His loss is great but his legacy remains through the extraordinary work he made. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. The Pace Gallery Milly and Arne Glimcher Andrea and Marc Glimcher Susan Dunne Douglas Baxter Peter Boris

A good man is hard to find, especially in this city. But is it harder or easier to find one than to find a good bar? And is it ever even possible to find such a man in such a bar? To reveal how Grant James Varjas answers these eternal New York questions would be to give away ''Accidentally, Like a Martyr,'' his latest play. The production is having its premiere run at the Paradise Factory Theater in the East Village, where the play is set, in a small, decidedly unhip gay bar.
HELLMAN--F. Warren. The best of the best. You made the world smile. God bless you. David Parshall
An article on Wednesday about political gains by Communists in Russia misstated the date of a rally in Moscow to protest election results. It took place on Dec. 10, not on Dec. 11.

CHAMBERLAIN--John. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation mourns the loss of John Chamberlain. His tireless pursuit of discovery, his curiosity, and his intuitive process distinguish him as one of the most important American sculptors of our time. His work was the subject of a Guggenheim exhibition in 1971 and will be celebrated in 2012 with a retrospective. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Prudence and his children Angus, Duncan, Alexandra, and Phoebe. He will be missed. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman; William L. Mack, Chairman; Jennifer Blei Stockman, President; Richard Armstrong, Director; Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation

The City Room column on Monday, about the legacy of a fatal racial attack 25 years ago in Howard Beach, Queens, misidentified which of the victims acknowledged carrying a knife on the night of the attack. It was Timothy Grimes who was accused of brandishing a knife at one point, not Cedric Sandiford.

An article last Friday about maintenance work performed on an elevator hours before it malfunctioned and killed a woman in Manhattan erroneously included one New York building among those prominent ones maintained by Transel Elevator Inc., the company that serviced the elevators where the accident occurred. Though Transel's Web site listed the Hippodrome Building among its clients, the contract was terminated in August.

Former president George H. W. Bush offered an informal endorsement of Mitt Romney in remarks published Thursday, saying that Mr. Romney ''is the best choice for us.'' The former president told reporters for The Houston Chronicle that he supported Mr. Romney because of his ''stability, experience, principles. He's a fine person,'' Mr. Bush, 87, said. ''I just think he's mature and reasonable - not a bomb-thrower.''

An article last Friday about a battle between the town of Hoffman Estates and Sears Holdings over the continuation of a tax break to Sears, stated incorrectly the effect of the expiration of a tax break in the town's special taxing district. Sears does not owe money, it is owed about $125 million under terms of the original tax break agreement with the state. The money will come from tax revenue generated within the district.
COHN--Harry. Daddy, happy birthday. It seems like yesterday we were laughing & telling jokes. Miss & love you, Diane.

More than 36 years after it was recorded, Zappa Records is finally releasing Captain Beefheart's album ''Bat Chain Puller,'' Billboard and The Wire report. The album has been widely bootlegged and has become something of a legend among fans of Captain Beefheart, the avant-garde rocker whose real name was Don Van Vliet. The project was reportedly shelved because of a disagreement between Frank Zappa, who produced the record, and a business partner, Herb Cohen. Alternate versions of some of the songs appeared on Captain Beefheart's 1978 album ''Shiny Beast (Bat Chain Puller),'' but the original tapes have been gathering dust in the vaults at Zappa Records.

Spanish police have arrested a 31-year-old man and charged him with stealing a demo version of one of Madonna's songs and illegally posting it on the Internet, Reuters reported. The police identified the man only by his initials: J.M.R. He was arrested in Zaragoza, charged and released, pending a trial. Investigators described him as an avid Madonna fan. Madonna was furious in November when the demo for the song, ''Gimme All Your Luvin','' popped up online. The singer's manager, Guy Oseary, made a public plea for the leaker to stop, saying a true fan would not stoop so low. Details of the theft were sketchy. The investigation started after the singer's lawyers traced the posting to Spain, which has a generally poor record on protecting property rights. Spanish investigators said they had found recordings of the song in the man's belongings.

A news analysis article on Wednesday about health care legislation that would leave many decisions to the states described a plan to address inconsistencies in health coverage from state to state incorrectly. The Obama administration intends to allow states to use a standard insurance plan as a benchmark for benefits until 2016, when it would determine which state-mandated benefits are not essential and must be either paid for by states or no longer mandated. It is not the case that the administration would establish a national standard of essential benefits in 2016.

Technically, ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' offers a stylized retelling of the story of Easter, up to the Crucifixion, and the Passover seder that was the Last Supper. But the producers of the coming Broadway revival of that Andrew Lloyd Webber/Tim Rice musical are using the Christmas season to announce the cast, which will keep intact the lineup from its La Jolla Playhouse incarnation in San Diego and retain most of the performers who originated the production at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario, Canada. Paul Nolan, who played Jesus in both of those previous stagings, will continue in the role for the Broadway production at the Neil Simon Theater, its press representatives said on Thursday. Also continuing on are Josh Young as Judas, Chilina Kennedy as Mary Magdalene and Bruce Dow as that biblical song-and-dance man, King Herod. Tom Hewitt, who played Pontius Pilate at La Jolla, will retain his role on Broadway as well; he took over from Brent Carver (a Tony Award-winner for ''Kiss of the Spider Woman''), who originated the character at Stratford. Other cast members include Marcus Nance as Caiaphas and Aaron Walpole as Annas.

SUSER--Lori Rubin, DDS. Loving mother to Samantha and Stephanie. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Fredric Suser. Cherished daughter of Marvin and the late Silvia Rubin. Beloved sister and aunt of Lisa, Ken, Jennifer and Daniel Kornblau; and Andy, Randy, Matthew and Jonathan Suser. We will love you and you will be in our hearts forever. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, L.I. on Friday, December 23, 2011 at 1:00pm. Donations may be made in memory of Lori to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 14 Pennsylvania Plaza Suite 1710, New York, NY 10122 www.ocrf.org.

A television review on Dec. 12 about ''Rollin' With Zach,'' whose host, Zach Anner, was a winner of the Oprah Winfrey Network's competition ''Your OWN Show: Oprah's Search for the Next TV Star,'' misstated the title of the show hosted by the other winner, Kristina Kuzmic-Crocco. It is ''The Ambush Cook'' -- not ''Kristina's Fearless Kitchen,'' an earlier title planned for the show.

FULD--Richard Severin, age 95, of Harrison, NY on December 21, 2011 peacefully surrounded by his loving family. Dear husband of 67 years of Betty (nee Schwab). Adoring father of Suzi Marger (Jeffrey), Richard S. Fuld Jr. (Kathy), grandfather of Matthew Buchsbaum (Erica), Merrie and Meg Buchsbaum, Jackie Schussler (Howard), Chrissie Fuld and Richie Fuld III. Great-grandfather of Ali, Maddie, Isabel, Max and Jonathan. Brother-in-law of Martin J. Schwab. Richard Fuld was a proud Army officer serving during WWII in the South Pacific under General Douglas MacArthur and mentored by Major General Harry Vaughan. Predeceased by his parents, Dr. Joseph and Josephine Fuld, and his in-laws Jack and Dora Schwab. Interment will be at Ferncliff cemetery following a private family memorial service.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Norman Krim, who as an executive of Raytheon oversaw the manufacture of transistors on a mass scale, referred incorrectly to vacuum tubes, which transistors replaced. Unlike transistors, vacuum tubes are not semiconductors.

Steven P. Jobs was not a musician, and opinions are mixed about whether the invention of iTunes will be good for the recording industry in the long run, but his mark on how music is distributed appears indelible, and so the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has decided to give him a Grammy award in February. Jobs, who died on Oct. 5, will be given a Trustees Award, which honors ''outstanding contributions to the industry in a nonperforming capacity.'' The academy's national board of trustees decided to honor Jobs because he ''helped create products and technology that transformed the way we consume music, TV, movies, and books,'' the announcement said.

Though the comedian Louis C. K. may not seem like the kind of guy who derives much joy from the holiday season - let alone anything else - Santa Claus has brought him an early Christmas gift. In an interview on Wednesday's broadcast of ''Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,'' Louis C. K. said he had grossed more than $1 million from his online comedy special, ''Louis C. K.: Live at the Beacon Theater,'' after 10 days on sale, and would be donating part of that money to charity. Having told Mr. Fallon that he'd never had $1 million all at once in his life, and then dismissing his electronically earned largess as ''a $5 impulse that 220,000 people had,'' Louis C. K. explained that he would use $250,000 to pay for the special (as he has said previously), spend another $250,000 in bonuses to people who work for him and give $280,000 to five charity organizations: Fistula Foundation, which works with women injured in childbirth; Green Chimneys which gives outdoor and animal therapies to children; charity: water, which provides clean drinking water; the Pablove Foundation, which sponsors pediatric cancer research; and Kiva, which provides small loans to people around the world. The remaining $220,000, Louis C. K. said, would go to himself, providing a colorful pantomime suggestion of the physical improvement he planned to purchase with the money.

The ''personhood amendment,'' granting legal rights to human embryos, might have seemed to be a political nonstarter after voters in Mississippi, arguably the most conservative and anti-abortion state in the nation, rejected such a proposal last month. But the idea has not faded in the Republican primaries. Mississippi voters said they thought twice about the proposal when they heard that it would not only ban virtually all abortions but also some forms of contraception like I.U.D.'s and morning-after pills, could hamper in-vitro fertilization clinics and could, doctors warned, discourage critical medical care for pregnant women. It has also caused a bitter split in the anti-abortion movement, with traditional leaders, including National Right to Life and the Roman Catholic bishops, opposed to the idea on strategic grounds, arguing that it would end in a legal debacle that only strengthens abortion rights.

Quarterback Matt Barkley announced Thursday that he would return to play his senior year at Southern California, a decision that revives one of college football's most distinguished brands. With the decision, Barkley, who will be a four-year starter, thrust himself to the forefront of next season's Heisman Trophy race and placed U.S.C. in the national title conversation.

An art review last Friday about the inaugural exhibition at the Frick Collection's new Portico Gallery for Decorative Arts and Sculpture, using information from a publicist, misstated the time period in which Houdon's statue of Diana, now back on display, was absent. It was three years, not five.

Ever get to the end of a road trip and realize you were just a few miles away from the shoe of the world's tallest man but you missed it? Maybe not, but On the Way, a new online travel site for road trippers, was designed to help find such unusual attractions. When you enter your start and destination, the program will populate a map of your route with restaurants, museums and less traditional tourist sites using programming interfaces like Google Places, Foursquare, Yelp and Lonely Planet's Points of Interest. It can help you find a Starbucks between New York and Washington, but it's better for local alternatives like Miss Shirley's Cafe in Baltimore.

But, there's always next year.

Via Brad DeLong, there's a paper by David Romer (pdf) summarizing recent research on fiscal policy, inspired by the crisis and aftermath. And his conclusion is not at all what you hear on the talk shows; it is that there is now overwhelming evidence that fiscal policy does in fact work when it's not offset by monetary policy. And since we're now in a liquidity trap in which conventional monetary policy has no traction, that's the world we're in.

On Christmas morning 1861, the steps of all three Lincoln sons could be heard pounding on the floorboards of the White House. The eldest, Robert, had recently arrived home from Harvard, to join his brothers, 8-year old Tad and 11-year-old Willie. The reunion of the Lincoln clan was a bright spot on what was proving to be a less than cheery Christmas. The Union had lost several key battles, while the Confederacy seemed no closer to collapse. Then, before the president could sit down to Christmas dinner with his family, he had yet another matter to attend to: deciding whether the Union could risk war with Britain.

While we don't want to spoil the surprise for viewers who haven't yet seen the ''American Horror Story'' finale by revealing which characters lived or died, Ryan Murphy, a creator of that FX series, had another surprise up his sleeve, announcing on Thursday that none of characters from its first season, living or otherwise, will return in Season 2, nor will the creepy Los Angeles mansion that was the setting for the show. ''The next year of the show - every season of the show - will be a different haunting,'' Mr. Murphy said in a conference call with reporters. ''So what you saw in the finale was the end of the Harmon house, and the second season of the show will be a brand new home or building to haunt.'' He added: ''Just like this year, every season of the show will have a beginning, a middle and an end.''

KING--Joan Harding, died after a difficult illness, peacefully at home, just shy of her 85th birthday. She was born in New York City in 1927, the oldest child of Marion Choate and Charles Barney Harding. A graduate of Miss Hewitt, Milton and Smith, she worked after college for the Bureau of Standards and the NAACP. She was wed to Thomas James King, late Professor at Dartmouth and City College, from 1950 to his untimely death in 1994. Joan was a loving, generous spirit. She was a warm and compassionate friend to all who knew her, with a keen and questioning mind. She returned to college in her late 40's to earn her RN, becoming a childbirth educator and stalwart board member of the Childbirth Education Association of Metropolitan New York. She was also a staunch supporter of environmental causes in Rockland County as a founding member of the Rockland County and West Branch Conservation Associations. She is survived by her brother, Prof. Robert Shaw Oliver Harding, her five children, Hilary Pulitzer, Dr. Charles H. King, Rufus C. King, Esq., Emily King and Dr. Mary Letwin, and grandchildren Lily, Michael, Jessie, Chloe, Maddie, Maria, Nick, Alex, Noah, Gus and Charles. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made in her name to the West Branch Conservation Association, Inc., 100 South Mountain Road, New City, NY 10956.

(TMC) OUT OF THE COLD (1999) Dan Scott (Keith Carradine) is a tap dancer whose once promising career on the Broadway stage has been derailed by his weakness for wine, women and song. To orchestrate a comeback, his manager books him a tour to Estonia, his mother's homeland. There he meets Deborah (Mia Kirshner) and the two fall in love during a dancing session. When upheaval hits Estonia with a Russian occupation, Deborah flees to the United States but Dan is unable to and is sent to a Siberian labor camp.

While devotees of the struggling sitcom ''Community'' gather in Rockefeller Center and don fake beards in hopes of convincing NBC to keep that show on the air, fans of Germany's equivalent of ''The Office'' are actually reaching into their pockets to see the series continue: They have raised about $1.3 million in an online campaign to produce a movie based on the German show, which is currently in its fifth and final season, The Hollywood Reporter said. Unlike its American cousin, the German comedy, ''Stromberg,'' did not begin as an officially licensed remake of the British ''Office'' created by Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant; its production company, Brainpool, later added an ''inspired by'' credit after certain similarities were noticed and legal action was invoked.

CHAMBERLAIN--John. April 16, 1927 - December 21, 2011. With tremendous sadness, Gagosian Gallery announces that John Chamberlain has died on December 21, 2011, in Manhattan. Brandishing a wicked sense of humor and notoriously ornery, Chamberlain was a larger-than-life personality who was as bold and expressive as his sculptures, photographs, paintings, and films. Larry Gagosian said John Chamberlain made an indelible mark on the history of art in the twentieth century. He was a spectacular, roaring figure who embodied the fierceness of mid-century American art and who was unparalleled in his adaptation of unlikely materials for his sculptures. His influence will be long reaching, and his death is a great loss. Our condolences go out to his family and friends. Larry Gagosian

Tiny, Cuckoo, Shelby Lee, Ricky G and Shua

Giants (7-7) at Jets (8-6) Saturday, 1 p.m. Line: Jets by 3 Eli Manning and Mark Sanchez are down in the dumps as Christmas Eve approaches. Fans are a little fed up with both. But can you imagine a world where neither of them had even been born? (That's your cue, Clarence.) The Giants enter this game with a 3-11 record. They are trying to build the franchise around quarterback/defensive tackle Jared Lorenzen. Tom Coughlin, fired long ago, is now a punctilious librarian who fines children for returning Dr. Seuss books two minutes early and blacks out all references to vampires and werewolves in the Twilight series - the resulting novels are only 600 words long but much improved. Without a younger brother for whom to set an example, Peyton Manning became an arrogant, underachieving jerk who hangs out on Ryan Leaf's couch playing Call of Duty. Riding a wave of popularity from going undefeated and winning the Super Bowl in 2007, Bill Belichick was appointed secretary of state, and Americans have been implanted with BeliChips that feed all of our thoughts and desires into a master computer that acquired a sentient personality indistinguishable from Tiki Barber's. With the playoffs far out of reach for both teams, coaches Eric Mangini and Jim Mora Jr. meet before kickoff on Saturday for a rousing duet of ''A Fairytale of New York'' by Kirsty MacColl and the Pogues. But the most frightening element of all in this alternate reality? Without Sanchez, Brett Favre is still the Jets quarterback. And he has his own basic cable network called Telefavro. So enjoy Manning and Sanchez, flaws and all, and take solace in the fact that one team's loss will be the other team's source of playoff hope. That's another way of saying that every time a bell rings, or a football skitters off the turf, an angel gets its wings. Pick: Giants

An article on Thursday about ''A Separation,'' an Iranian movie seen as a candidate for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film, referred incorrectly to its opening in New York and Los Angeles next Friday, which will be followed by showings elsewhere in the United States. While the opening before the end of the year does qualify the film for an Oscar, the screenings in New York and Los Angeles are the start of an open-ended presentation in theaters, not ''a limited Oscar-qualifying run.''

RIEDER--William P. (Bill), 71, died on December 14, 2011 in Sarasota, FL after a long illness. Born in South Bend, IN, he was educated at Yale and Harvard University and had a distinguished career at the Victoria and Albert Museum, J. Paul Getty Museum and as curator of European Decorative Arts at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, NYC. Survivors include his brother James (Mary) of Powell, OH, their children and grandchildren, numerous cousins and beloved friend and caregiver, Richard Wilcox. A private burial will be in South Bend. Family and Richard wish to express their appreciation to the staff at Tidewell Hospice. Memorial donations may be made to Tidewell Hospice, Inc., 5955 Rand Blvd., Sarasota, FL 34238.

MICHAL-SMITH--Harold of New York, December 20, 2011. Born Harold Smith in 1919 over his parents clothing store in Plattsburgh, he later hyphenated his last name to honor his mother's Michalson family, Baltic Jewish immigrants who settled in far upstate New York. From this modest start he created a life dedicated to the underprivileged and disabled. Dr. Michal-Smith earned undergraduate and masters degrees at Boston University and Harvard, before teaching and serving as school psychologist at Milford Academy. He then earned his psychology PhD at NYU and served on Princeton's faculty. Beginning in the 1950s, Dr. Michal-Smith focused on the needs of the developmentally disabled. He became a Professor of Pediatrics and Psychology at New York Medical College, and the Associate Director of its Mental Retardation Institute. Following exposure of abuses at Willowbrook State School on Staten Island (a facility for the mentally disabled) and ensuing lawsuits, Dr. Michal-Smith was appointed to the Review Committee to oversee compliance with the Courts Consent Decree, work for which he was widely praised by public officials and advocates for the disabled alike. In recognition of his body of work in the field he was elected President of the American Association on Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities. In addition to an active private practice, Dr. Michal-Smith authored several books, served on a number of Boards, worked with a broad international network of professionals, and received several awards for his efforts in the field. A lifelong traveler, he reveled in the people, culture, craft, and commerce of many countries. In retirement Dr. Michal-Smith was active in Ladina, an organization dedicated to the memory of Portuguese Jewish Marranos. He had a deep and abiding love of animals and was an early supporter of campaigns against vivisection. Dr. Michal-Smith will be remembered for his enduring love, generosity, and commitment toward friends and family alike. His long-term Partner, Dr. Murray Morganstern, and his brother, Dr. Stanley Smith, pre-deceased him. Dr. Michal-Smith is survived by his sister, Elaine Feiden, six nieces and nephews, 13 grandnieces and nephews, and one great-grandnephew. Memorial services at YAI, 460 W. 34 St., January 5, 5:00pm.

Melanie Amaro, a 19-year-old from Florida with a power voice and an apparent gift for making almost any hairdo look good, won ''The X Factor'' on Thursday night, beating out Josh Krajcik, the man with the most compelling rasp in America, for a $5 million recording contract. An emotional night ended with Ms. Amaro barely able to sing her final triumphant number, a reprise of ''Listen,'' the Beyonce anthem that started her on the path to the prize way back in September. The Final 12 contestants surrounded her onstage in a pileup of hugs and tears, with poor Steve Jones, the hapless host, barely able to shove his way through to dredge a few words out of her.

Yahoo's board decided on Friday to proceed with negotiations to sell the bulk of its shares in the Alibaba Group and Yahoo Japan to its Asian partners, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. A deal, which involves a complicated asset swap with Alibaba and Softbank, values the holdings at roughly $17 billion. Shares of Yahoo were relatively flat on Friday, rising about 1 percent, to close at $16.19.

WEISER--Elaine F.,73, died Friday. The funeral will be held Sunday, 10am at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury. Devoted wife, beloved mother, treasured grandmother and dear friend. Tireless fundraiser and organizer - National Board of Hadassah and past president of Nassau region. She is survived by Melville, husband of 50 years, children Karen and David Weiser, Allison and Jeff Rubin, Caroline and Glenn Weiser and grandchildren Samantha, Jason, Bryan, Darren, Olivia and William.

Donald J. Trump has withdrawn from the Republican Party to retain the ability to run as an independent candidate in the 2012 presidential election, his political adviser confirmed on Friday. ''Mr. Trump did this in order to preserve his legal right to run as an independent if in fact he's not satisfied with who the Republican candidate is going to be,'' said the adviser, Michael Cohen, a Trump Organization executive.

BERRY--Rynn. 96, of Manhattan. Died peacefully in his sleep on December 20, 2011. Beloved husband of Nancy for 64 years; father of their children, Charles, Peter and the late Eliot, and of Rynn, Jr. by a previous marriage; and grandfather of Christopher, James, Nicholas, Peter, Samuel and Shirley. Rynn was one of the leading patent and trademark litigators in the country and a longtime partner of Fish & Neave (formerly Fish, Richardson & Neave and now merged with Ropes & Gray). He joined in 1941 and, after service as an officer in the Army Air Corps in the Pacific during World War II, returned and spent his career at the firm. He served as a managing partner and helped corporate clients protect their crucial intellectual property. A keen and skillful squash and tennis player, he was a national squash doubles champion and instilled in his family a great love of racket sports. He graduated from Yale College in 1937 and Yale Law School in 1941. He was president of Yale's chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, the last surviving member of his class in his beloved senior society, Berzelius, and a member of a renowned class of the Corby Court law fraternity. For more than 30 years he was secretary of Yale's Class of 1937, maintaining his skills as a clear and effective writer and his close ties to the Yale community, for which he had great affection. Services will be private. Contributions in Rynn's memory may be made to Yale University Skillman Associates, c/o Friends of Yale Squash, Box 208216, New Haven, CT 06520.

Tyler, the Creator, the young Los Angeles rapper known for violent and grotesque lyrics, was arrested on Thursday night in a club where he was performing a Christmas concert and charged with vandalizing sound equipment, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said. Sheriff's deputies arrested him shortly after 11:30 p.m. as he left the club. A few minutes earlier bouncers at the club, the Roxy on Sunset Boulevard, called the police and said the rapper had destroyed an electronic soundboard.

The trustee liquidating MF Global's trading operations said on Friday that his office was seeking the return of more than $600 million from the failed firm's British arm, potentially setting up a cross-border fight over customer money. Giddens, said in a statement that he had identified about $600 million to $700 million in American customer money held at MF Global U.K. That money, he said, was held for clients who traded on foreign exchanges.

When it comes to holiday tipping and gifts, workers who scrub our floors tend to get more than people who educate our children, according to a survey from Consumer Reports. Housekeepers receive a median tip of $50, compared with $20 for teachers, the survey found.

Opera Boston, a small company known for innovative works, is shutting down because of financial problems, the board said in a statement on Friday, according to news media in Boston. The company this season had scheduled three productions, Berlioz's ''Be'atrice and Be'ne'dict'' in October and Tippett's ''The Midsummer Marriage'' and Bellini's ''I Capuleti e I Montecchi'' in the winter and spring. The company commissioned the opera ''Madame White Snake'' from the composer Zhou Long, who was given the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in music for the work. The company faced an ''insurmountable budget deficit,'' the board said. ''We find ourselves in a financially untenable situation, and the responsible thing is to work with our creditors and cease operations.'' The company will close Jan. 1. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A headline on Friday with an article about the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's removal of a major obstacle to new nuclear power plants in Georgia and South Carolina overstated the agency's action. It approved the plants' design, not their actual construction.

A cover article this weekend about new directions in black cinema misstates the distribution plans for the movie ''Pariah,'' an independent film by the director Dee Rees about being a black lesbian. And an accompanying picture caption misstates the day of its release. ''Pariah'' will have a limited opening on Wednesday, not on Monday; next week is not its national release. (Its wider release is planned for January.)

There are few images as enduring in American history as the one of General George Washington standing tall, next to the Stars and Stripes, in a rowboat gliding past mini-icebergs as he leads his troops across the Delaware River on Christmas Day 1776 to start a surprise attack on Hessian forces during the Battle of Trenton. In his 1851 portrait, ''Washington Crossing the Delaware,'' among the best-known of American paintings, the artist, Emanuel Leutze, did not shy away from imbuing the scene with a dose of glory, inspiration and heroism.

WEISER--Elaine. My dearest friend Elaine...our hearts are broken. With love to Mel, Allison, Jeff, David, Karen, Glen, Caroline, and all the grandchildren. With our love, Barbara and the entire Shapiro and Ginsburg family

CHAMBERLAIN--John. Dia Art Foundation staff and trustees mourn the loss of John Chamberlain, a visionary artist. Embracing the use of common materials, he created distinctive and lyrical sculptures that will be remembered among the great artworks of our time. His way through life was exemplary, and his voice, sharp and humorous, will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to Prudence Fairweather and the Chamberlain family. Nathalie de Gunzburg, Chairman, and Philippe Vergne, Director

For a moment, Uday R. Durg, who directs Lower Manhattan projects for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital construction unit, looks out of place in his hard hat and reflective orange safety vest. He is standing just a few yards from a construction zone at the Fulton Street Transit Center, but he is surrounded by ordinary straphangers in ordinary street clothes. Whether hurrying through the handsome new straightaway that has replaced the maze of switchback ramps along the A and C lines or standing on the widened, ornamented and newly opened southbound platform on the R line, the traveling public has begun to occupy completed portions of the sprawling complex. ''For the first time,'' Mr. Durg said, ''people are walking through the transit center.''

ROME--Dr. Doris Spector, 85, of Bolton, NY and Delray Beach, FL died peacefully at home on Thursday, December 22, 2011. Beloved mother to Marcia Levitz (Alan), Dr. Lisa Rome, Michael Rome (Lisa). Dear sister to Mildred Kayne. She adored and cherished her grandchildren Aaron Moskowitz, Lauren Rome and David Rome. Doris (Deo) was born in Albany NY in 1926, the daughter of Harry and Irene Spector. She married Howard Rome of Troy, NY. A graduate of Milne HS, Skidmore College ('47) and Albany Medical College ('50). Dr. Rome a Cytologist and Pathologist. Her career included Associate Professor of Medicine at the Albany Medical College. An investigator for the National Institute of Health on automated Cytology. Dr Rome trained with Dr. Papanicolaou at Cornell. She received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from Skidmore College. ('62) She was founder and President of Albany Cytopath Labs. A memorial service will be held in Albany, NY on December 26 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Albany Medical College Doris Rome Scholarship Fund, 47 New Scotland Ave. Albany, NY 12208. To sign the online family guestbook, please visit, www.levinememorialchapel. com

Don Sharp, a veteran film director who had never watched a horror movie until Hammer Films -- the English studio described, usually admiringly, as dripping cinematic blood -- enlisted him in the mid-1960s to help revivify its presentation of Gothic terror, died on Sunday. He was 89. Hammer announced the death, but did not give a cause or a location.

Mount Vesuvius preserved the city of Pompeii in ash nearly 2,000 years ago, but current neglect of this Unesco World Heritage site in southern Italy is taking its toll. A courtyard column of a Roman house collapsed on Thursday, the latest in a series of crumbling artifacts at the site, Reuters reported. Last year there were other collapses, including part of what is known as the House of Gladiators. The damage played a role in a no-confidence vote against Culture Minister Sandro Bondi earlier this year. Although Mr. Bondi survived the vote, he ended up resigning in March. ''This is a torment without end,'' Luisa Bossa, a lawmaker from the leftist opposition Democratic Party, told Reuters. ''We have been complaining for three years, but the country's most important archaeological area continues to fall apart. The truth is that the site has been left alone for years and now, a bit at a time, we are paying the price.''

A federal district court judge Friday granted a request by Fox Sports to stop, for now, the Los Angeles Dodgers' sale of their TV rights and wrote that a lower court might have erred in letting the process begin. The Dodgers had received the go-ahead by a federal bankruptcy court judge earlier this month to start marketing their future television rights about a year before their current contract with Fox allowed.

LINDGREN--Richard. Dick was a thinker, a talker, a reader and a singer. He adored the opera. He was from Jamestown, NY; his father was a Swedish immigrant and his mother was the daughter of a Lutheran minister. He and his identical twin Robert went to Yale, then Dick went to Harvard Business School and into the Navy. His first job, at White Weld, was the best one he ever had. He loved his wife, Anne; they were married for 49 years. He is survived by her, his children, Sarah, Hugo and Doug, and seven grandchildren. They all remember him as gentle, kind and funny. There will be a funeral at St Mary's Church, Shelter Island, NY, on Saturday, January 7, at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St Mary's.

That sound you hear is the wrapping being torn off of millions of Kindles and iPads. When those devices are fired up and start downloading texts, it will be the greatest shift in casual reading since the mass market paperback arrived six decades ago. Will this dislocation destroy the traditional book? Will it doom the traditional independent bookstore? Will Amazon and Apple control the distribution of thought and culture in America? All these questions will be played out imminently.

Must have been nearly 20 years ago, and I was scheduled to give a noon poetry reading in Paterson, N.J. My host, the poet Maria Mazziotti Gillan, picked me up on a sunny September morning across from the big post office on Eighth Avenue, and through the tunnel to Jersey we went. It was then that Maria told me I was only half the show; the other half was a woman named Ruth Stone. I would get the same ''honorarium'' (we are so pretentious in the poetry world), so not to fret. I'd never heard of Ruth Stone, and I figured she was an upstart from the corps of 10,000 American poets younger and better than I. We stopped at a humble house deep in a civilized part of New Jersey. When Maria honked her horn, nothing happened, so I was dispatched to go to the door. An elderly woman answered. She seemed out of breath or nervous or both. (No, I've never had that effect on elderly women, or on younger ones either.) ''We're here to pick up Ruth Stone,'' I said. ''Is this her house?'' It was the right house, and the elderly woman I was speaking to -- actually she looked to be about my own age -- was Ruth Stone herself. ''I must finish dressing,'' she said. ''Have a seat.'' Up the stairs she went. I heard a door close, then another, then a toilet flush, and down the stairs she came, looking exactly as she did when she answered my knock. ''And who might you be?'' she said, knowing damn well who I was, and then she gave me a moment of her marvelous laughter. I realized later Ruth was neither out of breath nor nervous: she was excited to be giving a public poetry reading and to be paid for it. Excited to be finally honored for the work she'd done for decades in an America that rarely honors or pays its poets. The reading took place in a modest, filled-to-capacity room in what appeared to be a school building in downtown Paterson. The schedule called for me to read last, but I insisted that I go before Ruth, that we observe the rule of the alphabet. Really, I just wanted to get it over with before I became nervous. And I also knew that if Ruth read before me, I'd be busy plotting my own reading and unable to focus on her work.

THOUSANDS of kids are going to find model train sets under the tree on Christmas morning -- freight trains, circus trains, Wild West trains, military trains, express trains, commuter trains. ... But one train setup you won't see is a replica of the street-level freight line that plied the West Side from 1846 to 1941. The line killed and mutilated hundreds of people, and its path well earned the name Death Avenue. In 1846, what was then the Hudson River Railroad negotiated a charter with the city to run tracks on an irregular route down 10th and 11th Avenues to a freight terminal at Beach and Hudson Streets and then to a final stop at Chambers Street. The trains were sometimes several blocks long, interfering with crossing traffic. Pedestrian deaths along the way were fairly common. The New York Times reported at least one each in 1851, 1852, 1853, 1854 and 1855, describing one victim as ''shockingly mangled.''

A capsule look at the Giants' 29-14 victory over the Jets: Key Performance Jason Pierre-Paul continues to establish himself as a dominant force. He ripped through the Jets' offensive line on his way to two sacks (for 14 yards) and two tackles for a loss. Pierre-Paul also knocked down Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez three times, ensuring that Sanchez had his head on a swivel every time he dropped back to pass.

No gentle way to describe this one: Shannon Stone (b. 1971) died trying to catch a baseball for his 6-year-old son, Cooper. It got a lot of press; maybe you saw the footage. They were at a Texas Rangers game. There was a foul ball to left field in the second inning. Josh Hamilton, an outfielder, snagged it and tossed it to the fans. Stone reached over a railing to grab it, flipped out of the stands and fell 20 feet. He was 39, a firefighter, voted Fire Officer of the Year in his department in 2009. At his memorial service, the pastor said how close he was with Cooper, and said he was the only dad standing and crying with all the mothers as they dropped their kids off at kindergarten for the first time. And he loved taking his son to games. Just as his father took him, when Shannon was a boy. His parents, Al and SuZann, told the story of one game, when Shannon was 12 or 13, to Lisa Pollak. SuZann: Well, at that time the Rangers had a third-base player named Buddy Bell. And that was Shannon's very favorite player, just as Josh Hamilton is Cooper's player. We were pretty close behind home plate, if I'm not mistaken. Where we were sitting, Buddy Bell hit a foul ball, and it came back over --

When she hit her mid-60s, with her career and husband deceased and her health wobbly, she might announce, ''Sue Mengers is dead,'' or begin sentences in her smoky voice with ''When I was alive. . . .'' Even maudlin, Mengers was magnificent. The first woman to become the Man among Hollywood superagents was full of exhilarating vulgarity. Though she rarely ventured out in the last decade, refusing dinner invitations by saying, ''I'd rather stick needles in my eyes,'' her salmon house in Beverly Hills was a portal to a place you didn't think existed: a salon shimmering with her ''twinklies,'' famous writers, editors, directors, executives and stars -- from Jack Nicholson to Jon Hamm, Robert Evans to Tina Fey, Gore Vidal to Aaron Sorkin. She would play the odalisque, lounging in a caftan on a couch in a seductively lighted room, murmuring, ''Oui, oui'' to her guests and calling out to her helper, ''Virginia, bring me my funny cigarettes,'' a silver box of hand-rolled joints.

EIGHT years ago, Tamara Monosoff came up with an invention that she was sure mothers like herself would appreciate: a device that prevents children from unspooling toilet paper from the roll. But she had no idea how to transform the concept into a marketable product. When she turned to the Internet, ''There was nothing -- no road maps, no anything,'' recalls Ms. Monosoff, who lives near San Francisco and was education director for the President's Commission on White House Fellowships for President Bill Clinton.

Diane Adams never thought she would become an activist. Then again, she said, ''I never thought the city would do something crazy like close our clinics.'' Ms. Adams, 56, is a member of Southside Together Organizing for Power, or STOP, an advocacy group pressuring Mr. Emanuel to reverse course and keep the centers open. The facility where she is a client, the Auburn-Gresham Mental Health Center on the South Side, is scheduled to close in a few weeks.

To the Editor: Camille Paglia's review of Greil Marcus's book ''The Doors: A Lifetime of Listening to Five Mean Years'' (Dec. 4) attempts a dirty trick: praising the author in general (''an American original'') to make her demolition work seem evenhanded. Paglia chastises Marcus for using the Doors' music to ''veer away to some other subject -- Thomas Pynchon, Christian Slater, Wayne Wilson, Pop Art.'' Yet in the Marcus books Paglia cites approvingly -- ''Mystery Train'' and ''Lipstick Traces'' -- comparisons between disparate cultural figures are central to his imaginative thinking. She complains that Marcus's ''garrulous footnotes'' (again, features of ''Mystery Train'' and ''Lipstick Traces'' that inject energetic humor into his analyses) belong ''in the back.'' Marcus isn't an academic (a condition she praises as ''a rarity'' earlier in the review), so who cares where the footnotes are tucked?

The documentaryphotographer Milton Rogovin (b. 1909) sometimes returned to the same people over and over for decades. He took these portraits of one family in Buffalo in 1973, 1984, 1992 and 2001. This interview, which has been edited, was conducted by Dave Isay for their 2003 book, ''The Forgotten Ones.'' It wasn't until I was 48 years old that my first opportunity came to take photographs. It was 1958. The previous year I had been summoned before the House Un-American Activities Committee in a vicious attack on me and my family. It wrecked my optometric practice and essentially silenced my voice.

FOR the last 11 years, at Christmas, the photographer Bruce Weber brings out a new edition of his ''All-American'' series, softbound books of photos and essays from his Little Bear Press that reflect his curiosity about other people's lives. Mr. Weber has a passion for the kinds of stories that often don't appear in the mainstream media, and he tells them in full. You can find his books at bruceweber.com. I was particularly struck by his latest, ''Just Life,'' and an eight-part story about military bravery and homecomings. The rest of the book includes essays about the founding director of the Peace Corps, R. Sargent Shriver; an interview with the filmmakers D. A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus, and various movie idols whose mugs and then some papered Mr. Weber's adolescent walls. And you can appreciate the connections between Hollywood he-men and soldiers. But Mr. Weber has touched on something quite relevant.

Robert Ettinger (b. 1918) is widely seen as the father of the cryonics movement, because he wrote one of its founding manifestos, the 1964 book ''Prospect of Immortality.'' He advocated freezing the dead, for revival someday when medical advances will be able to radically extend life. His son David explained to Ira Glass the procedure Ettinger's body underwent upon his death in July. 1. It was a tough time. I did more than I expected to because the hospice people said he had a couple weeks to live, and we didn't expect it so soon. We already had plenty of ice there; we already had the ice bath there. And in the last couple hours when it became apparent that it would happen more quickly, we were rushing to make sure everything was all in place. 2. The hospice nurse performed her examination and pronounced death very shortly after he stopped breathing. I placed his head in a cooling box with ice and icy water to immediately begin the cooling process. The quicker the cooling process can begin, the better; this limits deterioration. 3. Then he went into the ice bath, where there was ice both above and below him and cold water. A heart-lung machine was used. It presses on the sternum and keeps the heart pumping. This accelerates the cooling process, because it keeps the cooled blood circulating through the body, further cooling it. 4. The next step was to perfuse, and that was done at the funeral director's facility. The purpose of the perfusion is to replace the blood and water in the body with vitrification solutions. Without this, ice crystals could form and cause cellular damage. 5. The body was cooled down very slowly over five days. There's a computer-controlled cooling box which lowers the temperature in controlled amounts until it reaches liquid-nitrogen temperature. 6. My father, who said all of these things better than I can, said that ''being frozen is a terrible thing. The only thing worse is dying.''

A FAMILY sits around a table in a Chinese restaurant on Christmas in the climactic scene from the 1983 movie ''A Christmas Story.'' It is a scene that is repeated every year on Long Island and elsewhere: for those who do not celebrate the holiday -- or who do, but who have had enough of it -- there's not a lot to do on this day but go to the movies or have a meal out. And just try to find a non-Asian restaurant open on Christmas. Golden Temple in Syosset, which opened in time for Christmas last year, is among the newest Chinese restaurants on Long Island. Like most of these Asian newcomers, it is not strictly Chinese: its offerings include a sushi bar, a roster of Japanese fare and a half-dozen dishes from Thailand and Malaysia.

CARMEL, N.Y. FOR a speed-obsessed adolescent, it may be hard to believe that a shrink-wrapped sports car is not every driver's object of desire.
