Of the notable people who passed this year, many were active on Twitter. Here is a sample of their (unwitting) final messages. 'In besieged Libyan city of Misrata. Indiscriminate shelling by Qaddafi forces. No sign of NATO.'

Of all the professional sports teams in North America, probably none have the political resonance of the Montreal Canadiens. Beyond their more than 100 years of tradition and their 24 Stanley Cups, the Canadiens are the standard-bearers of a people, a culture and a certain idea about Quebec. Anything involving le club de hockey Canadien can easily end up being about French and English. Like the appointment of a new coach, in this case Randy Cunneyworth, who was named the slumping Canadiens' interim coach after Jacques Martin was fired Dec. 17. Cunneyworth does not speak French - a serious matter in a city where bilingualism is an article of faith, especially for the English-speaking minority.
LASDON--Richard. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

WEISER--Elaine. My dearest friend Elaine...our hearts are broken. With love to Mel, Allison, Jeff, David, Karen, Glen, Caroline, and all the grandchildren. With our love, Barbara and the entire Shapiro and Ginsburg family

Yvonne McCain(b. 1948) was the lead plaintiff in a Legal Aid Society lawsuit that took 25 years and more than 50 court orders to resolve. She herself never received a cash award, but on any given night, 10,000 families, including 17,000 children, receive emergency shelter from the City of New York as a result of the lawsuit. Occasionally an official court document captures someone's feelings and life story, and that's true of this edited affidavit. YVONNE McCAIN, et al.,PlaintiffsagainstMICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG, etc., et al.,Defendants

IRWINDALE, Calif. TIM ESTES, the president of Fiesta Parade Floats, remembers when the Rose Parade rulebook ran 20 pages. Now, as his company puts the final touches on 11 floats it is building for the 2012 parade, it has to be mindful of 140 pages of regulations and stipulations governing everything from dimensions to propulsion systems to evacuation procedures.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday in the Moment column about nuns' habits designed by JF & Son for the Community of Compassion, a new order of nuns, referred incorrectly to the order. It is Anglican Catholic, not Roman Catholic. The column also misstated part of the name of the Michigan community that is the location of the Cross in the Woods shrine, whose nun dolls helped inspire the habits' design. It is Indian River, not Indian Wells.

SIMONS--Rayanna Metz, died at age 90 November 21, 2011. She leaves her son Josh, his wife Loren, grandkids Aliza, Casey, many friends and family. A noted writer and editor, Rayanna's wit and candor spared no one. Her spirit and joie de vie will be missed by all who knew her.

I HAD modest expectations of Wonder Seafood Restaurant, which is nondescript in appearance, verging on the utilitarian. Yet on two visits, this Hong Kong-style Cantonese place lived up to its ambitious name -- for two very different reasons. The first, on a Sunday evening visit in which we were surrounded by empty tables, was a superb fish dish called Fish Two Ways.

At the end of one of the most bizarre weather years in American history, climate research stands at a crossroads. Scientists say they could, in theory, do a much better job of answering the question ''Did global warming have anything to do with it?'' after extreme weather events like the drought in Texas and the floods in New England.

AS he was overseeing rehearsals for the monumental, multimillion-dollar opening ceremony of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, with its cast of 15,000 and fireworks extravaganza, the film director Zhang Yimou faced enormous pressure. Hoping for a distraction, he turned to a book. But far from light entertainment, it was a novel called ''13 Female Martyrs of Nanjing.''

A decade ago, Dave Boyle (b. 1948) appeared in an episode of our radio show about this town where the mayor named the public-safety building after her late husband, a bookie for the mob. Alex Kotlowitz reported that story, and he wrote this one. Dave Boyle, a burly, pug-nosed, loud, foulmouthed man, stood down anyone he thought didn't play fair. So it seemed only apt that he ended up in Cicero, Ill., a working-class Chicago suburb that had a reputation for its hostility to outsiders. The town so violently resisted blacks moving in that the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was warned not to march there. And dating back to Al Capone, who made Cicero his headquarters, the town's government had been tied up with the mob.

THOUGH the threat of foreclosure has eased a little in the last 18 months, more than 2.6 million households are at least 60 days delinquent on their mortgage payments, according to Hope Now, a nonprofit coalition of lenders and agencies. Beyond the obvious threat of losing your home, falling behind can be costly: lenders charge late fees as well as legal and administrative costs, and your credit score will suffer. Experts say the sooner you deal with the situation, the better your chances of making a full economic recovery.
Television Neil Genzlinger

France Télécom agreed to sell its Orange Switzerland mobile-phone unit to the London buyout firm Apax Partners for 1.6 billion euros, or $2.1 billion, the first major step in the chief executive's plan to unload slow-growing European operations. The deal, which is subject to approval by Swiss authorities, will be submitted to France Télécom 's board in the week starting Jan. 9, the company said on Saturday in a statement.

Bears (7-7) at Packers (13-1) 8:20 p.m., Eastern; NBC Line: Packers by 13 Packers right tackle Bryan Bulaga (knee) is out. Left tackle Chad Clifton (back) is easing his way back after missing two months; he has been limited in practice and is unlikely to play. The primary backup tackle, Derek Sherrod, is out for the season with a broken leg. Green Bay's injury situation became so dire in its loss to the Chiefs that T. J. Lang took snaps at right tackle, a position he had never played, even in practice. ''It's next guy up,'' Coach Mike McCarthy said of the injuries, which is all well and good, except that the next guy might be Jerry Kramer. Health problems on the line can easily become health problems for Aaron Rodgers, but the Bears have played so badly in the wake of the Jay Cutler-Matt Forte injuries that the Packers could put a cardboard Rodgers cutout in the pocket and it would make little difference. Pick: Packers (Pick does not reflect the betting line)

Ira Glass, Julie Snyder and Lisa Pollak, producers of WBEZ Chicago's public-radio program ''This American Life,'' were guest editors of this section of the magazine. When The Times Magazine's editors invited us to be part of the annual ''Lives They Lived'' issue, they told us two things: 1) They wanted us to be bold and shake things up, and 2) Times readers love the issue just the way it is.

Molly Elyssa Gomolin and David Benjamin Katz were married by Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Thursday at Carlyle on the Green in Bethpage, N.Y., with Rabbi Elie Weissman taking part. The bride, 23, is a copywriter in New York for Health4Brands Chelsea, an advertising agency. She graduated from McGill University. She is a daughter of Joyce Y. Gomolin and Dr. Irving H. Gomolin of Plainview, N.Y.

After a long and avoidable delay, the N.B.A. finally opens its 2011-12 season Sunday. The new season brings two anniversaries worth noting. One you will probably hear quite a lot about: the 50th anniversary of the 1961-62 season. The other, the 35th anniversary of the Oscar Robertson Rule, maybe not so much. The second anniversary has a direct connection to this season in the person of Jim Quinn, a lawyer who should receive much of the credit for there being a season at all. He has a long history with the National Basketball Players Association, including previous successful negotiations with N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern. Had the union included him in this year's bargaining from the beginning, the season might have opened on time. Three weeks after the games would have begun, when the talks had stalled for what seemed like the last time, Quinn stepped forward and brought the parties together. After a five-month stalemate, he needed about five days to lay the groundwork for an agreement.

WASHINGTON -- As Iraq erupted in recent days, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in constant phone contact with the leaders of the country's dueling sects. He called the Shiite prime minister and the Sunni speaker of the Parliament on Tuesday, and the Kurdish leader on Thursday, urging them to try to resolve the political crisis. And for the United States, that is where the American intervention in Iraq officially stops.

LUSTERMAN--Dove, 88, loving wife of Leon for 64 years, mother of Nina and Daniel and their spouses Michael and Shelley, grandparent of Jordan and his wife Jessica, Tara, Anna, and her pride and joy great-grandson Aaron, passed away Friday, December 23rd. She was for many years an active environmentalist and bird watcher, as well as a music lover. She will be greatly missed and forever in our hearts. Memorial service will be at a later date.

An 18-hole mini course would have a maximum par of about 54; he would have needed 16 strokes. The Dear Leader invented the hole in zero. Seth Forman

A capsule look at the Jets' 29-14 loss to the Giants: Key Performance Rex Ryan perhaps overstated Mark Sanchez's performance by saying that ''there were times when he looked outstanding and there were times that weren't so good.'' When the Jets needed a jolt after halftime, Sanchez responded by committing all three of his turnovers and completing only 12 of 31 passes for 113 yards. He did not receive much help from his offensive line, but Sanchez reverted to the poor decision-making that had defined his play at earlier points this season.

Line them up side by side, the New York City Marathon victory photos: nine of them, 1978 to 1988, the most comic and elegant rebuke to generations of harrumphing athletic directors who insisted that no woman could safely run 26.2 miles. When Grete Waitz was born, in Norway in 1953, that was the received wisdom. Too exhausting, too competitive, too damaging to the delicate female organs, too . . . unwomanly. The year Waitz turned 13 in Oslo, as she was discovering track and cross-country and just how fast she might become, the Boston Marathon was infiltrated by a racer named Roberta Gibb, who had to run the most prestigious distance race in the United States by hiding behind a bush at the start and sneaking in. When Gibb crossed the finish line, her time -- 3:21 -- was unofficial. Her request for an entry form had been returned to her, along with a note explaining that the distance was too strenuous for a woman. As Waitz came of age, there was no shortage of confrontationalists in women's athletics. One of the most cherished stories in running is the one about a certain K. V. Switzer officially entering Boston in 1967, the year after Gibb ran it, and nearly being hauled off the course when officials discovered that the K stood for Kathrine. (The following day's newspapers ran photos of a teammate, her boyfriend, body-blocking an enraged race director as he tried to rip off Switzer's race number.) That was never Waitz's style. In 1978, the women-can't-marathon myth was beginning to fade; a few big races had gone coed, including Boston. There was even an international all-women's marathon. Waitz was a middle-distance star in Norway, not a marathoner, when Fred Lebow, the New York City Marathon founder, invited her to come join his race. It was assumed she'd run not as a serious competitor but as a rabbit, the speedy pacesetter who prods the others to glory and fades partway through.
Pop Jon Pareles

BANGKOK -- At the entrance to a neighborhood in Bangkok's garment district, an unambiguous message hangs on an archway decorated with an image of Thailand's king. ''If you live in Thailand, you must be loyal,'' says the sign, prominently suspended over the road. ''If you are not loyal, you are not Thai.''

Some stories, like this one, you hear the general outline and think you pretty much know the story. But when you learn the details, you realize you hadn't imagined the half of it. Mark Farmer, 56, Rick Fox, 56, and Tripp Miller, 49, lived together in a small group home for the developmentally disabled in Joplin, Mo. Each man had Down syndrome. Mark Lindquist was one of their caretakers. On Sunday, May 22, he had an evening shift with them. He told the reporter Charles Wilson that he met Mark Farmer while working at a larger group home.
PASADENA, Calif. HOW hard can it be to travel five and half miles at 2.5 m.p.h.?

PICKMAN--Morton "Mac", 98, died on December 22, 2011 peacefully at home with his beloved wife of 39 years, Gladys, by his side. He will be remembered for his generous spirit, sharp wit, and keen business acumen. Morton Pickman was born on December 5, 1913. He grew up in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn and obtained degrees from New York University School of Commerce and Brooklyn Law School. He fought in World War II as a member of the United States Army where he was awarded a Purple Heart for wounds received in action. From an early age, Mac worked with his father, Morris Pickman, developing and managing residential and commercial properties in Brooklyn and Queens Counties, New York. After the war, he re-joined his family's real estate business in Queens and assumed leadership after his father's death in 1960. Among the residential and commercial properties the Pickman organization developed are Forest Hills South (Forest Hills), Cunningham Heights (Hollis), Arrowbrook Gardens Apartments (Kew Gardens Hills), Briarwood Apartments (Briarwood), Lakeside Towers (Bayside), the Pickman Office Building (Forest Hills), and Franhill Shopping Center (Hollis), as well as other properties in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Today, Pickman Realty Corporation manages numerous commercial buildings and cooperative apartment units in Queens, owned by various family members. Mac's philanthropic endeavors were extensive. Among his charitable activities, he was a major supporter and served as a trustee of the Museum of Jewish Heritage A Living Memorial to the Holocaust in New York City, where he established the Keeping History Center in memory of his parents, Fannie and Morris Pickman, along with funding numerous other programs and projects of the museum, including the Pickman Museum Shop. He was recently honored by the American Committee of the Weizmann Institute of Science in New York City, Palm Beach, and Rehovot, Israel, where he served on the ACWIS Board of Directors, was a member of the President's Circle and a member of the Weizmann Institute International Board of Directors. Mac was an active supporter of the Anti-Defamation League and established and headed The Pickman Foundation, which contributes to a variety of charitable Jewish causes. In addition to his wife, Mac is survived by his son James, and his wife Elizabeth, and daughters Patricia Spears, and her husband Richard, and Teresa Pickman, and five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. His grandchildren are Joseph Pickman, Christopher Friedman (Jennifer), Elizabeth Winchester (Christopher), John Siris (Susan), and Scott Spears (Lisa). In addition, he is survived by his wife Gladys' children, who viewed him as a father: Ellen Danetz, and her husband Stephen, and Steven Willner, and their children Mark Danetz (Julie), Lisa Danetz (Craig Smith), Adam Willner, and Meredith Willner, who, in turn, have six children. He is also survived by his sister Esther Ellman, his former wife and mother of his children Charlotte Pickman Gertz, and by his extended family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, December 27 at 2pm, Temple Beth El, 333 SW 4th St., Boca Raton, Florida. A Memorial Service will also be held at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York City on January 26, 2012. Memorial contributions may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage, Edmond J. Safra Plaza, 36 Battery Place, New York, New York 10280 and The American Committee of the Weizmann Institute of Science, 633 Third Ave., New York, New York 10017.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y. THE Nativity scene at the Westchester Italian Cultural Center is a lively one. A woman sells lemons from her colorful stall, while beside her a vendor hawks baccala, the salted codfish beloved in Naples. Nearby, a butcher's stand, links of sausage draped around its frame, offers cuts of red meat.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Quirky Stroke Not Easy for Some,'' Dec. 16: Kathleen Hersey, a specialist in the butterfly, has difficulty with the breaststroke technique. Brendan Hansen, an Olympian: ''She walks around pigeon-toed all the time. So to try to get her to catch the water with the inside of her feet by pulling them out is a real challenge.''

BOYARSKY--Neal. We are profoundly saddened by the loss of our dear friend Neal Boyarsky. Our hearts are filled with sorrow, as well as with a lifetime of cherished memories and the unbreakable bonds of friendship spanning three generations. Your impeccable style, your warm heart and your generous spirit will always be remembered. You were a true original and our irreplaceable Fabric Czar. We will miss you so much. Our love to Shirley, Nicole and Jeff, Jon and Jen, Josh and Debbie and his five adoring grandsons who were the love of his life. The Gaspar Family

Margot, formerly a Clinical Social Worker in New York City, is survived by her children, David and Deborah, her daughters-in-law, Trise Ruskay and Sue Clemente, her grandchildren, Meagan, Morgan, and Benjamin, her step-grandchildren, Nathan and Benjamin, and her three great-grandchildren, Lilian, Isabella, and Caiden. Box 5060, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030.

The bankruptcy of Saab Automobile leaves owners, dealers and would-be customers with plenty of questions and some unpleasant answers. As The Times reported Monday, Saab filed for liquidation after a takeover by Chinese investors was blocked by General Motors. It retained veto power over any deals despite having sold the Swedish automaker in 2010 to Spyker Cars.

QUEEN OF AMERICA By Luis Alberto Urrea

CHAMBERLAIN--John. April 16, 1927 - December 21, 2011. With tremendous sadness, Gagosian Gallery announces that John Chamberlain has died on December 21, 2011, in Manhattan. Brandishing a wicked sense of humor and notoriously ornery, Chamberlain was a larger-than-life personality who was as bold and expressive as his sculptures, photographs, paintings, and films. Larry Gagosian said John Chamberlain made an indelible mark on the history of art in the twentieth century. He was a spectacular, roaring figure who embodied the fierceness of mid-century American art and who was unparalleled in his adaptation of unlikely materials for his sculptures. His influence will be long reaching, and his death is a great loss. Our condolences go out to his family and friends. Larry Gagosian

Reporters can, if necessary, weave their battle stories from 100 miles away. But photojournalists must be in the crucible -- standing, when they ought to be crouching; facing forward, when they ought to be running away. They can only hope they're not in the wrong place at the wrong time. In the chaos of the Libyan revolt, however, almost every time and place was wrong. A terrible price was paid. DAVID W. DUNLAP

An article last Sunday about expected cutbacks in the United States Navy and Marines misstated the location of a destroyer, the U.S.S. Cole, when it was bombed by Al Qaeda terrorists. The ship was refueling in the port of Aden, Yemen; it was not off the coast of Yemen.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- Giants players have talked all season about wanting a ''complete'' game. They have vowed, over and over, that they will deliver a ''total team effort.'' They have stressed -- even this week, amid the verbal flotsam and jetsam of a Giants-Jets rivalry game -- that there is no other way for them to play. But none of it happened Saturday. There was no four-quarter effort, no clean, dominating performance. In a virtual must-win game for the Giants, they survived -- remarkably -- on the strength of their defense and two flashes of light from a mostly moribund offense.
WEISER--Elaine. Truly a woman of valor. Your friendship will be treasured in our hearts forever and your legacy will live on in your incredible family. With much love, Ellyn, Rick and Family

Paul-Emile Deiber, an actor and director with the Comédie-Française for nearly three decades who brought his dramatic expertise to a second career as an opera director, died on Dec. 14. He was 86. He died after a fall at his home in Klosterneuberg, Austria, near Vienna, his wife, the former mezzo-soprano Christa Ludwig, said.

NEW YORK has always been too big an idea to be rendered successfully in a single image: simultaneously cruel and generous, dazzling and demeaning, unbearably vibrant and -- as it waits to see what path a tropical storm will take -- suspenseful but calm. But one thing that almost every New York moment has in common is a surprise of some sort. Some surprises are dreadful. An 8-year-old boy named Leiby Kletzky was supposed to walk the seven blocks back to his home in Borough Park, Brooklyn, one day in July, but he never made it. Other surprises were joyful. Same-sex couples did not go into the year thinking they would have the right to marry before summer was out. Felix Ramirez and Peter Vargas of the Bronx had already been together 24 years by the time they were wed at City Hall. (Or at least near it.)

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- A suicide car bomber drove a vehicle packed with explosives into a building used by paramilitary forces in northwestern Pakistan early on Saturday, killing at least six soldiers and wounding 11 others, police officials said. The attack took place near the town of Bannu, in the Bannu tribal region 25 miles east of North Waziristan. The paramilitary troops, known as Tochi Scouts, are deployed mainly in North Waziristan, the rugged mountainous region that is part of Pakistan's tribal area and that has been a stronghold of militants.

JULIO PABÓN came to New York from Puerto Rico in 1956, when he was 4, and grew up almost literally on the streets of the South Bronx. His family settled into a tenement apartment on Cauldwell Avenue, near the Hub, but when his parents divorced three years later, his mother returned to Puerto Rico. With his father working long hours as a hospital dishwasher, Julio was left largely to his own devices. ''I was always in the street,'' Mr. Pabón said. ''I thought that was life.''

MOSCOW -- Tens of thousands of citizens converged in Moscow on Saturday for the second huge antigovernment demonstration in a month, an early victory for activists struggling to forge a burst of energy into a political force capable of challenging Vladimir V. Putin's power. The first such demonstration, two weeks ago, was unprecedented for Mr. Putin's rule, and there were reasons Saturday's turnout could have been lower -- among them, winter holidays and the onset of bitter cold.

A Pentagon public relations program that sought to transform high-profile military analysts into ''surrogates'' and ''message force multipliers'' for the Bush administration complied with Defense Department regulations and directives, the Pentagon's inspector general has concluded after a two-year investigation. The inquiry was prompted by articles published in The New York Times in 2008 that described how the Pentagon, in the years after the Sept. 11 attacks, cultivated close ties with retired officers who worked as military analysts for television and radio networks. The articles also showed how military analysts affiliated with defense contractors sometimes used their special access to seek advantage in the competition for contracts. In response to the articles, the Pentagon suspended the program and members of Congress asked the Defense Department's inspector general to investigate.

Stacking boxes is not one of the more complex tasks that humans perform. We learn to do it as children, with alphabet blocks, Legos and the like. And yet for decades, the difficulty of stacking large boxes -- crates and containers -- was a major impediment to global trade. Merely moving one large container required painstaking work in which longshoremen attached and detached hooks to the corners of each container before moving on to the next one. They certainly could not repeat the process to stack containers many stories high. In the 1950s, a longtime trucking executive named Malcom McLean decided there had to be a better way, and he turned to Keith W. Tantlinger, an engineer at a truck-trailer manufacturer in Spokane, Wash., to solve the problem. Tantlinger developed a lock that connected to the corners of containers and that crane operators could mechanically open and close from their seats.

Cattaraugus, N.Y. AS winter approached, a retired secretary here named Carol Bonner was putting snow tires on her car when she noticed that her back-right rim was bent. Ms. Bonner took the car to Otto's Auto Body Shop and got bad news: the work was going to run her $244 -- more than half of her $417 monthly pension check.

A HUNDRED years ago this month, the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen and four teammates became the first men to reach the South Pole, arriving in triumph five weeks ahead of Robert Falcon Scott. The Amundsen crew would return safely to its base, but, heartbreakingly, Scott and his four British companions died on the return journey. The race to the pole has long attracted leadership experts, who like to contrast the Amundsen focus on efficiency and innovation with Scott's more deliberate dedication to scientific pursuit.

GOOR--Joel S.,on December 21, 2011. Rabbi of The Metropolitan Synagogue. Devoted father of Rick Goor and Sandy, Rabbi Don Goor and Cantor Evan Kent, Carolyn Hutchinson and Rick, and Beri Goor. Adoring grandfather of Dani, Emily, Maya and Deanna, dear brother of Barbara Rothblatt, loving companion of Rose Smith. Service Monday, December 26, 2011 at The Metropolitan Synagogue, 40 E. 35 St., NYC.

Ever since Peter Singer's ''Animal Liberation'' laid the groundwork for modern animal advocacy more than 35 years ago, it has been a central tenet of the movement that we go ethically astray when we let emotional proximity to humans and a handful of nonhuman species trump the obvious interests of other animals. Although animal rights proponents haven't always embraced Singer's brand of utilitarianism, they have generally followed his rejection of emotionalism, reserving particular scorn for the sentimentality that allows people to lavish money and attention on pets while happily eating cows and pigs -- mammals every bit as intelligent and capable of suffering as dogs and cats -- which lead tortured existences before arriving on our plates. In LOVING ANIMALS: Toward a New Animal Advocacy (University of Minnesota, $24.95), Kathy Rudy argues that such quarantining of emotion is a mistake. Instead, she writes, we ought to use our reciprocal emotional relationships with particular animals as the basis for a new advocacy, one that recognizes that humans are capable of loving animals and that some animals, at least, are capable of loving us back. A professor of ethics and women's studies at Duke University, Rudy counts herself among the ''border crossers'' -- humans who have especially ''intense emotional bonds with specific animals.'' And she believes these people have an important role to play in changing hearts and minds when it comes to the fair treatment of animals. Her book runs through the broad range of animal issues, from puppy mills to ethical eating to scientific research, showing how the introduction of emotion and affect might shift the debate on each topic.

PICKMAN--Morton (Mac). The leadership, staff, and worldwide community of the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, Morton Pickman. Along with his wife Gladys, Mac has been a passionate supporter of the Weizmann Institute's efforts to advance science for the benefit of humanity. He was a member of the Institute's International Board and President's Circle, as well as the American Committee's Board of Directors. His many important gifts with Gladys to Weizmann and its educational arm, the Davidson Institute of Science Education, include the establishment of the Morton and Gladys Pickman Chair in Structural Biology, the Gladys and Morton Pickman Laboratory for DNA Analysis, and the Gladys and Morton Pickman Building. The Pickmans' generosity also enabled the refurbishment of the Harry Levine Family Building, which is used for biological research. Most recently, they created The Morton Pickman International Conference Fund. In 2008, three generations of the Pickman family were honored at the American Committee's New York Gala for their many years of involvement and support. Mac's kindness, generosity, and inquisitive spirit will continue to impact the Weizmann Institute family. We extend heartfelt condolences to Mac's wife, Gladys; to his children James Pickman, Patricia Spears, and Teresa Pickman; to his stepchildren Ellen Danetz and Steven Willner, and their children; to his sister Esther Ellman; to his former wife and the mother of his children Charlotte Pickman Gertz; to his five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg Chairman, American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. & C.E.O. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

ROME--Dr. Doris Spector, 85, of Bolton, NY and Delray Beach, FL died peacefully at home on Thursday, December 22, 2011. Beloved mother to Marcia Levitz (Alan), Dr. Lisa Rome, Michael Rome (Lisa). Dear sister to Mildred Kayne. She adored and cherished her grandchildren Aaron Moskowitz, Lauren Rome and David Rome. Doris (Deo) was born in Albany NY in 1926, the daughter of Harry and Irene Spector. She married Howard Rome of Troy, NY. A graduate of Milne HS, Skidmore College ('47) and Albany Medical College ('50). Dr. Rome a Cytologist and Pathologist. Her career included Associate Professor of Medicine at the Albany Medical College. An investigator for the National Institute of Health on automated Cytology. Dr Rome trained with Dr. Papanicolaou at Cornell. She received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from Skidmore College. ('62) She was founder and President of Albany Cytopath Labs. A memorial service will be held in Albany, NY on December 26 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Albany Medical College Doris Rome Scholarship Fund, 47 New Scotland Ave. Albany, NY 12208. To sign the online family guestbook, please visit, www.levinememorialchapel. com

LILIEN--Charles "Chuck" E. 82, died Monday, December 12, 2011. He was born in Ohio, raised in Barrington, IL. Chuck graduated from The George Washington University in Washington D.C with a B.A. in Foreign Affairs and a M.A. in Government and Economic Policy, as a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society. He served as a Foreign Service Officer in the Department of State in Maracaibo, Venezuela; Brussels, Belgium; and Washington D.C. Thereafter, he worked in international commercial banking for The Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago in Chicago, IL and Wells Fargo Bank International in New York; then in international investment banking for the First Boston Corporation at its New York Headquarters. Chuck is predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Barbara Fleming of Washington D.C.; son, John F. Lilien of Washington D.C.; and parents, Kazimir K. Lilien originally from Poland and Ruth E. Parker of Chicago, IL. He is survived by his daughter, Ann F. Singer of Northvale, NJ; granddaughter, Melissa Nazzaro and husband, Dennis Nazzaro of Huntington, MA; and grandson, Christopher Singer and wife, Dawn Singer of Henderson, NV. Chuck is also survived by his great-grandson, Dominic Nazzaro. Throughout his life, Chuck was active in many community and professional activities, including the Executive Committee of the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, the Board of Directors of Association House (Chicago), the Advisory Board of the Council of the Americas (New York), the Committee on Foreign Commerce and Affairs of the New York Chamber of Commerce, the Board and Finance Committee of the Asheville Symphony Orchestra, the Board and Investment Committee of the UNCA Foundation (Asheville, NC) and the Endowment Committee of Warren Wilson College (Asheville, NC). Most notably, Chuck's passion for the performing arts resulted in his heartfelt work with the Asheville Area Center for the Performing Arts to fulfill their mission to build a state-of-the-art Performance Center in downtown Asheville. Although he did not survive to see this dream fully realized, Chuck's legacy and passion live on through this important project. His life-long commitment to volunteerism had a profound effect on so many lives. That commitment continues today through his family and friends. Chuck has chosen Washington D.C. as his final resting place. His ashes will be laid to rest in the family plot at The Congressional Cemetery in October 2012. Memorial donations can be made to The Performance Center in Asheville, PO Box 2745, Asheville, NC 28801 or by contacting 828-258-1850.

Wolfgang Oehme, a landscape architect who drew from a palette of feathery grasses and black-eyed Susans to create what he called ''horticultural explosions,'' free-form landscapes that some called exemplars of ''the new American garden,'' died on Dec. 15 at his home in Towson, Md. He was 81. The cause was colon cancer, said his son, Roland.

Newt Gingrich declared confidently the other day that he would get his name on the ballot for the Republican presidential primary in Virginia. In fact, he said he already had the requisite 10,000 signatures and an additional 2,000 to 3,000 for safety's sake and would probably collect even more. But that turned out not to be the case. In the wee hours of Saturday, the Virginia Republican Party announced via Twitter that Mr. Gingrich had failed to submit enough signatures by the Thursday deadline, highlighting the organizational challenges to his campaign and raising questions about his prospects in a drawn-out nominating fight.

Mike DeStefano(b. 1966)was still on the rise as a comedian when he died of a heart attack at 44. He was one of the finalists on NBC's ''Last Comic Standing'' and definitely stood out from the pack. He wasn't always the funniest, but there was something direct and heartfelt about him that made you root for him, and you could feel the weight of his personal story, always. He grew up tough in the Bronx. Had been addicted to heroin. Three months before his death, he spoke with his fellow comedian Marc Maron on the ''WTF'' podcast. With permission from DeStefano's family, we've edited and condensed the interview and replaced the words that can't be printed in a family newspaper. DeStefano: When I was 21, I found out I'm H.I.V. positive, O.K. I was diagnosed with H.I.V. That was 22 years ago, 23 years ago, and that's what changed my freakin' life. I met this beautiful girl, Fran, and she had been a recovering addict as well, and she was also [H.I.V.] positive. We moved to Florida.

The Ivy League, which is experiencing an athletic revival with several teams ranked nationally, is a doggedly atypical N.C.A.A. Division I sports conference. For starters, the eight members are virtual heretics in the landscape of American big-time college sports for fielding about 280 teams in 35 sports without athletic scholarships. The league also restricts activities like off-season practices, discourages weekday games and prohibits postseason play in football. But there is one thing the Ivy League does that truly sets it apart from its sporting brethren nationwide: it tracks and scrutinizes the finite, detailed academic credentials of every recruited athlete welcomed through the doors of the eight member institutions. And it has done so for more than 25 years -- creating a dossier of grades and test scores for more than 40,000 student-athletes.

To the Editor: Discussing the popularity of audiobooks, James Parker notes that they ''are on the rise'' (''The Mind's Ear,'' Nov. 27). But are they ''on the rise'' because they've just been discovered, or is it that The New York Times has finally conceded their importance after years of denying them the status they deserve?

THE Oxford English Dictionary defines a pastiche as ''a medley of various ingredients; a hotchpotch, farrago, jumble.'' The word is derived from the 13th-century Latin ''pasticium,'' a savory Mediterranean pie filled with whatever is left over in the kitchen. A modern analogue, pastitsio, can be found at every Greek diner in the land. ''The Enchanted Island,'' which receives its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera on New Year's Eve and runs in repertory through Jan. 30, is called a pastiche. Another creative use of leftovers, it is a Franken-opera formed from the severed limbs of other operas. But these limbs boast high pedigrees, having been created by the likes of Handel and Vivaldi. And they are animated by Phelim McDermott and Julian Crouch, the team that produced both the Met's much-admired ''Satyagraha'' and the Broadway crowd pleaser ''The Addams Family,'' and will be sung by stars including Joyce DiDonato, David Daniels and Plácido Domingo.

Christopher Maltman, baritone; New London Children's Choir; London Philharmonic Orchestra and Choir, conducted by Vladimir Jurowski (LPO 0058; CD). SINCE the London Philharmonic Orchestra engaged the Russian maestro Vladimir Jurowski as its principal conductor in 2007, this august institution has reaped consistently strong notices for its dynamic, exacting performances and broad repertory. Yet when Anthony Tommasini reviewed the orchestra in The New York Times during its visit to Carnegie Hall this month, he lamented a curiously pedestrian program that mostly failed to show the players or their conductor in the best possible light.

A HALF-CENTURY ago, a guy given a watch for the holidays would have torn off the wrapping paper to find a modest box containing a timepiece about the size of a quarter. This season that same package is more likely the size of a hamper, with inside it a hunk of bristling, steel-studded hardware and gears. Watches have bulked up steadily since the ''Mad Men'' era, incrementally becoming brawnier, thicker and wide enough across to invite comparison to sundials. Particularly over the last decade, high-end watchmakers like Breitling, Franck Muller, IWC, Lange & Söhne, Omega and Panerai and even traditionally conservative companies like Cartier led the way with models offering ample quantities of what the industry refers to as ''wrist presence.''

PAPAYE, Haiti -- For months after the earthquake that struck the capital, Manel Laurore pulled shattered bodies from his neighbors' homes, hunkered in fetid refugee camps and scrounged for food and water. Today, his main worries are when his bean, corn and plantain crops will come in.

To the Editor: Peter Keepnews, reviewing ''Alex Steinweiss: The Inventor of the Modern Album Cover,'' compiled by Kevin Reagan, and ''R. Crumb: The Complete Record Cover Collection'' (Dec. 4), laments the loss of great record cover art as LPs gave way to CDs, and CDs now give way to coverless digital downloads. If he feels ''a little lump'' in his throat ''about all the beauty we're in the process of losing,'' think how monks in the late Middle Ages felt as large, beautifully illuminated manuscripts gave way to plain printed books. Yet we seem to have enjoyed and benefited from that form for just over 500 years, including, in time, large-format books with color plates. Perhaps something similar will happen in the digital world, in which fantastic art is already experiencing a renaissance.

EARLY in Dee Rees's film ''Pariah'' it journeys into a Brooklyn strip club where scantily clad young black women gyrate to a sexy, foul-mouthed rap song. Lascivious customers leer, toss money and revel in their own unbridled lust. It is a scene that could have been in any of ''the hood movies'' that once proliferated or even a Tyler Perry melodrama in which Christian values would be affirmed after this bit of titillation. But in ''Pariah'' the gaze of desire doesn't emanate from predatory males but A.G.'s, that is aggressive lesbians, who, in a safe space where they enjoy the fellowship of peers, can be true to themselves. Other films have depicted this particular black alternative life (as did a couple of memorable characters in HBO's masterly series ''The Wire''), but no film made by a black lesbian about being a black lesbian has ever received the kind of attention showered on Ms. Rees's film. It was a major success at the Sundance Festival in January and, even before its limited release on Wednesday, has entered the conversation as a long shot Oscar contender courtesy of the aggressive folks at NBC Universal's specialty arm, Focus Features.

MANY people open a bottle of Champagne, even on New Year's Eve, with the gravity of a monk, showing the respect and discretion due a vinous masterwork. But there are those more-excitable oenophiles whose personal standard (''What would pirates do?'') dictates freeing the bubbly soul by lopping off the bottle's neck with a saber. Of course, if you don't have a backsword at home, an eight-inch chef's knife would do fine. 1. Remove the foil capsule and tear away the paper around the neck of the bottle as well.

FLEISHER--Seymour "Zoom", 88, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Fort Lee, NJ passed away December 18, 2011 surrounded by his adoring family. Engineer, entrepreneur, veteran, humanitarian, pilot, golfer, fisherman, athlete, father, family man and friend to all who knew him, Fleisher led an accomplished life full of friendships, success and love, all of which he was extremely proud. Born in Newark, NJ, served as Captain in 20th Air Force, 315th Bomb Wing during WWII. Graduated from Newark College of Engineering, now known as New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT), with B.S. in Mechanical Engineering. At NJIT he was both scholar and captain of the Varsity Basketball team where he earned the nickname "Zoom" for his fast footwork on the court. Inducted into NJIT Athletic Hall of Fame and served on Advisory Board to help create scholarship programs for NJIT collegial athletes. Founder and Chairman of Pilot Technologies Corp., a manufacturing firm of precision components and assemblies. Zoom celebrated over 52 years of marriage with his beloved late wife Estelle before her passing in 1997. He was loved and respected by so many and his loss will be felt deeply. His honesty and integrity will remain an inspiration to all who knew him. He is survived by son Bruce (Ellen); Granddaughter Ronni (Gioel Molinari) and great-grandsons Luca and Max; Grandson Steven (Julie); his own four brothers and two sisters; as well as his loving partner Anita Fishbein.

SHAPIRO--Leonard Leonard Shapiro, 81, of Newtown, PA, on December 17th, 2011, after a long illness. The holder of numerous patents, Shapiro was recognized as an expert in the field of industrial centrifuge design. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1930, Shapiro was graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School. He received his undergraduate degree in engineering from The City College of New York, where he was a president of Tau Beta Pi, the engineering honor society. Later, attending night school at Drexel University in Philadelphia, he completed a graduate degree in Mechanical Engineering. For 38 years, Shapiro worked in research and development at the Sharpless Corporation, later known as Pennwalt and Alfa Laval. Shapiro and his wife Bernice, an artist and educator, lived in Trenton, NJ, Bryn Mawr, PA, Upper Darby, PA, and Buckingham, PA. In retirement, he was an active participant in committee and volunteer work, which included service as a local Water and Sewer Commissioner and board member at a not-for-profit hospital. In 2003, Shapiro and his wife moved to Pennswood Village, a Quaker retirement community in Newtown, PA. There, he took part in choral, dramatic and musical productions, organized Adopt-a Road and Meals on Wheels programs, and led a popular weekly Science Times discussion group. Throughout his life, he made time for travel, museums, theater, and music and took pride in the many accomplishments of his friends and family members. Shapiro is survived by his wife Bernice, to whom he was married for 60 years; sister Joyce Shapiro Berg of Lady Lake, Florida; his brother Dr. Charles Shapiro of Novato, California; son, Robin Shapiro, daughter-in-law Kate Levin Shapiro and grand-daughter Marissa Levin Shapiro, all of New York City.

WASHINGTON -- It was a sunny Friday morning when federal agents in bulletproof vests and F.B.I. windbreakers pulled up to the brick home on a quiet cul-de-sac. As spectators watched from across yellow police tape, the agents loaded an S.U.V. and a motorcycle emblazoned with decals onto a flatbed truck and took them away. The home that the F.B.I. and Treasury agents searched this month hardly stood out from others on the street, but its owner did. The target was Harry Thomas Jr., a Washington city council member who is accused of siphoning over $300,000 in taxpayer money meant for children's sports.

AN urban farm off the East River. Artisanal food and crafts sold out of recycled shipping containers at the Dekalb Market. Smorgasburg and the Brooklyn Flea on the Williamsburg waterfront. They all share a hipper-than-thou aesthetic. They also share a pedigree: they were all set up to breathe some life into vacant lots.

Loulou de la Falaise might have been the last great muse of the 20th century, but the term made her uneasy. Although she seldom offered journalists clues to her personality, much less her feelings about collaborating with Yves Saint Laurent for three decades, Falaise no doubt thought that she was at least his equal in taste and endurance and so deserved more than a flaky handle. Still, to look at photos of Louise Vava Lucia Henriette Le Bailly de la Falaise is to feel the extreme effect of a stylish life and to wonder about its source. She was born in London, the daughter of a French count and an English fashion plate. But more important than her genetic attributes -- she was long and lanky with reddish curly hair -- was the way she carried herself. She seemed to reveal the secret when she said: ''Being a tomboy helps a bit. Most of the great style icons are tomboys, or they don't admire themselves physically.'' And it's true: beginning with Coco Chanel, some of the greatest icons felt freer in a men's blazer. Falaise herself was dressed as a maharajah on her wedding day. Did she feel unfeminine, despite her celebrated looks? Perhaps. But her boyish style had a quality of revolt that may have owed something to her roots; her great-grandmother, Vavarina Pike, was said to scandalize the locals by going around in men's cardigans and fedoras.

SOMETIMES there is a necessity for anniversaries, even for things that cannot be forgotten. The memorial services for 9/11 were remarkable for their grace and dignity. The falling water, beside the reflecting pools, spoke volumes. While the Republicans fumbled for their own sort of memory -- trying somehow to bring back the apparent ease of the Reagan years -- the rest of the country drove down a street of foreclosed homes. We were all, in some way, looking for a brand-new roof.

Laura Melton, pianist (Naxos 8.559638; CD). THE American composer Sebastian Currier was still a student at the Juilliard School when he wrote his Piano Sonata (1988), his only work in the genre. But the score already displays the hallmarks of his later pieces: exuberant energy, boisterous rhythms, emotional intensity and a broad coloristic palette. The violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is among the prominent soloists who have championed Mr. Currier's music recently.

THE WATER ROSE. And rose. Soon there were traffic lights flipping, doors tumbling, tatami mats spinning in the current. Cars began to float alongside washing machines, computers, people. The incredible could occur. And then the tsunami seemed to wash away the last vain dream of the 20th century: the nuclear answer. The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant went into meltdown and watched its poisons filter out to sea, and what remained is what we all must live with: the democratic rage of nature. No matter what we do, we cannot regulate how we are shaped by weather. We look for calm, but there is always an inevitability of storm. The images from Joplin, Mo., were pure with grief. A snowstorm paralyzed Tulsa, Okla. The Souris River shed more than a tear. The streets of Bangkok were almost apocalyptic during floods. There were droughts, earthquakes, wildfires scattering animals like dice. So, the question, then, is ancient: How with such rage shall beauty hold a plea? Rescuers in Turkey put their fingers on part of the pulse when they managed to pull 2-week-old Azra Karaduman from the rubble. Her mother and grandmother also emerged safely. She was tiny and voiceless, yet she said so much.

Nobody knows a man better than his ex-wife. So Moe Prager's ex-wife, Carmella, is wise to this veteran private eye, accepting the fact that no matter how many times he marries, his first love will always be Brooklyn. ''When you die, they should just bury you right here, under the boardwalk,'' she tells him in HURT MACHINE (Tyrus, $24.95; paper, $15.95), Reed Farrel Coleman's latest book in a series heavily saturated with local color. Since Prager has recently been told he has stomach cancer, that day may come sooner than Carmella thinks. But this stubborn old shamus is determined to do two things before his ashes are consigned to the sands of Coney Island: Attend his daughter's wedding, and find the person who murdered Carmella's older sister, Alta. Alta Conseco and Maya Watson, emergency medical technicians with the New York Fire Department, became pariahs after walking away from a dying man who was stricken at a trendy Manhattan bistro. Although Alta's death was clearly a retribution killing, her fellow E.M.T. (surely the murderer's next target) refuses to offer any explanation for their behavior. This silent treatment forces Prager to do exactly what we want him to do: Travel the length and breadth of the city talking to cops, firemen, gangsters and restaurateurs in their picturesque natural habitats.

To the Editor: Re ''The Price to Play Its Way'' (Dec. 18), which described American Bar Association standards in the nation's law schools:
THE FOLLY OF FOOLS The Logic of Deceit and Self-Deception in Human Life

These days, artists like Drake, Akon, T-Pain and Cee-Lo Green slide back and forth between singing and rapping so casually that it's easy to forget that there was a time when performers who valued their cred weren't allowed to do both. The few rappers who dared to try it either treated singing like a joke or risked becoming one. So for about a decade, Nate Dogg -- who was born Nathaniel Dwayne Hale -- had a niche more or less to himself. He was a singer with a doleful, cognac-smooth baritone. But he had a rapper's feel for the pockets of a beat and a rapper's taste for unprintable vulgarity, and whenever a tough-guy rap song seemed to call for a melodic refrain, tough-guy rappers called for Nate Dogg. Before he was a gangsta, he was a Marine -- a munitions specialist. When he was 19, he came home and found his girlfriend in bed with his cousin. ''I pulled my weapon out,'' he told Vibe in 2001, ''and had a talk with them for two days. We cried together for two days, and then I let them go.'' He said the incident got him dishonorably discharged; he was then evicted from his mother's house. He reconnected with a high-school buddy, aspiring rapper Calvin Broadus Jr., soon to be known as Snoop Dogg, and Warren Griffin III, who went by Warren G. They started a rap group and sold drugs on the side to pay the bills until their break came.

MY grandparents emigrated from Japan to California for a better life. My mother was 10 when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor, and she and her family were sent to an internment camp. We have a photo of the notice that was posted on a utility pole in their neighborhood, instructing people where to report. I grew up in Chicago, where my mom and dad met. I loved dogs, and they let me get one -- a poodle -- when I was 9. I had a green Schwinn bike with a basket on the front, and I used to ride around with the dog in the basket.

Think of how many dollhouse and train sets were botched in the assembly process by exhausted, irate football players Saturday night. Here is what happened in Saturday's games and what it means for the regular season's final week. A.F.C. East

AS part of her Hawaii-inspired resort collection, Stella McCartney is introducing a number of denim pieces subtly printed with tropical palms, the effect of which is similar to, but much more innovative and exciting than, acid wash or tie-dye. Available in early January, when Ms. McCartney is scheduled to open two new stores, one in Bal Harbour, Fla., and the other on Greene Street in SoHo, the jacket and bluejeans pictured here are as ready for sunny South Beach as they are the chilly streets of the Northeast. ''Denim is something that's already ingrained in everyone's wardrobe,'' she said, ''so we played with it to give it a new twist.'' Aloha! Stella McCartney jacket ($995) and jeans ($665) will be available in early January at Stella McCartney New York,

Seasonal BRONX The New York Botanical Garden Holiday Film Festival. Animated, classics and a documentary on the Holiday Train show. Fridays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. to Jan. 1. $10 to $25. The New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard. (718) 817-8700; nybg.org.

While poring over the Web site Legacy.com to prepare this issue, we noticed a trend. A search of the site's database -- which includes obituaries from more than 750 newspapers across the country -- turned up hundreds of obits published in 2011 with one phrase in common. A single thread appears and reappears, as a headline or an afterthought, in the final words written by the families of more than 300 people who departed this earth in the past year. In each of these obituaries was a phrase that read something like this: ''The first black American to . . .'' or ''The first African-American .''
Film Stephen Holden

IT sounded so intriguing. Margherita Aloi, the daughter of a winemaker and farmer from a small town in the Piedmont region of Italy, who attended the Culinary Institute of Barolo, was chosen by the New York restaurateur Pino Luongo to cook at his new, wildly successful Manhattan restaurant, Le Madri. It was 1989 and she was just 18. Mr. Luongo had the novel idea of staffing Le Madri, which means ''the mothers,'' with a rotating cadre of Italian women, each cooking her regional specialty. The young Ms. Aloi was hired as the fresh-pasta maker. Twenty years later, Le Madri has closed, but Ms. Aloi has accumulated an impressive résumé. She stayed on at the restaurant past the three months that had been originally arranged, eventually attaining the position of executive chef. From there, she partnered with Chris Mazzilli to open Arezzo (now closed) in Chelsea, followed by Aloi restaurant in New Canaan. In 2010, in partnership with Robert Scinto, a real estate developer, she took the helm at Il Palio, in Shelton, as the executive chef.

WITH Christmas upon us and New Year's just around the bend, many families are contending with long road trips and crowded flights. All those hours in the car and at the airport are bound to bring out tantrums in toddlers, squabbles among siblings and the familiar ''I'm bored'' from tweens. To help stave off meltdowns and keep the children entertained, I asked a range of experts, from professional toy-reviewers to travel-savvy mothers, for the best apps for iPads and iPhones. As a parent who is prone to guilt attacks when my own daughter spends too much time in front of a screen, no matter what its size, my aim was to find that sweet spot that falls somewhere between the ruthless thrill of hurling birds at pigs and the rigor of dividing fractions. I've also thrown in some unplugged options. Below are top picks organized by age.
LOUISVILLE, Ky. IT sounds like a taunt here in Bourbon Country: Go ahead, mix my Manhattan.

RADOM--Marjorie Roth (1912-2011). "Midge" was the first wife of playwright Edward Chodorov. She subsequently married Matthew Radom, USN Ret. who died in 2004. Family includes son Stephan Chodorov, daughter and son-in-law Ginger and Michael Montel, grandsons Pip Chodorov and Max Montel, sister Jessie Robinson and nieces, nephews and cousins. We will lift a glass in her memory at a later date.

Celebrating New Year's Eve in Las Vegas isn't a novel concept, but the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino Las Vegas is offering a fresh way to ring in 2012. The hotel has scheduled three days of events, beginning on Dec. 30, that emphasize its musical roots. The hip-hop star Drake (above), the alternative singer Corey Taylor, the heavy metal band Guns N' Roses and a popular local band, Sin City Sinners, are all scheduled to perform. Also, the techno D.J. Robbie Rivera and the 'Jersey Shore' star Pauly D will be hosting parties at the Vanity nightclub, and there will be seven open bars throughout the property. In years past, the hotel's New Year's Eve entertainment consisted of one concert and one party at Vanity.

WITH only a week left in 2011, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has a dubious distinction: its performance has been far worse than that of a basic basket of bonds in the last 12 years. But while betting on a large-cap stock index may not have paid off over that time, it would be wrong to assume that this has been the case for all sectors of the market. A quick glance at the numbers shows that the S.& P. 500 index of large domestic stocks has gone virtually nowhere since the technology bubble burst in 2000, while the Barclays United States aggregate bond index has returned more than 6 percent a year, on average.

HIP-HOP is primarily a celebration of black masculinity. Sure, there have long been significant black female and white male figures, but the majority of the conversation in hip-hop is and has always been about the actions, thoughts, feelings and ethos of black men. But this hegemony cannot last forever. Eventually the throne will have to be shared. The world of hip-hop has some diversity: Eminem, Mac Miller and Nicki Minaj now; the Beastie Boys, Lauryn Hill and Missy Elliott in the past. We have respected rappers of South Asian descent: M.I.A. and Heems from Das Racist. But what about the American white woman? Could she ever rock the mic for real? The cosmology of American celebrity requires several blond white women be major planets at all times. From Marilyn Monroe to Madonna to Britney Spears to Paris Hilton to Lady Gaga, our culture refuses to allow a void in the job called America's Favorite Blonde. (Some might say the woman currently holding that office is Beyoncé.) Given that cultural law, how long will it be until some blonde -- or any white woman -- rises to fame through hip-hop? I daresay it's inescapable. I'm surprised it hasn't happened already. Well, it may happen soon. We now have a small movement of white female rappers who want to be taken seriously, including Iggy Azalea, Kreayshawn and K.Flay.

WHEN Loren Munk began furtively filming New York City gallery and museum openings in 2006 -- ''working undercover,'' as he put it -- he was regularly kicked out by security guards and threatened with legal action for copyright infringement. Since then, however, Mr. Munk's camera has become a welcome guest, and using the alias James Kalm, he has uploaded more than 900 videos to his YouTube channels, the James Kalm Report and James Kalm Rough Cut, which have been viewed nearly two million times in total.

GILPATRIC--Marguerite S.,of New York, New York, died at home peacefully on December 18, 2011. She leaves two children, Elisabeth Converse of Santa Rosa, California and David L. Gilpatric of Winchester, Massachusetts. She also leaves seven grandchildren, Christopher and Stephen Gilpatric, Jennifer Mayes, Marguerite Yao, and Camille, Chadbourne and Grayson Converse, and three great-grandchildren, Timothy and Benjamin Mayes, and Jack Gilpatric. Much loved and admired by many friends and colleagues. A private memorial will be held at a later date.

The North River Mental Health Center on Chicago's Northwest side will not be closing, but Diana Bryant fears the closure of other centers citywide will affect her anyway. Ms. Bryant, 64, is worried that North River will not be able to manage the flood of new patients once the city closes six other centers.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Government soldiers opened fire on a giant demonstration in Yemen's capital on Saturday, killing at least nine protesters in the worst violence since President Ali Abdullah Saleh agreed to give up his post more than a month ago. The march, which activists said was peaceful, was to protest a deal granting Mr. Saleh immunity from prosecution for the killing of protesters.

One crucial aspect of the lockout-shortened 2011-12 N.B.A. season will be the hectic 66-game pace. Which teams will have the legs to keep up, and which teams will be worn out? The only real point of reference is the 1998-99 season, cut to 50 games after a protracted lockout. The standings were in chaos, and a No. 8 seed (the Knicks) reached the N.B.A. finals.
HELLMAN--F. Warren. The best of the best. You made the world smile. God bless you. David Parshall

TINT--Edith, 87, of Rockaway, NJ, on December 23, 2011. Devoted wife of the late Gilbert Tint, beloved mother of Judy and Barbara, adored grandmother of Bati, Ori, and Mikey, cherished daughter, sister, aunt, mother-in-law and friend. Services will be on Tuesday, December 27 at 11:30am, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY.

An article last Sunday about American subcompacts of the 1970s misidentified the author of a 1979 book, ''On a Clear Day You Can See General Motors.'' He is J. Patrick Wright -- not John Z. DeLorean, who was quoted extensively in the book.

AN architectural historian with a penchant for railroad stations, David Naylor has been traveling by train since the 1970s. He described the view from a train as a sort of movie, a documentary on the history of a region. ''I would say that compared to the fragmented views out of car windows and the miniaturized views out of planes, the meditative view out of a train window is even better than television,'' he said. Here are excerpts from conversations with Mr. Naylor about why and where to ride the rails.

IN the backyard, revelers gathered around a vat of boiling oil and counted down from 10. All eyes were on the 12-pound turkey, suspended by a rope. At ''One!'' the bird plunged into the fryer and everyone cheered. It was Dec. 25, 2010, and we were at Project Parlor, the bar my sister opened two years ago in Brooklyn. She had prepared a nondenominational feast for anti-holiday castaways and orphans with nowhere else to be. We ended up slouched around a battered piano like ne'er-do-wells in a Wild West honky-tonk, singing hoarse, half-drunken carols.

ASKED to recall unforgettable moments from the year in theater, one writer after another for The New York Times suggested scenes from Jez Butterworth's ''Jerusalem,'' which won Mark Rylance a Tony Award for best actor last spring. Stipulated: ''Jerusalem'' was full of memorable moments. Stipulated: The Times's critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood already named it among their Top 10 shows of the year. Further stipulated: No ''Jerusalem'' here. But much else to remember, some of it surfacing in the smallest and most offbeat of places.

''WE ARE THE 99 PERCENT.'' It was so much beyond a local slogan: the louder it was spoken, the more it began to say. My job, my streets, my economy, my riot, my skin. Cities shook their souls out. The yearning went global. Some protesters poured gasoline into bottles and lighted the sky with fire. Others unfurled hammocks under light poles. The idea was to be seen, to be heard, to be tweeted. The year 2011 was an evanescent spectacle of anger. Every corner was a world, and every world had its corners. The bankers stood back, the corporations hushed a moment, the politicians held their breath, and the cops took out their pepper spray. It might have begun in Wisconsin, had its adolescence in Greece, and shattered the night in London, but it lost and won its innocence in Zuccotti Park. Suddenly, a tent had as much meaning as a tower. Kids from all over the country boiled collard greens in the courtyard of commerce. The city's bureaucrats tried frantically to barricade them in, or out -- nobody seemed sure which. The anger rolled all the way down to Wall Street and the markets shivered a moment. When cold weather kicked in, the tents began to disappear and the anger diffused, but the images remained, another sort of fire in flight.

IT is no idle boast for Edgar Kendricks: The man can sit at any piano or organ in Harlem and summon a legion of church ladies in big hats to fill the pews and serve as his choir. Take last Saturday night, when more than 100 of his followers crowded into the narrow, windowless Glendale Baptist Church, which is squeezed between apartment buildings on West 128th Street.

SOMETIMES there is a necessity for anniversaries, even for things that cannot be forgotten. The memorial services for 9/11 were remarkable for their grace and dignity. The falling water, beside the reflecting pools, spoke volumes. While the Republicans fumbled for their own sort of memory -- trying somehow to bring back the apparent ease of the Reagan years -- the rest of the country drove down a street of foreclosed homes. We were all, in some way, looking for a brand-new roof.

Several years ago, David Iole boarded a train in Chicago after work and ran into a friend who told him he looked as if he was high on drugs. ''We're talking, and he goes, 'Man, you look lit,' '' said the Navy veteran, who is now in his mid-40s and is a patient at the North River Mental Health Center. ''I took offense to what he said, because I don't do drugs.''

By some miracle, you set aside a day to tackle that project you can't seem to finish in the office. You close the door, boot up your laptop, open the right file and . . . five minutes later catch yourself thinking about dinner. By 10 a.m., you're staring at the wall, even squinting at it between your fingertips. Is this day 50 hours long? Soon, you fall into a light, unsatisfying sleep and awake dizzy or with a pounding headache; all your limbs feel weighed down. At which point, most likely around noon, you commit a fatal error: leaving the room. I'll just garden for a bit, you tell yourself, or do a little charity work. Hmmm, I wonder if my friend Gregory is around? This probably strikes you as an extremely, even a uniquely, modern problem. Pick up an early medieval monastic text, however, and you will find extensive discussion of all the symptoms listed above, as well as a diagnosis. Acedia, also known as the ''noonday demon,'' appears again and again in the writings of the Desert Fathers from the fourth and fifth centuries. Wherever monks and nuns retreated into cells to labor and to meditate on matters spiritual, the illness struck.

ARLINGTON, Tex. -- His right hand wrapped in a bandage, the Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo stood on the sideline looking like a prizefighter who had thrown his last punch. Romo's throwing hand had crashed into a Philadelphia Eagle's helmet shortly after the Giants had beaten the Jets, which actually rendered Saturday's result here meaningless. But Romo's injury was hardly irrelevant and the speculation about his health will only mount as the Giants and Cowboys prepare for next Sunday's showdown in New Jersey, with the winner claiming the N.F.C. East title.
