When Richard Geller(b. 1946)died, students put his catch phrase, ''Math is #1,'' all over Stuyvesant High School, in New York City, where he had taught. It was taped onto lockers. It was drawn on a couple of desks. It was handwritten on a T-shirt. In the classroom, Geller was passionate and intense and demanding. One student remembered her math grade was the lowest one on her report card, ''but it was a Geller grade, and it was the one I was most proud of.'' Geller could have retired a decade before he died, but he didn't want to. He was a math teacher through and through. This is an edited and condensed version of a speech Geller delivered at Stuyvesant's graduation in June 2011. He died four months later.

Robert Easton, a character actor turned accent coach to the stars, who transformed Drew Barrymore into Amy Fisher, Ben Kingsley into Meyer Lansky and Gregory Peck first into Josef Mengele and later into Abraham Lincoln, among other feats of articulatory alchemy, died on Dec. 16 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81. His daughter, Heather Woodruff Perry, confirmed the death. Just weeks before he died, she said, her father was happily turning John Travolta into a Bosnian.

THOSE WEREN'T JUST tank lights leaving the desert behind. That was the darkness of a nearly nine-year war made visible. The soldiers moved through the sandstorms, and landed back home in the United States to deal with the continuing legacy of American foreign policies. In 2011, Barack Obama's promises were finally beginning to find their way onto the front pages. A spectacular nighttime raid found Osama bin Laden in Abbottabad, Pakistan. The helicopters landed. The weight of the past was kicked up in the dust. Author of a decade of killing, Bin Laden had endpages that were quick and sharp. He was shot dead, buried at sea, and the White House held its breath: it sounded so much like a sigh of joy, exhausted and necessary. The soldiers continued their journeys: it was a big world they were returning to. The seven billionth baby was born, starting global discussions on issues of environment, health and technology. Europe teetered on the edge of ruin, stunned by even more economic philandering. In Norway the island of Utoya heard gunshots among the trees. Parts of Africa were dealing, yet again, with an almost impossible hunger and thirst. But stories and images are always new, no matter how old the theme. The surprise of the world is that it can still surprise us.

The official restart of the Miami Heat begins on Sunday with far less noise than a year ago, when a team constructed on superstar intrigue evoked breathless predictions and sputtering vitriol in equal measure. Lest the legion of Heat haters forget, Miami fell only two games short of winning last season's N.B.A. championship. Now LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, Chris Bosh and a supporting cast are back, claiming that the new version is a stronger, a wiser and, yes, a better group after last season's lesson-learning.

HOEY--Patricia, (nee Morris), 79, of Manhattan died on December 21, 2011. An avid fan of theatre and devoted to her family, she leaves behind her loving, dedicated husband of 60 years, Ray, daughter and son-in-law, Patricia and Wayne Isom and two adored grandchildren, Jack and Catherine Isom. She will be dearly missed. Family will receive on December 27, 3-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. Funeral Mass in The Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral on December 28, at 10:30am.

A picture caption last Sunday with the continuation of an article about the economic health of Iowa misstated the location in Pella, Iowa, where the photograph of the Vermeer Mill was taken. It is in the town's historic district, not in the nearby ''Dutch-style center square.''

Some of my cousins and I, who have more disposable income, enjoy fine wines. I take a ''treat'' bottle to holiday meals and several nice budget bottles. This holiday, I brought a $200 bottle, which a wine-enthusiast cousin praised. My brother, who knows nothing of wine, proceeded to drink half of it and exclaim, ''Tastes just like the $3 bottle to me.'' Is there a polite way to ask nonoenophiles to drink the less expensive wine and let the wine lovers enjoy the special bottles? Erin, Honolulu

CHOCOLATE -- like fashion, wine and finance -- has become a complex cultural phenomenon. There is basic chocolate for the masses, artisanal chocolate for purists and avant-garde creations for connoisseurs. In Brussels, a polyglot city at the geographic and cultural crossroads of Europe, you get it all. The capital of Belgium may be known as the Capital of Europe, but it is also, at least as far as most chocolate aficionados are concerned, the World Capital of Chocolate. Ever since the Brussels chocolatier Jean Neuhaus invented the praline 100 years ago, the city has been at the forefront of the chocolate business. There are a million residents and some 500 chocolatiers, about one chocolatier for every 2,000 people. The average Belgian consumes over 15 pounds of chocolate each year, one of the highest rates in the world.

An illustration on Dec. 11 showing ski trivia on a map of the United States included an incorrect comparison of the amount of snow that fell last season at Mount Baker, Wash., with the height of the Seattle Space Needle. The amount of snow was 857 inches -- not feet -- so therefore it did not tower over the 603-foot-tall Space Needle. (Mount Baker would have needed more than 6,300 more inches of snow just to reach the top of the famous landmark.)

The painting is six feet tall, which is not so big in a gallery but gigantic in a house. Also it is of their mom. Sandra, Grace and John would tease her about it. They called it ''the dartboard.'' ''I mean, it was just huge,'' John says. ''Just huge. And I'd bring friends over, and they'd be like: 'Wow! That's, like, the biggest picture we've ever seen.'''

WHAT do you do after turning yourself into Julia Child, a bold, occasionally bossy woman who changed the way people think about food? You turn yourself into Margaret Thatcher, of course, an even bolder and bossier one, who changed the way people think about Britain. This is what Meryl Streep does in ''The Iron Lady,'' which opens Friday in New York. In yet another of her miraculous impersonations, which has already been nominated for a Golden Globe award, she seems even more Thatcher-like than Mrs. Thatcher, so that after the movie if you go back and look at photographs of Mrs. Thatcher in her prime, you can't help feeling that they're a little off. She no longer looks like herself. Sitting over tea recently at the Waldorf Astoria with Phyllida Lloyd, the film's director, Ms. Streep said that she had been hoping to make a movie about Elisabeth Kübler-Ross, and that Ms. Lloyd told her sarcastically, ''Yeah, that will pack them in.'' But when offered the role of Mrs. Thatcher, Ms. Streep didn't hesitate. ''You have to imagine yourself as a 62-year-old actress getting a phone call asking you to play the first female leader in the Western world elected on her own merits and not on the coattails of her husband,'' she said. ''To say, 'No, I'm not interested' would just be ridiculous. There is no other opportunity like it.''

Madonna was not careening around the outdoor skating rink at the Standard Hotel -- she's more likely to materialize upstairs at the Top of the Standard, the celebrity magnet formerly known as the Boom Boom Room -- but she and her ilk are well-represented on the piped-in soundtrack. On a recent Friday night, the mood was festive at the Kaffeeklatsch, the pop-up Alpine snack hut and rinkside cafe, at 848 Washington Street, where the shrieks of amateur skaters skidding, sliding and occasionally going boom, were also part of the entertainment. Admission is $12, rental skates are $3, heat lamps keep the crowd warm, and après-ski couture capped by furry hats is the prevalent attire. Grandma's hot chocolate is served with a twist: fortifying shots of bourbon, brandy, whiskey and whatnot -- Dutch courage for skittish skaters. IN THE SEATS Joshua Crouthamel, 31, an American freelance travel writer based in Sydney, Australia, and his partner, Kurt Fulepp, 27, an Aussie who does marketing for Bing, the Internet search engine, were on a weekend jaunt to experience ''New York Christmas kitsch.'' They met up with Melissa Maguire, 31, who attended New York University with Mr. Crouthamel. She is now a producer for NY1, married and living in Jersey City.
Margaret Sullivan is 58 and has been battling mental illness since she was 17. Several years ago, the illness almost won.

SEOUL, South Korea -- North Korea broadcast television footage on Sunday of the top military brass flanking the country's young new leader, Kim Jong-un, as they paid their respects to Mr. Kim's father, who died of heart attack a week ago, and vowed their allegiance to his chosen successor. Among the officials there was Jang Song-taek, Mr. Kim's uncle and a vice chairman of the powerful National Defense Commission, whose role as the young successor's caretaker has been magnified during the transition. Mr. Jang, 65, in what was said to be his first public appearance in a military uniform on state television, wore a general's insignia.

Alison D. Christie and Joseph Roby IV were married Wednesday evening in an outdoor ceremony at the Gulf Stream Golf Club in Gulf Stream, Fla. David C. Tassell, a Florida notary public and a friend of the bride's parents, officiated. Mrs. Roby, 33, is a teacher in San Francisco for Stretch the Imagination, an early-childhood educational school. She graduated from Fairfield University.

The Bible is the model for and subject of more art and thought than those of us who live within its influence, consciously or unconsciously, will ever know. Literatures are self-referential by nature, and even when references to Scripture in contemporary fiction and poetry are no more than ornamental or rhetorical -- indeed, even when they are unintentional -- they are still a natural consequence of the persistence of a powerful literary tradition. Biblical allusions can suggest a degree of seriousness or significance their context in a modern fiction does not always support. This is no cause for alarm. Every fiction is a leap in the dark, and a failed grasp at seriousness is to be respected for what it attempts. In any case, these references demonstrate that in the culture there is a well of special meaning to be drawn upon that can make an obscure death a martyrdom and a gesture of forgiveness an act of grace. Whatever the state of belief of a writer or reader, such resonances have meaning that is more than ornamental, since they acknowledge complexity of experience of a kind that is the substance of fiction.

In 1961, the N.B.A. was a far cry from the corporate behemoth that finally opens play on Sunday after bickering for months over billions in revenue. The league was 15 years old but still trying to find its way in a landscape dominated by baseball, football, boxing and college sports. That season, the Philadelphia Warriors star Wilt Chamberlain scored 100 points against the Knicks in Hershey, Pa., in front of barely 4,000 people, with no television crew, not even reporters from The Philadelphia Inquirer or any New York newspapers. The league seemed ripe for a challenge, and Abe Saperstein, the founder of the Harlem Globetrotters, was itching to give it one. He thought he had been promised the N.B.A.'s Los Angeles franchise only to see the Minneapolis Lakers go west and take his spot. So he formed the eight-team American Basketball League, with franchises from Hawaii to Philadelphia.

PICKMAN--Morton. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of our dear friend and Trustee, Morton Mac Pickman. Mac was an energetic, frequent, and generous supporter of our work and a real mensch. We shall miss him greatly. Our condolences go out to Gladys and their large and loving family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair David G. Marwell, Dir

In any other week, in any other city, in any other building, the sale of a three-bedroom apartment for $24 million - the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records - would not go unnoticed. But in the same week, in this city, the reported sale of a penthouse in the same building, 15 Central Park West, for a record-shattering $88 million, to the 22-year-old daughter of a Russian oligarch, dwarfed the first deal and made all others seem rather ho-hum.

A high-end hotel in Brussels, Tintin's stomping ground, is offering two new packages and four themed rooms to celebrate the popular comic book hero. The promotion - from the Hotel Amigo - is timed to correspond with the release of the film ''The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn,'' which opened on Wednesday in the United States. Both packages include a Tintin-themed gift, tickets to the Herge Museum, which highlights the work and life of Tintin's creator, Georges Remi (whose pen name was Herge), and a detailed map for a self-guided walking-tour to follow the escapades of Tintin, and his trusty dog companion Snowy, through the city. Stops include the daily flea market on the Place du Jeu de Balle, the setting of the film's opening scene.

TO baby boomers of a certain age Donna Reed was a sunny-bright television fixture for eight seasons, the perfect mom -- at least according to the prevailing values of the day -- radiantly gliding down the staircase every week to answer the beckoning phone, its ringing augmented by an impossibly perky musical theme fittingly titled ''Happy Days.'' ''The Donna Reed Show'' is seldom rerun, hobbled by its black-and-white photography, but its eponymous star is still regularly beamed back to mind this time of year with broadcasts of ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' the beloved Frank Capra film in which she co-stars with Jimmy Stewart, reminding viewers of her soft-spoken, wholesome appeal. The long-unseenfourth season of the 1958-66 series was released this month on DVD (from MPI Home Video), making it available for the first time to a new generation of viewers and older ones eager to become reacquainted.

THOSE WEREN'T JUST tank lights leaving the desert behind. That was the darkness of a nearly nine-year war made visible. The soldiers moved through the sandstorms, and landed back home in the United States to deal with the continuing legacy of American foreign policies. In 2011, Barack Obama's promises were finally beginning to find their way onto the front pages. A spectacular nighttime raid found Osama bin Laden in Abbottabad, Pakistan. The helicopters landed. The weight of the past was kicked up in the dust. Author of a decade of killing, Bin Laden had endpages that were quick and sharp. He was shot dead, buried at sea, and the White House held its breath: it sounded so much like a sigh of joy, exhausted and necessary. The soldiers continued their journeys: it was a big world they were returning to. The seven billionth baby was born, starting global discussions on issues of environment, health and technology. Europe teetered on the edge of ruin, stunned by even more economic philandering. In the fall, lights were lit for Kim Il-sung and a regime that has hidden its face. In Norway the island of Utoya heard gunshots among the trees. Parts of Africa were dealing, yet again, with an almost impossible hunger and thirst. But stories and images are always new, no matter how old the theme. The surprise of the world is that it can still surprise us.

WHITHER the hostess gown? Archaeological study of this now-defunct garment, popular from the 1930s to the 1970s (according to the Vintage Fashion Guild), reveals that the American lady of the house used to greet her dinner guests not in Lululemon yoga pants and a clammy tank top, but a billowing, brightly colored maxi-dress, often with a forgiving waistline, or no waistline -- sort of a cross between an evening formal and a bathrobe. The idea was to balance one's respect for and command of the occasion with the right to sprawl comfortably in one's living room on oversize lounging cushions, perhaps leaping up from time to time to rearrange the cheese straws. For hostess gowns had very little to do with actual cooking; indeed, many of the specimens that remain are downright fire hazards, with their tentlike sleeves.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''One More From the Heart,'' Dec. 17: I never missed George Vecsey's Sports of The Times column and enjoyed the way he wrote. He was insightful and funny. Readers were lucky he did this on the sports pages.

SERENA--Joan McGailey Joan McGailey Serena, 58, of Maple Plain, MN, passed quietly at home Monday, December 19; after a courageous two and a half year battle with metastatic melanoma. Joan was born in Briarcliff Manor, NY, graduated Kenyon College in Gambier Ohio, and was married to her husband of 19 years John, with whom they share two children, Katie and Jack. Starting almost 35 years ago with Associated Merchandising Corporation in New York City, later with Department 56, Marshall Fields, and Macy's in Minneapolis, Joan helped design and develop Christmas trim for the retail industry. Joan's work took her around the globe many times, visiting artisans and manufacturers throughout Europe and the Far East, bringing the best of their work home for our holidays. Joan was preceded in death by her mother, Dorothy Dorn, and her father, John Lawrence McGailey. At Joan's request there is no public memorial planned, contributions in Joan's name may be made to Mayo Clinic Cancer Center in Rochester, MN.

ASK the Croatian artist Sanja Ivekovic about her work, and she is likely to minimize her role in it. ''It is not a genius that is making art but the collaboration of many people,'' she declared this month, speaking in heavily accented English, as she strode into the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art. ''We should be grateful not to God for giving us our talent but to the people who support us.'' Ms. Ivekovic was attending -- along with Roxana Marcoci, the Modern's curator of photography, and a huge installation crew -- to the last details of her first American survey show, ''Sweet Violence,'' which opened at the museum last Sunday and runs through March 26. It gathers nearly 40 years' worth of work by the 62-year-old artist, starting with the videos, performances and photocollages that made her name in Europe in the early 1970s and extending to more recent projects like ''Women's House,'' a continuing series of multimedia works and events begun in 2002 in collaboration with women's rights groups around the world.

The 36 Hours column on Dec. 18 about Salzburg, Austria, misspelled the surname of a pianist who will appear at the International Mozarteum Foundation during Mozart Week next year. She is Mitsuko Uchida, not Uchika. And an accompanying map located the Mirabell Palace and Gardens incorrectly. The gardens are on the west side of Rainerstrasse, not on the east side. A corrected map is at nytimes.com/travel.

WASHINGTON -- The Justice Department has reversed its long-held opposition to many forms of Internet gambling, removing a big legal obstacle for states that want to sanction online gambling to help fix their budget deficits. The legal opinion, issued by the department's office of legal counsel in September but made public on Friday, came in response to requests by New York and Illinois to clarify whether the Wire Act of 1961, which prohibits wagering over telecommunications systems that cross state or national borders, prevented those states from using the Internet to sell lottery tickets to adults within their own borders.

Cam Newton, right, threw three touchdown passes, broke Peyton Manning's rookie passing record with a game to spare and outran smaller defensive backs on a 49-yard touchdown run up the middle to lead the Panthers to a 48-16 win over the Buccaneers. Rob Bironas kicked three field goals, including two 51-yarders, and set a league record by making at least one of 40 yards or more in his ninth consecutive game, helping the Titans beat the Jaguars, 23-17.

WHAT could provoke a boy to cry hysterically and scream that he hates his parents? In one case, it was getting a Hello Kitty sweater for Christmas. The caterwauling child starred in one of hundreds of prank videos this month by parents answering a challenge by Jimmy Kimmel, the late-night comic: Give your children a terrible Christmas gift a few weeks early, start filming and wait for the magic.

NEWBURGH, N.Y. -- When it comes to assessing the motivations of a motorcycle collector, it is never clear exactly where to draw the line between a hobby and an obsession. But it seems quite likely that Gerald A. Doering has crossed it.

If you'd been born to farmer parents in Battambang province, in the country of Cambodia, and been given the name Vann Nath (pronounced van NAT), you would have spent four years as a young man in a pagoda, carefully etching calligraphy on a palm leaf, and through that task, learned the Buddhist concepts that were meant to guide your life: a belief in nonviolence, truth-telling and mindfulness. After leaving the monkhood and taking up work as a commercial painter, you would have found yourself as a young husband and father, on the precipice of that April day in 1975 when the Lon Nol regime fell to the jungle forces of Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge. What follows is nearly incomprehensible: Millions are driven from their homes in a forced exodus from the cities; doctors, teachers and factory workers are summarily executed, as is anyone who wears glasses, speaks a foreign language or possesses a university degree. Money, religion, schools, sports, even love -- all abolished. Words like ''beauty,'' ''colorful'' and ''comfort'' are banned from the radio. The idea of happiness becomes anathema, as it is the supreme belief of Angkar -- the mysterious entity in charge -- that in order to purge individuality, the people must be made to suffer, and having suffered, will remain void of dreams and expectations. That is, without minds of their own, they'll be perfect revolutionary workers.

Nothing Sacred At a time when Technicolor was generally reserved for musicals or historical pageants, William Wellman's 1937 film ''Nothing Sacred'' made a memorably anomalous use of the process for a screwball comedy -- among the most cynical of the period -- largely set in the nightclubs and hotel rooms of an Art Deco Manhattan. The story, frequently recycled, concerns a disgraced tabloid newspaperman (Fredric March) who sees a chance to regain the favor of his editor (Walter Connolly) when he comes across the story of Hazel Flagg (Carole Lombard), a worker in a New England watch factory who learns she has radium poisoning. He arranges for Hazel and her cuddly, Capraesque doctor (Charles Winninger) to visit New York, where her tragic tale (and superlative gams) makes her the toast of the town. But Hazel, who's eager to escape small-town life, really isn't sick at all.

OPPENHEIMER--Diane, of Montauk, NY and Coral Springs, Fla., wife of the late Joseph Oppenheimer, has passed away on December 22, 2011. She was born on March 1, 1924 and leaves her beloved family Paula and Daniel Friedman, Peter and Janet Oppenheimer, Kenneth and Jill Oppenheimer, seven grandchildren, four great- grandchildren and sister Lila Harris. She will be forever in our hearts and prayers. The family is requesting any donations go to the Michal J. Fox Parkinson's Research Foundation at P.O.Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780 or 1-800-708-7644

RARELY does a Broadway show become one of the biggest cultural news stories of the year. But ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' had more offstage intrigue than any production in recent memory -- as well as a record-setting budget of $75 million, six delays to its opening night and the gold-plated creative team of U2's Bono and the Edge and the director Julie Taymor. So it's no surprise that from beginning to end Spidey dominated the year in theater news. But his wasn't the only story (just about a third of them, in this modest account): LONGEST SLOG The unheard-of 183 preview performances for ''Spider-Man'' -- to accommodate script, staging, cast and special-effects changes -- before the show finally opened on June 14. (Most Broadway musicals hold about 25 preview performances to prepare for an opening.)

THE WATER ROSE. And rose. Soon there were traffic lights flipping, doors tumbling, tatami mats spinning in the current. Cars began to float alongside washing machines, computers, people. The incredible could occur. And then the tsunami seemed to wash away the last vain dream of the 20th century: the nuclear answer. The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant went into meltdown and watched its poisons filter out to sea, and what remained is what we all must live with: the democratic rage of nature. No matter what we do, we cannot regulate how we are shaped by weather. We look for calm, but there is always an inevitability of storm. The images from Joplin, Mo., were pure with grief. A snowstorm paralyzed Tulsa, Okla. The Souris River shed more than a tear. The streets of Bangkok were almost apocalyptic during floods. There were droughts, earthquakes, wildfires scattering animals like dice. So, the question, then, is ancient: How with such rage shall beauty hold a plea? Rescuers in Turkey put their fingers on part of the pulse when they managed to pull 2-week-old Azra Karaduman from the rubble. Her mother and grandmother also emerged safely. She was tiny and voiceless, yet she said so much.

2 A.M. (TBS) A CHRISTMAS STORY (1983) ''You'll shoot your eye out.'' That's the oft-repeated refrain when Ralphie Parker (Peter Billingsley, above) tells adults he wants a BB gun for Christmas, and it's just another putdown for the 9-year-old boy, who is browbeaten by his parents, teased by his schoolmates and suckered by the Ovaltine company. The film, which is being shown every two hours till 6 p.m., listens in as a grown-up Ralphie (Jean Shepherd, the narrator) remembers his childhood in 1940s Indiana with comic nostalgia. 9 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS This week's topic is the political climate of 2011 and the bearing it will have on the 2012 election. Sitting at the roundtable are Tom Brokaw of NBC; Kathleen Parker of The Washington Post; Thomas Friedman of The New York Times; and Marc H. Morial, former mayor of New Orleans. The program ends with a Christmas Day message from Cardinal Theodore McCarrick, archbishop emeritus of Washington.
MAN SEEKS GOD My Flirtations With the Divine

To the Editor: While reading Anne Trubek's essay ''What Muncie Read'' (Nov. 27), I wondered by what criteria she deemed a found library ledger more fruitful in ascertaining exactly what people read than ''diary entries or sales figures.'' I currently have 126 books checked out from my university library, of which, woefully, I have read only a small fraction. Until they are finally recalled, many of these books will continue to lie on my shelves, where I have also stacked much of my lofty ambition along with them. Whether we buy or rent, I think it is safe to say that much of our book acquisition comes from a place of great optimism about what we will read, but turns out to be far from what we actually do read.

JACKSON--Clifford, 86, died Sunday, December 4, 2011 at his home in Park Slope. He was preceded in death by his parents Mae and Murray and his sister Louise. He was a lifelong resident of New York City who loved its offerings and challenges. He frequented the Public Library, the Metropolitan Opera, ballet and theater. He rode the subway system everywhere. He was an ardent outdoorsman who loved hiking and swimming. He followed his interest through world travel, visiting Asia, Europe and the Mid-East often. He escaped the Indian Tsunami by a day. He met all challenges head-on. Rest in peace, Cliff.

LAST year, Christmas was the biggest single day for e-book sales by HarperCollins. And indications are that this year's Christmas Day total will be even higher, given the extremely strong sales of e-readers like the Kindle and the Nook. Amazon announced on Dec. 15 that it had sold one million of its Kindles in each of the three previous weeks. But we can also guess that the number of visitors to the e-book sections of public libraries' Web sites is about to set a record, too.

THIS holiday season brings a set of gifts for the world of classical music, in the form of the highly uncoveted and arbitrarily granted Special Awards for 2011. It was a year of financial hardship for the arts (what year isn't?), especially for many opera houses, symphony orchestras, festivals and chamber music organizations, but high points also abounded. The following 10 prizes are bestowed in no particular order. BIGGEST FINANCIAL WOE The competition was intense. The Syracuse and New Mexico symphonies folded. The Louisville Orchestra spent much of the year in bankruptcy proceedings and suspended concerts for the fall. The Utica Symphony also fell silent. Even the storied Philadelphia Orchestra sought bankruptcy protection, unheard of for such a major ensemble. Philadelphia shares the prize with the New York City Opera, which moved out of Lincoln Center to save money, cut its budget by nearly two-thirds and is struggling with its orchestra and chorus over its proposal for a drastic reduction in work. A federal mediator has stepped in.

GOLDMAN--Jacob E. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Dr. Jacob E. Goldman, one of its foremost alumni, an early graduate of Yeshiva College who went on to earn graduate degrees in physics, a field in which he distinguished himself as a visionary corporate science manager at Ford Motor Company and Xerox where he founded the Xerox Lab and also held a wide array of leadership positions as a Board member of many scientific corporations. He was a longtime Trustee of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees where he was most recently an Honorary Trustee. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Rhoda Miller Goldman, his children and stepchildren, grandchildren and great grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Chancellor
POWSNER--Barbara (Roth), wife of the late Dr. N. Powsner of Plainview, NY. Mother of Rich, Cary, NC and David. Devoted bridge player, friend.

QUITTNER--Dr. Otto, 6/16/1924 - 12/21/201. Passed away in his New York City home. Husband to Judith, father to Anita, father-in-law to John Dunn. Founder and President of Qualiton Imports. Established 1964.
Classical Anthony Tommasini

Mary Medina first sought treatment for depression at Northwest Mental Health Center in Chicago after her son, who had joined the Army following the Sept. 11 attacks, had been sent to Iraq. ''He's in the Army and in Iraq and I didn't know when I was going to see him or talk to him or if he's even alive,'' she said. ''That's how bad things are. And when you're uncertain about your life, it really hits home.''

THE GIFT LIST: Do bankers give money for the holidays? Do designers give clothes? I don't know -- but I do know that, just like you and me, rich and famous authors often give books. Sometimes they even give best sellers. Exhibit A is Janet Evanovich (at No. 6 on the hardcover fiction list this week with ''Explosive Eighteen''), who will hand her husband a copy of Walter Isaacson's biography of Steve Jobs (at No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list). Evanovich, inset, also plans to give Mario Batali's new cookbook, ''Molto Batali,'' to her foodie son-in-law, and Dr. Seuss' ''How the Grinch Stole Christmas!'' to her grandson. He's named Max, just like the Grinch's beleaguered dog. Here's one reason to love Jodi Picoult, whose novel ''Sing You Home'' is at No. 6 on the trade paperback list this week: She's so nice, she actually took the wrapping paper off books to double-check their titles for this column. Now here's a reason to hate her: That was 16 days before Christmas, and her presents were already bought and wrapped. What will Picoult's family find in the slightly rumpled packages beneath the tree? For her husband, a first edition of Beatrix Potter's ''Tale of Timmy Tiptoes'' and a copy of Frommer's do-gooder travel guide, ''500 Places Where You Can Make a Difference.'' For her son studying Egyptology at Yale, ''Sacred and Profane: Treasures of Ancient Egypt From the Myers Collection.'' For her other son, also at Yale, Steven Petrow's ''Complete Gay and Lesbian Manners.'' And for her teenage daughter, Alexandra Horowitz's ''Inside of a Dog.''
JOURNEY TO THE ABYSS The Diaries of Count Harry Kessler, 1880-1918

GATHERING EVIDENCE: A Memoir, by Thomas Bernhard. Translated by David McLintock (Vintage International, $16.95.) Bernhard, the Austrian playwright and novelist who died in 1989, describes his harrowing childhood in Nazi-dominated schools and the bouts of pneumonia and tuberculosis that shaped his lifelong obsession with death. This volume includes ''My Prizes,'' translated by Carol Brown Janeway, a series of acerbic essays that recall Bernhard's literary awards and muster moral outrage against the idea of state-sanctioned art. THE ACCIDENT, by Ismail Kadare. Translated by John Hodgson (Grove, $14.) The Albanian novelist turns his attention from the carnage of Balkan history to the carnage of failed romance. When a taxi runs off the road in Vienna under suspicious circumstances, killing an Albanian couple in the back seat, a lonely researcher tries to solve the case by reconstructing their final weeks.

Mariah McManus The eager tunefulness of Mariah McManus's music almost gets in the way. So does the crisp songwriting, which is judicious with word choice and emotional delivery. But Ms. McManus is more complex than all that on the beguiling ''Nice To Meet You'' (Catcher and Rye). That's largely because of her sweet voice, which is sometimes direct and clear, and sometimes works over syllables using an aggressive tongue (with faint flickers of Bjorkian strangeness amidst the Taylor Swiftish purity). But it's always deceptive, because so much of what Ms. McManus is concerned with on these songs is rough terrain. The words of ''Make It Right'' are almost naïve, but Ms. McManus sings them with gale force. And on ''Anyway'' she sounds petulant but is really deflated, singing, ''I knew that someday you'd be leaving/Just didn't know it'd be so soon'' with punch, as if trying to push air out through each syllable. It makes the moments when she's expressing true wonder all the more powerful, as on her new holiday EP, ''Christmas Forever,'' which has a jangly ''Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)'' and a breezy tease of an original, ''You & Me.''
MAPLEWOOD PENTHOUSE $1,475,000

Some years it would be nice if there really were a Santa Claus. Imagine it. No lists, no shopping, no gift-wrapping, no bills, no shipping costs, an extremely low carbon footprint -- and on Christmas morning the miraculous appearance of presents that find just the right balance between desire and a sort of disciplinary justice. Picture a world in which what you get is what you want divided by what you deserve, and you can see the appeal of a real Santa, no matter what it would do to the gross domestic product of toy-producing and toy-consuming countries.

REIMAGINING EQUALITY Stories of Gender, Race, and Finding Home. By Anita Hill. Beacon, $25.95. At the end of the 19th century, Booker T. Washington condemned the one-room cabins housing a majority of the country's former slaves as ''the greatest embarrassment to the progress of the race.'' In his eyes, African-Americans could do little more to represent their preparedness for full participation in society than to set up house in a ''comfortable, tasty, framed cottage.'' Hill, a professor of social policy, law and women's studies at Brandeis, sees a similar connection between homeownership and full equality for black Americans: she eloquently recounts her family's journey ''from being property'' in antebellum Arkansas ''to owning property'' many years later in rural Oklahoma. But homeownership is just one of many factors that add up to true belonging in American society, she argues. Her book is a complex and at times confounding portrait of the ways in which black men and women have struggled to surmount myriad forms of injustice to own homes, and the social ills like gender discrimination and political exclusion that continue to imperil full equality even when that dream is attained. Hill says she began her research after revisiting the letters she had received in the years following her 1991 testimony in the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearings, letters that moved her ''to feel more at home in America.'' While saddled with a dense and sometimes befuddling conception of home, this ambitious book provides just as dignified and well intentioned a performance as the one she gave at those hearings.

DETROIT Trucks sighing under the weight of their cargo pull up, one after another, to the dock of an old manufacturing plant on the west side of ever-challenged Detroit. For all the convoluted coding contained in their bills of lading, these trucks carry freight as basic to life as air.

THE BREATH AND HUM of democracy seemed almost a libidinous thing in parts of the Middle East, but, in truth, the body heat had been simmering for years. The protests took hold in Tunisia in late 2010 after the street vendor Mohamed Bouazizi set himself on fire. The kindle caught and the spirit of his self-immolation lit a fuse across the region. A wave of protests struck Algeria, Egypt, Yemen, Jordan. Almost as soon as protesters in Cairo were being herded away from Tahrir Square, they were dancing at the news of Mubarak's resignation. Ruling families began to fall. Power-transfer treaties were brokered. Parliaments were dissolved. Monarchs locked their gates and boarded their windows. In Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was ousted and killed. NATO planes streaked a sky so blue it seemed it to speak of other Septembers. Faces, too, were lit by a new blue light. It was the era of the revolution down through the wires: time was collapsed and geography shrunk by the use of social networking. The whole world was indeed watching, listening, e-mailing. Some in the media lost their lives for the art of the images that emerged -- the photographs didn't just capture singular moments, but they looked backward and forward at the same time, at what has happened, and what is yet to come. The light from the Arab Spring rose from the ground up; the hope now is that the darkness doesn't fall.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Thousands of people attended funerals in Damascus on Saturday for the victims of two powerful bombs that exploded outside government security buildings the day before, as human rights activists reported a large-scale assault on a restive city by government troops. The bombings in the Syrian capital on Friday killed at least 44 people and wounded more than 160, in the worst attack on official installations since the beginning of the uprising in March.

SCHNECK--Jerome M.,MD. Noted psychiatrist and medical author. Died December 19, 2011, age 91. Survived by wife (Shirley) of 68 years.

ROME -- On a recent morning, Maurizio Compagnone, an employee of Italy's internal revenue service, stood before a classroom of middle school students in a leafy neighborhood here, preaching the virtues of paying taxes. ''You may think, 'I'm 13, why should I care about taxes?' '' he said with earnest enthusiasm as the students looked on, slightly bored. ''But you can take a step in the right direction. You can change the behavior of the people around you, your parents and friends.''

A different kind of hoedown: Traditional Persian music will be heard in the Metropolitan Museum's recently renovated Islamic galleries the night of Jan. 28 in a concert by Kayhan Kalhor, who plays the Persian spike fiddle (metmuseum.org).

AS a teenage aesthete, Louis Comfort Tiffany started making trips abroad to paint in the 1860s, paid for with his inheritance from the family jewelry business. For six decades he regularly took long vacations to sketch. In the Middle East, he painted camel caravans, pyramids and mosque doorways. On trips around America, he set up his easel at Long Island cow pastures, Yellowstone canyons and Pacific Northwest redwoods. About 125 of his landscapes and streetscapes can be seen through March 18 in ''The Paintings of Louis Comfort Tiffany: Works From a Long Island Collection,'' at the Nassau County Museum of Art. The paintings are from collectors who have requested anonymity.

LASDON--Richard Haven, passed away December 23rd after a prolonged battle with pancreatic cancer. The New York City native is survived by his brother Jeffrey, his sister Susan, sister-in-law Jeanette and niece Jacqueline. His many charitable interests included the New York City Ballet and numerous organizations associated with the arts. His friendship and support have furthered the careers of many artists and musicians both domestically and abroad. Animal welfare was near to his heart as are his surviving dogs Chelsman and Smidgen. Generous to a fault, a unique perspective of the world gave birth to a sense of humour and quick wit that will be missed by all who knew him. Family will receive friends Monday 7-9pm. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Tuesday, 1:30pm.

In the 1970s, giants walked the land and felled one another with reverberant blows. Joe Frazier, a model of disciplined persistence, pressed forward on the attack until he finally dropped Muhammad Ali with a perfect left hook in the 15th round of their first bout. An exhausted George Foreman took a week to fall down in the ring in Kinshasa after Ali gulled him into punching himself out and then finished him with a couple of shrewd shots. Foreman clubbed Frazier to the canvas eight times in less than seven rounds. Larry Holmes, knocked unconscious by Earnie Shavers with a straight right that might well have been the hardest punch of the decade, woke up, rose in time to beat the 10-count, defeated Shavers and held on to his title. In most weight classes of boxing, which has declined from mainstream to niche over the past half century, the golden age occurred sometime before 1960. But a last-gasp convergence of unmatched talent and TV exposure caused the heavyweights to peak late. In the '70s, four undisputed all-time greats -- Ali, Frazier, Foreman and Holmes -- fought their way to the top through extraordinarily tough competition.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. -- Roughly 24 hours before tipping off the N.B.A. season at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks conducted one final practice Saturday and took stock of the team that they hope will compete for a championship. ''It should be an exciting year,'' Coach Mike D'Antoni said. ''We're looking forward to it. I know the players are looking forward to playing. It should be great.''

Hello, world: those were the words that appeared on the screen once you had programmed and run the iconic first example in the book ''The C Programming Language,'' which Dennis Ritchie, the creator of C, co-wrote with Brian Kernighan. I remember that slim volume's revelatory power when I read it -- its generous, collegial style, more a talk with presumed equals than a textbook. I still have on my shelf the copy I used, a first edition. The pencil scratches seem to indicate I was figuring out what the hell I was doing. I was a self-taught programmer, and it was through Ritchie that I came to understand the layers of software that worked beneath the screens and printers and keyboards and mice. The newness of C's conception -- and the elegance of it -- was that the language was both ''high'' and ''low.'' Higher-level languages -- like Cobol and Fortran -- kept you out of the innards of the machine. ''Lower-level'' languages -- called ''assembler'' -- worked on only specific hardware. Closed environments dominated the computing world of the 1970s and early '80s. An operating system written for a Hewlett-Packard computer ran only on H.P. computers; I.B.M. controlled its software from chips up to the user interfaces.

Dear devoted fans of a certain 1946 Frank Capra holiday movie: Relax. The holiday production at Long Wharf Theater has done absolutely no harm to the original. In fact, it has added another layer of nostalgia. ''It's a Wonderful Life: A Live Radio Play'' is exactly what it says it is. Five actors, supported by a sound-effects man, deliver the lines of all the characters from the movie. Four are dressed in fashions suggesting that their characters live in the golden age of radio, almost certainly the 1940s. The fifth (Alex Moggridge) appears to be a 21st-century guy who has wandered into a dusty, deserted old radio studio and sees the others as ghosts. In short order, though, he is interacting with them. In fact, he finds himself cast in the role of George Bailey, originally played by Jimmy Stewart.

THE bicycle swung wide left under Alexander Barouh as he furiously pedaled to the end of his 500-meter sprint, bringing gasps from the crowd standing only a few feet from his front wheel. ''Don't steer!'' some spectators in the Lower East Side bar shouted.

In ''The Pre-K Underground,'' on the cover of Metropolitan last week, Soni Sangha wrote about how she and other city parents, whose children were priced out of private schools and denied spots in public ones, turned to co-op prekindergartens, which can be illegal, to begin their children's education. Hundreds of readers commented on NYTimes.com, voicing outrage at helicopter parenting, government red tape and the very concept of pre-K. Here are some responses. WOW. More evidence of how crazy New Yorkers are, and what ''slaves of NY'' they must be to put up with this sort of miserable lifestyle and abuse to have the right ZIP code.

Thierry Henry was in London two weeks ago to be honored as part of Arsenal's 125th anniversary celebrations. But could he be going back next month for a longer stay? Pressed, no doubt, by reporters eager for even the faintest whiff of a story heading into the January transfer window, Arsenal Manager Arsene Wenger on Friday acknowledged that he would ''have to think about'' reacquiring Henry on a short-term loan. Robin van Persie has needed little help so far this season, but the addition of Henry -- at least for January and February -- would be good cover for the club while forwards Gervinho (Ivory Coast) and Marouane Chamakh (Morocco) are on national team duty at next month's African Cup of Nations.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel visits Richmond, England (Hampton Court, above), a frugal day trip from pricey London. Read his account and share your London-area trip ideas.

Jack trained every day of his life as if he were going to the Olympics. He had a belt and a rope that he tied to the end of the pool so he could swim in place. To get used to the cold, we put water in the bathtub, and I poured 50 pounds of ice over him, and there he sat for an hour. In those days, people thought that when you're over 40, you're over the hill. But Jack wanted to show people that just because you're getting old, you just don't quit exercising.

MARIANNE FAITHFULL is still restless after all these years, taking puffs midsong on a forbidden Marlboro Light. She is still preening, tucking her shoulder-length hair behind her ears, a childish tic she has never quite abandoned. And she is still seasoning performances with raspy renditions of ''As Tears Go By,'' the doleful tune that shot to the top of the charts in the youth-besotted London of the 1960s, sealing her status as a pop idol and emblem of raffish London chic.

To the Editor: In her review of Anka Muhlstein's ''Balzac's Omelette: A Delicious Tour of French Food and Culture With Honoré de Balzac'' (Dec. 4), Nancy Kline writes, ''It is Balzac, Muhlstein tells us, who first 'brought meals into literature, in all their diversity.' '' But, almost 1,800 years before Balzac, Trimalchio's feast, in Petronius's ''Satyricon'', is plenty diverse -- from sows' udders to dormice dipped in honey and sprinkled with poppy seeds to a cooked boar out of whose belly fly live birds. The pioneer foodie of French literature, three centuries before Balzac, was François Rabelais. Book 4 of ''Gargantua and Pantagruel,'' in which the Gastrolaters make culinary offerings to Gaster, the Lord of the Belly, provides a five-page epic menu that includes 100 varieties of salad, 20 sorts of tarts, and comfits in a hundred colors, as well as hedgehogs, porpoises and stuffed monkeys. Balzac's omelette might be savory, but Rabelais's gourmands can choose from ''eggs fried, buttered, poached, boiled, baked in the embers, fried in the pan, scrambled, whisked, &c.''

To the Editor: David Orr, in his poetry column, provides a cogent overview of the old, but always worth asking, question of whether a poem is more than what can be paraphrased (''Ways of Saying,'' Dec. 11). He notes that this is not merely a two-sided argument, and shows that the debate is further complicated when a translator comes between the reader and the poet -- as is the case with the Spanish poet Luis de Góngora's long poem ''The Solitudes,'' translated by the masterly Edith Grossman. Just as translation of poetry is deemed by some to be impossible, using prose to explain poetry strikes many of us who are poets as foolhardy. But, ah, the nobility of the quest. I suspect Góngora and his shipwrecked young man would join me in toasting Orr: Salud y amor y tiempo para disfrutarlo. We have been fools once in our lives.

Danielle de Niese, soprano; Andreas Scholl, countertenor; English Concert, conducted by Harry Bicket (Decca B0015869-02; CD). THE soprano Danielle de Niese's new album, ''Beauty of the Baroque,'' may be satisfying to listeners who imagine the Baroque's beauties to resemble the blandly charming photographs in the booklet notes: flowing fabrics and precious jewels amid classical statuary and 17th-century furnishings.

Andrei Cimpian and Joseph Paul Robinson were married Friday in Auburn, N.Y. Florence M. Riley, a town justice of Sennett, N.Y., officiated at the home of Carmela Spoto, Dr. Robinson's maternal grandmother. Dr. Cimpian, 32, and Dr. Robinson, 33, are assistant professors at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where Dr. Cimpian teaches developmental psychology and Dr. Robinson teaches educational psychology. They received Ph.D.'s from Stanford, Dr. Cimpian in psychology and Dr. Robinson in the economics of education.

L.A. EYEWORKS is as famous for its ads, which feature black-and-white photographic portraits of celebrities wearing the company's high-design eyeglasses, as it is for the frames themselves. The photographer Greg Gorman has shot those portraits since 1982, and now 171 of them have been compiled in ''Framed,'' a book that is for sale on the company's Web site (laeyeworks.com). Mr. Gorman's subjects, who come from the worlds of entertainment, music, sports, art and dance, include Pee-wee Herman (left, Mr. Gorman's first), Pedro Almodóvar and Andy Warhol (who liked the ad campaign so much that he asked to be included in it). They offer a compelling look at three decades of pop culture, glamour and, of course, glasses. ''Framed,'' $50 at laeyeworks.com. BROOKE HODGE

In recent years, New Yorkers fortunate enough to indulge worries over domestic compensation have been besieged with more and more advice and debate every December -- from newspapers, magazines, parenting blogs, real-estate blogs -- on how much to tip the people who take care of our children, open our doors, adjust our radiators, park our Priuses. And yet there is little to suggest that this mountain of charts and bullet points has eased the tension. What economists cite as the vexing information asymmetries central to these transactions appear to have been rectified hardly at all. What this means is that even after you've rifled through the data and researched the gratuities administered by your neighbors and friends, you don't know what you don't know. Your superintendent could tell you what Mrs. Parsons in 5F gave him, but presumably he won't. And Mrs. Parsons, if you ask her, is likely to abstain from the truth.
VIDEO: Nasir Maman, a professor at Polytechnic Institute of NYU, demonstrates a system where a tablet recognizes the unique movement of a user's fingers. nytimes.com/technology

FELDMAN--Dr. Charles. The Yeshiva University is saddened by the passing of Dr. Charles Feldman, a distinguished physician and a respected community leader. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Rella (Levenstein) Feldman and their five children and grandchild. May the entire Feldman family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Chancellor

Ever get to the end of a road trip and realize you were just a few miles away from the shoe of the world's tallest man and you missed it? Maybe not, but On the Way, a new online travel site for road trippers, was designed to help find such unusual attractions. When you enter your start and destination, the program will populate a map of your route with restaurants, museums and less traditional tourist sites using programming interfaces like Google Places, Foursquare, Yelp and Lonely Planet's Points of Interest. It can help you find a Starbucks between New York and Washington, but it's better for local alternatives like Miss Shirley's Cafe in Baltimore (above). A link will take you to the venue's Foursquare or Yelp pages, where you can see reviews.

A PHOTOGRAPH is sometimes a perfect testament to the notion that we can't afford to lose our delight. While the news, and its makers, might dwell on what we've lost, we occasionally still witness the most remarkable music: marriages, journeys, longings, births and returns. Every now and then, the ground just won't show its shadows.

Because of an editing error, a report in the soccer roundup in some editions last Sunday about Barcelona's match against Santos in the Club World Cup final that day misidentified, in some copies, the team Barcelona was trying to match in winning six trophies in a season. Barcelona, not Real Madrid, previously won six trophies in a season, in 2009.

KING--Joan Harding, died after a difficult illness, peacefully at home, just shy of her 85th birthday. She was born in New York City in 1927, the oldest child of Marion Choate and Charles Barney Harding. A graduate of Miss Hewitt, Milton and Smith, she worked after college for the Bureau of Standards and the NAACP. She was wed to Thomas James King, late Professor at Dartmouth and City College, from 1950 to his untimely death in 1994. Joan was a loving, generous spirit. She was a warm and compassionate friend to all who knew her, with a keen and questioning mind. She returned to college in her late 40's to earn her RN, becoming a childbirth educator and stalwart board member of the Childbirth Education Association of Metropolitan New York. She was also a staunch supporter of environmental causes in Rockland County as a founding member of the Rockland County and West Branch Conservation Associations. She is survived by her brother, Prof. Robert Shaw Oliver Harding, her five children, Hilary Pulitzer, Dr. Charles H. King, Rufus C. King, Esq., Emily King and Dr. Mary Letwin, and grandchildren Lily, Michael, Jessie, Chloe, Maddie, Maria, Nick, Alex, Noah, Gus and Charles. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made in her name to the West Branch Conservation Association, Inc., 100 South Mountain Road, New City, NY 10956.

EAST HADDAM VILLAGE ''MAME'' opens the 2012 season at Goodspeed Musicals' riverfront stage here in April, and as casting begins, the theater has a little something extra to offer top-level talent: housing in a new ''artists' village.''

KOLL--Donald Milton, 78, of Newport Beach and Beverly Hills, California, passed away peacefully with his wife and family at his bedside on December 6, 2011. Don lived inspirationally for the last six years after suffering physical limitations from a stroke. Don was born in Santa Monica, California, to Milton and Edna Koll. He attended Harvard School in Los Angeles and became an Eagle Scout. In 2010, Don was awarded distinguished Eagle Scout buy the Boy Scouts of America. After earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in economics from Stanford University in 1955, Don joined the Air Force as a fighter pilot. Don started his real estate career building custom homes in Newport Beach and, in 1962, he founded The Koll Company. The Koll Company quickly grew into one of the leading real estate companies in southern California and has been responsible for the development of over 90 million square feet office, industrial and retail space in the last 50 years. He brought Jack Nicklaus championship golf courses to Los Cabos, Mexico, at his Palmilla and Cabo del Sol resort developments which was a major contribution to making Los Cabos a world class destination. He was an entrepreneur, a great family man and a mentor to literally dozens of people in commercial real estate throughout California and across the United States. He was Presidential appointee to the Board of Trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum and the American Red Cross, and has served on the boards of CB Richard Ellis, Wells Fargo Bank, the Irvine Company, and Fidelity National Title. Don was an avid supporter of the Boy Scouts of America, Stanford University and many local charities in Orange County and Los Cabos, Mexico. Don has always enjoyed traveling the world, especially to St. Tropez and Los Cabos. He is survived by his wife Kathi, his six children and their spouses, three step-children and their spouses, 21 grandchildren, and his brother Ed. A service in his memory was held at Our Lady Queen of Angels in New Port Beach, California on Decemeber 14, 2011. In lieu of flowers, please donate to: UCLA Neuro-Critical Care Research Fund; Attn: Dr. Paul Vespa, 757 Westwood Blvd., Rm. #

Pupi Campo, a Cuban bandleader who brought rippling syncopation to Jack Paar's ''Morning Show'' on CBS television in the early 1950s and to his long career in nightclubs around the country, died on Dec. 12 at a hospice in Las Vegas. He was 91. His wife, Joette, confirmed the death.

As this magazine goes to press, the Names of the Dead has run 142 times in this newspaper this year, listing members of the U.S. military killed in the Iraq and Afghan wars. This appeared on May 17. Interviews were conducted by Bruce Wallace. AMARU AGUILAR (b. 1984)

THE diamond pattern on this hand-carved rock crystal and white gold Power ring ($14,000) may look like a snowflake, but it actually represents the sun. ''The energy of the sun is the most powerful force on earth,'' said Visnja Brdar, a jeweler based in New York. ''I wanted to create a piece that reflected that energy. When I wear it, I radiate and feel that anything is possible.'' Known for graphic simplicity and fastidious pavé work, Ms. Brdar makes pieces with uplifting themes like Love, Courage, Freedom and Faith. She may as well have called this one Perseverance, since it took two years to make. ''I finally found a way for the crystal to appear as if it is floating on the finger,'' she said. ''It is perfect.'' At

Fifth Avenue and 57th Street is the epicenter of Christmas spirit in the city, the exuberance of the shoppers complemented by the shop windows. At Bergdorf Goodman's celebration of animals, photos 1, 2, 3 and 4, the details are mind-boggling. For the store's black-and-white window, 5, 6 and 7, everything except the mannequin is made from shredded paper. Across the street, Tiffany, 11, made an extraordinary effort, affixing carousel facades to its 15-foot-high windows. Viewers zoom in on miniature carousels, 12 and 13. Farther south, Lord & Taylor, 8, 9 and 10, moved its Victorian vignettes ahead 100 years, creating enchanting peeks at a midcentury Christmas. Way uptown at the New York Botanical Garden, the miniature trains in the holiday show pass buildings made of materials from the forest floor. This year, there's a new element, a step-by-step display of the creation of a replica of Kykuit, the Rockefeller home on the Hudson, 14, 15 and 16.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Behind the Scenes, Shaking Up the Fight Game,'' After Al Haymon, the boxing promoter-manager, started representing the promising fighters Lamon Brewster and Andre Berto, they lost their biggest bouts. Brewster was easily knocked out in his rematch with Wladimir Klitschko, and Berto lost badly to Victor Ortiz, a fight many thought should have been competitive.

MAHONEY--Margaret E.,a leader in American health care philanthropy, died on December 22, 2011, after a long illness. Mahoney was the first woman to head a major U.S. philanthropic foundation, becoming president of The Commonwealth Fund in New York City in 1980. Prior to her leadership of The Commonwealth Fund, she was a senior executive of The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and of the Carnegie Corporation. She played a key role in the transition of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation from a family foundation to one of the largest U.S. foundations in the 1970s, and revitalized The Commonwealth Fund, which was founded in 1918 and today has assets of $680 million. In a career spanning more than four decades, Mahoney helped redefine and reenergize American health care philanthropy. Under her leadership, The Commonwealth Fund became a significant force for improving the delivery of health care, addressing the health care and developmental needs of vulnerable populations, and strengthening key health care institutions. Upon her retirement from The Commonwealth Fund in 1995, Mahoney worked with the Fund and others to create Healthy Steps for Young Children, a national initiative to encourage pediatricians to focus on developmental issues in the first three years of a child's life. Some 50 Healthy Steps practices are in operation around the country, and serve as models for integrating health care and social services needed by vulnerable children. A leader of American philanthropy from the late 1960s into the 1990s, Mahoney was noted as a talent spotter and for her willingness to take risks with promising, but yet unproven, health care professionals and researchers. A native of Nashville, Tennessee and a graduate of Vanderbilt University, Mahoney served as a Foreign Affairs Officer for the U.S. Department of State from 1946 to 1953 before entering the foundation field. She received honorary degrees from many colleges and universities including Smith College, Williams College, Brandeis University and the Medical College of Pennsylvania. She served on numerous non-profit boards including the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, Columbia University, the Alliance for Aging Research, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, the Dole Foundation, the New York Academy of Medicine, and the Dartmouth Medical School/Koop Institute Board of Overseers. She was a member of the National Academy of Science's Institute of Medicine, which she helped create in the 1970s.

Good sentences, the ebullient critic and novelist Wilfrid Sheed wrote in 1990, are sent into the air like a series of jazz licks. ''You noodle around with tempo and sound until you get the perfect fit for that particular song, and then, so long as you can sustain it, God is on your side and everything comes easily and even the waiters smile.'' Sheed made the waiters, and everyone else, smile on a regular basis throughout his five-decade career. He wrote some 20 books, from comic novels to an illness memoir, but his essays are where his solos still soar. His four collections -- ''The Morning After'' (1971), ''The Good Word and Other Words'' (1978), ''Essays in Disguise'' (1990) and ''Baseball and Lesser Sports'' (1991) -- deliver an electrical charge: they're learned, fearsome, timeless and funny. All four can be had for pennies on used-book Web sites; together they are the literary bargain of 2012.

Not long before his 80th birthday in 1999 the choreographer Merce Cunningham went back to his hometown, Centralia, Wash., and spent some time with his brother Jack, a lawyer. After they talked about old acquaintances, Jack suddenly asked, ''Merce, when are you going to make something the public likes?'' Cunningham told that story deadpan, which was like him. But when he did so a month later at Zellerbach Hall in Berkeley, Calif., no further comment was needed. Minutes before, he and his dancers had received a huge ovation for the world premiere of his ''Biped.'' This was to be the most sensational, abundant and internationally acclaimed work of his old age, a cornucopia that kept suggesting images of death and transcendence, with choreography partly devised on a computer and with décor that used dazzling computer-generated imagery that he had choreographed. For the remaining 10 years of his life he was routinely (and rightly) hailed as the world's greatest living choreographer.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week's image. Four hundred fifty million years ago, seismic forces transformed shale from the ocean floor into the schist that makes up most of Manhattan today. The geologic results are easily seen in the leafless forest. From the high vantage point of our site, we can survey the rise and fall of the island's topography. Hanging over the Hudson River is the park's western ridge, dotted with distant tree trunks.

The finances of major professional sports teams exist largely as the secrets of privately held companies, except for the community-owned Green Bay Packers, who report their profits without a hint of resistance. But elements of the Mets' finances have emerged publicly in the last year that show fans and potential investors how unprofitable the Mets are and also how deeply in debt the operation is.

BOSPHORUS brings new flavors to the county with a compendium of dishes reflecting cooking traditions from far-ranging regions that were once part of the vast Ottoman Empire. Today, this wonderfully diverse cuisine is the product of Turkey's proximity to numerous bodies of water and its gentle climate, which accounts for several growing seasons a year. A Turkish friend once remarked that in terms of agriculture, Turkey is completely self-sufficient; it produces everything except pineapples.

This is another love story, another spouse remembering a departed spouse, exactly like the couple on the motorcycle except no bike, no heroin, no H.I.V. and it takes place in Eau Claire, Wis. Mary Coy writes about her mother (b. 1932): After my dad died on Aug. 30, 2001, my mother made sure we marked each anniversary. At first, my brothers and sister and I would travel hours to get home, but eventually we got to the point where just one or two of us would make it back to go to Mass with her and spend the day together.

To the Editor: Regarding ''My Life in Hotels'' (Dec. 4), add one more tip to your excellent piece. This from a friend and hotel executive: hotel blankets are not cleaned with each change of sheets. Strip the bedspread, stow it, call housekeeping and request an additional sheet to ''top sheet'' your bed. A little gratuity to the housekeeper usually ensures that your bed will be freshly top-sheeted when the room is serviced. Barbara Eustace Miller

To the Editor: Re ''When Science Leaps From the Page'' (Novelties, Dec. 18), which looked at new electronic textbooks:

Some of Chicago's most vulnerable citizens -- those who depend on public financing for mental health services -- face a new year that may bring less of something they deeply need: help. Their plightfocuses on Mayor Rahm Emanuel's recent budget, which would close 6 of the city's 12 mental health centers serving poor and uninsured Chicagoans to save $3 million.

BEDERMAN--David Jeremy. July 26, 1961 - December 4, 2011. David J. Bederman, K. H. Gyr Professor in Private International Law at Emory University School of Law, died on December 4, 2011, in Atlanta, Georgia. The cause of death was complications from appendiceal cancer. He was 50. David was a scholar, author, legal historian, beloved teacher, litigator and Supreme Court advocate. He was a renowned expert in such widely differing areas as legal history, constitutional law, admiralty, and international law. David was also Chairman of the Board of Odyssey Marine Exploration, Inc. "In the law, David was a giant, a person seen once in a generation," Professor David D. Caron, President of the American Society of International Law, said on the ASIL website. David J. Bederman is survived by his wife, Lorre B. Cuzze; his beloved daughter, Annelise G. Bederman; and his parents, Dr. Sanford and Jolayne Bederman. In lieu of flowers, donations in honor of Professor Bederman may be made to: the Patients' Assistance Fund at the Winship Cancer Institute at Emory University, or the laboratory of Dr. H. Richard Alexander, Jr., at the University of Maryland.

Pupi Campo, a Cuban bandleader who brought rippling syncopation to Jack Paar's ''Morning Show'' on CBS television in the early 1950s and to his long career in nightclubs around the country, died on Dec. 12 at a hospice in Las Vegas. He was 91. His wife, Joette, confirmed the death.

''WE ARE THE 99 PERCENT.'' It was so much beyond a local slogan: the louder it was spoken, the more it began to say. My job, my streets, my economy, my riot, my skin. Cities shook their souls out. The yearning went global. Some protesters poured gasoline into bottles and lit the sky with fire. Others unfurled hammocks under light poles. The idea was to be seen, to be heard, to be tweeted. The year 2011 was an evanescent spectacle of anger. Every corner was a world, and every world had its corners. The bankers stood back, the corporations hushed a moment, the politicians held their breath, and the cops took out their pepper spray. It might have begun in Wisconsin, had its adolescence in Greece, and shattered the night in London, but it lost and won its innocence in Zuccotti Park. Suddenly, a tent had as much meaning as a tower. Kids from all over the country boiled collard greens in the courtyard of commerce. The city's bureaucrats tried frantically to barricade them in, or out -- nobody seemed sure which. The anger rolled all the way down to Wall Street and the markets shivered a moment. When cold weather kicked in, the tents began to disappear and the anger diffused, but the images remained, another sort of fire in flight.

Michael Wood's first three books about literature concerned a Frenchman (Stendhal), a Latin American (García Márquez) and a Russian emigrant to America (Nabokov). If this sounds like the start of a bar joke, it also confirms Wood's commitment to cultural diversity -- as does the fact that between Stendhal and García Márquez, he also found time for a book about film, ''America in the Movies.'' In a recent e-mail, Wood recalled that when Wilfrid Sheed reviewed that book in 1976, he ''said I had a grasshopper mind. It wasn't a compliment but it's not untrue, and one can make some sort of virtue even out of bad habits.'' In Wood's case, the virtue he has made of his restless imagination has been a career as an English professor spanning more than 40 years, including 16 so far in his current position at Princeton, and a sideline as a prolific reviewer of books and movies. ''I have favorite authors and directors -- Proust, Calvino, Kafka, Emily Brontë, Hitchcock, Orson Welles, Buñuel,'' he said, ''but among different literatures and media I tend to go by mood. If I feel like reading something inextricable I go to Mann or Musil, and if something quick and ironic to almost any French novel (even Proust is quick in his way). . . . What makes my imagination work, I guess, is always a question rather than an achievement. I like to say 'What?' rather than 'Ah, how lovely.' Have I got tired of topics? Not really, but then I keep moving among them, don't give them much of a chance to tire me.''

Keeping with the hectic theme of a shortened N.B.A. season, teams had just 16 days to sign free agents after the lockout officially ended. That did not stop the league from having a healthy amount of turnover. Nine of these 10 teams made major attempts, either through quality or quantity, to reshape their rosters using free agency and trades while also getting their draft picks up to speed. The Nets, meanwhile, have yet to make a splashy move, something that would seem necessary if the team hopes to retain the star guard Deron Williams. CHART KEY; Player Efficiency Rating (PER), developed by the statistician John Hollinger, attempts to reward a wide range of a player's positive contributions to the team and penalize him for negative play. The league average is set at 15.0.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- The Giants were disgusted to arrive at MetLife Stadium on Saturday morning and see the four Super Bowl logos outside their locker room concealed by black curtains. When their kicker, Lawrence Tynes, pulled back the curtains, someone with the Jets came by to yank them over again. The Giants' anger endured late into the afternoon, when Brandon Jacobs got into a postgame verbal altercation with Rex Ryan, the Jets' coach. Jacobs said Ryan told him to shut up and that he responded by saying he would punch Ryan in the mouth.

It was a plan conceived over a breakfast of bread and butter. Bernardo Bertolucci, the director of ''Last Tango in Paris,'' liked it, the assistant director liked it and so did the film's star, Marlon Brando. They left it to Brando to break the news to his young co-star, Maria Schneider. At the time, Schneider was 19, a runaway and a stoner with the bravado of a young woman who had been living on her own, modeling and acting, since she was 15. Brando was playing a grieving widower seeking solace in sex with a young woman whose name he didn't know. Schneider played that woman, Jeanne, in a role that called for extensive nudity and explicit scenes with Brando, a middle-aged man coming off a decadelong downhill slide. If Schneider had reservations about the part, she was too young to say so, and she had no one to say it for her. She had fled her mother, and barely knew her father, a well-regarded French actor named Daniel Gélin -- an old friend, it turned out, of Brando's.

An article on Dec. 11 about the heavy-metal band Korn and its incorporating dubstep, a kind of electronic dance music, into its sound misspelled the surname of the band's guitarist who is known as Munky. He is James Shaffer, not Schaffer.

AT&T's decision to drop its bid for T-Mobile is a victory for the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission, which steadfastly opposed a deal that would have locked the wireless market into a duopoly and been bad for consumers. But the battle to defend competition in telecommunications is hardly over. As regulators moved to block the AT&T deal, Verizon Wireless was buying big chunks of spectrum from the nation's largest cable carriers and signing agreements with them to sell each other's services to consumers around the country.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- After a week of breathless banter and rehashed rhetoric, the back and forth between the Giants and the Jets -- which by Friday seemed to border on the nonsensical -- ultimately reached a nasty conclusion. Jets Coach Rex Ryan and Giants running back Brandon Jacobs were involved in a verbal altercation after the Giants' 29-14 victory on Saturday. Neither man has been shy about speaking out, and the two exchanged harsh words as the teams shook hands.

My first reality-TV death -- the first that stung -- was Frankie, from ''The Real World.'' Some of you may remember the sister. Punk-goth from Wisconsin. Twenty-two, but seemed much younger: defensive and chirpy, suddenly happy or sleepy. Hair a deep chemical russet. She was a cutter, too; she cut herself with a kitchen knife. Her mother later identified this as her legacy, that she brought attention to cutting. Also, she was pathologically fearful of ships. If one came into sight (it was San Diego; they lived on water), her cast mates knew to throw a jacket over her head, to stop her seizing up. But Frankie's true identifying oddity on the show was that she had bad cystic fibrosis in her lungs. And would talk about how it was going to kill her soon, while chain-smoking clove cigarettes. She was a girl whose rage to live could vent itself only through the death wish. She was captivating in a way you somehow resented. When she died, I felt nothing but then thought about her for a long time. Reality TV is aging, and we who grew up with it and in some way grew up poisoned by it are aging, so it's unsurprising that reality-TV stars are dying. Still, 2011 marked some kind of crossing. Last year opened the door with perhaps the first real on-screen reality death scene, that of Capt. Phil Harris, hard-living skipper of a crab-fishing boat on ''The Deadliest Catch.'' He was felled by a stroke in his cabin, and died in the hospital days later, all of it captured, much of it shown, edited to a Shakespearean pitch. His two sons, who each worked on the ship, who worshiped and feared their father -- we saw their faces. The footage startles even in an age when the antics of people on these shows have at last become truly Roman.
Dance Jack Anderson

SOLOF--Henrietta, 99, dearest sister and aunt. You will be missed by all. Love, Winikoff Family.

A television column last Sunday about the best shows of the year -- including the ABC series ''Revenge'' -- misstated the given name of the character played by Joan Collins on the old ''Dynasty'' TV series, which ''Revenge'' was compared to because of its campy melodrama. The character was Alexis Carrington, not Alex.
