THE BREATH AND HUM of democracy seemed almost a libidinous thing in parts of the Middle East, but, in truth, the body heat had been simmering for years. The protests took hold in Tunisia in late 2010 after the street vendor Mohamed Bouazizi set himself on fire. The kindle caught and the spirit of his self-immolation lit a fuse across the region. A wave of protests struck Algeria, Egypt, Yemen, Jordan. Almost as soon as protesters in Cairo were being herded away from Tahrir Square, they were dancing at the news of Mubarak's resignation. Ruling families began to fall. Power-transfer treaties were brokered. Parliaments were dissolved. Monarchs locked their gates and boarded their windows. In Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was ousted and killed. NATO planes streaked a sky so blue it seemed it to speak of other Septembers. Faces, too, were lit by a new blue light. It was the era of the revolution down through the wires: time was collapsed and geography shrunk by the use of social networking. The whole world was indeed watching, listening, e-mailing. Some in the media lost their lives for the art of the images that emerged -- the photographs didn't just capture singular moments, but they looked backward and forward at the same time, at what has happened, and what is yet to come. The light from the Arab Spring rose from the ground up; the hope is now that the darkness doesn't fall.

Eric Lindquist has worked as a therapist at Beverly-Morgan Park Center long enough to know how hard its closing will hit the people who depend on it for help. ''Closing the clinics makes life immensely more complicated for people whose lives are already on the edge,'' he said.

In most American counties, some indigent criminal defendants are represented by a public defender, and others by a private court-appointed lawyer. A new RAND study focusing on Philadelphia exposes a vast difference in how clients fare depending on the kind of lawyer they are assigned. The startling findings show that merely providing an indigent defendant a lawyer, as the Constitution requires in felony cases, is not enough to secure justice. If that lawyer is not screened for quality, trained to handle the client's type of case or paid enough to cover the time required, the client is unlikely to get fair treatment -- whether in the Philadelphia system or anywhere else.

Maybe it seems this way every year, but 2011 felt marked by more than its fair allotment of iconic deaths. Steve Jobs, Betty Ford, Elizabeth Taylor, Geraldine Ferraro and Christopher Hitchens, as well as Osama bin Laden and Muammar el-Qaddafi. You will not read about them in these pages. The Lives They Lived is not a greatest-hits issue. Instead, we gravitated to those lives with an untold tale. For storytelling expertise, we enlisted Ira Glass and his team from ''This American Life'' to edit a special section devoted to ordinary people (it starts on Page 33). And through social media, we put out a request to readers for pictures of loved ones. A sample of the hundreds of submissions is on the last page, beautiful evidence that every life is a story worth remembering.

MIAMI -- To live in South Florida is to make peace with flying cockroach behemoths, brigades of lizards that dart across walls (bedroom and otherwise) and frogs the size of cannonballs that loiter on driveways. But even in a state as hospitable as this one to scaly, slithering creatures, enough is enough. Florida has the highest number of nonnative amphibians and reptile species, according to a recent University of Florida study, and some of them are obliterating native Floridian creatures.

While the news, and its makers, might dwell on what we've lost, we occasionally still witness the most remarkable music: marriages, journeys, longings, births and returns. Every now and then, the ground just won't show its shadows.

FORMAN--Rena Bass. On November 27, 2011, we lost Rena Bass Forman: a lover of nature, a passionate artist, but above all a devoted daughter, wife, and mother. Rena, 57, died from complications of a malignant brain tumor. Born on March 17, 1954, she was the only child of Anne Loewy Bass, a holocaust survivor, and Milton Bass, a garment business owner in Manhattan. She grew up in New York City, studying ballet with George Balanchine. Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis ended her career as a dancer, but her love of the arts endured. She attended Hofstra University and Rutgers University, earning a Master's degree in Arts in Education. In 1978, Rena married Scott Forman. They moved to Massachusetts in 1981 where she worked at the DeCordova Museum for two years. She began to photograph landscapes in 1978. Several of her hand-painted photographs were published in various treatises on the topic. She began shooting medium format black and white, gelatin silver, sepia-toned photographs in the late 1980's. She has been represented by the Bonni Benrubi Gallery and the Winston Wachter Fine Art gallery since 1991. Rena traveled the globe in search of inspiring landscapes. Her bodies of work include images from locales as diverse as the American Southwest, Turkey, Indonesia and Chilean Patagonia to Atlantic Canada, Iceland, Greenland and the Norwegian Archipelago of Svalbard. Her work has been shown and collected widely throughout the United States and Europe. It is imbued with the timeless atmosphere of diverse and endangered landscapes. She is survived by her dearest husband, Scott Forman, MD of Piermont, New York, two devoted daughters, Zaria of Brooklyn, Leila, of Cambridge, Massachusetts, and her loving father, Milton Bass of Tamarac, Florida. Please send donations to Wings Trust, Greenland Expedition, P.O. Box 52, Palisades, New York 10964.

WITH his round face, button nose and pointy orange tuft of hair, the character Tintin looks familiar, even to those who may think they haven't seen him before. Long beloved in Europe, he is making his American big-screen debut in the 3-D animated film ''The Adventures of Tintin,'' which opened on Wednesday in the United States, two months after its debut overseas. The character sprung from the mind and pen of the Belgian illustrator Hergé in 1928 while he was working at a daily newspaper. Tintin, a boy journalist with an enterprising spirit and a trusty dog named Snowy, became the star of a series of ''Adventures of Tintin'' comic books that Hergé illustrated until his death in 1983. The character seemed an ideal match for the director Steven Spielberg, who said he saw much of himself in Tintin and sought to adapt his adventures into a feature film.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - The artist Winslow Homer was a 19th-century American landscape and maritime painter who began his career as a magazine illustrator and lithographer. Eventually, his interests expanded to both oil and watercolor painting, and his success was so great that he was able to give up his illustration career and paint full time. His most famous works captured the lives of the men and women who worked near the seaside, as well as children at play.

"The London Merchant," a tragedy from 1731 that was one of the first British dramas to focus on the middle and working classes - and that has apparently never received a professional production in North America - will be performed Jan. 6-28 at the Theater at the Church of Notre Dame in Morningside Heights in Upper Manhattan. Written by George Lillo, "The London Merchant" is about the downfall of a young apprentice who is led astray by a prostitute. It was highly popular in the 18th century. The Storm Theater Company and Blackfriars Repertory Theater will jointly produce the work, directed by Peter Dobbins, Storm's artistic director. A spokesman for the production, Pete Sanders, said on Monday that the producers had done research on the history of the play and could not find evidence that it had been performed professionally in the United States or Canada.

It was an extraordinary day for me. To understand why, it may be useful to explain a bit about my research. Using advanced closed-circuit mixed-gas rebreather technology, my colleagues and I have spent the past two decades traveling the tropical Pacific Ocean to to document life that occurs below the realm of scuba divers. The environment that I focus on -- tropical reef habitats at depths of about 200 to 500 feet -- has variously been referred to as deep coral reefs, mesophotic coral ecosystems and the coral-reef "Twilight Zone."

Anticipating a flood of library patrons who received e-readers as holiday gifts, the New York Public Library will offer a free service for instructing users how to download e-books, library officials said. Free e-books are available for members of the New York Public Library and can be downloaded remotely without a visit to the library. Patrons can visit nypl.org/ebookcentral for instructions on downloading e-books and other digital materials, including video and music. The library will also offer in-person assistance from Jan. 4 to Jan. 13 at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building and the Mid-Manhattan Library at 455 Fifth Avenue. Nearly 22,000 e-books are available at the New York Public Library, a number that has been growing rapidly along with the widespread adoption of e-readers.

EDINBURGH -- James Holloway, the director of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, says there aren't many national portrait galleries in the world. ''Only six or seven, and it is their job to be very local,'' said Mr. Holloway, dapper in a three-piece tweed suit as he showed a visitor around the museum. It was a few days before the much-awaited reopening of the portrait gallery on Dec. 1 after a £17.6 million, or $27.5 million, renovation that has, among other things, given the institution 60 percent more space to display its huge collection -- 3,000 paintings and sculptures, 25,000 prints and drawings, 38,000 photographs -- a good part of which has been languishing in storage for decades.

The 10-year-old war in Afghanistan remained just a blip on the American news media's radar in 2011. Of all the news content in newspapers and on the Web, television and radio this year, Afghanistan accounted for about 2 percent of coverage, according to the Project for Excellence in Journalism, an arm of the Pew Research Center.

Violet, the red-tailed hawk who has been suffering from a crippling leg injury, was captured for treatment on Saturday in Washington Square Park. According to the blogger Roger--Paw, who posted a detailed account of it, the Long Island-based raptor rehabilitators Robert and Cathy Horvath of the nonprofit Wildlife in Need of Rescue and Rehabilitation, netted her on the ground after she had flown down from a tree branch to retrieve her prey.

The screaming. That was the sound of what might have been the American sports moment of 2011. A husband, a wife, two boys and two girls -- the rollicking screaming in our house on July 10 resounding and surely somehow reaching and linking with the roars in other homes across the country. We looked at the television and then at one another as the United States tied Brazil in the 122nd minute in the Women's World Cup in Dresden, Germany.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about an Australian study that found recent technology for artificial hips and knees did not perform any better than older designs misstated, in some editions, the nationality of researchers who, in a separate study, examined differences in the reported performance of such devices before their introduction and later in registry data. They were Austrian, not Australian.

The Federal Aviation Administration has its reasons for preventing passengers from reading from their Kindles and iPads during takeoff and landing. But they just don't add up. Since I wrote a column last month asking why these rules exist, I've spoken with the F.A.A., American Airlines, Boeing and several others trying to find answers. Each has given me a radically different rationale that contradicts the others. The F.A.A. admits that its reasons have nothing to do with the undivided attention of passengers or the fear of Kindles flying out of passengers' hands in case there is turbulence. That leaves us with the danger of electrical emissions.

An article on Wednesday about a plunge in the value of the rial, Iran's currency, to a historic low of 15,150 to the dollar, misstated its exchange rate against the dollar in late October and its decline in percentage terms since then. It cost about 12,500 rials to buy a dollar in late October, not 7,000, which means it has declined by about 20 percent in value against the dollar since then, not ''more than 50 percent.''

An obituary on Tuesday about Bob Brookmeyer, the valve trombonist, composer and arranger, misstated the year that the cornetist Thad Jones left the big band Mr. Jones and the drummer Mel Lewis led, after which Mr. Brookmeyer became its musical director. It was 1979, not 1978.

I.B.M. just issued its annual list of five predictions of developments in technology that it thinks will come true in the next five years. Like lots of predictive lists, particularly those that come around New Year's, this is something of a pseudo-event that serves as an advertisement for the predictor's own product or service. I.B.M.'s is no different in that regard, but it is worth looking at, both for the pedigree of who is doing the predicting, and what I.B.M.'s choices say about itself. ''To predict the next five years, you have to have a deep understanding of the last 50,'' said Bernie Meyerson, vice president of innovation at I.B.M., and a highly regarded researcher in advanced microprocessor design and computer systems who oversees the list's creation.

2:55 p.m. | Updated to reflect comment from the Consumer Electronics Association. The technology industry's premier trade show got a lump of coal in its stocking this year from one of its most faithful exhibitors, Microsoft, which said the 2012 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas would be its last.

When the arching path of the baseball barely eluded the awkward reach of Nelson Cruz's glove by 12 fateful inches, a new Game 6 was introduced to history. In one of the greatest games played on a diamond, the Texas Rangers were one strike from winning their first World Series, one swing-and-a-miss from ending a 51-year drought that (still) ranks third behind only the Chicago Cubs' and the Cleveland Indians' records of extended failure.

MAHONEY--Margaret E. The Board of Directors and staff at American Skin Association (ASA) mourn the passing of its longtime friend and Board member -- Margaret E. Mahoney. For nearly two decades, Margaret was an active member of our Board and her advice and leadership were invaluable. Margaret devoted her career to work with philanthropies on issues concerning health, education, arts and humanities. ASA was fortunate to have Margaret as a member of our Education Council for many years and under her leadership, ASA was able to launch its award-winning public school program The Wonders of Skin: Looking Good, Being Healthy. Margaret's efforts reached over 12 million children, teachers and parents. Her dedication, leadership, and advocacy for children's education will never be forgotten said Howard P. Milstein, Chairman of ASA's Board. Margaret was the first woman to head a major foundation, The Commonwealth Fund, a national philanthropic foundation in New York City, where she had a distinguished career. A native of Nashville, Tennessee, Margaret graduated magna cum laude from Vanderbilt University and holds many honorary degrees from the nation's most prestigious universities. Margaret truly made a difference. ASA extends our heartfelt sympathy to her family, friends and colleagues. We will miss her. Howard P. Milstein Chairman Barbara A. Gilchrest, MD Acting President & Vice Chair George W. Hambrick, Jr. MD Founder & President American Skin Association

The United States Chamber of Commerce has confirmed Chinese hackers last year broke into internal networks. The breach is, in some ways, a twist of fate for the Chamber. It has been one of the more vocal critics of cybersecurity legislation. In an internal draft document circulated earlier this year, the Chamber criticized the White House's legislative proposals on cybersecurity as ''regulatory overreach'' and cautioned that ''layering new regulations on critical infrastructure will harm public-private partnerships.''

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about the divergent careers of Eddy Curry and Tyson Chandler since they were Chicago Bulls teammates misidentified, in some editions, the team that drafted Chandler in 2001. Curry was drafted by the Bulls that year, but Chandler was selected by the Los Angeles Clippers and traded to the Bulls on draft day; he was not selected by the Bulls.

8 P.M. (Sundance) THE MORTIFIED SESSIONS In this series celebrities go through shoeboxes containing the most embarrassing artifacts of their awkward years: prom photos, diaries and love notes. This is the latest medium for Mortified, a project that began in the late '90s, in which celebrities' self-excoriation and poignant discoveries have taken forms like a stage show and a book written by David Nadelberg, ''Mortified: Real Words. Real People. Real Pathetic.'' The guests in this episode are Anthony Michael Hall (''The Breakfast Club,'' ''Sixteen Candles'') and Lea Thompson (''Back to the Future,'' above, with Mr. Nadelberg). They will explore some humiliating moments from their younger years, including the time Mikhail Baryshnikov called Ms. Thompson ''stocky.'' 8 A.M. (HBO2) CATCH ME IF YOU CAN (2002) This Steven Spielberg film tracks the exploits of Frank Abagnale Jr. (Leonardo DiCaprio, above), a con man who, by the time he was no more than 18, had persuaded people that he was a doctor, a lawyer and a pilot. He thinks he has struck gold when he discovers a way to forge paychecks and bilks Pan Am for millions. But the scam attracts the attention of an F.B.I. fraud investigator named Carl Hanratty (Tom Hanks). '' 'Catch Me' is the most charming of Mr. Spielberg's mature films, because is it so relaxed,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''Instead of trying to conjure fairy-tale magic, wring tears or insinuate a message, it is happy just to be its delicious, genially sophisticated self.

Few newsstands merit a cameo role in a major motion picture, but the octagonal structure with a gracefully tapering roof at Columbus Circle is such an echt newsstand that Woody Allen cast it in ''Bullets Over Broadway.'' ''It's like something from a Berenice Abbott photograph,'' said Adrian Benepe, the parks commissioner, whose agency oversees the newsstand since it sits at the southwest corner of Central Park. However, its days selling newspapers, magazines, lottery tickets, candy and soda have ended. It is now being transformed to serve as an office and shop for the Bike and Roll rental operation that's come to be a fixture in recent years at Columbus Circle.

Falcons (9-5) at Saints (11-3), 8:20 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: Saints by 6 Recent ''Monday Night Football'' intros have featured football legends reciting vaguely inspirational speeches pertaining to the home team's current fortunes: Barry Sanders spoke of Detroit pride, Joe Montana hailed the return to relevance of the 49ers and Jerry Jones praised himself for positioning himself ahead of dozens of worthy Cowboys luminaries in a quest for 60 more seconds of television exposure. This game will be introduced by Betty White, who briefly quarterbacked the Falcons in the 1970s under the pseudonym Kim McQuilken. Production stills show White in a cozy Christmas setting, perfect for Dec. 26. If the Falcons and the Saints meet again in the playoffs, the halftime show will be a reunion of ''Designing Women.''

Anticipating a flood of library patrons who received e-readers as holiday gifts, the New York Public Library will offer a free service that teaches users how to download e-books, library officials said. Free e-books are available for New York Public Library members and can be downloaded without a visit to the library. Patrons can find instructions on downloading e-books and other digital materials, including video and music, at nypl.org/ebookcentral. The library will also offer in-person help from Jan. 4 to 13 at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, and at the Mid-Manhattan Library, at 455 Fifth Avenue, at 40th Street. Nearly 22,000 e-books are available through the New York Public Library.

LINDGREN--Richard. Dick was a thinker, a talker, a reader and a singer. He adored the opera. He was from Jamestown, NY; his father was a Swedish immigrant and his mother was the daughter of a Lutheran minister. He and his identical twin Robert went to Yale, then Dick went to Harvard Business School and into the Navy. His first job, at White Weld, was the best one he ever had. He loved his wife, Anne; they were married for 49 years. He is survived by her, his children, Sarah, Hugo and Doug, and seven grandchildren. They all remember him as gentle, kind and funny. There will be a funeral at St Mary's Church, Shelter Island, NY, on Saturday, January 7, at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St Mary's.

YANOSIK--Joseph J.,77 years old, of Lloyd Harbor, NY, passed away on December 23, 2011 after a brave year-long battle with cancer. He died peacefully at his home surrounded by his loving family. Joe was born on September 30, 1934 in Yonkers, NY to Joseph Yanosik and Julia Fecisko. He met the love of his life, Marie LaGaccia, while they were both in their teens, and they married in 1958. Throughout school, Joe was a gifted athlete excelling in basketball and golf. Joe graduated from New York University in 1957 with a B.S. degree in Electrical Engineering Eta Kappa Nu and soon became Chief Engineer at Litton Industries. In 1966, he founded his own company, Betatronix Inc., which he built into the nation's leading manufacturer of custom precision potentiometers. Betatronix became a critical supplier to the aerospace and defense industries, and was the recipient of several supplier awards from Raytheon, Hughes and NASA. Joe was a brilliant design engineer responsible for several innovations and patents in his specialized field of potentiometers. End products ranging from Sikorsky helicopters to NASA's Mars Rover all featured his designs. He literally wrote the book on outer space potentiometers, contributing to Space Vehicle Mechanisms and Design, the industry textbook. He loved his work, and chose not to retire until well into his seventies. Mr. Yanosik was a quiet-spoken yet hard-working man full of inner strength and perseverance. When Betatronix was completely destroyed by a fire in the late 70s, he rebuilt it from scratch into a multi-million dollar company. After running Betatronix as President for 40 years, Mr. Yanosik retired in 2007 and spent his remaining years playing golf and spending time with his family. Joe was a longtime member of the Huntington Crescent Club and the Loxahatchee Club in Jupiter, Florida, and he won their club championships many times over the years. Up to his final days, Joe displayed the warmth and humor that defined his personality. A true gentleman, he will be remembered by all who knew him as a wonderful human being. He is survived by his wife Marie, his son Joseph, his daughter Marianne, his sister Lorraine Kostik and his beloved granddaughter Kelly. Visitation will be on Tuesday, December 27th, and Mass/Burial will be held at St. Patrick's in Huntington, NY on Wednesday, December 28th. Contact M.A. Connell Funeral Home at 631-427-1123.

COLLINS--Edward J.,83, died December 21, 2011. Born in Rochester, NY he attended Aquinas H.S., served in the Navy, later earned his BS from Yale University '50, and MBA from Wharton School of Business. Became Managing Partner with Arthur Andersen & Co. accounting firm heading the Frankfurt, Germany office and later Stamford, CT office until his retirement in 1987, served as City of Rye Councilman for six years and Deputy Mayor of Rye, NY, devoting his later life to unrelentless volunteer community work. Ed is survived by his wife Dorothy (Dottie) of 55 years and his children Edward, Ellen and Peter and four grandchildren. His intelligence, wisdom, compassion, generosity and humor will be missed by all. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home Rye, NY on Tuesday, December 27 from 2-4pm and 6-9pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection on Wednesday at 10am.

Discovery Channel has found success with shows like ''Dirty Jobs'' with Mike Rowe, above, and ''American Chopper,'' and the History Channel has had series like ''American Pickers'' and ''Pawn Stars'' consistently make the top 15 shows in weekly cable TV ratings (box, top right). SHELLY FREIERMAN

Forget about the 10. Officially speaking, 265 features are in contention for the best picture Oscar, as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced this month. One you may not have heard much about is ''The Way,'' a family drama written and directed by Emilio Estevez and starring his father, Martin Sheen. Inspired in part by a trip the Sheen patriarch took with Mr. Estevez's son, Taylor, it's the story of the pilgrimage a father (Mr. Sheen) makes along the pilgrim road to Santiago de Compastella in Spain, after having his life jolted by the death of a wayward son (Mr. Estevez, in a cameo part; astute moviegoers may also recognize Yorick van Wageningen, who plays a gregarious Dutchman, as the social worker who menaces Rooney Mara in ''The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo''). But ''The Way'' is an unusual, highly personal film -- see if you can count the number of Estevezes in the credits -- and it was promoted in an unusual manner, with a bus tour of college towns and midsize cities, where father and son did Q. and A.'s.

BEDERMAN--David Jeremy. July 26, 1961 - December 4, 2011. David J. Bederman, K. H. Gyr Professor in Private International Law at Emory University School of Law, died on December 4, 2011, in Atlanta, Georgia. The cause of death was complications from appendiceal cancer. He was 50. David was a scholar, author, legal historian, beloved teacher, litigator and Supreme Court advocate. He was a renowned expert in such widely differing areas as legal history, constitutional law, admiralty, and international law. David was also Chairman of the Board of Odyssey Marine Exploration, Inc. "In the law, David was a giant, a person seen once in a generation," Professor David D. Caron, President of the American Society of International Law, said on the ASIL website. David J. Bederman is survived by his wife, Lorre B. Cuzze; his beloved daughter, Annelise G. Bederman; and his parents, Dr. Sanford and Jolayne Bederman. In lieu of flowers, donations in honor of Professor Bederman may be made to: the Patients' Assistance Fund at the Winship Cancer Institute at Emory University, or the laboratory of Dr. H. Richard Alexander, Jr., at the University of Maryland.

PICKMAN--Morton "Mac", 98, died on December 22, 2011 peacefully at home with his beloved wife of 39 years, Gladys, by his side. He will be remembered for his generous spirit, sharp wit, and keen business acumen. Morton Pickman was born on December 5, 1913. He grew up in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn and obtained degrees from New York University School of Commerce and Brooklyn Law School. He fought in World War II as a member of the United States Army where he was awarded a Purple Heart for wounds received in action. From an early age, Mac worked with his father, Morris Pickman, developing and managing residential and commercial properties in Brooklyn and Queens Counties, New York. After the war, he re-joined his family's real estate business in Queens and assumed leadership after his father's death in 1960. Among the residential and commercial properties the Pickman organization developed are Forest Hills South (Forest Hills), Cunningham Heights (Hollis), Arrowbrook Gardens Apartments (Kew Gardens Hills), Briarwood Apartments (Briarwood), Lakeside Towers (Bayside), the Pickman Office Building (Forest Hills), and Franhill Shopping Center (Hollis), as well as other properties in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Today, Pickman Realty Corporation manages numerous commercial buildings and cooperative apartment units in Queens, owned by various family members. Mac's philanthropic endeavors were extensive. Among his charitable activities, he was a major supporter and served as a trustee of the Museum of Jewish Heritage A Living Memorial to the Holocaust in New York City, where he established the Keeping History Center in memory of his parents, Fannie and Morris Pickman, along with funding numerous other programs and projects of the museum, including the Pickman Museum Shop. He was recently honored by the American Committee of the Weizmann Institute of Science in New York City, Palm Beach, and Rehovot, Israel, where he served on the ACWIS Board of Directors, was a member of the President's Circle and a member of the Weizmann Institute International Board of Directors. Mac was an active supporter of the Anti-Defamation League and established and headed The Pickman Foundation, which contributes to a variety of charitable Jewish causes. In addition to his wife, Mac is survived by his son James, and his wife Elizabeth, and daughters Patricia Spears, and her husband Richard, and Teresa Pickman, and five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. His grandchildren are Joseph Pickman, Christopher Friedman (Jennifer), Elizabeth Winchester (Christopher), John Siris (Susan), and Scott Spears (Lisa). In addition, he is survived by his wife Gladys' children, who viewed him as a father: Ellen Danetz, and her husband Stephen, and Steven Willner, and their children Mark Danetz (Julie), Lisa Danetz (Craig Smith), Adam Willner, and Meredith Willner, who, in turn, have six children. He is also survived by his sister Esther Ellman, his former wife and mother of his children Charlotte Pickman Gertz, and by his extended family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, December 27 at 2pm, Temple Beth El, 333 SW 4th St., Boca Raton, Florida. A Memorial Service will also be held at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York City on January 26, 2012. Memorial contributions may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage, Edmond J. Safra Plaza, 36 Battery Place, New York, New York 10280 and The American Committee of the Weizmann Institute of Science, 633 Third Ave., New York, New York 10017.
MORVILLO--Robert G. A man of integrity and intense loyalty. We cherish our forty-five years of friendship and memories. Elly & Steve Hammerman

The political universe in the coming week begins and ends with the borders of Iowa, where the six contenders for the Republican nomination will race toward the Jan. 3 caucuses. Their dual mission: persuasion and organization to lay the groundwork for a strong showing. The candidates' effort to win over voters in the Hawkeye State continues in earnest, with several bus tours, new television ads, piles of direct mail and attempts to influence the scores of journalists who plan to descend on Iowa on Monday. With no more debates before the caucuses and the big endorsements already in the past, it's time for the candidates to set their sights on wooing the many still-undecided voters (and to let the ''super PACs'' take aim at their rivals with negative ads).

The candidates - in this case, nearly 100 photography books published this year - took over every inch of available counter space in the photo department, where they were carefully scrutinized by a group of opinionated voters, each of whom was given just 10 Post-it notes as ballots. Impassioned speeches were made. Votes were cast: a few books grew polychromatic bouquets of Post-its - each voter had his or her own individual color - while others sprouted single lonely Post-its. Votes were changed: worthy candidates, including the likes of Diana Vreeland and Gerhard Richter, were abandoned. Finally, after weeks, a group of winners emerged. Like all campaigns, it was brutal. Online retailers and low-cost set makers have also put pressure on profit margins.

Of course Novak Djokovic cared. How could he not? It was the semifinals of the United States Open, with an overflow crowd at Arthur Ashe Stadium anticipating an imminent resolution to an exhausting match, an elegant ending for that most elegant of champions, Roger Federer. All Federer needed to secure victory was one more point, and up by 5-3, 40-15 in the fifth set, he had not one but two chances with his wicked serve to get it. ''I don't know how it happened,'' Djokovic said at the postmatch news conference, and neither did anyone else.

DES MOINES -- Mitt Romney and his allies are making an assertive final push this week to increase his chances of a strong finish in the Iowa caucuses, the outcome of which could help determine the length of the Republican presidential nominating battle. Any questions about whether Mr. Romney is playing to win in Iowa will be dispelled in the closing days of campaigning here. He introduced a new TV commercial on Monday, promoting his economic vision and his family values -- a message that is fortified by a hard-hitting punch from a well-financed outside group attacking two of his rivals.

''The London Merchant,'' a tragedy from 1731 that was one of the first British dramas to focus on the middle and working classes - and that has apparently never received a professional production in North America - will be performed Jan. 6-28 at the Theater at the Church of Notre Dame in Morningside Heights in Upper Manhattan. Written by George Lillo, ''The London Merchant'' is about the downfall of a young apprentice who is led astray by a prostitute. It was highly popular in the 18th century. The Storm Theater Company and Blackfriars Repertory Theater will jointly produce the work, directed by Peter Dobbins, Storm's artistic director. A spokesman for the production, Pete Sanders, said on Monday that the producers had done research on the history of the play and could not find evidence that it had been performed professionally in the United States or Canada. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CHAVKIN--Esta Joy (nee Greenberg) of New York, 88, passed away peacefully on December 24, 2011 surrounded by her family after a courageous battle with cancer. FESSLER--Geri Ilene. Founder of the Heather on Earth Music Foundation. Born in Brooklyn, NY on March 13, 1961 and a lifelong resident of Merrick, NY, our beautiful Geri passed away on December 21, 2011. Loving daughter to Myrna Rosenbaum and the late Stephen Rosenbaum, adoring sister to Dr. Mara Greenwald, beloved wife to Eric Fessler, devoted mother to Heather, Gillian, Shaina, and Taryn, and friend to thousands whose life she touched. Our warrior Geri founded the Heather on Earth Music Foundation to honor the memory of her daughter Heather Samone, who passed away on September 28, 1985. The foundation's purpose mirrored Geri's endlessly positive outlook on life, which she lived by the words Smile, Live, Love, Laugh, and her lifelong love of music. The nonprofit organization is the first of its kind created solely to provide funding for the implementation and subsequent ongoing support of music therapy programs in children's hospitals from New York to Tel Aviv. Geri was a remarkable woman who made it her life's work to deliver the magic of music into children's hearts as they are healing. To honor Geri's memory, please lend your support by visiting www.heatheronearth.org.

SALTZMAN--Sandra Gabrilove. Sandra, aged 63, died December 24 after a difficult illness, peacefully in her home with her family at her side. Sandra attended The Fieldston School, Brown University and the New York University School of Law. She inspired generations of Assistant District Attorneys with her exacting and discerning approach to case prosecution. Subsequently, she was an instructor at the Lawyering Program at the NYU School of Law. Gourmand, refined traveler, Japanese art connoisseur, and a virtual polymath, Sandra enriched all with her keen perceptivity, enthusiasm, insight and unshakeable resilience. Beloved wife of the late Michael I. Saltzman, Esq., cherished daughter of Dr. J. Lester Gabrilove, Baumritter Professor of Medicine, Emeritus of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, adored sister of Dr. Janice L. Gabrilove, James F. Holland Professor of Medicine, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, devoted aunt to Mark and Matthew Dirzulaitis and Lauren Saltzman, sister-in-law to Michael Dirzulaitis and Alan (Joanna) Saltzman. The family will be receiving visitors on Tuesday at 6:00-8:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home and services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Avenue, on Wednesday at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Michael I. Saltzman Fund at the New York University School of Law.

Sorry, Tiny Tim, there's no getting around it: This week represents the beginning of one of the unhappiest seasons on Broadway, when struggling plays and musicals prepare to close once the tourists leave town. One show will finish on a high note - Hugh Jackman will conclude his limited run on Sunday with roughly $14 million in ticket sales in just 10 weeks - while others will end at a loss. The $6 million flop ''Bonnie & Clyde'' will close Friday without recouping any of its money and ''The Addams Family'' will exit on Saturday without earning back all of its $16.5 million capitalization. The Kim Cattrall-led production of ''Private Lives'' is also shutting down on Saturday, five weeks earlier than planned because of weak tickets sales. Then, closing in January (always a slow-selling month), are the 2009 Tony Award winner for best musical, ''Billy Elliot''; the revival of the Stephen Sondheim musical ''Follies''; and the new play ''The Mountaintop,'' starring Samuel L. Jackson and Angela Bassett. A Broadway concert starring Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin also closes the piano next month.

Sometimes it's good news when a study's hypothesis is not proved. That was the case, certainly, with a new study of older runners, in which researchers assumed that athletes over 60 would be noticeably less efficient than their younger counterparts. For the experiment, published in The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research, researchers at the University of New Hampshire and other institutions recruited 51 competitive runners, ranging in age from 18 to 77. Each trained regularly and had placed in the top three in his or her age group in a local 5-kilometer or 10-kilometer road race. Their goal was to assess running economy, a measure of how much oxygen someone uses to run at a certain pace. Economical runners can continue at a given speed longer than inefficient striders, outdistancing them.

WASHINGTON -- When Representative Ed Pastor was first elected to Congress two decades ago, he was comfortably ensconced in the middle class. Mr. Pastor, a Democrat from Arizona, held $100,000 or so in savings accounts in the mid-1990s and had a retirement pension, but like many Americans, he also owed the banks nearly as much in loans. Today, Mr. Pastor, a miner's son and a former high school teacher, is a member of a not-so-exclusive club: Capitol Hill millionaires. That group has grown in recent years to include nearly half of all members of Congress -- 250 in all -- and the wealth gap between lawmakers and their constituents appears to be growing quickly, even as Congress debates unemployment benefits, possible cuts in food stamps and a ''millionaire's tax.''

A private memorial service will be held and donations can be made in his memory to SaveVenice.org.

6:03 p.m. | Updated Continuing to smart from its failure to get on the primary ballot in Virginia, Newt Gingrich's campaign said it would explore ways to persuade the Republican Party of Virginia to bend its rules and allow Mr. Gingrich and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who also failed to qualify, to join the only two names now on the ballot: Mitt Romney and Ron Paul. ''It does call into question whether or not there are some flaws in the system,'' said R. C. Hammond, a spokesman for Mr. Gingrich. He said he hoped that either Mr. Gingrich would appear on the March 6 primary ballot or that there would be a provision to write in his name.

We lost Peter Gent this fall. He was a decent wide receiver, but he was one heck of a storyteller. For my money, he is the father of jock lit. His book ''North Dallas Forty'' may have been the first adult novel I read. It was the tale of the fictional North Dallas Bulls, and it read an awful lot like the late 1960s Dallas Cowboys team that Gent had played and given his body for.

SUTTON--Albert, M.D. A loving and wonderful husband, father, grandfather, brother and friend, passed away on December 24. He was an exceptionally skilled and caring urologist who was on the staff at North Shore Hospital and Long Island Jewish Medical Center, serving as Chief of Urology from 1977-1981. He was a longtime member of the faculty of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine where he had a profound and lasting influence upon a generation of younger urologists. In 1989 he was elected president of the New York Section of the American Urological Association. To honor his years of service, the Albert Sutton Visiting Professorship in Urological Surgery was created in 2001. He is survived by his wife Beverly, children Ira, Jodi, and Elizabeth, and seven grandchildren.

BEDERMAN--David Jeremy. July 26, 1961 - December 4, 2011. David J. Bederman, K. H. Gyr Professor in Private International Law at Emory University School of Law, died on December 4, 2011, in Atlanta, Georgia. The cause of death was complications from appendiceal cancer. He was 50. David was a scholar, author, legal historian, beloved teacher, litigator and Supreme Court advocate. He was a renowned expert in such widely differing areas as legal history, constitutional law, admiralty, and international law. David was also Chairman of the Board of Odyssey Marine Exploration, Inc. "In the law, David was a giant, a person seen once in a generation," Professor David D. Caron, President of the American Society of International Law, said on the ASIL website. David J. Bederman is survived by his wife, Lorre B. Cuzze; his beloved daughter, Annelise G. Bederman; and his parents, Dr. Sanford and Jolayne Bederman. In lieu of flowers, donations in honor of Professor Bederman may be made to: the Patients' Assistance Fund at the Winship Cancer Institute at Emory University, or the laboratory of Dr. H. Richard Alexander, Jr., at the University of Maryland.

Television programming has its own holiday traditions, and they were reflected in the Nielsen ratings over the weekend. An encore telecast on NBC of ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' the 65-year-old Christmas stalwart, was the No. 1 program in all ratings categories on Saturday, with 4.6 million total viewers. It was the most-watched film on any of the broadcast networks since April. On Sunday, the National Basketball Association began its season just in time to continue its annual Christmas schedule with a slate of highly anticipated games. According to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates, the late afternoon matchup between the Chicago Bulls and the Los Angeles Lakers was the third-highest-rated regular-season game since ABC started showing N.B.A. games in 2002. (The Bulls came back in the final seconds to win, 88-87.)

(Starz) HOW DO YOU KNOW (2010) Reese Witherspoon taps into her intimidating side to play Lisa, a 31-year-old softball star whose world-class aspirations have been dealt a huge blow. Owen Wilson is Matty, the professional pitcher whose spell she falls under and who thinks he may be ready to give commitment a try. Then George (Paul Rudd) enters Lisa's life, first as a dud of a blind date, then as a friend whose father-cum-boss, Charles (Jack Nicholson), isn't all that unhappy about letting his son take the fall for his own financial misdeeds. Now Lisa needs to decide. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that this romantic comedy from James L. Brooks was ''so wan and disconnected to anything that feels like real life or, just as good, a screwball interpretation of it that it's hard to know what Mr. Brooks was really after, other than passing the time with some talented movie people.''

FELDSTEIN--Sidney, 90, passed away on December 10, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Martha, loving father of Wally and Haila, son-in-law David and daughter-in-law Marilyn, grandchildren Ilysa, Daniel, and Chunmui, and three great-grandchildren. Sidney was caring and generous. He had a zest for life. He had flair and wit, and a lifelong passion for jazz. He delighted in the happiness of family and friends, and made new friends to the very end. We miss him and will forever love him madly.
THE FACTS The singer Amy Winehouse was 27 when she died in July after drinking too much alcohol - a fact that earned her an unfortunate membership in what some have called the Forever 27 Club.

The approach of a new year brings reflections on the old. For writers about culture, this is a fancy way of saying it's time to compile a list of the finest achievements of the year in the field you cover, preferably keeping the number to an easily digestible 10. Accordingly my colleague Ben Brantley and I have assembled our lists. I generally prefer to keep my choices in alphabetical order. These lists are ornery things to put together in the first place, and somehow deciding which show is worthy of crowning the list feels artificial and often impossible. To begin with, comparing, say, a new musical with a Shakespeare revival, and then ranking one above the other, is an absurdity. Also I always feel that being No. 10 on someone's ranked-in-order top 10 list must give little more joy than being left off entirely.

WEBER--Elita Dee Blackton. After Music and Art HS, Dee was in the first graduating class of F.I.T. and was a professor there for 36 years. Her remarkable wit and creativity lives on. We'll all miss her so.

Aristotle believed circular motion to be a distinguishing characteristic of perfection. If you have ever seen a world-class runner cruise around a track, you may well agree that a body curving in motion is a sight of beauty. On a snowy day in late October, Luis Galvan was not particularly quick or light as he trudged around the otherwise deserted track at McCarren Park in the Williamsburg and Greenpoint area of Brooklyn. He was hunched forward against the wind, a red-and-blue umbrella protecting him from the onslaught of snow. More like a clumsily falling moon rock than a planet harmoniously orbiting the sun, Galvan did not seem concerned with beauty, but commitment.

GRUMBACH--Aileen, October 17, 1926 December 24, 2011, of Roslyn, NY, after a brief illness. Devoted wife of Leonard and mother of Lillian Nayder (Matt Johnson), Diane Selinger (Neil), and Carol Grumbach (Michael Cohen). Inspirational grandmother of Nate, George, William and Sam. Proud graduate of Hutchins College, Univeristy of Chicago. Outstanding poet with work in The Paris Review and elsewhere. Greatly respected English professor at Nassau Community College. She will be sorely missed for her love of ideas, humor, irreverence, and generosity.

Dharavi may no longer be Asia’s — or even Mumbai’s — biggest slum, but it is still its most iconic. By some estimates, the slum is home to one million people in an area about two-thirds of Manhattan’s Central Park. Land that once was on the outskirts of Mumbai has now been swallowed by the city and has been subject to multiple rehabilitation attempts since the 1970s.

Covering more than two decades, "Pretty Much Everything" (Taschen, $700) is the first comprehensive monograph of the celebrated Dutch photo team Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin. The three-volume set, which includes a silk-screen print, jumbles together over 600 photos: some began as advertisements, while others first appeared in gallery shows. If the resulting mix - glamorous celebrity portraits, androgynous fine art photos and mannerist fashion editorials - feels a bit schizophrenic, that's kind of the point. Van Lamsweerde said the book was constructed, in part, to show that the distinctions between these genres matter less and less (at least for in-demand photographers like her and her husband). "Sometimes our work that's been published as an advertising campaign ends up on the walls of a museum," she noted. A full interview with Van Lamsweerde is after the jump.

In The New York Times on Wednesday, Stephanie Clifford reports about the phenomenon of alcohol-induced online shopping. Reliable data is scarce, but one comparison-shopping site says that nearly half the people it surveyed in Britain had shopped online after drinking.  And online retailers suspect that enough shoppers buy online goods in the evening while they are drunk, or even just tipsy, that they are aiming promotions for later hours, hoping to tempt buyers after the bars close.

ROME -- Italian archaeology officials on Wednesday played down Italian news reports that chunks of masonry had been falling off the Colosseum. "Nothing has collapsed" at the Colosseum "since the 18th century," said a statement issued by a department of the Culture Ministry responsible for Rome's archaeological sites. The Colosseum, the first-century A.D. arena, is Italy's most popular tourist draw.

If all the Phys Ed columns published this year have a single message, it is that now is a fine time to own a body. The diverse exercise-related experiments published in 2011 and covered in this space each week suggest that it's possible to retain your cognitive powers, muscle mass, running speed and waistline, even as you age, and that a little exercise can go a long way in terms of physiological benefit. Recent, important science even tells us that coffee, chocolate and beer enhance exercise performance, which is fortunate, since I have no plans to give up any of those. As most of us prepare our exercise resolutions for 2012, now seems an ideal time to review the past year in fitness science and the lessons it contained, both encouraging and cautionary.

MILAN -- The French utility EDF, Europe's biggest power generator, said Tuesday it would raise its stake in the Italian energy company Edison, as it seeks to secure a bigger foothold in the country. The deal is the third big acquisition by a French company in Italy this year, activity that had raised nationalistic concerns despite the European Union's single-market rules.

To look at N.F.L. owners and league executives that night in late July was to be reminded of emergency room doctors who had just resuscitated a patient, but were still not sure he would survive. The lockout had consumed every moment of the off-season, sending owners and players into mediators' offices and federal judges' courtrooms, riding in a never-ending caravan of black sport utility vehicles to the next staredown. On that day, at a hotel near the Atlanta airport, the owners had finally approved -- 31-0, with the Oakland Raiders abstaining in one final act of defiance before their owner, Al Davis, died less than three months later -- a collective bargaining agreement that would ensure the season starting on time and assure a decade of labor peace. One problem remained: the players had not seen the final deal, and some of them felt strong-armed. The players announced they would not vote on the deal that night. For a few hours, as owners raced for the airport and reporters took up spots at the hotel bar -- it offered the best vantage point to catch the owners coming and going, really -- the N.F.L. was in a bizarre state of limbo, waiting to exhale except for that very real whiff of chaos wafting through the air.

Get ready for some Democrat-on-Democrat infighting in New Jersey. Representative Steve Rothman, a Democrat whose 9th District has been upended by redistricting, will face off against a fellow Democrat, Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., who currently represents the state's 8th District. Under the newly configured districts, Mr. Rothman's home town of Fair Lawn was plopped into the redrawn 5th District, currently held by Representative Scott Garrett, a Republican and one of the more conservative members of the House. The new district favors Republicans and would have offered an uphill race for Mr. Rothman. So he will move, and run against Mr. Pascrell in the new 9th District, creating the latest House battle between incumbents of the same party, a natural outgrowth of redistricting, which occurs every 10 years. There are roughly a dozen such races around the country, divided almost equally among incumbent Republican and Democrats.

DES MOINES -- As the Republican presidential candidates make their final pleas to voters across Iowa, a local offshoot of the Occupy Wall Street protests here has traded in tents for its own campaign office. A handwritten ''Occupy the Caucus'' sign hangs from the second-story windows of an old brick storefront, just blocks away from the state Capitol in the city's downtown. Organizers rented the office -- $1,500 for a one-week lease -- expecting hundreds of Occupy demonstrators from across Iowa and surrounding states to gather and take advantage of the news media presence leading up to the Jan. 3 caucus.

The life expectancy for babies born in New York City reached 80.6 years in 2009, the highest level recorded and one that surpasses the national life expectancy rate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday. Life expectancy at birth in the city has increased nearly three years since 2000; the latest figure is more than two years higher than the most recently reported national rate, 78.2 years.

''War Horse,'' Steven Spielberg's film adaptation of Michael Morpurgo's children's novel (and a subsequent play based on it), will open in theaters Christmas Day. But it has the look of a movie that could have just as easily played on movie screens 50 years ago. The wide open spaces, the glowing skies, the rolling hills have the feel of John Ford films, which inspired Mr. Spielberg and his longtime cinematographer, Janusz Kaminski. Mr. Kaminski spoke by phone about what he and Mr. Spielberg were seeking in the lighting and photography of this drama, which traces the life of a boy and his horse through World War I.

MetLife announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell the bulk of its retail bank deposits business to GE Capital, as it seeks to focus on its core insurance business. Under the terms of the deal, GE Capital will acquire about $7.5 billion of MetLife's deposits. The rest, about $3 billion in deposits, will be transferred over the next six months, MetLife said in a statement.

The New York Times said Tuesday that it was promoting its longtime design director, Tom Bodkin, to deputy managing editor, the latest change to the masthead since Jill Abramson took over as executive editor in September. Mr. Bodkin, who has been the paper's design director since 1987, had held the title of assistant managing editor. He will continue to oversee a team of 130 art directors, Web designers, graphic artists and others responsible for the look and feel of the paper and its Web site. The promotion is effective Jan. 1.

He lived with unwavering integrity and devotion to family, clients, friends and the practice of law. We offer our deepest sympathy to Cathy and their four sons.

The reunion they said would never happen, already happened once before but didn't happen in time for a Grammy Awards nomination concert, appears to be happening (again). The classic lineup of Van Halen, including David Lee Roth and the brothers Eddie and Alex Van Halen, and what remains of their colossal 1980s-era hair looked as if they were poised to regroup for a new concert tour after the appearance of videos that were posted on the band's Web site, www.van-halen.com. The black-and-white segments, set to parts of the Van Halen songs ''Jump,''''Panama'' and ''Hot For Teacher,'' show the bandmates rehearsing and goofing around while a ticker on the bottom of the screen reads: ''Van Halen on Tour 2012'' and ''First tickets on sale Jan. 10.'' No other information was immediately available. Van Halen replaced Mr. Roth with Sammy Hagar after the release of its album ''1984'' and spent the next 25 years in an on-and-off feud with him. Still, the group and Mr. Roth have made a couple of attempts at reuniting, most recently in a tour that ran in 2007 and 2008. The Recording Academy, which organizes the Grammy Awards, made veiled promises this year of a band reunion that would take place at its Nov. 30 nomination announcement concert; some tea-leaf readers believed that the academy's clues pointed to Van Halen while others thought they indicated the Beach Boys, but no reunion materialized on the Grammys show. (The Beach Boys announced they were getting back together a couple of weeks later.)

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the Maillardet automaton, a 200-year-old mechanical robot at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia, misattributed work done to restore the automaton. As the article correctly noted, Andrew Baron, a restorer of vintage mechanisms in Santa Fe, N.M., did the work -- not Charles F. Penniman, the Franklin Institute volunteer who was shown examining the brass cams that serve as the automaton's read-only memory.

SALTZMAN--Sandra Gabrilove. Sandra, aged 63, died December 24 after a difficult illness, peacefully in her home with her family at her side. Sandra attended The Fieldston School, Brown University and the New York University School of Law. She served for 18 years in the Manhattan District Attorneys Office and ultimately as Deputy Chief of the Special Prosecutions Bureau responsible for complex white collar crime. She inspired generations of Assistant District Attorneys with her exacting and discerning approach to case prosecution. Subsequently, she was an instructor at the Lawyering Program at the NYU School of Law. Gourmand, refined traveler, Japanese art connoisseur, and a virtual polymath, Sandra enriched all with her keen perceptivity, enthusiasm, insight and unshakeable resilience. Beloved wife of the late Michael I. Saltzman, Esq., cherished daughter of Dr. J. Lester Gabrilove, Baumritter Professor of Medicine, Emeritus of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, adored sister of Dr. Janice L. Gabrilove, James F. Holland Professor of Medicine, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, devoted aunt to Mark and Matthew Dirzulaitis and Lauren Saltzman, sister-in-law to Michael Dirzulaitis and Alan (Joanna) Saltzman. The family will be receiving visitors on Tuesday at 6:00-8:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home and services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Avenue, on Wednesday at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Michael I. Saltzman Fund at the New York University School of Law.

An article on Tuesday about debate over research that produced a highly contagious airborne version of the A(H5N1) avian flu virus omitted the context for a quotation by Richard H. Ebright of Rutgers University, who opposes such research. In predicting that the virus would ''inevitably escape, and within a decade,'' Dr. Ebright also described security measures that he thought would lower the chances it would be unintentionally released that quickly, including restricting its possession to fewer scientists and laboratories.

On his rise to boxing stardom, Manny Pacquiao often seemed invincible. He acted in movies, released albums filled with tender ballads and became a congressman in his native Philippines. Inside the ring, he bloodied larger men, knocked others out cold, even shattered the orbital bone in one opponent's face. Ever the master multitasker, Pacquiao has proven he can do anything -- except record a definitive victory over Juan Manuel Marquez.

An obituary on Dec. 5 about the racecar driver Jim Rathmann misidentified the state where Mr. Rathmann, born Royal Richard Rathmann, traded driver's licenses with his older brother, James, and began racing under his brother's name because he was under age. He was in California, not Iowa.

NORINSBERG--Robert M.,beloved father of Michael and Jon Norinsberg, grandfather of Max and Nika Norinsberg, and son of the late Jack and Susan Norinsberg, passed away on December 25, 2011 at the age of 76. A warm, loving and compassionate man, Bob was a friend to everyone he knew. Bob's extraordinary kindness, generosity and infectious sense of humor will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Bob's unconditional love, support and guidance will be impossible to replace. We miss him so much already, and we will never, ever forget him. A graveside service will be held for Bob today at 11:00am at Beth David Cemetery 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY (516) 328-1300.

Though ''Hell on Wheels'' may not match the ratings-increasing power provided by the undead hordes of its AMC sibling ''The Walking Dead,'' its own shambolically attired characters will be back for a second season, the cable channel announced on Tuesday. ''Hell on Wheels,'' a historical drama set during the post-Civil War construction of the Transcontinental Railroad, stars Anson Mount as a former Confederate soldier seeking his wife's killers; the rap artist Common as a freed slave; and the aptly named Colm Meaney as a ruthless industrialist.

Christmas was anything but merry for Sears Holdings. On Tuesday, the retailer, which operates both Sears and Kmart stores, announced plans to shut up to 120 locations after a sharp drop in sales this holiday season.

CHAVKIN--Esta Joy (nee Greenberg) of New York, 88, passed away peacefully on December 24, 2011 surrounded by her family after a courageous battle with cancer. Esta was a devoted and beloved wife, mother, sister and grandmother. She is survived by Wallace Chavkin, her husband of almost 67 years and the love of his life for the last 72 years, her daughter, Carol L. Chavkin, her son Jeffrey S. Chavkin, her daughter-in-law Katherine E. Chavkin, her grandchildren Dr. Jessica Chavkin, Arielle Chavkin and Peter Chavkin, Peter's wife Jessica Chavkin, and her brother Howard Greenberg. Esta, a high school valedictorian and a graduate of Barnard College, was a world traveler and an accomplished pianist who, as part of a program that enabled gifted classical musicians to play with symphony orchestras, performed on several occasions in her seventies with a Philadelphia based symphony orchestra. She will be deeply missed and never forgotten.

Hannibal Lecter is going away for a long time -- and so are Bambi, Forrest Gump and the adorable moppet played by Jackie Coogan in a classic Charlie Chaplin feature: the movies featuring these characters are among the 25 cinematic works that have been added to the National Film Registry, the Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday. These films, which include Jonathan Demme's ''Silence of the Lambs,'' Walt Disney's animated feature ''Bambi,'' Robert Zemeckis's ''Forrest Gump'' and Chaplin's ''The Kid,'' as well as Billy Wilder's ''Lost Weekend,'' John Cassavetes's ''Faces'' and John Ford's ''The Iron Horse,'' have been selected for preservation ''because of their enduring significance to American culture,'' James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress, said in a statement. The 25 movies were chosen from 2,228 nominated by the public this year.

Ticket sales for serious-minded Broadway shows were akin to a lump of coal last week during the run-up to the Christmas holiday, according to an analysis of weekly show grosses released on Tuesday. Grosses for the new musical ''Bonnie & Clyde'' (featuring murder and doomed love) fell by 25 percent compared with the previous week, while the revival of ''Follies'' (unhappy marriages) dropped nearly 20 percent and the play ''Other Desert Cities'' (family members fighting at Christmastime - can you believe it?) declined about 12 percent. ''On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,'' a musical revival about psychiatry and reincarnation, was down an eye-popping 50 percent, to $351,294 from $744,076; that show had seven performances last week, instead of the usual eight, which explains some of the fall-off.

Mr. Scharfer was the beloved husband of Thelma for 58 years; loving father of Paul (Joyce) Scharfer, Shari (Ed) Rollins, Joel (Donna) Scharfer, and predeceased by the late Joyce Kagan; cherished grandfather and dear brother, he will be missed by all. Graveside Services will be held on Wednesday, December 28th at 1:15pm at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ.

In the 1987 film ''Fatal Attraction,'' a psychopathic woman terrorizes a married man with whom she has had a one-night stand, making more and more threatening gestures toward him and his family until her violent demise becomes inevitable. The film originally had a rather arty conclusion, in which the woman, played by Glenn Close, commits ritual suicide as she listens to a recording of ''Madame Butterfly.'' Preview audiences rejected the ending as unsatisfying, however, and at the insistence of a marketing executive, Joseph Farrell, Paramount Pictures had the director, Adrian Lyne, reshoot it.

OBITUARIES A picture caption on Saturday with an obituary about John G. Lawrence, a plaintiff in a landmark gay rights case, misstated the given name of the man with whom he was arrested under the Texas sodomy law in 1978. As the obituary correctly noted, he was Tyron Garner, not Tryon.

BAER--Fernand (Tony). The world is not the same, dear, dear Tony. Oh how I miss your cheery self and, of course, your calls, emails, "purple" updates, and the latest news of the world and more. There will never be anyone like you. You will never be forgotten. Love, Catherine

A film review on Dec. 2 about the documentary ''A Journey in My Mother's Footsteps,'' by Dina Rosenmeier, referred incorrectly to her five siblings' connection to the film. One in fact does appear, although he is not credited and does not portray himself. The review was also imprecise in citing a scene ''featuring developmentally disabled and H.I.V.-positive toddlers'' at an institution in India. Only one of the children is said to have been H.I.V.-positive and in the film is described, without elaboration, in this way: ''She was H.I.V.-positive, turned negative.''

The creators of ''Hand to God,'' a well-reviewed, recently shuttered Off-Broadway production that revolves around a demonic sock puppet, are in talks with several producers about a possible commercial run of the play in New York, according to people involved in those discussions. Meanwhile, the head of the nonprofit theater where ''Hand to God'' ran this fall disclosed that it would return there for an eight-week encore this winter. Theater executives working on ''Hand to God'' said on Tuesday that among the producers considering the show were Kevin McCollum and Roy Miller, who have produced open-ended runs of new works, including the Broadway musicals ''[title of show]'' and ''The Drowsy Chaperone.'' The executives, who would speak only on condition of anonymity because the discussions with producers are meant to be private, said that proposals included an Off-Broadway run in 2012 and a possible Broadway production during the 2012-13 season.

An article on Dec. 9 about the exposure of Mexican workers to toxic lead in spent batteries misstated the unit of measure for estimating this year's lead exports from Mexico to China. According to government trade statistics, such exports will amount to an estimated $150 million, not 150 million tons.

You cannot eat just two, or even four or five - skinny, crispy churros still warm from the fryer, that is. Though New York has no shortage of restaurants and street vendors offering these fluted fritters that are popular in Spain and Latin America, a new bakery, La Churreria, will specialize in them. They will be sold in paper cones to go, or on plates for munching at a marble counter or table. Jesus Manso (known as Lolo) is opening this narrow storefront, with mirrors and a medley of decorative tiles, next to his Socarrat Paella Bar in NoLIta. Churros can also be gilded with a warm chocolate dip; thicker ones will be filled with chocolate.

The 1,300 nurses at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center had given notice they would strike on Jan. 3 but were able to resolve disagreements over health benefits. Officials at Mount Sinai Medical Center said Tuesday that they, too, had reached a tentative settlement with the nurses' union, though details of the deal were not available.

dePOLO--Harry R.,died Tuesday, December 20th at his home in Connecticut. An architect known for his design of hotels worldwide, he was a graduate of Cooper Union and Carnegie Mellon University and worked at Skidmore Owings and Merrill in New York before forming his own architectural firm. He was a visionary whose work graced both large cities and small towns alike and his creative vision, generosity, wit and humor will be greatly missed. He is survived by his daughter Adrianne dePolo, son in law Peter Becker, grandchildren Key and Carina Becker, brother Mario dePolo, sister in law Anne, nieces Lisa, Jeanne and nephew Mark- as well as many dear friends and colleagues. A private memorial service will be held and donations can be made in his memory to SaveVenice.org.

Instead of awarding F's for the worst deals and deal-making of the year, I am going to focus on two of the year's biggest buyouts. The first: J.Crew's $3 billion buyout by its chief executive, Millard S. Drexler, and the private equity firms TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners. The second: Del Monte Foods' $5.3 billion acquisition by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, Vestar Capital Partners and Centerview Capital. Both acquisitions showed that sometimes being bad pays very well.

OSCEOLA, Iowa -- Gov. Rick Perry said Tuesday that he had undergone a ''transformation'' on the issue of abortion and now believed that there should be no exceptions made for rape, incest or the life of the mother. That statement came just days before the Iowa caucuses as Mr. Perry and several of his rivals are trying to appeal to conservative, religious voters. But Mr. Perry described the change as a heartfelt one that came after he watched a DVD of a movie called ''The Gift of Life.''

''It's a nice Christmas present, isn't it?'' said U. W. Clemon, Alabama's first black federal judge. Mr. Clemon, who stepped down from the bench in 2009 after three decades of service, was talking about an extraordinary about-face this month from the federal appeals court in Atlanta. He was home with a cold, but he sounded delighted to have played a part in persuading the court that some words still carry the sting of oppression, even in the modern South.

The digital cookbook has been given a new format that makes consulting it closer to handling a printed book, going page by page instead of the kind of flowing format provided for some eBook readers. On epicurious.com/cookbooks, there is now an introductory list of 75 eCookbooks - entire books reproduced exactly as they appear on a bookshelf or in a store in what are called ''tastebook editions'' by the company. They are sold online for $10.99 to $24.99. Most of the books were published in the last 10 years, and all are titles from the various imprints of Random House by authors like Lidia Bastianich, Bobby Flay, Martha Stewart, Tom Colicchio and Alice Waters. The Web site offers a chance to see a preview of each book, lets purchasers add the book to their personal recipe box (which is available free on the Epicurious site), or send the book to someone else. The books are also sold on tastebook.com for input into a mobile device, but for the recipe box it is necessary to access the Epicurious Web site.

ROME--Dr. Doris Spector, 85, of Bolton, NY and Delray Beach, FL died peacefully at home on Thursday, December 22, 2011. Beloved mother to Marcia Levitz (Alan), Dr. Lisa Rome, Michael Rome (Lisa). Dear sister to Mildred Kayne. She adored and cherished her grandchildren Aaron Moskowitz, Lauren Rome and David Rome. Doris (Deo) was born in Albany NY in 1926, the daughter of Harry and Irene Spector. She married Howard Rome of Troy, NY. A graduate of Milne HS, Skidmore College ('47) and Albany Medical College ('50). Dr. Rome a Cytologist and Pathologist. Her career included Associate Professor of Medicine at the Albany Medical College. An investigator for the National Institute of Health on automated Cytology. Dr Rome trained with Dr. Papanicolaou at Cornell. She received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from Skidmore College. ('62) She was founder and President of Albany Cytopath Labs. A memorial service will be held in Albany, NY on December 26 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: Dr. Doris S. Rome and Dr. Lisa S. Rome Scholarship Fund, 47 New Scotland Ave, Albany, NY 12208 or Congregation Beth Emeth, 100 Academy Rd., Albany, NY 12208. To sign the online family guestbook, please visit, www.levinememorialchapel. com

For years Drummers World on West 46th Street was a destination for percussionists of all stripes. Numerous jazz drummers made trips there. Roadies for famous touring bands stopped by. People involved with Broadway productions bought instruments. Even members of symphony orchestras traveled to the shop to find equipment. At one point in the past decade, there were three drum stores on the block of 46th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. Soon, that number will be reduced to zero. Wednesday is the last day of business for Drummers World, which opened on West 45th Street in 1979 and moved to 46th Street 11 years later.

An article on Sunday about ethics rules passed by the City Council in Washington in the wake of misconduct accusations against city officials misidentified the offenses to which the chief of staff for Councilman Jim Graham pleaded guilty. The aide, Ted G. Loza, pleaded guilty to accepting illegal gratuities and making a false statement. Mr. Loza, who was not identified by name in the article, did not plead guilty to bribery.

1 P.M. (Lifetime) DAN IN REAL LIFE (2007) Steve Carell portrays an advice columnist and the widowed father of three daughters who travels to Rhode Island for a family gathering and stumbles on the woman of his dreams (Juliette Binoche, above, with Mr. Carell, center) in a local bookstore. She also happens to be the new girlfriend of his brother (Dane Cook). John Mahoney, Dianne Wiest, Alison Pill, Norbert Leo Butz and Amy Ryan round out the ensemble cast. The moral of this film from Peter Hedges, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, is '' 'expect to be surprised,' and the surprise is how frequently it succeeds. 'Dan in Real Life' is neither wildly farcical nor mockingly cruel, but rather, for the most part, winningly gentle and observant.'' 9:30 A.M. (CUNY) CITY TALK Joshua David and Robert Hammond, founders of Friends of the High Line, discuss plans for that Manhattan park's third and final section, which will terminate at the Hudson Yards. Dan Barasch, a founder of the Delancey Underground project, explains his vision for turning what was once a trolley terminal beneath Delancey Street, near the Williamsburg Bridge on the Lower East Side, into a subterranean public park. Doug Muzzio hosts the program, repeated at 4:30 and 9:30 p.m.

DUBUQUE, Iowa -- Newt Gingrich has been aggressively outspent by rivals on television and radio ads that have done serious damage to his standing in polls, especially here in Iowa. But a new independent ''super PAC'' supporting Mr. Gingrich plans to spend more than $1 million in the next seven days on TV, radio and digital spots, most in Iowa ahead of the Jan. 3 caucuses. The group, Winning Our Future, has produced a TV ad that echoes Mr. Gingrich's version of his economic accomplishments while speaker of the House, which he is making the focus of a weeklong bus tour. They include welfare reform, tax cuts and balanced budgets.

6:00 p.m. | Updated The New York Times Company announced on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to sell the company's Regional Media Group to Halifax Media Holdings, of Daytona Beach, Fla., for $143 million in cash. The announcement comes just a week after the Times Company said it was in advanced talks with Halifax to sell its regional media group, which consists of 16 regional newspapers including The Gainesville Sun; The Press Democrat in Santa Rosa, Calif.; The Sarasota Herald Tribune; and The Tuscaloosa News.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - Have you ever started filling in a long answer based on the crossings, with little awareness of what the complete entry might be, but as you scribble and the answer dawns on you, you can feel the smile spread across your face? That's what happened to me as I filled in 3 Down. I wound up laughing out loud at UP THE WAZOO, but it was the first time I think I was actually aware that the writing and the smiling were happening at the same time.

Last week, Nina (all names and identifying details have been changed) asked our parenting crowd source for advice about a question she's been struggling with for some time. When her husband and his first wife divorced, his now ex swore he'd never see the children on a holiday, and in the eight years since, she's made good on her promise. During that interval, he met Nina, they married, and had two children together. He's never objected to his ex-spouse's claim to his children for the holidays (or even her constant pulling them back from other arranged visits), but Nina wondered if maybe he - they - should. What if her stepchildren (now 11 and 15) think they weren't wanted?

Over on the Lens blog, Sgt. Thomas James Brennan writes about the close bonds that form during battle, even between soldiers and the combat photographers documenting them. When Finbarr O'Reilly, a Reuters photographer, embedded with Sgt. Brennan's squad of Marines in Afghanistan last October, he was a little guarded around the man with the camera. But the war didn't give him time or space to hold onto those feelings. And conversations with Mr. O'Reilly, coupled with the closeness of battle, forged a bond between the men that continues to today. A bond was cemented with the commonalities the men shared, as Sgt. The classic and highly prized wooden speedboats made by Chris-Craft have long been fitted with potent automobile engines, including small-block Chevy V-8s and Chrysler Hemis. Now, Infiniti has joined with Nashville State Community College and Freeport Boat Outlet of Maine to customize a 1962 Chris-Craft Holiday and equip it with a 400-horsepower 5.6-liter V-8 from an Infiniti QX56 S.U.V. It's the kind of pairing of classic and contemporary that has always been part of the automotive scene, but has perhaps been more rare in the world of boats.

I admit to having been surprised by the reaction to my two posts on the burden of debt. I thought I was saying something that would be obvious once it was pointed out; instead, many of the comments were baffled, and quite a few were utterly enraged.

The ecosystem of the delta where the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers meet has been in the legal equivalent of an intensive care unit for four years. But just before Christmas, an upbeat report came in, showing that a year of copious rain and snow had significantly improved.the delta's condition.
