The number of undefeated teams in college basketball continues to shrink to a precious few, as Indiana and Louisville lost Wednesday. Four teams remain perfect: No. 1 Syracuse is 14-0, No. 20 Murray State and No. 6 Baylor are 13-0, and No. 8 Missouri sits at 12-0.

Heather Peters of Los Angeles is taking a novel approach to addressing her legal grievances against Honda for what she says are the fuel economy shortcomings of her Civic Hybrid. When Finbarr O'Reilly, a Reuters photographer, embedded with my squad of Marines in Afghanistan last October, I strategically positioned myself between him and my men, to keep them out of trouble. I based my decision on experience and preconceived notions regarding combat journalists. On the first night, I questioned him for hours about his upbringing, his background and his political outlook on the war, to get a better feel for who he was. It appeared that he wasn't a bad guy after all. We shared a lot of views. But I remained cautious. You can never judge a book by its cover.

The last few years have seen a new generation of alternative publications and editorial talent emerge, and London is very much a part of the scene. This month saw the release of the fourth issue of P.E.A.R. (Paper for Emerging Architectural Research). Printed on newspaper stock, this zine (included in "Archizines," a show I curated at the Architectural Association School of Architecture) was started by the editorial collective of Rashid Ali, Matthew Butcher, Julian Krueger and Megan O'Shea, with the designer Avni Patel, in 2009. A few issues in, they have really hit their stride. "The paper aims to re-establish the fanzine as a primary medium for the dissemination of architectural ideas, musings, research and works, and to present the complexity and variety of architectural practice," O'Shea explains. "We actively seek to publish thinking that wouldn't ordinarily be seen in the mainstream architectural press, and we are interested in showing that the architectural is concerned with more than just architecture."
The Alibaba Group, the fast-growing Chinese Internet company, has hired an influential lobbying firm in Washington as it navigates a potential takeover bid for Yahoo.

A federal judge in New York has ruled that Marvel Entertainment owns the rights to Ghost Rider, a supernatural character possessed by a spirit of vengeance who first appeared in 1972. The character was the subject of a lawsuit by a writer seeking to cash in on lucrative movie rights, according to a report by The Associated Press. United States District Judge Katherine Forrest threw out on Wednesday the four-year-old claims by ruling that Gary Friedrich, a freelance writer, gave up all ownership rights when he signed checks including language-relinquishing rights to the predecessor companies of Marvel Entertainment.

Deliberations were heated Thursday in India's Rajya Sabha, or upper house of Parliament, over the Lokpal bill, which would create an anti-corruption body of ombudsmen in India. The United Progressive Alliance, or U.P.A., does not have a majority in the Rajya Sabha, unlike in the Lok Sabha, so the bill will have a more difficult time passing.

The list of the top-grossing films of 2011 is, more or less, a list of sequels, starting with the top film, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2," which is the final sequel in a long series. Those results are a product of "a flight to financial safety that has been building for a decade," Michael Cieply writes. It appears that 2012 will not be so different, with the major studios planning about 10 sequels or "reboots" (that is, a familiar series that begins again, from the top).

When Napoleon acquired 695 ancient statues from the Borghese family collection in 1807, flabbergasted contemporaries called the act "an indelible shame." The collection was born two centuries earlier when Cardinal Scipione Borghese, nephew of Pope Paul V, made it his life's work to bring together the masterpieces available to him. He assembled more than 2,000 pieces, including antique statues, sculptures by Bernini and canvases by Raphael, Caravaggio and Titian.

An article on Saturday about airlines' giving up colorful fuselage paint as a reflection of a more sober approach to the business described incorrectly the 2005 deal that combined US Airways and America West. It was a merger, and the entities retained the name US Airways; US Airways was not ''acquired'' by America West.

With only a few days left in the year, major crime in New York City has risen in 2011 - up less than 1 percent from the previous year, but up nonetheless, according to the latest Police Department data. But that is not how the city sees it.

On Nov. 20, the Chicago Bears' season went slip-sliding away on a single play. With the team well on its way to a fifth straight win, wide receiver Johnny Knox slipped at the San Diego 20-yard line, and the pass that was thrown his way -- a quick slant based entirely on timing and trust -- was instead intercepted by Chargers cornerback Antoine Cason. The play occurred late in the fourth quarter, and while it was inconsequential to the game's outcome, quarterback Jay Cutler broke the thumb on his throwing hand while attempting to prevent the interception return for a touchdown by taking on Cason's lead blocker. For a Bears fan (a k a me), the news seemed utterly catastrophic. ''The season is over!'' was the initial lament.

ALGONA, Iowa -- Sometimes the gods of campaign scheduling smile on you. On Tuesday, in a swipe at Newt Gingrich's failure to get on the Virginia primary ballot, Mitt Romney compared the disorganization of the Gingrich campaign to ''Lucille Ball at the chocolate factory,'' a nod to the classic ''I Love Lucy'' episode in which the star falls endlessly behind an assembly line of moving candies.

A report in the Observatory column on Dec. 20 about a cold gas cloud that researchers say is headed for the black hole at the center of the Milky Way described the black hole, known as Sagittarius A*, incorrectly. A black hole consumes only material that crosses its event horizon, as the cold gas cloud is expected to do beginning in 2013; it is not the case that Sagittarius A* will eventually consume everything in the galaxy.
LAWRENCE--Roz. Beloved mother and grandmother. We love you and you will be in our hearts and thoughts forever. Debbie, Ira, Cara, Robbie, Marc, Jonathan, Lisa, Bennett and Nicole.

What might the moment before world annihilation sound like? While most would prefer not to experience the sound firsthand, it is one that has been imagined and portrayed cinematically in several ways, from a whimper (Sidney Lumet's ''Fail-Safe'') to a bang (the 1983 TV movie ''The Day After,'' which didn't depict the end of everything, exactly, but did portray the unthinkable). Lars von Trier's ''Melancholia,'' the apocalyptic drama that has received as much critical praise as its director has received public scrutiny, chooses to end the world with Wagner. The prelude to Richard Wagner's opera ''Tristan and Isolde'' guides audiences through many of the film's darkest and brightest moments. And the sound designer Kristian Eidnes Andersen, who also worked with Mr. von Trier on ''Antichrist,'' uses his understanding of music composition to bring those sounds to the height of emotional impact.

FRANKENTHALER--Helen The family of Helen Frankenthaler, the eminent American abstract painter, announced with profound sadness her death at the age of 83, on December 27, 2011, at her home in Connecticut after a long illness. Deeply loved by her family and cherished by her many friends around the world, she is survived by her husband of seventeen years, Stephen M. DuBrul, Jr.; and by her nieces, Ellen Iseman and Beverly Ross, and four nephews, Peter Iseman, Fred Iseman, Alfred Ross, and Clifford Ross. She is also survived by two stepdaughters, Lise Motherwell and Jeannie Motherwell, from her first marriage, to the artist Robert Motherwell, and by two stepchildren, Jennifer DuBrul and Nicholas DuBrul, as well as three grandnephews, two grandnieces, four step-granddaughters, two step-great-grandsons, and one step-great-granddaughter. Helen Frankenthaler was born in Manhattan in 1928, the third daughter of New York State Supreme Court Judge Alfred Frankenthaler and Martha Lowenstein Frankenthaler. Her sisters, Marjorie Frankenthaler Iseman and Gloria Frankenthaler Ross Bookman, predeceased her. Helen Frankenthaler graduated from The Dalton School, having attended The Brearley School and The Horace Mann School. A 1949 graduate of Bennington College, she served as a member of the College's Board of Trustees from 1967 to 1982. She was the recipient of twenty-six honorary degrees, as well as other notable honors, including the National Medal of the Arts, in 2001. Most recently, she was appointed as an Honorary Academician of the Royal Academy of Arts, London in 2011. From 1985 to 1992, she was a member of the National Council on the Arts, part of the National Endowment for the Arts. A perfectionist and planner to the end, she made clear her wish to be buried at her alma mater, Bennington College, in Vermont, where a private ceremony will be held. A memorial service in New York City will be announced in the weeks ahead. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Bennington College or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York City. Helen was a family treasure, a national treasure, and will be forever missed by those who knew her well and by a public who admired her vibrant works of art. In her career she was an original, brilliant, energetic, witty presence who shone brightly in our firmament. With her passing, her world and her family are left with a deep void and diminished color.

COOPER--Adrienne. Died December 25, 2011 in New York. The Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring mourns the passing of Adrienne Cooper, our External Affairs Officer. Adrienne was a dear friend, valued colleague, passionate social justice activist, and inspiring performer. The City Room column in some editions on Saturday, about progress on the Fulton Street Transit Center in Lower Manhattan, included several errors. A passageway under Dey Street links the PATH, E and R lines to stations on the 2, 3, 4, 5, A, C, J and Z lines, but not to the M train. (That line was rerouted last year and no longer runs through Lower Manhattan, though it did when the center was planned.) The new mezzanine is along the A and C lines -- not the A and E lines, as the article noted at one point. And the entrance to the transit center at 135 William Street is new; it has not been rehabilitated.
CUMMINGS--Claire, passed Tuesday morning. She is survived by her sister Jane, her godsons Daniel and Michael, and all those whose lives she touched with her caring and loving nature.

A critic's notebook article on Tuesday about the year in theater included an outdated reference to the Sydney Theater Company's production of Chekhov's ''Uncle Vanya,'' which came to the Kennedy Center in Washington. It will in fact be presented at the Lincoln Center Festival in New York, in July.

Dr. Robert Ader, an experimental psychologist who was among the first scientists to show how mental processes influence the body's immune system, a finding that changed modern medicine, died on Tuesday in Pittsford, N.Y. He was 79. His death followed a long illness and complications of a fracture suffered in a fall, his daughter Deborah Ader said.

DES MOINES -- The top Iowa adviser to Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota announced Wednesday night that he was jumping ship to support the candidacy of Representative Ron Paul of Texas. Kent Sorenson, a state legislator who has been at Mrs. Bachmann's side for months, made his decision in the closing days of the Iowa caucus campaign. It was a significant blow to Mrs. Bachmann, who has struggled to regain the fleeting summertime glory of winning the Iowa straw poll.

An article on Tuesday about North Carolina's concealed-handgun permit program misstated the name of the town that is home to the Hogs Pen Pub, the site of a fatal shooting in 2008 by the holder of one such permit. It is Macclesfield, not Macclesville.

GOLDENTHAL--Edgar Joseph, 94, a NYC Dentist for 53 years. Graduate from UNC, Chapel Hill, NC 1936, UPenn College of Dentistry 1940. Chairman 7th Zionist District, founded Westchester chapter of Americans for Democratic Action, taught at 1st District Dental Society, and History at Lynn University. A Major in the US Army Dental Corp spending 44 months in the South Pacific during WWII. Ed was endlessly creative; a writer of plays, musicals, essays and poems, publishing three books as well as a talented sculptor and inventor. He inspired those around him with his never tiring fascination with life and unwillingness to quit. He is survived by his three sons, Dr.s Michael, Mark and Jonathan and eight grandchildren: Sarah, Emily, Becky, Ariel, Isaac, Alexander, David and Ethan. Ed once said, Get rid of my clothes as soon as possible. I'm not in my clothes. I'm in your heads. Remember me with love and I remain alive. Service Thursday, December 29, 2011, 11:15am at The Riverside 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave.

Sidney Crosby, the Pittsburgh Penguins' star captain, is a stealth presence these days. He is not on the ice at games or practices, and remains quite silent in the news media about what is going on with him. He sustained a concussion from two hard hits over a two-game span at the start of 2011 and was sidelined for nearly 11 months. His start to this season was delayed until Nov. 21, and it now appears he could be out again as postconcussion symptoms resurface.

DES MOINES -- As he arrives in Iowa today, Ron Paul is continuing to wage his expensive television campaign against Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney with a new advertisement that dubs them part of ''the Washington machine.'' Mr. Paul has used his prowess as a fund-raiser to blanket the airwaves with slickly produced and biting ads. The latest will air in Iowa and New Hampshire beginning today, his campaign said.

An article on Saturday about the painter Mort Künstler's updated version of ''Washington Crossing the Delaware,'' by Emanuel Leutze, misidentified the version of the painting that is usually displayed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is a version of the painting that Leutze began in 1850 after the original, begun in 1849, was damaged in a fire. The museum does not display the original.

The beleaguered, blustery coach of the Jets takes the podium for his midweek news conference, his team coming off a critical loss and facing depressingly long playoff odds of their own making. He faces down the skeptical news media, a glint of defiance in his eyes, firm resolve in his lower jaw, bear claw and stale coffee on his breath. He did not give the following speech, but the world would be a lot more fun if he had: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.

It was another low-key post-holiday night for television on Tuesday as the broadcast networks filled the schedule with more repeats. CBS was the No. 1 network over all in viewers and tied Univision for the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. CBS's broadcast of the 34th annual Kennedy Center Honors attracted a sizable older audience with an average of 8.4 million total viewers, but the 18-to-49 crowd shied away. It tied the 2002 broadcast for the lowest-rated Kennedy Center Honors in viewers 18-to-49 and was down 27 percent in that advertiser-beloved category when compared to last year. A repeat of ''NCIS'' on CBS was the highest-rated program in every category for the night and drew 12.5 million total viewers.

(IFC) JUNEBUG (2005) A worldly Chicago art dealer (Embeth Davidtz) travels to rural North Carolina to meet the parents of her golden-boy husband (Alessandro Nivola) and receives a chilly if courteous reception in this dramatic comedy from Phil Morrison. Ben McKenzie plays the younger brother who misinterprets a helping hand as something more. Amy Adams earned an Oscar nomination for best supporting actress for her turn as the pregnant wife who sees a star in the family's midst. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called the film ''wise, bittersweet, beautifully acted.''

A group of Muslim leaders plans to boycott Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's annual interfaith breakfast on Friday to protest what it calls the unfair surveillance of Muslims by the New York Police Department. In a letter sent to Mr. Bloomberg on Wednesday, 14 Muslim leaders said they would not attend the breakfast because of what they described as ''very disturbing revelations'' about the city's treatment of Muslim New Yorkers. They were referring to a series of articles released by The Associated Press beginning in August that detailed the use of undercover officers and informants to gather and maintain information about political activity among Muslims in circumstances in which there was no indication that crimes had occurred.

We had the utmost respect and love for our treasured Eddie. We will miss him and carry his legacy in our hearts always. Nancy, Howard, Michael, Jennifer, Matthew and Caroline

Like a circle in a spiral, like a wheel within a wheel, never-ending news is spooling off a never-ending reel ... Now a quiz is set to test you and your memory of the memes ... like the stories that you find, in the pages of The Times. Answers will appear tomorrow on this page.

ROME -- Italian archaeology officials on Wednesday played down Italian news reports that chunks of masonry had been falling off the Colosseum. ''Nothing has collapsed'' at the Colosseum ''since the 18th century,'' said a statement issued by a department of the Culture Ministry responsible for Rome's archaeological sites. The Colosseum, the first-century A.D. arena, is Italy's most popular tourist draw. The statement was issued after culture ministry officials used a crane to peruse up close an area of the massive structure where bits of plaster were said to have detached and fallen on Tuesday, according to news reports. On Christmas Day tourists found small fragments of tufo, the porous rock typical of ancient Roman monuments, on the ground. Anna Maria Moretti, the official responsible for the ancient sites, denied that any material had fallen Tuesday and noted that the tufo that detached on Dec. 25 came from a patch smaller than ''five centimeters.''

For the obsessives who keep close watch on the music charts, this time of year can be repetitive. Driven by holiday shopping, the same few hits tend to dominate week after week. So it's no shock that in the sales week that ended on Christmas, Michael Buble and Adele once again sit in the top two spots of the latest Billboard album chart.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday previewing some of that day's soccer matches in Britain reversed the home teams in those matches. Manchester City played at West Bromwich Albion, Wigan played at Manchester United, Blackburn played at Liverpool, and Plymouth Argyle played at Bristol Rovers.
An article on Tuesday about the various activities around the track at McCarren Park in Brooklyn misstated the year the pool at the park opened. It was 1936, not 1934.

Italy's short-term borrowing costs dropped sharply on Wednesday at an auction of government bills, easing the immediate pressure on the country's economy. The sale of 9 billion euros ($11.8 billion) of six-month Treasury bills was seen as the first postholiday indication of the condition of the beleaguered euro zone, the 17 members of the European Union that use the euro.

OTTAWA - For beleaguered investors in Research in Motion, the drastic collapse of the company's share price through 2011 eventually became a cause for optimism. In December, shares of the BlackBerry maker spiked on reports that several technology titans could be suitors. But the optimism has been fleeting; the company has grappled with service failures, weak product introductions and dwindling market share. Shares of RIM have dropped by 75 percent since February.

REDSTONE--Edward. The Crohn's & Colitis Foundation mourns the passing of Edward Redstone, who generously supported our mission in honor of Michele Sweetwood, wife of son, Steven. Our sympathies and condolences are with his wife Madeline and family.

FRANKENTHALER--Helen. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. With its graceful spontaneity and masterful deployment of color, her work re-made abstraction into a fabric on which both light and depths call to each other. She changed the ways we can see the world.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about Robert G. Morvillo, a prominent New York trial lawyer, misstated the middle initial of the former vice-presidential candidate who was married to John A. Zaccaro, one of Mr. Morvillo's clients. She was Geraldine A. Ferraro, not Geraldine R.

Plastic stars showered from confetti cannons inside Conseco Fieldhouse, swirling to the court on gusts of change in women's college basketball. The traditional powers -- Tennessee, Connecticut, Stanford -- were absent on this April night. Instead, the players from Texas A&M jumped and hugged and celebrated their first N.C.A.A. championship. The game took only 40 minutes on the clock, but more than 40 years on the calendar of cultural acceptance. In a feverish, engaging game, Texas A&M's press was smothering and its Barkley-esque forward Danielle Adams was unstoppable inside and out, with 30 points and 9 rebounds in a 76-70 victory over Notre Dame. As the Aggies hoisted the championship trophy, perhaps no university had ever come as far in the embrace of women on the court and in the classroom.

Federal authorities investigating the demise of MF Global think that the firm began improperly moving customer money to a middleman on Oct. 27, according to people briefed on the matter. The transfers, which indicate the brokerage firm misused client funds earlier than previously believed, represent a new line of inquiry in the hunt for more than $1 billion in missing money.

Keegan Bradley had a look of loss on his face. People like to think that professional athletes have steely-eyed game faces. Instead, sometimes they have an expression that says, ''I just lost.'' Bradley was standing next to the 15th green on the final day of the P.G.A. Championship and he had flubbed a simple chip, sending his ball skittering past the hole until it plopped into a pond on the other side of the green. Standing nearby, I looked into Bradley's eyes and saw a 25-year-old tour rookie thunderstruck by a turn of events that suddenly left him five strokes off the lead with three holes to play.

As first lady of New York City during much of the 1990s, Donna Hanover - the former Mrs. Rudolph W. Giuliani - surely developed an opinion or two about the ferocity of the City Hall press corps. This spring, in an instance of art imitating life, she'll have a chance to show what she thinks of the Fourth Estate when she makes her Broadway debut playing a presidential campaign reporter in the revival of ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man,'' the producers announced on Wednesday. Ms. Hanover, a television journalist who has performed previously in Off Broadway productions like the recent ''Picked,'' has been cast as one of the journalists covering the national party convention where two candidates - to be played by John Larroquette (a Tony Award winner this year for ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'') and Eric McCormack (an Emmy winner on ''Will and Grace'') - are maneuvering for the nomination. Also joining the cast, the producers said, were Tony winner Jefferson Mays (''I Am My Own Wife'') as a businessman with ties to Mr. McCormack's character, and Dakin Matthews (Broadway's ''A Man for All Seasons'') as an influential senator.

7:02 p.m. | Updated The New York Times mistakenly sent an e-mail on Wednesday to more than eight million people who had shared their information with the company, erroneously informing them that they had canceled home delivery of the newspaper. The Times Company, which initially mischaracterized the mishap as spam, apologized for sending the e-mail. The people who received the message represented a cross section of readers who had given their e-mail addresses to the newspaper, said Eileen Murphy, a spokeswoman for the Times Company.

The Dyson Hot space heater answers an age-old question. ''How can I get greater efficiency and a higher circulation of air from a radiant heat source?'' What the engineers at Dyson -- the outfit that rethought the way vacuum cleaners and hand dryers work -- have done with this device is to make use of a new way to heat air and move it around a room. The Dyson Hot creates a column of warm air that can be sent in various directions thanks to its tilting and oscillating base. The end result, Dyson says, is a heater that has no external moving parts like spinning blades and can run almost half as hot as conventional models while still providing the same or better output. Such technology does not come cheaply -- the Dyson Hot costs $400. Here is how all of that innovation works. SAM GROBART

Because of an editing error, the Media Equation column on Monday, about competition and new consumer choices in media, misidentified the organization that started The Daily, an iPad-only news report. It is News Corporation -- not The Wall Street Journal, which the corporation owns. The column also misstated the time slot occupied by ''The Rachel Maddow Show'' on MSNBC. The show appears at 9 p.m. Eastern time, just after the time slot previously occupied by Keith Olbermann. It did not take over Mr. Olbermann's time slot.

Violet, the red-tailed hawk whose intimate family life in a nest overlooking Washington Square Park was chronicled on a live-streaming webcam, delighting more than a million viewers with the sacred spectacle of nature, died on Thursday. She was believed to be about 5 years old. Violet had ''heart-related complications'' following surgery to amputate her necrotic foot, said Robert Horvath, a raptor rehabilitator based on Long Island. He said he was awaiting necropsy results.

Thousands of artifacts salvaged from the Titanic's watery tomb in the North Atlantic will be sold in a winner-take-all auction scheduled for April, the centennial of the luxury liner's sinking, The Associated Press reported. The estimated value of the 5,500 pieces of fine china, still-fragrant perfume bottles, ship fittings and more recovered by RMS Titanic Inc., a court-appointed salvaging company, is $189 million. The auction is scheduled for April 1 at Guernsey's, the New York auction house.

Many judges are lucky to handle just one era-defining case during their tenures on the bench. In his 16 years as a federal bankruptcy judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez has handled three. The first, Enron, came up in late 2001. Eight months later, WorldCom followed, forcing the judge to handle both cases simultaneously. And the last, Chrysler, arrived in 2009.

In a boost to Emerson College's ambitions to be a force in theater, the two leaders of the American Voices New Play Institute - an influential national player in conversations and research about playwriting - will move next year from Arena Stage in Washington to become part of ArtsEmerson, the Boston college's two-year-old theater programming arm. The leaders, David Dower and Polly Carl, will bring with them several online projects that have gained a following in theater circles nationally: the online journal HowlRound, the live-streamed New Play TV and an interactive New Play Map, in which theaters can use a database to share production histories for new plays, details about the writers and other information.

''We need another Margaret Thatcher, another Iron Lady,'' she said to a crowd of supporters in Legends American Grill in Marshalltown on Thursday afternoon.

An article on Dec. 17 about a hearing in the case against Tim Curley and Gary Schultz, two Penn State University officials who have been charged with perjury and failure to report a crime, quoted incorrectly from testimony by John McQueary, the father of Mike McQueary, a Penn State assistant football coach who had testified that he witnessed the former Penn State assistant Jerry Sandusky sexually assaulting a young boy. Although, as the article correctly noted, John McQueary testified that he thought that university officials had failed in their handling of the episode, he said, ''I am not in position to say Gary Schultz didn't do anything about it.'' He did not say, ''I'm now in the position to say Gary Schultz did nothing about it.''

KEMPLER--Cecelia (Sue). The partners, counsel, associates and administrative staff of Dewey & LeBoeuf LLP deeply mourn the passing of our retired partner and dear friend, Sue Kempler. Sue co-chaired the Firm's Insurance Practice and chaired its Life Insurance Practice. She was the first woman on the Firm's Executive Committee and the Managing Partner of the Washington DC office. After her retirement, she served on the Board of AEGON U.S. and on the Supervisory Board of AEGON N.V., and she was the founding Director of the Kaye School of Finance, Insurance and Economics at Florida Atlantic University. Law was Sue's second career, and she pursued it with passion and boundless energy. She was an inspirational leader, mentor, role model, partner and friend. She was a shrewd and highly skilled lawyer who was always the absolute personification of client service. She was wise, warm and witty, charming, generous and fun. And always elegant. She fought her final battle with the great courage, dignity and determination that characterized her life. We extend our condolences to Sue's beloved partner of 31 years and spouse, Virginia Ellen Cropper, and to her family. Donations in Sue's memory can be made to: Boca Raton Regional Hospital Foundation (Lynn Cancer Institute) re: Cecelia Sue Kempler, c/o BRRH Foundation, Inc., 745 Meadows Road, Boca Raton, Florida 33486.

I don't go out to get gas at night. I don't run to any stores. I try to do everything in the daytime and to be back before night falls. JUANITA KENNEDY,65, of Highland Park, Mich., a cash-strapped city that has turned off many of its streetlights to save money. [A11]

Musical revivals are one of the bread-and-butter staples of any Broadway season, but the arrival of ''Porgy and Bess'' -- oops, I mean ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' -- at the Richard Rodgers Theater this winter does not remotely qualify as business-as-usual fare. This is not just because the new production has come thundering into town after its Boston tryout, trailing a boldface-name-inspired controversy. Most theater watchers will be aware that proposed changes to the original book inflamed the sensibilities of no less a musical-theater master than Stephen Sondheim, prompting a letter of protest to The New York Times. But the production, directed by Diane Paulus (''Hair''), would be important even without the mild media tempest inspired by Mr. Sondheim's letter. The music and lyrics, by George and Ira Gershwin and DuBose and Dorothy Heyward, are considered by most authorities (Mr. Sondheim included) to be among the greatest ever heard on Broadway.
A collection of some of the best pictures and most memorable moments of 2011.

An article on Monday about Jack Robison and Kirsten Lindsmith, two college students with Asperger syndrome who are navigating the perils of an intimate relationship, misidentified the character from the animated children's TV show ''My Little Pony'' that Ms. Lindsmith said she visualized to cheer herself up. It is Twilight Sparkle, the nerdy intellectual, not Fluttershy, the kind animal lover.

INTERACTIVE The New York Times submitted a set of questions to each of the major presidential candidates about their views on the scope and limits of the powers they would wield if elected. nytimes.com/us

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about the casting of Donna Hanover as a reporter in the coming Broadway revival of ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man'' referred incorrectly to her journalism career. Ms. Hanover is a reporter for a program on CUNY TV; she is not a ''former'' journalist.

CHAMBERLAIN--John. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with sadness the death of John Chamberlain. One of the most important American sculptors of our time, Chamberlain's distinctive approach and intuitive understanding of material, gesture, and space amounted to a new sculptural language. He was the consummate artist; his curiosity knew no bounds and his influence will be felt for years to come. The Whitney is proud to hold a number of Chamberlain's works in our permanent collection, the first of which was acquired in 1963. Over 30 exhibitions at the Museum have included his work. We extend our condolences to his wife, Prudence Fairweather, and his children, Angus, Duncan, Alexandra and Phoebe. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman; Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus; Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman; Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman; Neil G. Bluhm, President; Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director; Donna De Salvo, Chief Curator and Deputy Director for Programs

With the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary just days away, five Republican presidential contenders responded to a survey on executive power by The New York Times, which is publishing the full text of responses at nytimes.com/politics. Here are some of the candidates' answers. CHARLIE SAVAGE Q Under what circumstances, if any, would the Constitution permit the president to authorize the targeted killing of a United States citizen who has not been sentenced to death by a court?

The cable guy is becoming sleeker and more sophisticated, just like the televisions and computers he installs. Long depicted as slovenly cranks who dodged growling dogs and tracked mud on the living room carpet, cable guys (and gals) these days often have backgrounds in engineering and computer science. That kind of training is now required -- along with a new dress code for some, calling for button-down dress shirts and slacks -- as cable companies and their telephone rivals try to lure customers and increase revenue with a suite of products like cloud-based cable boxes and iPad apps that let subscribers set recording times remotely.

HENRY--Edward I. M.D.,82 years old, died in Chevy Chase, MD. Treasured husband for 61 years of Sondra; Formerly of Great Neck and Bayside, NY; Loving and devoted father of Dr. Scott (Terry), Tricia (Dr. Howard Sachs), and Gordon (Debbie); proud grandfather of his cherished Rachel, Jenifer, Ben, Logan, Oliver, Spencer, Theo; Cousin of Howard Kamens; Brother-in-law of Linda Davidson; Graduated Stuyvesant High School; Syracuse University, Phi Beta Kappa; New York Medical College; Attending Physician, North Shore Hospital / Long Island Jewish Hospital; Captain, US Army; Caring physician to all who sought his advice; Loved family reunions, medicine, football, tennis, travel, photography, driving in Europe; Admired and respected by all who knew him. Lived life fully.
International IN RUSSIA, ORTHODOX CHURCH

One day in April, the Los Angeles Dodgers owner Frank McCourt sat at a conference table in Manhattan emanating indignation. Nearly a week before, Bud Selig, the commissioner of baseball, had installed a monitor to oversee the team's finances. McCourt was plenty offended by that. Now, he had just learned in a meeting at baseball's offices that Selig was deferring his decision on a TV deal that McCourt desperately needed. In such a state, doesn't an enraged man deserve a nice massage?

SIDAMON-ERISTOFF--Constantine. The Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, esteemed Board member from 1967 to 1992. Connie provided Carnegie Hall with invaluable guidance during its formative years as a not-for-profit organization, and he will always be remembered for his generosity and leadership as a member of the Steering Committee for the Campaign for Carnegie Hall, which culminated in the Hall's historic restoration and renovation in 1986. All of us at Carnegie Hall have greatly valued Connie's presence in our lives, and we will miss him deeply. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Anne, his daughter Elizabeth, his sons Andrew and Simon, and to the entire Sidamon-Eristoff family. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

The Mets know things are not great at Citi Field. Attendance dropped again last season as they finished with a losing record for the third consecutive season. Revenue fell from virtually every source. On Wednesday, Standard & Poor's, the credit rating agency, took notice. It changed its near-term outlook from stable to negative on the $695.4 million in bonds issued on behalf of Queens Ballpark Company, a Mets subsidiary, to build Citi Field.

YOUNG--Richard. International lawyer, son of Owen D. Young, on November 18, in Van Hornesville, NY, at 92. Memorial service in summer. Gifts to St. Lawrence University or Van Hornesville Community Corp.

Sean Collins, who created Surfline.com, whose forecasts and real-time views of beaches reach 1.5 million surfers a week, died on Monday in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 59. While playing tennis, he had a heart attack, his business partner, David Gilovich, said.

LONDON--Charlotte, beloved wife of the late Joseph, devoted mother of Ellen Sutton (Michael), Mindy (Scott Price) and grandmother to Matthew Sutton passed away peacefully on Wednesday December 28. Services Friday December 30 at 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

FRANKENTHALER--Helen The family of Helen Frankenthaler, the eminent American abstract painter, announced with profound sadness her death at the age of 83, on December 27, 2011, at her home in Connecticut after a long illness. Deeply loved by her family and cherished by her many friends around the world, she is survived by her husband of seventeen years, Stephen M. DuBrul, Jr.; and by her nieces, Ellen Iseman and Beverly Ross, and four nephews, Peter Iseman, Fred Iseman, Alfred Ross, and Clifford Ross. She is also survived by two stepdaughters, Lise Motherwell and Jeannie Motherwell, from her first marriage, to the artist Robert Motherwell, and by two stepchildren, Jennifer DuBrul and Nicholas DuBrul, as well as three grandnephews, two grandnieces, four step-granddaughters, two step-great-grandsons, and one step-great-granddaughter. Helen Frankenthaler was born in Manhattan in 1928, the third daughter of New York State Supreme Court Judge Alfred Frankenthaler and Martha Lowenstein Frankenthaler. Her sisters, Marjorie Frankenthaler Iseman and Gloria Frankenthaler Ross Bookman, predeceased her. Helen Frankenthaler graduated from The Dalton School, having attended The Brearley School and The Horace Mann School. A 1949 graduate of Bennington College, she served as a member of the College's Board of Trustees from 1967 to 1982. She was the recipient of twenty-six honorary degrees, as well as other notable honors, including the National Medal of the Arts, in 2001. Most recently, she was appointed as an Honorary Academician of the Royal Academy of Arts, London in 2011. From 1985 to 1992, she was a member of the National Council on the Arts, part of the National Endowment for the Arts. A perfectionist and planner to the end, she made clear her wish to be buried at her alma mater, Bennington College, in Vermont, where a private ceremony will be held. A memorial service in New York City will be announced in the weeks ahead. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Bennington College or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York City. Helen was a family treasure, a national treasure, and will be forever missed by those who knew her well and by a public who admired her vibrant works of art. In her career she was an original, brilliant, energetic, witty presence who shone brightly in our firmament. With her passing, her world and her family are left with a deep void and diminished color.

Thanks to the Arts for Transit program, there are moments of genuine delight to be found in the New York City subway. There are also delightful surprises that have nothing to do with artistic intent. Or spelling ability.

An article on Monday about the study of the literary history of word processing by Matthew G. Kirschenbaum, an associate professor of English at the University of Maryland, misstated part of a comment by Darren Wershler, the research chairman in media and contemporary literature at Concordia University in Montreal. He said, ''Writing about word processing when that's how you write is like trying to write about the back of your own head'' -- not ''like trying to write about your own hand.''

GOLDKLANG--Belle, age 93, on Wednesday, December 28, 2011. Wife of the late Norman; mother of Marvin, Dr. Gerald and Joyce; sister of Gladys Barnhard, Marilyn Chaiken, and the late Robert; also survived by 13 grandchildren, and 11 great-grandchildren. Services, Friday, 10:30am at Bernheim-Apter Kreitzman, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ. Memorials to: Magen David Adom, Hadassah or the charity of your choice.

An article on Thursday about a sharp drop in Italy's cost of borrowing misstated the worth in dollars of 450 billion euros, the amount Italy needs to raise in 2012. That amounts to $582 billion, not $582 million.

LEA--Barbara, of New York City and Raleigh, NC passed away on December 26, 2011. Singer, actress, writer, teacher, friend. You dedicated your life to championing the songs and writers who contributed to the Great American Songbook and you continue to serve as an inspiration to those who wish to follow in your footsteps. Through your recordings, radio programs and the memories of those who saw your live performances, your voice will never be stilled. A memorial will be held in New York City at a later date.

Remember when he was bad? When he was so good at being the guy you least wanted hiding in your closet? From the time Kevin Spacey appeared in ''American Beauty'' -- and won the 1999 Academy Award for best actor -- he has mostly specialized in delicate studies of moral ambivalence, of ordinary men tainted by everyday corruption and disillusion. (Check out his exemplary performance as a Lehman Brothers-style executive wrestling with his conscience -- and losing, of course -- in this year's ''Margin Call.'') Much of Mr. Spacey's stage work has followed suit, with high-voltage turns on Broadway as Eugene O'Neill's lyrical losers in ''The Iceman Cometh'' and ''A Moon for the Misbegotten.'' He even tried the conventional leading-man thing (''Pay It Forward'' on screen; the Cary Grant part in ''The Philadelphia Story'' onstage in London).

MORVILLO--Robert G. We mourn the loss of an esteemed colleague who set the standard for professional excellence. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Cathy, their four sons, Chris, Greg, Scott, and Rob, their wives and children. Hafetz Necheles and Rocco

Yankees caps are everywhere these days, perhaps even on planets yet to be discovered. One of the Libyan rebels who captured and then killed Libyan ruler Muammar el-Qaddafi was seen wearing a Yankees hat in one of the disturbing videos of the event.

Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-10pm. Funeral Mass Saturday 10:45am, St. Andrew Avellino RC Church.

An article last Friday about swing dancing in Manhattan misstated the surname of the musician whose cover of the Andrews Sisters' hit ''Bei Mir Bist Du Schön'' was played at the Frim Fram Jam in early December. He is Gordon Webster, not Walker.

R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, will climb Mount Kilimanjaro in January. He's doing it in part to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats. It was Alexander Graham Bell who once said, ''Before anything else, preparation is the key to success.'' Presently, I am in the final hours of my own preparation to ascend the largest free-standing mountain that this Earth has to offer, Mount Kilimanjaro.

SIDAMON-ERISTOFF--Constantine. The partners and staff of Lacher & Lovell-Taylor mourn the passing of our dear colleague and friend of a lifetime, whose wisdom, sage advice and leadership meant so much for so long to so many. Profound sympathies go to his beloved Anne, their children and grandchildren. Michael Lacher Lacher & Lovell-Taylor

Another year down, another drop of the ball, another chance to get it all right. The parties of New Year's Eve are ostensibly the way to start another trip around the Sun with a burst of exuberance. But really New Year's Eve is a confessional, a way to scrape off the muck of the year that's ending with loud music, maybe some libations and a collective sense of relief and exultation.

Set amid ocean and mountains, Vancouver is not the kind of place you associate with anarchic violence. But through the years there has been a weird local penchant for rioting over canceled rock concerts, visits from the prime minister, economic summits -- and, of course, whenever the Canucks lose Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals. So there we were June 15, a colleague and I venturing warily out of Rogers Arena through streets strewn with broken glass, burned-out cars and roving bands of hopped-up youths in Canucks sweaters. Not long before, we had been interviewing the celebrating Bruins, who were happily passing the Cup among themselves and their families. Now we were moving through the tail end of a riot that started among the 100,000 fans watching the game on giant screens outside the rink and spread throughout downtown, causing some 170 injuries and an estimated $5 million in damage.

GARVEY--Edward J. The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, senior staff and membership mourn the passing of AHRC New York City Board Member, Edward J. Garvey, and extend sympathy to his beloved and bereaved family. Ed was a member of AHRC since 1967 and became a member of the Board of Directors in 1969. During those years he served as Chapter President, as well as in other Board Officer positions, and he was the AHRC Annual Dinner Chairperson in 1981 and 2002 and was presented with AHRC's Anne Kraus Memorial Award for volunteerism in 2004. Ed was a strong, longtime supporter of the importance of direct care staff, and was an influential force of the AHRC Board in advocating on behalf of direct care staff. We offer our sincere condolences to Ed's wife, Rita, and children Edward, Robert, Joseph and Peter, and grandchildren. His son, Peter resides in an AHRC group residence. Ed will be remembered by his "AHRC family" and will be greatly missed. The funeral is scheduled to be held Saturday morning at 9:45am at St. Thomas Apostle Church, 87-49 87th St. in Woodhaven, NY. Dr. Melvin Gertner, President AHRC New York City; Dr. Lorrie Henderson, Executive Director, AHRC New York City

FRANKENTHALER--Helen Remembering Helen... No greater creative force and no greater force of the human spirit. Her embrace and love of life was a gift to the many lives she so dearly and profoundly touched. Forever missed, forever in my heart. With love, Ann (Freedman)

LeVINE--Robert Caldwell, died December 23, 2011 peacefully at his home in Naples, Florida. Robert is the beloved father of Jeananne Stine of Baltimore, MD, Robert B. LeVine of Brussels, Belgium, Mary LeVine of Naples, FL, Ron LeVine of New York City, NY and Jamie LeVine of Mamaroneck, NY and adored grandfather of Eric LeVine, Maryruth Stine, Marc LeVine, Sarabeth Stine, Terry LeVine, Charlie Stine, James Hickey and Ella LeVine. Born February 6, 1933 to Harry and Mary LeVine in Pittsburgh, PA, Robert graduated from Bethany College in 1955 and was married to Jean Bovill in 1956. The couple moved to Manhattan in 1959 and were long-time residents of New York City and Westchester County, NY before Robert retired from JP Morgan Investments; where he served as Managing Director. Jean died in 2008 and Bob joins her now just in time for Christmas. An elegant pair, they were an example of true love and devotion. Our home was filled with laughter and music, and our father was a true gentleman. We couldn't have been luckier. Friends will be received in Naples, FL Thursday December 29, from 3:00pm to 5:00pm, at the Diplomat, 1919 Gulf Shore Boulevard North. Friends will be received in Pittsburgh, PA Friday January 6, 2012 from 2:00pm to 4:00pm and 6: 00pm to 8:00pm at McDonald-Linn Funeral Home, 529 California Ave., Pittsburgh, PA with a Funeral Service the following day at 10:00am. Burial will take place at Union Dale Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in honor of Robert C. LeVine may be sent to Bethany College, Erickson Alumni Center, Bethany W. Va., 26032. For online condolences, please visit www.fullerfuneralhome.com

REDSTONE--Edward Stanton. of Rancho Mirage, CA, formerly of Boston, suddenly on December 23, 2011. Beloved husband of Madeline Redstone. Devoted son of the late Michael "Mickey" and Belle Redstone. Devoted father of Steven and Michele Sweetwood, Lawrence and Jennifer Sweetwood, Howard Sweetwood and his wife Jennifer and Michael Redstone. He was the adored and treasured grandfather of Amanda, Melissa, John, Theodore, Sydney and Maxwell Sweetwood and Jesse, Alex and Emily Redstone. Survived by his brother, Sumner Redstone and his family. He was preceded in death by his first wife Leila, his daughter Ruth Ann Redstone and his beloved grandson, Gabriel Adam Redstone. Mr. Redstone graduated Colgate University and Harvard Business School. He was partner with his brother Sumner Redstone in National Amusements Inc. before turning to a new career in banking. He was Chairman of the Martha's Vineyard National Bank and First Bank Corp. in Lowell, MA. In Boston he was involved with the Jimmy Fund created by his father. Mr. Redstone continued his philanthropy in California donating money and time to numerous causes: The Eisenhower Medical Center Board of Trustees and the Eisenhower Board of Directors, The Stroke Center Board of Directors, Betty Ford Center (where his wife Madeline, is on the Board of Trustees) and The Barbara Sinatra Children's Center. Services at The Brezniak-Rodman Chapel in Newton, MA on Thursday, December 29, 2011. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to The Betty Ford Center Foundation 39000 Bob Hope Drive, Rancho Mirage, CA 92270 or call (760-773-4105).

What a difference inches made when Michael Vick and Aaron Rodgers battled to the finish of an N.F.L. wild-card playoff game Jan. 9 in Philadelphia, where pessimism always reigned until Vick got loose on a potential run to the ultimate competitive redemption. But with less than a minute left and the Eagles trailing the Packers, 21-16, Vick dropped back to pass on first down from the Green Bay 27, about to risk it all on the part of his game long viewed with suspicion.

RACKOW--Marie-Therese. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with great sadness the passing of Marie-Therese Rackow, beloved wife of Asriel (Rickey), whose compassion and generosity helps strengthen the Jewish community in New York and beyond. We extend our condolences to Asriel; their children, Daniel, Jacqueline, and the late Robert; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

FRANKENTHALER--Helen. The Directors of Ameringer McEnery Yohe mourn the passing of a true American visionary. Helen Frankenthaler's life and art produced a remarkable body of work that inspired an artistic movement and continues to inspire new generations of artists and viewers in her unique pursuit of truth and beauty. We will miss your grace and friendship but just need to look at your paintings to find the source of your spirit and the joy you have brought to us. Will Ameringer Miles McEnery James Yohe

Can they be saved? Two musicals that flopped on Broadway in the 1980s but went on to become cult legends -- the stage adaptation of the novel ''Carrie'' and the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth heartbreaker ''Merrily We Roll Along'' -- will receive important revivals in New York this winter.

9 P.M. (Showtime) THE COMPANY MEN (2010) Ben Affleck, Tommy Lee Jones (above left, with Mr. Affleck) and Chris Cooper portray mid- to high-level employees at a fictional Boston company confronting sudden corporate downsizing -- the better to justify the chief executive's $22 million salary on the eve of a probable merger. ''Some of the details are wrong,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this feature-film directing debut from John Wells. ''Yet the minor miscalculations pale beside the film's unflinching depiction of the perils of heedless upward mobility that, for all the luxuries it affords, looks pretty grim.'' Playing an employee who rose from the factory floor to an executive suite across 30 years, Mr. Cooper, he added, ''gives a great, tragic performance of a man who lashes out like a trapped snake when he realizes that, in his words, 'my life ended, and nobody noticed.' '' 7 A.M. (Cinemax) THE MUSE (1999) Albert Brooks wrote (with Monica Johnson), directed and stars in this satire on the creative process, playing Steven Phillips, the kind of Hollywood screenwriter who is lauded with humanitarian awards rather than Oscars. In other words, he has lost his edge. Then, at the suggestion of Jack (Jeff Bridges), a much more stellar writer, Steven takes on a muse (Sharon Stone) named Sarah. She's the answer to Steven's prayers, Jack insists. Just look what she has done for Martin Scorsese. ''Although Sarah is played dreamily by Ms. Stone, who wafts through the film with an alarming mix of nymphlike abandon and horse sense, 'The Muse' does reach a philosophical dead end when it comes to appeasing her,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The Times.

MINKIN--George. July 18, 1920, died December 25, 2011 at age 91. He was the beloved husband of Helen Minkin. He was the son of Belle Celia Rusitzky and Jacob Minkin, a nationally known labor attorney. He was sibling to Sybil Jackson (deceased) and Noah Minkin (surviving) of Arlington, Virginia and uncle to Leonard Jackson (deceased) and Marsha Jackson, Larry Jackson and Nancy Riedel (surviving). Mr. Minkin served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II. He received B.A. (1941), LL.B. (1947), and LL.M. (1948) degrees from Harvard University, and from 1948 to 1950, he was Assistant Dean at Harvard Law School. He is a retired partner of Carter Ledyard & Milburn LLP. Over his long career, George earned the trust and respect of clients and colleagues alike. A private memorial service is planned.

New TV shows are liable to pop up any time these days, but over the last few years January has solidified its position as the start of television's second season. There are probably more series making their debuts or having their season premieres next month than there were during the official start of the 2011-12 broadcast network season in September. A quick scan turns up more than 70. The January premieres are a motley, cable-dominated bunch, including a reality show about taxidermy and the fifth season of ''Jersey Shore.'' But that also makes them a more vibrant collection than the fall's dire crop of new and returning network shows. And there are a few high-toned productions sprinkled in, like the new season of ''Downton Abbey'' and Dustin Hoffman's first appearance as a TV-series regular in HBO's ''Luck.''

The underground movement to draft Sarah Palin into the Iowa caucuses has moved onto television, with a group called Sarah Palin's Iowa Earthquake running ads across the state. The ad is decidedly low-tech and has run on some of Iowa's smaller broadcast stations like WOI in Des Moines, a sign that the group is not putting much money behind its campaign.

LEIGHTON--Florence Marie (Nicholls), age 98, on December 29, 2011, after an eight year battle with dementia. Beloved wife for 68 years of the late Lewis C. Leighton, loving mother of Robert and Barry Leighton and Diane Ackerman and adoring grandmother of Kelly Ackerman. Graveside services will be private.

A federal judge in New York has ruled that Marvel Entertainment owns the rights to Ghost Rider, a supernatural character possessed by a spirit of vengeance who first appeared in 1972. The character was the subject of a lawsuit by a writer seeking to cash in on lucrative movie rights, according to a report by The Associated Press. United States District Judge Katherine Forrest threw out on Wednesday the four-year-old claims by ruling that Gary Friedrich, a freelance writer, gave up all ownership rights when he signed checks including language-relinquishing rights to the predecessor companies of Marvel Entertainment. ''The law is clear that when an individual endorses a check subject to a condition, he accepts that condition,'' she wrote. On his MySpace page, Mr. Friedrich sets up a distinction between the comic book appearances by Ghost Rider and his use in other media, including a film starring Nicolas Cage in 2007. ''That movie and related products,'' he writes, ''were made and sold without any authorization or participation'' by him.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column last Friday about plans to release the Captain Beefheart album ''Bat Chain Puller'' more than 36 years after it was recorded misstated the given name of the biographer of Don Van Vliet, who performed as Captain Beefheart. The biographer, who said Mr. Van Vliet had resisted releasing the recording when he was alive, is Mike Barnes, not Mark.

One thing that apparently comes as a surprise to many people who love to intone about what history tells us about the dangers of debt is the fact that Britain has had remarkably high public debt relative to GDP for most of its modern history. But here's a question: how relevant are these historical debt levels to current concerns?
Math is a friend of mine. There have been a number of occasions in my life when doing the math on an economic model has led me to conclusions very different from my preconceptions.

I love making New Year's resolutions. No matter if 25 percent of resolutions are forgotten within a week, and 88 percent go by the wayside entirely. It's a time to wipe the slate clean, reset expectations and get excited about what lies ahead. It's a time for hope, and I'll take hope for any reason. While I have run across a number of excellent lists for both business and personal resolutions this week, I thought I'd share some of mine and invite you to share yours. Bring on 2012!

DES MOINES -- Newt Gingrich openly cried on Friday morning during an event with a group of mothers in an Iowa coffee shop as he described his own mother's illness. FRANKENTHALER--Helen. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn the loss of Helen Frankenthaler. Her searing intellect and fearless innovations launched a new direction for postwar painting. By experimenting with the qualities of paint and canvas, she was able to create, in her own words, "explosive landscapes, worlds and distances, held on a flat surface." Frankenthaler's work was first shown at the Whitney in 1955 and has subsequently been included in over 40 exhibitions at the Museum. A mid-career retrospective of her work was organized by the Whitney in 1969. The Museum is also proud to hold close to a dozen works in our permanent collection; the first of which, Blue Territory, was acquired from the 1955 Annual. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Stephen M. DuBrul Jr., and her stepdaughters, Jeannie and Lise Motherwell. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg Alice Pratt Brown, Director Donna De Salvo, Chief Curator and Deputy Director for Programs

Big-box stores may be worrying about their sales on Black Friday, Mega Monday and all the days in between, but sellers of high-end contemporary art seem to have done well this year. On the evidence of some auction results, at least, the market for such art rose significantly as jittery investors put their money into art instead of stocks, Bloomberg News reported. ''The art market is a place for new people these days,'' Christophe Van de Weghe, a New York dealer, was quoted as saying. ''There are Americans nobody has seen before who are excited by this world and who want an alternative to shares. And then there are buyers coming in from places like India and China.''

A performing arts center planned for the World Trade Center site has taken a step forward with the naming of a board by the National September 11 Memorial & Museum foundation. On the list are the developers Larry Silverstein and John E. Zuccotti; Christy Ferer, founder and chief executive of the Vidicom video company; Julie Menin, chairwoman of Community Board 1; and Zenia Mucha, executive vice president of the Walt Disney Company. Joseph C. Daniels, president of the Sept. 11 foundation, added that Patricia E. Harris, the first deputy mayor, would serve as an ex-officio member representing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Naming a board was a prerequisite for tapping into $100 million that the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation had set aside for the center, which is to be designed by Frank Gehry. Even though the deadline was the end of this year, the naming of the board members, like other issues related to the World Trade Center site, including financing for the Sept. 11 museum, had been held up by tension between Mayor Bloomberg and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. The governor still has the option of naming someone to the board.

Theater NEW BROADWAY MUSICAL The crashing, crushing and smashing sounds that regularly emanate from ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' -- the accident-prone $65 million musical now (and perhaps forever) in previews -- have all but drowned out the advance word on a show that, in a Spidey-free season, would surely have some of the loudest buzz on Broadway. That's ''The Book of Mormon'' (opening March 24 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater), a singing, dancing history of the founding of the Mormon Church that also tells the parallel story of two contemporary disciples who go to spread Joseph Smith's gospel in Uganda.

An article on Friday about the closing of a discount retailer in Boston misstated the name of the store in the headline and in some references. The store is Filene's Basement, not simply Filene's. (Filene's Basement was opened in 1909 in the basement of Filene's department store in Boston. The two became separate companies in 1991. Federated Department Stores acquired the Filene's department stores in 2005 and closed some and converted the remaining stores to Macy's in 2006.)
An article on Monday about Christmas morning in New York misstated the number of visitors to the city. About a million visit the city each week, not each year.

LeVINE--Robert Caldwell, died December 23, 2011 peacefully at his home in Naples, Florida. Robert is the beloved father of Jeananne Stine of Baltimore, MD, Robert B. LeVine of Brussels, Belgium, Mary LeVine of Naples, FL, Ron LeVine of New York City, NY and Jamie LeVine of Mamaroneck, NY and adored grandfather of Eric LeVine, Maryruth Stine, Marc LeVine, Sarabeth Stine, Terry LeVine, Charlie Stine, James Hickey and Ella LeVine. Born February 6, 1933 to Harry and Mary LeVine in Pittsburgh, PA, Robert graduated from Bethany College in 1955 and was married to Jean Bovill in 1956. The couple moved to Manhattan in 1959 and were long-time residents of New York City and Westchester County, NY before Robert retired from JP Morgan Investments; where he served as Managing Director. Jean died in 2008 and Bob joins her now just in time for Christmas. An elegant pair, they were an example of true love and devotion. Our home was filled with laughter and music, and our father was a true gentleman. We couldn't have been luckier. Friends will be received in Naples, FL Thursday December 29, from 3:00pm to 5:00pm, at the Diplomat, 1919 Gulf Shore Boulevard North. Friends will be received in Pittsburgh, PA Friday January 6, 2012 from 2:00pm to 4:00pm and 6: 00pm to 8:00pm at McDonald-Linn Funeral Home, 529 California Ave., Pittsburgh, PA with a Funeral Service the following day at 10:00am. Burial will take place at Union Dale Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in honor of Robert C. LeVine may be sent to Bethany College, Erickson Alumni Center, Bethany W. Va., 26032. For online condolences, please visit www.fullerfuneralhome.com

A cover article this weekend about the legality of visual artists' appropriating the images of others misstates the action the Supreme Court took in a 1994 case regarding the group 2 Live Crew's sampling of a Roy Orbison song. The court referred the case back to a lower court and, in the process, clarified the legal standard to be applied; the court did not find fair use in the case.
KATZ--Ira. We can't believe 5 years has passed already. You are missed and loved as much today as ever. With love, Elaine, Jeffrey, Suzi, your grandchildren and rest of your loving family.

On ''Fox News Sunday,'' Mike Huckabee claimed that if the weather is bad in Iowa this Tuesday, Representative Ron Paul will win the state caucuses over Mitt Romney, whose supporters are not as dedicated. Current forecasts predict the weather will be relatively balmy, with no chance of rain or snow - which, according to Mr. Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, will favor Mr. Romney. A 2007 study in the Journal of Politics shows that weather does influence voter turnout in the general election: Every inch of rain tends to decrease turnout by almost one percentage point, while every inch of snow above a precinct's historical average for the week deters roughly half a percentage point of voters.

BERKELEY--Norborne, Jr.,Bunny of East Hampton and Manhattan New York and former President of Chemical Bank, died peacefully, at age 89, in his home in East Hampton, on December 29th, 2011 following a two-month illness with congestive heart failure. Norborne was born June 5, 1922 in Bethlehem, PA, the only son of Norborne Berkeley and Dorothea Randolph Berkeley. His one sister, Dorothea Berkeley Brush, died in 1991. Mr. Berkeley was President of Chemical Bank and Chemical NY Corporation (now JPMorgan Chase) from 1973-1982. He was a Director of both the Corporation and the Bank since 1972, and had been with Chemical since 1950, serving in a variety of positions before becoming President. From January, 1982 until June, 1982 he served as Chairman of the Executive Committee, at which time he retired at the age of 60. Mr. Berkeley was a graduate of the Episcopal High School in Alexandria, Virginia (1941), Yale University, BA, (Class of 1945), where he was a member of the Senior Society, Scroll and Key. He held an LL.B. degree from the University of Virginia (1949) and completed the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration in 1966. In World War II, Mr. Berkeley served in Europe with the US Field Artillery, First Army V Corps, from 1943-1945 and participated in five major campaigns, including the Normandy Invasion. During his career, he served on numerous corporate, educational and charitable boards including Freeport McMoran Inc., Uniroyal Inc., Anglo Energy LTD; Tuskegee University, Episcopal High School, New Canaan Country Day School (Board President), Metropolitan Opera (Managing Director), Whitney Museum of American Art, Local Initiatives Support Corporation, LISC, (Chairman), and the Vera Institute of Justice. Mr. Berkeley was appointed by President Ford, and served two Administrations (both Republican and Democratic) on the US Advisory Committee for Trade Negotiations. Mr. Berkeley was an avid and accomplished sportsman throughout his life, including baseball at Yale, squash, skiing and golf. He enjoyed playing his father's ukelele and singing old, family songs; the cultural opportunities in New York City, especially the theatre; and travel around the world. His friendships formed at Yale were very special to him throughout his life and his sense of humor, value system and compassion for his fellow man will always be remembered by his many, many friends and family. He was the very loving and adored husband of Jennifer Puchta Berkeley for twenty one years and had three children by a first marriage to Diane Gould Berkeley: Sally Berkeley Tiller, Raleigh, North Carolina; Dr. Anne Randolph Berkeley, Wilmington, North Carolina; Norborne Berkeley III, Bill New York, NY, plus three wonderful grandchildren: Gabe and Jocelyn Tiller and Carmen Berkeley. Caring nieces, nephews and cousins and, his beloved Labrador retriever, Skye, also survive him. The family kindly requests no flowers and instead, if desired, suggests donations to one's own favorite charity, in Norborne Berkeley Jr.'s memory. A celebration of his life will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton, NY at 11:00am, on Saturday, January 21st, 2012.

DES MOINES -- With Representative Ron Paul performing solidly in Republican presidential polls - and near the top in Iowa - a recurring question nags at political wise-guys: Will the Texas libertarian's corps of loyal and energized supporters be an asset to an eventual Republican nominee? Or will they be a liability if that nominee is not named Ron Paul -- meaning, they will vote only for Mr. Paul as a third-party or write-in candidate, or stay home altogether, which would probably help the prospective Democratic nominee, President Obama?

1:13 p.m. | Updated DES MOINES -- One thing about having children campaign for you: They don't always stay on message. At an event in New Hampshire featuring four of Mitt Romney's sons, one addressed a question about why Mr. Romney has not yet released his income tax returns.

An article on Friday about the enhanced stature of cable installers misstated the speed of the Internet service that was set up in the home of a Comcast customer. It is 22 megabits per second, not megabytes.

The rapper C-Murder has failed to convince a Louisiana appeals court that his conviction on a second-degree murder charge was flawed, The Associated Press reported. In 2009 a jury found C-Murder, whose real name is Corey Miller, guilty of fatally shooting a 16-year-old fan during a fight in 2002 at a nightclub in the New Orleans area. Sentenced to life in prison without parole, Mr. Miller appealed the conviction, saying the trial was unfair. But on Wednesday Louisiana's Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the jury's decision. The three-judge panel rejected Mr. Miller's arguments that prosecutors had systematically kept black people off the jury and that the judge had allowed jurors to hear ''prejudicial and unsubstantiated'' testimony.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's annual interfaith breakfast is typically a feel-good event, a chance for the mayor and other city officials to mingle with representatives of many religions. But the mood at this year's event, held on Friday morning at the New York Public Library, was dampened slightly by a controversy involving accusations of police surveillance of Muslim communities and a long-running dispute over religious groups meeting in public schools.

Remember when you were a kid and your parents harped on the importance of ''delayed gratification'' to get ahead in life? (You know: Put that birthday money in the piggy bank and save for something nice, instead of blowing it all now on Milky Way bars.) Well, it turns out that your propensity to wait (or not) is also reflected in your credit score, according to a study from researchers at Columbia and Stanford published online in Psychological Science, a journal of the Association for Psychological Science. (Here's a link to the press release, though the journal itself is behind a pay wall.)

A repeat of ''The Big Bang Theory'' was enough to give CBS an easy ratings victory (in total viewers and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic) on Thursday, according to Nielsen data. All of the networks had a full slate of repeats, resulting in lower viewership totals across the broadcast board, but the audience for CBS's geeky comedy has proved to be very loyal, even for previously aired episodes. It still drew 10.2 million total viewers Thursday night, losing less than a third of its fall live audience average of 14.7 million for new episodes. Although its authenticity has been called into question, Discovery Channel's ''Moonshiners'' has frequently found itself to be among the top-rated cable shows on Wednesday nights. The most recent episode tied for the highest-rated cable program among adults 18-to-49 to go with a total of 2.6 million viewers.

The 2012 Yankees are shaping up to look an awful lot like the 2011 version after the team reached a deal to bring back Andruw Jones. Jones, 34, was a dependable fourth outfielder who provided a solid right-handed bat off the bench for the Yankees last season, with 13 home runs and 33 runs batted in in 190 at-bats.

JACKSON--George Duncan, Emeritus Professor of History at Hofstra University, died at his home on the morning of December 25, 2011 from complications which arose from a 2001 accident that left him a quadriplegic on a ventilator. He is survived by his wife Karen Schiller Jackson, four biological children and three step-children.

JEFFERS--Lucy Latane Gordan, December 20, peacefully at home after a long illness at age 93. Widow of William Nicholson Jeffers. Survived by her daughter and son-in-law Anne and Thomas Robinson, grandchildren Emily and William, and numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral services in progress. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Calvary Hospice would be appreciated.

Before he departed the stage, before the curtain dropped and the N.B.A. plunged into six months of self-imposed darkness, LeBron James gave his critics a stinging farewell to remember. The Miami Heat had just lost the championship to the Dallas Mavericks. James was a prime culprit, for his abysmal fourth-quarter play throughout the finals. To those who resented the Heat's bravado and bluster, this was karmic payoff. So, James was asked, did it bother him that people were celebrating his failure?

The Consumer Federation of America estimates that more than 325,000 auto accidents will occur during this year's holiday travel period, resulting in more than 200,000 claims filed with the nation's insurance companies. To help drivers navigate the claims process, and avoid getting underpaid, the federation has published a new guide, ''Navigating the Auto Claims' Maze: Getting the Settlement You Deserve.''

There are few rituals in sports as anticipated as baseball's opening day: the thaw of winter, the sunshine and green grass, the hope that a championship is in the offing. For the 30,000 fans at QVC Marine Field on April 12 who went to see the Chiba Lotte Marines play the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles, there were also flags at half-staff, darkened scoreboards and a moment of silence for the thousands of people who died in the earthquake and tsunami that devastated Japan a month earlier.

FRANKENTHALER--Helen. The Directors of Ameringer McEnery Yohe mourn the passing of a true American visionary. Helen Frankenthaler's life and art produced a remarkable body of work that inspired an artistic movement and continues to inspire new generations of artists and viewers in her unique pursuit of truth and beauty. We will miss your grace and friendship but just need to look at your paintings to find the source of your spirit and the joy you have brought to us. Will Ameringer Miles McEnery James Yohe

A cheery holiday card from Tati and Gerry at Ansonia Records rests on the counter of Manny Rivera's Brooklyn music store, hidden behind a pile of compact discs, domino sets and assorted tropical knick-knacks. It's a nice, personal touch in a business that has long since lost it. Forty two years ago - when Manny was born into the retail record business - companies like Ansonia could barely keep up with the demand for Latin music, from classic trios, romantic duos and swinging mambo bands. Then Willie, Hector, Johnny and Jerry led the Fania invasion, taking no prisoners and turning New York City into the spiritual home of salsa.

An article in some editions on Thursday about a group of Muslim leaders who plan to boycott Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's annual interfaith breakfast misstated the name of a group whose New York leader, Zead Ramadan, is boycotting the event. It is the Council on American-Islamic Relations, not the Council on Arab-American Relations.

Connecticut's 11-game run to the N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship began with a win over DePaul and ended with a victory against Butler, but it will long be remembered for Kemba Walker's winning shot against Pittsburgh on March 10. With 18 seconds left in their Big East tournament quarterfinal and the score tied, 74-74, the Huskies went through the motions of drawing up plans for the final shot, but there was never any doubt on either bench that Walker would be the one to take it.

MINKIN--George. July 18, 1920, died December 25, 2011 at age 91. He was the beloved husband of Helen Minkin. He was the son of Belle Celia Rusitzky and Jacob Minkin, a nationally known labor attorney. He was sibling to Sybil Jackson (deceased) and Noah Minkin (surviving) of Arlington, Virginia and uncle to Leonard Jackson (deceased) and Marsha Jackson, Larry Jackson and Nancy Riedel (surviving). Mr. Minkin served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II. He received B.A. (1941), LL.B. (1947), and LL.M. (1948) degrees from Harvard University, and from 1948 to 1950, he was Assistant Dean at Harvard Law School. He is a retired partner of Carter Ledyard & Milburn LLP. Over his long career, George earned the trust and respect of clients and colleagues alike. A private memorial service is planned.

Death placed his hand on someone we loved more than life itself, and yet we still don't understand. Mom and I grieve for you at every moment. Rest in peace, sweet boy. Dad

Once again, a reality television show has viewers asking whether it's real or unreal. This time, the authorities are answering with a no. The series in question is ''Moonshiners,'' a new entrant on the Discovery Channel that ostensibly shows people in rural Virginia who make their own alcohol and the state agents who pursue them. In an online interview one person suggested that he actually made moonshine, which is illegal; in response, the agency that regulates alcohol in Virginia said on Thursday that the show was just a dramatization. ''If illegal activity was actually taking place, the Virginia ABC Bureau of Law Enforcement would have taken action,'' the agency told The Associated Press.
