An article on Thursday about the growth of solar power in India overstated the number of American homes that could have their needs met by 20,000 megawatts of solar panels, the amount that India is planning to install by 2020. Those panels would produce an amount of energy equal to the consumption of about 3.3 million homes, not 20 million.

HANDLER--Evelyn. The family of Evelyn Handler mourns the loss of a loving and devoted wife, mother, sister and grandmother. Through the many accomplishments over an illustrious career that spans Hunter College, the University of New Hampshire, Brandeis University, the California Academy of Sciences and Board of Director positions that include the Student Loan Corporation, Evelyn improved the lives of thousands upon thousands of young people with boundless energy, dedication, creativity and a remarkable understanding of how to make an institution "great." We will miss her love, guidance and support without measure. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the University of New Hampshire School of Law, 2 White St, Concord, NH 03301.

One of Spain's most popular holiday events, the colorful Procession of the Three Kings, will proceed down the Paseo de la Castellana from Nuevos Ministerios to Plaza de Cibeles on Friday between 6:30 p.m. and 9 p.m. It features the elaborately dressed kings, their pages and helpers, who ride on floats distributing sweets to the children lining the route. There are at least 30 carriages, theatrical re-enactments, dancers, musicians, jugglers, street performers, royal pages, giant puppets and many other entertaining characters.According to the Bible, at this time of year, three wise and powerful kings brought gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh to the infant Jesus. To celebrate the occasion, on Jan. 5, children in Spain go to bed early, awaiting the morning, when they hope to find the presents that they requested of the three kings in letters written on Boxing Day, Dec. 26. They leave shoes on windowsills or balconies or under the Christmas tree to be filled with toys.

If 2010 and 2011 are any guides, about 100,000 of the most serious sorts of crimes will be committed in the city in the coming year, from murder to auto theft. The Police Department will remain under public scrutiny. This year may determine the fates of 16 officers indicted in October in a ticket-fixing investigation in the Bronx. Plea negotiations for several officers accused in a gun-and-cigarette smuggling case will unfold. And a panel of former prosecutors will most likely issue findings on the integrity of the city's crime statistics -- a rare instance in which Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has opened internal books to outside review.

From farmers to power plant operators to homeowners, everyone in Texas is wondering when the grueling 15-month drought will end. The answer, alas, is that nobody knows. Recent rain and snow have pushed state precipitation totals above the average for December, but this appears to be ''a short-term aberration in an overall long-term dry pattern,'' Victor Murphy, a southern regional official with the National Weather Service, said in an e-mail.

In 1958, Richard and Mildred Loving were arrested in a nighttime raid in their bedroom by the sheriff of Caroline County, Va. Their crime: being married to each other. The Lovings -- Mildred, who was of African-American and Native American descent, and Richard, a bricklayer with a blond buzz cut -- were ordered by a judge to leave Virginia for 25 years. This month, the International Center of Photography is mounting a show of Grey Villet's photographs of the couple. That exhibit is complemented by an HBO documentary telling the story of the Lovings' struggle to return home after living in exile in Washington, where Mildred, gentle in person but persistent on paper, wrote pleading letters to Robert F. Kennedy and the A.C.L.U. Two lawyers took their case to the Supreme Court, whichstruck down miscegenation laws in more than a dozen states. The Lovings' belief in the simple rightness of their plea never wavered. Asked by one of his lawyers if he had a message for the Supreme Court, Richard said he did: ''Tell the court I love my wife.'' Number of states where interracial marriage was illegal in 1958: 24

FRANKENTHALER--Helen The family of Helen Frankenthaler, the eminent American abstract painter, announced with profound sadness her death at the age of 83, on December 27, 2011, at her home in Connecticut after a long illness. Deeply loved by her family and cherished by her many friends around the world, she is survived by her husband of seventeen years, Stephen M. DuBrul, Jr.; and by her nieces, Ellen Iseman and Beverly Ross, and four nephews, Peter Iseman, Fred Iseman, Alfred Ross, and Clifford Ross. She is also survived by two stepdaughters, Lise Motherwell and Jeannie Motherwell, from her first marriage, to the artist Robert Motherwell, and by two stepchildren, Jennifer DuBrul and Nicholas DuBrul, as well as three grandnephews, two grandnieces, four step-granddaughters, two step-great-grandsons, and one step-great-granddaughter. Helen Frankenthaler was born in Manhattan in 1928, the third daughter of New York State Supreme Court Judge Alfred Frankenthaler and Martha Lowenstein Frankenthaler. Her sisters, Marjorie Frankenthaler Iseman and Gloria Frankenthaler Ross Bookman, predeceased her. Helen Frankenthaler graduated from The Dalton School, having attended The Brearley School and The Horace Mann School. A 1949 graduate of Bennington College, she served as a member of the College's Board of Trustees from 1967 to 1982. She was the recipient of twenty-six honorary degrees, as well as other notable honors, including the National Medal of the Arts, in 2001. Most recently, she was appointed as an Honorary Academician of the Royal Academy of Arts, London in 2011. From 1985 to 1992, she was a member of the National Council on the Arts, part of the National Endowment for the Arts. A perfectionist and planner to the end, she made clear her wish to be buried at her alma mater, Bennington College, in Vermont, where a private ceremony will be held. A memorial service in New York City will be announced in the weeks ahead. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Bennington College or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York City. Helen was a family treasure, a national treasure, and will be forever missed by those who knew her well and by a public who admired her vibrant works of art. In her career she was an original, brilliant, energetic, witty presence who shone brightly in our firmament. With her passing, her world and her family are left with a deep void and diminished color.

WERNER--Anne Power, died of cancer on Christmas Day 2011, at her home in North Hampton, New Hampshire. Anne has no immediate survivors. She does leave, however, her good friend, Father Daniel Morrissey, and a host of others enriched by their relationship with this extraordinary woman. Anne was born in Paris in 1928, the only child of Annabella, an international film star. In 1939 Annabella married the American actor, Tyrone Power, who adopted Anne. She always spoke fondly of Power, and he of her. On April 5, 1941, Tyrone wrote in his journal, "Today is Anni's birthday. I told Anni there was another present out front. She didn't say a word, just went over and touched the horse. After hugging the breath out of me, she kept whispering over and over again, My horse, my dear little horse." Anne grew up in the Hollywood of the 1940s, a dazzling time. Yet in her telling of it Anne was not dazzled. The simple joys of daily family life remained most vivid to her. Her parents entertained some of the most beautiful and celebrated people in the world, and from her upstairs room she could watch the arriving guests, the Clark Gables, the Gary Coopers, the Henry Fondas, Judy Garland. To Anne they were not celebrities, and certainly not icons, but rather friends of the family from down the street. From childhood Anne spoke French and English. In her twenties she became fluent in German. Throughout her life she read broadly in those languages, deepening her love of history. Her experience as a world traveler made her an informed conversationalist. She was thoughtful, articulate, an eager listener, who genuinely wanted to know what others had to say. Anne exercised horses at Longchamp Racecourse in Paris. She also taught actors to ride, and while on the set of Decision Before Dawn, she met Oskar Werner, a prominent actor in European classical theater and film. After they married in 1954, they travelled throughout the world as Oskar became an international film star, but they lived in Liechtenstein. Anne was always very grateful that she was able to come to know the great literature of the German language and the music and opera of Werner's native Austria. Their marriage ended in 1968. Anne returned to the United States, settling in North Hampton, a small New Hampshire seaside town. She put down roots which deepened over time, taking a position as an aide teaching deaf children to speak, a job she held for nearly twenty years. After retiring she continued to work as a volunteer at the North Hampton Library. In 1998 Anne designed and built a home filled with light and welcoming to guests. She lived only a mile from the ocean, which she loved in all its moods, and could walk to it almost every day. Anne kept close ties to France and returned each summer to Annabella's sheep farm, Contramundo, in the foothills of the Pyrenees, outside St Jean de Luz. There in the Basque countryside Anne welcomed many American friends together with Romanov emigres, writers, politicians and artists who visited her mother. For each guest Anne made the beauty and vitality of Contramundo a unique and unforgettable memory. Tolstoy writes in War and Peace, which Anne reread many times, "Love hinders death. Love is life. Everything, everything I understand, I understand only because I love. Everything is, everything exists, only because I love. Everything is connected only by that." Contributions in the name of Anne Power Werner may be made to the Public Broadcasting System, 2100 Crystal Drive, Arlington, VA 22201, or to the New Hampshire Public Radio, 2 Pillsbury Street, Suite 600, Concord, NH 03301. To sign an on line guest book, please visit www.brewittfuneralhome.com

This year, for the first time in decades, New Yorkers will be allowed to hail livery cabs legally on the street. Thousands of cars, not painted yellow but equipped with meters and credit-card readers, will be licensed to pick up fares outside of busy parts of Manhattan. How the zones will be enforced remains an open question. If you can't still find a taxi, you may be able to rent a bike. By summertime, the city will unveil an ambitious bike-sharing system, with 10,000 bicycles available for short-term rentals at 600 locations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Similar programs are immensely popular in London, Paris and Washington, but critics worry about congestion, safety and where the kiosks will be placed.

The consequences of lawmakers' roughly $5.4 billion reduction in state financing to public education in 2011 will dominate 2012. The budget slashing has already galvanized more than half of the school districts in Texas into four different lawsuits against the state, which will wind up in court next fall. In March, official numbers of how many and what types of employees were laid off by school districts will be released, just before the primaries -- the first real indicator of the budget cuts' political ramifications. Also in the spring, the state's approximately 350,000 ninth graders will be the first to take the end-of-course exams that are part of Texas' new standardized testing system.

BUCK--Richard M.,"Dick," 81, on December 20, 2011. Only child of Earl R. and Florence M. Buck from Kendall, NY. BA and MA, SUNY Albany; MS, Columbia University. Dick joined the New York Public Library system in 1959 and in 1967 began his 30-year tenure as Administrator at the Library for the Performing Arts, where he initiated and directed a multitude of exhibits, galas and fundraisers, including the annual "White Elephant Bazaars." He was Secretary-Treasurer of the Theater Library Association from 1970-96 and Councilor of the American Library Association from 1990-94. In 1997, Dick moved permanently to Miami Beach, where he was active until his final years with the Miami Design Preservation League. He is survived by a cousin, Dennis Buck of Manhattan. Memorial to be held on January 6th from 6-8pm at the Mantell Plaza, 255 W. 24th St., Miami Beach, FL 33140.

Ronan, 14: Last spring I decided: no more being a guy; I want to be a girl. I've felt it coming for maybe two years. Then last spring I tried it, and I thought I'd just go for it. I dress like a girl too. I like it so far. I go to a school called FACE, and it's very open, so no one was surprised. I'm not the only person who does this. I wake up at about 5:40 every morning. Usually I'll stay in bed five minutes, then I'll take a shower, blow-dry my hair and brush it out. Then I'll get dressed and do my makeup. I do my own makeup. My mom doesn't do makeup with me. She doesn't like makeup. The earrings I got as a gift. I think my grandmother gave them to me.

CAROLINA HERRERA BÁEZ, not to be confused with her mother, Carolina Herrera, has been a quiet influence in her family's atelier for most of her life. But it isn't until now, with the introduction of her own accessory, that she could call herself a designer. The Mini Matryoshka bag, a bucket tote in Goya leather, comes in seven Bauhaus-inspired color blocks, like canary yellow and grass green, or a Mondrian-esque red and black. There is much in the capsule that can be credited to her mother. ''She has a small-purse philosophy,'' Ms. Herrera Báez said, explaining why, for example, the bag is the compact size that it is. ''You carry only what is essential.'' But the graphic look and feel are original. ''Sometimes, great ideas on paper are just that,'' Ms. Herrera Báez said. ''The ability to fine-tune an aesthetic in tandem with intuition is a good trait for any designer to have.'' Tuck that one in your tote. Carolina Herrera Mini Matryoshka bag, $470 at CH Carolina Herrera boutiques; (212) 744-2076. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

An opinion essay on Dec. 11 about anti-Catholic prejudice during the 1928 presidential campaign of Alfred E. Smith referred imprecisely to Hugh L. Carey, and a correction in this space on Dec. 18 erroneously attributed a distinction to Mr. Smith. While Mr. Smith (who served from 1919 to 1920 and again from 1923 to 1928) was the first Catholic to be elected governor of New York State (and Mr. Carey, who served from 1975 to 1982, was the second), Mr. Smith was not the first Catholic governor. The correction also referred incorrectly to Malcolm Wilson, governor from 1973 to 1974. He was one of several Catholics who succeeded to the position without having been elected (including Martin H. Glynn, who served from 1913 to 1914 and was the state's first Catholic governor). Neither Mr. Wilson nor Mr. Carey was the second Catholic governor; Mr. Smith was.

The drumbeat of anticipation for the game between No. 1 Louisiana State and No. 2 Alabama began in September and reached a fever pitch by early November. It was billed as a once-a-decade regular-season game until it suddenly did not matter anymore. On the morning of Nov. 5, a grand jury report became public and once again put the focus of the college sports world far off the field. The report described child sexual abuse accusations against the former Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky, which set off a firestorm that cost the jobs of Joe Paterno, the longtime coach, and Graham B. Spanier, the university president.

AT the start of a promising new year -- and let's face it, they're all promising -- how much of the city really cares about you? You think steel cares? Steel is cold. Glass? Glass will cut you. Neon cares. Neon wants you to come inside where it's warm. It promises everything that lures people to New York: temptation and salvation, sustenance and health, romance and prophecy. No two neon signs are alike, and individual signs change over time, starting to flicker or losing a letter. Even at its most knowing, neon keeps its innocence.

Here's a sampling of readers' responses to Alastair Macaulay's column on the choreographer Merce Cunningham as his company completed its two-year legacy tour. ''Without the bias of an education in dance, I came to Merce on my own. Sitting in the rafters at City Center every March, I'd watch the legions leave halfway through, unable to grasp the language of his gestures or the sounds that accompanied them. Years later when coincidence led me to share my life for some years with a dancer in the company, Merce admitted his pleasure at testing the limits of his audience, suggesting in not so many words that the ones who made it through somehow earned the pleasures he suffered, and earned, in his own art.''

PHILADELPHIA - One of the chief topics of conversation at any N.H.L. Winter Classic is where the next Winter Classic will be held. The New York area is a candidate for the 2013 outdoor game, according to John Collins, the N.H.L.'s chief operating officer and the architect behind the league's wildly successful outdoor game.

IT was pitch black at 8:30 a.m. on a frigid Icelandic morning, but at least there was no snow falling. Though cloud cover the night before had scuttled my chance to see the Northern Lights, my plan for a 36-hour road trip from Reykjavik, ending a great four days in Iceland, was in full effect. I had spent the previous day's precious daylight hours (about five at this time of year) seeing the geysers, waterfalls and icy landscapes of the Golden Circle, a popular route that loops northeast from the capital of Reykjavik and back again. When the sun disappeared, at about 3 p.m., I headed southeast to the snow-covered coast, skirting imposing mountains to arrive at a guesthouse called Vellir, on Route 219 off the main highway, where I planned to spend the night. I was to get moving before the sun rose, driving the 10 miles to Vik -- supposedly a picturesque village of 300 people, black sand beaches and amazing rock formations.
BEST PICTURE A.O. SCOTT

It was not a stellar year for huge sport utility vehicles, and the big news in pickup trucks was hidden under the hood -- Ford's shift to an efficient V-6 engine, replacing a thirsty base-level V-8 in its perennially bestselling F-150. A wave of new electric cars and plug-in hybrids may be on the way, but the internal combustion engine showed no signs of stepping aside for an upstart successor. On the contrary, some new models were powered by gasoline-burning piston engines, often in downsized form and paired with ultra efficient transmissions, that delivered mileage nearly unthinkable a few years ago.

Hotel restaurants often reinvent themselves to keep up with food trends. At a time when new is the norm, though, some long-standing restaurants are sticking to tried and true. The Polo Lounge at the Beverly Hills Hotel, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year, is one of those exceptions. It opened in 1949 with an American menu, and six of its original dishes are still available. Two of them -- the tortilla soup and the McCarthy salad, above -- make up 15 percent of the sales for the restaurant.

All signs point to the public release of performance rankings for thousands of New York City teachers in 2012. The records rate 12,000 of the city's 75,000 teachers and are based on how much progress students made on the state's standardized tests, a controversial measurement tool. After several court rulings favoring the rankings' disclosure, the teachers' union is running out of legal options to keep them confidential. Losing on this issue would not be likely to undermine the union's political clout, though. Public education will undoubtedly play a central role in the 2013 mayoral race, and candidates will be expected to lay out their visions for the future once their campaigns pick up steam. One key question will be whether they will push to keep the schools under mayoral control.

When the Big City Book Club reconvenes for its next online literary discussion on Jan. 10, we will be talking about Alfred Kazin's ''A Walker in the City,'' the writer's 1951 memoir of growing up in Brownsville, Brooklyn. The book is a celebration of Mr. Kazin's poor immigrant childhood in the pushcart universe of 1920s and '30s Jewish New York. It is also a record of his path out of that world, and his arrival among the New York Intellectuals, the storied group of Jewish writers and social theorists who graduated from City College and included Daniel Bell, Nathan Glazer and Irving Howe, among others.

When I was young, I played a dice baseball game for hundreds of hours a year. My favorite part of managing was using the bullpen. I loved all the random names bunched together on the stat sheet with the big stars. Sometimes, I recreated old World Series by studying the cumulative box scores in the Baseball Encyclopedia. I tried to use everybody. How awful it would feel, I reasoned, to be eligible for the World Series but never play.

COVERING more than two decades, ''Pretty Much Everything'' (Taschen, $700) is the first comprehensive monograph of the work of the Dutch wife-and-husband photo team Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin. The three-volume set, which includes a silkscreen print, jumbles together 666 photos. Some were originally ads; others first appeared in gallery shows. The resulting mix, in which glamorous celebrity portraits meet androgynous fine-art photos and manneristic fashion editorials, may seem a bit schizophrenic. But Ms. van Lamsweerde said that the book was constructed to show that these distinct genres matter less and less, at least for globally in-demand photographers like them. ''Sometimes our work that's been published as an advertising campaign ends up on the walls of a museum,'' she said. Above, ''Hilary and Irina at the St. Regis Hotel,'' originally published in 2006 in Self Service magazine. STEPHEN HEYMAN

Gambling is becoming a blood sport among developers. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants a constitutional amendment to legalize full casino gambling. That's the easy part. There are already nine racetrack casinos and six American Indian casinos in New York. But the battle will be fierce over how many new casinos to allow, and where. The racetracks don't want competition. Other interests would cut the ties between casino gambling and horse racing. The Seneca and Oneida Nations oppose legalization. The Las Vegas and Atlantic City outfits favor casinos everywhere, especially in Manhattan; otherwise they will try to kill the amendment. What will Donald J. Trump or Stephen A. Wynn do? In the meantime, it's a full employment act for the lobbyists.
UPPER EAST SIDE CO-OP $965,000

In the wake of its latest high-profile exoneration, the Texas criminal justice community is grappling with the issue of prosecutorial misconduct. Murder charges against Michael Morton have been officially dismissed, and he is now out of prison after 25 years, but the ramifications of his case have just begun. His lawyers have asked a Texas court to launch an unprecedented inquiry into whether Ken Anderson, the prosecutor who secured Mr. Morton's conviction, ought to face criminal charges and professional discipline.

JACKSON--George Duncan, Emeritus Professor of History at Hofstra University, died at his home on the morning of December 25, 2011 from complications which arose from a 2001 accident that left him a quadriplegic on a ventilator. He is survived by his wife Karen Schiller Jackson, four biological children and three step-children.

1 ''Give me time, and I'll give you a revolution,'' Alexander McQueen once said. Like anyone born to achieve, he resented the small distractions -- and the fashion business provides plenty of them. Well, even he probably never dreamed that 661,509 people would go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to see his clothes. What were they expecting to see? Genius, yes; but the plain, early tailored pieces, like the bumster trousers and perfectly cut jackets, told a lot. The man knew what he was doing. Knowledge was his revolution. And whether or not he could see it, Mr. McQueen had built a durable brand. The Met show -- and the royal wedding dress designed by his successor, Sarah Burton -- was proof of that. 2 If you know anything about Ms. Burton (her skill, her objectivity, her patience), then it wasn't a surprise that Kate Middleton chose McQueen to make her gown as well as the streamlined dress worn by her sister, Pippa. Ms. Burton is a good listener, and she would have been sensitive to the bride and the overwhelming demands of the occasion. The dress distilled English tradition and needle crafts; its flawless fit and styling were communicated to a television audience of tens of millions, no small thing when the medium is cloth. So far, the Duchess of Cambridge has refused to allow herself to be pushed into the high-fashion trap. She wears clothes beautifully, from Reiss and Zara to McQueen, but the lady is no clothes horse. The last thing she wants to be, it seems, is another Jackie, Grace or Diana.

Gov. Rick Perry was riding high when he stepped off his first presidential campaign bus, the one with the phrase ''Get America working again'' plastered on its side. It was mid-August, during that first hopeful week of his run for the White House. The sky was the limit back then. Even some liberal critics were predicting that he would waltz to the Republican presidential nomination. Oops. It did not work out that way.

The 2013 mayoral election will loom over most everything in New York City politics this year. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will try to solidify his legacy. A new Cornell University science graduate school will hold its first classes in September (its planned $2 billion campus on Roosevelt Island will materialize more slowly), and construction will start on a 51-story office building over the Hudson railyards -- a major step toward City Hall's vision for Manhattan's far West Side.

POPLACK--Rabbi Alvin Myron, 91, died on December 24, 2011 with his three children by his side. He was predeceased by 66 days by his wife of 66 years, the former Rosalind Schachter. Son of Rabbi Alter and Genia Trakeniski Poplack, he was ordained at Rabbinical Seminary Chaim Berlin (New York) in 1944. Rabbi Poplack held a Masters from Yeshiva University, and a PhD from Jewish Teachers Seminary. During WWII he served as civilian chaplain in the USO Jewish Welfare Board. He held pulpits in Detroit, MI, Medford, MA, and Lebanon, PA before becoming Rabbi (1956) and Rabbi Emeritus (1986) of the Bellerose Jewish Center (New York). He served as President of the Queens Council for Soviet Jewry, and Secretary of the New York Board of Rabbis. As Senior Chaplain, Rabbi Poplack spearheaded the reconstruction of the International Synagogue at JFK Airport, and was spiritual leader to the JFK community and travelers from all over the world. He was the author of Carved In Granite: Holocaust Memorials in Metropolitan New York Jewish Cemeteries (2003), a work read and endorsed by leading Holocaust scholars. He is profoundly missed by his loving children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and by family, friends, colleagues, former congregants and the countless people whose lives he touched.

In last week's Big City column, Ginia Bellafante wrote about the New York holiday ritual of tipping doormen and other staff in residential buildings. Readers commented on NYTimes.com; below is a sampling. Tipping, whether for doormen or wait staff, is just a way for employers to get away with paying low salaries. And a way for recipients to avoid paying income tax. Abolish tipping and pay people a decent wage.

BERKELEY--Norborne, Jr.,Bunny of East Hampton and Manhattan New York and former President of Chemical Bank, died peacefully, at age 89, in his home in East Hampton, on December 29th, 2011 following a two-month illness with congestive heart failure. Norborne was born June 5, 1922 in Bethlehem, PA, the only son of Norborne Berkeley and Dorothea Randolph Berkeley. His one sister, Dorothea Berkeley Brush, died in 1991. Mr. Berkeley was President of Chemical Bank and Chemical NY Corporation (now JPMorgan Chase) from 1973-1982. He was a Director of both the Corporation and the Bank since 1972, and had been with Chemical since 1950, serving in a variety of positions before becoming President. From January, 1982 until June, 1982 he served as Chairman of the Executive Committee, at which time he retired at the age of 60. Mr. Berkeley was a graduate of the Episcopal High School in Alexandria, Virginia (1941), Yale University, BA, (Class of 1945), where he was a member of the Senior Society, Scroll and Key. He held an LL.B. degree from the University of Virginia (1949) and completed the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration in 1966. In World War II, Mr. Berkeley served in Europe with the US Field Artillery, First Army V Corps, from 1943-1945 and participated in five major campaigns, including the Normandy Invasion. During his career, he served on numerous corporate, educational and charitable boards including Freeport McMoran Inc., Uniroyal Inc., Anglo Energy LTD; Tuskegee University, Episcopal High School, New Canaan Country Day School (Board President), Metropolitan Opera (Managing Director), Whitney Museum of American Art, Local Initiatives Support Corporation, LISC, (Chairman), and the Vera Institute of Justice. Mr. Berkeley was appointed by President Ford, and served two Administrations (both Republican and Democratic) on the US Advisory Committee for Trade Negotiations. Mr. Berkeley was an avid and accomplished sportsman throughout his life, including baseball at Yale, squash, skiing and golf. He enjoyed playing his father's ukelele and singing old, family songs; the cultural opportunities in New York City, especially the theatre; and travel around the world. His friendships formed at Yale were very special to him throughout his life and his sense of humor, value system and compassion for his fellow man will always be remembered by his many, many friends and family. He was the very loving and adored husband of Jennifer Puchta Berkeley for twenty one years and had three children by a first marriage to Diane Gould Berkeley: Sally Berkeley Tiller, Raleigh, North Carolina; Dr. Anne Randolph Berkeley, Wilmington, North Carolina; Norborne Berkeley III, Bill New York, NY, plus three wonderful grandchildren: Gabe and Jocelyn Tiller and Carmen Berkeley. Caring nieces, nephews and cousins and, his beloved Labrador retriever, Skye, also survive him. The family kindly requests no flowers and instead, if desired, suggests donations to one's own favorite charity, in Norborne Berkeley Jr.'s memory. A celebration of his life will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton, NY at 11:00am, on Saturday, January 21st, 2012.

Visions of sugarplums and flights of fancy with Frosty won't end with the New Year's hangover if Montreal can help it. The city is home to a new Snow Village (snowvillagecanada.com), a mini-city of snow and ice that includes models of some local landmarks like the Olympic Village. Scheduled to run Jan. 6 to March 31 in Parc Jean-Drapeau, the 1.5-acre village features a 60-seat restaurant with tables made of ice, a convention center with capacity for 200, an Ice Chapel designed for weddings, above, and a 30-room hotel with beds that are simply mattresses placed atop ice pedestals.

2:10 a.m. | Updated More than 500 people associated with the Occupy Wall Street movement gathered in Zuccotti Park on Saturday and, in a return to scenes from earlier in the year, the evening began with the sound of drumming and calls of the now familiar slogan, ''We are the 99 percent'' - and it ended with torn-down barricades and a scuffle with police officers. Just after 10:30 p.m. on New Year's Eve, officers carried a person out of the park, prompting protesters to follow behind them, shouting ''Shame!'' The reason the person was escorted away was unclear.

It is sometimes the case that on the morning of Jan. 1, I arise bleary-eyed from a brief sleep with those famous final words of Beckett's ''Unnamable'' on my mind: ''You must go on, I can't go on, I'll go on.'' Fortunately, I'm not reflecting on the whole messy enterprise of life itself. I'm concerned with drinking. Can I, should I, really keep going after a season of festive drinking that ended a little too festively? Before I go on, a disclaimer: You should not have cause to make a habit of the hair of the dog. And if you're under the impression it will truly help KO your hangover, you're standing on shaky scientific ground. Moving on, then: When it comes to picking a next-day drink, I enjoy making bloody marys a good deal more than I like drinking them. A pint of Guinness frequently feels like just the thing, but it's not as nourishing as it looks. What I really want is protein and a bit of effervescence.

Dad started taking me to Gregory's Bar and Restaurant in Kew Gardens, Queens, in 1986, when I was 6. He was single and looking for love. So he bought a black Chrysler Laser hatchback, a white Members Only jacket and sneakers with saw-blade soles. And every other weekend, when I wasn't with my mom, he took me to Gregory's. There are many reasons Gregory's was a magical place. Inside the front door there were two real whale bones, seven feet tall and touching at the top. There was an enormous captain's wheel and the ''crow's nest table'' -- an ordinary table perched about five feet in the air on a large ''mast,'' accessible only by ladder.

WAINER--Andres Rojas, 1942-2011. Former Agence France Presse and UPI Latin American Desk Correspondent; and later Chilean Press Attache to the US under President Salvador Allende died in his home on December 24, 2011 from complications of primary systemic amyloidosis. In the latter half of his life Mr. Rojas was in private practice as a landscape designer. He lived in Petaluma, CA with his wife Catherine, daughter of renowned ophthalmologist Dr. Charles Schepens, and founder of Sausalito Springs, an early certified organic farm in California. He is survived by: his wife Catherine; his daughter Dr. Alicia Rojas, a physician and assistant professor at Columbia University Department of Psychiatry; and his son Clarence, artisan blacksmith and chief engineer for Pacific Coral Reed Foundation's new vessel's maiden voyage to Indonesia. There will be a private Memorial Service on January 7, 2012. Please call (415) 206-0230 for details.

PATRICK--Ellen Goldman, 68, passed away December 18 at her home in Shelburne, MA. Ellen was a wise and loving wife, mother, and friend. She was an enlightened thinker, with a keen intellect, and a passion for life. Her husband, David; daughter, Liza; and son, Stephen will honor and love her forever --- as will her extended family and many, many friends. There will be a celebration of Ellen's life in the spring.

A Maryland judge is being asked to find CarMax, the automotive retailer, in contempt of court for failing to abide by a 2008 class-action settlement. That settlement required that consumers be given a clear warning when a used vehicle offered for sale was once in a rental fleet. ''CarMax still does not disclose its vehicles' prior use as short-term rental vehicles,'' according to a filing made last month in the Baltimore County Circuit Court by lawyers for the plaintiffs in the class-action suit.

Pat Sajak, who celebrated his 30th anniversary as the host of the game show ''Wheel of Fortune'' last week, holds another proud distinction: he has attended every N.H.L. Winter Classic. He plans to be in the crowd at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia on Monday, when the Flyers host the Rangers in the fifth annual outdoor event. Q.

This most uncertain political year starts with something we know: Nearly one in five members of the Texas House will not be coming back. Whether they are running for higher office (about half) or because they have had quite enough for now (the rest), almost 30 members of the 150-member House will not seek re-election. Couple that with the high number of freshmen elected in 2010, and you can bet that the next legislative session will have an abundance of inexperience. What amounts to huge turnover in the State Senate is small by any other standard, with four of the 31 members saying they will not be back. The rest -- and perhaps the new replacements -- might see the most political fallout after the November elections. If Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst is elected to the United States Senate, the senators will elect his replacement from their own ranks in a process that is like a professional version of a race for student body president. Every candidate knows every voter, and everyone will know how everyone else voted.

Budget constraints brought on by the bad economy have already made it more difficult for Albany to bail out failing hospitals in the city. North General in Harlem, propped up for years by the local political establishment, closed in 2010. So did St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, and two hospitals in Queens closed in 2009. Brooklyn is next. In the coming year, the state will have to decide how to deal with a few struggling hospitals serving poor communities there. Mergers and reorganizations are on the table, and thousands of jobs and the welfare of tens of thousands of patients are at stake.

SEOUL, South Korea -- Kim Geun-tae, one of South Korea's best-known pro-democracy activists, whose constant smile belied his mental and physical struggle with the aftermath of torture he suffered from a past military dictator's spy agency, died here on Friday. He was 64. The cause was pneumonia and kidney failure, his family said. Mr. Kim had long battled Parkinson's disease and other illnesses that family members attributed to the torture he underwent as a dissident in the 1980s.

From last season's Super Bowl to the off-season lockout, from the whirlwind free-agency period to Tebowmania, this has been an N.F.L. year like any other, only more so. Here is a look back at the year that almost wasn't. JAN. 15 The Jets defeat the Patriots in what Rex Ryan probably convinced himself was the Super Bowl.

Relations along the Texas-Mexico border depend on the outcome of two elections, one at home and one abroad. Some posit that if President Obama is re-elected, he may finally act on his 2008 campaign promise to fix the country's immigration system. He has called for this for years, but has simultaneously deported more illegal immigrants than any other president. Between Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.'s recent visit to Texas and the United States Justice Department's crackdown on enforcement of Arizona's controversial immigration law -- which Texas lawmakers continue to toy with -- his administration appears to be working to counteract this reputation.

MINKIN--George. July 18, 1920, died December 25, 2011 at age 91. He was the beloved husband of Helen Minkin. He was the son of Belle Celia Rusitzky and Jacob Minkin, a nationally known labor attorney. He was sibling to Sybil Jackson (deceased) and Noah Minkin (surviving) of Arlington, Virginia and uncle to Leonard Jackson (deceased) and Marsha Jackson, Larry Jackson and Nancy Riedel (surviving). Mr. Minkin served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II. He received B.A. (1941), LL.B. (1947), and LL.M. (1948) degrees from Harvard University, and from 1948 to 1950, he was Assistant Dean at Harvard Law School. He is a retired partner of Carter Ledyard & Milburn LLP. Over his long career, George earned the trust and respect of clients and colleagues alike. A private memorial service is planned.

''BLOOD KNOT,'' the 1961 play that vaulted Athol Fugard into international prominence, features two young South African men, one black and one white, grappling over what the world owes them. ''The Train Driver,'' which Mr. Fugard, above, wrote in 2010, features two older South African men, one black and one white, grappling over what they owe the world. These works bookend a rich career for Mr. Fugard, who turns 80 this June and is being honored this season with four major New York productions. These two plays, along with the 1989 political drama ''My Children! My Africa!,'' make up a big part of the Signature Theater Company's inaugural season in its new home. But first comes ''The Road to Mecca,'' which opens Jan. 17 at the Roundabout Theater Company's American Airlines Theater. Rosemary Harris stars in the 1984 drama as Miss Helen, an Afrikaner widow who earns the mistrust of her village when she begins filling her yard with ambitious, whimsical sculptures after the death of her husband.

SOREK--Moshe, M.D.,passed away December 19, 2011. Born November 2, 1936 to Hannah and Aharon Souraski in Haifa, Israel. A graduate of the Hebrew University Medical School in Jerusalem, Moshe emigrated to the United States and started his medical career at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City. Thereafter, for twenty five years, he headed the department of Nuclear Medicine at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Sorek was a talented physician and an inspiring teacher. He will be loved and missed by his wife Dalia, son Joe, daughters Michelle and Ruth, grandchildren Molly and Nate, brother Natan and his family, and relatives in Israel. Interment was in Scottsdale, Arizona.

An interview on Dec. 11 with the lawyer Gloria Allred misspelled, in one instance, the given name of one of her clients. She is Joslyn James, not Jocelyn.

SIDAMON-ERISTOFF--Constantine. The Boards and staff of the National Audubon Society and Audubon New York are deeply saddened by the loss of our committed board member and a true leader, Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff. As the founding Chair of Audubon New York, Connie was a consensus builder and knew how to help people and organizations find common ground. But, as a tenacious defender of the environment, he knew when to use the law and regulation to appropriate and maximum effect. He served on the Board of the National Audubon Society with passion and energy and was a model for his fellow members. Every day, he lived his life-long commitment to creating a healthy planet for wildlife and for generations of people to come. We are grateful for his dedication to conservation and public service. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Anne and the Sidamon-Eristoff family.
Sam Anderson, the magazine’s critic at large and resident marginalia obsessive, selects highlights from a year in reading.

DUNAIF--Charles B.,M.D. died on December 26, 2011. Survived in loving memory by his wife Patricia, daughter, Karen Bartfield and his niece and nephew Paula and Bruce Winston. A memorial to be announced at a later date

Nothing in 2012 is likely to have a bigger impact on the lives of immigrants in New York than the Obama administration's plan to review every pending case in the nation's immigration courts. The goal is to speed the deportations of convicted criminals while sparing many illegal immigrants who have no criminal records and have deep roots in the community. In the absence of comprehensive revisions to federal immigration law, meanwhile, state governments will continue to move unilaterally on immigration issues. New York remains one of the nation's friendlier states to immigrants, and some legislators are seeking to expand educational opportunities for illegal immigrants by making them eligible for state financial aid and scholarships. The idea has received the backing of the Board of Regents, and a related bill may come up for a vote in 2012.

GOLDEN--Jerome C.,89, December 27, 2011. A native Long Islander, Jerry was loved by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Gloria, children David (Harriet), Nancy (Nel), and Bill (Drew), four grandchildren, sister-in-law Barbara and too many friends to count.

BE honest: would you rather look at Toby the Lab or the funeral of Kim Jong-il? I thought so. This is my last post for 2011, an eventful year in fashion, a most peculiar year that saw a feverish spread of luxury brands in places like China and Brazil, chasing new wealth, even as insiders saw the Galliano scandal as a sobering episode for an industry that tends to push its talent hard. I wonder, though, if the insider's influence hasn't waned. To be sure, people admire the genuinely talented, and we're attracted to star personalities both on the runway and in the front row. It's also true that fashion, like everything else, runs in cycles - one moment it's guilty of gluttony, the next it regrets the whole thing. But outsiders seldom feel these mood swings; they just know what they want, and the business side of fashion houses (along with the more astute creative directors, like Christopher Bailey of Burberry) has seen to it that they get what they want.

On July 9, when Derek Jeter hit a home run into the left-field seats at Yankee Stadium, his father, Charles, stood and cheered with the rest of the crowd, his eyes growing moist as the ovation lingered. But Charles Jeter might not have been the proudest father in the stadium that day. For later that afternoon, when the game was over and the fans were gone and the workers were using leaf blowers to chase away runaway hot dog wrappers in the grandstand, Raul Lopez found his eyes tearing up, too.

SHEEHAN--Hyacinthe (nee Contessa). A retired NYC Public School English Teacher and Assistant Dean at Ft. Hamilton High School passed away on December 30, 2011 at the age 88. She was the beloved wife of the late Arthur B. Sheehan. Mrs. Sheehan was the loving mother of James Sheehan and his wife Laureen of Pittsburgh, PA; John Sheehan of Brooklyn, NY; and Catherine S. MacDonald and her husband Louis of Winchester, MA. She was the dear sister of Eileen Gorman and her husband Bernard; and the late Joseph Contessa Jr. She was the daughter of the late Joseph and Elizabeth Contessa. She leaves behind her caring sister-in-law Norma Contessa as well as many nieces and nephews. She was the proud grandmother of Emily and Patrick Sheehan; Katie, Ryan and Douglas MacDonald. Everyone had a favorite Bergdorf Goodman holiday window designed by David Hoey. For me, it was the underwater scene fashioned in mosaic tiles, the work of Brett Day Windham. By coincidence, pavé mermaid dresses were popular this fall. There were even fishtails, right, on Barbara Walters, and a net dress, bottom left, that looked like sea foam. The colors ranged from deep blues, left, to shades of pearl, right. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

THE only safe thing to say about the future is that, borrowing from Mort Sahl, it lies ahead. After that, we are all on our own. The year just past provided ample evidence of the unpredictable nature of that elusive quantity known as news. Who, on Jan. 1, 2011, could have foreseen the Dominique Strauss-Kahn sexual assault case, or Tropical Storm née Hurricane Irene, or the relatively stress-free passage of a same-sex marriage law, or Representative Anthony D. Weiner's political death by tweet, or the rise of the Occupy Wall Street movement, or -- ending the year on a painful note -- the killing of Police Officer Peter J. Figoski?

When the sports arena that anchors the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project finally opens in September, after more than eight years of lawsuits and construction delays, it will undoubtedly transform Downtown Brooklyn. But will the 19,000-seat Barclays Center, soon to be home to the Nets and host to Jay-Z, the circus and 200 other events a year, help its neighborhood become an epicenter of entertainment and commerce, as most officials predict? Or will it be a vortex of traffic, trash and other civic headaches, as some residents fear? Wedged into the triangle between Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, on top of a rebuilt transit hub, the arena has already closed streets, bred rats and infuriated neighbors during its construction. And the ribbon-cutting will not be the end. Forest City Ratner intends to break ground this spring on the first of 16 more buildings planned for the area around the stadium: a 32-story residential tower that could make pioneering use of lower-cost modular construction.

Cowboys at Giants, 8:20 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, NBC This winner-take-all finale at MetLife Stadium will decide the N.F.C. East. The Giants are looking to make the playoffs for the first time since 2008, and perhaps secure Tom Coughlin's coaching job. The Cowboys are looking to return to the postseason after a one-year hiatus.

Across the city's 1,700 parks, the coming year will see much new development as well as the reopening of some long-defunct attractions. The most intriguing might be the $50 million renovation of the McCarren Park pool in Brooklyn, on the Greenpoint-Williamsburg border. One of 11 that opened in 1936 under the reign of Robert Moses, the pool was closed in 1984 after deteriorating badly. In its heyday, it must have felt like a vast lake, accommodating a staggering 6,800 people in its 55,440 square feet. (Under today's codes, that expanse would allow 2,200 bathers.)

Last year featured the much-anticipated return of an Albany tradition: a Cuomo as governor. This year will restore another: pigs in a blanket. In the bleak Albany winter, the little things count. A new ethics law brokered by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo last year lifted what amounted to a ban in 2007 on hors d'oeuvres at receptions for public officials. That means lawmakers can once again enjoy events like the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce's Brooklyn Night, featuring Nathan's hot dogs, Junior's cheesecake and refreshments from Brooklyn Brewery.

HANDLER--Evelyn. The family of Evelyn Handler mourns the loss of a loving and devoted wife, mother, sister and grandmother. Through the many accomplishments over an illustrious career that spans Hunter College, the University of New Hampshire, Brandeis University, the California Academy of Sciences and Board of Director positions that include the Student Loan Corporation, Evelyn improved the lives of thousands upon thousands of young people with boundless energy, dedication, creativity and a remarkable understanding of how to make an institution "great." SCHWARZ--Wolfgang, a clinical psychologist for 62 years, passed away on December 27 at the age of 85. Born in Stuttgart Germany on October 30, 1926, he came to America at the age of seven. He leaves behind the love of his life, his wife Susan, and an extraordinary family of 18, including his children: Amy, Casey, Darcy and husband Lloyd, Priscilla and husband Amit, Lydia and husband Alun, Emily, Jaime and wife Jessica, and Noah and wife Mary and five grandchildren: Tamsin, Armand, Sabrina, Saskia and Miles as well as close friends and family and grateful patients. In his words, "It's been a great ride." Remembrance may be made to the New York Academy of Science Wolfgang Schwarz Memorial Fund at nyas.org/ gift.

The new year will determine how Texas proceeds with two contentious public health matters: family planning and the state's huge uninsured population. The Obama administration has rejected Republican state lawmakers' efforts to block Planned Parenthood from participating in the Medicaid Women's Health Program, but has extended the program into March so the state can reconsider its options. Will the state simply end the program, which does not finance or perform abortions? Will the federal government back down? It's a game of who will blink first, with cancer screenings and birth control for some 130,000 low-income Texas women hanging in the balance.

A year of upheaval in higher education raised many questions about the future of colleges and universities in Texas. Should professors at research universities readjust their priorities? Do current financing models create the wrong incentives for administrators? What is the role of regents? The coming year will be a quest for answers.

FRANKENTHALER--Helen. The Directors of Ameringer McEnery Yohe mourn the passing of a true American visionary. Helen Frankenthaler's life and art produced a remarkable body of work that inspired an artistic movement and continues to inspire new generations of artists and viewers in her unique pursuit of truth and beauty. We will miss your grace and friendship but just need to look at your paintings to find the source of your spirit and the joy you have brought to us. Will Ameringer Miles McEnery James Yohe

After an astonishingly quick and robust recovery from the recession, the city's financial industry was hit hard in 2011. The big American and foreign banks that dominate the action on Wall Street resharpened their axes and cut even more staff members last year than in 2009: more than 200,000 jobs were lost, many of them in the city. Whatever New Yorkers think of bankers, the city's economy relies on their outsize compensation. The city's Independent Budget Office forecasts that the financial companies will continue to shed jobs through the first half of 2012. And then the hiring will be grudging: Marisa Di Natale, an economist at Moody's Analytics, predicts that Wall Street will not regain all its lost jobs for more than a decade.

Much of the attention on the Oklahoma City Thunder in the first week of this season focused on whether Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook could co-exist. Talking heads are discussing whether or not they are friends, and what their recent argument means to the future of the franchise. The situation begs this question: Why do star players need to be friends?
A photo grouping of famous movie villains on Dec.11 misidentified a silent-film actress. She was Pina Menichelli, not Theda Bara.

ROSS--Jesse, born June 9, 1927, Hoboken, NJ, died December 28, Boynton Beach, FL. Widower of Rosalyn, beloved father of Linda, Barbara and Judy. Services Tuesday, 2pm, New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon, NY. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Jewish National Fund.

Members of New York's Congressional delegation are bracing for a brutal 2012. New York's population growth has not kept pace with that of other states. As a result, the number of representatives the state has in the House will shrink next year to 27 from 29.

CHACE--Minturn V.,70, of Mt. Kisco, N.Y. died December 28, 2011 of cancer. "Mike" graduated from Milton Academy in 1959, Harvard College in 1963, and Harvard Business School in 1969 (MBA with distinction). He served in the U.S. Navy from 1963 to 1967, as the ASW Officer on board the Destroyer Forrest Royal DD872. Mike was a management consultant and financial VP for several N.Y. firms. His favorite assignment was as Medical Coordinator for Project Orbis, the flying eye hospital. Most recently, he was a founding director of Bedford Management Group until retirement in 2006. Mike was active in the Episcopal Church of St. Matthews, Bedford. For 20 years he was President of Westmoreland Sanctuary for Wildlife and Forest Conservation. His passions were skiing, sailing and choral singing. Mike is mourned by his wife Helen Clay, daughters Martha and Susie, son-in-law John, former son-in-law Tom, four grandchildren, three sisters and one brother. Services will be held at St. Matthews, Rte. 22, Bedford on Monday, January 9th at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Westmoreland Sanctuary, 260 Chestnut Ridge Rd., Bedford Corners, N.Y. 10549; or to the Northeast Harbor Sailing School, P.O.Box 12, Northeast Harbor, ME 04662.

EISENMAYER--Mildred F.,94, passed away peacefully on Friday, December 23, 2011 at The Edgehill Community in Stamford, CT. She was cared for by the devoted staff of Edgehill and the Compassionate Care Registry. Mildred was born on October 18, 1917 in St. Louis, MO to the late Arthur and Mathilda Klie Eisenmayer. Mildred spent most of her career with Cullman Ventures, Inc. where she enjoyed many years working in New York City. Mildred's commitment and dedication to her career was an inspiration to all who knew and worked with her, and she lived life her way. To celebrate Mildred's life and her memory, a gift can be made to The Edgehill Appreciation Fund, 122 Palmers Hill Road, Stamford, CT 06902.

A cover article this weekend about the legality of visual artists' appropriating the images of others misstates the action the Supreme Court took in a 1994 case regarding the group 2 Live Crew's sampling of a Roy Orbison song. The court referred the case back to a lower court and, in the process, clarified the legal standard to be applied; the court did not find fair use in that case.

MILLER--Dorothee C. 1933-2011. Quogue, New York resident Dorothee C. Miller died on Tuesday, December 20 of cirrhosis of the liver at Stony Brook Medical Center after a five-week hospitalization. She was 78. Ms. Miller was the daughter of Sophie and Lester Cornelius. She grew up in Richmond Hill, NY and attended Jamaica High School, thereafter working variously at The Sperry Company and The Singer Company. She also worked part-time as a fashion and television model for The Harry Conover Agency and Pendleton. Later in life, she went back to school, receiving two Associate Degrees from Queens College, New York. She was predeceased in 1998 by her beloved husband of 21 years, Willie, as well as her cherished longtime companion Robert Lovett, Sr. of Hampton Bays, NY in 2008. Dorothee was always cheery and quick with a smile, generous in her hospitality, unwavering in her opinions, independent to the last, and she will be missed greatly by her family and many friends. Ms. Miller is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Joan and Richard Gibbs of Oak Creek, CO, her son and daughter-in-law, Todd and Lenore Evans of Remsenburg, NY, her son and daughter-in-law, Scott and Cynthia Evans of Chestertown, NY, and her grandchildren Alyssa, Cole, Casey, Kristin, Cody, and Jessie. According to Ms. Miller's wishes, there will be no funeral or memorial services. Her cremains will be scattered across Long Island Sound by her family. The family would appreciate that in lieu of flowers, a gift donation be made to The Betty Ford Legacy Fund in memory of Dorothee Miller, either online, or by calling 800-854-9211 x4105.

The ''Texas Miracle,'' which Gov. Rick Perry has credited with creating nearly half of the jobs in the national work force since mid-2009, may have dominated headlines in 2011, but heading into 2012 the state's job growth should look far more routine. Richard Fisher, president of the Dallas Federal Reserve, said Texas job growth was likely to remain at about 1.5 percent to 2 percent. While the state gained 289,900 private-sector jobs in the last year, Texas' news is not all good. The state's unemployment rate hovered above 8 percent in 2011, while the rest of the nation improved, and the national unemployment rate dropped to 8.6 percent by November. According to the latest statistics from the Texas Workforce Commission, the state lost 63,900 public-sector jobs, largely as a result of lawmakers' budget cuts, and mostly in public education. Texas is only a few months into those cuts.

GESUALDO--Hector M. Trustees and staff of Randall's Island Sports Foundation mourn the loss of our treasured Board member. For ten years we depended upon his wisdom, great spirit and guidance in improving the lives of New York City's children.

KEMPLER--Cecelia (Sue). The partners, counsel, associates and administrative staff of Dewey & LeBoeuf LLP deeply mourn the passing of our retired partner and dear friend, Sue Kempler. Sue co-chaired the Firm's Insurance Practice and chaired its Life Insurance Practice. She was the first woman on the Firm's Executive Committee and the Managing Partner of the Washington DC office. After her retirement, she served on the Board of AEGON U.S. and on the Supervisory Board of AEGON N.V., and she was the founding Director of the Kaye School of Finance, Insurance and Economics at Florida Atlantic University. Law was Sue's second career, and she pursued it with passion and boundless energy. She was an inspirational leader, mentor, role model, partner and friend. She was a shrewd and highly skilled lawyer who was always the absolute personification of client service. She was wise, warm and witty, charming, generous and fun. And always elegant. She fought her final battle with the great courage, dignity and determination that characterized her life. We extend our condolences to Sue's beloved partner of 31 years and spouse, Virginia Ellen Cropper, and to her family. Donations in Sue's memory can be made to: Boca Raton Regional Hospital Foundation (Lynn Cancer Institute) re: Cecelia Sue Kempler, c/o BRRH Foundation, Inc., 745 Meadows Road, Boca Raton, Florida 33486.

The new year will bring more high-profile political corruption cases to the city's federal courts. Pedro Espada Jr., a Democrat who served as the State Senate majority leader, is to go on trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in March. Mr. Espada and his son, Pedro Gautier Espada, are accused of siphoning more than half a million dollars in federal money from the nonprofit health care network they operated in the Bronx and spending it on items like meals, theater tickets and a lavish birthday party.

FLEISIG--Ross, an aerospace engineer for over 55 years, died in Binghamton, NY at age 90. Born in Montreal, Canada, Mr. Fleisig grew up in Forest Hills, Queens and lived most of his life in Garden City, New York. He received Bachelor's and Master's Degrees in Engineering from Polytechnic University. Mr. Fleisig enjoyed a long career as an aerospace engineer, working for Chance Vought Aircraft, Sperry Gyroscope Corporation, and the Grumman Corporation. As Spacecraft Team Manager at Grumman during the development of the Apollo Lunar Module, he directed a team integral to the success of the Apollo 11 LM-5 Eagle, the first spacecraft to land humans on the moon. Mr. Fleisig was a member of many professional organizations, including the American Astronautical Society, National Society of Professional Engineers, and American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. He was an accomplished author and lecturer, receiving numerous honors from private and governmental organizations, and was also a member of the Mineola-Garden City Rotary Club, Garden City Casino, and the Garden City Ski Club. Mr. Fleisig was married to Marjorie Marie Hall, who predeceased him in 2000. He is survived by their two daughters Ann Machlin and Dale Gallis, and two grandchildren Russell Gallis and Thea Gallis Musselman.

On July 11, 2002, six Moroccan gendarmes occupied Isla de Perejil [1], or Parsley Island, an uninhabited, Spanish-administered rock of about 37 acres, just 220 yards off the Moroccan coast. If the standoff had lasted longer than a few days, and if blood had actually been spilled, we might now know it as the Parsley War. But on July 18, they were overwhelmed and forcibly ejected by Equipo 31, a crack team of Spanish special forces soldiers. No shots were fired.

Sam Oliver was going to be married. The recently widowed lieutenant colonel, 35 years old, had proposed to a young lady back home in Massachusetts and she accepted. Now he just needed to get time off from his duties along the Virginia section of the Washington defenses. On New Year's Day 1862, he applied by letter for a three-week furlough. He submitted it to his commanding colonel, William Greene, who was pleased to comply - not because he wanted Oliver's happiness, but because he wanted to get rid of him.

The combination of an N.F.L. division rivalry game between the Dallas Cowboys and the New York Giants with playoff implications for both teams and a lack of competition from other broadcast networks worked strongly in NBC's favor on Sunday. Preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates suggest that the game -- won by the Giants, 31-14 -- was not only the highest-rated "Sunday Night Football" game since the program moved to NBC in 2006, but that it also had the best overnight rating of any Sunday prime-time N.F.L. broadcast in 13 years. It barely beat the ratings for this season's Week 1 game between the Cowboys and the New York Jets.

The celebrity chef Rick Bayless will take to the Chicago stage this March. Promoted as "a theatrical feast," the show will run from March 21 through April 22 at the Water Tower Pumping Station. Tickets - for $200 to $225 - include dinner.

The reality show "So You Think You Can Dance" is getting shorter. Weeks or maybe months before Fox would have announced the change, the program's executive producer, Nigel Lythgoe, disclosed in a Twitter message on Sunday that the network had canceled the results show for the season scheduled to start in May. "I will have to change the format," he added. Fox previously split the show into two nights, revealing the weekly results a day after the competitions. The eighth season, last year, lost ground to another summer competition, "America's Got Talent" on NBC, but it remains an important piece of Fox's schedule. A Fox scheduling executive said on Twitter on Monday that the reasons for the shortening would be explained "in due time."

3. NEW ORLEANS SAINTS (13-3, South) 6. DETROIT LIONS (10-6, wild card) The Saints are the team nobody wants to play, particularly at the Superdome, where they have rewritten large sections of the offensive record book this season. The Lions have the battle scars to prove it. On Dec. 4, Detroit ventured into New Orleans and fell behind, 17-0, and trailed at halftime, 24-7, on the way to a 31-17 New Orleans victory. It's no secret why. The Saints, with the top passing offense, have more weapons than any other team in the N.F.L. The 6-foot-6 tight end Jimmy Graham is practically uncoverable, and when teams try to double-team him, they leave somebody like Marques Colston alone. When the Carolina Panthers tried to blanket Graham on Sunday, Colston had 145 yards receiving and 2 touchdowns. Drew Brees merely set the single-season mark for passing yards and broke his own record for completion percentage.

More than ever in 2011, phrases typed into search engines offered instant access to news and information, with many stories time-stamped with a posting time or phrases like ''6 minutes ago.'' Web sites ranked their most popular stories, tallied user comments and offered a link to Facebook: ''share.'' The top 25 subjects sending traffic to news sites mostly mixed gossip, celebrity news and sensation, like the Casey Anthony murder trial, Charlie Sheen and Lindsay Lohan. Hurricane Irene, above, ranked sixth. The search term ''bin laden wives'' was No. 17, followed by ''iPhone 5.'' SHELLY FREIERMAN

DES MOINES -- Iowa voters will kick off the Republican presidential voting on Tuesday. But logistically, there is much more to it than that. One reason the Hawkeye State retains its influence in the nominating fight is the nature of its caucus system, which forces candidates to do far more than persuade voters to punch a hole or fill in an oval.

In 1891, Yusuf Sadallah arrived in Lower Manhattan from the town of Baskinta, in the part of the Ottoman Empire that is now Lebanon. Going by the name of Joseph Sadallah, he set up a trading shop on Washington Street, where other immigrants from the Levant -- Syrians, Lebanese and Palestinians -- had created a vibrant Arab quarter known as Little Syria. Most residents were Christian, their loyalties divided only between St. George's Syrian Catholic Church at 103 Washington Street and St. Joseph's Maronite Church at 57 Washington Street, later at 157 Cedar Street.

A capsule look at the Jets' 19-17 loss to the Dolphins: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE In the final game of his career, Miami linebacker Jason Taylor tormented his former team by forcing Mark Sanchez's second interception midway through the fourth quarter. Taylor beat D'Brickashaw Ferguson and wrapped up Sanchez, whose throw caromed off Nick Mangold and deflected into the hands of Randy Starks, whose return led to a field goal that extended Miami's lead to 16-10.

HUGHES--John J.,of Millbrook, New York and of Tarrytown, New York and retired Chairman and President of the former Sleepy Hollow Bank in Sleepy Hollow, New York, died peacefully on December 31, 2011 at age 82. Mr. Hughes was born on February 5, 1929 in New York, the only son of Thomas M. Hughes and Agnes Hughes. He was predeceased by his two sisters Sally Hughes and Mary Daly. He attended The Irving School in Sleepy Hollow, and Georgetown University in Washington, DC, graduating in 1950. He served in the United States Army from 1950 to 1952. Mr. Hughes worked for the Manufacturers Hanover Bank from 1952 to 1956. In 1956, he became Chairman and President of The Sleepy Hollow Bank a community bank located in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Mr. Hughes served as President of the Westchester County Banker's Association and served on several banking industry groups. Mr. Hughes was a lifelong horseman. He was a long time member of the Golden Bridge and Millbrook Hunts, and he rode horses throughout the United States and in Ireland. His passion for horses also included driving and show jumping. He was also an accomplished golfer, playing for many years at Sleepy Hollow Country Club and won the Men's golf championship at Lake Placid Country Club. He is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Mary Kelly Hughes, and by five children: John J. Hughes, Jr. of Tarrytown, NY; Thomas Hughes of Cuttingsville, Vermont; Patricia Barnes, of Mendham, New Jersey; Katherine Shelburne of Byfield, Massachusetts; and Kelly Hughes of New York and Sharon Connecticut. John Hughes is also survived by eight wonderful grandchildren: John Hughes III, Thomas Hughes, Joseph Hughes, Michaela Barnes, Kelsey Barnes, Caitlin Shelburne, Kelly Shelburne, and Alec Shelburne. The family suggests donations to one's own favorite charity in the memory of John J. Hughes. A celebration of his life will be held at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church, 130 Beekman Avenue, Sleepy Hollow, New York on Wednesday Visitation will be at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY on Tuesday from 4-7pm. Interment will be private.

HIRSHBEIN--Omus. Died December 31, 2011. Survived by wife Jessica; sons Peretz and Hillel; daughters-in-law Laura and Emily; grandchildren Abigail, Daniel, Hannah, and Eli. Funeral 10am, January 2, 2012, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. Donations to YIVO or Juilliard.

PALMER--Helen G. Family, friends, colleagues, bridge partners, mystery lovers, Democrats, agitators, and loyal Californians all mourn the sudden passing of Helen Palmer, December 30, 2011 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital. Our "Iron Lady", Helen lived to a spirited 94 and thrived in robust health, sharp wit, and open heart throughout. She was born in Lennox, South Dakota, raised throughout the Midwest, started her family with the late B. Mitchell Palmer in San Francisco and moved to Los Angeles where she remained for the rest of her years. Irrepressibly enterprising, she enjoyed an expansive career spanning advertising sales at the Los Angeles Times and a series of creative businesses launched with her sister-in-law, best friend and confidant, Rita Corwin. In later years, she turned this energy to serving as a scion of the Beverly Hills Bridge Club, where she rose to the rank of Silver Master and competed without mercy, even to her last hand. Above all, Helen's greatest passion was her family. Her marriage to Mitch was a true partnership, ahead of its time, and the two stood side-by-side at the head of a still-expanding family. They are survived by their son Mark J. Palmer of Beverly Hills, their daughter Stephanie Palmer McClelland and her husband Carter McClelland of Manhattan; Mark's daughter Jenni Palmer and her husband Sam Gall of greater Los Angeles; Stephanie and Carter's children Cary McClelland, Spencer McClelland and his wife Eliza, all of New York; Rita Corwin and Rita's children Leni Corwin, Miles Corwin, his wife Diane, and their son Marius of Pasadena and Altadena. Helen's delight in our accomplishments was the fire that drove us forward, and her counsel the light that shone the way. She remains in our memory - scotch in one hand, sudoku in the other, and smiling always. A memorial will be scheduled, and, in lieu of flowers, the family requests that gifts in Helen's name be sent to the West Hollywood Library and Susan G. Komen for the Cure.

PHILADELPHIA - When the N.H.L. and NBC originally plotted the Winter Classic, the idea was to present two traditional rivals. It does not hurt that this year's matchup - the Rangers and the Flyers - play in the first- and fourth-largest television markets in the country, but these clubs also have a venomous history that is hard to equal. Rivalries truly intensify with playoff encounters, and the Rangers and the Flyers have met 10 times in the postseason, with Philadelphia winning six times. The teams' antagonism sprang to life during their first spring encounter, the 1974 semifinals.

FEINSTEIN--Jerome, 85, died peacefully December 30, 2011 in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida with his family at his side after a long battle with cancer. Twitter welcomed the new year in with a bang-- by more than an hour of unavailability Saturday morning. The reason: Look to where 2012 had already begun.

Almost two-thirds of adults who used the Internet in 2011 also belonged to social networks, like Facebook and Twitter, according to the Pew Internet and American Life Project. Most people said they adopted these tools to stay connected with relatives and friends, new and old, the Pew study found. But what were they saying and sharing, beyond a baby's first words, prom photos and other personal status updates?

3. HOUSTON TEXANS (10-6, South) 6. CINCINNATI BENGALS (9-7, wild card) It's a good thing the Texans locked in their playoff spot so early, because they enter the postseason with absolutely no momentum. Houston lost the final three games of the season and will start the franchise's first playoff game with a rookie quarterback, T. J. Yates. The Texans were so desperate for something positive Sunday that they went for a 2-point conversion in the final minute to try to beat the Titans in an otherwise meaningless game for them. The Texans will have to do what they have been doing since Matt Schaub was hurt - lean on the running game (which is ranked second in the league) and their second-ranked defense, and try to eke out close victories.

A capsule look at the Giants' 31-14 victory over Dallas to clinch the N.F.C. East and a playoff berth: Key Play/Performance Greg Jones, a reserve linebacker, pounced on a muffed punt by returner Will Blackmon in the first quarter, saving the Giants from a turnover that could have been costly. The Cowboys also failed to recover a Giants fumble in the second quarter. One they did recover in the third was nullified by a penalty.

ABC extended ''Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve'' on Saturday night, and it appeared to pay off, giving the network its best end-of-the-year prime-time ratings since 2000. The two new hours of New Year's Eve merriment, from 8 to 10 p.m., drew about 8.3 million viewers, an unusually high number for a Saturday night. Repeats on the other networks drew between 1.5 million and 3 million viewers. ABC's 10 p.m. hour of ''Rockin' Eve'' with Ryan Seacrest drew nearly 13 million viewers, while a competing special on NBC with Carson Daly drew about 3 million. The NBC special was a source of controversy online because the artist Cee Lo Green changed the words of John Lennon's famous song ''Imagine,'' singing ''And all religion's true'' instead of ''And no religion too.''

With Aaron Rodgers resting for the playoffs, Matt Flynn set Packers records with 480 yards passing and 6 touchdown passes in a 45-41 win over the Lions. Flynn, who had attempted 88 passes in four years as Rodgers's backup, finished 31 of 44 in what he will remember as a very profitable day: Flynn is a free agent after this season. David Akers extended the N.F.L. single-season field-goal record he set last week by connecting twice in the 49ers' 34-27 win over the Rams. He finished the regular season with 44 field goals but made his day extra special by throwing a 14-yard touchdown pass -- the first of his career -- in the third quarter.

FLEISCHER--Myron, died on December 26, 2011, shortly after reaching his 90th birthday on August 21. Myron had a sly sense of humor and an analytical mind that served him well as a chess master with the Marshall Chess Club. As a young man during World War II he was a radar instructor in the Army, a skill he later used in building his own radio equipment. The younger son of the esteemed Rabbi Benjamin Fleischer, Myron was distinguished by his deep knowledge of Judaism and love of Jewish texts but he also delighted in reading mysteries. Myron is deeply mourned by his sisters Estelle and Judith, and his numerous nieces and nephews.

Google's mission to compete with Facebook in social networking may be gaining speed. On Tuesday Paul Allen, a researcher, published an analysis saying that Google+, the company's social networking service, has reached 62 million registered users. More important, one-quarter of all users signed up in December alone, he said, putting it on a path to sustained global growth.

That sound you hear is the wrapping being torn off of millions of Kindles and iPads. When those devices are fired up and start downloading texts, it will be the greatest shift in casual reading since the mass market paperback arrived six decades ago. Will this dislocation destroy the traditional book? Will it doom the traditional independent bookstore? Will Amazon and Apple control the distribution of thought and culture in America? All these questions will be played out imminently. The migration to e-reading is usually reported as a one-way journey: You get a device, start downloading and never look back to the old-fashioned book. You start mocking those type-filled volumes reeking of another century. Meanwhile, the defenders of the old ways are digging in their heels. I know readers who swear never to read anything electronic, saying they find the format muddy and confusing and sad.
