Time Warner Cable replaced the MSG Network on Sunday afternoon with NBA TV, the latest move in the pricing dispute that led to the removal of MSG and MSG Plus at midnight Saturday from the cable operator's New York metropolitan area and Buffalo systems. Shifting NBA TV to MSG's slot offers little benefit to Knicks fans. NBA TV's games are carried nationally but are blacked out in the markets of the teams playing. Games of the Rangers, the Islanders and the Devils are also being blacked out. Time Warner Cable planned to replace MSG Plus on Monday morning with the NHL Network. More coverage on nytimes.com/sports.

ROCK--Leon. Far Hills, NJ, passed away peacefully on December 30, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Mildred Glogover Rock; loving father of Steven of Marlboro, NJ; Jan Rock Zubrow of Far Hills, NJ and Barbara Goldman of Scarsdale, NY. He is also survived by five grandchildren: Matthew and Spencer Zubrow, Aaron and Jonathan Goldman and Benjamin Rock. Leon was born December 1, 1927 in Bronx, NY. He attended City College of New York and the Harvard Law School. For over 50 years he was a practicing attorney in New York, as well as the author of Preparation and Pursuance of Civil Litigation. Leon was an ardent student of history, quick to research the details of any discussion topic. He was also a life long supporter of the State of Israel, imbuing in his children the importance of the Jewish homeland. In addition, Leon was an active New York Yankees fan and gourmet of all traditional Jewish foods. The funeral service will be held on Monday, January 2 at 11:30am at Wien and Wien Memorial Chapels, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ followed by a graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ. Donations in lieu of flowers, can be made to Birthright Israel, in celebration of Leon's life and love for Israel. www.birthrightisrael.com.

"Lysistrata Jones," the new Broadway musical about a college basketball team that brought dribbling, passing, and hoop shots to the Walter Kerr Theater, will close after the Jan. 8 matinee performance, the producers announced on Tuesday, following two months of weak ticket sales. The show opened on Dec. 14 to a mix of positive and negative reviews from critics, and it failed to develop a following despite the relative lack of new original musicals on Broadway last fall, with some ticket sales agents saying that the title - a modern-day twist on the classic Greek play - was off-putting to some potential theatergoers and tourist groups. (The only other original musical to open on Broadway during the fall season, "Bonnie & Clyde," received worse reviews and closed on Friday.)

MARIJANA CONDIC and Lisa Leipziger, friends in Frankfurt, had a modest mission: to make espadrilles that were sturdier than the Spanish styles they love to wear. "I came back from holiday in Spain and told Marijana we have to do something special with espadrilles so they don't fall apart after a month," Ms. Leipziger said. Their label, Lika Mimika, is the happy result. The unisex styles, in soft lamb, goat and calfskin, are hand-stitched in Spain and come in a range of neutrals and Pop colors. Two new styles, lined with rabbit fur or curly lamb shearling, are a clever travel shoe: cozy for the flight and vacation-ready upon landing.

"I can finally afford Jason Wu!" squealed a fan upon hearing about the forthcoming Jason Wu for Target collection, in stores Feb. 5. The capsule, Wu's first in collaboration with a mass retailer, possesses a lot of the label's familiar, feminine spirit but takes more direct inspiration from French New Wave films and the actress Jean Seberg. Pleated frocks with sailor-striped hemlines, dainty silk blouses with neck ties and collars, and sportier knits and tennis skirts stand out as some of the line's most wearable pieces. "My goal was not to duplicate anything from my main collection," Wu says. "Instead I designed completely new clothes and accessories that reflect my taste and have a voice of their own." Friendly reminders of Wu's work (like the touch of lace on a trench coat or T-shirt) are matched with a delightful dose of animal humor. (Meet Milu, a mischievous kitty and the collection's mascot, who makes appearances as a print on a scarf and tee.) Here, a Riviera cotton striped A-line dress and canvas satchel explain why Wu calls the whole gamut "gamine chic." It seems, as they say, les jeux sont faits.

I just saw my first commercial for those Lego Friends for girls I wrote about here before the holiday, and after my first glimpse of Heartlake City, the new Lego world, I wondered if I'd spoken too soon about my willingness to place my order now. As the new Ladyfig characters in their brightly colored cafe morphed, on screen, into animated creations that looked far more Polly Pocket than Lego Hermione Granger, I cringed a little. Then I took a closer look at the building, with its ice-cream cups, flowers and railings. And it occurred to me that maybe the real problem with Lego, for girls and boys, isn't the gender specificity of the various building sets. It's that there are so many sets for building so many specific things.

The conventional wisdom holds that Rick Santorum's last-minute bid to consolidate the not-Mitt Romney vote in Iowa is, like so many other developments in this election season, nothing but good news for Romney - because Santorum's rise is preventing Rick Perry or Newt Gingrich from gaining ground instead, and in a drawn-out campaign Romney would ultimately "be more threatened by Gingrich or Perry" (as HotAir's Ed Morrissey puts it) than by the former Pennsylvania senator. "On record, on economic conservative credibility, on ties to big donors," Dave Weigel writes, "Santorum's not the opponent Romney feared most." "If Perry or Gingrich are in the top three, we have a real race headed into South Carolina," Erick Erickson suggests. But if Santorum wins Iowa, "we might as well sit back and declare Mitt Romney the nominee." (Judging by these quotes, the Romney camp seems to agree.)

As our colleague Michael Cieply noted, Hollywood didn't exactly take a break over the holidays. Among other bits of business, the Oscar nomination ballots went out last week. The potential acting nominees include Brad Pitt, a contender for his performances in both "Moneyball" and "The Tree of Life." That last one may be a longshot, but, in a variation on the I'm-just-glad-to-be-nominated theme, Mr. Pitt told our colleague Dennis Lim that he's happy that his work is even part of the conversation. "I've been around long enough to know it's very fickle and it's a cyclical wheel," he said in the interview. "But I will say this: It is surprisingly fun when your number comes up." Read more »

In Monday's New York Times, Brian X. Chen reported on the story behind the failure of Hewlett-Packard's TouchPad tablet, which was pulled off the market after just seven weeks. The article cited former employees of both Palm, which made WebOS, the core software on the TouchPad, and Hewlett-Packard, which acquired Palm. They said the creation of WebOS was flawed, and ultimately led to the TouchPad's failure.

CAIRO - After the first two of three rounds of elections, Egypt's first since former President Hosni Mubarak's ouster last February, the previously banned Muslim Brotherhood has taken 40 percent of seats in Parliament. It is poised to become the main political player on the scene. But anyone who tries to predict exactly what the Muslim Brotherhood - whose primary focus has long been religious and social work - will do with its newfound clout is simply fooling himself. No one knows, not even the Brotherhood itself.

Americans have been eagerly crossing the Atlantic just to gorge themselves in Paris for centuries, but their gastronomic passion has never been even remotely reciprocated, until now. Three of the city's best new modern bistro chefs are American, and Paris's first gourmet food truck, Le Camion qui Fume, selling blue-cheese burgers, caramelized onions, frites and more, was recently outfitted by Kristin Frederick, a Californian.

MOSCOW - After New Year's - the biggest traditional family holiday of the year - Russia descends into an odd, sleepy state for 10 days. Most businesses go on vacation, Moscow's hellish traffic temporarily evaporates, and Russians spend their days in that hazy state between hangover and drink, either at their snowed-in dachas or on warmer shores. A couple of days after Orthodox Christmas on Jan. 7, they will emerge from hibernation and stumble into work, dazed by the prospect of three more months of winter.

KAPLAN--Gerald Lee, passed away December 28, 2011, age 80. Beloved husband of Mary Ann. Cherished brother-in-law of Linda and Michael Ellentuck. He will be missed.

SUMMERS--Norman. It is with profound sadness that Congregation B'nai Jesuhrun of Short Hills, NJ announces the passing of Cantor Norman Summers. Cantor Summers served Congregation B'nai Jeshurun with love, honor, and distinction from 1959 until his retirement in 1999, and then as emeritus. The beauty of his voice was surpassed only by his magnificent soul and his kind and gentle spirit. Funeral services will be private. Members of the congregation and community are invited to pay their respects to the family on Wednesday, January 4th from 4:00-6:00pm at B'nai Jeshurun followed by a minyan service in the Sanctuary at 6:00pm. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Carole and her family. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz Cantor Howard M. Stahl Rabbi Matthew A. Reimer Rabbi Karen R. Perolman Maureen A. Spivack, President

The combination of an N.F.L. division rivalry game between the Dallas Cowboys and the New York Giants with playoff implications for both teams and a lack of competition from other broadcast networks worked strongly in NBC's favor on Sunday. Preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates suggest that the game -- won by the Giants, 31-14 -- was not only the highest-rated ''Sunday Night Football'' game since the program moved to NBC in 2006, but that it also had the best overnight rating of any Sunday prime-time N.F.L. broadcast in 13 years. It barely beat the ratings for this season's Week 1 game between the Cowboys and the New York Jets. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SCHWARTZ--Miriam, 96, on December 28, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Bennie, cherished mother of Sheldon and Judy, devoted mother-in-law of Rose and the late Marvin, adored grandmother of Lori (Paul), Barbara (David), Gregg (Kathy) and Michael, treasured great-grandmother of Madelaine, Dylan, Caroline, Kyle, Kyra and Trevor. Contributions can be made to the American Macular Degeneration Foundation.

DES MOINES - They are known as caucus captains: volunteers who will deliver impassioned, seemingly spontaneous final sales pitches for their favored Republican presidential candidates on Tuesday night, moments before Iowans cast their ballots. In reality, it is rarely if ever left to the imagination of these supporters to come up with these all-important remarks. Instead, the campaigns provide detailed scripts that leave little room for improvisation. (Even opening greetings are laid out: ''My name is -------- and tonight I am here to vote for Rick Santorum.'')
SCHWARTZ--Leonard, loving husband, father, grandfather and friend died peacefully in his sleep on Monday, January 2, 2012. Donations may be made in his name to Save the Children.

A picture on Saturday with an article about Wang Yang, the up-and-coming Communist Party secretary of the southern Chinese province of Guangdong, was published in error. The photograph, from Bloomberg News, showed Wang Rong, the party secretary of Shenzhen, not Wang Yang, who was praised in the Communist Party's flagship newspaper after he defused a tense situation in the village of Wukan, where thousands of residents were protesting local corruption.

8:30 P.M. (ABC) WORK IT Lee Standish (Ben Koldyke), a family guy, and his friend Angel Ortiz (Amaury Nolasco), a ladies' man, lose their jobs at Pontiac when the company folds in this new series. But then Lee discovers that a drug company is seeking female sales representatives, so he attends an interview in heels, a skirt and makeup. When he lands a job, he takes Angel, also in drag, to this workplace of women, where their colleagues seem to accept them. Everyone, that is, but Grace (Rebecca Mader), a manager, who knows something isn't right. It doesn't help when Angel falls for his boss, Vanessa (Rochelle Aytes). Or that Lee can't disclose his feminine subterfuge to his wife, Connie (Beth Lacke), or their daughter, Kat (Hannah Sullivan). But they sure do like this newfangled Mr. Sensitivity. (Above, from left, Mr. Koldyke, Mr. Nolasco, Kate Reinders, Ms. Mader and Kirstin Eggers.) In the premiere of ''Celebrity Wife Swap,'' at 9, Steffanie Sampson, engaged to the drug- and anger-addled actor Gary Busey, trades lives for 10 days with Gayle Haggard, married to the Rev. Ted Haggard, who in 2006 resigned as senior pastor from his New Life Church and as president of the National Association of Evangelicals after admitting to using crystal meth and having sex with a masseur. And in the winter premiere of ''Body of Proof,'' at 10, Dr. Megan Hunt (Dana Delany) scrutinizes the details in the case of a bride who plummeted to her death on her wedding day. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER In this Season 13 premiere, 10 pairs of contestants show up at the ranch and discover that not only will they be split from their loved ones, but they must also compete against them. Bob Harper and Dolvett Quince return as the trainers, guiding the competitors toward a $250,000 grand prize. Alison Sweeney hosts.

When the financier Sanford I. Weill wanted a sense of what the music hall being built at Sonoma State University would sound like, he asked a friend, the pianist Lang Lang, to stop by to play. Mr. Weill liked what he heard, so he and his wife, Joan, went on to donate $12 million toward the project's $130 million cost. Now the university says that Mr. Lang will be the featured performer when the hall opens in September on the university's campus in California's wine country. On Monday, the university also announced a multiyear series in which the San Francisco Symphony will perform four subscription concerts annually at the complex, starting in the inaugural 2012-13 season.

He came to this country after fighting in the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising, and surviving the Holocaust and the loss of his parents and brothers. Here, as a garment worker, he devoted his life to his family, the labor movement, Zionism and Jewish culture. He will be remembered in our hearts forever.

What's the first step toward cooking and eating better this year? Perhaps you should start by learning how to boil water. While that may not sound like much of a cooking technique, you will gain a new appreciation for the hidden potential of boiled food after reading the new book ''An Everlasting Meal: Cooking with Economy and Grace,'' by the chef and food writer Tamar Adler. Placing a pot of water on a hot burner allows us to ''do more good cooking than we know,'' she writes.

IF you want to know what is wrong with American health care today, exhibit A might be the two new proton beam treatment facilities the Mayo Clinic has begun building, one in Minnesota, the other in Arizona, at a cost of more than $180 million dollars each. They are part of a medical arms race for proton beam machines, which could cost taxpayers billions of dollars for a treatment that, in many cases, appears to be no better than cheaper alternatives. Proton beam therapy is a kind of radiation used to treat cancers. The particles are made of atomic nuclei rather than the usual X-rays, and theoretically can be focused more precisely on cancerous tissue, minimizing the danger to healthy tissue surrounding it. But the machines are tremendously expensive, requiring a particle accelerator encased in a football-field-size building with concrete walls. As a result, Medicare will pay around $50,000 for proton beam therapy for a patient with prostate cancer, roughly twice as much as it would if the patient received another type of radiation.

BERKELEY--Norborne, Jr.,Bunny of East Hampton and Manhattan New York and former President of Chemical Bank, died peacefully, at age 89, in his home in East Hampton, on December 29th, 2011 following a two-month illness with congestive heart failure. Norborne was born June 5, 1922 in Bethlehem, PA, the only son of Norborne Berkeley and Dorothea Randolph Berkeley. His one sister, Dorothea Berkeley Brush, died in 1991. Mr. Berkeley was President of Chemical Bank and Chemical NY Corporation (now JPMorgan Chase) from 1973-1982. He was a Director of both the Corporation and the Bank since 1972, and had been with Chemical since 1950, serving in a variety of positions before becoming President. From January, 1982 until June, 1982 he served as Chairman of the Executive Committee, at which time he retired at the age of 60. Mr. Berkeley was a graduate of the Episcopal High School in Alexandria, Virginia (1941), Yale University, BA, (Class of 1945), where he was a member of the Senior Society, Scroll and Key. He held an LL.B. degree from the University of Virginia (1949) and completed the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration in 1966. In World War II, Mr. Berkeley served in Europe with the US Field Artillery, First Army V Corps, from 1943-1945 and participated in five major campaigns, including the Normandy Invasion. During his career, he served on numerous corporate, educational and charitable boards including Freeport McMoran Inc., Uniroyal Inc., Anglo Energy LTD; Tuskegee University, Episcopal High School, New Canaan Country Day School (Board President), Metropolitan Opera (Managing Director), Whitney Museum of American Art, Local Initiatives Support Corporation, LISC, (Chairman), and the Vera Institute of Justice. Mr. Berkeley was appointed by President Ford, and served two Administrations (both Republican and Democratic) on the US Advisory Committee for Trade Negotiations. Mr. Berkeley was an avid and accomplished sportsman throughout his life, including baseball at Yale, squash, skiing and golf. He enjoyed playing his father's ukelele and singing old, family songs; the cultural opportunities in New York City, especially the theatre; and travel around the world. His friendships formed at Yale were very special to him throughout his life and his sense of humor, value system and compassion for his fellow man will always be remembered by his many, many friends and family. He was the very loving and adored husband of Jennifer Puchta Berkeley for twenty one years and had three children by a first marriage to Diane Gould Berkeley: Sally Berkeley Tiller, Raleigh, North Carolina; Dr. Anne Randolph Berkeley, Wilmington, North Carolina; Norborne Berkeley III, Bill New York, NY, plus three wonderful grandchildren: Gabe and Jocelyn Tiller and Carmen Berkeley. Caring nieces, nephews and cousins and, his beloved Labrador retriever, Skye, also survive him. The family kindly requests no flowers and instead, if desired, suggests donations to one's own favorite charity, in Norborne Berkeley Jr.'s memory. A celebration of his life will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton, NY at 11:00am, on Saturday, January 21st, 2012.

HUGHES--John J.,of Millbrook, New York and of Tarrytown, New York and retired Chairman and President of the former Sleepy Hollow Bank in Sleepy Hollow, New York, died peacefully on December 31, 2011 at age 82. Mr. Hughes was born on February 5, 1929 in New York, the only son of Thomas M. Hughes and Agnes Hughes. He was predeceased by his two sisters Sally Hughes and Mary Daly. He attended The Irving School in Sleepy Hollow, and Georgetown University in Washington, DC, graduating in 1950. He served in the United States Army from 1950 to 1952. Mr. Hughes worked for the Manufacturers Hanover Bank from 1952 to 1956. In 1956, he became Chairman and President of The Sleepy Hollow Bank a community bank located in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Mr. Hughes served as President of the Westchester County Banker's Association and served on several banking industry groups. Mr. Hughes was a lifelong horseman. He was a long time member of the Golden Bridge and Millbrook Hunts, and he rode horses throughout the United States and in Ireland. His passion for horses also included driving and show jumping. He was also an accomplished golfer, playing for many years at Sleepy Hollow Country Club and won the Men's golf championship at Lake Placid Country Club. He is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Mary Kelly Hughes, and by five children: John J. Hughes, Jr. of Tarrytown, NY; Thomas Hughes of Cuttingsville, Vermont; Patricia Barnes, of Mendham, New Jersey; Katherine Shelburne of Byfield, Massachusetts; and Kelly Hughes of New York and Sharon Connecticut. John Hughes is also survived by eight wonderful grandchildren: John Hughes III, Thomas Hughes, Joseph Hughes, Michaela Barnes, Kelsey Barnes, Caitlin Shelburne, Kelly Shelburne, and Alec Shelburne. The family suggests donations to one's own favorite charity in the memory of John J. Hughes. A celebration of his life will be held at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church, 130 Beekman Avenue, Sleepy Hollow, New York on Wednesday at 10am. Visitation will be at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY on Tuesday from 4-7pm. Interment will be private.

Before Europe's debt crisis flared anew last summer, rattling markets and choking off a revival in mergers and acquisitions, huge corporate cash piles and cheap debt had fostered hopes that deal-making would recover strongly last year. In the first half of 2011, the dollar volume of announced mergers worldwide neared its highest levels since the financial crisis. But that momentum proved fragile as deal volume tumbled 19 percent, to about $1.1 trillion, in the second half of 2011, compared with the same period the year before, according to Thomson Reuters data.
Please, please take your seats. Thank you once again for coming to DealBook's annual closing dinner, where we toast and roast the world of finance - and look ahead to the new year.

Early in my career as a critic at The New York Times, I began receiving nuisance calls from a ghost. This was before I had caller ID (or an unlisted number), and for a week or so I would pick up my phone only to hear an angry actress berating me for not singling out her performance in my review of an Off Broadway show in which she appeared as a specter. Since her part was wordless (and consumed less than a minute of stage time), I didn't really feel I could honor her request that The Times publish an addendum mentioning that she had been a very good ghost, which I disingenuously told her while she was on the phone.
ELLMAN--Sidney. Beloved Dad - Missing you every day, ten years now. Joyce Ellman and family

The reality show ''So You Think You Can Dance'' is getting shorter. Weeks or maybe months before Fox would have announced the change, the program's executive producer, Nigel Lythgoe, disclosed in a Twitter message on Sunday that the network had canceled the results show for the season scheduled to start in May. ''I will have to change the format,'' he added. Fox previously split the show into two nights, revealing the weekly results a day after the competitions. The eighth season, last year, lost ground to another summer competition, ''America's Got Talent'' on NBC, but it remains an important piece of Fox's schedule. A Fox scheduling executive said on Twitter on Monday that the reasons for the shortening would be explained ''in due time.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BUCKLEY--Ann, 84, died at home in Sharon, CT, on December 30. She grew up in Rye, New York, Graduated from Manhattanville College, and moved to Sharon on her marriage to James L. Buckley in 1953. She spent most of the years from 1971 until 2000 in Washington, D.C. where her husband served in various government positions. In 2006, she was in a car accident that left her a quadriplegic and with the mission to demonstrate that one can accept the consequences of such an accident and make the most of life, without complaint. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, her daughter Priscilla Buckley, sons Peter, Jay, Bill, David, Andrew, her sisters Kay Cooley and Helen Reilly, her brother Richard Cooley, and eight grandchildren. Contributions in her memory may be made to St. Bernard's Church or Christopher Reeve Foundation, 636 Morris Turnpike, Ste. 3A, Short Hills, NJ 07078.

Chicken fingers. No one - no chef and no parent - wants to raise a child who eats only chicken fingers. Or only white bread, or pasta-with-butter-and-nothing-else. The question of how to raise that highly desirable child who eats everything is one many first-time parents grapple with, and Fanae Aaron, an author and art director, was one such parent. Unlike most of us, though, who approach the process through trial and error, asking around the playground and either embracing or completely rejecting the foods we grew up with, Ms. Aaron set out to ask chefs how they fed their kids (who, she rightly presumed, mostly ate more than just white food).

Sir Michael Dummett, one of the most influential philosophers of the 20th century, died last week in Oxford, England. He held the position of Wykeham Professor of Logic at Oxford University from 1979 until his retirement in 1992. Below is a gathering of reminiscences from fellow philosophers, including Hilary Putnam, Timothy Williamson, Dorothy Edgington, Daniel Isaacson, and several others who knew Dummett, worked with him or were influenced by his life and work. We invite readers to offer their own contributions in the comments section.

The distinguished fine art photography collector W.M. Hunt's latest book, "The Unseen Eye" (Aperture, $75), is an extraordinarily unique photography collection, and it was, hands down, my favorite book of 2011. All the works amassed here feature subjects whose eyes are covered, abstracted or otherwise averted from the viewer's gaze. It's Hunt's own uncanny, adventurous and frequently provocative eye that allows him to pull off this quirky conceit so well. His selections range from the virtually unknown 19th-century works by Fratelli Alinari - featuring a man covered by a blanket walking on a high wire - to Richard Avedon's picture of Sophia Loren throwing her head back in ecstasy, taken around 1970. The imagery here is rich with undertones of mischief, mystique and the macabre. Works by Diane Arbus, Weegee, Edward Steichen and William Eggleston are also included. And if you can't get enough from the book alone, a portion of Hunt's collection is on exhibit in Rochester, at the George Eastman House until Feb. 19. Happy Hunting.

CAREY--William Polk. It is with sincere regret that we mourn the passing of our dear friend, William P. Carey. Bill was a long-standing and valued client who will always be remembered for his high moral character and genius for innovation in real estate finance. He excelled in his business acumen, high-reaching ideals, and inspiring generosity. This was expressed in his many charitable endeavors, especially in the area of higher education. We shall remember him with the highest regard and wish his family strength in bearing the sorrow of this great loss. May he rest in peace. Bloom Hochberg & Co., P.C.

ROBBIE--Jorene Frenkl, passed away on January 2nd, 2012. Loving wife to the late Gerald Alan Robbie, daughter to the late Kurt and Tony Frenkl, and mother to Hillary Kay Robbie. A graduate of Hunter HS, Barnard College, Columbia graduate school, and Fordham Law School, Jorene worked tirelessly as a law librarian, and was a devoted friend, wife, and mother. She will be missed. Funeral Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:15am on Thursday the 5th of January.

JUDOVITS--Dr. Hugo, 99, of New York and Atlanta, died on December 23, 2011 with his daughter and son-in-law by his side. Born in Naprad, Transylvania, he obtained his law degree (JD) in 1936 and his Doctorate of Juridical Science (SJD) from University of Cluj in 1939. Denied his rights to practice law, he was deported into forced labor and later the Mauthausen concentration camp from where he was liberated in 1945. He became a renowned jurist honored for his exceptional fairness, legal knowledge and integrity. A loving and devoted husband and father, he cared for his cherished wife Erna until her death in 1997. Following the loss of his brother-in-law Tibor Grady (died 1998) he helped care for his sister in law, Kato (died 2004). A generous and gentle spirit to the end, he will be dearly missed. He is survived by his daughter Dalia Judovits and her husband, Hamish Caldwell of Atlanta, and his niece and nephew Edith and Tom Judovits of Los Angeles.

SIEGEL--Stanley Z. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Stanley Z. Siegel, Esq., a prominent international attorney and rabbinic alumnus of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) who attended the Marsha Stern Talmudical Academy High School for Boys and Yeshiva College. With his wife Patricia, he was a YU Guardian and received the Yeshiva University Heritage Award. May Patricia, their children: Laura, Rabbis: Steven Lewis Siegel; Aharon Yisroel Siegel and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

Our deepest sympathy is extended to their sons, Daniel, Michael, Joel and Samuel, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

Could the television broadcast audience be growing less susceptible to the charms of ''The Bachelor'' on ABC? The season premiere of the series averaged 7.7 million total viewers over a two-hour period on Monday night, according to Nielsen data, down from the 9 million viewers who watched the 15th-season premiere last January. There was also a 17 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with last year. This placed ABC a distant second in the overall ratings among the broadcast networks, behind the CBS Monday comedy block. CBS finished No. 1 in all ratings categories in every prime-time half-hour. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CAREY--William Polk. Boys & Girls Harbor mourns the loss of its longtime friend and generous benefactor William Polk Carey. The Harbor Board, staff, and alumni express our deepest sympathy to the entire Carey family. Tony Duke Sr., Founder of Boys & Girls Harbor

A television review on Tuesday about ''Jane by Design,'' on ABC Family, misidentified the film in which the character Duckie appeared in comparing a character in ''Jane by Design'' to him. It was ''Pretty in Pink,'' not ''Sixteen Candles.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the TicketCity Bowl in Dallas, in which Houston beat Penn State and quarterback Case Keenum set a college football bowl record for most passing yards in a single quarter with 227 in the first, misstated the previous record. Browning Nagle of Louisville, facing Alabama in the 1991 Fiesta Bowl, threw for 223 yards in one quarter, not 233.

Liverpool has decided not to appeal the eight-game suspension given to striker Luis Suarez, who was found to have used racial insults against Manchester United defender Patrice Evra in December. But the club took a few parting shots at the findings of the commission that handed down the ban before announcing its decision not to appeal it. It is our strongly held conviction that the Football Association and the panel it selected constructed a highly subjective case against Luis Suarez based on an accusation that was ultimately unsubstantiated.

Admired aunt to Peter Fuchs, Betsy Osterman, and Patricia Sagon. Strong-willd and compassionate. Lover of music and opera; avid collector.

CHASE--Beverly Huntingdon Seaman, 92, of Rye, New York. Died peacefully at her home on December 31, 2011, of Alzheimer's. OFFICE SUPPLIES 3M, the maker of Post-it notes and Scotch Tape, has agreed to buy the office and consumer products business of the Avery Dennison Corporation for $550 million in cash. The Avery Dennison unit, which makes folder dividers and a popular brand of highlighters, will expand 3M's already extensive line of office and consumer supplies. The unit is expected to report profit of about $95 million on revenue of about $765 million for 2011. Avery Dennison said it planned to use some of the proceeds to reduce debt and buy back shares. EVELYN M. RUSLI

8:13 p.m. | Updated OTTAWA - The directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway have rebuked the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, rejecting his plan to replace the rail line's chief executive with a former rival.

One of the major casting questions pending on Broadway is whether ''Newsies,'' this spring's new Disney musical, will star Jeremy Jordan, whose performance as the newsboy Jack Kelly drew critical acclaim in the show's premiere in New Jersey last year and helped persuade Disney Theatrical Productions to transfer it to New York. Now that Mr. Jordan is free from the Broadway musical ''Bonnie & Clyde,'' which closed on Friday, it's a good bet that he'll be hawking ''papes'' as Jack on Broadway. The director of ''Newsies,'' Jeff Calhoun, who also directed Mr. Jordan in ''Bonnie & Clyde,'' recently told BroadwayWorld.com that ''it'll be fun to be with Jeremy again'' - which was apparently an inadvertent slip on his part, since a moment later Mr. Calhoun lamented that he might get ''in trouble'' for saying that. Speaking of the actor and Disney, Mr. Calhoun added, ''I'm sure they'll work out things, and he'll be back as Jack Kelly.'' Mr. Jordan, when told of Mr. Calhoun's remarks, laughed and then came close to confirming the scoop to that theater Web site: ''I think it's safe to say that I will probably be on board with that. It's not 100 percent by any means yet, but I imagine pretty soon things will all get worked out.''
SPATZ--Natalie, January 4, 1908 - June 6, 2000. Beloved, cherished, adored and treasured mother. Happy Birthday Mama. One lifetime with you was not enough. Allen, Kenneth and Diane

Van Halen has invited music writers and critics to an intimate concert at Cafe Wha? in Greenwich Village on Thursday night as a prelude to a tour with the band's classic lineup later this year. Nothing official has been released, but journalists have been told the group will play a short set. The one-night performance in that 250-seat club on MacDougal Street in Manhattan marks the latest enigmatic hint that the band has sent about its plans for the year. In late December, the band released videos on its Web site showing the original frontman, David Lee Roth, as well as the brothers Eddie and Alex Van Halen, rehearsing and goofing around while a ticker on the bottom of the screen read: ''Van Halen on Tour 2012 and ''First tickets on sale Jan. 10.''

BRAKA--David, 102, passed away peacefully on January 1. Son of the late Isaac and Sophie. He is predeceased by Pauline, his loving wife of 75 years. Devoted father of, Jeannette Bogart (Fred), Ivor Braka (Robin Aronsohn) and Robert Braka (Linda Sager). Treasured by his eight grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Born in Beirut, Lebanon his family later emigrated to Manchester, England. He was the eldest of nine children and is survived by sisters, Fortune Hazan and Esther Lever and brothers, Elie Braka, Albert Braka and Joe Braka. At the tennis courts at the Manchester Country Club he met the love of his life, Pauline Perez. In 1940 during World War II his wife with their two young children traveled on the Mayflower, the last ship leaving England bound for the United States. David followed shortly thereafter. They raised their family in Manhattan and Deal, N.J. before permanently residing in Aventura, Florida. Not only was he an avid tennis player and master bridge player but also loved a competitive game of backgammon. As a philanthropist he was a founding board member of the International Sephardic Education Foundation (ISEF). In Florida he was one of the founders of the Edmond J. Safra Synagogue Sephardic Synagogue of Turnberry of which he was named the Chairman Emeritus. He was a brilliant man who was admired and respected by all who knew him. The family's loss is profound as he was our leader.

The path into the playoffs for the Giants is clear enough. Win and they're in as the N.F.C. East champion. The Jets' path to an A.F.C. wild card is much more complicated, and more dependent on the fortunes of other teams, including the Bengals, the Titans, the Broncos and the Raiders. The only other unsettled playoff berth is the A.F.C. West championship, which will go to the Broncos or Raiders. Watching the final games of the regular season to see who wins the last few playoff berths is one of the most exciting times for a football fan. But if what you're interested in is which teams are most likely to make it to the Super Bowl, you'll pay even more attention to the teams jockeying for the top seeds.

TOLINS--Roger. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the bereaved family. Richard Lewis, President

WAINER--Andres Rojas, 1942-2011. Former Agence France Presse and UPI Latin American Desk Correspondent; and later Chilean Press Attache to the US under President Salvador Allende died in his home on December 24, 2011 from complications of primary systemic amyloidosis. In the latter half of his life Mr. Rojas was in private practice as a landscape designer. He lived in Petaluma, CA with his wife Catherine, daughter of renowned ophthalmologist Dr. Charles Schepens, and founder of Sausalito Springs, an early certified organic farm in California. He is survived by: his wife Catherine; his daughter Dr. Alicia Rojas, a physician and assistant professor at Columbia University Department of Psychiatry; and his son Clarence, artisan blacksmith and chief engineer for Pacific Coral Reed Foundation's new vessel's maiden voyage to Indonesia. American dance companies are once again heading overseas to practice a kind of choreographed diplomacy as part of the second season of DanceMotion USA. The Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs of the State Department and the Brooklyn Academy of Music are to announce on Wednesday plans for the international tours of the four American dance companies taking part. Under the direction of Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton the program, according to a news release, ''embraces the full use of diplomatic tools, in this case dance, to engage people and create opportunities for greater understanding.'' This year's companies include Rennie Harris Puremovement, which will tour Egypt, Israel and the Palestinian territories (March 9-April 6); Sean Curran Company, which will tour in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Turkmenistan (April 5-May 3); Jazz Tap Ensemble, which will tour in Mozambique, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Zimbabwe (April 9-May 7); and the Trey McIntyre Project, which will tour China, South Korea, the Philippines, and Vietnam (May 5-June 3)

It's not too early to be looking ahead to the N.F.L. draft, especially if you're a promising underclassman wanting to turn pro. Baylor's junior quarterback, Robert Griffin III, the recent Heisman Trophy winner, and Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck, who has a year of eligibility remaining, lead the crop of players who have declared for the draft. And in case you're booking ahead on your new 2012 calendar, the N.F.L. draft is scheduled for April 26-28.

A critic's notebook article on Friday about new and returning television shows in January misstated the broadcast date for the first of three ''Absolutely Fabulous'' specials on BBC America. It is Sunday, not Monday. The article also misstated the number of seasons ''30 Rock,'' on NBC, has been on the air. It is returning for its sixth season, not its fifth.

TOLINS--Roger Alan. Loving husband of Doris Levine Tolins for fifty-one years. Devoted father of Fran Weingast and Jonathan Tolins and father-in-law of Joshua Weingast and Robert Cary. Cherished grandfather of Arielle and Joanna Weingast, and Selina and Henry Tolins-Cary. Dear brother-in-law to Dr. Melvyn and Pam Levine, and uncle to Ian, Susan, and James S. Levine. He will be affectionately remembered by numerous cousins, friends, and business associates. He graduated with distinction from Dartmouth College and received an LL.B. and LL.M. from New York University School of Law. He enjoyed a distinguished career of more than fifty years as an attorney, founding the firm of Tolins & Lowenfels with Lewis Lowenfels. A lover of history and opera, he was most passionate about his family, his work, and his time on the golf course. Services Thursday, Temple Beth Sholom 401 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, New York, at 10am. Donations in Roger's memory may be sent to Hadassah and the American Cancer Society.

ROLLINS--Jane, 85, of New York, NY, passed away peacefully on January 1, 2012. Born Pearl Rose Levine on June 14, 1926 to Eva and Henry Levine, she lived in the Bronx, NY and graduated from New York's High School of Music & Art. She married Jack Rollins in 1948 and they resided on Manhattan's Upper West Side and at their summer home in Old Chatham, NY for most of their 63 year marriage. Jane was a professional singer with The Tattlers, a vocal quartet performing in nightclubs and theaters nationwide, and a musical cast member of television's "Your Hit Parade" in the early 1950's. When she left singing to raise a family she was an active member of the PTA, a Girl Scout leader, and a founding member of the West 83rd Street Block Association, one of the first organizations of its kind, as well as a vital helpmate to her husband in his career as a personal manager and film producer. Jane is survived by her husband, her three children, Susan Rollins of New York, NY, Hillary Rollins of Santa Monica, CA, and Francesca Rollins of Los Angeles, CA, and her younger sister, June Levine of Walnut Creek, CA. She is also survived by four grandchildren, two sons-in-law, cousins, nieces, nephews and numerous beloved friends who were like family to her. The funeral will be held Wednesday, January 4th, at 4pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Amsterdam Avenue and 76th St. Additional memorial services in Old Chatham and Los Angeles are planned for the near future. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, one of the many causes she championed.

Leading a new federal agency intended to help prevent another financial crisis may seem like a dream job for most economic gurus, but the government made a nomination only last month after a painfully slow search process. The Treasury Department first considered at least three other candidates during the 17-month hunt for a director of the new agency, the Office of Financial Research. But they all rebuffed the role, in part over fears of the contentious Congressional approval process. The White House finally unveiled the in-house nominee - Richard Berner, a counselor to the Treasury secretary who was formerly the chief United States economist for Morgan Stanley - in a little-noticed news release late on a Friday in December.

Sunrise, sunset. An old year ends, a new one begins; a rock 'n' roll residency comes to an end, another one continues. And while Patti Smith has brought an end to her New Year's Eve performances at the Bowery Ballroom, the Allman Brothers Band will continue its annual tradition of playing a run of dates at the Beacon Theater in March. That long-lived Southern rock group, including the keyboardist Gregg Allman, has announced 10 shows at the Beacon on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, its representatives said, on March 9 and 10, 13 and 14, 16 and 17, 20 and 21, and 24 and 25. This year's residency comes during a year in which the Allman Brothers Band will celebrate the 40th -- yes, 40th -- anniversary of its live album ''Eat a Peach'' and is to receive a Grammy Award for lifetime achievement in February.

Broadway producers and theater owners charged higher-than-usual prices for many seats last week to take advantage of tourists over the temperate New Year's weekend, and the resulting profits were enormous. Eighteen of Broadway's 34 shows earned more than $1 million, with ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' setting a record for the highest gross ever on Broadway -- $2,941,794 for nine performances - according to data released by producers on Tuesday afternoon. Over all, Broadway musicals and plays grossed a total of $37.7 million, compared to $35 million for the same holiday period last year. The average paid admission last week was $117 last week, compared to about $106 a year ago.

PATRON--June Eileen, passed away January 1st at her home in Washington, DC. She is survived by cousins, colleagues and friends. Born and raised in New York City, she graduated from Hunter High School in 1961, received a BA with Honors in Government from Clark University in 1965 and an MA in Political Science from The American University in Washington, DC. Her professional career was with the U.S. Department of Labor in Washington, DC where she held increasingly responsible positions in the Manpower Administration, the Office of the Under Secretary, the Employment Standards Administration, and the Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration. A charter member of the Senior Executive Service, she helped administer the Black Lung Program and, after passage of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, was the senior civil service executive in charge of administering that program until her retirement in 1995. Since her retirement, she has travelled extensively and been active in alumni affairs of Clark University. Services Thursday 1pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

FARBER--Doris Balmuth, passed away on January 3, 2012, at her home in Manhattan, surrounded by her family. She faced her death as she lived her life: fearlessly, without self-pity, and with elegance and dignity. Born in Brooklyn in 1923, she was the adored and adoring daughter of Beatrice Landau and Irving Balmuth. She attended the Crown Heights Yeshiva before graduating from Erasmus Hall High School at age 16 and Hunter College three years later. She attended Columbia and Brooklyn Law Schools and was admitted to the New York Bar in 1946. She later chose to work with her father and beloved brother Jerome running the family business, Standard Furniture Showrooms, and retired in 1977. Doris married Saul J. Farber, M.D. in 1949 and enjoyed 57 wonderful years enthusiastically sharing his life at NYU Medical Center and within the broader community of academic medicine. Doris participated fully in the cultural life of New York, which she shared with her many loving friends. She was deeply devoted to her family, and raised them with pride and love of their Jewish heritage and Israel. She is survived by her children: her son Joshua M. Farber and his wife Nancy M. Hardy, her daughter Beth M. Farber and her husband Stephan M. Loewentheil, and five grandchildren who were the lights of her life: Kara, Nathaniel and Jacob Loewentheil and Daniel and Josephine Farber.
FARBER--Doris. You will be deeply missed and always remembered. Our eternal love, Martin Begun and Louise Sunshine.

(Cooking) NOT MY MAMA'S MEALS Bobby Deen, above, a son of the Food Network star Paula Deen and a chef in his own right, takes on recipes for Southern comfort food created by his mother and makes them leaner and lighter. In this series premiere he transforms Ms. Deen's Krispy Kreme bread pudding and chocolate mousse pie into fat- and calorie-reduced fresh-fruit bread pudding and frozen chocolate pie. 12:55 P.M. (Sho2) TWO LOVERS (2009) Joaquin Phoenix portrays Leonard Kraditor, a Brooklynite in his 30s who, after a breakup and a breakdown, lives in Brighton Beach with his parents (Moni Moshonov and Isabella Rossellini), works for his father's dry-cleaning business and dabbles in photography. Gwyneth Paltrow is Michelle, a sophisticated, slightly unstable beauty newly arrived in Leonard's apartment building, where she is being kept by a married lawyer (Elias Koteas). And Vinessa Shaw is Sandra, the daughter of a business associate of Leonard's father's and an advantageous catch. How can Leonard choose? Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that this film from the director James Gray was ''modest in scale, but the feelings that run through it are large and intense.'' In the end ''the flaws in 'Two Lovers' are inseparable from its strengths,'' he added. ''You could, I suppose, criticize the movie for being too sincere; too generous to its imperfect, self-deluded characters; too absorbed in their small crises and disproportionate reactions. But that criticism might sound a lot like praise.''

Order another corsage for ''Bridesmaids,'' because it's going to the Producers Guild of America party. That organization announced on Tuesday that it had chosen the comedy as one of its 10 best film nominees of the year, possibly advancing its standing with the Academy Awards voters on the road to the Oscars. ''The Ides of March,'' George Clooney's political thriller, also got a nod from the producers, another lift for that film following several Golden Globe nominations. ''The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,'' which so far has been a longer shot, according to many Academy Awards watchers, made the list too. The other films the Producers Guild chose are the expected bunch: ''The Artist,'' ''The Descendants,'' ''The Help,'' ''Moneyball,'' ''Midnight in Paris,'' ''Hugo'' and ''War Horse.''

At the Thurgood Marshall Academy for Learning and Social Change, a public school on West 135th Street in Harlem, every one of the 82 members of the senior class is expected to apply to college.  At a suburban or private school, or at a wealthier city school, these seniors would have all the help they need.  They would have been raised in families where going to college is a given. They would have advisers who know about a wide range of colleges and have contacts in admissions offices.  They would take test-prep courses and rewrite their personal essays numerous times with the help of a savvy editor.  They would have a list of deadlines to meet and be constantly pushed to meet them by parents and school advisers.

In riffing on the multiple reasons that I'm enjoying the Republican nomination process as a supremely entertaining piece of transmedia storytelling, I made passing mention of Rick Perry's Unpopular Opinions, a one-topic Tumblr inspired by the Texas governor's ad titled "Strong." In that spot, Perry asserted that "you know there's something wrong in this country when gays can serve openly in the military, but our kids can't openly celebrate Christmas." The Internet found that argument laughably suspect, and in addition to making the YouTube version of the commercial one of the most "disliked" videos ever, responded with a barrage of interactive/remix mockery. The aforementioned Tumblr is a conspicuous example, and is made of up GIFs of the same self-assured, Carhartt-clad Perry from the commercial, captioned with phrases like " 'The Wire' was a dumb show" and "Kim Jong the Second was a humane leader."

"These are not aristocratic feet. I'm here to tell you these are working feet," says Park Avenue's go-to podiatrist, Suzanne Levine, after a quick examination of my not-so-pretty pieds. In all fairness, my childhood and adolescence were spent studying ballet. Anyone who's worn a pair of pointe shoes will confirm that dancing in them is a kind of quiet torture that ceases to bother only after you've grown numb to the pain. Your feet never really recover from the trauma. I sought out Levine and a few other foot gurus after determining spring's must-have shoes: the bejeweled slip-ons from Oscar de la Renta, the velvet clogs from Miu Miu and the heel-less metallic numbers with super-pointy toes from Louis Vuitton, among others. The problem? All of these options are of the 18th-century mule variety. In other words, they leave your heels fully exposed, and mine, still callused and battered to a point seemingly beyond return, were in no position to be naked.

Corey Stoll was just a little-known actor who happened to be appearing opposite Scarlett Johansson in "A View From the Bridge" on Broadway when Woody Allen - who cast Ms. Johansson in his film "Match Point" -- came to see the show. Not long after, Mr. Stoll, best known from his role as the bald detective on the short-lived "Law & Order: Los Angeles," was called in to see Mr. Allen about a part in "Midnight in Paris." He was duly petrified but wound up with the role of Hemingway. He donned a wig and a mustache, and on screen he was one of the most memorable stars in a cast that included Owen Wilson and Marion Cotillard.

The Japanese designer Sori Yanagi, who died on Dec. 25 in Tokyo at the age of 96, is best known for his 1956 Butterfly Stool. It is both elegant and utterly simple: two curved pieces of molded plywood are held together through compression and tension by a single brass rod. The stool's graceful shape recalls a butterfly's wings, and has also been compared to the form of torii, the traditional Shinto shrine gates. According to Matilda McQuaid, the deputy curatorial director at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, the stool "epitomizes Yanagi's approach to design. He loved traditional Japanese crafts and was dedicated to the modernist principles of simplicity, practicality and tactility that are associated with Alvar Aalto, Charles and Ray Eames, and Le Corbusier."

Akram Khan's first full-length solo work, "Desh" received rapturous critical notices and attracted capacity audiences when it had its premiere at Sadler's Wells this past October. So much so that the theater, unusually, decided to present "Desh" - a work in which Mr. Khan explores the confluence of his Bangladeshi origins with his British upbringing - again this season, in February. But Mr. Khan has had to cancel these coming performances, as well as a run of "Sacred Monsters," with Sylvie Guillem, in France this week, because of an injured Achilles tendon, which is likely to keep him offstage for several months. Sadler's Wells plans to schedule a replacement run of "Desh" in October.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences released its shortlist of contenders for the visual effects Oscar yesterday, and the Bagger's readers already have quibbles with the selection. Why didn't "The Adventures of Tintin," "Super 8" and "Green Lantern" (yes, the lone fan has spoken up) make the cut? The 10 films that did make it through include "Hugo," which may well also be a contender in another visual category, best art direction. The Bagger's colleague, Mekado Murphy, takes a closer look at the production design of that film, which included a bookstore set with 40,000 books, or, shall we say, booklike objects. Some of the "books" are actually fiberglass creations painted to look like tomes. "Since the books are so heavy, when you have to move them for the camera, you lose too much time," explained the production designer, Dante Ferretti. Read more »

The designer Angela Scott's lovingly offbeat boots and heels don't sell by the thousands and can't be found in more than a handful of stores - Jeffrey in New York and Tomorrowland in Japan are two of them - but that's exactly how the Texas-based designer likes it. "I think there's something unique about a product that isn't overproduced," says Scott about her shoes, all of which are bench-made in small-batch factories by cobblers who hand-stitch and mold the vegetable-tanned leather and eco-friendly cork soles that characterize Scott's collection. "I'd love to just be in one shop, the best shop, in cities around the world. That would be a lovely place for me to sit," she says.

For more than 20 years, the fine art photographer Harold Ross has been making images using a technique known as "painting with light," which involves casting light on and around subjects in the dark during a time exposure. Mr. Ross, who also does commercial and studio photography, prefers to call the process "sculpting with light." Using a Phase One Back on a Hassleblad for still life photographs and a Cambo Wide RS for landscapes, he spends hours creating his images, which look like oil paintings, rich in color and depth.

CHASE--Beverly Huntingdon Seaman, 92, of Rye, New York. Died peacefully at her home on December 31, 2011, of Alzheimer's. Loving wife of Hollis H. for 69 years, dear mother of Kenneth Huntington of Manhattan, sister-in-law of Wilbur Porteus Chase of Kensington, MD. Born April 7, 1919 in Manhattan, daughter of the late Julian Huntington Seaman and Gladys Lorraine Dodge (later Preston), granddaughter of Frank Morgan Seaman of Yama Farms, Napanoch, NY. Longtime resident of Westchester Country Club; service on January 6 at 2pm at Rye Presbyterian Church; private interment in family crypt at Ferncliff Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Alzheimer's Association or Hospice & Palliative Care of Westchester.

A music producer and a downtown theater said on Wednesday that they would establish a festival of new music-theater works next January called ''Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now.'' The festival will last two weeks and take place at the Here Arts Center in the South Village, in collaboration with Beth Morrison Projects, which produces musical events. It will feature what Ms. Morrison called ''serious young composers'' whose works are often termed ''contemporary classical'' or ''post-classical.'' The organizers released few details about the festival, saying only that it would feature one commission, two unnamed ''presentations,'' concerts and panels.

The High & Low Finance column on Dec. 16, about the regulation of so-called short sales, misstated what was publicly known about some stocks involved in two Securities and Exchange Commission enforcement actions against traders. All the stocks appeared on a list, maintained by the securities exchanges, of heavily shorted shares in which there had been a large number of failures to deliver the shares. It is not the case that most were absent from that list.

An article last Thursday about 75 subjects frequently talked about in 2011 misidentified the New York mayor for whom John Zuccotti was a deputy. He served under Abraham Beame, not Edward Koch. The article also misstated the year that MoMA staged a Marina Abramovic retrospective. It was 2010, not 2011. And the article described her appearance in the show incorrectly. She was not nude, although some models were.

SMART--G. Oliver. The Board of Governors of the Circumnavigators Club records with profound sorrow, the death of its past International President - 1980, G. Oliver Smart, on December 23, 2011, and extends its deepest sympathy to his family.

1/5/12 | Updated In a deal that represents billions of dollars in revenue for the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment giant and Comcast said Wednesday that they had reached a decade-long distribution agreement covering all of Disney's television content, including streaming for iPads and other devices. The unusually long-term agreement provides a window into the future of television viewing and how its content will be consumed. Comcast, the nation's largest cable provider, will gain the rights to provide the Disney Channel, ESPN, Disney XD, ABC Family and the ABC broadcast network, among other Disney-owned services, to subscribers wherever they want to watch.
GROBERG--Marcia. 1/5/2005. Marcia lived a life of noble kindness and sentiment, strength and purity of character and charity for all. I mourn her death and celebrate her life. David Levidow

An article on Saturday about a population explosion among snow geese misidentified a type of bird that snow geese may try to displace when they arrive in the waters of the Sacramento National Wildlife Refuge in the wintertime. It is the white-fronted goose, not the white-footed goose. And the article referred imprecisely to the Tule goose. It is a subspecies of the white-fronted goose, not a separate species.

Having managed in Los Angeles, Joe Torre now wants to return to the Dodgers, but this time as part of an ownership group. Torre resigned from his job as executive vice president for baseball operations for Major League Baseball on Wednesday to join a group seeking to buy the Dodgers. The group is led by Rick J. Caruso, a Los Angeles real estate developer best known for the Grove, a successful retail and entertainment development near the Farmers Market in the city.

The Daily News of New York on Wednesday appointedColin Myler, a former editor of the recently closed News of the World tabloid in London, its editor in chief. Effective on Tuesday, Mr. Myler, 59, will succeed Kevin Convey, a former editor of The Boston Herald who has led The Daily News since 2010.

JAKUPS--Judy Nobel. Died suddenly of a heart attack on January 1st 2012. She was a smart, talented and beautiful woman who brought life and incredible spirit wherever she went. She is loved and will be missed by her husband Thomas, son Jack, brother Barry and his wife Maija, twin sister Laurie Everitt, parents Fred and Gilda Nobel, and everyone who had the honor of knowing her. Memorial services will be held at 1:30pm January 7 at The Universalist Church of West Hartford, CT. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York City.

9 P.M. (Lifetime) PROJECT RUNWAY ALL STARS Thirteen designers from past seasons (among them Elisa Jimenez, above, from the fourth season) return to the sewing room to do battle again. The model Angela Lindvall oversees the drama; Joanna Coles, the editor in chief of the American edition of Marie Claire, is the mentor; and Isaac Mizrahi, the creative director of Liz Claiborne New York, and Georgina Chapman, the creative director and designer of Marchesa, are the judges. In ''24 Hour Catwalk,'' a new series at 10, four fashion designers must create a three-piece collection and present a runway show in a single day. Alexa Chung hosts. James LaForce, a media consultant; Derek Blasberg, a fashion writer; and the designer Cynthia Rowley are the judges. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DIVING INTO NOAH'S FLOOD The archaeologist Jeff Rose explores the destructive forces of water that might have inspired the biblical story of Noah's Ark and the great flood. Dr. Rose suggests that a flood once swallowed an area as large as Britain, creating the Persian Gulf and forcing tribes of Neolithic people to retreat.

YOUNG--JOHN F. 1919-2011 Jack departed peacefully on December 6. He is survived by his wife Ann, brothers George and Roger, sister Claire Trabulsi and his many friends, business associates, yachtsmen and crews throughout the northern hemisphere. A memorial service will be held on April 28 in Essex, Conn., to celebrate his life and achievements.

BRAKA--David, 102, passed away peacefully on January 1. Son of the late Isaac and Sophie. He is predeceased by Pauline, his loving wife of 75 years. Devoted father of, Jeannette Bogart (Fred), Ivor Braka (Robin Aronsohn) and Robert Braka (Linda Sager). Treasured by his eight grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Born in Beirut, Lebanon his family later emigrated to Manchester, England. He was the eldest of nine children and is survived by sisters, Fortune Hazan and Esther Lever and brothers, Elie Braka, Albert Braka and Joe Braka. At the tennis courts at the Manchester Country Club he met the love of his life, Pauline Perez. In 1940 during World War II his wife with their two young children traveled on the Mayflower, the last ship leaving England bound for the United States. David followed shortly thereafter. They raised their family in Manhattan and Deal, N.J. before permanently residing in Aventura, Florida. Not only was he an avid tennis player and master bridge player but also loved a competitive game of backgammon. As a philanthropist he was a founding board member of the International Sephardic Education Foundation (ISEF). In Florida he was one of the founders of the Edmond J. Safra Synagogue Sephardic Synagogue of Turnberry of which he was named the Chairman Emeritus. He was a brilliant man who was admired and respected by all who knew him. The family's loss is profound as he was our leader.
COOPER--Wyatt E.,September 1,1927-January 5th, 1978. Daddy and Carter within us always. Gloria and Anderson

A picture caption on Monday with an article about the demise of the TouchPad tablet from Hewlett-Packard misstated the corporate affiliation of the two executives shown. Jon Rubenstein, former chief executive of Palm, is a senior vice president at H.P., which acquired Palm in 2010; Todd Bradley is executive vice president of H.P.'s personal systems group. Neither was a Palm executive at the time the photograph was taken in early February 2011.

WEST DES MOINES, Iowa -- Having only decided not to continue her presidential bid on Wednesday morning, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota has yet to decide whether to run for re-election to Congress. Her spokeswoman, Alice Stewart, said that Mrs. Bachmann ''just made up her mind about this this morning,'' and that ''she hasn't made a decision'' about her next step.

Viewing at the Lewis & Carey Directors of Funerals, 312 West Main St, Boonton, NJ on Friday from 4-8pm. Funeral Liturgy in St. Pius X Church, 24 Changebridge Rd, Montville, NJ on Saturday at 10:00am. Microsoft Word, for both Windows and Mac OS X systems, is full of keyboard shortcuts to help speed things along as you work. Although the Web has plenty of pages listing the shortcuts, like Microsoft's own collection for Word 2010 at bit.ly/eMfs5o, you can also generate a chart from the Word program, which can be handy if you want to print it or edit the list to add custom key commands. In later versions, like Word 2010 and Word 2007, you first need to show the Developer tab if it is not already displayed on the Ribbon. In Word 2010, click the File tab and choose Options. In the Word Options box, click Customize Ribbon, select Developer and click OK. In Word 2007, click the Office button, click the Word Options button and click Popular to get to the ''Show Developer Tab in the Ribbon'' option.

3:35 p.m. | Updated Landon Donovan provided some wonderful highlights during his two-month, 13-game loan to Everton in 2010. Though credited with only two goals during his brief time with the Toffees, Donovan played extremely well: he injected speed on the wing, served up assists, took corner kicks and helped the squad earn victories over the likes of Manchester City, Manchester United and Chelsea. Named the club's player of the month for January, he made a lasting impression with fans, teammates and Everton Manager David Moyes. So expectations are understandably elevated with the 29-year-old Donovan in the starting lineup with the club Wednesday against Bolton (3 p.m. EST, Fox Soccer Plus).

In separate radio interviews Wednesday, Jets quarterbacks past and present unloaded on the team for fostering a culture of dysfunction and selfishness. And neither of them was Joe Namath. The rookie Greg McElroy, when asked about the mood in the Jets' locker room after Santonio Holmes's scuffle with teammates during Sunday's game against Miami, told WZNN-FM in Birmingham, Ala., that a ''corrupt mind-set'' existed, which made the locker room ''definitely not a fun place to be, I can assure you.''

GINSBERG--Allen, renowned diamond expert, of Boynton Beach and formerly of Manhattan, died December 14, 2011, in Florida, after a brief illness. Born September 1, 1924, in New York, Mr. Ginsberg was raised in upper Manhattan and the Bronx. After graduating from the High School of Commerce, he fought with distinction as an infantryman in WWII, volunteering for reconnaissance duty ahead of the front lines in France and Germany. After the war, he worked as a diamond cutter in Manhattan, and rose to the highest echelons of the diamond industry, principally during his long tenure at Zale Corporation, where he served as a Director and as President of the International Diamond Division. Mr. Ginsberg's influential role in the world's diamond markets on behalf of Zale took him around the globe twice a year and on numerous overseas trips in between--this son of the Great Depression a regular, esteemed visitor to the Far East, Russia, India, Africa, Israel and Europe. Mr. Ginsberg was a serious reader, an avid golfer, a staunch supporter of Israel and the ADL, a sparkling conversationalist who loved to laugh, and, perhaps most strikingly of all, a world-class listener. Gracious, humble, warm-hearted, and of the utmost integrity, Mr. Ginsberg was treasured throughout his life by his wide circle of family, friends, and business colleagues. He was predeceased by too many years by his older brother, Jack. Mr. Ginsberg will always be greatly loved and missed by Betty, his wife of 63 years, daughters Carol Ginsberg Brown and Barbara Ginsberg, sons-in-law Eric Brown and Ira Schreck, grandchildren Alex, Vivian, Jesse and Daniel, brother Mike, nieces and nephew, and all fortunate enough to have known him well. A service celebrating his memory will be held in Manhattan on Sunday, February 12, 2012, 11am, at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 W 88th St. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 621 NW 43rd St., Ste 450, Boca Raton, FL 33487.

Updated 5:42 p.m. | The Queens private detective who raped his ex-girlfriend and then framed her for a series of fictional crimes was sentenced to the maximum of 32 years in prison on Wednesday, bringing to a close one of the most bizarre cases to grace a courtroom. Using knowledge he acquired partly from watching crime dramas like ''C.S.I.,'' the private detective, Jerry Ramrattan, 39, orchestrated what prosecutors in Queens called one of the most elaborate frame-ups in recent history.

Barnes & Noble has put Sterling Publishing up for sale, nearly a decade after it bought the publishing house, a person briefed on the matter said Wednesday. The move was another sign that Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookstore chain, has intensified its focus on the digital side of the book business by shedding other assets. Sterling Publishing, based in New York, has imprints focused on nonfiction, children's books, crafting, cooking and self-help, among others.

''Relatively Speaking,'' a triple bill of short comedies that marked Woody Allen's return to Broadway as a playwright after 30 years, will close on Jan. 29 after a total of 153 performances, the show's producers announced in a statement on Wednesday. A spokesman for the producers said that they expected to recoup their full investment by the time the show closes; the producers declined to provide that dollar amount. Directed by the actor John Turturro, the production includes a brief play about bad parenting, ''Talking Cure,'' by the playwright and film director Ethan Coen, and an absurdist look at mortality, ''George is Dead,'' written by Elaine May and starring Marlo Thomas in a critically admired performance. Rounding out the show is Mr. Allen's marital farce ''Honeymoon Motel,'' which includes Caroline Aaron, Steve Guttenberg, Julie Kavner, and Mark Linn-Baker in the cast.

RUBIN--Albert. Loving husband of Lillian Rubin for fifty-four years. Beloved father of Philip Rubin and Marjorie Harris and father-in-law of Mardi Schecter and Josh Harris. Cherished grandfather of Jesse, Lucy and Ella Rubin and Hannah, Stuart, Thomas, Pierce and Bridget Harris. He was well regarded by business associates and respected for the contributions he made during forty-five years in the Packaging Industry. He will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him. For more information please contact "Sinai Chapels" 800-446-0406.

HEAVY DISCOUNT The Italian bank UniCredit, which is seeking to raise capital to comply with new requirements, offered existing shareholders a significant discount on new stock on Wednesday, sending its shares tumbling. The bank, Italy's largest, announced that it would sell new stock at 1.943 euros a share in an effort to raise nearly 7.5 billion euros ($9.7 billion). At that level, the company said, the price represented a 43 percent discount. The market reacted swiftly to the news, driving UniCredit's shares down more than 9 percent, to 5.77 euros, in afternoon trading.

RUMOR has it that the Proenza Schouler designers, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, are scouting Madison Avenue for space for their first store. Imagine the possibilities: a shop where sweet salesmen wear name tags bearing only their mothers' maiden names. In the meantime, take note of the label's growing collection of lust-worthy accessories, including this new canvas-and-python striped bag in the PS1 tote shape: smart and cool, just like the clothes.

An article on Wednesday about the effectiveness of former Senator Rick Santorum's lean political operation in the Iowa caucuses referred incorrectly to Tom Latham, whose daughter ran Mr. Santorum's field operation in the state. Mr. Latham currently represents Iowa's fourth Congressional District in the House of Representatives; he is not a former congressman.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about legislative measures to curb online piracy, misspelled the surname of a founder of the Web site Kickstarter, who commented on the effort. He is Yancey Strickler, not Stickler.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. - By the end of the day Sunday, the Giants will have faced a number of notable opponents on their quest for a Super Bowl: the New England Patriots, the San Francisco 49ers, the New Orleans Saints, the Green Bay Packers and three guys named Ryan. On Dec. 24, the Giants beat the Jets and their portly, outspoken coach, Rex Ryan, to win the unofficial city championship. Last Sunday, they defeated the Dallas Cowboys and their portly, outspoken defensive coordinator, Rob Ryan, to clinch a playoff berth. So perhaps it is only fitting that they open the postseason Sunday against Atlanta and the steely, sure-armed Matt Ryan.

Fred Milano, one of the original members of Dion and the Belmonts, who wove his backup tenor tones into the musically seamless harmonies of 1950s and '60s hits like ''A Teenager in Love'' and ''Where or When,'' died on Sunday at a hospital on Long Island. He was 72 and lived in Massapequa, N.Y. The cause was complications of lung cancer, his brother-in-law Mark Alter said.

A few weeks back, a colleague, Jenna Wortham, wrote about the growing popularity of emoji, which are much more elaborate versions of emoticons. Emoji, which in Japan is as common as teenage girl pop ensembles, can be had on your iPhone just by changing your keyboard settings. Activate it and you can send a broad selection of pictures, from animals like bears and mice, to pictures of mugs clinking - a one-character invitation for drinks.

AT Joinery, a new boutique in Williamsburg, you'll find an eclectic selection of fashion and quirky housewares from little-known names from around the world, all of it carefully curated by the owner, Angela Silva (shown). There are Warmi sweater dresses handmade in Colombia, arty print tops from the Japanese-Brazilian designer Fernanda Yamamoto and wood-handle natural brushes made by the German company Redecker. You'll discover chambray lounge pants from Choctaw Ridge, a New York label; demure satin lingerie from Fortnight in Canada; and mud-cloth print coats from Osei-Duro, produced by a women's co-op in Ghana. For each item she sells, Ms. Silva, who worked as an art director, designs a thoughtfully written hangtag detailing the origin of the piece. She was inspired to open the shop, she said, while writing her style blog, How to Change a Flat. ''I felt like I had the makings of a store and was enjoying it more than what I was doing.''
