The police said Wednesday that ''no criminality is suspected'' in the case of the 15-year-old Staten Island girl who died Monday after jumping in front of a city bus, and whose uncle alleged that bullying at school was partly to blame. The death of the girl, Amanda Cummings, has been ruled a suicide by the city medical examiner's office. Amanda died six days after being struck by a southbound Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus in Dongan Hills, Staten Island, with a suicide note in her pocket, the police said.

KUPFERBERG--Selma Ruth. Beloved wife of Max, devoted mother of Saul (Gail Coleman), Rhoda Kupferberg Joss (Paul Joss), dear sister of Harvey Share. Services Friday 11:30am "Sinai Chapels" 162-05 Horace Harding Expy Fresh Meadows, NY.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Ed Snider, the chairman of the company that owns the Philadelphia Flyers, referred incorrectly to his role in the origination of the team, which began play in the National Hockey League in 1967. He was part of a group led by Jerry Wolman that established the Flyers; Snider was not the sole founder.

KAHN--D. Dan. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express great sadness at the loss of D. Dan Kahn of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, a legendary supporter with decades long ties to the Technion. One of the largest gifts ever made to the ATS was for the D. Dan and Betty Kahn Mechanical Engineering Building, now under construction at the Technion. Mr. Kahn and his late wife Betty also funded the D. Dan and Betty Kahn Medical Robotics Lab and the D. Dan and Betty Kahn Protective Shield to secure the campus. They were also among the original supporters of the aeronautical engineering building, the first on the Technion's Mount Carmel campus. A past president of the ATS Detroit Chapter, Mr. Kahn was a member of the national Board of Directors and of the Technion International Board of Governors. A Technion Guardian, he was recognized with an honorary fellowship in 2006, and an honorary doctorate in 2011. Active in many organizations and institutions in his hometown, Mr. Kahn also established a cardiovascular medical engineering research fund at the University of Michigan to encourage collaboration with Technion scientists. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children Andrea Wolfe, and husband Lawrence; Patrice Aaron, and husband Mark; and Mark Kahn, and wife Judy; and the entire Kahn family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

The sign is now of the times. A new liquor shop on Lenox Avenue in Harlem that was at the center of a gentrifying neighborhood's dispute about storefront aesthetics has replaced its old sign with one more suitable to the sedate vision the enclave has of itself.

EVEN if that much-deserved island getaway isn't happening this month, fashion designers have made certain that you can at least be dressed for the part. The resort collections of Michael Kors, Alexander Wang, Derek Lam and McQ were awash in water-world references. Then, on the spring runways, Joseph Altuzarra showed sculptural dresses with the sleek lines of wetsuits, and Peter Pilotto sent out tropical prints with the sporty-sexy look of scuba gear. (The model Miranda Kerr, above, already scored one of the Pilotto dresses for a recent event.) As Marina Larroude, the senior fashion editor of Style.com, notes, a scuba-cute shape is modern and unfussy. ''It looks fresh and has a young vibe,'' she said. Clockwise from above: Michael Kors stretch wool racer-back dress, $1,795 at net-a-porter.com. Alexander Wang scuba swimsuit, $365; silk vest, $450; and jogging pants, $545, at

NEUHAUS--Neal P.,60, a gentleman and a gentle man, died peacefully on January 3 with his friends and family at his side. A lifelong New Yorker, he lived life with dignity, grace, humor and intellect. A beloved friend, adored son, nephew and cousin and to hundreds of faculty and students at York Prep, where he taught math for 35 years, he was "the man." Neal never had an unkind word to say, nor could one be said about him. He will be greatly missed. Contributions to the York Prep Scholarship Foundation in Honor of Neal Neuhaus would be appreciated and can be sent to: York Prep School, 40 W. 68th St., New York, NY 10023.

James Franco, the laconic actor who collects M.F.A.'s when he isn't starring in movies or hosting the Oscars, will publish his first novel in 2013. ''Actors Anonymous,'' a follow-up to ''Palo Alto,'' a book of short stories that was released in 2010, was acquired by Amazon Publishing New York, the company said on Wednesday. Ed Park, the senior editor who acquired the book, called it ''a hugely ambitious and wild ride.'' ''Like James himself, this novel transcends categories,'' he said in an e-mail. The book is one of the most high-profile acquisitions that Amazon Publishing has made. Mr. Franco jumped to Amazon from Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, which published ''Palo Alto.'' A spokesman for Scribner declined to comment.
BERG--Dr. William, loving and devoted husband, dad, grandfather, uncle and best friend. Your enthusiasm and zest for life will live on in all of us. We love you.

CARTER--Judge Robert L. The Board of Directors, Staff, children and families of Northside Center for Child Development note with sadness the passing of Judge Carter, an activist and fighter for justice for all people. He joined our Board in 1965, and we are deeply grateful for his many years of service as a member of our Board, and more recently on the Northside Council of Advisors. Judge Carter was a close friend of Northside's founders, Drs. Kenneth and Mamie Phipps Clark, and relied on their "Doll Study" research to attack the scourge of segregation, bringing their work into the historic Brown vs. Board of Education case. He understood Northside's mission to give children the strength to meet the impact of racial subjugation and discrimination and not be defeated. His determination and spirit to fight injustices everywhere made this world a better place. We loved him and will miss him terribly. Michael Goldstein, Chairman Susan Patricof, President Thelma Dye, Ph.D., Executive Director/CEO

WICKS--David, 70, died December 30, 2011, of complications following heart surgery. He is survived by his wife, Joan, daughters Perrin and Sara, sons-in-law John Butterworth and James Malone, granddaughters Lila and Eva, sister Elizabeth Wicks, and brother John Wicks. A Memorial Service will be held at 4 o'clock on January 11 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and Fifth Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Trinity College Rowing, and Darden School of Business, UVA.

MARIJANA CONDIC and Lisa Leipziger, friends in Frankfurt, had a modest mission: to make espadrilles that were sturdier than the Spanish styles they love to wear. ''I came back from holiday in Spain and told Marijana we have to do something special with espadrilles so they don't fall apart after a month,'' Ms. Leipziger said. Their label, Lika Mimika, is the happy result. The unisex styles, in soft lamb, goat and calfskin, are hand-stitched in Spain and come in a range of neutrals and Pop colors. Two new styles, lined with rabbit fur or curly lamb shearling, are a clever travel shoe: cozy for the flight and vacation-ready upon landing.

TAGUE--Charles Francis, 87 passed away peacefully on January 1. Proud member of the "Greatest Generation" he lived his life with humor, dignity and a selfless sense of duty and was cherished by his six children and 11 grand-children. Born August 16, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY, educated at St. Anne's Academy and Fordham University. Drafted to the Navy during W.W.II, he was a signalman aboard LCF-18 at D-Day, and later served in the South Pacific. On August 6, 1949, he married his life's love Alicia. Together they lived in Jackson Heights, NY, Colts Neck, NJ, Upper Saddle River, N.J. and Jackson, N.J., sharing with their family and friends 62 years of memories. He enjoyed a distinguished career as a Financial Officer. He is survived by his sons Patrick, Charles, Thomas, James and daughters Mary Alicia Haberman and Beth Anne Giuliano , their spouses, Brenda, Gloria, Elise, Liza and Joseph, and 11 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Church of the Presentation, Upper Saddle River, NJ.

ROSENTHAL--Alvin. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Alvin Rosenthal, Trustee Emeritus of The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust. In his role at the Helmsley Trust he lent his vision to a number of Trust-supported programs that had a significant impact on Mount Sinai: The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust Center for Cardiac Electrophysiology, The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust Cardiac Translational Research Center, The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust Inflammatory Bowel Disease Center, and the Sinai-Helmsley Alliance for Research Excellence (SHARE) Network. We are truly grateful for Mr. Rosenthal and the Helmsley Trust's support of our institution and extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Rosenthal family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs Wayne Keathley, President, The Mount Sinai Hospital Valentin Fuster, M.D., PhD, Physician-in-Chief and Director, Mount Sinai Heart Lloyd Mayer, M.D., Co-Director, Immunology Institute The Mount Sinai Medical Center

Hugh Jackman, whose recent Broadway concert smashed several box office records, grossing $14.6 million in just 10 weeks, has committed to returning to Broadway in the 2013-14 season to star as the early-20th-century escape artist Harry Houdini in the long-gestating musical ''Houdini,'' the lead producers of the project announced on Wednesday. The musical will feature a score by Stephen Schwartz, the composer of ''Wicked'' and ''Godspell,'' and a book by Aaron Sorkin, who won the Academy Award for best adapted screenplay last year for ''The Social Network'' and is the Emmy-winning creator of the NBC series ''The West Wing.'' ''Houdini'' will be directed by the Tony Award winner Jack O'Brien (''Hairspray''); Scott Sanders and David Rockwell are the lead producers.

Thinksound's ms01 headphones don't make much of an impact - but that's not necessarily a bad thing. The midprice headphones are intended to be low impact, as in eco-friendly. The headphones are made from renewable sources of wood with PVC-free cables and packaging made from recycled materials.

When Kemba Walker was last in Madison Square Garden, he was the best player on a Connecticut team that was beginning a roll that would carry it to the N.C.A.A. championship. The Walker who took the floor for the Charlotte Bobcats on Wednesday night looks the same, and still has a killer crossover dribble, but as a rookie he has assumed the role of backup point guard, playing behind D.J. Augustin on a struggling team.

GAUGER--Stanley. The Allen-Stevenson School mourns the passing of Stanley D. Gauger, a beloved member of our faculty from 1949-87 who led the Music Department and Orchestra, enriching the lives of 100s of our students. His legacy lives on through the Stanley Gauger Music Fund, which makes instrumental music affordable at Allen-Stevenson.

KAY--Eugene C. ("Gene") on December 31, 2011. Survived by his loving wife, Helen, children, grandchildren, brothers and nieces. Loved and respected by all who knew him. Memorial services January 6, 2012, at the Orender Family Home, Manasquan, New Jersey 08736.
An article on Tuesday about advances in solar thermal energy technology misidentified the Colorado city where the National Renewable Energy Laboratory maintains offices. It is Golden, not Boulder.

You're in line for coffee. You really want to check your family's Facebook posts to see if there's anything you need to know about, but they're lost among status updates from friends. You never did spend the time to create a group of just your relatives, so there you are, thumbing through your iPhone's entire news feed. You don't have to live this way. A new app called Jildy, released for the iPhone last week and under development for Android phones, sorts your Facebook friends into lists of those who interact with one another, so you can read or post to just those people quickly.

Openings The latest designer to set up shop in the newly hopping SoHo neighborhood is Stella McCartney. After 10 years in the meatpacking district, the store is relocating this week to 112 Greene Street; (212) 255-1556; stellamccartney.com. The two-story landmark space will stock Ms. McCartney's ready-to-wear collection and accessories alongside her lingerie line and the sportswear she designs for Adidas. On the sculptural brass-rail units are resort-collection offerings like her Hawaiian print silk shifts, $1,595. ... Early next month, Moscot, the eyewear brand, will open a shop in the Cobble Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, at 159 Court Street; (212) 647-1550; moscot.com. Although Moscot has been a Manhattan staple since 1889, this is its first outpost across the bridge. It will sell favorites like the circular Lemtosh frames and the square-shape Nebb style, each $225.

DES MOINES -- It was, perhaps, the closest finish ever between two candidates in a presidential caucus. At just before 3 a.m. Eastern time on Wednesday, the chairman of the Iowa Republican Party went on television to announce the official result: Mitt Romney had beaten Rick Santorum by eight votes out of 60,022 cast for the two men.

CHACE--Minturn V.,70, of Mt. Kisco, N.Y. died December 28, 2011 of cancer. "Mike" graduated from Milton Academy in 1959, Harvard College in 1963, and Harvard Business School in 1969 (MBA with distinction). He served in the U.S. Navy from 1963 to 1967, as the ASW Officer on board the Destroyer Forrest Royal DD872. Mike was a management consultant and financial VP for several N.Y. firms. His favorite assignment was as Medical Coordinator for Project Orbis, the flying eye hospital. Most recently, he was a founding director of Bedford Management Group until retirement in 2006. Mike was active in the Episcopal Church of St. Matthews, Bedford and St. Marys-by-the-Sea Northeast Harbor, ME. He was Past Commodore of the Northeast Harbor Fleet. For 20 years he was President of Westmoreland Sanctuary for Wildlife and Forest Conservation. His passions were skiing, sailing and choral singing. Mike is mourned by his wife Helen Clay, daughters Martha and Susie, son-in-law John, former son-in-law Tom, four grandchildren, three sisters and one brother. Services will be held at St. Matthews, Rte. 22, Bedford on Monday, January 9th at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Westmoreland Sanctuary, 260 Chestnut Ridge Rd., Bedford Corners, N.Y. 10549; or to the Northeast Harbor Sailing School, P.O.Box 12, Northeast Harbor, ME 04662.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Vital Signs column on Tuesday about vitamins associated with better mental functioning in the elderly misstated the credentials of Gene L. Bowman, the lead author of a study that established the associations. Dr. Bowman is a researcher in neurology at Oregon Health and Science University; he is not a neurologist there.
BELLUSH--Bernard. Teacher, Mentor, Friend. With gratitude and love from Joseph and Carole Hankin.

Adele, the British retro-soul singer who dominated music in 2011, rounded out her exceptional year in a truly appropriate way: at the top of the charts. Her album ''21'' (XL/Columbia), released 10 months ago, is No. 1 on Billboard's latest chart, which ranks sales during the final week of 2011. Adele's ''21'' sold 144,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a big drop from the week before when 399,000 copies were snapped up, many surely as last-minute stocking-stuffers. But in the relatively slow week after Christmas that was more than enough for ''21'' to notch its 14th week at No. 1.

KNAPP--Russell Sage (Col. USAF, Ret.) died peacefully at home on January 3, 2012 at age 91. Beloved husband of Bettina, who predeceased him after 61 years of marriage, loving father of Albert and Charles and daughter-in-law Susan, devoted grandfather of Emily and Caroline. His life expressed the American experience of achievement through diligence, hard work and an open heart to those in need. A 1940 graduate of Baruch College, he was a highly decorated World War II veteran whose courage and bravery in action over Europe were recently recognized by the Government of France which named him a Knight in the National Order of the Legion of Honor. He graduated from the Columbia University School of Law in 1947 where he was Editor of The Law Review and then went on to an extraordinary career in law and business, as Partner of the late Senator Jacob Javits in the law firm Trubin, Sillcocks, Edelman and Knapp. Despite his own success, Russell Knapp never forgot the obligation to help others. Without fanfare or publicity he was a major supporter of higher education and medical research. The family foundation he established will carry on his philanthropy. Through his exemplary conduct, he influenced and mentored many people. Through his charity, he helped many more who will never know his name. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery. The family requests that contributions in his memory be sent to the Russell Sage Knapp Education Fund, Council on Foreign Relations, 58 E. 68th Street, New York, NY 10065, or The Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center, Columbia University Medical Center, 1150 Saint Nicholas Avenue, New York, NY 10032 att: Jennie Preval.

TOLINS--Roger Alan. Loving husband of Doris Levine Tolins for fifty-one years. Devoted father of Fran Weingast and Jonathan Tolins and father-in-law of Joshua Weingast and Robert Cary. Cherished grandfather of Arielle and Joanna Weingast, and Selina and Henry Tolins-Cary. Dear brother-in-law to Dr. Melvyn and Pam Levine, and uncle to Ian, Susan, and James S. Levine. He will be affectionately remembered by numerous cousins, friends, and business associates. He graduated with distinction from Dartmouth College and received an LL.B. and LL.M. from New York University School of Law. He enjoyed a distinguished career of more than fifty years as an attorney, founding the firm of Tolins & Lowenfels with Lewis Lowenfels. A lover of history and opera, he was most passionate about his family, his work, and his time on the golf course. Services Thursday, Temple Beth Sholom 401 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, New York, at 10am. Donations in Roger's memory may be sent to Hadassah and the American Cancer Society.

An article on Tuesday about library branches in Queens that offer their services in dozens of languages misstated the surname of the head librarian at the Broadway branch in Astoria. He is Logan Ragsdale, not Ragland.

DAVIS--Lenore Passman, Fort Lee, NJ, on January 3, 2012. Born in 1920. She saw flappers, the Great Depression, World War II, the '50's (she wore aprons), the '60's (she teased her hair), snail mail (she preferred it), email (she learned how to do it), 9/11 (she saw the Towers fall), and the birth of a great- grandson (she held him). As a 20th Century woman, she had two successful careers: first as an interior designer and later, as a psychiatric social worker. Predeceased by her adoring husband of nearly 60 years, Arthur. Survived by her loving family: Nan Davis, Ruth Davis and Bill Drew, Rob and Nina Davis, Jonathan and Courtney Davis and great-grandson Stone Arthur, Jesse Davis, Drs. David Drew and Daria Homenko, Mark Drew, and Minna and Richard Passman, as well as her dear caregiver, Yvette Conyers, and staff. An hour of remembrance will be held at her residence on Friday, January 6, from 1-2pm and visiting hours will be held from 2-8pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Fresh Air Fund or the Smile Train.

TANEY--Amie Robertson Hollingsworth, born Westchester, PA, September 27, 1921, passed peacefully January 3, 2012, Darien, CT. Beloved wife of J. Charles Taney, II (deceased). Survived by eight children, eleven grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren with two more due this year. University of Pennsylvania class of 1943; Masters in Education, Sarah Lawrence Bank Street College (1972). Guidance counselor at St. Barnabas (Bronx, NY) and Our Lady of Victory (Dobbs Ferry, NY), followed by work as college guidance consultant. Volunteered in college guidance at Truman High School and Salesian Prep. Also long-time volunteer at pregnancy care center New Rochelle. Founded and attended a Prayer Group in Westport, CT that began in the mid-1950's and still meets today. Enthusiastic student of Spanish language classes, Iona College. Avid traveler. Proud member of Kappa Kappa Gamma. Played for the first women's lacrosse team at University of Pennsylvania as well as field hockey. Played hardball, not softball, and had a terrific batting average. Visiting will be on Friday from 24 and 79pm at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 le Count Place, New Rochelle, NY. (914) 632 0324 with an 11:00am funeral mass on Saturday at the College of New Rochelle's Holy Family Chapel with interment to follow in the Spring Grove Cemetery, Darien, Ct. www.georgetdavis.com

Michael Mermel, the prosecutor quoted extensively in Martin's article, was asked in early December to leave his position. Michael J. Waller, the Lake County state's attorney, said: "The comments attributed to Mike Mermel do not reflect my views on the role of the Lake County state's attorney's office. Nor do they reflect the manner in which my staff has conducted themselves over the last 21 years."

My column last week described how the Food and Drug Administration is declining to regulate the use of antibiotics in animal agriculture. After withdrawing its own 34-year-old request/promise to restrict the routine use of penicillin and tetracyclines in farm animal feed, the F.D.A. made it crystal clear that, despite the increasingly common threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in supermarket meat, it would leave the regulating up to industry itself.

"This collection is about fabric, technology and volume," Alber Elbaz said at the start of his prefall presentation earlier today. Citing innovations in fabric - first, with the incorporation of metals into knits and wovens, and now with things that have been bonded, plastified and waxed - as his muse, Elbaz went on to show a collection full of texture (felted wool and fox), shine (sequins and coated cotton so glossy it looks wet) and stunning proportions (fly-away jackets and exaggerated, egg-shaped shoulders). Here, a romantic all-emerald look that illustrates all three of Elbaz's points is anchored by a giant cameo pendant.

Bjork said on Friday that she would perform her "Biophilia" show for 10 nights in New York in February. The residency will mark the first time the Icelandic singer and songwriter has brought the elaborate stage performance of her recent compositions about nature to North America. Six performances will take place at the New York Hall of Science in Queens, starting on Feb. 3, and four shows will be staged at Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan, beginning on Feb. 22. No other performances have been scheduled in the United States. The show had its premiere at the Manchester International Festival in England and has received ecstatic reviews from critics. Performed in the round, it features a 24-woman choir, a giant Tesla coil and several large custom-built instruments that Bjork and her collaborators invented: a portable pipe organ, four 10-foot pendulums that play harp notes as they swing, a gramophone-like contraption called a "Sharpsichord" and another piece called a "gameleste," which is a fusion of a celesta and a gamelan. The songs are eerie and convoluted, with unusual melodies and fluctuating meters, meant to capture the patterns in natural phenomena like those of gravity, lunar cycles, DNA and crystals.

As an art director, I'm constantly scanning design, illustration and art blogs to seek out new talent for the magazine. One of my favorite blogs, "It's Nice That," produces a collectable quarterly magazine of the same name with the mission of "championing creativity." The editor, Alex Moshakis, describes it as a place for informal conversation about contemporary art, culture and design. Both the blog and the magazine feature expertly curated work from emerging and established artists. The magazine also includes a fiction section, interviews with artists and a revealing feature called "On the bookshelves of..." in which writers discuss the books that inspire them. The current issue focuses on the future of independent publishing and features interviews with i-D magazine's founder, Terry Jones, and the publisher of Nieves Books, Benjamin Sommerhalder; it also includes profiles on contributors to The Times Magazine Taryn Simon and Martin Parr. It's definitely worth checking out.

The second season of Carrie Brownstein and Fred Armisen's rigorously lo-fi comedy "Portlandia" arrives on IFC on Friday night riding a relentless wave of hype. The trick with risotto is learning how to cook it right, which takes a certain amount of repetition. A proper risotto is made by adding hot broth, in increments, to a particular kind of short-grained Italian rice (arborio or carnaroli) and cooking it, uncovered, over a brisk flame. Ideally it's best to learn at the elbow of someone who knows how, because the process can be a bit difficult to describe. Risotto is not so much about a recipe as it is a technique. Once mastered, it is a joy to make.

The Academy's tagline for this year's Oscars is "Celebrate the movies in all of us," and with its first promo for the Feb. 26 show, to be broadcast on ABC, the movie they would most like to celebrate is "Transformers." Megan Fox and Josh Duhamel star in the spot, which pokes gentle fun at the dust-up over the ouster of Brett Ratner and Eddie Murphy as producer and host, and features cameos from William Fichtner (correctly cast as a version of the telecast's new producer, spiky-haired Brian Grazer), Robin Williams and others. To be fair, the promo, made with the imprimatur of FunnyOrDie, also has shades of "Mission: Impossible" and "The Princess Bride," at least in Mr. Crystal's hair and makeup (although he looks more like Carol Kane). If it's a sign of the kind of telecast we'll see next month, we can bet on highly referential, high-production-value montages and familiar humor.

It has become old hat to see "The Walking Dead," the series about human survivors in a world overrun by zombies, on our best-seller lists. This week, two more collected editions join the lists. On the hardcover list, the second omnibus of the series, which reprints issues 24 through 48 of the series, written by Robert Kirkman and illustrated by Charlie Adlard, arrives at No. 4. On the paperback list, vol. 15, which reprints issues 85 through 90, lands at the top spot. It's in good company, with a compendium edition including the first 48 issues at No. 2, and vol. 1, which contains the first six issues, at No. 9.

Long, long ago, during the preppy revolution of the early 1980s (well documented by Lisa Birnbach in "The Official Preppy Handbook," her madras-covered tome of the time), I readied myself to head off to college, leaving the barren, southern Arizona desert for the verdant campus quads of Virginia. Upon receiving my anxiously awaited acceptance letter, I turned to consult my latest L.L. Bean catalog (this being the pre-Internet dark ages, natch) to order my first pair of L.L. Bean boots and one of those legendary Norwegian sweaters. I wanted to head east fully prepared for its snow-filled winters, wearing my handbook-approved school uniform, made by the most iconic, trusted outfitter I knew - or at least had read about.

Grandparents, and in particular the grandparents on the "in-law" side, can provide a nearly endless series of quandaries for some parents. In the last few years, the coffee scene in New York City has been something of a land rush, with some notable out-of-town companies setting up shop and teaching us a thing or two about how to roast, brew and correctly steam milk for a cappuccino. Some of them opened coffee shops (La Colombe Torrefaction, of Philadelphia; Gimme! Coffee, of Ithaca, N.Y.). Some opened training labs (Counter Culture Coffee, of Durham, N.C.; Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea, of Chicago), and some opened roasting facilities and coffee bars (Blue Bottle Coffee, of San Francisco and Oakland, Calif.; Stumptown Coffee Roasters, of Portland, Ore.).

Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest book chain, said on Thursday that it was considering spinning off its Nook e-reader division in an effort to help the nascent - and expensive - digital business grow, report Julie Bosman and Michael J. de La Merced in The New York Times.They write that while the company has made quick work of capturing almost 30 percent of the e-book market in two years, the rise of digital reading has increased the pressure on it to devise a winning long-term strategy against Amazon, which still dominates e-book sales.Sales of Nook devices for the nine-week holiday period ending Dec. 31 were up 70 percent over the same period a year earlier, Barnes & Noble said Thursday, while all Nook-related sales, including devices, accessories and digital content, were up 43 percent.Brian X. Chen, technology reporter for The Times, writes in an accompanying article that the Apple iPad has yet to wipe out the e-readers like the Nook, though that was the popular prediction. DES MOINES, Iowa - On Tuesday, at 6:55 p.m. sharp, I come to the school gym that serves as Precinct 025 to meet Adam ("Just call me Adam" Adam), torchbearer of the Rick Perry for President campaign. "Where are you from?" he asks. "Israel," I say. "You mean the nation of Israel?" "Both the nation and the land but mostly the State of Israel." His candidate, Texas Governor Perry, keeps talking about how important it is to defend Israel, to stand with Israel. Adam will make his contribution to this important cause by defending the visiting Israeli journalist from whatever menace caucus night might hold.

This weekend's games include a duel between two quarterbacks who passed for 5,000 yards, neither of whom is the league's most valuable player and one of whom is not even a Pro Bowler. A 12-4 team from a great division is on the road against an 8-8 team from a terrible one. A division champion on a three-game losing streak faces a wild-card team that was 1-5 against opponents that finished with winning records. Two playoff participants were outscored by their opponents for the season: the Giants by 6 points and the Broncos by 81. Two of the teams have not won a playoff game in two decades. In June 2010, after a dugout fight with a teammate during a game against the White Sox, Zambrano had dinner with Guillen. Last August, after Zambrano packed his belongings and left the Cubs during a game in Atlanta, Guillen's wife spoke with him and Guillen publicly called Zambrano his friend. Guillen was then the White Sox manager, but now he manages the Miami Marlins. And Zambrano, who never pitched for the Cubs after the Atlanta tirade, will be part of Guillen's rotation.

KAUFMAN--Myrna, of Delray Beach, FL. died on January 5. Beloved wife and Best Friend of Ronald Kaufman. Cherished Mother of Wendy Kaufman and Steven Harkins, Alan and Bonnie Kaufman, Jill and David Jablow. Adored Grandmother of Samantha and Alixandra Kaufman, Stacey and Billy Jablow. Loving Sister of Bruce and Judy Hirshon. Myrna had a deep love for family and friends. She was charming, graceful and was passionate about the arts, travel, politics and continuing education. She was loved more than "All the words, in All the books, in All the world" and will be deeply missed by all those who were fortunate enough to know her. Our love will last always and forever. Services at The Sanctuary of Abraham & Sarah, New Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ 07653, Sunday, January 8 at 1:15pm. Donations in her memory may be donated to St. Judes Hospital, 262 Danny Thomas Place, Memphis, TN 38105.

The architects Diller Scofidio + Renfro and the architectural firm HWKN (HollwichKushner) have been hired to design a new entertainment complex to replace the Pavilion dance club, a gay landmark in Fire Island Pines that was destroyed in a fire last year. In November fire gutted the Pavilion, a rite-of-passage spot where three generations of gay men rubbed shoulders with celebrities like Calvin Klein and Madonna while they socialized, danced and drank. In addition to the Pavilion building, the adjacent LaFountaine building, containing seven Pines businesses, was ruined.
GELLER--Jack, M.D. endogrinologist January 9, 1925-January 6, 2011 you are... here, there, everywhere. Always, your family

GARDNER--Elizabeth (Libby). Died December 22, age 90. WASP aviator during WWII, brave and caring social justice activist, writer, computer programmer, autodidact with a vast range of curiosities and pursuits. Loved by daughter Eve, brother Robert, and many others whose lives she touched.

The case of the vacant ''Star Trek'' role appears to be solved - or has it? The ''Sherlock'' star Benedict Cumberbatch, who offers a contemporary portrayal of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's consulting detective, Sherlock Holmes, on that BBC and PBS series, has been cast in a major role in a sequel to ''Star Trek,'' the cinematic reimagining of James T. Kirk's outer-space adventures from J. J. Abrams and his crew. But just what role Mr. Cumberbatch will play in the new movie is a mystery all its own. The Web site Deadline.com wrote that there was ''no word yet on whether he'll be a hero or villain'' in the ''Star Trek'' sequel, while the Showblitz blog of Variety wrote that Mr. Cumberbatch would ''play the villain,'' in a role that the ''Carlos'' star Edgar Ramirez previously auditioned for. The film journalist Devin Faraci wondered if Mr. Cumberbatch would be playing Sybok, who is Spock's half-brother (and apparently named for a random assemblage of Scrabble tiles), though he acknowledged this was highly illogical speculation.

In this presidential election cycle can you handle just one more Republican debate? If that already sounds like a joke - and we haven't even mentioned that it will be moderated by Larry King and its panelists will include Mike Tyson - that's precisely the goal of a satirical event that will be presented on Friday morning by Yahoo! and Funny or Die and hopefully offer some comic relief from The Election Season That Wouldn't End (And Yet Somehow Only Just Started). The two online companies announced on Thursday that they would present a mock debate, called the ''Yahoo! News/Funny or Die GOP Presidential Online Internet Cyber Debate'' that will be shown on Yahoo! Web sites.

The upcoming Broadway revival of ''The Heiress'' has found its Catherine Sloper: Jessica Chastain, who received critical acclaim for film performances last year as a snubbed southern wife in ''The Help'' and as a nurturing young mother in ''The Tree of Life,'' will play the title role in the 1947 play to be directed by Moises Kaufman (''33 Variations''), the producers announced on Thursday. Ms. Chastain will be making her Broadway debut as the plain-looking daughter who exacts revenge on her overbearing father; Cherry Jones last played the role on Broadway 17 years ago, in a performance that earned her the Tony Award for best actress in a play. Ms. Chastain is a graduate of the Juilliard School with some notable theater credits, such as Desdemona opposite John Ortiz and Philip Seymour Hoffman in the 2009 Off Broadway production of ''Othello'' and the title role in Oscar Wilde's ''Salome,'' with Al Pacino, in Los Angeles. In recent weeks she has earned several critics' and industry awards and nominations for ''The Help,'' ''The Tree of Life,'' and another 2011 film, ''Take Shelter'' with Michael Shannon.

SHIPMAN--Stephen E.,of Weston, CT, on January 1, 2012, age 69 years. Beloved husband for 25 years to Joan Armbruster. Proud father of Stephen Jr., Robert, and Michael Shipman. Funeral Services held in Wisconsin. Stephen worked on Wall Street for almost 40 years. muellerfuneralhome.com

FINDLER--Richard, 54, left us too soon on January 4. His humor, his warmth and his loving heart will be forever missed by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held Sunday, January 8, 11:45 at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. We love you Richie.

CAREY--William Polk. The Board of Trustees, officers and staff of The Rensselaerville Institute deeply mourn the loss of our long-serving trustee and generous benefactor, Bill Carey. We will endeavor to carry out his vision of positive change in the world. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Clyde E. Rankin, III, Chairman of the Board of Trustees

WEIL--Marion. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Marion Weil and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

MARIS COCHRANE SULLIVAN,director of the Institute for the Study of War in Washington, on efforts by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to include the militant group Asaib Ahl al-Haq in Iraqi politics. [A10]

BIEDERMAN--Robert Hugh, passed away on Thursday, January 5th, 2012. He is survived by his beloved wife Terry, brother Harvey, and the Gordon family, and predeceased by parents Sidney and Clarice. He was an enthusiastic financial adviser, avid skier, swimmer, biker and jogger. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Funeral Service on Sunday, January 8th at 2pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC.

WOLF--Arlene. Our deepest sympathies to Marty and the entire family on the loss of your beloved Arlene. She was an exceptional wife, a loving mother, grandmother, daughter, sister, and most of all a dear friend. She will live forever in our memory. Bill & Monica Winters

DEVECSERY--Eva. It is with great sorrow that the family of Eva Devecsery announces her sudden and unexpected passing on Monday, January 2nd, 2012. She was pre-deceased by her son Peter Bors, and is survived by her daughter, Maria Kollar (Bors), daughter-in-law Sandra Bors, grandson Leland Bors, granddaughter Tabitha Creighton, great-grandson Ajax Creighton, sister Martha Fabuss, her niece, Judy Ross (Fabuss), and nephew Les Fabuss. A strong and intelligent entrepreneur, she was a doyenne of the New York fashion scene, leading in the world of made-to-measure ateliers. Having worked in some of the great fashion houses of the world, she began her own atelier nearly forty years ago, making it a "must-do" stop for New York society. Passionate and creative in all facets of her life, she was also a great patron of the opera and classical music world. Her sense of taste, exquisite style, and desire for perfection were always apparent in her life, whether at her atelier or her home. She will be dearly missed by her family, friends, clientele and staff. The family will be holding a memorial service in the future, and request that, in lieu of flowers, donations are made to the ASPCA or the Lymphoma Research Foundation.

These days, $3.50 won't even buy a ''tall'' latte at Starbucks. But in 1962 that's what a ticket cost to see a performance of Paul Taylor's work ''Aureole,'' set to the music of Handel. The Paul Taylor Dance Company said on Thursday that it was adding a performance during its three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center to mark the work's 50th anniversary, with tickets costing $3.50. The added show will take place March 13.

TAGUE--Charles Francis, 87 passed away peacefully on January 1. Proud member of the "Greatest Generation" he lived his life with humor, dignity and a selfless sense of duty and was cherished by his six children and 11 grand-children. Born August 16, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY, educated at St. Anne's Academy and Fordham University. Drafted to the Navy during W.W.II, he was a signalman aboard LCF-18 at D-Day, and later served in the South Pacific. On August 6, 1949, he married his life's love Alicia. Together they lived in Jackson Heights, NY, Colts Neck, NJ, Upper Saddle River, N.J. and Jackson, N.J., sharing with their family and friends 62 years of memories. He enjoyed a distinguished career as a Financial Officer. He is survived by his sons Patrick, Charles, Thomas, James and daughters Mary Alicia Haberman and Beth Anne Giuliano , their spouses, Brenda, Gloria, Elise, Liza and Joseph, and 11 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Church of the Presentation, Upper Saddle River, NJ.

KNAPP--Russell Sage (Col. USAF, Ret.) died peacefully at home on January 3, 2012 at age 91. Beloved husband of Bettina, who predeceased him after 61 years of marriage, loving father of Albert and Charles and daughter-in-law Susan, devoted grandfather of Emily and Caroline. His life expressed the American experience of achievement through diligence, hard work and an open heart to those in need. A 1940 graduate of Baruch College, he was a highly decorated World War II veteran whose courage and bravery in action over Europe were recently recognized by the Government of France which named him a Knight in the National Order of the Legion of Honor. He graduated from the Columbia University School of Law in 1947 where he was Editor of The Law Review and then went on to an extraordinary career in law and business, as Partner of the late Senator Jacob Javits in the law firm Trubin, Sillcocks, Edelman and Knapp. Despite his own success, Russell Knapp never forgot the obligation to help others. Without fanfare or publicity he was a major supporter of higher education and medical research. The family foundation he established will carry on his philanthropy. Through his exemplary conduct, he influenced and mentored many people. Through his charity, he helped many more who will never know his name. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery. The family requests that contributions in his memory be sent to the Russell Sage Knapp Education Fund, Council on Foreign Relations, 58 E. 68th Street, New York, NY 10065, or The Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center, Columbia University Medical Center, 1150 Saint Nicholas Avenue, New York, NY 10032 att: Jennie Preval.

JAKUPS--Judy Nobel. Died suddenly of a heart attack on January 1st 2012. She was a smart, talented and beautiful woman who brought life and incredible spirit wherever she went. She is loved and will be missed by her husband Thomas, son Jack, brother Barry and his wife Maija, twin sister Laurie Everitt, parents Fred and Gilda Nobel, and everyone who had the honor of knowing her. Memorial services will be held at 1:30pm January 7 at The Universalist Church of West Hartford, CT. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York City.

Major League Soccer will have its longest season this year, with the final played Dec. 1. The season will start March 10, five days earlier than in 2011. Last year's final was Nov. 20. With the expansion Montreal Impact giving the league 19 teams, M.L.S. is switching to an unbalanced schedule, keeping the regular season at 34 games per team. About 83 percent of games are on weekends and holidays. A record nine games are scheduled for April 28. (AP)

Despite the absence of stars, Steven Spielberg's military epic ''War Horse'' was a box office winner of the holiday season and is a contender in this awards season. There is, of course, the horse. But perhaps much of the movie's appeal is in the filmmaking, which includes the work of the sound designer Gary Rydstrom, who has won Oscars for ''Saving Private Ryan,'' ''Titanic,'' ''Jurassic Park'' and more. In his long career Mr. Rydstrom has worked on ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,'' ''Terminator 2: Judgment Day'' and ''Spaceballs.'' But he had never done a World War I movie, and sonically the prospect excited him.

SNYDER--Helen Kaiser, 92, of Manhattan died January 4, 2012. She is mourned by her daughter Kezia Snyder, granddaughter Kiara Barrow, brother Herbert Kaiser, nieces and nephews, and many other family members. Helen was a self-educated woman who, in the face of many hardships and terrible tragedy, never lost her interest in literature and the arts. She left an indelible impression on all who knew her.

Lucille Elaine Banta memorial Saturday January 14, 2012 from 3pm-5pm At Broadway Presbyterian Church 601 West 114 Street. Side door NY NY 10025. Bring your best memories to share with friends and family.
BERG--Dr. William, loving and devoted husband, dad, grandfather, uncle and best friend. Your enthusiasm and zest for life will live on in all of us. We love you.

WICKS--David, 70, died December 30, 2011, of complications following heart surgery. A Memorial Service will be held at 4 o'clock on January 11 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and Fifth Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Trinity College Rowing, and Darden School of Business, UVA.

WICKS--David. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of David Wicks, a close friend and devoted Board member. VNSNY was honored to have David as an engaged Board member for 11 years. During his tenure, David served on the Quality, Technology, and Audit Committees, as well as on the Boards of VNSNY CHOICE and Family Care Services, VNSNY affiliates. David continually challenged our organization to be innovative, strategic, and future-oriented. Both Board members and Staff valued David's calm advice, sustained support and friendship, as well as his deep commitment to VNSNY's mission. David shall be greatly missed, and we extend our most heartfelt sympathies to his family and friends. Douglas D. Broadwater, Chair of the Board Mary Ann Christopher, President & CEO

An article on Tuesday about technology to store the output of solar power plants misstated, in some copies, the given name of the chief executive of BrightSource, which plans to deploy the technology in some solar plants in California. He is John Woolard, not Paul.

The blighted border of Williamsburg, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick has been more like the Bermuda Triangle than the Broadway Triangle for developers over the last two decades. The 31-acre site spanning the three Brooklyn neighborhoods has sat largely vacant while a lawsuit that has exposed religious and racial divisions over low-cost housing has brewed for two years.
GRECO--Gabriel J.,M.D. You're always in my heart. Love Norma

Several weeks after reaching contract agreements with relievers Frank Francisco and Jon Rauch, the Mets introduced the pitchers on a conference call with reporters Thursday. Unlike many off-seasons, there has been no need for a news conference at the ballpark to show off a splashy new addition. Naturally, then, General Manager Sandy Alderson said this season's most critical improvements would have to come from existing players. Alderson insisted he was very encouraged about the season, largely because of a rotation of Johan Santana, Mike Pelfrey, Jon Niese, R.A. Dickey and Dillon Gee.

9:13 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest book chain, said on Thursday that it was considering spinning off its Nook e-reader division in an effort to help the nascent - and expensive - digital business grow.

Brendan Cochrane had been, by and large, a model parolee. After serving 10 years for attempted murder, he started a video production business, moved into an apartment in Manhattan, got engaged and abstained from drugs and alcohol. But last year, after four years on parole, he found himself back in prison for six months.

An article on Monday about speculation over who published climate scientists' private e-mails online misspelled the given name of a blogger who defends climate science against what he views as misinformation campaigns. He is Brendan DeMelle, not Brenden.

Federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global have expanded their inquiry to include the actions of the CME Group, the operator of the main exchange where the commodities brokerage firm conducted business, according to people briefed on the matter. CME, which also served as MF Global's primary regulator, has come under heavy criticism after $1.2 billion in customer money disappeared from MF Global. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the government agency leading the case, is scrutinizing CME's conduct in the days before MF Global filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 31.

CHAN--Rev. Paul. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and friend. The Wednesday 10

Jeff Fisher is interviewing for the St. Louis Rams' coaching job after meeting with the Dolphins.The team said that initial interviews were taking place in Denver, with the owner Stan Kroenkean active participant. Kroenke's family owns the Denver Nuggets and the Colorado Avalanche. Kevin Demoff, the Rams' chief operating officer, said earlier this week that Kroenke would be involved in the search and added that the decision was ''his call.'' Unlike Steve Spagnuolo, who was fired Monday after going 10-38 over three seasons, Fisher offers the Rams plenty of head coaching experience. He has a career record of 142-120. (AP) LIONS' JOHNSON PRACTICES Detroit Lions receiver Calvin Johnson joined his teammates on the field for the first time this week ahead of Saturday night's playoff game at New Orleans. Johnson has said he was resting a sore Achilles' tendon. (AP)

Having designed the auditorium for the Walt Disney Concert Hall, the architect Frank Gehry is now turning his attention to the stage itself, creating a set for the Los Angeles Philharmonic's production of ''Don Giovanni.'' Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte will design the costumes. Gustavo Dudamel, the Philharmonic's music director, will conduct. The opera will run for four performances, beginning May 18. Aiming for a ''moving still-life on the stage,'' Mr. Gehry's design elevates the orchestra upstage to focus attention on the action downstage and foster intimacy between the soloists and audience.

Newt Gingrich is running for president of the United States, but as he blazed a trail over the White Mountains, he showed that he had not forgotten that all politics is local. In the small northern towns of Plymouth, Littleton and Lancaster, Mr. Gingrich dropped a new opening into his usual remarks, promising to fight a controversial power line project from Canada unless the cables were buried.

One day after leaving the United States national team's training camp in Arizona for ''club-related reasons,'' Los Angeles Galaxy defender Omar Gonzalez flew to Germany and on Thursday agreed to a short-term loan with Nuremberg of the Bundesliga. ''We are delighted that Omar has traveled with us in training camp,'' the Nuremberg spokesman Martin Bader said on the club's Web site in a Google translation from German. ''We were considering having him join us in summer 2012 but we have got the opportunity to loan him at least until the start of the M.L.S. season.'' He added, ''Omar is an interesting candidate, a young, talented player who could be a good fit for 1.FC Nurnberg.''

The family of a Canadian man struck and killed by a truck while riding his bike in Brooklyn has sued the Police Department to release records of the accident. The lawsuit, filed last week in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by the parents of the man, Mathieu Lefevre, said that the police had improperly denied their request for evidence under the state's Freedom of Information Law.

Beset by low ratings and high studio costs, Martha Stewart's daytime talk show is coming to an end. The domestic-style maven will host her last new episode in May, The New York Post reported; repeats will then run on the Hallmark Channel through the end of the summer. The talk show had been attracting an average of 225,000 viewers on any given day.

Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue on Sunday, 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing.

We offer our deepest condolences to Bill's family and friends. Chad Jemison, Executive Director Susan Kessler, Board President

An answer in the Small Business feature on Thursday about the Boston restaurateur Barbara Lynch referred incorrectly to the founding of the Stride Rite Corporation. It was started by Jacob A. Slosberg and Philip Green -- not by Arnold Hiatt, who joined the company later and became its president.

ONEIDA, N.Y. - Some local residents, when eating out, instinctively turn their utensils upside-down to look for a telltale sign: the word ''Oneida,'' stamped into the back of the handle. The ''Oneida flip,'' as it's called, is a ritual carried over from an era when Oneida Ltd., the company headquartered here, dominated the global market in flatware, setting tables all over the world with its stainless steel forks, spoons and knives. In recent years, the ritual became a painful reminder of the company's troubles.

An article Dec. 24 about friction between Turkey and France referred incorrectly at one point to the status of legislation that would make it a crime in France to deny the genocide of Armenians by the Ottoman Empire. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, the lower house of the French parliament approved the measure on Dec. 22; it has not become law.

When Occupy Wall Street protesters set up their encampment in September in Zuccotti Park, a new category of activist emerged alongside fixtures like meeting facilitators and medics. The new participants carried laptops and cellular phones as they accompanied marches and wandered through Zuccotti Park, all the while sending a flow of moving images to computer screens around the city and beyond.

A year ago, as Washington grappled with the shooting rampage that nearly took the life of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, the centrist group Third Way made a modest suggestion to members of Congress: Mingle with lawmakers from the opposite party at the State of the Union address. The suggestion, championed by Senators Mark Udall, a Colorado Democrat, and Lisa Murkowski, an Alaska Republican, started a miniature phenomenon. A few lawmakers went hunting for bipartisan ''dates'' to sit with. Although President Obama's 2011 address featured the usual partisan applause lines, the television cameras could pick out hints of bipartisanship.

LUCEK--Audrey Marie, a resident of Scarsdale, NY for thirty years, died on December 30, from lung cancer. Born in the Bronx in 1936 to William and Agnes Cerny, educated at Fordham and NYU, she worked as a speech therapist teaching special education and autistic students in the Bronx. Audrey was a choir member and active within the parish of Saint Pius X Church, where a memorial service will take place on Saturday, January 7, at 11am.

KUPFERBERG--Selma. Queens College mourns the loss of our dear friend who, with her husband, Max, has been a generous and visionary benefactor. We extend our deepest sympathy to their son, Saul, Queens College Foundation Board member, and the entire Kupferberg family. President James Muyskens COO Sue Henderson The Queens College Foundation

GINSBERG--Allen, renowned diamond expert, of Boynton Beach and formerly of Manhattan, died December 14, 2011, in Florida, after a brief illness. Born September 1, 1924, in New York, Mr. Ginsberg was raised in upper Manhattan and the Bronx. After graduating from the High School of Commerce, he fought with distinction as an infantryman in WWII, volunteering for reconnaissance duty ahead of the front lines in France and Germany. After the war, he worked as a diamond cutter in Manhattan, and rose to the highest echelons of the diamond industry, principally during his long tenure at Zale Corporation, where he served as a Director and as President of the International Diamond Division. Mr. Ginsberg's influential role in the world's diamond markets on behalf of Zale took him around the globe twice a year and on numerous overseas trips in between--this son of the Great Depression a regular, esteemed visitor to the Far East, Russia, India, Africa, Israel and Europe. Mr. Ginsberg was a serious reader, an avid golfer, a staunch supporter of Israel and the ADL, a sparkling conversationalist who loved to laugh, and, perhaps most strikingly of all, a world-class listener. Gracious, humble, warm-hearted, and of the utmost integrity, Mr. Ginsberg was treasured throughout his life by his wide circle of family, friends, and business colleagues. He was predeceased by too many years by his older brother, Jack. Mr. Ginsberg will always be greatly loved and missed by Betty, his wife of 63 years, daughters Carol Ginsberg Brown and Barbara Ginsberg, sons-in-law Eric Brown and Ira Schreck, grandchildren Alex, Vivian, Jesse and Daniel, brother Mike, nieces and nephew, and all fortunate enough to have known him well. A service celebrating his memory will be held in Manhattan on Sunday, February 12, 2012, 11am, at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 W 88th St. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 621 NW 43rd St., Ste 450, Boca Raton, FL 33487.

8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION The series travels to Fayette County, Iowa, to surprise Audrey Gibbs, who, seven months after the death of her husband, had a brain aneurysm that left her legally blind. Doctors cannot predict whether she will lose her sight completely. Unable to continue her work as a cosmetologist, she has become a massage therapist, which doesn't require sight, the better to support her six children. In this, the penultimate episode, Ty Pennington (above, foreground, with Ms. Gibbs) and his crew remodel the family's farmhouse, which has no working toilet and a caved-in ceiling. The musician Bret Michaels lends a hand. 7:15 A.M. (Sho2) THE LAST PLAY AT SHEA (2010) The histories of Shea Stadium, the Mets, Billy Joel (below) and New York City itself across four and a half decades intersect in this documentary from Paul Crowder, which focuses on Mr. Joel's concerts on July 16 and July 18, 2008 -- the last performances given in the stadium, which was torn down the next year. ''For the July 18 concert,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, Paul McCartney ''miraculously appeared, having been whisked through customs at Kennedy International Airport after a flight from London that had been allowed to land early. He was sped to the stadium by a motorcade in 11 minutes and driven onto the field in time to perform by Pete Flynn, the dedicated groundskeeper who had driven the Beatles to the same stage 43 years earlier.'' Mr. Holden added: '' 'If it weren't for the Beatles,' Mr. Joel declares, 'I wouldn't do what I do.' Call it perfect symmetry. The final number, 'Let It Be,' rings as a sweet valedictory to all the struggle, the teamwork and the glory captured in this wonderful film.'' In the film ''The Love We Make'' (2011), at 11 on Showtime, Albert Maysles, Bradley Kaplan and Ian Markiewicz capture Mr. McCartney's experiences in New York City after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and his performance the next month with Elton John, Mr. Joel and David Bowie in the ''Concert for New York City'' at Madison Square Garden. Mr. McCartney had been on the runway at Kennedy when the attacks occurred.

Federal prosecutors said Thursday that they were likely to file a new indictment against Rajat K. Gupta, possibly adding new criminal charges in the insider trading case against the former head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company. It was ''more likely than not there will be a superseding indictment'' filed in the case by the end of January, Richard C. Tarlowe, an assistant United States attorney, said during a pretrial hearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

MEIXNER--Charles, on January 3, 2012. Husband of the late Maris (nee Albear). Reposing at Leo F. Kearns 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park Friday 4-7pm. Funeral Service Saturday 10am. Interment St. John's Cemetery Middle Village.

Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 25 about Cornell's successful bid to build an applied science campus in New York City in conjunction with the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology erroneously included a program among those offered by the university. While Cornell has programs in hotel management, labor relations and agriculture, it does not have one in forestry.

Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended in New York City. GREER--Helen Ina 1930-2012, quietly in her sleep on January, 1, 2012. Devoted sister and aunt and a staunch and loyal friend to many people around the world. She worked tirelessly as a nurse for the less fortunate. She worked for two years in the Peace Corps. in Benin and later was a leader in Project Hope, a New York organization that worked with the homeless. She loved travel and the theatre. She will be sorely missed by all her relatives, friends and all the homeless of New York on whose behalf she worked so hard for. Memorial Service Sunday, January 8, 2012, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76 Street at Amsterdam Ave.

My Sunday column looks at new evidence of the importance of early childhood and pregnancy on life outcomes. I've been increasingly impressed by the research that suggests that biological mechanisms -- such as the way cortisol floods a small child under stress, disrupting brain development -- appear to lay the groundwork for social disadvantage later. But I was looking for a peg to write about this, and then the American Academy of Pediatrics provided it by issuing a landmark policy statement endorsing this new science of toxic stress.

8 P.M. (Sho2) BLUE VALENTINE (2010) Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, above, who earned an Oscar nomination, portray Dean and Cindy -- he is a housepainter with a dreamy streak; she is a more practical-minded nurse -- who cannot halt the downward spiral of their relationship in this drama by Derek Cianfrance. The movie toggles between their youthful courtship in Brooklyn six years earlier and their grim present-day reality in Pennsylvania. ''Ms. Williams and Mr. Gosling are exemplars of New Method sincerity, able to be fully and achingly present every moment on screen together,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But Cindy and Dean remain, for all their sustained agony and flickering joy, something less than completely realized human beings. Mr. Cianfrance's ingenious chronological gimmick, coupled with his anxious, clumsy plotting, leaves them without enough oxygen to burst into breathing, loving life.'' 10:30 A.M. A Spare Times entry in some editions on Friday about a screening of the film ''#WhileWeWatch,'' which looks at the occupation of Zuccotti Park during the Occupy Wall Street protests, omitted the time for the screening scheduled for Wednesday. It is at 6 p.m. at the Paley Center for Media on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, and is to be followed by a discussion.

Bjork said on Friday that she would perform her ''Biophilia'' show for 10 nights in New York in February. The residency will mark the first time the Icelandic singer and songwriter has brought the elaborate stage performance of her recent compositions about nature to North America. Six performances will take place at the New York Hall of Science in Queens, starting on Feb. 3, and four shows will be staged at Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan, beginning on Feb. 22. No other performances have been scheduled in the United States. The show had its premiere at the Manchester International Festival in England and has received ecstatic reviews from critics. Performed in the round, it features a 24-woman choir, giant Tesla coils and several large custom-built instruments that Bjork and her collaborators invented: a portable pipe organ, four 10-foot pendulums that play harp notes as they swing, a gramophone-like contraption called a ''Sharpsichord'' and another piece called a ''gameleste,'' which is a fusion of a celesta and a gamelan. The songs are eerie and convoluted, with usual melodies and fluctuating meters, meant to capture the patterns in natural phenomena like those of gravity, lunar cycles, DNA and crystals. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Scott Thompson is getting a very friendly welcome to Yahoo. The Internet pioneer disclosed in a regulatory filing late on Friday what its incoming chief executive stands to receive when he begins work on Monday or soon thereafter. It's a package with a hefty amount of stock grants worth about $22.5 million, atop a $1 million annual salary.

Schedule information on Friday with a theater review of a work in the Under the Radar festival, ''Alexis. A Greek Tragedy'' at La MaMa in the East Village misstated the telephone number for La MaMa. It is (212) 475-7710.

An editorial on Sunday about Westchester County not living up to a housing settlement incorrectly identified the writer of a letter on the issue. It was written by an official at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and sent to the court-appointed monitor, James Johnson. Mr. Johnson was not the author. The editorial also referred imprecisely to one of the letter's criticisms. It said the county failed to promote affordable housing through zoning changes. It did not say no homes were built under the settlement.

Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller, the Broadway producing team behind the Tony Award-winning musicals ''Rent,'' ''Avenue Q'' and ''In the Heights,'' said on Friday that they were ending their 21-year business partnership to produce independently. The two men, long-time friends and among the most successful Broadway producers over the last two decades, said in a joint interview that going it alone will yield greater autonomy and flexibility to pursue their own interests. They both described the move as part of ''the natural evolution'' of their careers.

A theater review and listings of credits on Friday about ''Goodbar,'' at the Public Theater, using information from the program, misspelled the surname of one of the directors. He is Tom Ridgely, not Ridgley.

For most Wall Street bankers, 2011 was a year they would rather forget. Investors will soon find out just how bad that year was for the country's biggest financial institutions. In recent days, analysts have been lowering their fourth-quarter earnings estimates for Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup and Bank of America. Analysts are also bracing for lower earnings from JPMorgan Chase, which on Friday will be the first of the Wall Street banks to report results.

With the start of a new year, many people resolve to shed their holiday paunch by hitting the gym more frequently. It's easy to stay motivated for a few weeks, but then other things seem to take precedence -- late nights at work, happy hour or the couch. So, what if it cost you $5 every time you missed the gym? Do you think you'd be more likely to go?

After one of its worst years in recent history, the concert industry rebounded slightly in 2011. But with consumers buying fewer tickets, the industry was still down from its peak in 2009. According to Pollstar, a trade magazine that collects sales data from promoters and ticket vendors, the Top 100 tours in North America last year sold $2.34 billion in tickets. That was a 6.3 percent increase from 2010, when the lagging economy and a number of weak summer lineups caused sales to drop by as much as 15 percent, the concert industry's first decline in 15 years.

The Frame column on Friday, about viewing things in New York City as unintentional works of art, misstated how high the subway across the Manhattan Bridge is above the city in citing the view. It is 135 feet, not 300 feet.

A Spare Times for Children entry in some editions on Friday about workshops at the Children's Museum of the Arts in Greenwich Village featuring Tranqui Yanqui included outdated information. The museum said on Friday that it had learned that Tranqui Yanqui, whose real name is Nick Mahshie, would not be able to lead the workshop scheduled for Thursday, although he will still lead the ones scheduled for today and tomorrow.

William Duell, a diminutive character actor whose puckishness and understated comic flair enlivened Broadway shows, television series and Hollywood films, died at his home in Manhattan on Dec. 22. He was 88. The cause was respiratory failure, his wife, Mary Barto, said. Mr. Duell, who was less than five and a half feet tall and weighed not quite 140 pounds, was never a star, but he had a slyly roguish and perpetually boyish mug that always added spice to the roles of cabdrivers, shoeshine men, butlers and desk clerks he often played. He brought a kind of perky oddity even to serious roles.

As a kid, I just wanted to be a parish priest, and to think that now the pope has named me a cardinal -- that's awesome. TIMOTHY M. DOLAN, archbishop of New York, on his elevation to cardinal by Pope Benedict XVI. [A17]

Citigroup's effort to sell a consumer-lending business has collapsed in recent days, as wobbly markets and a lackluster economy shut down hopes for a deal, a person with knowledge of the matter said. Last year Citigroup began exclusive talks with a pair of private equity firms and Berkshire Hathaway, Warren E. Buffett's conglomerate, to sell OneMain, a lender that offers home equity and personal loans to risky borrowers. The talks coincided with the bank's broader effort to shed noncore businesses in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

The White House will propose a 0.5 percent pay raise for civilian federal employees in the 2013 budget, an administration official said on Friday. The increase is bound to run into opposition from Republicans in Congress, who want to extend a freeze in pay for federal workers as part of an effort to pay for a one-year extension of the payroll tax cut, which the White House is seeking.

10:21 p.m. | Updated Officers responding early Friday to a call of a jumper on the roof of a four-story building inBrooklynfound a blood trail leading down to Apartment 4A. The door was ajar, and when they walked in, the police said, the picture got even worse: A young mother was sitting on a couch in the living room, babbling and cradling her fatally wounded 2-year-old girl. The girl, identified by officials as Cathryn Nwegbo, was in cardiac arrest with puncture and strangulation wounds to her neck and face, one city official said, adding that she also had ''major bleeding to the back of her head.''

He held executive positions in music publishing, and was actively involved with many civic organizations during his lifetime in Freeport. Funeral services will be at Congregation B'nai Israel, 91 North Bayview Ave. Freeport, NY, on Sunday, January 8, 2012 at Noon.

J. R. R. Tolkien may have been the creator of one of the most popular fantasy series of the modern era, but nearly 40 years after his death the author of ''The Hobbit'' and ''The Lord of the Rings'' is still receiving some of the toughest reviews of his career. Tolkien's latest detractor, according to a report in a Swedish newspaper, is the jury for the 1961 Nobel Prize in literature, which dismissed him as a candidate for the honor, saying Tolkien wasn't up to snuff. BBC News, citing recently disclosed papers that were printed in the Sydsvenska Dagbladet newspaper, said that C. S. Lewis, the essayist and author of his own ''Chronicles of Narnia'' fantasy books, tried to nominate Tolkien, his friend and fellow Oxford faculty member, for the Nobel. But the jury deemed that Tolkien shall not pass, writing of his work that ''the result has not in any way measured up to storytelling of the highest quality,'' according to papers kept in the Nobel archive in Stockholm.

A television review on Friday about the ''Absolutely Fabulous'' 20th-anniversary specials, on BBC America, misidentified the area of London where Eddy has a town house. It is Holland Park, not the nearby Notting Hill.

Lions (10-6) at Saints (13-3) Saturday, 8 p.m. Line: Saints by 10.5 From the birth of the N.F.L. until 1960, no quarterback ever threw for more than 3,000 yards. As recently as 1997, it was still possible for Jeff George to lead the league with less than 4,000 yards passing: 3,917, to be exact. For most of football's history, a 3,000-yard season was an accomplishment, 4,000 yards were a feat and 5,000 yards marked the distance from home to the nearest hardware store, not an attainable passing goal.

It is has become a staple of Mitt Romney's campaign stump speech: the claim that appointees to the National Labor Relations Board are ''labor stooges'' whose anti-business approach has impeded economic growth. But a top adviser to Mr. Romney's presidential campaign has his own intriguing relationship with the labor board: as a member in the early 2000s, he found that two companies controlled by Bain Capital, the private equity firm founded by Mr. Romney, had violated labor rules.

The Mets agreed to terms with the Venezuelan infielder Ronny Cedeno on a one-year contract worth $1.1 million with extra performance bonuses based on playing time in the event he becomes a regular player. Cedeno, who can play second base and shortstop, will get a chance to compete for the starting second baseman's job, depending on whether the Mets decide to trade Daniel Murphy, or he could simply be a backup middle infielder.

Bucks readers share their financial resolutions for 2012: I started my resolution a few months ago to pay off my school debt in 1.5 years. To help reach this goal I've worked out the extra payments I can afford per month and have started tracking every expense in Excel to make sure I stay on track. Barring a financial setback, I'll be down to about 7k this time next year and then debt-free a few months later.

An article on Page 20 this weekend about Stephen Colbert misspells part of the title of a segment from ''The Daily Show'' that featured him when he was a regular performer on the program. It was ''Even Stevphen,'' not Stephven. The article also misspells the surname of an actor Colbert worked with in the Second City troupe. He is Steve Carell, not Carrell.

Akram Khan's first full-length solo work, ''Desh'' received rapturous critical notices and attracted capacity audiences when it had its premiere at Sadler's Wells this past October. So much so that the theater, unusually, decided to present ''Desh'' - a work in which Mr. Khan explores the confluence of his Bangladeshi origins with his British upbringing - again this season, in February. But Mr. Khan has had to cancel these coming performances, as well as a run of ''Sacred Monsters,'' with Sylvie Guillem, in France this week, because of an injured Achilles tendon, which is likely to keep him offstage for several months. Sadler's Wells plans to schedule a replacement run of ''Desh'' in October. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

TOSCANINI--Walfredo, 82, died at home in New Rochelle, NY, on December 31, of leukemia. Husband of Elaine (nee Troostwyk); father of Liana, Maia (Tom Brown) and Cia (Murdoch McBride); grandfather of Wyatt and Liam. A Democratic party activist and former city councilman and deputy mayor of New Rochelle, Toscanini was an architect who worked for the State of New York and in private practice. He strove to preserve and promote the artistic legacy of his grandfather, conductor Arturo Toscanini, as well as the memory of his mother, prima ballerina Cia Fornaroli, and his father, Walter Toscanini. A native of Milan, he immigrated to America at age nine. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Manhattan, Wednesday, January 11, at 3:30. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent in his name to Leukemia Fighters/New York Presbyterian Hospital or Smile Train out of Washington, DC.

Omar Gonzalez will not get to test himself in the German Bundesliga, and may not have the opportunity to play in Major League Soccer this season. The American defender, who plays for the defending champion Los Angeles Galaxy in the United States, saw his short-term loan to Nuremberg of the German Bundesliga end before it really began when he sustained a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee in a tackle. As bad as the injury is for the 23-year-old Gonzalez, the circumstances were even more bizarre -- he was injured in a collision with the club's other American player, Timmy Chandler.

LONDON -- British authorities announced on Friday that they had fined the accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers 1.4 million, or $2.2 million, for failing to safeguard client assets at JPMorgan Chase's securities business in London. The fine is the largest ever imposed by Britain's Accountancy and Actuarial Discipline Board, the local regulator.

SEIGLE--Saul, Brooklyn-born son of Clarence and Anna Seigle, passed away on January 5, 2012, at the age of 97. Following WWlI, he gave up Brooklyn and a law practice to marry his beloved Natalie S. Rosen, and settle in her hometown of Providence. In addition to his loving wife of 69 years, Saul is survived by a son and daughter, four grandchildren, and an adoring sister. He was predeceased by one son and his younger brother.

MANCHESTER, N.H. - After a year or more of anticipation, actual votes have been cast. But the 2012 Republican presidential contest will not proceed in a straight line, evenly spaced out over the next six months. Philosophy is one of the oldest areas of inquiry. Out of control behavior fueled by alcohol and other drugs is one of the world's oldest problems. What could these old timers offer each other? Philosophy has a long, stable relationship with reason and more specifically, the relationship between reason, emotions and the will. Addiction seems to involve a total abdication of reason, a messy tangle of emotions and a lack of will.
