PALMER--Helen G. Family, friends, colleagues, bridge partners, mystery lovers, Democrats, agitators, and loyal Californians all mourn the sudden passing of Helen Palmer, December 30, 2011 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital. Our "Iron Lady", Helen lived to a spirited 94 and thrived in robust health, sharp wit, and open heart throughout. She was born in Lennox, South Dakota, raised throughout the Midwest, started her family with the late B. Mitchell Palmer in San Francisco and moved to Los Angeles where she remained for the rest of her years. Irrepressibly enterprising, she enjoyed an expansive career spanning advertising sales at the Los Angeles Times and a series of creative businesses launched with her sister-in-law, best friend and confidant, Rita Corwin. In later years, she turned this energy to serving as a scion of the Beverly Hills Bridge Club, where she rose to the rank of Silver Master and competed without mercy, even to her last hand. Above all, Helen's greatest passion was her family. Her marriage to Mitch was a true partnership, ahead of its time, and the two stood side-by-side at the head of a still-expanding family. They are survived by their son Mark J. Palmer of Beverly Hills, their daughter Stephanie Palmer McClelland and her husband Carter McClelland of Manhattan; Mark's daughter Jenni Palmer and her husband Sam Gall of greater Los Angeles; Stephanie and Carter's children Cary McClelland, Spencer McClelland and his wife Eliza, all of New York; Rita Corwin and Rita's children Leni Corwin, Miles Corwin, his wife Diane, and their son Marius of Pasadena and Altadena. Helen's delight in our accomplishments was the fire that drove us forward, and her counsel the light that shone the way. She remains in our memory - scotch in one hand, sudoku in the other, and smiling always. A memorial will be scheduled, and, in lieu of flowers, the family requests that gifts in Helen's name be sent to the West Hollywood Library and Susan G. Komen for the Cure.

EVANS--George. Longtime Darien, CT resident, World War II veteran, Cornell graduate and 30-year General Electric executive passed away peacefully on January 2, 2012. A Spring memorial is being planned. Donations may be made to: soundkeeper.org to help protect Long Island Sound, where George loved to sail and fish.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Bring on a Playoff, but Save the Bowl System,'' Jan. 2: The debate about a playoff system ignores the most important part of college football: the student-athletes. There is a clear need in professional sports for a playoff system to determine each year which team is the best.

This year's Harkness Dance Festival, which opens at the 92nd Street Y on Feb. 17, brings exciting news: The slippery choreographer Doug Elkins has updated his 1990 dance ''Mo(or)town,'' a play on Shakespeare's ''Othello'' set to the music of Motown. ''Mo(or)town/Redux,'' right, will be performed on March 2 and 3 at 8 p.m. and on March 4 at 3 p.m. The festival closes on March 18 with Susan Marshall's ''Sawdust Palace.''
The Tata Technologies electric mobility concept, or Emo, is a pure concept vehicle, with no clear path to production. So why was it built? In a word, validation.

IN his latest book, ''The Unseen Eye'' (Aperture, $75), W. M. Hunt, the fine-art photography collector, disassembles an extraordinary range of images, all of which show people whose eyes are covered, abstracted or otherwise averted from the viewer's gaze. It is Mr. Hunt's own uncanny eye that allows him to pull off this quirky conceit so well. His selections run from virtually unknown 19th-century works by Fratelli Alinari, featuring a man covered by a blanket walking on a high wire, to Richard Avedon's picture of Sophia Loren throwing her head back, taken around 1970. At right, Seymour Sheer's ''There's a Girl Under There,'' from 1967, is at once whimsical and nerve-racking. Works by Diane Arbus, Weegee, Edward Steichen and William Eggleston are included. A corresponding exhibition is at the George Eastman House in Rochester until Feb. 19. Happy hunting. JUDITH PUCKETT-RINELLA
RIVERFRONT CAPE $849,000
The Novelties column last Sunday about Wordnik, the online dictionary, misstated the given name of its president and chief executive. He is Joe Hyrkin, not Joel.

KANTOR--Alice, passed January 6th. Fled Austria in 1938, and settled in New York. She was a researcher for Time Life and for CBS. She leaves behind her brother Gideon. She was a courageous woman and will never be forgotten.

BRADLEY--Karen, Died, surrounded by family, on December 31, 2011. Born 1944 in Brooklyn, NY. New York University's Director of Human Resources 1972-2006. Survived by husband of 43 years, Gary, and two daughters, Ellen and Joanna. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America

An article on Dec.25 about the late women's running pioneer Grete Waitz referred imprecisely to the first time Fred Lebow, a founder of the New York City Marathon, ran the race.While the marathon he ran in 1992 with Waitz was his first time to run the modern course that passes through all five boroughs, it was not his first New York City Marathon. (He ran at the race's inception, in 1970, when it looped through Central Park; he eventually created the modern course.)

Next up for the Big City Book Club is ''A Walker in the City,'' Alfred Kazin's 1951 memoir of his Jewish immigrant childhood in Brownsville, Brooklyn, his path out of that world and his arrival among the New York Intellectuals. Join Ginia Bellafante, the Big City columnist, for a live online discussion on the City Room blog Jan. 10 from 1 to 4 p.m.

West Virginia's Kevin Jones, left, the Big East's leading scorer and rebounder, had 22 points and 16 rebounds for his 11th double-double of the season as the Mountaineers beat No. 9 Georgetown, 74-62. Towson lost at Old Dominion, 75-38, breaking the Division I record for consecutive losses with 35. New Jersey Institute of Technology has the overall record of 51, but did it while transitioning from Division II.

Gov. Mitt Romney said that during his tenure at Bain Capital, a private equity firm, he helped create 100,000 jobs, even when layoffs from downsized firms are factored in. The Romney campaign bases that figure on the current employment of three major companies that Bain Capital invested in during Mr. Romney's tenure: Staples, Sports Authority and Domino's.

VAN DINE--Vance, 86, of Glen Cove and Manhattan, died peacefully on December 26, 2011. A graduate of Yale University, where he was a member of the Skull and Bones Society, Vance also served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. He was a passionate sailor and had a distinguished career in investment banking with Morgan Stanley. Vance is survived by his sister, Valerie Meadows, and was preceded in death by his dear wife, Isabelle Brewster Van Dine, and his beloved daughter, Rose Maxwell Van Dine. He will be interred next to his wife and daughter at Saint John's of Lattingtown.

HUTZLER--Lois L. The Browning School community is saddened by the death of Lois L. Hutzler: parent, grandparent, trustee. For forty years she has been deeply involved as a volunteer in every aspect of the School. Trustee since 1982, Lois was a board officer as Secretary, and also invaluable as editor of school publications. Her husband Joel, sons Michael '83 and John '86 (Casey), and grandsons Jay '16 and Stuart '19 are in our thoughts. At the family's request contributions in her honor may be made to The Browning School. A memorial service is planned for Wednesday, February 1 at 4pm at Christ Church, 520 Park Avenue at 60th St. James S. Chanos, President, Board of Trustees Stephen M. Clement, III, Headmaster Susan A. Grimbilas, President, Parents Association Michael P. Beys '89, President, Alumni Association

A three-bedroom TriBeCa penthouse with a 22-foot-high wraparound loggia offering open river and Midtown views that sold for $6.9 million was the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records. The 2,300-square-foot duplex is on the 32nd and 33rd floors of the 35-story glass tower at 101 Warren Street and has 1,076 square feet of covered outdoor space. The building opened in 2008; on its lower floors, it houses the area's first Whole Foods Market.

At the Thurgood Marshall Academy for Learning and Social Change, a public school on West 135th Street in Harlem, every one of the 82 members of the senior class is expected to apply to college. And at this time of year, Nicholas Raschella's college office in the basement of the school is usually jammed with 10 or 15 students waiting to use the office's three computers to research colleges and financial aid, or to work on their essays and applications. Even for a great college counselor -- and Mr. Raschella is one -- it's too much to do alone.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Julie Bosman with notes from the field, and Gregory Cowles with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Children's Books Weekly online-only reviews of picture books.

Lions (10-6) at Saints (13-3) Saturday, 8 p.m. Line: Saints by 10.5 From the birth of the N.F.L. until 1960, no quarterback ever threw for more than 3,000 yards. As recently as 1997, it was still possible for Jeff George to lead the league with less than 4,000 yards passing: 3,917, to be exact. For most of football's history, a 3,000-yard season was an accomplishment, 4,000 yards were a feat and 5,000 yards marked the distance from home to the nearest hardware store, not an attainable passing goal.

SCHIFFRIN--Milton J. ("RED"), PH.D. Milton Schiffrin ("Red" to most of his friends) passed away quietly December 2, 2011 at age 97. Born on the East Coast to Russian immigrant parents, and to very modest circumstances, Red was the oldest of three brothers. During the Great Depression, Red temporarily dropped out of college to help support his parents and siblings, working in a sweat shop for $8 a week. Although he originally had majored in music, when he returned to college he completed his BS in chemistry and math. However, music always remained a special passion of his. He particularly enjoyed opera and classical music, and with his basso profundo voice, he loved to sing. Red completed his formal education in Montreal, Canada, at McGill University, where he received his Ph.D. in physiology, studying under Pavlov's number one disciple, Leo Babkin. In 1942 he joined what was then the Army Air Force and the same year, he met and married his British bride, "Phemie." They enjoyed a marriage lasting almost 50 years, ending only with her passing. In 1946 Red became a clinical research associate at Hoffman-La Roche, a large pharmaceutical company based in Basel, Switzerland. He stayed with "Roche" throughout his working career, ultimately assuming the position of Vice President and head of "Drug Regulatory Affairs." Red became a recognized expert in the ins and outs of obtaining FDA approval of new drugs. Red also taught at three medical schools, wrote or contributed to several medical textbooks, and contributed more than 40 articles to medical journals. He was inducted into several prestigious professional and scientific societies, and in 1973, was greatly honored to be made President of the American Medical Writers' Association. Despite many lifetime accomplishments and honors, Red's greatest pleasure was in helping and bringing joy to others. He loved poetry and prose, politics and humor, and he read extensively. He retained his extremely sharp mind and rich memory to the end, easily reciting long passages from favorites such as Shakespeare. Recently, his brother Harold and he challenged each other to remember stanzas of the poem, "Invictus." They exchanged recitations, line by line, and Harold noted that the poem's famous closing line, "I am the Master of my fate, I am the Captain of my soul" could have been written to summarize Red's character and strength. Red is survived by his brother, Harold, his two children, Hilary Greenstreet and David Schiffrin, two granddaughters, Kari and Brooke Schiffrin, and the second love of his life, "June" Davis.
Theater Jason Zinoman

DAVIS--Joan A.,on January 5, 2012. Beloved wife of Gerard, devoted mother of Joseph, Margaret, Michael, and William. Adored mother-in-law of Evelyn, Tony, and JoAnn. Cherished grandmother of Dominique, Rebecca, Jeremiah, Elijah, Isabel, Catherine, and Joseph. Loving sister of Margaret and sister-in-law of William. Mass Monday, 10am at St. Saviour Church. Reposing at the chapel of Joseph G. Duffy, 9th St. between 4th and 5th Avenues, Brooklyn. Visiting Saturday, 3-6pm and Sunday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Helen Owen Carey Child Development Center, 71 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, NY 11217. helenowencarey.org - in her memory appreciated.

CLARK--Portia M. February 12, 1920-January 1, 2012. Retired from a spirited career in book publishing, survived by her longtime partner, nieces and nephews. In lieu of service and flowers, donate to Doctors Without Borders, online or phone: 888-392-0392
MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS CO-OP $775,000

Charles W. Bailey, who edited The Minneapolis Tribune for most of the 1970s, when it was among the most polished of the nation's midsize daily newspapers, after earlier winning renown as a co-author of the best-selling cold war novel ''Seven Days in May,'' died on Tuesday in Englewood, N.J. He was 82. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, said his daughter Victoria Bailey, executive director of the Theater Development Fund in New York. Mr. Bailey died at the Lillian Booth Actors Home.

TOSCANINI--Walfredo, 82, died at home in New Rochelle, NY, on December 31, of leukemia. Husband of Elaine (nee Troostwyk); father of Liana, Maia (Tom Brown) and Cia (Murdoch McBride); grandfather of Wyatt and Liam. A Democratic party activist and former city councilman and deputy mayor of New Rochelle, Toscanini was an architect who worked for the State of New York and in private practice. He strove to preserve and promote the artistic legacy of his grandfather, conductor Arturo Toscanini, as well as the memory of his mother, prima ballerina Cia Fornaroli, and his father, Walter Toscanini. A native of Milan, he immigrated to America at age nine. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Manhattan, Wednesday, January 11, at 3:30. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent in his name to Leukemia Fighters/New York Presbyterian Hospital or Smile Train out of Washington, DC.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Moment in the Bronx That Made Two Fathers Proud,'' Jan. 1: Christian Lopez, who caught the home run ball for Derek Jeter's 3,000th hit, returned it to Jeter without requesting payment. An article on the facing page of the newspaper noted that Alex Rodriquez has been paid $127 million over the past four seasons, while the Yankees have received only $82 million in on-field value for his services, in large part because of injuries and falling performance.

Last Wednesday, after an unusually mild autumn and early winter, Bryant Park's fountain was dripping with icicles, and logs were burning in the fire pit. It was 13 degrees out! The last of the holiday tourists, many from tropical climates, had just left the city, and overnight a different fashion look emerged. Collars were pulled up, caps were pulled down, scarves were twisted round and round, and eyes peered out of narrow slits. Some reached into their closets for mothballed fur coats.

GRENIER--Tom. February 12 1953 - December 31 2011. Died suddenly at home, after a wonderful day. Devoted husband to Katherine (Cass), loving father who stayed at home to raise his children Nicholas and Eva. Creative painter, cartoonist, sculptor and conceptual artist. Predeceased by his father Wallace and sister Barbara Anderson. A true original, he will be deeply missed by his wife and children, mother Mary Jane (Kit), sisters Margaret Markman and Anne, eleven nieces and nephews and many others. A celebration of Tom's life and art will be held this summer.

GLADFELTER--L. Dean, retired Head of the New York Times National News copy desk died peacefully of natural causes on December 22, 2011 at 84 after years of battling dementia. Formerly of Westfield, NJ, Dean is survived by Patricia, his wife of 60 years, and their daughter, Mary. Dean devoted nearly three decades to ensuring the Times readers received top quality national news. He tirelessly covered Watergate, countless elections and other political matters with an admirable attention to detail and accuracy. Dean's co-workers referred to this creator of the "Quibble-gram" teaching tool as "one feisty editor". Originally from York, PA, Dean graduated from Penn State in 1951 after serving as editor of the Penn State Daily Collegian and being elected to Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Delta Chi. Prior to joining the Times, Dean worked for the York Gazette and Daily, the Philadelphia Daily News and the Philadelphia Inquirer. Memorial services will be held in the spring.

FARBER--Doris Balmuth, passed away on January 3, 2012, at her home in Manhattan, surrounded by her family. She faced her death as she lived her life: fearlessly, without self-pity, and with elegance and dignity. Born in Brooklyn in 1923, she was the adored and adoring daughter of Beatrice Landau and Irving Balmuth. She attended the Crown Heights Yeshiva before graduating from Erasmus Hall High School at age 16 and Hunter College three years later. She attended Columbia and Brooklyn Law Schools and was admitted to the New York Bar in 1946. She later chose to work with her father and beloved brother Jerome running the family business, Standard Furniture Showrooms, and retired in 1977. Doris married Saul J. Farber, M.D. in 1949 and enjoyed 57 wonderful years enthusiastically sharing his life at NYU Medical Center and within the broader community of academic medicine. Doris participated fully in the cultural life of New York, which she shared with her many loving friends. She was deeply devoted to her family, and raised them with pride and love of their Jewish heritage and Israel. She is survived by her children: her son Joshua M. Farber and his wife Nancy M. Hardy, her daughter Beth M. Farber and her husband Stephan M. Loewentheil, and five grandchildren who were the lights of her life: Kara, Nathaniel and Jacob Loewentheil and Daniel and Josephine Farber.

Because of an editing error, a review in some editions last Sunday about Polpettina, a restaurant in Eastchester, N.Y., described a chicken entree incorrectly. It is half of a roasted chicken, not a ''half-roasted'' chicken.

LONDON has become an incubator for alternative architecture publications. The current issue of P.E.A.R. (Paper for Emerging Architectural Research), a zine printed on newspaper stock, features, among other projects, the Filter House, above, by Matthew Butcher, one of P.E.A.R.'s founders. Another founder, Megan O'Shea, said, ''We are interested in showing that the architectural is concerned with more than just architecture.'' The latest issue of Block, a magazine for new writing about architecture and the city, examines the idea of facade, with contributors like the artist Pablo Bronstein. America Deserta Revisited, a new five-part venture from the London artist Tom Keeley, was a result of a train trip across the United States; Mr. Keeley called it ''a series of urban guidebooks to the soul, rather than the sights, of a place.'' ELIAS REDSTONE

FISCHER--Ray J.,of Armonk, NY on January 7, 2012 at the age of 68. Born in New York City on February 23, 1943, he was the son of Abraham and May Weiner Fischer. Ray had been a Real Estate Investor in the Tri-State area. Survived by his loving wife Barbara (Roller) and his loving son Adam. Visitation Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway Tarrytown, NY 10591 Monday from 5-8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to Hospice & Palliative Care of Westchester 311 North St. White Plains, NY 10605 or Muscular Dystrophy Assn. with donation targeted for DM2 research; www.mda.org would be appreciated.

VAN DYKE--Jon Markham. University of Hawaii Law Professor, 68, a scholar and practitioner known internationally for expertise in human rights, environmental, ocean and constitutional law, died November 29, 2011 in Wollongong, Australia. He was born 1943 in Washington, D.C. He graduated from Yale University and Harvard Law School. Van Dyke wrote six books, edited another six books, and authored hundreds of articles and book chapters. He won numerous teaching and research awards including the UH Regents Medal for Excellence in Research. His recent books "Sharing the Resources of the South China Sea" and "Who Owns the Crown Lands of Hawaii" have been recognized as significant contributions to these issues. He was co-author of the casebook, "International Law and Litigation in the U.S." Among his many accomplishments were his efforts to promote the rights and entitlements of Native Hawaiians, stop dumping of nuclear waste at sea and establish nuclear-free zones, restore water to the streams of Hawaii, obtain compensation for the victims murdered or tortured by the Marcos regime, implement peace and reconciliation in Northeast Asia, promote the rule of law in the South China Sea, and protect whales, ocean animals, and orangutans. He promoted the Law of the Sea Treaty, was an expert in ocean law and maritime delimitations and was devoted to protecting the ocean environment. Van Dyke consulted with Korea on Dokdo and international justice and Turkey on ocean issues, represented Pacific Islanders including the victims of atmospheric nuclear testing and climate change and worked for Greenpeace International on the protection of the oceans. Donations for the Jon Van Dyke Fund at UH Law School may be made online www.uhfoundation.org/jonvandyke or by check payable to UH Foundation (JVD Fund) at WSRSL, 2515 Dole Street, Honolulu, HI 96822. Net proceeds, if sufficient, will be used to establish the Jon Van Dyke Institute for International Law and Justice. There will be a memorial service January 14 at the East-West Center in Honolulu. Survived by his wife, Sherry Broder; children, Jesse, Eric, and Michelle Broder Van Dyke; brother, Stuart of Washington, DC.; sister, Jan of Greensboro, NC.

''It's becoming conventional wisdom that the U.S. does not have as much mobility as most other advanced countries.'' Isabel V. Sawhill, an economist at the Brookings Institution. At least five big studies in recent years have found Americans to be less economically mobile than people in comparable nations. ''People are skittish. They're saying: 'Show me, show me, show me. Prove it to me, prove it to me, prove it to me.''' Robert Doll of the assetmanagement firm BlackRock, speaking on Tuesday, the first trading day of the year, when stocks gave back some of their early gains. Investors remained skeptical about the strength of the economy and saw a cloudy outlook for the euro zone.

THE London designer Alice Cicolini works with Kamal Meenakar, a master craftsman in Jaipur, India, on her collection of candy-colored jewels, which employ champlevé, an intricate enamel process (called meenakari in India). ''I'm drawn to enamel because it's like painting on precious metal,'' said Ms. Cicolini, whose latest pieces incorporate exotic shapes and motifs associated with religious architecture found along the ancient Silk Road. This silver, gold, enamel and peridot ring is around $2,500 at matchesfashion.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE
An article last Sunday about critics' favorite cars of 2011 misstated the horsepower of one of Lawrence Ulrich's picks. The Ford Mustang Boss 302 is rated at 444, not 414.

Father of John of New York City, Elinor "Norrie" of Glasgow, Scotland and Matthew of Bernardston, MA. Grandfather of Sam and Lucy Crocker. Survived by his stepchildren Kim, Susan, Ivory, Richard and Abigail Littlefield; and seven step-grandchildren. Brother of Margaret Ives of Newton, William Crocker of Cambridge, Mary Strang of Meeker, CO and the late Charlotte Cleveland and Sarah Garrison. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church Cambridge, Zero Garden St. Cambridge on Monday, January 9 at 2pm. Relatives and friends kindly invited. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers donations in Rev. John Crocker Jr.'s memory can be made to the Crisis Ministry of Princeton and Trenton 136 East Hanover St. Trenton, NJ 08608. Rev. Crocker was Chaplain at Brown University and MIT; and Rector of Trinity Church in Princeton, NJ. During his career, John was an advocate for civil rights and the peace movement. He was an avid sailor as well. On line guest book at: www.brownandhickey.com

An article in some editions last Sunday about a pair of spacecraft launched by NASA to answer persistent questions about the Moon misstated a factor that scientists will have to take into account in analyzing mission data. They will have to consider effects like the pressure of light from the Sun pushing on the spacecraft, not on the Moon.

Two things seem certain after the N.H.L. Players' Association's rejection of the league's realignment plan at Friday's deadline. First, the current division setup and playoff format are now likely to be in place next season. Second, this first sign of open rancor could augur a heated negotiation when the collective bargaining agreement expires in September.

When I first met Hayley Parker-Barker, in 2007, she was just Hayley Parker, a sweet, level-headed senior at F.I.T. and an intern at Narciso Rodriguez. She acquired Barker when she married her husband, Cameron, whom she has known since they were toddlers. And now they have a child of their own, Ender, and live near Salt Lake City, where Cameron is studying computer programming. But I digress. Well, actually, careers these days are one big digression. ''We just sort of boomeranged,'' Ms. Parker-Barker, 25, said brightly of the last few years. She thought, as many fashion graduates did, that she would be living in New York, working for a big-name designer and eating pizza at Roberta's. But the recession, as well as a rekindled romance with Cameron and a return to Utah, changed that. Ms. Parker-Barker isn't complaining, though.

RESNIK--Solomon "Sol," 82, January 2 in New York. Beloved husband, stepfather and grandfather. Faculty member in political science at Queens College; taught for many years at the Center for Continuing Education at Sarah Lawrence College. Dr. Resnik had a profound impact upon and a continuing interest in the lives and work of his students. A dissident voice who encouraged thoughtful consideration of social and political issues. Survived by wife Barbara, four stepchildren, six nieces and nephews and 10 stepgrandchildren. His sharp wit, gentle spirit and keen intellect will be missed. Memorial service at 2pm, January 27 at Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York City. See Legacy.com.
Bill Maher's essay on Jan. 1, on new rules for the new year, was incorrectly labeled. It was an opinion article, not a news analysis.

When Preservation Hall opened in 1961, its purpose was to save traditional jazz. It was probably a decade late. Dixieland was on its second or third revival, while the rest of jazz was evolving frantically. From then until now, the music of the Preservation Hall Jazz Band stood perfectly still. The instruments and the repertory have barely altered in decades: tuba, trombone, banjo, clarinet; ''Mood Indigo,'' ''St. Louis Blues,'' ''When the Saints Go Marching In.'' It was considered backward music for tourists; it was Dixie Beatlemania. And yet. Fifty years later, there is no other place like Preservation Hall. It's hot and uncomfortable, and no alcohol is served. The musicians change nightly -- the original players are long gone -- but the sound is the same. The band has been playing its own funeral for the past 50 years, and it shows no signs of dying. renovations to preservation hall since 1961: 0

PRINCE--Harvey M.,MD, age 81. Loving husband, brother, father and grand- father. Internist, bibliophile, US Army veteran, lover of music and politics, unshakeable Yankees and Giants fan. He will be sadly missed.

''I CAN finally afford Jason Wu!'' squealed a fan upon hearing about the coming Jason Wu for Target collection, in stores Feb. 5. The line, Mr. Wu's first in collaboration with a mass retailer, possesses a lot of his label's familiar feminine spirit but takes more direct inspiration from French New Wave films and the actress Jean Seberg. Pleated frocks with sailor-striped hemlines, dainty silk blouses with ties at the neck and little collars, and sportier knits and tennis skirts stand out as some of the most wearable pieces. ''My goal was not to duplicate anything from my main collection,'' Mr. Wu said. Friendly reminders of his work (like the touch of lace on a trench coat or T-shirt) are matched with a delightful dose of animal humor. (Meet Milu, a mischievous kitty and the collection's mascot, who makes appearances as a print on a scarf and tee.) Here, a Riviera cotton striped A-line dress and canvas satchel explain why Mr. Wu calls the whole gamut ''gamine chic.'' Jason Wu for Target poplin dress, $40, and satchel, $50. Go to target.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

MONSERRATE--Carey. The friends and family of Carey Monserrate are grieving for him, with love and sorrow. Carey was born in New York City on October 28, 1970, and died there on December 28, 2011. He grew up largely in Providence, Rhode Island, graduating from the Wheeler School in 1988, and then cum laude from Harvard, where he studied English and American Literature as a member of the class of 1992. He formed many close friendships in his school years-and everywhere he went-which endured throughout his life. Carey was a writer, editor, poet, and musician. He lived with an openness to the world and to the experiences of others: born Catholic, he considered himself culturally Jewish and spiritually Zen Buddhist. In Red Hook, Brooklyn, he was well known as a community activist, engaged with his neighbors on issues ranging from helicopter-noise pollution to economic justice; he was also the founding manager of the Red Hook Wobblies softball team. He would cook for friends and loved ones or gather them for expeditions to Chinatown restaurants, and talk with them for hours around the table. His conversation, like his correspondence and his kindness, could lighten their darkest moments. Carey took his own life. His mother, Rose Monserrate, mourns the loss of her beloved son. Carey is also survived by his paternal grandmother and a loving circle of uncles, aunts, cousins, and step- and half-siblings. A memorial in New York is being planned. In Carey's memory, donations may be made to Added Value, www.added-value.org, or to the Buddhist Peace Fellowship: www.bpf.org.

9 P.M. (13, 49) DOWNTON ABBEY ''Masterpiece Classic'' inaugurates a new chapter in this soap opera, created by Julian Fellowes, about masters and servants at the twilight of the British Empire. Hugh Bonneville returns as Lord Grantham, who, with three daughters and no direct male heir, is being forced to hand down his beloved ancestral home to a middle-class third cousin, Matthew Crawley (Dan Stevens), along with the fortune of his American-born heiress wife (Elizabeth McGovern, above). Maggie Smith is his imperious mother, and Siobhan Finneran is Miss O'Brien, Lady Grantham's Machiavellian maid. The story reopens in 1916 at the Battle of the Somme, where Matthew -- his romance with Lord Grantham's eldest daughter, Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery), derailed -- is now an officer trying to keep his troops alive. ''As the dowager countess, Ms. Smith has many of the best lines and usually the last word,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. ''When her middle granddaughter, Lady Edith, frets that she will end up a spinster, Lady Violet says briskly, 'Don't be defeatist, Dear, it's very middle class.' There is nothing middle class about 'Downton Abbey.' Even a world war can't sever the bond between aristocrats and the servants who love them.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY In a broadcast from New Hampshire, Ms. Crowley interviews the Republican presidential candidate Jon Huntsman, as well as Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California.

JURIST--Harvey I. Born 1924, Brooklyn, NY. Died January 6, 2012, Queens, NY. A child of both immigrants and the Great Depression, he rose to become a "sturdy son" of City College and then a CPA. Senior partner at Clarence Rainess & Company, Brout & Company, and BDO Seidman. Predeceased in 2003 by his wife of 57 years, Roslyn. Survived by sons Eric (Lynne) and Kenneth (Gail), grandchildren Elizabeth (Michael), Karen (Dan), Benjamin and Aaron, and brother Alvin (Rene). He was a man of great integrity who embraced responsibility for his family, friends, clients and partners. His entire family "stands on his shoulders." Contributions are encouraged to be made to the National Parkinson Foundation: www.parkinson.org.

STETTNER--Alfred M.,84, Medusa, New York, died on December 28, 2011 in Manhattan. Born in the Bronx, NY in 1927, to Bertha and Charles Stettner, Fred married Enid in 1960. Fred, a United States Army veteran of World War II, spent his youth living in Manhattan and working in television production until 1970 when he and his wife, Enid, moved their family full-time to their farm in southern Albany County. Fred started a second career as a real estate broker in 1970 and continued to work until the day of his death. Fred was extremely active in his beloved community, attending and working with the Town Board, Planning Board, in local politics and many other local organizations. Fred was a true humanitarian who helped many people throughout his life and had a great love and respect for all creatures, great and small. He will be missed by many. A celebration of his life will be held in the Spring or early Summer up at his farm. Fred is survived by his devoted wife of 52 years, Enid; three children, Ann, Nina and Adam, and six grandchildren. Donations can be made in Fred Stettner's name to the Medusa Volunteer Fire Department, 28 Rte 351, Medusa, 12120.

DuBRUL--Stephen M.,Jr., died on January 4th at home. Born March 18, 1929 and raised in Michigan, Mr. DuBrul attended Notre Dame University (1946-48) and graduated from the University of Michigan in 1950. Thereafter, he served with the Central Intelligence Agency for the first two years of the Korean War. In late 1952, he volunteered for the U.S. Army and eventually served in a special unit of the Army's Counter Intelligence Corps until Fall 1954. From 1954 to 1956, Mr. DuBrul attended Harvard Business School, where he was a George F. Baker Scholar, receiving a Master's degree with Distinction. Mr. DuBrul entered the investment banking business in 1956 as an associate with Lehman Brothers in New York, where he became a partner in 1960 and a Senior Managing Director in 1968. At Lehman, he was active in all phases of the firm and served as a member of the Executive Committee and Chairman of Lehman Commercial Paper, Inc. In 1972, he joined Lazard Freres & Company as a General Partner. He left Wall Street for Washington in December 1975. From January 1976 to May 1977, Mr. DuBrul was President and Chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, which he reorganized for President Ford. Since 1978, Mr. DuBrul had his own independent consulting and private banking practice. He served as a director of a number of major public corporations, including Radio Corporation of America, RCA Corporation and NBC, Continental Can Company, Continental Group, Inc., General Dynamics Corporation, Great Northern Paper Co., Jewel Companies, Inc., R. H. Macy & Co., May Department Stores Company, Acme-Cleveland Corporation, Weatherhead Company, Midland-Ross Corp., Tappan Manufacturing Company, Signal Companies, Inc., Sainsbury (USA) Inc., Shaw's Supermarkets, Inc. and the Jeffrey Company. Mr. DuBrul served in numerous professional, governmental, philanthropic and academic organizations. In the early 1960's, he was a White House consultant to the Council of Economic Advisors under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. He was Director, Treasurer and Chairman of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, and served as Trustee of the Carnegie Foundation for Advancement of Teaching and the Buckley School of New York. He was also a member of the Visiting Committee to Harvard Business School, having previously served as President of the Harvard Business School Association and Chairman of the Harvard Business School Fund. From 1968 to 1971, Mr DuBrul was a Governor of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, and from 1972 to 1975, a Director and Executive Committee member of the Securities Industry Association. He served as a Trustee of International House and President of Episcopal Missions Society of New York. He is survived by his two children, Nicholas DuBrul and Jennifer DuBrul Missbrenner, his three grand-daughters, and his beloved Edee. A memorial service will be held at a later date in New York City.

CHUNKY, cabled, cropped: knits are popping up in everyone's wardrobe this season. (Chalk it up to all those knitting clubs and yarn bombers.) But who would expect to check into a hotel room and find the sheets, the bedside lamp and even the morning breakfast hand-knit? Such is the case in the Do Knit Disturb room at the Hotel Pelirocco, a funky bed-and-breakfast in Brighton, England. Kate Jenkins, a local artist who got her start designing knitwear for Marc Jacobs, spent a month (and 11 pounds of yarn) creating the room. The bedspread, curtains and wallcovering are all knitted; the telephone, lampshade, flower vase, teapot and teacup are covered in crochet. There's even a knitted fried English breakfast, with woolen eggs and bacon. It makes one itchin' to go! Hotel Pelirocco, 10 Regency Square, Brighton; hotelpelirocco.co.uk. LENA DE CASPARIS

LEVINE--Sanford C.,89, of Dobbs Ferry died on January 6th after a heroic struggle with multiple illnesses. His wife of 65 years, Laurel (Gottlober) mourns and misses him. For the last six years of his life, she cared for all of his needs during his serious illness. He is mourned also by his daughters Linda and Amy, a grandaughter, Leah, and another daughter Elizabeth. Born in New York City, Mr. Levine grew up in the Inwood section of New York. He graduated from Clinton High School and the New York University School of Law. Mr. Levine was the original renaissance man. No piece of masking tape or stray wire in his home went unused. He cherished every drill, wrench and soldering gun; if a tool or cable did not exist to meet his needs, he fashioned it himself, employing tubing, duct tape, electrical connectors, solder, and whatever else was at hand. His motto seemed to be don't buy it before you try to make it. In the attic of his large home, Mr. Levine built a darkroom and for many years he had a tidy retreat from the four females in his life there he could develop his photos and employ his creativity to create beautiful pictures of his of his wife and daughters to whom he was devoted; A lover of music and literature, Mr. Levine worked for a time at the record label, Allegra, owned by his uncle, Sam Puner, where he pressed records, and wrote liner notes. He also worked as a chemist, audio-visual technician, prosthesis designer and writer among other endeavors, until he finally attended New York University Law School. He passed the New York Bar in 1957. Mr. Levine lost a leg when he was a young man. His parents were concerned he would never marry, but he met Laurel Gottlober in 1946 when he was playing chess outside the tennis court where Miss Gottlober was playing. He proposed a month later. Miss Gottlober's mother had had other plans for her daughter, and had the new fiance followed, particularly to his favorite jazz clubs on 52nd Street. However, the mother-in-law to be grew to revere her son in-law, whose talent and skill with bricks and mortar, and later, the law, were shared with gentility. Though considered disabled, Mr. Levine never filed for disability to sustain him, but worked throughout his life, as a family practice lawyer, and later as an Administrative Law Judge for the state of New York. He retired in 1993. Mr. Levine loved books and words; in his older years, as his tight circle of friends passed away, he found some solace writing poetry and studying mathematics. He loved to travel and even journeyed twice on trips where dialysis was provided. Ultimately those trips had to stop. Before they did, The Levine couple explored most of Europe, Israel, Egypt, and parts of South and Central America. A faithful New Yorker, a younger Mr. Levine loved prowling Canal Street for tools and stereo equipment., and shmoozing in delis with his friends. One of his final requests, from his hospital bed, was via a note handed to his wife. It read "egg cream." Services will be private. A memorial is planned for the spring.

Imagine that the lettered balls in the three-dimensional grid at the right are arranged in two vertical layers: M, S, P / B, S, U / L, A, N in front, and I, T, O / L, E, R / O, C, K in back. Find as many words of exactly five letters as you can spell by following the rods connecting the balls. You may return to a letter and use it twice in one word (as the I in LIMIT), but you may not ''stand'' on a letter and use it twice before proceeding (as the T in MITTS).

Sinai Hospital; Higher Education Programs supporting low income students; and outreach programs in New York City Museums. Alvin was a renaissance man of knowledge, wisdom and integrity.

HARRIS--Henry William, M.D.,pulmonary physician and tuberculosis expert, dies at 92 years old. Dr. Harris, whose academic medical career spanned 57 years and included his appointment as Professor of Clinical Medicine at New York University School of Medicine and Director of Graduate Training for the Chest Service at Bellevue Hospital, was also President of the American Thoracic Society (1962-1963), Vice President of the American Lung Association (1972-1973) and recipient of the University of North Carolina Distinguished Alumni Service Award and the Life and Breath Award of the American Lung Association of New York City. He died at home on December 19, 2011 in Mineola, NY from lung cancer. Dr. Harris was born in Catawba, NC and educated at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Harvard Medical School, where he graduated cum laude in 1943. He received advanced training in internal medicine and infectious diseases at the Boston City Hospital and Thorndike Laboratory in Boston as well as Bellevue Hospital in New York City. He was Board Certified in Internal Medicine and Pulmonary Diseases, published more than 75 scientific and clinical papers, particularly on the clinical features and therapy of tuberculosis, and served as a member of the examining committee of the Pulmonary Subspecialty Board of the American Board of Internal Medicine. He was a physician/faculty member at multiple institutions, including the US Army, the Gundersen Clinic in La Crosse, WI, the University of Utah School of Medicine, the Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania, the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens and New York University School of Medicine. He also served as Medical Coordinator and Senior Medical Consultant for the Bureau of Tuberculosis of the Department of Health of New York City. Dr. Harris served on the Board of Directors of the Tuberculosis Associations of Utah, Brooklyn and New York City, where he served as president. He was also the President of the American Bureau for Medical Advancement in China (ABMAC) for five years and received the Health Award First Class from the Ministry of Health of the Republic of China in Taiwan, the highest award given to foreign medical professionals and the third such award ever granted. He was buried in Catawba, NC. He is survived by his younger sister, three sons and seven grandchildren.

KNOWLTON--Evelyn Hope, 106 years, December 31, 2011, Medford, NJ. Graduate of Smith College. After studies at the Graduate School of Business Administration, Harvard University, she entered the field of business history. Her major works were "The Resurgent Years, 1911-1927" (1956), a history of Esso, now Exxon-Mobil, which she co-authored with George Gibb, and "Pepperell's Progress" (1948), the history of the cotton textile company. Her parents Rev. Joseph Adams Puffer and Emily Hope Puffer predeased her. In 1942, she married Harry E. Knowlton. She is survived by her son, Stephen Knowlton. A life-long Unitarian, she helped establish the Fourth Unitarian Society of Weschester in Mohegan Lake, New York. Memorial services are scheduled at Medford Leas Continuing Care Retirement Community for Saturday, February 4 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Smith College are encouraged.

Sinai School of Medicine & Distinguished Life Fellow of the APA while working on groundbreaking innovations in biofeedback, hypnotherapy, and other therapies in the field of psychiatry. He's greatly missed by his many friends and relatives.

Mr. Romney stated that government consumes 37 percent of the economy's output, but that figure should be put in perspective considering that he is running to head the federal government. That 37 percent reflects the combined size of the federal, state and local governments. The Congressional Budget Office has reported that federal government spending alone in 2010 was equivalent to 23.8 percent of the gross domestic product, and it forecast the percentage would be the same when final figures are in for 2011.

FINN--Dr. Harold M.,June 3, 1922-December 9, 2011, one of the fathers of modern radar. He served on several army planning teams. Harold was a Fellow of the IEEE, Fellow of the Military Sensing Symposia, member of the Society of Old Crows, Eta Kappa Nu, Tau Beta Phi. Graduate of CCNY, University of Maryland and University of Pennsylvania. Born in New York City. Served in the US Army Signal Corps 3102 Signal Battalion in the China Defensive in Ma Xian Ping, Kweichow Province 1942-1945. Survived by his wife, three sons, two grandchildren, two brothers, nephews, a niece and their children. He entertained us with juggling, swam almost a mile a day in the Pacific Ocean, walked miles to and from work whenever he could and was an early defender of the environment and loved his garden.

It was coincidental, but two successful N.H.L. team executives, Detroit's Jimmy Devellano and Toronto's Brian Burke, spoke out about fighting in the game last Thursday. They represent diametrically different points of view on the subject, and they were not speaking in response to each other, but it was as good as a point/counterpoint presentation of dueling editorials. ''I would abolish fighting, like today,'' Devellano, the Red Wings' senior vice president, said on a podcast for the New York cable network SNY. ''I would eliminate it immediately. I can do without it. I don't need it.''

FEIN--Nancy, 68, beloved grandmother, mother and sister. Devoted educator, advocate and friend. Her spirit will forever soar in the hearts of her family, colleagues and students. Funeral: Sunday, January 8, 11am, Schoem's Chapel, 150 W. Rt 4, Paramus, NJ. Burial to follow at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Queens.

GARDNER--Elizabeth (Libby). Died December 22, age 90. WASP aviator during WWII, brave and caring social justice activist, writer, computer programmer, autodidact with a vast range of curiosities and pursuits. Loved by daughter Eve, brother Robert, and many others whose lives she touched.

MELVILLE--Allen Whitley, 84, died January 1, 2011 at Duncaster Retirement Community in Bloomfield, CT. The daughter of Ennis P. Whitley and Alice Lanning Whitley, Allen Melville was born January 29, 1927, in Evanston, IL and spent her childhood in Grand Rapids, MI. She attended Sarah Lawrence College before marrying Frank Melville in 1947. A lifelong supporter of liberal causes and organizations, particularly the American Civil Liberties Union, she became especially active in advocating for people with mental illness after she and Frank moved from New Canaan to Norfolk in 1980. She served on the Protection and Advocacy board, helped to establish Prime Time House in Torrington, and made a concern for mental illness crucial to the work of the Melville Charitable Trust, on whose board she served for many years. Predeceased by her husband and her younger brother, Michael, she is survived by four sons, Stephen, Lanning, Gregory, and Cameron, and three grandchildren, Geoffrey, Alan, and Erin. A memorial service is planned in Hartford later this year. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Duncaster Retirement Community, 80 Loeffler Road, Bloomfield, CT 06002 or to Prime Time House, Inc., 836 Main St., Torrington, CT 06790. Kenny Funeral Homes, 39 Maple Ave. Norfolk has care of services.

A California agency is campaigning to get car owners to change their motor oil at a longer interval, claiming that the time-honored practice of switching the oil every 3,000 miles is financially wasteful, detrimental to the environment and unwarranted. A survey conducted in August by New American Dimensions, a marketing research company, of 1,000 car owners with vehicles registered in California found that about half changed their oil every 3,000 miles or less, although very few automakers call for such frequent intervals. It also found that less than 10 percent consulted their car manuals for recommended oil-change schedules.

An entry in the Video column on Dec. 25 about the movie ''The People Against O'Hara'' misidentified a film that dealt with similar legal material and the year that it was released. ''The Verdict'' by Sidney Lumet -- not ''Verdict'' -- was released in 1982, not in 1975. (That was the year the French movie ''Verdict'' was released in the United States.)

HOW do you make the experience of live theater pop on film in a way that makes a potential ticket buyer say, ''I've got to see that''? Television commercials are a mainstay, but expensive. Trailers -- which can run longer than 15 or 30 seconds and be widely distributed -- are increasingly being used to promote theater, but producing them is still a challenge in terms of style, access and cost. ''Everybody is trying it, and I don't think anyone has nailed it,'' said Thomas Weitz, the director for digital assets at Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago. The result, he said, is a grab bag of approaches that hasn't yet been codified into the voice-of-God style that makes movie trailers so easy to parody.

JAKUPS--Judy Nobel. Died suddenly of a heart attack on January 1st 2012. She was a smart, talented and beautiful woman who brought life and incredible spirit wherever she went. She is loved and will be missed by her husband Thomas, son Jack, brother Barry and his wife Maija, twin sister Laurie Everitt, parents Fred and Gilda Nobel, and everyone who had the honor of knowing her. Memorial services will be held at 1:30pm January 7 at The Universalist Church of West Hartford, CT. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York City.

WAGER--Michael. The family of Leonard and Felicia Bernstein and The Leonard Bernstein Office mourn the passing of Michael Wager. We are already missing his wit, his erudition, his deep love of the arts, and the many spirited gatherings in his beautiful living spaces. Our hearts go out to his entire family.

Where is Europe? You might as well ask: What is Europe? For it is a concept as well as a continent, and the borders of both oscillate wildly. For the ancient Persians, it was that small stepping stone separating them from Greece. In the Middle Ages, it became virtually synonymous with Christendom. A relatively recent and generally unaccepted theory sees Europe spanning half the globe, from Iceland to the Bering Strait, nearly touching Alaska.

Thanks so much to all who contributed to our lively - if somewhat technologically challenged - discussion about the scientists who made bird flu take wing. Responses reflected an unusually wide array of ideas, from the conviction that nothing in the world could justify experiments like those in question to the equally impassioned conviction that nothing should get in their way. Similarly, some argued that the data these experiments produced are of only marginal usefulness, while others felt they would prove as invaluable as Galileo's discovery. But what, as Andrew S asked, is the most appropriate ethical framework for sorting through these claims? For those who might have more to say, we'll keep the comments open for a while longer. Readers, have at it!

Foundation for Jammable Resources is an artist collective-cum-band whose shows blend installation, punk and performance art. They started jamming together at parties, realized they had a lot in common and ultimately had a drum war in front of the Ballroom late one night during a Chinati Open House weekend. They started playing and experimenting with music with John Rayburn and decided they liked what they were doing and wanted to play live. The ballots for this year's Oscars were only recently sent out and already there's a move afoot to change the rules for next year's ceremony. The Academy may move this week to consider only documentaries reviewed by The New York Times or The Los Angeles Times eligible for an Oscar, our colleague Michael Cieply reports. The change would probably trim the number of features under consideration, which rose more than 20 percent from 2010 to 2011, but he adds it would also affect DocuWeeks, screenings sponsored by the International Documentary Association: "The new rule puts a squeeze on those who do not have a commercial distributor, and particularly calls into question the viability of DocuWeeks, which has consistently shoehorned films into the Oscar process." What do our critics think of the plan to qualify only films that have been reviewed in the paper? "It's flattering," A.O. Scott says. Read more »

An article on Wednesday about Idaho teachers' resistance to a statewide plan for technology in the classroom misstated an element of the plot of ''The Book Thief,'' a novel being taught by one teacher. The book, set in Germany during World War II, centers on a girl living with a foster family; she is not being hidden as a Jew. (The family does shelter a Jewish man.)

HOUSTON TEXANS (11-6) at BALTIMORE RAVENS (12-4) These teams played back in October, a 29-14 victory for the Ravens. Not surprisingly, the Ravens, long one of the dominant run defenses in the league (they ranked second this season), shut the run down that day, holding Arian Foster to 49 yards. That probably will not stop the Texans from trying to run again, not after Foster was so successful running, mostly to the outside, for 153 yards against the Bengals. The Texans ran 35 times and attempted only 20 passes.

An article on Wednesday about Clint Dempsey's success as an American soccer player in England omitted credit for the source of three quotations. Dempsey's remarks about the pressures of the English Premier League -- he called it a ''roller coaster'' -- and his hopes to one day compete in the elite Champions League were first published on the Fox Soccer Web site in December. His remarks about how he views himself -- ''I'm just someone who wants to make it in the world'' -- were first published in The Daily Mail in May 2010.

The Five Thirty Eight column on Thursday, about the upside of Mitt Romney's close victory in the Iowa caucuses, referred imprecisely to the results of the 1972 Democratic caucuses there. While Edmund S. Muskie finished ahead of all other candidates, he did not technically win. ''Uncommitted,'' a choice, but not a candidate, received the most votes. (The issue of whether Mr. Muskie actually won Iowa is a longstanding one. On Jan. 26, 1972, The Times declared Mr. Muskie the ''victor'' in a story on Page 16. The Times also took note of Jimmy Carter's ''impressive victory'' in the 1976 Iowa caucuses, even though he too finished second, behind ''uncommitted.'')

KLARREICH--Lynn. Died on January 7, 2012 after a five year heroic struggle against Ovarian Cancer. A graduate of Adelphi University she had a long and distinguished career as a staffing industry owner and executive. Survived by her husband Joel, sister Bonnie Malen, children Jason and Renee Klarreich and Meryl and Noah Heller and the grandchildren she adored, Jack, Ryan, Lila, Owen and Rex. Services today at 9:30am at Plaza Community Chapel 91st and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Ovarian Cancer Research at NYU Hospital.

ROTHSTEIN--Stanley 86, January 7, 2012 in Santa Monica, California (formerly of New Rochelle, NY.) A child of Brooklyn who grew up in the shadow of Ebbets Field, a graduate of Erasmus High School and Brooklyn College, with a Masters from the University of Pennsylvania, he was a proud U.S. Navy veteran of WWII. He followed his father into the knitwear manufacturing business in New York where he was President of JimKnit Company. He was the rock of his family, a thoughtful, warm, and wise man of few but impactful words with a twinkle in his eye who always saw the best in everyone. He is survived by his beloved wife of 61 years, Phyllis (Rosner) Rothstein. Loving brother to his deceased sisters Elaine and Hermine. Loved and cherished father to Lisa (Bill) Finkelstein and Robin (Jerry) Sinclair, and beloved "Poppy" to his adoring granddaughter Sophie Frances Sinclair, of whom he was immensely proud. Loved by his dogs Jinni and Linc, he was happiest when sculpting and gardening and was a dedicated long-time volunteer at The New York Botanical Garden where donations in his memory can be made online at www.nybg.org or at 2900 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458. He will be missed.

MCWHINNIE--John, age 43, rare book and art dealer and curator whose vision and passion were unique. I have lost a teacher, mentor and dear friend. Matthew and I send our heartfelt condolences to his beloved Maria.

KANTOR--Norman. 1927 2012. Born and raised in Plainfield, NJ to Abraham and Rose Kantor. He graduated from Plainfield High School in 43 and Cornell University in '47. He also played football (QB) at Georgia Tech for a year during ROTC in 45 (not the Bulldogs best year). He was a long-time resident of Westfield, NJ and New York City. He is predeceased by his wife Margaretha of 42 years and his brother, Marvin and two sisters, Miriam and Leonore. He is survived by his two children, Steven Kantor (who resides with his wife Jane in New York City) and Clarissa Taylor (who resides with her husband BJ in Westfield). He also is survived by his four grandchildren who he adored Chloe, Caroline, Ben and Jack as well as his devoted friend of recent years Andrea Berger. In 1960, Norm took over United Supply Co. from his father and grew it into the largest family-owned HVAC and plumbing supply house in NJ. Known nationally throughout the industry as a great innovator, Norm introduced the first retail plumbing showrooms, Kitchen & BathWorks, in 1982. The company is celebrating 100 years of success and continues to be owned and run by the family an accomplishment in which he took great pride. But his priorities were never financial success, they were much richer goals and, by example, he taught us all. He saw everyone as a friend and treated everyone with dignity, respect and empathy. Each person he met was important to him and if they had time to listen, he had a story for them sometimes even if they didn't have time to listen. Optimism was his religion. He taught us life was a wonderful gift and each day was another chance to do good and enjoy it. He put family and friends first and as everyone he met quickly became his friend, his life was busy and full until his last months. Norm also was gifted with many passions and talents. A jack-of-all-trades, he was an accomplished fine artist and sculptor, a film producer (Pretty Boy Floyd, Black Like Me), and a great writer who never published. He had a great love for and knowledge of tennis and Shakespeare. He was a memorable dancer (crazy legs) but not a great singer although that never stopped him. He was truly one of those rare people who lived his life the way we all hope to, but rarely do with unstoppable optimism, an undeniably warm smile and happy laughter through thick and thin. This was his gift to us all. We love you Dad

An obituary on Nov. 14 about William Aramony, a former president of United Way of America who went to prison for misusing funds, misstated the reasons he received only $7,781 in pension benefits and deferred compensation after he had sued United Way while in prison claiming he was owed $4.2 million. An appeals court denied him much of that claim under tax and pension laws and reduced it further, saying he had to repay United Way for the harm he inflicted through his fraud and to cover punitive damages, taxes and lawyers' fees; the court did not say he ''had to repay the money he stole.'' (The erroneous phrase first appeared in an article on June 22, 2001, about the court ruling.)

A capsule look at the Giants' 24-2 victory over Atlanta in their wild-card playoff game: Key Play Eli Manning will never be known as fleet of foot, but he has shown superior instincts in the pocket all season. He demonstrated them again on a 14-yard scramble in the second quarter, avoiding the rushing John Abraham on third-and-2 and slipping away to the left to sustain a drive that ended with the game's first touchdown.

SMIT--Hans. Dean David M. Schizer and the Columbia Law School community mourn deeply the loss of Hans Smit, a distinguished professor and a leading scholar and practitioner in the field of international arbitration and international procedure. For more than 50 years, Hans was a powerful presence at Columbia Law School, where he made a remarkable contribution to the institution, to generations of students, and to the field of international arbitration. After earning his LL.B. and LL.M. from the University of Amsterdam in 1946 and 1949, respectively, Hans worked in private practice in The Hague and New York City. He earned a master's degree at Columbia in 1953 and graduated first in his class with an LL.B. from the Law School in 1958. Hans joined the Columbia Law School faculty in 1960, where he directed the Project on International Procedure, which attracted top legal minds such as Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who served as a research associate and associate director. He also directed other pioneering international law programs at Columbia, including the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law and the Center for East European Law. In 1965, Hans helped establish the Law School as a global hub for the study of international law by serving as director of the Project on European Legal Institutions. The project yielded a seminal work, The Law of the European Economic Community. Hans was a member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences and the International Academy of Comparative Law, and he was knighted by the Queen of the Netherlands. Our hearts go out to his wife, Beverly; their son, Robert H. Smit, and their daughter, Marion Smit, for this great loss.

For a couple of months now, Amazon has practically begged you to buy a Kindle Fire. Maybe you did. And maybe you are insanely happy that you can now spend hours on the couch playing Angry Birds rather than reading some boring old book, which is all you could do on your old Kindle. Sure, you could give that rejected Kindle to an aging relative who is faithful to the old ways of literacy. Now you have another option: sell it to Amazon for real money, or at least a near-equivalent -- an Amazon gift card.

Articles on Wednesday and Thursday about Fordham's victory over No. 22 Harvard in men's basketball, using incorrect information from Fordham, misstated the length of the Rams' losing streak against ranked opponents. It had been 17 games, since a 68-67 victory on Dec. 9, 2000, against No. 24 St. John's at Madison Square Garden -- not 54 games since a 63-59 victory on Feb. 26, 1978, against No. 18 Georgetown at Rose Hill Gym. The Thursday article also referred imprecisely to Fordham's loss this season to Northwood University of Florida. It was a preseason game, not a regular-season contest.

In a thatched hut in Juba, the capital of South Sudan, about 10 young men and women sat on lawn chairs made of brown plastic. They loudly typed on the computer keyboards on the tables in front of them. Two fans were blowing heavily. But the loud humming, which turned all speaking in the room into yelling, didn't come from them. It came from the backyard, and when it suddenly stopped, the young people saved their work. Minutes later their screens turned dark. It was hours to deadline for The Citizen, until recently the only daily print newspaper in South Sudan, and its staff had to wait until the generator was refueled.

It is exceedingly rare for a new television newscast to be made almost entirely from scratch, as is the case with ''CBS This Morning,'' which will replace ''The Early Show'' on Monday morning. Many of the producers and talent bookers for ''CBS This Morning'' are new to the network, as are two of the three anchors, Charlie Rose and Gayle King.

KRYSTON--Daniel Joseph, 69, of Chestnut Ridge, NY died on January 6, 2012. Mr. Kryston was an attorney for the City of New York for 40 years. He was a past president of Municipal Engineers of the City of New York and was a strong advocate of social justice and until the time of his illness served as chair and president of the Henry George School of Social Science in New York City. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth B. Kryston; daughters, Koreen Kryston Thomas and husband Rowland and Janeen Kryston Waddell and husband Sean, five grandchildren and brother, Frank Kryston. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held 11:30am, Wednesday, at St. Margaret's R.C. Church, Pearl River, NY. Visiting is Tuesday from 3 - 5 and 7-9pm at Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home Inc. Pearl River, NY. In lieu of flowers friends may send memorial donations to St. Dominic's Home, Executive Director, 500 Western Highway, Blauvelt, NY 10913 or United Hospice of Rockland.

''Set-top box'' is one of those puzzling anachronisms, like ''record industry,'' that seems to persist for no clear reason. Perching a cable tuner, TiVo or Apple TV on top one of today's slim television sets would require either amazing balancing skills, very strong adhesive or a bit of both. For the last several years, Roku has been one of the companies selling devices that let users stream Internet video to their televisions from a big lineup of programming sources, including Netflix and Hulu Plus. Even though you can't balance them on top of a modern television set, the Roku boxes are tiny things, roughly the size of a hockey puck.

Amazon.com, through its Web services business, stores vast amounts of data for companies worldwide. Does it want to start analyzing it too? Specialists in data science say the company has become increasingly interested in the business models of firms that make and sell pattern-finding algorithms for extremely large data sets. They theorize that Amazon wants to move beyond its cloud services businesses -- which rents data storage and raw computing power -- and add to these offerings analysis software that can be rented, and possibly modified, to suit a company's needs.

Anne Tyng, an architectural theorist who worked with the celebrated modern architect Louis I. Kahn and had a daughter with him, died on Dec. 27 at her home in Greenbrae, Calif. She was 91. Her death was confirmed by William Whitaker, the curator of the Architectural Archives at the University of Pennsylvania, which holds Kahn's collection as well as Ms. Tyng's.

KLARREICH--Lynn. Tannenbaum Helpern Syracuse & Hirschtritt is saddened by the passing of Lynn Klarreich, wife of our esteemed partner, Joel. Lynn was a warm, gracious, loving woman who battled cancer with strength and dignity. We extend our sympathy to her devoted husband, her caring sister, her beloved children and adored grandchildren.

Bristol-Myers Squibb agreed late Saturday to buy Inhibitex, a maker of a hepatitis C treatment, for about $2.5 billion in cash, as major drug companies seek to bolster their pipelines with more profitable specialty products. Under the deal, Bristol-Myers will pay $26 a share through a two-step merger, beginning with a tender offer. That represents a huge 163 percent premium over Inhibitex's closing price Friday.

SACHS--Howard, PhD, M.D.,85, died December 6, 2011. Survivor of the WWII battle for Okinawa. He became a pioneering scientist in neuroendocrinology after getting his doctorate in biochemistry from Columbia University in 1953. At age 48, he left a prestigious scientific career and became a physician, with one goal--to help people. Dr. Howard Sachs is survived by his loving daughters, Susan, Linda and Nancy.
LANYI--George. 21 years without you. We miss you every day. Mother and Paul

GRIFFEL--Marion. Died January 6. Beloved wife of Harold. Mother of Richard, Martin (Amy). Grandmother of Jeremy, Sam, Jared, Alex. Beloved sister of Daniel Cohen. Beloved Aunt. Retired teacher. Loved by everyone. She deeply touched many lives. She will be surely missed.

Music in 2011 was dominated by Adele, who had the top album and the top digital song, ''Rolling in the Deep,'' which was also the most-played song on the radio. Based on album sales, Adele was the top artist, followed by Justin Bieber, above, and Michael Bublé. Digital album sales rose 19.5 percent from 2010, to 103.1 million. Again, Adele was tops, but a different audience buys digital music rather than CD albums, so ''Under the Mistletoe'' and ''Own the Night'' were not among the top 10, but ''Mylo Xyloto'' by Coldplay and ''Torches'' by Foster the People were. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Penguin Group USA has plucked its first author from its new electronic slush pile. Ace Books, an imprint of Penguin, has signed the debut novelist Kerry Schafer to a two-book deal, only weeks after Ms. Schafer posted writing samples on Bookcountry.com, a Web site Penguin introduced in April that invites writers of genre fiction to share their work.

TOSCANINI--Walfredo, 82, died at home in New Rochelle, NY, on December 31, of leukemia. Husband of Elaine (nee Troostwyk); father of Liana, Maia (Tom Brown) and Cia (Murdoch McBride); grandfather of Wyatt and Liam. A Democratic party activist and former city councilman and deputy mayor of New Rochelle, Toscanini was an architect who worked for the State of New York and in private practice. He strove to preserve and promote the artistic legacy of his grandfather, conductor Arturo Toscanini, as well as the memory of his mother, prima ballerina Cia Fornaroli, and his father, Walter Toscanini. A native of Milan, he immigrated to America at age nine. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Manhattan, Wednesday, January 11, at 3:30. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent in his name to Leukemia Fighters/New York Presbyterian Hospital or Smile Train out of Washington, DC.

BERMAN--James S.,71, on January 6, 2012. Architect, inventor, commodore, and generous friend, Jim gave everything to the people he cared about. Of his many achievements, he took greatest pride in living a magical life as a member of the Berman family. He will be forever missed by wife, Donna; children, Jessica, Leigh, Ben and Lynn; children-in-law, Lane, Rosalie and Yejin, and grandchildren, Sloan, Cary, Adam and Chase. Service at St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, Saturday, January 14, 10:30am.

An article on Wednesday about athletes who have quit on themselves or their teams, misstated the professional credentials of Chris Stankovich, who was quoted questioning the importance of winning championships to highly paid players. He is licensed as a professional clinical counselor; he is not a psychologist.

NO. 1 LOUISIANA STATE (13-0) VS. NO. 2 ALABAMA (12-1) 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Matchup to Watch Alabama linebackers versus L.S.U.'s Jordan Jefferson Jefferson took over as the Tigers' starting quarterback after his performance against Alabama in the teams' first game, a 9-6 overtime victory by L.S.U. The Tigers struggled offensively in that game. Some of their best offensive plays in the second half were option rushes by Jefferson. Alabama linebackers Dont'a Hightower and Courtney Upshaw are expected to be chosen in the first two rounds of the N.F.L. draft and will be the key to slowing Jefferson on the ground.

An ultra-low budget, ultra-poorly reviewed horror movie, ''The Devil Inside,'' kicked Tom Cruise out of the top slot at the North American box office over the weekend. ''The Devil Inside,'' acquired by Paramount Pictures for $1 million, was a strong No. 1, taking in an estimated $34.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. That surprisingly robust result, attributed largely to an aggressive online marketing campaign, reinforces Paramount's status as the current kingpin of the horror genre, which has sagged of late with the exception of the studio's ''Paranormal Activity'' franchise. But don't expect ''The Devil Inside'' to have a long life in theaters: Buzz quickly turned negative over the weekend, with the exit polling company CinemaScore giving the film an F grade.

The Beliefs column on Dec. 24, about a longstanding boycott against the Salvation Army over its opposition to homosexuality, referred imprecisely to its use of lobbyists. While the Salvation Army's national office does not employ registered lobbyists, some of the organization's local units have done so.

Because of an editing error, a report in the college basketball roundup in some editions on Friday described DePaul's 84-81 men's victory over Pittsburgh incorrectly. The game ended in regulation time, not in overtime. (The headline also included the error in some copies.)

8 P.M. (Sho2) THE KING'S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, left, in an Oscar-winning role, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps him conquer his debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Bertie's wife and staunch support system, who can't quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorcée who derails Bertie's older brother, David (Guy Pearce), from his position as Edward VIII. ''It isn't exactly 'Pygmalion,' not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie's biggest draws,'' Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which earned Mr. Hooper an Oscar as best director. ''Each character has his moments, instances when Bertie the closed book tentatively opens and Logue's arrogance gets away from him, but both are too decent, too banal and the film too ingratiating to resonate deeply.'' In the end, she added, ''like many entertainments of this pop-historical type, 'The King's Speech' wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.'' The film also received Academy Awards for best picture and original screenplay (David Seidler). 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELOR Ben Flajnik, a 29-year-old winemaker from Sonoma, Calif., takes the 18 remaining bachelorettes on an exploration of his hometown vineyards. Two of the women receive one-on-one dates with Mr. Flajnik, while the others must show him another side of their personalities in auditions for a community-theater production written by children.

If that enormous White Star liner had made port on her maiden voyage that year, 1912 would probably have been known by generations of New Yorkers as the year of the great Equitable disaster. The world seemed to end in fire and ice on Jan. 9, 1912, when the ''city's first skyscraper'' - as The New York Times called it - erupted like a sumptuous Second Empire volcano on lower Broadway. Horse-drawn fire trucks clattered to the scene from around Manhattan and thundered to the island over the Brooklyn Bridge, but to no avail, as temperatures dipped to 16 degrees and winds gusted up to 68 miles an hour. Water was turned to spray, spray was turned to ice and soon the equipment and then the enormous structure itself were turned into fantastic frozen sculptures.

MAAS--Elyse Goldman, died peacefully at her home on January 7, 2012. She was born in 1921 and raised in Baltimore. A sixty year resident of Scarsdale, she was involved in various local service organizations and was a founding member of Westchester Reform Temple. Her greatest pride and achievement, however, were her three children, Louis Thalheimer, Elizabeth Wachs, and Marjorie Coleman, seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY on Monday, January 9 at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to CASA of Westchester, (Court Appointed Special Advocate) 580 White Plains Road, Tarrytown, NY 10591, where she volunteered for many years, or to White Plains Hospital in White Plains NY.

But the 2012 Republican presidential contest will not proceed in a straight line, evenly spaced out over the next six months. Rather, it is broken up into different phases, each of which will have its own, interesting political dynamic that will affect how the candidates campaign, how they hoard their cash and how they travel. Mitt Romney's lead in New Hampshire - he is ahead of his nearest competitor,Ron Paul, by 20 points in most polls - may prove decisive. Consecutive Romney victories in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina would be unprecedented for a Republican candidate, and could prompt the others to drop out quickly. But if that does not happen, the fight could drag out for months.

Carven's Guillaume Henry was looking at Diane Arbus photographs from the 1960s for inspiration for his prefall collection. "Ordinary people looking extraordinary," said Henry about his muse: a very specific suburban girl who rides the subway in the early morning, is moody, makes her own clothes (or wears her mother's) and wants to look pretty but can only afford synthetic shoes. Hence, the plastic tortoise kitten heels, the fabrics that make references to shag carpets and couches (her only resources) and the jackets made of a leather that's washed to look faux (she's just not that fancy). "She's sweet looking but not dull," Henry said. And she has a terrific, intuitive sense of style, one that doesn't require money. Here, because he likes "calm, strong, happy colors with metallics," is a yellow shearling jacket and skirt look paired with the coolest metallic pumps and matching camera bag. Anything but dull, indeed.
