But what makes Gurung the next generation's red carpet go-to for the avant-garde (Rooney Mara, Jessica Chastain) is his ability to imprint himself on traditional fabrics and textures.

In the course of the 2000s, under a tax-cutting, business-friendly Republican administration, middle class paychecks grew much more slowly than the economy as a whole, upward mobility for the poor continued to lag behind parts of Western Europe, and the combination of unfunded tax cuts and deficit spending worsened the country's fiscal picture just as the Baby Boomers were poised to retire. Then came the financial crisis, touched off in part by gross recklessness on Wall Street. Then came the Great Recession, which threw millions of Americans out of work, hit downscale workers much harder than it did the college-educated, and sent the deficit spiraling upward to unprecedented heights.

Our colleagues at Bucks report on a provocative idea floated by a man from Boulder, Colo., who suggested, in a letter published in The Wall Street Journal, that insurance companies refuse to pay claims for accidents caused by texting. But industry representatives reached by Bucks said that the proposal may be a nonstarter. Read more at Bucks »

According to a partial list compiled by Dan Kois for The New York Times Magazine, moviegoers at 3-D films last year had Captain America's shield, Justin Bieber's hand and 40 partly chewed bean buns flung at them in stereoscopic illusions. This year, audiences can get ready to guard their laps against Cirque du Soleil acrobats who appear to be flying off the screen: Paramount said on Tuesday that it had acquired the distribution rights for a new 3-D movie about that Montreal-based circus troupe, written and directed by Andrew Adamson (of the "Shrek" and "Narnia" franchises) and produced by, among others, James Cameron (a filmmaker who knows a thing or two about 3-D movies). The film, called "Cirque du Soleil Worlds Away," will feature performances from various shows presented by the troupe. Rob Moore, the vice chairman of Paramount, said in a statement that it will also include "a timeless original story written especially for this movie." The studio said "Cirque du Soleil Worlds Away" is planned for worldwide release later this year.

Soft round shapes, softer tie-neck blouses and clean, pleated dresses in even softer dusty colors star in Clare Waight Keller's second collection for Chloé. Paired with all of these pretty, work-ready clothes are accessories that look just as beautiful and uncomplicated, like glossy slip-in ankle boots and slipper-front pumps - and there's a new bag, Lucy, a slim three-pocket with zipper closures that comes in multiple colorways and fabrics, with leather handles or a chain strap. The check version of the bag is shown here with cropped pants, a brushed wool plaid coat and this editor's favorite new flat: an emerald green loafer embellished with metal-tipped fringe.

If you were trying to get the college football system torn up and thrown out, you couldn't have orchestrated the end of this season any more persuasively. Yes, Alabama took all the drama out of who should be No. 1 with its 21-0 victory over thought-to-be-unbeatable Louisiana State Monday night, but what a small victory that turned out to be. It capped the year of Jerry Sandusky and Joe Paterno's fall, of Ohio State's probation forming the other big rapids in a raging river of ethical failures and misplaced priorities. It came at the end of a string of uninspired, made-for-bad-TV bowls, played so far after the season ended that even the major players needed name tags. And the finale was a conference rematch about as attractive as a Kris Humphries-Kim Kardashian reunion.

"This prefall collection is all about the best of Givenchy," the house designer Ricardo Tisci said at yesterday's presentation. Inserting a mix of what Tisci named "American 1950s housewife" and "French '70s style" into "the best of our men's, women's and couture," he delivered a look that is all tough and refined and, literally, ready to wear now and for seasons to come. Hits include pieces featuring a subtle paillette print, a herringbone and cashmere suit, wool jackets stiffened with men's fabrications, then wrapped in places with the softest organza, and this expertly tailored croc-trimmed tuxedo. Worth noting also are the collection's elongating boots, furry baseball caps and sharp talon ear studs (see: editors swooning).

Suzie Gilbert, a friend and neighbor, has for many years been a hard-working bird rehabilitator, a career described beautifully in her recent book "Flyaway." She also recently launched a blog, The Crooked Wing, and alerted me to a post on a remarkable occurrence last month in Utah, when thousands of migrating eared grebes, evidently disoriented by a storm, began crash landing on roads, parking lots and the like -- surfaces they apparently mistook for water. They can only take flight from water, making such landings a death sentence for those that survived the impact.

In an article published on Christmas Day in The New York Times, I described specific elements of the mysterious Academic Index, a tool used by Ivy League institutions - and increasingly other colleges and universities - to measure the basic academic qualifications of recruited athletes. The Academic Index, created in the 1980s and never disclosed publicly by the institutions themselves, uses a formula that assigns each recruit a number based on his or her standardized tests scores and high school grade point average.

BUENOS AIRES - Last week, I took a look at President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner's cancer diagnosis and how she has personalized power far too much. On Saturday, Argentinians were stunned to learn that, after removing the president's thyroid gland, doctors discovered she didn't have cancer after all but rather a benign tumor. Following the initial relief, doubts quickly set in: despite assurances that such misdiagnoses can happen, many Kirchner critics cited the episode as another example of why the government's words can't be trusted.

In Amsterdam, which claims to have the greatest number of museums per square mile in the world, few topics are left unexplored. There is a museum that delves into sex, another on war (or at least the Dutch resistance), and a museum dedicated, of course, to marijuana. JOHANNESBURG - Africa's oldest liberation movement, the African National Congress (A.N.C.), held a lavish birthday bash last weekend to celebrate its founding 100 years ago. More than 40 heads of state gathered in the small church in the small city of Bloemfontein, the A.N.C.'s birthplace, to celebrate the party's role in defeating white-minority rule and apartheid. And deservedly: the A.N.C.'s accomplishments as a liberation movement are extraordinary.

MULLIGAN--Thomas Sr. Passed away peacefully surrounded by loved ones on January 5, 2012. He is predeceased by his wife Geraldine, who passed away in 2010 and his first wife Mary, who passed in 1971. Devoted father of Neil and Thomas Jr. Treasured by his granddaughters, Casey, Julia, Liv and Emma as well as many nephews and nieces. Thomas was a graduate of St. John's University and was the middle of three children from Olyphant, PA. He is survived by his loving sister Margaret Stone. He was predeceased by his brother Joseph. Thomas was a WWII Veteran in the Coast Guard and worked 43 years in the Financial Department of The New York Times. After retiring, he enjoyed traveling and spending time with his family and friends. He was aboard the Queen Mary II for its' maiden voyage, kissed the Blarney Stone in Ireland and went to Pasadena, California to watch his football Giants win Superbowl XXI. He lived life to the fullest. After losing his wife in 2010, Thomas moved into the home of his son Neil and daughter-in-law Sandra. The entire Mulligan family cannot express their appreciation enough to Sandra for all her expert care and compassion. Dr. Sandra spent her days caring for her patients in the hospital and her nights caring for her father-in-law. Visitation will be from 4-8pm, Wednesday, January 11 at John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ. A Mass of Catholic Burial will be at 10am, Thursday January 12, at The Church of the Nativity, 180 Ridge Rd., Fair Haven, NJ.

In a terse four words, the Supreme Court on Monday issued an order upholding prohibitions against foreigners making contributions to influence American elections. The decision clamped shut an opening that some thought the court had created two years ago in its Citizens United decision, when it relaxed campaign-finance limits on corporations and labor unions. On Monday the Supreme Court, upholding a lower court's decision in Bluman, et al., v. Federal Election Commission, refused to extend its reasoning in Citizens United to cover foreigners living temporarily here.

Just when we were finally getting used to the fact that there's going to be a James Bond movie called ''Skyfall,'' Paul McCartney has announced the title of his album of pop standards. And that title, he announced on Monday, is ''Kisses on the Bottom.'' We'll give you a moment to contemplate that. Ready to continue? O.K. Mr. McCartney, who is not a Jewish grandparent but is an admirer of Fats Waller, explained on his Web site that the album title was a reference to Waller's 1930s hit ''I'm Gonna Sit Right Down and Write Myself a Letter,'' and not to any other ''anatomical interpretation'' suggested by ''those who have historically subjected his every move to microscopic scrutiny.''

A few days after the White House made clear that President Obama intended to spend much of 2012 pounding Congress as an obstacle to progress, Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, posed a question via Twitter. ''If POTUS runs 'against Congress' how does he explain D controlled Senate?'' asked Mr. Cornyn, who is chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, the organization charged with electing Republicans to the Senate.

CAIRO -- At first Samira Ibrahim was afraid to tell her father that Egyptian soldiers had detained her in Tahrir Square in Cairo, stripped off her clothes, and watched as she was forcibly subjected to a ''virginity test.'' But when her father, a religious conservative, saw electric prod marks on her body, they revived memories of his own detention and torture under President Hosni Mubarak's government. ''History is repeating itself,'' he told her, and together they vowed to file a court case against the military rulers, to claim ''my rights,'' as Ms. Ibrahim later recalled.

MANCHESTER, N.H. - The 2012 primary campaign has been by far the most volatile on record, with one candidate after another surging to the front of the pack and then falling back again. Although this might seem self-evident, it can also be quantified. The Times's FiveThirtyEight blog has developed a measure of poll volatility that calculates how much a candidate's polling shifted month to month, above and beyond random variance. Since 1984, when primary polling became widespread, the candidates with the three highest volatility scores have been Newt Gingrich, Rick Perry, and Herman Cain, all of whom ran this year.

DERRY, N.H. -- Rick Santorum said Monday that comments he made last week in Iowa about food stamps that some construed as racially charged were the result of his having been tongue-tied and were not a reference to black people. Moreover, he said he has done more in black communities ''than any Republican in recent memory.''

TANNE--Sol, 88, died January 9, 2012 of complications following a hip fracture. A native New Yorker, Sol became a Renaissance man. Born on the Lower East Side on May 30, 1923, the son of Louis and Esther (Weiss) Tanne, Sol graduated from a neighborhood yeshiva, Stuyvesant High School, and Cooper Union, where his electrical engineering studies were interrupted by service in the US Navy in the South Pacific. After completing his degree, Sol became an international management consultant based in New York and then Rotterdam, The Netherlands, where his firm specialized in industrial automation and the movement of goods within factories and between ship and shore. On his return to New York he became a member of The Commodity Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange, where he served as vice-chairman and chaired many committees. He also helped found Purvis Systems Incorporated of Middletown, RI, a technology company specializing in communication systems for public safety and the defense industry. Although Sol was a scholar of Judaism, an athlete, a dancer, and a yoga leader, art was his major interest outside work. He studied sculpture at the Rotterdam Art Academy. In New York he painted portraits, figures, and still lifes in watercolor, oil, acrylic, and pastel. He was a life member of the Art Students League. His pastels have been exhibited at the National Arts Club and published in "Sol Tanne: Artist." Sol is survived by his wife of 43 years, the medical journalist Janice Hopkins Tanne; his nieces Jeanette Eisenmesser (Stanley) and Rita Osak. Services on Thursday at 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

It took thieves all of seven minutes to slip in through a balcony door and steal paintings by Picasso and Mondrian from the National Art Gallery in Athens on Monday, Tthe Associated Press reported. The police said that the burglars intentionally set off alarms Sunday evening to lure guards into disabling a sensor in the museum. One alarm did subsequently go off, but the guards arrived too late to catch a thief. The works stolen were a cubist female bust by Picasso with a dedication that read ''in homage to the Greek people'' for their resistance to Nazi occupiers during World War II, a representational painting of a riverside windmill dated 1905 by Mondrian and a pen-and-ink drawing of St. Diego de Alcala by the 16th-century painter Guglielmo Caccia. A second painting by Mondrian was cut out of its frame but dropped as the thieves fled.

Already, the benches in gym locker rooms and beside basketball courts are filling with 2012's early casualties, those of us who, goaded by New Year's resolutions, are exercising a bit too enthusiastically and developing sore muscles. Many of us will then drape ice packs over our aching muscles. But a new review article published this month in the journal Sports Medicine suggests that for sore muscles, ice is not always the panacea that most of us believe it to be and that, in some instances, it can be counterproductive. For the study, researchers at the University of Ulster and University of Limerick in Ireland reviewed almost three dozen earlier studies of the effects of using ice to combat sore muscles, a practice that many who exercise often employ. Ice is, after all, the ''I'' in the acronym RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation), which remains the standard first-aid protocol for dealing with a sports-related injury. Icing is also widely used to deal with muscles that twinge but aren't formally injured. Watch almost any football, basketball or soccer game, at any level, and you'll likely see many of the players icing body parts during halftime, preparing to return to play.

Leo was a true gentleman, a caring dentist and a man of great character. His sweet, gentle strength, devotion to family, kindness, wisdom and integrity will remain in our hearts forever.

Fueled by Tim Tebow mania and capped by Tebow's 80-yard game-winning touchdown pass on the first play of overtime, the broadcast of the Denver Broncos' 29-23 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers produced huge ratings for CBS on Sunday. According to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates it was the highest-rated National Football League wild-card playoff game in 24 years and CBS averaged nearly 42 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour. Later in the night the two-hour series premiere of NBC's ''The Firm'' struggled mightily out of the gate. It averaged 6.3 million viewers and was the lowest-rated regular-season drama debut ever for NBC in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. But it wasn't all bad news for the other networks. On ABC ''Once Upon a Time'' reversed its recent decline and returned strongly after a short holiday hiatus with 10.3 million viewers, accompanied by its best rating among viewers 18 to 49 since mid-November.

Tony Iommi, 63, the lead guitarist for Black Sabbath, has lymphoma and will undergo treatment in London, according to a statement posted on his Web site on Monday. The news of Mr. Iommi's illness came as the original members of that British heavy metal band are writing and recording their first album together in 33 years. The statement said the other band members from the first lineup -- the vocalist Ozzy Osbourne, the bassist Terry Butler and the drummer Bill Ward -- would travel to London to finish the record, which they had been working on at a Los Angeles studio with the producer Rick Rubin. ''Iommi is working with his doctors to establish the best treatment plan -- the 'Iron Man' of Rock 'n' Roll remains upbeat and determined to make a full and successful recovery,'' the statement read. No details about the condition of Mr. Iommi, above, were released. It was unclear if a tour scheduled for later this year would proceed as planned. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
MEISTER--Bert, MD. We think about you on your birthday and all the other days as well. We miss and love you now and always. Arlene, Lynn and Barbara

LAS VEGAS - Last year, Intel began talking about a new category of superthin notebook computers called the Ultrabook. At this year's International Consumer Electronics Show, the company, the world's biggest maker of computer chips, made it clear that it planned to pour a lot of money and effort into turning Ultrabooks into the next big computing phenomenon. Ultrabooks are essentially an effort to bring to notebooks based on Microsoft's Windows operating system the lightweight, thin design of Apple's MacBook Air, a machine with the thickness of a short stack of papers. Intel knows a lot about the MacBook Air because it supplies the chips that run Apple's product, but the company wants the much larger market of Windows-based notebooks to embrace the style of the Apple device, too.

MANCHESTER, N.H. -- For weeks this winter, as Newt Gingrich's presidential hopes faltered under the weight of millions of dollars in attack ads paid for by backers of Mitt Romney, a small group of Gingrich supporters quietly lobbied for help from one of the richest men in America: Sheldon Adelson, a billionaire casino owner and Mr. Gingrich's longtime friend and patron. Mr. Romney's supporters were also calling, imploring Mr. Adelson to stay out of the race.

Bernie Williams was the first homegrown core Yankee from the recent championship seasons to appear on the Hall of Fame ballot. The election results announced Monday were not encouraging. Williams, the Yankees' center fielder from 1991 through 2006, received only 55 votes among the 573 ballots cast by the Baseball Writers' Association of America. Williams will remain on the ballot for at least another year, but with just 9.6 percent of the vote, he is a long way from the 75 percent needed for induction.

An article on Saturday about Rick Santorum's no-holds-barred political style described incorrectly an event in which he engaged in a heated discussion about same-sex marriage. It was a nonpartisan gathering called College Convention 2012 -- not a group called ''College Republicans.'' And because of an editing error, the article also misstated part of the name of a professional wrestling organization for which Mr. Santorum once lobbied. It is the World Wrestling Federation, not the World Wrestling Foundation.

So often, political art makes us feel that the cure is as bad as the disease. Didactic, self-righteous and smug, full of easy slogans, this sort of art leaves people just as boxed in as the systems it supposedly critiques. When enduring such work, it can seem impossible that art could have anything to say to politics and still maintain its integrity, still offer us another way of seeing the world and being in it. It takes an encounter with an artist like Rabih Mroue to remember that this isn't true, that art can do whatever it wants to do.

Thierry Henry returned to his longtime club Arsenal and scored the only goal Monday in a 1-0 win against visiting Leeds United in the third round of the F.A. Cup. Henry, who has rejoined Arsenal on a two-month loan from the Red Bulls, began the match on the bench. He received an ovation merely for warming up at the start of the second half. When he finally entered the match, in the 68th minute, the crowd roared its approval. Ten minutes later, he controlled a slicing pass on the left side of the penalty area with a deft touch, then curled a low shot past goalkeeper Andrew Lonergan and inside the far post. More at nytimes.com/goal.

The investigation into MF Global is intensifying as federal authorities unearth new details and confront potential obstacles in their hunt for roughly $1.2 billion in customer money that disappeared from the brokerage firm. While prosecutors and regulators have jointly conducted dozens of depositions with former and current employees, a senior official in the Chicago office of MF Global recently declined to meet with the federal authorities, people briefed on the investigation said.

An article on Saturday about job statistics for December described the data incorrectly at one point. It showed a rate of 8.5 percent for unemployment, not for employment. The article also referred incorrectly to the historical significance of high unemployment during presidential elections. Franklin D. Roosevelt was twice re-elected with a jobless rate higher than 8.5 percent; it is not the case that no sitting president has won re-election with a jobless rate that high.

HENNIKER, N.H. - Untold numbers of New Hampshire voters have tried to get a few words with the Republican presidential candidates barnstorming their state. But it's likely that Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is the only one with whom some have conversed in Chinese. At his campaign stops, people young and old have approached Mr. Huntsman with a chipper ''Ni hao'' (hello) or ''Ni hao ma'' (how are you). Some have waded through the gauntlet of television cameras to tell Mr. Huntsman, the former ambassador to China, about their trip to Beijing, their dining experiences in Hong Kong or their son's college semester in Shanghai.

ALBANY - A special election to replace former State Senator Carl Kruger will be held on March 20, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday. Mr. Kruger, a Democrat, resigned last month just before tearfully pleading guilty to corruption charges. His party has a significant enrollment advantage in his south Brooklyn district, but Republicans are eying his seat because of the success of Representative Bob Turner in a special Congressional election last fall.
An article on Monday about the travails of a daily newspaper in South Sudan misstated, in some copies, the year that the country gained independence. It was in 2011, not ''this year.''

The results are in from a yearlong feasibility study commissioned by the City of Helsinki and undertaken by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum to examine the possibility of building a Guggenheim Museum in Finland. The study concluded that such a project would significantly increase Helsinki's efforts to become a cultural capital. Among the recommendations: to build the museum on a city-owned site on Helsinki's South Harbor waterfront; to have an international architecture competition to decide who should design the building; to create a midsize museum of about 129,000 square feet, with 42,000 square feet of exhibition space; and to set it up largely as a noncollecting institution. The estimated cost would be around $178 million. Richard Armstrong, director of the Guggenheim Foundation, said of the study's results: ''It's one of those courtship moments when you look at one another and say let's see how we can complement each other. It's a big next step.'' The study is now in the hands of the City Board and the City Council of Helsinki, which will review the material over the next few weeks and decide whether to proceed. If they do then they will begin an architectural competition. In a telephone interview, Mayor Jussi Pajunen called the study ''very valuable.''

KAU--Nicholas James Peter April 15, 1990 - January 10, 2009 "It is a woe 'too deep for tears,' when all Is reft at once, when some surpassing Spirit Whose light adorned the world around it, leaves Those who remain behind, not sobs or groans, The passionate tumult of a clinging hope; But pale despair and cold tranquillity, Nature's vast frame, and web of human things, Birth and the grave, that are not as they were." We honor him by the Nicholas J.P. Kau Fund for Shakespeare and Wrestling, at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 St., New York 10024. Elizabeth Olmsted, Randall Kau, Andrew Kau, and Timothy Kau

TUNCER--Kaya. We mourn the loss of a beloved member of our Board of Directors, Kaya Tuncer, Chairman of ESBAS (The Aegean Free Zone) located in Izmir, Turkey. A pioneering Turkish-American entrepreneur and philanthropist, Mr. Tuncer was an ardent contributor to education and U.S.-Turkish friendship, especially with his organization, and our partner, Global Friendship Through Space Education, which brought youths from around the world to Space Camp Turkey. We will remember him with fondness and gratitude and cherish his memory by continuing to support his vision of strong ties between our two countries. Our thoughts are with his family, friends and colleagues. The American Turkish Society

Steve Murphy's living room was a harsh turf. There was no rug, only a slice of cold linoleum glued to a concrete floor - hard as Lambeau Field, the Green Bay Packers' tundra, on an icy afternoon. We wore elbow pads and kneepads and kept the windows wide open to minimize the chances of breaking one. When the football sailed through one after a bad throw, it was a beautiful thing to watch - the spiraling ball taking a sweet, long ride. We'd hang from the second story windowsill and slip down to the street to get the ball. It was just another play.We got away with it because Mr. and Mrs. Murphy never got home before 6. Besides, where else could we go? We had no backyards, and it was the 1960s in New York City - we were barely allowed to ride the subways by ourselves, and grass fields were scarce. But I loved the sport. I carried my football everywhere, just in case anyone wanted to play catch. I slept with it to prevent fumbling. And even more important, I loved the New York Giants. The "ny" on their helmets was tattooed on my heart. It's no wonder that - 35 years after the team moved to the Meadowlands in New Jersey - they're still called the New York Giants.

Of all the domestic policy differences between the Bush and Obama administrations, just about the sharpest and most telling may be their opposite responses to the drive by Republican-dominated states to require voters to present photo identification at the polls. The Bush administration thought photo ID was a dandy idea. The Obama administration recognizes it for what it is: a cynical effort to insure that fewer young people and members of minority groups (read, likely Democratic voters) are able to cast a ballot.

But "The Tree of Life," Terrence Malick's film that incorporates the formation of the universe into the tale of one Texas family, has awards prognosticators taking notice of its nontraditional visual techniques. MOSCOW - A documentary video has just gone viral in Russia. A man and a woman - he a political activist, she a radio reporter - videotaped themselves entering an auditorium they say is located in Moscow's State University of Transportation. It is a weekend day during winter break, and the room is full. About 50 young people - presumably students at the university, though this is never made clear - are seated at desks, with stacks of papers in front of them. Hundreds of completed forms sit on a long desk at the front of the auditorium. During the nearly seven minutes that the recording lasts, the man and woman keep asking: "What are you doing?" They never get an answer and in the end are forcibly removed from the premises.

If it's your job to plan the touring schedule of rebellious rock, hip-hop and country musicians, you might consider organizing future itineraries to avoid the Sierra Blanca highway checkpoint near El Paso. It was there, The Associated Press reported, that the rapper Snoop Dogg was arrested on Saturday for a misdemeanor drug charge, which might not be newsworthy in and of itself, except that Willie Nelson was busted at that same border crossing in 2010. In the case of Snoop Dogg, the hip-hop star was done in by a real snoop dog, which sniffed out some marijuana cigarettes on his tour bus after a border agent smelled pot on the vehicle. A little more than two ounces of the drug were turned up, The A.P. said, and the rapper, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, was cited for possession of drug paraphernalia and released. Judge Becky Dean-Walker of Hudspeth County told The A.P. that these cases are usually resolved by a no-contest plea and a mailed-in fine of up to $500.

BLACK--Lawrence E. "Larry", born September 5, 1926 , NJ, died, age 84, January 11, 2011, New York City. Son of Anna Sveda and John Czarnecki; leaves wife, Rachel Aline Black (nee Amsellem), married 54 years; daughters Suzanne A. Black and Lorelei Vargas (Marcos), their child, Magghi Mae; sister/ niece, Harriet/Deb DeLuca. Tuck School/Dartmouth College, MBA, 1952; NYU, BA, 1950. US Navy Pharmacy Mate WWII, International businessman. Worked with USAID and NGO's Prolific writer, resounding political orator, spoke his truth - even in the face of opposition, charming, brilliant, witty, generous, a true intellectual. In retirement Professor of Economics. Lived on Central Park West for 50 years, walked his dog, Waldo, in Central Park and loved apple pie, Zabar's. Contributions in his Honor for students in need: Touro Business College, 27 W. 23 St, NYC, NY, 10010.

GERENA--Joseph G. Christmas Day 1949 to January 7, 2012. Joe's gift to us was a perfect soundtrack to life that masterfully blended wit, enthusiasm, and a thirst for knowledge that he shared happily and freely. Joe didn't know a little about a lot of things; he knew a lot about almost everything. He spoke everyone's language and had no acquaintances, only friends. Joseph G. Gerena Fine Art was where his passion lived, and where so many discovered his gift. He leaves his wife Marge Levin, stepdaughter Alexis Katz, and adored grandson Marcus Mooney. He was the son of Gilberto Gerena-Valentin and the late Francia Luban and leaves his sisters Marielia and Gilmari Gerena-Riquelme. A memorial service is being planned.

On Monday, the United States Education Department put New York State on notice for failing to reach some of the goals it set in its application for the federal Race to the Top education program. On Tuesday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo narrowed the target, laying the blame squarely on school districts and teachers' unions for failing to compromise. The sides have not yet agreed on the parameters of an evaluation system that the state promised to adopt, potentially jeopardizing the roughly $700 million it was awarded through the program.

Following the lead of its larger rival HBO, Showtime is beginning to broaden access to an Internet service that lets its subscribers stream hundreds of television episodes and feature films. The service, called Showtime Anytime, was turned on for Verizon FiOS customers on Tuesday, and will be extended to several other cable and satellite distributors later this year. Already available for Comcast and AT&T U-verse customers, and now available for the first time on the iPad, it is part of a push toward subscriber-only streaming.

BLUTMAN--Max S.,lived until the age of 93. Born in Brooklyn, he married his elementary school sweetheart, Edna, served as a bombardier and translator in WWII, and sold plastics at Pantasote. Despite his humble roots, he had a brilliant mind, conversed fluently in all of the romance languages, and wrote hundreds of funny, self-deprecating poems for family on birthdays. He will be greatly missed by his two daughters, son, five grandchildren, and brother Bernie, who all adored him.

The Los Angeles Dodgers and Fox Sports reached a deal on Tuesday that would end their litigation over the sale of the team's television rights after the 2013 season. The agreement, which must be approved by the federal bankruptcy judge hearing the team's Chapter 11 filing, would end the team's pursuit of plans to market its TV rights before Fox's exclusive negotiating period to extend its current deal ends Nov. 30.

STAYING INDEPENDENT The online health company WebMD said on Tuesday that it had taken itself off the auction block, after failing to attract satisfactory offers from potential buyers. The company also said its chief executive, Wayne T. Gattinella, had resigned. He is being succeeded on an interim basis by Anthony Vuolo, the company's chief financial officer, while the board looks for a permanent successor.

Given the Bloomberg administration's continued push to have the city become more hospitable to bicyclists, it should come as little surprise that the TD Five Boro Bike Tour has grown in popularity - almost to its own detriment. Last year, the registration period lasted all of 24 hours, freezing out many who had wanted to participate. And once the event began, about 3,000 riders were stranded for hours in a major bicyclist bottleneck on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

BUMSTED--William Joseph, died peacefully at his home in John's Island, Vero Beach, Florida on January 5, 2012. Deeply loved by his family, he is survived by his wife Gloria, his children from his late wife, Nancy: David Wentz Bumsted (Heather), Martha B. Zipp (Brian), two step-children Alexandra and Lloyd Nimetz, and five grandchildren: Phoebe and David Bumsted, Jr; William Bumsted O'Hearn, Elena and Jack Zipp. A 1940 graduate of Dartmouth College and a member of "the greatest generation," Mr. Bumsted served in the Pacific in the Army. He was born May 25, 1919 and started work at the international insurance brokerage firm Johnson and Higgins the day after Pearl Harbor. He became President of the Venezuelan office and later a Partner of the firm in New York, leading the International and Marine Cargo departments. An avid golfer, Mr. Bumsted was a member of Baltusrol and Pine Valley as well as the John's Island Club, and for many years the Lake Placid Club. He was President of the Lake Placid Educational Foundation and was active in the community of Lake Placid, NY, his spiritual home. An astute businessman with a keen wit and love for people, he captured the hearts of all whom he encountered. Filled with joy and goodness he has left each of us a better person. A service will be held at 1pm on Thursday, January 12, 2012 at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Vero Beach. Memorials may be made to the VNA of Vero Beach, Florida or the SOA of Lake Placid, New York.

An article on Tuesday about Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino owner who is supporting Newt Gingrich's candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, misstated Mr. Gingrich's place of finish in the Iowa caucuses. He came in fourth, not fifth. (Gov. Rick Perry of Texas was fifth.) The article also misstated the year that a Supreme Court decision paved the way for ''Super PACs'' to spend money to support candidates while being independent of their campaigns. The ruling was in 2010, not in 2011.

Miguel Batista pitched the final game of the 2011 season for the Mets, beating Cincinnati, 3-0, at age 40 to become the oldest pitcher in franchise history to throw a shutout. Now Batista will try to see what he can do for the Mets at 41. Batista has signed with them for the 2012 season; his role has yet to be determined. Batista primarily pitched for St. Louis last season before being released in June. For the Mets, he was 2-0 with a 2.64 earned run average in nine appearances in September.

Besides Yonkers and Albany, Greenburgh 11 -- not Greenburgh -- in Westchester County has yet to do so.

Because of an editing error, the Off the Menu column last Wednesday contained an outdated reference to Alex Volland, an owner of the new restaurant Barrio 47. He is no longer a partner in the restaurant Paradou. Also because of an editing error, the column misidentified the Manhattan neighborhood where the original branch of the restaurant Blue Smoke is located; it is west of Kips Bay, not in it.

According to a partial list compiled by Dan Kois for The New York Times Magazine, moviegoers at 3-D films last year had Captain America's shield, Justin Bieber's hand and 40 partly chewed bean buns flung at them in stereoscopic illusions. This year, audiences can get ready to guard their laps against Cirque du Soleil acrobats who appear to be flying off the screen: Paramount said on Tuesday that it had acquired the distribution rights for a new 3-D movie about that Montreal-based circus troupe, written and directed by Andrew Adamson (of the ''Shrek'' and ''Narnia'' franchises) and produced by, among others, James Cameron (a filmmaker who knows a thing or two about 3-D movies). The film, called ''Cirque du Soleil Worlds Away,'' will feature performances from various shows presented by the troupe. Rob Moore, the vice chairman of Paramount, said in a statement that it will also include ''a timeless original story written especially for this movie.'' The studio said ''Cirque du Soleil Worlds Away'' is planned for worldwide release later this year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

INDIANAPOLIS -- The Colts' uncharacteristically wretched season -- the perennial N.F.L. playoff contenders finished 2-14 -- has dimmed some of the luster of the first Super Bowl to be played here, on Feb. 5. But residents can take some consolation from a mini-building boom in anticipation of the big game, with its 150,000 expected visitors and worldwide television audience. The centerpiece is a 1,000-room J. W. Marriott hotel, a 34-story swoosh of Colts-blue glass that will serve as media headquarters. And the city will spend a total of $187 million on infrastructure like bridges, sidewalks, streets and parks. For fans there is Tailgate Town, a winter playground with a turf field, interactive games and an 80-foot-high zip line. It will connect to the Indiana Convention Center, where the league will have the 800,000-square-foot N.F.L. Experience fan festival.

The Disruptions column on Monday, about so-called dynamic pricing, which raises prices when demand is highest, referred incompletely to the practices of Uber, a company that allows people to reserve car service through a smartphone app. While the app does not show the total fare in dollars when customers book a ride, Uber did show a ''surge pricing'' multiple to customers booking rides for New Year's Eve. It is not the case that Uber's customers were never informed of the pricing policy for that night.

SAN FRANCISCO - Google's popularity was built on its ability to help people find just the right Web pages. Then came the social Web, led by Facebook, where people go to see vast amounts of material that has largely been off-limits to Google - conversations and photos posted by their friends. On Tuesday, Google sparked controversy when it made some of the biggest changes ever to its search results, adding content from its fledgling Google Plus social network. That includes posts, photos, profiles and conversations from Google Plus that are public or were shared privately with the person searching.

8 P.M. (13, 49) KANGAROO MOB In the last 50 years, the population of eastern gray kangaroos around Canberra, the capital of Australia, has multiplied from a few hundred to tens of thousands. Forced to search for food beyond the city's drought-stricken hills, the hungry creatures have moved into urban territory, dining on parkland and lawns -- and dying by the thousands in run-ins with cars. That has led the government to reduce herds through extermination, prompting an emotional backlash. This ''Nature'' episode follows a gang of street-wise kangaroos to reveal how they survive in the city. Among them are Black Spot, above, at more than 6 feet tall the mob's dominant male and the father of most of the joeys in his group, and Madge, who teaches her son Sonny about survival among humans while carrying a nursing joey named Alice in her pouch. The program also ponders the prospect of relocating kangaroo herds or controlling their numbers through forced contraception. 11 A.M. (MoreMax) OUT OF AFRICA (1985) Meryl Streep earned her sixth best-actress Oscar nomination as the Danish writer Karen Blixen, who later published under the name Isak Dinesen, in this sweeping drama about her life on a coffee plantation in British East Africa, now Kenya, for which Sydney Pollack won for best director; the film won best picture. Klaus Maria Brandauer was also nominated for his role as Baron Bror Blixen, her Swedish-born cousin and husband. Robert Redford plays Denys Finch Hatton, the love of her life.

KOENIG--Dr. Leonard Eli, much loved husband, father, grandfather, and great grandfather, in Los Angeles of natural causes on Sunday, January 8, 2012. He was 97. Len was born May 25, 1914 on Selwin Avenue in the Bronx, NY to Oscar and Becky Koenig from Strch, Austria. He had one sister, Helen. Len graduated from Indiana University in 1937 with a BA in science and math, then attended Colombia University Dental School where he graduated in 1942 with honors. He went on to complete a residency at New York Hospital for Joint Diseases, and opened his own practice in 1946. On April 11, 1948 Len married the love of his life, Pauline Ladin, a French teacher at Hunter College. Dr. Koenig served in the Korean War, and was stationed at Fort Sam Houston and later at Fort Bragg. Leonard and Pauline had two daughters, Carole June Koenig, May 2, 1952, and Phyllis Ann Koenig, September 22, 1955. The family moved to Dumont, New Jersey in 1957 to raise the girls. There they lived a life fully engaged, with extended family always at hand and yearly trips with their daughters each summer. Their joy came from sharing and being with family and friends. Despite always saying that parents shouldn't chase their kids, they broke their own rule and moved to California to be near their daughters in 1984. They lived in Leisure Village in Camarillo, where they were active as ever in the community and Len found time to tutor illiterate migrant workers. Len was an accomplished violinist and pianist, having studied since age three. He was blessed with a wonderful singing voice and was active for 16 years in the Channel Island Clippers, a barbershop ensemble. When Pauline died on October 30, 2008, Phyllis and Carole moved Leonard closer to them in Los Angeles, to The Village at Sherman Oaks. Dr. Koenig is survived by his daughters, his son-in-law Reuben Aaronson, his grandchildren Sophie Jaffe, Zach Aaronson, and Kathryn Stull, his grandson-in-law Dr. Adi Jaffe, his great-grandchildren Kai Jaffe, Sonny Walker Siemenski, and Sadie Pearl Siemenski, his nieces Orlean Shimberg and Zara Abel, his great nieces Michelle Schader and Jessica Shimberg Lind, and his great nephews Mark and Brian Abel. Leonard was a delight to all those who met him. His love of life and his compassion for others shone bright and pure and inspired everyone around him. He is remembered as one of the kindest, gentlest people we've known. Words cannot convey our gratitude at receiving the gift of his presence and care. May we all remember him by striving to extend this gift of joy and love to all those we meet in his honor. Thank you Len. Services will be held at Riverside Chapel and Cemetery in Saddlebrook, New Jersey at 11am on Friday, January 13, 2012. A gathering for family and friends will take place at Avalon Bowery, 11 East First Street, New York, NY 10003.

Things that refuse to die include Dracula, fungus, Jason from the ''Friday the 13th'' movies, zombies - and Lehman Brothers. You would probably like to forget Lehman in the wake of its collapse in 2008, an event that set off a near Armageddon in the financial world. Lehman filed for bankruptcy and soon afterward its investment banking arm was sold to Barclays of Britain for $250 million. That same week, Bank of America bought Merrill Lynch and most likely overpaid by tens of billions.

COHN--Peggy (Margaret), age 86 died January 10, 2012. Born and raised in New Rochelle to Edward Gordon and Ethel Branner Gordon. She graduated from Edgewood Park Junior College in 1943. She is predeceased by her husband Maurice J. Cohn and her brothers Gilbert and Donald. She is survived by her four children, Carol Cohn of Ossining, NY, Ellen Cohn of Manhattan, Jeanne Mirer of Brooklyn and Andrew Cohn of Newton, MA. She is also survived by her son-in-law Franklin Mirer and daughter-in-law Marcia Leavitt and her four grandchildren, Michael Mirer, Marisa Cohn, Elisabeth Mirer and David Cohn and by her great-grandson Jonah Mirer, as well as her niece Laura Georgakakos and her nephews Toby Gordon, Richard Gordon and Thomas Gordon, and her great nephews Conrad Gordon and Peter Georgakakos as well as her friend of many years and sister-in-law, Joan Morse Gordon. She put her family and friends first and everyone she met quickly became her friend. She loved reading, theatre, travel and bridge. She treasured and frequently visited her far flung family, including beloved cousins, knitting them together and sharing their stories with empathy and love. Her life was busy and full until her last year, including political involvement with the People's Center for Peace & Justice in Ossining which she helped found and WestPAC in White Plains, NY. Service 1:00pm, Thursday, January 12, at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

An article on Sunday about the arrest of an executive assistant at News International, the British newspaper arm of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, as part of the investigation into illegal phone hacking by The News of the World tabloid, misstated the extent of the subsidiary's acknowledgment of its involvement in hacking the voicemail of a teenage murder victim, Milly Dowler, in 2002. News International has acknowledged hacking the girl's phone, not deleting her messages. (Scotland Yard has not determined who deleted the messages, which gave the girl's family false hope that she might have still been alive.)

An obituary and a headline on Monday about Tony Blankley, the opinion columnist and former aide to Newt Gingrich, misstated his age, and the obituary also misstated the year of his birth. He was 63, not 62, and he was born on Jan. 21, 1948 -- not on Jan. 21, 1949. The obituary also omitted two survivors. Besides his wife and three children, Mr. Blankley is survived by his mother, Beatrice Blankley, and a sister, Maggie Blankley.

Months after his abrupt departure from AMC's hit zombie series, ''The Walking Dead,'' Frank Darabont has risen again to write, direct and produce the pilot episode of a new series for TNT, it was announced on Monday. TNT said in a news release that it had ordered a pilot for ''L.A. Noir,'' adapted from John Buntin's book of the same title, about the real-life battle between the Los Angeles Police Department and the West Coast mob from the 1930s through the '60s. The planned series, if it is picked up by the network, will be set in the '40s and '50s, and focus on the conflict between the Los Angeles police chief William Parker and the mobster Mickey Cohen. Mr. Darabont, who has chronicled the criminal element (and its life behind bars) in his films ''The Shawshank Redemption'' and ''The Green Mile,'' will produce the pilot with Michael De Luca (''Moneyball,'' ''The Social Network'') and Elliot Webb.

The Black Keys, Radiohead, Snoop Dogg and Dr. Dre will headline the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in April, according to the event's Twitter page. The annual festival, held in Indio, Calif., will feature two weekends, April 13-15 and April 20-22, with the same acts.

''Duck really is the other pork, isn't it?'' my friend Cathy asked last week. And of course, she's right. The two animals meander aimlessly around the barnyard, grazing and grunting and generally acting like hungry teenagers. But all the while they are building up a formidable cushion of sweet fat that has the miraculous quality of improving just about any food it touches. No wonder Momofuku Ssam Bar settled on duck as a focus for its lunch menu last spring. That restaurant didn't come into its own until it introduced its bo ssam dinners, where groups can feast on a whole pork shoulder slowly roasted until it is as spoonable and irresistible as cake frosting. What do you do after you've started a citywide pork frenzy? Rotisserie duck wouldn't strike everybody as the obvious answer, but it's the one that occurred to Ryan Miller, Ssam's chef de cuisine. Whole roast ducks are served to groups, bo ssam-style, but the solo diner can get a few slices in a bowl with rice and watercress. And the Ssam Bar team took advantage of this great new supply of cooking fat to come up with a few other duck-centric menu items. In the early days, the restaurant called this its Duckaholic Lunch, but that name seems to have passed out of use.

ALEXANDER--Alex E. passed away on January 10 at his home. Survived by his sister Alice Schneider, nephews, Arnold and Martin and great niece and nephews, Lindsay, Jeremy, Joseph and Paul. The son of Joseph and Eugenia Alexander, Alex was born in Warsaw, Poland on February 4, 1935. Surviving WWII by the heroic efforts of his family, Alex eventually emigrated to the US. He served in the US Army in Korea, went on to graduate from City College and received his Masters and Phd from Columbia. Alex was an admired and respected professor in Russian Language and Literature for 40 plus years at Hunter College. The family will conduct a private interment. A memorial service will be held in early spring. For information please contact his family at alexafam@gmail.com. Memorial donations may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

Every year since 1976, McDonald's has increased its annual payout to shareholders. This year it will keep the streak alive, raising its annual dividend to $2.80. In doing so, it will join a broad range of companies that weathered a challenging economy and are now delivering their best payments to shareholders since the financial crisis. If analysts' forecasts come true, that trend will continue later into the year, as companies release more of their cash and try to win over investors still hesitant about putting their money back into stocks.

TANNE--Sol, 88, died January 9, 2012 of complications following a hip fracture. A native New Yorker, Sol became a Renaissance man. Born on the Lower East Side on May 30, 1923, the son of Louis and Esther (Weiss) Tanne, Sol graduated from a neighborhood yeshiva, Stuyvesant High School, and Cooper Union, where his electrical engineering studies were interrupted by service in the US Navy in the South Pacific. After completing his degree, Sol became an international management consultant based in New York and then Rotterdam, The Netherlands, where his firm specialized in industrial automation and the movement of goods within factories and between ship and shore. On his return to New York he became a member of The Commodity Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange, where he served as vice-chairman and chaired many committees. He also helped found Purvis Systems Incorporated of Middletown, RI, a technology company specializing in communication systems for public safety and the defense industry. Although Sol was a scholar of Judaism, an athlete, a dancer, and a yoga leader, art was his major interest outside work. He studied sculpture at the Rotterdam Art Academy. In New York he painted portraits, figures, and still lifes in watercolor, oil, acrylic, and pastel. He was a life member of the Art Students League. His pastels have been exhibited at the National Arts Club and published in "Sol Tanne: Artist." Sol is survived by his wife of 43 years, the medical journalist Janice Hopkins Tanne; his nieces Jeanette Eisenmesser (Stanley) and Rita Osak. Services on Thursday at 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The Season 2 premiere of ''Downton Abbey'' on PBS on Sunday drew an average of 4.2 million total viewers, a number that would impress even the most cold-hearted dowager. That performance doubled the average prime-time rating for PBS, according to Nielsen data, and the show experienced an 18 percent jump in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with the typical rating from the first season. It was a quiet night on Monday among the broadcast networks as CBS and Fox ran repeats to avoid direct competition with the title game of the college football Bowl Championship Series on cable. ABC won the night over all, but a new episode of ''The Bachelor'' hit a series low in the 18-to-49 demographic and dropped slightly in total viewers, to 7.2 million from the 7.7 million who watched last week's premiere episode.

CAREY--William Polk. On behalf of the Trustees of the St. Elmo Educational Foundation, and the Board of Governors of the Delta Phi National Fraternity, we record with deep sadness the passing of our dear "Brother Bill." A 30 year Trustee and Chair of the Foundation, and 60 plus year Member of our Order, Bill was our most generous benefactor. Bill Carey will be forever in our gratitude and our memories by "raising the bar" in leadership. Board of Trustees, St. Elmo Foundation Board of Governors, Delta Phi National Fraternity

The White House said Tuesday that Cecilia Munoz, who has led its efforts to overhaul immigration laws, had been named director of the Domestic Policy Council, making her one of President Obama's chief advisers on a broad swath of issues, including education and gay rights. Ms. Munoz, the highest-ranking Hispanic in the White House, had served as director of intergovernmental affairs. She replaces Melody Barnes, who left this month. Her promotion is notable because it comes at the start of an election year in which Hispanic voters are expected to play a major role.
MIRON--Herbert. Beloved friend, treasured neighbor. Thank you for your friendship and wise counsel. We love you, Gerry and Lois Kirsh

MANDEL--George, CPA, passed away on January 8. A respected community activist, a passionate force behind the Workmen's Circle's Westchester Yiddish Festival for 37 years, and founding member of the Westchester Jewish Council. He served as Westchester Estate Planning Council chair and received the NYSSCPA's Lifetime Achievement Award. He is survived by his loving family: Abigail, wife of 71 years; children, David and Diane, Louise and Elliott; grandchildren, Rachel, Douglas, Jason and Devin, Jeffrey and Angela; and great-grandchildren, Carmen, Anne and Lewis. A Memorial will be held Wednesday, January 11th, 1pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.), New York. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Workmen's Circle in support of Yiddish culture, 247 W. 37th St., New York, NY 10018.

Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team - a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen - are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sunday's showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men - they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee - have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

Today, the Ace Hotel unveils its latest collaboration with the Tokyo-based fashion house Beams. Founded in 1976, Beams is both a private clothing label and department store, as well as a major force within the Japanese retail scene. Keith Urban will return to the stage for the first time since undergoing surgery on his vocal cords late last year when he sings at the Grand Ole Opry in February, the Opry announced Thursday. Mr. Urban has been forced to rest his voice since doctors at Vanderbilt University Medical Center removed a benign polyp from one of his vocal cords. Left untreated polyps can bleed when a singer is performing, leading to scarring on the vocal cords that can alter a voice's timbre.

Teaching children to graciously receive a gift they are not thrilled with is a common etiquette question, but last week, a parenting quandary came in that took the problem just a little farther. What if those unwanted gifts also bring an unwanted message? Gretchen's daughter Mia (all names have been changed) has always worn boys' clothing - not just gender-neutral clothing, but emphatically boys' clothes, right down to the skin. She's always said she wished she'd been born a boy. But Mia's grandmother (Gretchen's mother-in-law) sends boxes after boxes of fabulously frilly pink dresses, tights and bows.

Auberge Laurent, an elegant, brick-walled wine bar with a lounge area in the back, serves an array of wines, mostly French, and a few beers by the glass and the bottle, along with a brief menu of cheeses and charcuterie. This newcomer to Harlem is owned by Lawrence Page and was supposed to have been the uptown location for his Pink Tea Cup. Mr. Page, who owns the Actors' Playhouse in Greenwich Village, bought the original Pink Tea Cup, a venerable diner-style soul food spot on Grove Street, which had closed, and moved it to a larger space on Seventh Avenue South.

T Magazine's second annual pre-Golden Globes dinner was held at the Gardens of Taxco in West Hollywood Wednesday night. The quaint and quirky Mexican restaurant kicked off the festivities with tequila shots all around (and around and around). Dustin Hoffman and family caught up with some friends, Lisa Love, Geena Davis and Judy Greer, along with the "Quantum of Solace" director Marc Forster. (Hoffman and Sasha Spielberg had a laugh over a prank call to her father, Steven Spielberg). Also in attendance were Miranda Kerr, China Chow, Rashida Jones and the directors of "The Motel Life," Gabe and Alan Polsky. "I wish all parties could be like this," said Elisabeth Moss, of "Mad Men," clad in body-con Cushnie et Ochs. Huddled in terribly good-looking booths (and snacking on enchiladas and chicken mole) were a trio of up-and-comers from "War Horse" (Jeremy Irvine, Juno Temple and Emma Roberts) and the Golden Globe-nominated starlet Jessica Chastain ("The Help"). Bret McKenzie (song man for "The Muppets" and one half of Flight of the Conchords) made a late-night visit. Kermit was nowhere to be found.

A wonderfully surreal vision comes into view as you walk across Waterloo Bridge: a boat moored atop the Southbank Centre's Queen Elizabeth Hall. And this is not just any boat. A collaboration between the architect David Kohn and the artist Fiona Banner, it is part sculpture, part micro-hotel. "A Room for London," as it is known, is the result of a design competition run by two inspired clients - Living Architecture, which commissions and rents vacation houses designed by cutting-edge architects, and Artangel, which commissions contemporary art projects - to offer a unique, one-bedroom accommodation with some of the best views in London, and a program of live performances and events. ("A Room for London" has a one-night, two-person limit, and rates start at 120 pounds, or about $185.65.)

Sam Grobart, personal technology editor for The Times, reports that automakers are pursuing two tracks when it comes to technology in cars. They want to bring all the tools and entertainment from the drivers' smartphone onto the dashboard. At the same time they want to add safety features that make driving almost foolproof -- which could save a driver from the very distractions that the smartphone integration has created.

The end of Mahler's Ninth Symphony contains some of the most spiritual and peaceful music ever written. So when a cellphone began ringing - and ringing, ringing, ringing without cease - during a performance by the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday evening, Alan Gilbert did something conductors virtually never do. He stopped the performance. And then things really got bizarre.

8:16 p.m. | Updated Wall Street investors will receive significant new protections under a plan adopted by federal regulators on Wednesday, an overhaul that comes in the wake of the collapse of MF Global.

The Red Hot Chili Peppers have postponed the start of their tour this year until late March because Anthony Kiedis, the group's lead vocalist, has undergone surgery to repair a broken foot, according to the band's Web site. The cause of the injury has not been made public, but surgeons operated on Mr. Kiedis's right foot to remove a crushed sesamoid bone - a small bone in the ball of the foot at the base of the big toe -- and to reattach a flexor tendon, the statement said. The 49-year-old front man is expected to recover fully. The band intended to begin its tour to promote its most recent studio album, ''I'm With You,'' in Sunrise, Fla., on Jan. 20. The new schedule calls for them to start in Tampa, Fla., on March 29. The group will end the first leg of the tour in mid-April, when it is slated to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of fame at a ceremony in Cleveland, and then resume touring in mid-August.

BACKING DOWN Carl C. Icahn, below, struck out in his effort to buy the Commercial Metals Company, announcing on Wednesday that he was withdrawing his $1.7 billion bid to take over the metal recycler. Mr. Icahn disclosed that, as of his offer's deadline at midnight on Tuesday, his investment firm had received only 23 percent of the company's shares. That fell short of his requirement of 40.1 percent, which combined with his own 10 percent stake would have given him control of Commercial Metals. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

The Yankees signed the free-agent minor league outfielder Preston Mattingly, the son of the former Yankees first baseman Don Mattingly, to a minor league contract. Preston Mattingly was drafted by the Dodgers, the team Don Mattingly now manages, in the first round (31st over all) in 2006. He played at two levels in the Dodgers organization in 2011, batting .232 with 5 doubles, 5 home runs and 19 runs batted in over 53 combined games with Class A Great Lakes and Class A Advanced Rancho Cucamonga.

Rob Marshall, the Oscar-nominated director of ''Chicago,'' is taking on another movie musical -- ''Into the Woods'' -- as part of a new producing deal with Walt Disney Studios. Disney said on Wednesday that it had signed Mr. Marshall's company, Lucamar, to a two-year first-look contract and announced that his first project would be an adaptation of ''Into the Woods,'' Stephen Sondheim's 1980s-era mash-up of beloved fairy tales. James Lapine, who wrote the stage musical with Mr. Sondheim, is at work on a script; the film will feature the original score and possibly new songs by Mr. Sondheim. Casting has not started, and Disney said it was unclear when a movie version of ''Into the Woods'' might reach theaters because Mr. Marshall was also hoping to tackle a remake of ''The Thin Man'' for Warner Brothers.

LAS VEGAS -- Apple does not exhibit at C.E.S. and its executives haven't deigned to speak at the event for years. Yet the company's shadow looms large. For one, there are the rows and rows of booths dedicated to iPad cases, iPod docks and an endless array of other accessories for Apple products.

BOSTON - Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard professor seeking the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts in November, announced Wednesday that she had raised $5.7 million in the last three months of 2011. That tops the roughly $3.2 million that Mr. Brown raised over same period, which itself is no shabby total in a race expected to be one of the costliest and most intense in the nation.

LAS VEGAS -- Every year the camera manufacturers set up huge booths at C.E.S., where they display an impressive array of tiny, powerful cameras. And every year this exercise seems a bit more quaint. That's because the camera industry is still very much about better picture quality - megapixels and zoom lenses - even though the story these days is not just what the image looks like, but what you do with it after you take it. People want to share those pictures instantly on Facebook or Instagram, or through e-mail. And they can do that with the camera in their smartphone.

THALACKER--Arbie. The Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation notes with sadness the death of Arbie Thalacker, a trustee of the Society since 1993 and President of the Board from 2009 to 2011. Arbie's absence will be felt profoundly, but his legacy and personal warmth and wisdom will be remembered with great joy and gratitude. Arthur Levin, President Andrew Berman, Executive Director

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Alabama running back Trent Richardson misstated, in some editions, the year his former backfield mate Mark Ingram won the Heisman Trophy. It was 2009, not last year.

Now comes the economic-bust phase of the Republican primaries. Iowa and New Hampshire, the first two states to hold nominating contests, are both among six states with the lowest unemployment rates in the nation. Their economic strength benefited Mitt Romney, who has performed much better with affluent, white-collar voters than with those who are struggling, according to exit polls.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a mini-building boom in Indianapolis that began after the city was named the host of this year's Super Bowl gave an outdated name for the main sports arena there. It is now the Bankers Life Fieldhouse; it had been the Conseco Fieldhouse until it was renamed in late December.

An article on Wednesday about a trend toward increasing stock dividends misspelled part of the name of a company cited as an example of one whose stock returns and dividend yields exceeded the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. It is Bristol-Myers, not Bristol-Meyers.

At the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, you can even find electronics in glasses. PixelOptics is demonstrating eyeglasses in which an electronic current is passed through liquid crystals to change the prescription on the fly. Called the emPower line, the glasses are frames with progressive lenses with three focusing zones. Only two zones work at a time, eliminating problems some progressive lens wearers experience when the upper and lower prescriptions interfere with the middle. (It's called ''swim.'')

As fellow members of the "October 1929" club, we will raise a glass of 1929 claret to the memory of your wise, witty and thought-provoking comments over the decades. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Laique and to Omar and Leslie. Dan and Joanna Rose Bill and Nancy Zeckendorf
A theater review on Wednesday about ''The Bee,'' at Japan Society in Manhattan, omitted a co-author of the play. It is by Hideki Noda and Colin Teevan, not by Mr. Noda alone.

An article on Tuesday about some Lenox Hill Hospital patients' complaints about security measures accompanying the birth of a daughter of Beyoncé and Jay-Z misspelled the given name of the hospital's spokeswoman. She is Ann Silverman, not Anne.

EDELMAN--Eleanor L. died peacefully in her sleep at her home in Bronxville, New York on January 7, 2012. For 53 years, she was the wife of Albert I. Edelman, an attorney who predeceased her. She was born Eleanor Louise Weisman in 1924 in St. Louis, Missouri and was known to her friends as Elly. Along with her beloved sisters, Beryl and Nanette, she graduated from Mary Institute in St. Louis and received her BA from Wellesley College. Returning to school after raising her children, she received an MS in Historic Preservation from Columbia University in 1984. In partnership with her great friend, Sophia Schachter, she worked for many years on architectural preservation projects in the New York City area. She lived in Bronxville, New York for more than fifty years and spent weekends and summers at her beloved 1720 house in East Hampton, Long Island. She was a Board Member of The Family Consultation Service, The East Hampton Historical Society and the Nature Conservancy (South Fork Shelter Island Chapter). She was Founder and first President of The Bronxville Skating Club, The Loft Film and Theater Center in Bronxville and Friends of The Sarah Lawrence Library. She will be mourned by those who loved her. She leaves behind her four children, Gwen A. Edelman, Thomas J. Edelman, Jennifer B. Edelman and Cornelia Edelman Moss as well as her grandchildren Elizabeth G. Edelman, Eleanor A. Edelman, Theo Edelman Moss and Jules Edelman Moss. Devoted wife, mother and grandmother, she was a woman of class, generosity and loyalty. Rest in Peace. A memorial service is being held at Temple Emanu-el, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, tomorrow, January 13th, at 11am

R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, is climbing Mount Kilimanjaro this month to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats. The last two days of hiking have carried us over steep barren ridges and into deep gorges filled with streams of glacial runoff. ''I don't have conversations with my husband's staff,'' she told Gayle King of CBS News in an interview broadcast on Wednesday morning. ''I don't go to the meetings.''

Europe has a $1 trillion problem. As difficult as the last two years have been for Europe, 2012 could be even tougher. Each week, countries will need to sell billions of dollars of bonds - a staggering $1 trillion in total - to replace existing debt and cover their current budget deficits.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a decision by Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey to block the nomination of Judge Patty Shwartz to a federal judgeship misstated the timing of an interview Mr. Menendez had with her. It was when Judge Shwartz, a federal magistrate judge, was under consideration for a federal judgeship in August, not after her nomination to the appeals court in October. The last time William Shatner was featured on a Broadway stage, the original productions of ''The Sound of Music'' and ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' were still playing nearby and a star trek was not much more than a gleam in the eye of President John F. Kennedy (or maybe Gene Roddenberry). Now, 50 years after he played Paul Sevigne in the 1961 staging of ''A Shot in the Dark'' and went on to a fairly prolific acting career, Mr. Shatner, 80, is making a return voyage to Broadway in a one-man show that will begin performances next month. Press representatives for the show, called ''Shatner's World: We Just Live in It,'' said on Wednesday that it would be presented at the Music Box Theater, and will offer the actor's take on his journey ''from Shakespearean stage actor to internationally known icon and raconteur, known as much for his unique persona as for his expansive body of work on television and film,'' according to a news release.

A LONGSTANDING friendship between Jean Paul Gaultier and the eyewear designer Alain Mikli, who met at Paris Fashion Week more than 20 years ago, has resulted in an inspired collaboration. For the Jean Paul Gaultier by Mikli eyewear collection, the two visionaries created 20 models (12 optical, 8 sunglasses) with inventive tweaks to classic shapes: Wayfarer styles with triple temples that fan out, drawing on the lines of M. Gaultier's Breton shirts; two-tone cat's-eyes that have multiple temples; and this glamorous round pair with a comblike triple temple. The collection had its debut in Dallas in November, to coincide with the Gaultier exhibition at the Dallas Museum of Art, and is available now for $285 to $400 at Alain Mikli, 986 Madison Avenue; (212) 472-6085.

A NEW social-network shopping site, motilo.com, with links to high fashion e-commerce sites, makes online shopping with friends more like the real thing. Think of it as Polyvore meets Facebook. Register and invite friends to create head-to-toe looks, all the while video-chatting with your fashion buddies. ''It's that power of referral that will often help tip you into making a purchase,'' said Sofia Barattieri di San Pietro, the site's chief executive, who came up with the idea on a shopping trip to Paris with a friend. All of the items featured are linked to retailers like net-a-porter.com and farfetch.com. You will also find photo shoots; outfits put together by contributing stylists, including Anna Dello Russo, the designer Laetitia Crahay and the French fashion journalist Mademoiselle Agnès; and fashion available only on the site. Up now: the Muzungu Sisters, a collection of handmade pieces -- Moroccan caftans, a Peruvian multicolor bolero -- that the friends Tatiana Santo Domingo and Dana Alikhani have collected on their worldly travels.

MANDEL--George. The Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring mourns the passing of our activist and long time Board member. George dedicated a lifetime of service as Chair of our Education and Camp Committees. He created and spearheaded the WC Westchester Yiddish Festival for over three decades. Our heartfelt sympathies to wife, Abigail, children David and Louise and their families.

Adele's ''21'' (XL/Columbia) is officially the fastest-selling record in seven years, so it's not a surprise that this week the album tops Billboard's chart for the 15th time. What is notable -- and a relief for the music industry -- is that it continues to rack up significant sales at a time of year that has been embarrassingly slow in recent years. Adele's album sold 124,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is a healthy number in any week. But it's miraculous given the abysmal sales last January and February, when the industry's record for the lowest sales for a No. 1 album was broken again and again buy a string of releases, culminating with just over 40,000 sales for Amos Lee's ''Mission Bell.'' Once again, Adele's success is giving the music business something to celebrate.

It was a marquee proposal by Jay H. Walder, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority during the relatively flush times of 2009: Replace the MetroCard with a computer chip-enabled ''smart card'' that would speed up boarding times and save the agency millions of dollars a year. The technology is used in many of the world's more advanced transit systems, including in Boston, Washington and London, where Mr. Walder had been its architect. Plans called for a rollout in New York by 2015.

MANCHESTER, N.H. -- In the sour, fearful mood that economic setbacks have produced, American voters loathe both major symbols of the forces squeezing their pocketbooks and life savings. President Obama will seek re-election vowing to rein in one of them: Wall Street. Mitt Romney will focus on the other: Washington.

The court overturned the conviction for sodomy, not the entire verdict.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about Wall Street firms' increasing compensation as a percentage of revenue, misidentified, in some copies, AT&T's acquisition target in a deal for which Greenhill & Company, which has one of the highest compensation-to-revenue ratios on Wall Street, served as an adviser. It was T-Mobile USA, not Sprint.

TANNE--Sol, 88, died January 9, 2012 of complications following a hip fracture. A native New Yorker, Sol became a Renaissance man. Born on the Lower East Side on May 30, 1923, the son of Louis and Esther (Weiss) Tanne, Sol graduated from a neighborhood yeshiva, Stuyvesant High School, and Cooper Union, where his electrical engineering studies were interrupted by service in the US Navy in the South Pacific. After completing his degree, Sol became an international management consultant based in New York and then Rotterdam, The Netherlands, where his firm specialized in industrial automation and the movement of goods within factories and between ship and shore. On his return to New York he became a member of The Commodity Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange, where he served as vice-chairman and chaired many committees. He also helped found Purvis Systems Incorporated of Middletown, RI, a technology company specializing in communication systems for public safety and the defense industry. Although Sol was a scholar of Judaism, an athlete, a dancer, and a yoga leader, art was his major interest outside work. He studied sculpture at the Rotterdam Art Academy. In New York he painted portraits, figures, and still lifes in watercolor, oil, acrylic, and pastel. He was a life member of the Art Students League. His pastels have been exhibited at the National Arts Club and published in "Sol Tanne: Artist." Sol is survived by his wife of 43 years, the medical journalist Janice Hopkins Tanne; his nieces Jeanette Eisenmesser (Stanley) and Rita Osak. Services on Thursday at 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

''In the Solitude of Cotton Fields,'' a visceral adaptation of a French play by Bernard-Marie Koltés, portrays a high-octane, sexually charged meeting between a dealer and a client, where the goods exchanged are unclear, but the high stakes are not. On another level, this production, staged in Polish with English supertitles by Radoslaw Rychcik, is about a confrontation between theater and rock concert. The rock concert wins. This show at La MaMa E.T.C. opens in smoky darkness as a band called the Natural Born Chillers lays down a pounding bass line while two silhouetted figures dance. The Dealer (Wojciech Niemczyk) does a ferocious, fist-punching twist, while the Client (Tomasz Nosinski) shrinks and unfolds his body in a repeated violent motion.

A capsule summary on the DealBook page on Wednesday about the sudden retirement of Jasjit Bhattal as head of Nomura Holdings' wholesale banking division misstated his tenure as chief executive. He held the post for less than one year, not less than two years.
