AS ''The Artist,'' the black-and-white silent film set in late 1920s Hollywood, gathers Oscar chatter, the Jazz Age fashion of that time is having a moment in real time. Cloche hats, the toppers the ingénue Peppy Miller (charmingly played by Bérénice Bejo, right) wears on her rise to stardom, were all over Ralph Lauren's romantic spring runway, as well as at Marc Jacobs. ''There's a mystery to the cloche,'' said Mark Bridges, the costume designer of ''The Artist.'' ''They sort of half hide the face and are coy.'' Mr. Bridges used period styles to frame Ms. Bejo's face, but these cloches are available now -- for warmth and a little hat flirting. Clockwise from bottom left: Victor Osborne velour cloche, $200 at Victor Osborne, 160 Orchard Street; (212) 677-6254. Barbara Feinman fur felt cloche, $210 at Barbara Feinman Millinery,

Tired of the AutoPlay box in Windows 7 popping up and suggesting a program you never use whenever you insert a disc or connect a USB drive to the computer? Using the AutoPlay settings box, you can customize the programs that Windows uses to handle CDs, DVDs and other types of media on the computer. Go to the Start menu to Control Panel, click on ''Hardware and Sound'' and click on AutoPlay. In the list of media types like Blank CD or DVD Movie, use the drop-down menu to choose your preferred program (or action) for each type of disc or drive. You can also choose to turn off AutoPlay altogether -- just remove the check on the box next to ''Use AutoPlay for all media and devices'' and click the Save button.

Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the playoffs, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team - a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen - are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sunday's showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotels and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men - they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee - have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win. My buddies in Chatham, N.J. - lifelong Giants fans like myself - had long expressed jealousy over my 2008 trip to Lambeau Field, where I saw the Giants beat the Packers on their way to a Super Bowl championship.

LAS VEGAS -- Struggling to make a profit and distinguish themselves from competitors, television manufacturers are going big. Really big. At the C.E.S. this year, manufacturers tried to outdo one another by showing off the biggest television. If another manufacturer's TV was bigger, they would scoff that the quality wasn't nearly as good - the old ''size doesn't matter'' argument. It's not a new theme, but the TV makers were hitting it hard anyway.

(VH1) THE 17TH ANNUAL CRITICS' CHOICE MOVIE AWARDS The Broadcast Film Critics Association will bestow its honors at this ceremony hosted by the comedians Paul Scheer and Rob Huebel, from left above, and featuring Fitz and the Tantrums as the house band. George Clooney will present Sean Penn with the Joel Siegel Award, named for the longtime ''Good Morning America'' film critic who died in 2007. Martin Scorsese will receive the Critics' Choice Music+Film Award, created to recognize a filmmaker who heightens storytelling through the effective use of music. The best picture nominees are ''Drive,'' ''Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close,'' ''Hugo,'' ''Midnight in Paris,'' ''Moneyball,'' ''The Artist,'' ''The Descendants,'' ''The Help,'' ''The Tree of Life'' and ''War Horse.'' 8:30 A.M. (USA) STATE OF PLAY (2009) Cal McAffrey (Russell Crowe) is a scruffy reporter for a Washington newspaper; Della Frye (Rachel McAdams) is its fresh-faced political-gossip blogger. Together they try to get at the truth behind the death of a researcher who worked for a congressman (Ben Affleck) who is digging up dirt on a mysterious securities contractor. The congressman just happens to be Cal's college roommate and best friend. Was it really an accident? Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said this thriller ''is both shallower and muddier than its clear-eyed source.'' Still, he added, anyone who is sentimental about the newspaper business and ''who cherishes memories of 'All the President's Men' or 'His Girl Friday' will smile when 'State of Play,' directed by Kevin Macdonald ('The Last King of Scotland'), now and again hits the sweet spot of the genre.''

LAS VEGAS - The most nagging complaint from people who own Android phones has been short battery life. The reason? Its ability to run apps in the background drains battery life. A new version of Motorola's Droid Razr, introduced here at the International Consumer Electronics Show, tries to address that with a battery that can last a claimed 21 hours.

FELLOWS--James A. A public broadcasting pioneer, James A. Fellows, 77, died January 6. His career spanned 47 years. He led the National Association of Educational Broadcasters in Washington, DC, when it championed the transformation of educational TV and radio into today's national public broadcasting system (1961 1981). The Corporation for Public Broadcasting honored him for outstanding contributions to the field. He led the Central Educational Network in Des Plaines, IL (1983 2003).

The producers of the new musical ''Leap of Faith'' are hoping to bring the show to Broadway this spring, instead of in fall 2012 as previously announced, according to one of the producers, Daryl Roth. In a newsletter sent to friends and colleagues and some journalists on Tuesday night about her current projects, Ms. Roth wrote that there should be news shortly on ''Leap of Faith'' and that ''hopefully'' it will open in the spring. The musical, which is expected to star four-time Tony Award nominee Raul Esparza as an evangelical con man, has been rumored recently as the next tenant for the St. James Theater, given the possibility that its current musical, ''On A Clear Day You Can See Forever,'' will close soon. ''On A Clear Day,'' starring Harry Connick Jr., opened in December to mostly negative reviews and has been selling modestly at the box office. ''Leap of Faith'' would be the latest addition to a Broadway season that had a dearth of new original musicals only a few months ago. Two other upcoming original musicals, ''Newsies'' and ''Once,'' have been announced for Broadway over the last couple of months, joining ''Rebecca,'' ''Ghost,'' and ''Nice Work If You Can Get It'' in the line-up of such shows opening this spring.

A profile on Saturday about the Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou misspelled the surname of a German filmmaker to whom some critics compared Mr. Zhang because of his work on the opening ceremony of the 2008 Olympics. She was Leni Riefenstahl, not Reifenstahl.

COHN--Peggy (Margaret), age 86 died January 10, 2012. Born and raised in New Rochelle to Edward Gordon and Ethel Branner Gordon. She graduated from Edgewood Park Junior College in 1943. She is predeceased by her husband Maurice J. Cohn and her brothers Gilbert and Donald. She is survived by her four children, Carol Cohn of Ossining, NY, Ellen Cohn of Manhattan, Jeanne Mirer of Brooklyn and Andrew Cohn of Newton, MA. She is also survived by her son-in-law Franklin Mirer and daughter-in-law Marcia Leavitt and her four grandchildren, Michael Mirer, Marisa Cohn, Elisabeth Mirer and David Cohn and by her great-grandson Jonah Mirer, as well as her niece Laura Georgakakos and her nephews Toby Gordon, Richard Gordon and Thomas Gordon and her great niece Lydia Gordon and her great nephews Conrad Gordon, Aaron Gordon and Peter Georgakakos as well as her friend of many years and sister-in-law, Joan Morse Gordon. She put her family and friends first and everyone she met quickly became her friend. She loved reading, theatre, travel and bridge. She treasured and frequently visited her far flung family, including beloved cousins, knitting them together and sharing their stories with empathy and love. Her life was busy and full until her last year, including political involvement with the People's Center for Peace & Justice in Ossining which she helped found and WestPAC in White Plains, NY. Service 1:00pm, Thursday, January 12, at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

GOODMAN--Dr. Sanford, devoted and loving husband of Dr. Amy Wysoker, died after a long illness on January 8, 2012. Dr. Goodman spent his life helping others, a chiropractor with golden hands and a sharing heart. Dr Goodman is survived by his wife, sisters; Sonya Margolin, Zita Manson and brothers-in-law; Richard Wysoker, Charles Regan, Michael Manson, Harold Margolin, and sisters-in-law; Stephanie Wysoker and Nancy Regan.

When Fernando Martinez signed with the Mets on July 11, 2005, there was great excitement surrounding a 16-year-old from the Dominican Republic who was projected to become an elite outfielder. The Mets had beaten out several teams by luring Martinez with a $1.4 million bonus, and the clamor over him grew when he made his major league debut on May 26, 2009, at age 20 after consistently being ranked as the Mets' top prospect.

COREN--Bertram, of Haverford, PA, formerly of New York City and Ft. Lee, NJ, on January 8, 2012, at the age of 94. Beloved husband of the late Olga Coren, father of sons Daniel and Robert, father-in-law of Gretta Leopold and John Gintell. He was an editor and publisher of science textbooks, a talented sculptor, and an avid amateur astronomer. He continued to be a vital contributor to the intellectual life of the Quadrangle retirement community until the end of his life. He will be deeply missed.

The strangest thing about the accident, friends say, was not the blood-soaked victim - a disc jockey from Brooklyn, traveling in Portland, Ore., for a spell. It was not the wayward taxi that landed on him.

REYNOLDS--Michael J.,73, on January 10, 2012. Dearly missed by wife Sue and children Amy, Katie and Michael. Graduate of Manhattan College. He began his career with New York Life Insurance Company followed by Frank B. Hall, AON and Pentegra. Decker Funeral Home in Windham, NY.

WASHINGTON -- As arguments flare in Israel and the United States about a possible military strike to set back Iran's nuclear program, an accelerating covert campaign of assassinations, bombings, cyberattacks and defections appears intended to make that debate irrelevant, according to current and former American officials and specialists on Iran. The campaign, which experts believe is being carried out mainly by Israel, apparently claimed its latest victim on Wednesday when a bomb killed a 32-year-old nuclear scientist in Tehran's morning rush hour.
Q. I have a dial-up Internet connection for my PC. I've been told that with dial-up, one doesn't need security software. Is this true?

WANG--ZiXin, 103, passed away peacefully on January 4, 2012. Dr. Wang was the husband of Yu-Qi Cai for over 50 years. Children ZhongYing, ZhongFang, ZhongQiang, JoAnn Rowland, ZhongSheng, Dr. Sherry Weigand. Nephew Ke Cai. Grandchildren XiaoBo, Fang Zhang, David Shui, Lily Su, Daniel, Charlie, and Benjamin. Funeral at 3pm January 14, 2012, Central Funeral Home, Flushing NY.

LAS VEGAS -- The electronics casemaker Speck has rolled out an iPhone cover that is supposedly kind to the thumbs. The new CandyShell Grip is an iPhone case designed especially with gamers in mind, adding soft-finned grips so that Doodle Jump fiends and other game aficionados won't suffer fatigue no matter how many levels they clear.

The TV Watch column on Wednesday, about sexism in shows including ''Are You There, Chelsea?'' on NBC, misspelled the name of the character who is Chelsea's older sister. She is Sloane, not Sloan.

Gaffney, S.C., a small Southern town, has found itself the unexpected star of the latest bruising fight in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

DUNCAN, S.C. -- Conventional wisdom dictates that for either Newt Gingrich or Rick Santorum to vault past Mitt Romney and win the South Carolina primary on Jan. 21, they must handily win the vote of upstate social conservatives, like the ones who packed a high school lunchroom here Friday night. But if the reactions of the 500 or so people here were any indication, these voters remain split.

The Times has posted an article on its Web site by Richard Perez-Pena and Jenny Anderson arguing that "the early-admissions game'' was made "much tougher this year for the group that has long dominated it: prep schools in New York and beyond where the vast majority of seniors apply to their top choices in November in hopes of avoiding the springtime scrum."

The advent of the Internet has prompted endless claims that we are living through an unprecedented revolution in communication, one that has annihilated the concept of distance. Yet the real revolution came with the arrival of the telegraph in the 19th century.
U.C.L.A. forward Sydney Leroux was the top pick in Friday's W.P.S. draft. Whether she -- or anyone else -- will get to play in the league this season is another question.

The United States Marine Corps has identified the four Marines shown in a video urinating on what appear to be dead Taliban fighters, and has named a lead investigating officer to decide whether they should be charged, Marine officials said. In an article in Saturday's issue of The Times, Elisabeth Bumiller and Matthew Rosenberg report that Marine officials were also attempting to identify the person who shot the controversial video.

A credit downgrade for several European nations, unexpectedly strong jobs numbers for December and the suspension of iPhone sales in Apple stores in China were among the top business news stories of the week.
Wall Street, more than three years after the financial crisis, has loosened its lending tap. Consumers, however, have yet to reap the benefits.

Jessica Ingram still recalls the summer day a decade ago when she stood at Court Square Fountain in Montgomery, Ala., taking in the details spelled out in historical markers. There, near the State Capitol, she read that the square was the site of the city's slave market. That none of the men, women or children had been given last names. How much they fetched.
The editor-in-chief of mrporter.com discusses how his site combines editorial content with commerce and the future of online retailing.

Carl C. Icahn disclosed on Friday that he had acquired a 14.5 percent stake in CVR Energy, saying the refining company's shares were undervalued. This makes Mr. Icahn and his affiliates the largest shareholders in CVR, according to Reuters. In response, CVR said its board had adopted a poison pill takeover defense that would be set off if Mr. Icahn reached a 15 percent ownership stake. Read more »

The International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week offered thousands of novel gadgets and high-tech products like remote-controlled indoor helicopters, ultrathin computer glass and refrigerators that play Pandora.

Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the expansion of Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport, an overturned houseboat in the Bronx and the mayor's State of the City address.

At the Critics' Choice Awards on Thursday and the American Film Institute luncheon today, they were inundated with well-wishers, from Brad Grey, chairman of Paramount, to Sacha Baron Cohen.

In Sunday's Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich, Phil Patton and Paul Stenquist take the measure of the 2012 Detroit auto show, which is scheduled to open to the public this weekend, and where media previews concluded on Tuesday.

On Friday, Standard & Poor’s cut the ratings on nine of the 17 European countries that use the euro currency. France and Austria lost their coveted AAA ratings, which were lowered one notch to AA+, and Italy and Spain had their ratings cut by two notches. Germany, Finland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands all retained their AAA status, while the ratings of Portugal and Cyprus were cut to junk.
In this Sunday's Book Review, Alexander Star reviews a new book about the reactions of Americans to the powerful and controversial work of the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. Mr. Star writes:

Anthony Roth Costanzo will step into the counter-tenor role of Prospero in the Metropolitan Opera's production of "The Enchanted Island" on Saturday evening. He will replace David Daniels, who is ill, the Met said. Mr. Costanzo is cast as Ferdinand in the opera, and will be replaced in that part by Jeffrey Mandelbaum. The switch also occurred in Act II of Thursday's performance.
A Trinidadian man who was convicted of plotting to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport was sentenced Friday to life in prison.

The online activist group known as Anonymous, which has targeted opponents of the Occupy Wall Street movement and businesses that stopped providing services to WikiLeaks, has set its sights on a new adversary: media executives.

Back in 2002, Lynne Ramsay was a film director on the verge. Her second feature, the gorgeous, impressionistic drama ''Morvern Callar,'' made its debut at Cannes and grabbed the attention of serious moviegoers; in The Times, the critic Elvis Mitchell called it ''one of the most important pictures'' of the year. Meanwhile, a dark first novel that Ramsay was preparing to adapt and direct surprised the publishing world by landing at the top of The New York Times best-seller list.
All the fashion news of the week that's fit to reprint.

Lions Gate Entertainment said on Friday that it had agreed to buy Summit Entertainment for $412.5 million in cash and stock, uniting the studios behind "The Hunger Games" and the "Twilight" movie franchises. Lions Gate was advised by JPMorgan Chase, Barclays Capital, Jefferies and the law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. Summit was counseled by Liner Grode Stein and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Read more »

An arms race seems to have sprung up among the new breed of beer stores that specialize in imports and craft labels. If one offers 250 different brews, the next stockpiles 400. Now, Ted Kenny, a former beer salesman, is raising the ante with at least 700, including 20 on tap, at Top Hops Beer Shop, the new store he plans to open Saturday on the Lower East Side.

If Mitt Romney had his way, we'd only talk about income inequality in "quiet rooms"-I'm picturing wood-paneling and cigar smoke. If Rick Santorum had his way, we wouldn't even use the term "middle class" since, apparently, "there are no classes in America." Middle-income people, maybe, he says, but no middle-class people.

Phil Angelides, the former chairman of the Federal Crisis Inquiry Commission, is leading an investment group that is seeking to buy troubled mortgages, Matthew Goldstein and Jennifer Ablan of Reuters report. The idea is to buy the loans at a discount and rework them to keep homeowners in their homes and making payments. Read more »
A look back on our reporting of the past week's highs and lows in finance.

The early days of winter may seem an odd time to bring out new athletic footwear, but there are some good reasons: for one, millions of consumers have vowed to exercise more in the new year; for another, there are lots of sports events on TV that draw big audiences filled with shoe buyers.

Ten years in the lives of three couples in Argentina spin, quite slowly, in "El Pasado Es un Animal Grotesco" ("The Past Is a Grotesque Animal"), from the Argentine writer and director Mariano Pensotti. The piece, making its U.S. premiere in a co-production of the Coil and Under the Radar festivals, features actors performing on a slowly rotating set to a soundtrack that includes music from the band Of Montreal.
A federal judge in Virginia on Friday denied Rick Perry, Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum and Jon M. Huntsman Jr. spots on the state's presidential primary ballot.

Early into the new year and the Formula One news is picking up again little by little, especially from Italy where the Ferrari team held its annual Christmas company event, called Wrooom, in Madonna di Campiglio, this week.

Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team - a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen - traveled to Lambeau Field for Sunday's showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It was a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men - they were joined by two pals in Milwaukee - agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes were to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

The Library of Congress has been gradually posting to Flickr its trove of more than 40,000 photos from the Bain Collection, comprising the surviving photos of the Bain News Service, a photo agency founded by George Grantham Bain that flourished in the early 20th century.

The Louis Vuitton prefall collection is an absolute delight. Rounded silhouettes on coats, cap-sleeved baby-doll dresses in peach and yellow and a return of the beloved Stephen Sprouse leopard in blue/navy on a smart suit, all possess the same whimsy we saw at Marc Jacobs's most recent spring collection. Star accessories include grommeted berets and sharp heels - kitten-height and higher - with shiny steel-toe tips. Fur is sprinkled liberally throughout, on coat pockets, collars and shoes (making feet look like puppy paws; it's quite fun). Here, a dress with the collection's signature Sgt. Pepper's trompe l'oeil gets a pop of pretty pink.

CBS once again managed to dominate prime time among the broadcast networks on Thursday night, easily taking first place in all ratings categories. According to Nielsen, a very large percentage of the 15.9 million people who watched "Big Bang Theory" stayed put and sampled the series premiere of "Rob." Although that comedy has been poorly received critically, it drew 13.5 million viewers. The new drama "Person of Interest" also did well as it posted its best numbers ever and reached 14.7 million people.

LAS VEGAS -- A restored, fully operational 1920 Henderson Four Model K was the top sale Thursday at the Auctions America by RM event at the Rio Las Vegas Hotel and Casino, as a three-day, three-auction marathon kicked off at three locations here. Including a 12 percent sales commission, the Henderson changed hands for $50,960, slightly below its preauction estimate.

A study published in the British Medical Journal this week provides stronger evidence that taking some antidepressants during pregnancy doubles the risk of a baby developing pulmonary hypertension. Researchers have long suspected a link between the use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.'s, and the condition, but previous studies have been small and inconclusive (with results ranging from there being no link to a six times greater risk).

The lead prosecutor in the insider-trading case against Raj Rajaratnam is leaving the United States attorney's office in Manhattan and joining the law firm Dechert as a partner in its white-collar criminal defense practice.

It's certainly a part of everyone's vocabulary, but for me it's a word that especially permeates sports culture in regard to team logos and uniforms. It often means one thing: quality.

The catch: the tiny group would be responsible for $3.6 million in renovations and improvements.

Scott Boras does not get everything he seeks in every negotiation. But it is wise not to doubt him. This is the agent who persuaded teams to give seven-year, $126 million contracts to Barry Zito and Jayson Werth, and persuaded another to hand not one, but two player options to Rafael Soriano.

Walt Disney Studios on Friday named a Hollywood veteran to lead its worldwide marketing and publicity efforts: Ricky Strauss, the president of Participant Media, a progressive-minded production company with credits like "The Help" and the documentary "An Inconvenient Truth."

As I reported in Thursday's paper, New York State environmental regulators are sorting through more than 20,000 public comments as they develop the final rules for high-volume hydraulic fracturing, the much-debated process to extract natural gas from underground shale formations.

TPG Capital is weighing a potential investment in the Olympus Corporation of Japan, in which it would join with a strategic partner to invest as much as $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

This week Martha Rose Shulman encourages home cooks to get more creative with apples, taking her recipes beyond traditional dishes like applesauce and apple pie. She also encourages home chefs to leave the skin on when possible.

Sidney Crosby skated Friday, his first time on ice since experiencing a recurrence of concussion symptoms after a game Dec. 5. After the Penguins' morning skate in Sunrise, Fla., he skated for 27 minutes and sounded afterward like a player whose return to the lineup is far from imminent.

The fall/winter 2012 edition of Pitti Uomo concludes today (witness, in real time, the fashion flock hopping trains to Milan, where the fanfare will commence tomorrow). Here in Florence, the Palazzo Corsini provided the ornate backdrop for the fair's featured event - Valentino's return to the runway with a show for the house's men's-wear line, now under the creative direction of Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli. It was an elegant affair with sleek, cropped trousers and voluminous jackets all finely finished in what Chiuri referred to as a couture approach to men's wear.

If the gang from "Bridesmaids" was dancing around the line between comedy and emotional honesty, the filmmakers behind "50/50" were stomping on it. The film, inspired by the screenwriter Will Reiser's real-life story of being given a cancer diagnosis in his mid-20s, treats its subject matter as he did in real life: as dreadfully serious and dreadfully funny. It has been earning some nominations and prizes for its screenplay - and some good-natured ribbing from Mr. Reiser's friend Seth Rogen, who starred as the best friend and served as a producer with his writing partner, Evan Goldberg.

I spent a recent holiday in Paris appreciating some of the simple things the French do so well. No, not foie gras and Champagne, but rather humbler products, like cured pork and lentils. Nearly every butcher shop sells brined pork (called demi-sel or petit salé), ready to take home and simmer. On a shelf nearby is a box of lentils, usually the certified lentilles du Puy, arguably the best lentils in the world. Cooked together, they are a classic combination, not fancy at all but uncommonly good.
Procter & Gamble, the giant marketer of household staples, will expand a popular advertising campaign around the world in connection with its sponsorship of the 2012 Summer Olympics.
Royal Dutch Shell has been on a six-year crusade to drill in Arctic waters off Alaska's coast, and has spent about $4 billion on the effort so far without drilling a single well.
January 13, 2012 - President Obama asks Congress for greater authority to shrink the federal government.
A collection of photos from the day in sports, including shots from the Sydney International tennis tournament and World Cup downhill skiing.
A town house on Central Park West that comes with its own 60-foot lap pool and that sold for $22.375 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city public records.
In the years before the financial crisis, private offerings of stock held much allure. They often offered outsize returns, but only to those who seemed to have the inside track.

It's hard to believe that Alexander Wang, just 28 years old, is presenting his 19th collection. Building off of signature concepts - cutouts, cool-girl black and the use of technical fabrics - Wang's prefall collection is heavy on the separates; a study in wearable sportswear, akin to that of the 1990s. Pops of maroon (on a printed sheer dress) and a greenish mustard (on a ruched skirt dress) emerge among all of the black, white and gray, carrying over into accessories. A soon to be coveted pointy-toe heel with mesh detailing and tight ankle strap demonstrates Wang's ability to evolve ideas from one season to the next. (Have a look at his spring shoes and tell us there isn't a resemblance.) Clarity arrives in the form of a skirt suit bearing the collection's defining trompe l'oeil plaid.

As conservative Christian leaders struggle to coalesce behind a single candidate of the religious right, the Romney campaign has put out a radio ad in South Carolina that in essence asks the evangelical leaders, "Why not me?"
Hostess Brands is back in bankruptcy again, arguing that its last filing did not really accomplish all that much, despite taking a rather long time.

The Miami Herald reports that a number of prominent Cuban-American citizens have made formal complaints to Daimler, the parent of Mercedes-Benz, after an image of Che Guevara appeared on a screen behind Dieter Zetsche, the Daimler chief executive, during his keynote address at the Consumer Electronics Show. Manchester City's Mario Balotelli been called everything from mercurial to daft. One thing is for certain, he knows how to draw a crowd on and off the soccer field.

On Thursday night, the "Hack-a-Dwight" strategy became less of an occasional tactic and more of a general basketball philosophy. In desperation because of Kwame Brown's injury and Andris Biedrins' foul trouble, Golden State Warriors Coach Mark Jackson employed a game-long plan of intentionally fouling Dwight Howard, a notoriously poor free throw shooter who was otherwise destroying Golden State's interior defense.

The manga list is in flux this week, with seven newcomers. They include regulars on the list, like the latest volume of "Naruto," about the ninja in training, which lands at No. 1. The other series involve battles ("Yu-Gi-Oh GX," at No. 2), pirates and treasures ("One Piece," at No. 3), werewolves and vampires ("Rosario+Vampire," Season II, at No. 4), a demon bridge ("Black Bird," at No. 5), romance ("Skip Beat!," at No. 6) and mourning ("Dengeki Daisy," at No. 10).

On Jan. 1, Rajon Rondo of the Celtics had 18 points, 14 rebounds and 11 assists in a win over the Wizards. Of the 158 games this season, that is the only triple-double recorded so far.

So much attention has been paid to "Pina," Wim Wenders's 3D homage to the choreographer Pina Bausch, that it's easy to overlook another documentary that is also competing for the Academy Award for foreign-language film. "José and Pilar," directed by Miguel Gonçalves Mendes, is Portugal's submission, and it too comes with an impressive pedigree. Co-produced by the directors Pedro Almodóvar and Fernando Meirelles ("City of God"), it examines the relationship of love and support that sustains José Saramago, the Portuguese novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1998, and his wife, Pilar del Rio, as Saramago battled to write one last novel before his death in 2010 at the age of 87. Mr. Gonçalves Mendes, 33, is in the United States this month for festival showings of the film and spoke by telephone from Palm Springs. Here is an edited version of what he had to say:

Current TV's audience is small -- very small. The channel's executives freely admit that in conversations, and will probably say so again on Friday when they hold a news conference with TV reporters gathered in Los Angeles.

India has long faced an uneasy tension between allowing free expression to its citizens and staunching sectarian violence among its people. It was one of the first countries to ban "The Satanic Verses" by Salman Rushdie. Lawsuits forced the Indian painter Maqbool Fida Husain to live in exile during the last several years of his life. An academic book about the 17th-century warrior known as Shivaji was banned for fear of offending Shivaji's modern-day fans, until the Supreme Court lifted the prohibition.

Tom Robbins has a terrific story in the magazine on Sunday about the making - and unmaking - of the '60s radical Judith Clark. Clark drove one of the getaway cars during the Brink's holdup in 1981 when two police officers and an armored-car guard were killed. Furious at a system that she thought was unjust, Clark refused to be represented in court, trumpeted revolutionary action and ended up with a 75-year sentence that she is still serving. Over many visits and phone conversations, Robbins explored Clark's life behind bars and her slow transformation from unrepentant young radical to a reflective, deeply regretful model inmate. Clark talks a great deal about the importance of her relationship with her daughter - who was 11 months old at the time of the crime - in changing her. And the role her parents played in nurturing that relationship.

Daniel Arsham is two parts artist, one part architect. As the co-founder, with Alex Mustonen, of the design firm Snarkitecture he has made his mark in the public realm with projects like "Goal Posts," which commemorates the former Miami Orange Bowl, and "Dig," an exhibition and performance at the Storefront for Art and Architecture in New York. Meanwhile, his art practice is thriving with collaborations with Merce Cunningham, Hedi Slimane and Jonah Bokaer, and his first solo show at L.A.'s OHWOW gallery, where, on Jan. 20, Arsham will present three new bodies of work, "the fall, the ball, and the wall." "Ball" refers to Arsham's recent and final collaboration with the Merce Cunningham group and includes one of Arsham's massive hanging Pixel Clouds. The "wall" alludes to Arsham's befuddling sculptures that appear to ooze from the surface of the wall. And the "fall" relates to structures that seemingly defy the laws of nature. "I'm trying to create a space where the architecture appears to be in movement," he explains, "as if it is in the process of forming or deforming itself."

Tooshie, the Paris-based swimwear line devoted to making bums look beautiful, has now partnered with A.P.C., the Francophile favorite, to create an 11-piece capsule collection. Included in the offering are powder blue trunks for men and this psychedelic one-piece for women. "I like the idea of an eccentric print on a very simple bathing suit," says A.P.C.'s designer Jean Touitou. "Often you see prints like this on terrible shiny materials. The idea was to find a nice matte one." As for the fit, Tooshie's designer Natascha Sayn Wittgenstein took care of that: "It's not about focusing on shapes - cover this, reveal that - but keeping it elegant with these small pieces of fabric," she says. Jump in!A.P.C + Tooshie swimsuit, $280. Go to apc.fr.

DHAKA, Bangladesh - Last month there was an extraordinary attack at the Dhaka Children's Hospital. One of the dozens of stray cats that call the hospital home reportedly walked into a neonatal ward, mounted a bed where a six-day-old girl was receiving phototherapy treatment for jaundice and tried to take her as prey. According to the Daily Star, the cat had pulled the newborn off her bed and onto the floor, and dragged her partway to the ward's open door before anyone noticed.

The president had the power to lawfully consider the Senate to be on break despite its “pro forma” sessions, a memorandum said.

A previously secret legal memorandum concluded that President Obama had the power to lawfully consider the Senate to be on a lengthy break – even though Congress contended otherwise – and make recess appointments.

LOS ANGELES- If you've been waiting to see Billy Crystal, last a movie lead nine years ago in ''Analyze That,'' back on the big screen, wait no more. Mr. Crystal, this year's Oscar host, will appear in a supporting role in ''Small Apartments,'' an indie film that will screen at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tx., during a film program that runs from March 9 through March 17, the festival announced on Thursday. Directed by Jonas Akerlund, ''Small Apartments'' is a comedy, based on a script and novel by Chris Millis, about a deadbeat who kills his landlord.

He is survived by daughters Melissa Lipson and Nicole Carpenter, grandchildren Casey, Cole and Zachary. Service Sunday at New Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus. In lieu of flowers, donations United Hospice of Rockland.

Formerly of Rockland Co., NY, later of Clearwater, FL, he was happy in his life and a first-class card counter. He is gone to soon and greatly missed. The Baker & Dickman Families

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Wednesday with a music review of a concert by the Amphion String Quartet, part of the New School's Schneider Concerts chamber music series, misidentified the site of the Tishman Auditorium, where the concert was held. It is at the New School, on West 12th Street in Manhattan -- not at Mannes College the New School for Music, which is on West 85th Street.

9:48 p.m. | Updated Patti Smith has canceled a private show she was going to perform for residents Thursday night at the Chelsea Hotel after some said they would not attend. Sam Himmelstein, a lawyer for the tenants' association at the hotel, said Ms. Smith called him on Thursday night to inform him of her decision.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the performance of Alabama quarterback A J McCarron in the Crimson Tide's victory over Louisiana State in the Bowl Championship Series title game on Monday night misspelled the surname of Alabama's best receiver, who left with an injury early in the game. He is Marquis Maze, not Mays.

In a move unusual by Broadway standards, the producers of the new musical ''Leap of Faith'' said on Thursday that the show would begin performances on April 3 at the St. James Theater, now home to the Harry Connick Jr. musical ''On a Clear Day You Can See Forever.'' Broadway producers usually delay such announcements until a couple of days after the current show has posted a closing notice, but in this case the ''Faith'' producers quickly announced their plans for the St. James, even as the producers of ''On a Clear Day'' were notifying cast members and investors. They did so because word has been spreading that their show would open at the St. James and that ''On a Clear Day'' would close. It will have played for two and a half months when it closes on Jan. 29. ''Leap of Faith'' will star Raúl Esparza as a con man who faces a Kansas sheriff (played by Jessica Phillips) as he tries to fleece townspeople. ... To no one's surprise, Disney Theatrical Productions has announced that Jeremy Jordan, who earned good notices when the musical ''Newsies'' played at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., last summer, will star in the Broadway version, opening at the Nederlander Theater on March 15. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Thursday about the barrage of attacks on Mitt Romney in South Carolina by other Republican presidential candidates misstated, at one point, part of the name of a ''super PAC'' supporting Newt Gingrich. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, the political action committee is Winning Our Future -- not Winning the Future. (That is a slogan the White House uses to promote President Obama's policies.)

GRUNTHER Howard B. M.D. Died January 11, 2012. We mourn the loss of a wonderful man and compassionate doctor, Howard Grunther. He has left behind his loving wife, Eileen, his cherished children, Richard, Scott and Lisa, and adored grandchildren, Sam, Adam, Amy and Benjamin. He will be remembered with love by his devoted sister and brother-in-law, and nieces and nephews. His many friends, colleagues and patients held him in the highest esteem for his loyalty, dedication and kindness. He was taken from us too soon and will never be forgotten. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Sunday at 11:15am.

The collapse of MF Global has wreaked havoc on farmers, ranchers and other investors who were clients of the brokerage firm, prompting a loud outcry over the disappearance of $1.2 billion in customer cash. But they are not the only ones to suffer. The financial information giant Bloomberg L.P. lost about 600 subscriptions to its computer terminals - which translates to nearly $1 million in monthly revenue - after MF Global filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 31. The sudden loss of business caused Bloomberg employees to miss their target sales by 12 percent in 2011, people briefed on the matter said, a shortfall that could take a toll on the firm's bonuses.

LOS ANGELES - It's not unusual for the subjects of documentaries to dislike what they see on screen, sometimes resorting to defamation lawsuits. A Florida time-share developer, David Siegel, is taking the unusual step of suing not over the content of a film about his family but over a written description of it. Mr. Siegel, a focus of ''The Queen of Versailles,'' about his construction of a 90,000-square-foot megamansion and close encounter with the recession, has filed a defamation suit in United States District Court in Orlando, Fla., against the Sundance Institute, the film's director, Lauren Greenfield, and her husband. At issue is a description of the film in a Sundance-issued news release in November.

An article on Monday about changes in the rules for a documentary feature film to qualify for an Academy Award misstated the surname of the chief operating officer of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at one point. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, he is Ric Robertson, not Roberts.
9:05 p.m. | Updated As American Airlines trudges through its bankruptcy proceedings, potential suitors are coming out of the woodwork.

Kenny Lao has the kinds of credentials - a master's in business administration from New York University and a former job as a Wall Street analyst - that might come in handy when pitching business to Goldman Sachs. But the only deals he had to offer Goldman were stuffed, steamed and served in packs of six.

BAIR--Charles K. January 11, 2012 in Myrtle Beach, SC. Survived by his second wife, Mary, daughters Susan Egan of Brooklyn and Elizabeth Bair of Groton, MA and son James Bair of Myrtle Beach. His career was in marine insurance in New York City.

GRUBER--Murray, 94, died on January 10, 2012. Trained as a pharmaceutical chemist, he was the founder of Dermik Labs and developed innovative products for the treatment of intractable skin problems. He was honored by the American Academy of Dermatology for his many contributions to the field. Murray was very philanthropic, endowing programs in cancer research and supporting many medical and Jewish causes. Beloved husband of Helen Gruber and the late Lila Gruber. Devoted father of Barry Gruber, Daryl Kulok, Sharon Draghi and the late Neil Molberger. Cherished grandfather of Charlie and Georgia Kulok and Benjamin and Nicolas Draghi. He will be sorely missed.

Representative Jerry Lewis of California, the Republican who has represented San Bernardino and the Redlands for 33 years in Congress, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of this term. ''After months of consultation with loved ones and family, my wife Arlene and I have decided to retire from public life,'' he said in a statement.

McKITRICK--Edyth Stevenson. Funeral services honoring Edyth McKitrick will be held on January 14, 2012 at 2:00pm at Grace Church in New York, on 10th Street and Broadway. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lewy Body Dementia Association, LBDA.org.

Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team - a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen - are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sunday's showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men - they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee - have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win. A Giants-Packers playoff game was even more improbable in 2008 than it was this season. For the Giants to get to Green Bay, they had to win road playoff games against Tampa Bay and heavily favored Dallas. So the idea of going to Green Bay wasn't even on my radar. Until the Giants beat the Cowboys, that is, and Wilson, my law school roommate, called to say he had an extra ticket. Luckily my wife understood, and I was able to find a Sunday morning flight that got me into Milwaukee in time to drive to Green Bay with Wilson, his wife, Lisa, and one of her good friends.

JAFFIN--Charles L.,of Princeton, NJ, died on December 22, 2011. Mr. Jaffin was born in Brooklyn in 1928, attended the Bronx High School of Science and Princeton University, graduating with high honors in 1948. He attended Columbia Law School and was editor of the Law Review. He married Rosanna Webster in June 1952. Joined the firm of Carter, Ledyard & Millburn, then became a partner of Lewis & MacDonald. He helped orchestrate its merger with Battle Fowler. Mr. Jaffin is survived by his wife, and children: David W. Jaffin of Woodbury, Connecticut; Jonathan H. Jaffin of Potomac, Maryland; Rhoda Murphy of Short Hills, NJ; Lora Peters of Baltimore, MD; and Katherine Gibson of North Scituate, RI; by 11 grandchildren; and by a brother, Richard Jaffin of Fort Lauderdale, FL. A memorial service is planned for Friday, January 13 at 11:00am at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, NJ. Donations can be made to The Institute for Advanced Study or the University Medical Center at Princeton Foundation.

An article on Thursday about covert actions to set back Iran's nuclear program misstated, in some editions, the title of an Iranian nuclear scientist who was killed in a car bombing on Wednesday in Tehran. The scientist, Mostafa Ahmadi Roshan, was deputy director -- not director -- of commercial affairs at the Natanz uranium enrichment site.

9 P.M. (13), 10 P.M. (49) LET ME DOWN EASY Anna Deavere Smith, below, examines human resilience through the lens of the national debate on health care in this ''Great Performances'' presentation, taped in February at Arena Stage in Washington. From a roster of 300 people interviewed on three continents Ms. Smith depicts 19 characters, including a rodeo bull rider, a New Orleans doctor during Hurricane Katrina, former Gov. Ann Richards of Texas and the cyclist Lance Armstrong. ''Let Me Down Easy'' was inspired by Ms. Smith's work at the Yale School of Medicine, where she was a visiting professor. ''Instead of devising an organized primer on issues pertaining to health care in America,'' Charles Isherwood wrote in The New York Times when he reviewed this one-woman show in October 2009, ''Ms. Smith has created a loosely framed but vivid compendium of life experienced at its extremes, drawn about equally from the suffering and the ministering sides of the story.'' 8 A.M. (TCM) THE APARTMENT (1960) Five Oscars -- including best picture, best director (Billy Wilder) and best screenplay (Wilder and I. A. L. Diamond) -- were bestowed on this romantic comedy starring Jack Lemmon as an aspiring executive who lets his bosses use his apartment for assignations, only to fall for the big chief's mistress (Shirley MacLaine, left with Lemmon). Lemmon and Ms. MacLaine also earned Oscar nominations. The film kicks off a daylong tribute to bachelorhood, which continues with ''Any Wednesday'' (1966), about a businessman (Dean Jones) who catches his boss (Jason Robards) keeping a mistress (Jane Fonda) in the company apartment, at 9:15; ''Sunday in New York'' (1963), about a philandering pilot (Cliff Robertson) who becomes moral when his sister (Ms. Fonda) contemplates a premarital fling, at 11:15; ''Boys' Night Out'' (1962), in which a sociology student (Kim Novak) works as a kept woman to four friends (James Garner, Tony Randall, Howard Duff and Howard Morris), at 1:15 p.m.; ''Bachelor in Paradise'' (1961), with Bob Hope as an author who seduces suburban women (Lana Turner and Paula Prentiss) for a new book, at 3:30; and ''The Tender Trap'' (1955), with Frank Sinatra as a swinging theater agent who finds love with an actress (Debbie Reynolds) immune to his charms, at 5:30.

KAPLAN--Dr. Louise J.,died of pancreatic cancer on Monday, January 9th at Beth Israel Hospital. Dr. Kaplan was a world-renowned psychoanalyst, author and lecturer, mother, grandmother, and dear friend to many. She lived in Greenwich Village for 50 years, many of them shared with her late husband, psychoanalyst Dr. Donald M. Kaplan, who passed away in 1994. In 1963, Louise edited The Domesday Dictionary, a pioneering collaboration between Donald and poet/ scholar Armand Schwerner. Louise graduated from Brooklyn College and earned a Ph.D. from New York University. A protege of Dr. Margaret Mahler, Louise played a key role in the Child Study Center at NYU. Dr. Kaplan published several books, including Oneness & Separateness, Female Perversions, No Voice is Ever Wholly Lost, and her most recent work, Cultures of Fetishism. Survived by her daughter, Ann E. Kaplan, and son, David A. Kaplan, as well as her grand-daughters Ariel (from Ann) and Marae (from David). Louise's immediate family includes her brother-in-law, Dr. Harvey Kaplan, daughter-in-law, Elaine Lacognata Kaplan, and niece, Caroline Kaplan. A gathering will be held on Sunday, January 22nd from 1-4pm. Contact Ann or David for details. In lieu of flowers or gifts, the family wishes that donations be sent to the Children's Museum of the Arts, www.cmany.org, where Louise's son is executive director.
HOGAN--Howard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Howard Hogan., associated with The New York Times from May 1, 1967 until retiring on July 1, 1983.

FOR those of us of a certain age it's black and white that defines our cultural imagination. The early and best Popeye cartoons (wonderfully animated by the Fleischer brothers) and the Three Stooges shorts were in black and white, as were the first and most resonant images of Sinatra, Elvis and the Beatles. And weekends meant diving into the delightful late-night abyss of monster movies like ''Them!'' and ''The Thing From Another World.'' And I don't know about you, but I (mostly) dream in black and white. Even our first forays into writing and drawing were in black and white (or black and buff, if your grammar school went for the cheap paper). We weren't quite Neanderthals smearing charcoal on limestone walls, but some of us sure looked as if we'd wrestled with our tooth-nibbled No. 2 pencils. Didn't every second-grade class have a kid nicknamed Smudge?

An article on Jan. 5 about the difficulty Americans face in rising through the economic ranks described incorrectly the concept of intergenerational income elasticity, used by economists to examine the persistence of income inequality across generations. When economists estimate the elasticity of father-son income to be 0.5, it means that for every 1 percent increase in a father's income, his sons' income can be expected to increase by about 0.5 percent. It does not mean that if one man earns $100,000 more than another, his sons would earn $50,000 more on average than the sons of the poorer man.

LONDON - The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Thursday that it would eliminate 3,500 jobs in its investment banking division over the next three years in response to volatility in global financial markets. The bank, in which the British government holds an 82 percent stake, plans to revamp its wholesale banking division, as well as seek buyers for unprofitable operations.

An article on Jan. 1 about Afghanistan's director of orphanages, who is trying to reform a system plagued by the country's corruption and infamous for its poor care of children, misstated the location of Badakhshan Province, where he visited one orphanage that housed 150 boys in 10 rooms. Badakhshan is in northeast Afghanistan, not northwest.

GRUBMAN-GRAHAM--Wallace K.,passed away peacefully in Concord, NH on January 6, 2012. Mr. Grubman-Graham was the devoted husband of 61 years to his loving wife Ruth Graham and the father of three sons, James Grubman (deceased), Steven Graham and Eric Grubman. He was born in New York City and attended Columbia University. He was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of National Starch and Chemical Company, and subsequently, Director of Unilever PLC. Wallace and his wife raised a family in Plainfield and Mendham, NJ, then lived for many years in London and Surrey, England. They most recently lived in Northwood, NH and Rockport, Maine. He is survived by his wife Ruth and sons Steven Graham of E. Longmeadow, MA and Eric Grubman of Summit, NJ; granddaughters Erika, Christine and Alison Graham; and grandsons James and Samuel Compton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Foundation of Massachusetts Eye and Ear, Inc., 243 Charles Street Boston, MA 02114 or online at: masseyeandear.org. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church in Summit, NJ on January 17th at 11am. For more complete information on services, please see the entry for Wallace K. Graham at: BaileyFuneralHomes.com
I'm not thinking about anything now. My child is dead. NGADOK, a woman in South Sudan whose 6-year-old son was killed by members of a rival tribe. [A8]

A television review on Thursday about a documentary on the West Memphis Three case, ''Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory'' on HBO, and a picture caption with it misspelled the given name of one of the men convicted of murdering three children in West Memphis, Ark., in 1993. He is Jessie Misskelley Jr., not Jesse.

Henrik Lundqvist, Marian Gaborik and Dan Girardi were selected to play in the All-Star Game on Jan. 27 in Ottawa.''It's a great reflection on the organization, top to bottom,''John Tortorella said. Girardi, a defense man who leads the league in ice time, joked that Tortorella -- named as one of the game's coaches -- might double-shift him if he coaches Girardi's squad. Knowing Girardi needs rest more than participation in an exhibition game, Tortorella joked, ''I probably won't play him.''

WASHINGTON - John R. Bolton, a neoconservative who served as President Bush's ambassador to the United Nations, endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Thursday. Mr. Bolton had toyed with the idea of running for president himself last year but never took any serious steps to do so. In a statement released by Mr. Romney's campaign, Mr. Bolton praised Mr. Romney's foreign policy views.
International ASIA BUYERS OF IRAN CRUDE

A few months into a DC Comics initiative under which the superhero publisher restarted its long-running series at issue No. 1, some of those narratives will go no further: the company announced on Thursday morning that it is canceling six of its comic books and introducing six new ones, keeping the total amount of its continuing titles at the magic number of 52. The comics that DC will cancel, effective in April, are ''Blackhawks,''''O.M.A.C.'', ''Men of War'' and ''Hawk and Dove,'' as well as ''Mister Terrific'' and ''Static Shock,'' which are among the rare mainstream titles to focus on African-American heroes.

The country music star Jason Aldean and the rapper Nicki Minaj will be among the first-time performers during the Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 12, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Thursday. Mr. Aldean and Ms. Minaj are nominated for several awards. They will be joined by Kelly Clarkson, Foo Fighters, Bruno Mars and Taylor Swift. There was no word in Thursday's announcement about whether Adele would perform during the ceremony, to be held at the Staples Center in Los Angeles and broadcast on CBS. She had the best selling album last year with ''21'' (XL/Columbia) and is nominated for six awards, including record, album and song of the year. But she underwent throat surgery last fall to stop bleeding in her vocal cords and her participation remains up in the air.

Robert Ballard has made quite a few notable discoveries in deep waters around the world in the last 27 years. But most people still want to hear him use the T-word. He will do it, as he did for about half an hour on Wednesday at the Explorers Club in Manhattan, but he does not have to like it. Indeed, the stated purpose of his appearance was to promote a coming exhibition in Mystic, Conn., that will be devoted to his discovery on Sept. 1, 1985, of the wreckage of that most famous of ocean liners. You know, the really big one. The one that hit an iceberg.

Bill Janklow, a four-term governor of South Dakota with a colorful and brash persona whose political career ended abruptly when, as a congressman, he was convicted of manslaughter for killing a motorcyclist while speeding, died on Thursday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 72. The cause was brain cancer, said Marshall Damgaard, a former aide.

Thomas Quasthoff, 52, the celebrated German bass-baritone renowned for his sensitive, expressive performances and deep artistic intelligence, says he is retiring from the concert stage. ''My health no longer allows me to live up to the high standard that I have always set for my art and myself,'' he said in a statement on his Web site. ''I owe a lot to this wonderful profession and leave without a trace of bitterness. On the contrary, I am looking forward to the new challenges that will now enter my life.''

Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some editions on Monday with the City Room column, about a fatal fire on a frigid day in 1912 at the headquarters of the Equitable Life Assurance Society in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to an image of the building shown on a rental circular. As noted at the top of the circular, it was from 1875; the circular did not show ''the building in 1892.''

An article on Dec. 29 about plans for American arms sales to Iraq misstated part of the name of a research and policy institute in Washington. It is the Center for Strategic and International Studies, not the Center for Security and International Studies.

Miguel Terekhov, a dancer with the two leading Ballets Russes troupes of the 1940s and '50s and a co-founder, with his wife, of the School of Dance at the University of Oklahoma, one of America's leading university dance programs, died on Jan. 3 at the home of a daughter in Richardson, Tex. He was 83 and lived in Oklahoma City. The cause was complications of fibrosis of the lungs, said Camille Hardy, associate professor in the School of Dance.

When big-name investors increase their personal stakes in stocks, the purchases can be a positive sign for the companies. Edward S. Lampert sent a murkier message this week after buying extra shares in Sears Holdings, the troubled retailer.
LUPPO--Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Luppo., associated with The New York Times from July 1, 1963 until retiring on March 30, 1997.

CHANGE OF PLANS The ING Group is abandoning plans for an initial public offering of its combined Asian and European businesses, citing turbulence in the equity markets. The firm, which said it was now considering a future sale of its Asian business, still plans to pursue a separate I.P.O. for its European arm. ''Given the uncertain economic outlook and turbulent financial markets, especially in Europe, ING has decided to explore other options for its Asian insurance and investment management business,'' Jan Hommen, above, the chief executive of ING, said in a statement. EVELYN M. RUSLI

GRUNTHER--Howard B. We deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, colleague, and former partner, Dr. Howard B. Grunther, a compassionate, gifted, and dedicated physician with whom we were associated in the practice of diagnostic medical imaging for over three decades. More than a colleague, Howard was a dear friend to each of us, an engaging and kind human being who endeared himself to his fellow physicians, our staff, and most significantly to his patients. He was a beacon who enlightened all by his medical knowledge, his clinical acumen, his personal and intellectual integrity, and, his devotion to his family, his friends, his colleagues and to his patients. New York Medical Imaging Associates Daniel Maklansky, M.D. Jerold Kurzban, M.D. Burton Cohen, M.D. Jerald Zimmer, M.D. Alain Hyman, M.D. Barry Berson, M.D. Joseph Maklansky, M.D.

GRUNTHER--Dr. Howard. We sadly mourn the passing of our dearest and most cherished friend Howard Grunther. He will always be remembered as one of the kindest and most compassionate people we will ever know. He captured the hearts of those who were fortunate enough to have known him and adored him. He was a dedicated husband, father, grandfather and an exceptional friend and physician. We love you and will miss you deeply. Harvey and Arlene Blau & Family

GRUNTHER--Howard. Our dearest brother-in-law and uncle was an ever-present and always dependable force in our lives. Quiet and thoughtful, he invariably found the right answer to difficult problems. Howard was admired by friends and colleagues who knew him for his intellect, sense of humor, and depth of character. We will remember him for his complete devotion to family and miss him profoundly. Karen and David, Andrew and Leslie, and Elissa and Evan.
LOS ANGELES - You might think that being a star, writer or director of a Golden Globe-nominated movie automatically means you get a seat to the big show on Sunday. Nope.

SUMTER, S.C. -- After a campaign event here on Saturday, a woman told Mitt Romney that she was jobless and broke. In response, Mr. Romney reached into his pocket and handed cash to the woman, Ruth Williams, 55, of Columbia.

It's hard to believe that anyone but scholars of modern literature or paid critics have read W.H. Auden's dramatic poem "The Age of Anxiety" all the way through, even though it won a Pulitzer Prize in 1948, the year after it was published. It is a difficult work - allusive, allegorical, at times surreal. But more to the point, it's boring. The characters meet, drink, talk and walk around; then they drink, talk and walk around some more. They do this for 138 pages; then they go home.

Apologists for rising inequality often argue that since most Americans' income has risen despite rising inequality, there's no reason to complain about inequality other than envy. So it's worth remembering that we used to expect economic growth to deliver large increases in real income, not just a bit of a rise that's accomplished in large part through longer working hours; and that a major reason so many have seen such small gains is that a large part of growth has been siphoned off to the very high end.

Salman Khan: Ormax Media, a leading research and consulting firm for the entertainment business released key findings of "Front Page," their annual report on movies and television. One of the key features of the report is the list of the top 10 male and female stars in Bollywood. Using a star tracking methodology, data was collected through the year from a sample of more than 30,000 moviegoers. The star rankings threw up a few surprises. Among the heroes, Salman Khan was, of course, the top choice for 2011. This is hardly unexpected since he single-handedly propelled two mediocre films - "Ready" and "Bodyguard" - to blockbuster status. But the surprise was how far ahead he is of the competition. He has a 47 percent share, which almost equals that of Shah Rukh Khan (27 percent) and Aamir Khan (22 percent) combined.

Jammu and Kashmir: An inquiry commission headed by a retired Supreme Court judge began a probe on Thursday, into the custodial death of Syed Mohammad Yousuf, a worker of the ruling state party, the National Conference. The commission has been asked to complete the inquiry within six weeks. The death of Mr. Yosuf in September had raised political controversy in the state (Kashmir Live).

India has long faced an uneasy tension between allowing free expression to its citizens and staunching sectarian violence among its people. Keith Urban will return to the stage for the first time since undergoing surgery on his vocal cords late last year when he sings at the Grand Ole Opry in February, the Opry announced Thursday. Mr. Urban has been forced to rest his voice since doctors at Vanderbilt University Medical Center removed a benign polyp from one of his vocal cords. Left untreated polyps can bleed when a singer is performing, leading to scarring on the vocal cords that can alter a voice's timbre. Mr. Urban postponed a Jan. 18 benefit concert for the Country Music Hall of Fame and rescheduled the tail end of his 2011 concert tour for later this year. His appearance at Ryman Auditorium in Nashville on Feb. 3 will be his first performance since he sang on a Christmas television special in mid-November, The Associated Press reported.

A news analysis article on Wednesday about the challenges facing Mitt Romney in the South Carolina primary misstated the history of Republicans who have won both of their party's first two nominating contests, in Iowa and New Hampshire. No non-incumbent Republican has done it since the Iowa caucuses became a key part of the campaign in the 1970s; it is not the case that it happened in 1976, when Gerald R. Ford won both Iowa and New Hampshire. (Though not elected to the presidency, he was indeed an incumbent that year.)

A Political Memo article on Thursday about Mitt Romney's speech after his New Hampshire primary victory on Tuesday quoted incorrectly from one of his comments. Referring to President Obama, Mr. Romney said, ''He wants to turn America into a European-style social welfare state'' -- not ''a European-style entitlement society,'' which is how the statement was rendered in the text of the speech released by the Romney campaign.

Saints (14-3) at 49ers (13-3) Saturday, 4:30 p.m. Line: Saints by 3.5 The heavily favored Saints traveled to the West Coast in last year's playoffs to face the Seahawks, the easy-to-overlook champions of the league's weakest conference. Seattle's passing game was a donkey cart compared to the Drew Brees Lamborghini, but the Seahawks made the most of their few assets: a bruising running back, a defense full of sure tacklers and a fiery coach, fresh from the college ranks, who provided an extra jolt of rah-rah motivation. Seattle stunned the defending-champion Saints, proving that discipline, determination and home-field advantage can still defeat one of the N.F.L.'s next-gen passing games. Once in a while, anyway.

The director John Doyle, who won a Tony Award in 2006 for his Broadway revival of the Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical ''Sweeney Todd,'' will mount the first New York revival of Mr. Sondheim's 1994 musical ''Passion'' at Classic Stage Company starting in February 2013, the Off Broadway theater announced on Friday. Mr. Doyle is known for having cast members play musical instruments on stage in place of a band, as he did in ''Sweeney Todd'' and his 2006 Broadway revival of Mr. Sondheim's ''Company,'' but a spokesman for Classic Stage said that Mr. Doyle was not expected to have his actors double as musicians for this production.

He was a dedicated husband, father, grandfather and an exceptional friend and physician. We love you and will miss you deeply. Harvey and Arlene Blau & Family
