Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Streit), devoted father of Frances, Emilie, Sarah Jane Grosbard, and the late Andrew, dear father-in-law of Alan Green, Bridget Murphy, Michael Grosbard and John Williams, adored grandfather of Isobel and Henry Green, Oliver and Benjamin Cohen, Lily and Lucy Grosbard and Summer and Lincoln Williams. Service Monday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to Bronx High School of Science, University of Pennsylvania or Columbia Law School.

HAAR--Professor Charles M. died January 10, in Miami, FL. Professor Haar was the Louis D. Brandeis Professor of Law at Harvard Law School where he taught for over half a century. A father of American Zoning and Land Use, he served in many presidential administrations and was responsible for President Johnson's fair housing legislation. Predeceased by his wife Suzanne Keller, he is survived by his first wife Natalie Zinn Haar, his children Jeremy Haar, Susan Eve Haar and Jonathan Haar and his grandchildren Jesse, Will, Adam Horowitz, and Yael Haar and Ayelet Haar. A private service will be followed by a memorial in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to The Jerusalem Foundation, Inc., 420 Lexington Avenue, Suite 1645, New York, NY, 10170.

Julie Andrews will direct a new musical, ''The Great American Mousical,'' based on the children's book of the same name that she wrote with her daughter, Emma Walton Hamilton. Goodspeed Musicals will put on a developmental production of the show on its second stage, the Norma Terris Theater in Chester, Conn., from Nov. 8 to Dec. 2, theater leaders are scheduled to announce on Saturday afternoon. Ms. Andrews, below, directed a version of ''The Boy Friend'' for Goodspeed in 2005, but this is her first time overseeing a new show. Zina Goldrich and Marcy Heisler will write the music and lyrics, Hunter Bell the book. Christopher Gattelli (''Godspell'') will do the choreography. Sets and costumes will be designed by Tony Walton, Ms. Andrews's former husband and Ms. Hamilton's father, who did the illustrations for the book, which came out in 2006. A New York Times review praised the book as an ''entertaining story about what happens when the leading lady of a new Broadway musical winds up in a Havahart trap before the premiere -- the lady being a pampered mouse named Adelaide.'' Ms. Andrews was traveling and unavailable for comment, according to Goodspeed. By e-mail Mr. Bell, best known for ''[title of show],'' described working with this ''Mary Poppins'' and ''Sound of Music'' star as ''so inspiring.'' ''Her work ethic and stamina are astounding,'' he said. ''And she makes a mean cup of tea!''

Matt Every produced one of the best rounds and the most memorable quotation of the second day of the Sony Open in Honolulu. Every, who carded a six-under-par 64 for a two-shot lead, was perhaps best known for a three-month tour suspension he received in 2010 after he was arrested during a tournament in July on a misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession. All charges were later dropped. Every explained Friday why he did not jettison the friends he was with at the time of his arrest. ''If one of my friends likes to smoke marijuana every now and then, I'm not going to say, 'Well, you can't be my friend anymore,' '' Every said. ''Honestly, man, I know more people who smoke marijuana than who don't smoke marijuana. I know that's probably not the politically correct thing to say, but it's the truth. It's not a big deal to me.''

BAIR--Charles K. January 11, 2012 in Myrtle Beach, SC. Survived by his second wife, Mary, daughters Susan Egan of Brooklyn and Elizabeth Bair of Groton, MA and son James Bair of Myrtle Beach. His career was in marine insurance in New York City.

This is a momentous day for the diverse people of Burma. And we will continue to support them and their efforts and to encourage their government to take bold steps. SECRETARY OF STATE HILLARYRODHAM CLINTON,on the move to normalize diplomatic relations between the United States and Myanmar following sweeping political reforms. [A1]

Last month ads started running in The Casper Star-Tribune newspaper in Wyoming asking for photographs and footage of former Vice President Dick Cheney, below, who lived in the state for years and maintains a home there. The solicitors are a team of filmmakers, led by R. J. Cutler, who are producing a film tentatively titled ''The World According to Dick Cheney.'' Showtime formally announced the project on Thursday and characterized it as part of a push to have premieres of standout documentaries on the channel. In a statement Mr. Cutler said the film would be balanced and multidimensional. ''Like it or not, we live in a world defined by the domestic and international vision of Dick Cheney -- perhaps the single most influential nonpresidential figure in American political history,'' he said. Showtime did not indicate when the film would be broadcast, but a producer told The Star-Tribune that it was scheduled for the fall.

KAPLAN--Dr. Louise J.,died of pancreatic cancer on Monday, January 9th at Beth Israel Hospital. Dr. Kaplan was a world-renowned psychoanalyst, author and lecturer, mother, grandmother, and dear friend to many. She lived in Greenwich Village for 50 years, many of them shared with her late husband, psychoanalyst Dr. Donald M. Kaplan, who passed away in 1994. In 1963, Louise edited The Domesday Dictionary, a pioneering collaboration between Donald and poet/ scholar Armand Schwerner. Louise graduated from Brooklyn College and earned a Ph.D. from New York University. A protege of Dr. Margaret Mahler, Louise played a key role in the Child Study Center at NYU. Dr. Kaplan published several books, including Oneness & Separateness, Female Perversions, No Voice is Ever Wholly Lost, and her most recent work, Cultures of Fetishism. Survived by her daughter, Ann E. Kaplan, and son, David A. Kaplan, as well as her grand-daughters Ariel (from Ann) and Marae (from David). Louise's immediate family includes her brother-in-law, Dr. Harvey Kaplan, daughter-in-law, Elaine Lacognata Kaplan, and niece, Caroline Kaplan. A gathering will be held on Sunday, January 22nd from 1-4pm. Contact Ann or David for details. In lieu of flowers or gifts, the family wishes that donations be sent to the Children's Museum of the Arts, www.cmany.org, where Louise's son is executive director.

An article in some editions on Nov. 12 about a woman whose home of 20 years was destroyed by a fire and who sought help from the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, a beneficiary of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misspelled her surname. She is Mariya Vakhlis, not Vaklis. The error, which was repeated in a picture caption, was pointed out last week by Ms. Vakhlis's caseworker.

GRUNTHER Howard B. M.D. Died January 11, 2012. We mourn the loss of a wonderful man and compassionate doctor, Howard Grunther. He has left behind his loving wife, Eileen, his cherished children, Richard, Scott and Lisa, and adored grandchildren, Sam, Adam, Amy and Benjamin. He will be remembered with love by his devoted sister and brother-in-law, and nieces and nephews. His many friends, colleagues and patients held him in the highest esteem for his loyalty, dedication and kindness. He was taken from us too soon and will never be forgotten. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Sunday at 11:15am.

It was a bold experiment. For the first time in the century-long history of New York City's 24-hour subway system, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was going to shut down large sections of an entire train line from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. for four nights in a row to let workers scrub down and spruce up the tracks. Transportation officials said it was the best alternative to their standard approach of sending workers in to repair tracks while the trains were still running, usually on weekends. Better, they argued, to do all the work at once rather than a little at a time. But transit officials did not know how much it would anger straphangers already filled with complaints about their mass transit system.

Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team - a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen - are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sunday's showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men - they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee - have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win. The weekend cannot come soon enough. There are a lot of thoughts racing through my head about the preparations, and many people have offered suggestions on what to do when we get there. One was my longtime tailgating bud Jerry Dougherty, who went to Lambeau three years ago.

An Associated Press article on Friday about sales of the cholesterol drug Lipitor referred imprecisely to a discount card that Pfizer is offering. While some patients will be able to get the drug with a $4 co-payment, not all will be eligible for such a discount because the card carries many restrictions.

The online activist group known as Anonymous, which has targeted opponents of the Occupy Wall Street movement and businesses that stopped providing services to WikiLeaks, has set its sights on a new adversary: media executives. In protest of antipiracy legislation currently being considered by Congress, the group has posted online documents that reveal personal information about Jeffrey L. Bewkes, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, and Sumner M. Redstone, who controls Viacom and the CBS Corporation. Those companies, like almost every major company in the media and entertainment industry, have championed the Stop Online Piracy Act, the House of Representatives bill, known as SOPA, and its related Senate bill, called Protect I.P.

The Westlake Chemical Corporation, a manufacturer of raw materials used in plastics, has made an unsolicited all-cash bid to acquire the Georgia Gulf Corporation, a commodity chemicals maker, for $30 a share. The deal, which values Georgia Gulf at around $1 billion, would create one of the largest manufacturers of olefins, vinyls and other materials used in construction and other industries. It represents a 23 percent premium over Georgia Gulf's stock price, which closed at $24.48 on Thursday.

Sidney Crosby skated Friday, his first time on ice since experiencing a recurrence of concussion symptoms after a game Dec. 5. After the Penguins' morning skate in Sunrise, Fla., he skated for 27 minutes and sounded afterward like a player whose return to the lineup is far from imminent. ''The symptoms are getting a lot better,'' Crosby told reporters after his non-contact workout. ''But no, I wouldn't say I'm symptom-free. I'm allowed to lightly exert. That's positive. When you're sitting home for a bit, it's nice the symptoms are better and it's nice to take that step on the ice. It felt good to be back out there. There were some restraints, but it's better than being on the bike. We'll see how it goes.''

BASS--Richard, 86, died on January 12, 2012 in Scottsdale, Arizona. Beloved husband of Elizabeth; loving father to Andrew, Dani, Peter, Robin and Steven, and devoted grandfather to Jordan, James, Isabel, Jacob, Sophie, Oliver and Annie. Dad was a gifted pediatrician in New York for over 40 years and adored by generations of parents and children. An avid and skilled photographer, enthusiastic tennis player and world traveler. An adventurous spirit who embraced all life had to offer, proud of his Jewish roots in Flatbush, and blessed with a wry sense of humor and the gentlest of souls. He will live in our hearts forever. Charitable contributions may be made in his memory to: Banner Alzheimer Institute, 901 E. Willetta Street, Phoenix, AZ 85005; or Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014.

Wall Street, more than three years after the financial crisis, has loosened its lending tap. Consumers, however, have yet to reap the benefits. Results announced on Friday by the nation's strongest and biggest bank by assets, JPMorgan Chase, point to a divided economy where big businesses are gaining ground while consumers still cannot find their footing.

WASHINGTON -- Both are Harvard-educated millionaires. Both have been criticized as elitist and technocratic. Both have struggled to handle the populist anger coursing through politics. In an election climate largely defined by the anxieties of the middle class, working people are now more likely than not to face a choice in November between two candidates who sometimes seem to have trouble relating to them.

COLUMBIA, S.C. - Real presidential candidates have real television ads. And now so does Stephen Colbert. The Comedy Central star and political satirist, who has been saying he is forming an ''exploratory committee for president of the United States of South Carolina,'' will begin advertising in Charleston. The amount of money he is spending to run the commercials is small - just $7,600 on one television station so far, according to someone who monitors political ads.

A federal judge in Virginia on Friday denied Rick Perry, Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum and Jon M. Huntsman Jr. spots on the state's presidential primary ballot. The judge, John A. Gibney Jr. of Federal District Court in Richmond, rejected the challenge by the candidates to the state's rules requiring the submission of 10,000 signatures.

Political polls offer one way of ranking how candidates are seen on issues. But there is another way, through campaign donations. Adam Bonica, a political scientist at Stanford, has devised away to rank candidates on issues using their political contributions as his measure.

Though the latest jobs report provided some reason for tempered optimism, older Americans who find themselves unemployed are typically out of work much longer than their younger peers. And that can make the road to retirement much more challenging. So in this week's Your Money column, I took a look at some of the tricks that older Americans might use to tide them over financially until they find work or manage to eke their way to retirement.

Adele is widely predicted to sweep the Grammy Awards next month. But the question on every tongue in the music industry is whether she will also perform. So far there is no official word, and some have placed odds against it since Adele has not performed anywhere since having throat surgery in November. But as the Magic 8 Ball said, signs point to yes.

On Friday, Mitt Romney's campaign released a television ad in South Carolina to combat growing attacks on his career as a corporate buyout specialist at Bain Capital. The 30-second spot, titled ''Bright Future,'' is the first Romney campaign ad to address directly his record in the private sector.

Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 20 about deliberations by Pakistan's Supreme Court on whether to open an investigation into a memo suggesting a power struggle between the civilian government and the military overstated the influence that the ruling Pakistan Peoples Party has over the city of Karachi. While the party has a powerful base in Sindh Province, of which Karachi is the capital, the city is under the sway of a different party, the Muttahida Qaumi Movement.

8 P.M. (TCM) STARRING SPENCER TRACY Katharine Hepburn, who starred in nine films with Tracy and had a relationship with him for 25 years, called him ''the greatest movie actor'' and said that she had heard that Laurence Olivier, Lee Strasberg and David Lean agreed. Tracy seemed a natural on the screen and would advise young actors, ''Never let them catch you at it'' and ''Show up on time, know your lines and don't bump into the furniture.'' But if acting was easy, life was not. Born in 1900, Tracy died at 67 after years of depression and alcoholism, and the cause of his afflictions was never clear to those closest to him. Hepburn surmised it was his Roman Catholic guilt. Tracy never divorced his wife, and he and Hepburn were able to keep their liaison private with the cooperation of the news media. Tracy was nominated for nine Oscars, including a posthumous nod for ''Guess Who's Coming to Dinner,'' which he finished only 15 days before dying of a heart attack; he won for ''Captains Courageous'' and ''Boys Town.'' This tribute begins with ''Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo'' (1944), about the first American strike on Japan in retaliation for the bombing of Pearl Harbor. It continues with ''Adam's Rib'' (1949), with Tracy and Hepburn, above, as husband-and-wife lawyers on opposite sides of an explosive case, at 10:30; ''The Last Hurrah'' (1958), about a longtime mayor up for re-election, at 12:15 a.m.; ''Father's Little Dividend'' (1951), the sequel to ''Father of the Bride,'' in which Tracy's curmudgeonly patriarch copes with becoming a grandfather, at 2:30; and ''Cass Timberlane'' (1947), about an aging judge who sets tongues wagging when he marries a young beauty (Lana Turner) from the wrong side of the tracks, at 4. NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Newton N. Minow, the Federal Communications Commission chairman under President John F. Kennedy, discusses his 1961 speech to the National Association of Broadcasters in which he called American television ''a vast wasteland.''

The videographer for a youth orchestra at the New England Conservatory in Boston is a sex offender who was convicted of abusing a minor in 1994 and has been banned from the conservatory, the school said on Friday. The orchestra's longtime conductor, Benjamin Zander, above, who is also a motivational speaker and the conductor of the Boston Philharmonic, said he had been fired for hiring the videographer, Peter E. Benjamin, The Boston Globe reported. The conservatory acknowledged that Mr. Zander, 72, stopped working there on Thursday, the day it said a ''senior member of the faculty'' had been disciplined for hiring Mr. Benjamin. It did not identify the faculty member, but The Globe said it was Mr. Zander. Mr. Zander conducted the Youth Philharmonic Orchestra, which is part of the conservatory's preparatory division, serving students ages 5 to 18. A letter went out to 6,500 parents of past and present students of the prep school describing the matter so they could ask their children about any incidents. None were reported. Mr. Benjamin was banned from the conservatory, said a spokeswoman, Karen Schwartzman. He also recorded a class taught by Mr. Zander at the Walnut Hill School, an affiliate of the conservatory in Natick, Mass., she said. In December, she said, someone reported his presence at the conservatory. He had been videotaping the orchestra since about 2002. Mr. Zander did not respond to a phone message left at his office on Friday. ''It's a tragedy, an absolute tragedy, that I've been fired for an absolute nothing,'' he told The Globe. He said Mr. Benjamin's conviction had come nearly 20 years ago. ''He's been blameless for 20 years,'' Mr. Zander added. Mr. Benjamin told The Associated Press that Mr. Zander's reported firing was ''a huge overreaction.''
COHEN--Eileen S. Missing you even more on your birthday. We are grateful for your constant and unconditional love and support.

A paint-flecked floor is Nelson Seda's stage. When the weather is too cold or wet, he clears the chairs from his bedroom, turns up the music and dances, his arms and legs a blur of impossibly graceful angles. An hour later, he may pick up his markers and draw - on canvases, old posters, shoeboxes, anything. And for good measure, he might end the day freestyle rapping. Nelson is a young man possessed - in every sense - of a singular idea. For him, the various aspects of hip-hop have become touchstones, inspiring him to push himself and share his art with others at workshops, after-school centers and parks. Only 20 years old, he's always being told that he was born 25 years too late for the culture's heyday.

Updated, 10:07 p.m. | Two police officers shined a searchlight behind the single-family home in East New York, Brooklyn, on Thursday night, authorities said, and found a ''highly anxious'' woman flailing her arms inside a Chevrolet Tahoe. It was the same woman whose rapid-fire calls to 911 had reported a home invasion. Her boyfriend, Dale Ogarro, had been grabbed by two armed men wearing hoods, masks and latex gloves and led - gun to his head - into his residence in the basement of the home, on Schenck Avenue.

CAREY--William Polk. The Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York records with great sadness the passing of William Polk Carey. A former Governor of our Society, Bill was known for his generous support and valued leadership. He was instrumental in helping to establish our Educational Endowment Fund which will have a lasting effect on future generations. A proud 11th generation descendant of Samuel Fuller, Bill wears our Mayflower tie in his press photo. He will be greatly missed.

As 1862 dawned, the Union's military fortunes appeared decidedly grim. Defeats like those suffered at Bull Run and Ball's Bluff, as well as the growing realization that Gen. George McClellan was at best a reluctant warrior, gave rise to a growing claque of congressional critics. On Dec. 10, 1861, they had established the Joint Committee on the Conduct of the War, designed to examine every aspect of the war effort and empowered to "send for person and papers" as needed. Far from being a dispassionate check on the Executive Branch, however, the committee was, from the very beginning, a tool for partisan politics, a weapon forged out of, in Senator Charles Sumner's words, "a strong desire to hold someone responsible" for the Union Army's recent misfortunes.

More than a few eyebrows were raised when the Hollywood Foreign Press Association invited Ricky Gervais back to host the Golden Globes tonight. You may remember the kerfuffle that resulted the last time he emceed ceremonies and offended a few celebrities in the room. Or maybe they weren't entirely offended, as our colleague Dave Itzkoff writes in his profile of the comedian. He adds that Mr. Gervais "has become the entertainment industry's favorite irreverent person, because he manages to be irreverent in such a deeply reverent way."

Might the miserly use of neural resources be one of the essential keys to understanding how brains make sense of the world? Some recent work in computational and cognitive neuroscience suggests that it is indeed the frugal use of our native neural capacity (the inventive use of restricted "neural bandwidth," if you will) that explains how brains like ours so elegantly make sense of noisy and ambiguous sensory input. That same story suggests, intriguingly, that perception, understanding and imagination, which we might intuitively consider to be three distinct chunks of our mental machinery, are inextricably tied together as simultaneous results of a single underlying strategy known as "predictive coding." This strategy saves on bandwidth using (who would have guessed it?) one of the many technical wheezes that enable us to economically store and transmit pictures, sounds and videos using formats such as JPEG and MP3.

Alan Krueger, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers -- who is not only a colleague of mine at Princeton, but gets a lot of my mail and vice versa -- gave a very informative speech on inequality last week that should have received more press than it did. Much of it was stuff that inequality mavens already know, but he had one striking result that was what I suspected but hadn't seen demonstrated: a clear negative relationship between inequality at a point in time and intergenerational social mobility.

Norman Siegel and Herbert Teitelbaum were classmates at New York University law school. Mr. Siegel is married to Saralee Evans, a former acting State Supreme Court justice. Their wedding ceremony was performed by Emily Jane Goodman, a Supreme Court justice. They all come from Brooklyn. Collectively, they have 161 years of legal experience and a record of impact in and out of court. And now, when most of their contemporaries are contemplating retirement or have already quit, the four of them are starting a new law firm.

During sudden bursts of activity, bottlenecks occur as traffic moves among dense clusters of servers in data centers. Typically, the servers are stacked one on top of another in rack after rack - and are connected by switches, routers and cables. To better handle the congestion, researchers are testing a shortcut that does not involve costly rewiring. They are experimenting with wireless links, mounted atop the server racks, to supply extra bandwidth for moving data along during crunch times, Anne Eisenberg reports in The New York Times. Read more in the Novelties column. »

Jon Hamm has been a bad boy, and not just in his scenes in "Bridesmaids." A few days ago Mr. Hamm let it slip in a podcast interview that the long-awaited season premiere of "Mad Men," the AMC period drama on which he plays the advertising executive Don Draper, would be shown on March 25. Though a few days of radio silence from the network followed Mr. Hamm can now wipe those beads of sweat from his Brylcreemed brow: AMC has confirmed the news, announcing over the weekend that Season 5 of "Mad Men" would begin on that date, with a two-hour episode written by the series' creator, Matthew Weiner, and directed by Jennifer Getzinger, who directed the episode "The Suitcase" last season.

In an analysis of the comparative strengths of political parties in Uttar Pradesh, Outlook magazine finds that no clear majority emerges and predicts that the state elections scheduled for February may end in a hung verdict. Despite the eunuchs being a marginalized community, a local trader said, "a hijra is better than all of these useless parties," suggesting a sense of despair about the current crop of political candidates.

When 907 Fifth Avenue was built in 1915, it was one of the first grand limestone apartment houses to open along Central Park, and it filled quickly with names that routinely graced the society pages. Today it is still considered one of the city's most elegant prewar co-ops. Residents have included Martha Stewart and Huguette Clark, the reclusive heiress who died last spring and who owned a floor and a half in the building.

Facebook suggested I friend him. I guided the mouse toward his photo, and the little pointed hand hovered over his face. Fear and anger swelled up but curiosity won out and I clicked ''Add Friend.'' He accepted within minutes. Stunned, I wondered if he had forgotten raping me, or if he thought I had. In 1973, I was a lonely 13-year-old nerd living on Long Island. He was in a crowd that hung out in a parking lot behind the school, sprawling over the cement steps like bored cats on a sofa. One afternoon, making sure my long hair covered the blemish on my cheek, I went over and said, ''Hi.''

Lavish dining programs in first-class cabins on long-haul flights are nothing new, but Etihad Airways, based in Abu Dhabi, has recently gone one step further by bringing chefs from top-rated restaurants on board to prepare meals in the air. The airline has recruited 100 chefs from restaurants including the Fat Duck in Bray, England, and the Fenix Restaurant in Melbourne, Australia, to make meals for fliers who wish to forgo the premade items on the menu.

Longtime devotees of the sportswear designer Tony Melillo will be pleased to learn that, after roughly a three-year absence, his precision-cut T-shirts will be returning to stores next month through an exclusive arrangement with Barneys New York. Since the start of his original Nova USA collection 15 years ago, as well as during his 2003 collaboration with Generra and at least two earlier attempts to develop a signature brand, Mr. Melillo has been a friend to people who care about where the sleeves and hems of their basics fall on bodies with good biceps. (Some physically fit customers have been known to hold onto Mr. Melillo's T-shirts for years, parceling their wear selectively to make them last longer.)

While many North American ski resorts are suffering from a lack of early-season snowfall (see the Practical Traveler column, Page 3), some, like Grand Targhee in Wyoming, have enough to share. Thanks to its advantageous location in the Teton Valley, the resort has had 142 inches of snow since early November and is offering free skiing and snowboarding to lodge guests with a 2012 season pass to any ski resort in the United States or Canada. A reservation of three or more nights is required and all guests must present their season passes at check-in.

HAAR--Professor Charles M. died January 10, in Miami, FL. Professor Haar was the Louis D. Brandeis Professor of Law at Harvard Law School where he taught for over half a century. A father of American Zoning and Land Use, he served in many presidential administrations and was responsible for President Johnson's fair housing legislation. Predeceased by his wife Suzanne Keller, he is survived by his first wife Natalie Zinn Haar, his children Jeremy Haar, Susan Eve Haar and Jonathan Haar and his grandchildren Jesse, Will, Adam Horowitz, and Yael Haar and Ayelet Haar. A private service will be followed by a memorial in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to The Jerusalem Foundation, Inc., 420 Lexington Avenue, Suite 1645, New York, NY, 10170.

A report in some editions of the Slap Shot hockey column last Sunday about a decision by the National Hockey League Players' Association to reject the N.H.L.'s realignment plan summarized the league's proposal incorrectly. The league wants two conferences of eight teams and two conferences of seven teams, for a total of 30 teams -- not conferences of six and seven teams.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments on Michael Kimmelman's column about parking lots. ''My favorite place in Wrightsville Beach, N.C., is a crummy cinderblock hotel that overlooks the central public parking lot. If you take a second-floor room overlooking the parking lot, you can see the world: people change their clothes there, have parties, hopefully prepare fishing rods, children run around, there are clandestine assignations (not very clandestine since everyone can see them).''

Monument Valley, Ariz., June 23, 2011 This is my mom, Eva Grayzel, jumping for joy as the sun was setting. She is a 13-year survivor of Stage 4 tongue cancer. After getting a second chance at life, she now shares her personal survival story by traveling around the globe and educating people about oral cancer. This photo was taken during a weeklong road trip with my aunt and sister. My mom always plans side trips during her travel so she can visit new places and find inspiration. JEREMY COHEN, New York City

GRUNTHER--Dr. Howard. We sadly mourn the passing of our dearest and most cherished friend Howard Grunther. He will always be remembered as one of the kindest and most compassionate people we will ever know. He captured the hearts of those who were fortunate enough to have known him and adored him. He was a dedicated husband, father, grandfather and an exceptional friend and physician. We love you and will miss you deeply. Harvey and Arlene Blau & Family

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Why Wait to Watch Instant Replay?'' Jan. 6: Just as the Securities Exchange Commission has rules against insider trading, the N.F.L. should consider instituting rules against insider viewing during a play. Judi F. Reiss

''GUARANTEED to Last: L. L. Bean's Century of Outfitting America'' (Melcher Media, $29.95) celebrates the centennial of that company founded by the intrepid outdoorsman Leon Leonwood Bean and the footwear that started it all: the Maine Hunting Shoe. After combining a rubber galosh with the top of a leather hunting boot (a ''You got your chocolate in my peanut butter'' moment), L. L. hit upon a flexible, lightweight boot for hunters that quickly found an audience beyond the backwoods. L. L. Bean was a pioneer of direct marketing, and his first typewritten testimonials quickly evolved into illustrated catalogs as the range of merchandise grew. Many tote bags, chamois shirts, field coats and Wicked Good Slippers later, pilgrimages to the original factory store in Freeport, Me., continue to be a rite of passage for Beaniacs everywhere. BRUCE PASK

MITT ROMNEY may not have officially clinched the Republican nomination, but his victory has never really been in doubt. Nor has his viability in November: the most fanatical Tea Partiers are not about to withhold their votes and risk allowing President Obama to be re-elected. Pundits have already begun the endless debate over whether Mr. Romney's wealth and religion are hindrances or assets. But there has yet to be any discussion over the one quality that has subtly fueled his candidacy thus far and could well put him over the top in the fall: his race. The simple, impolitely stated fact is that Mitt Romney is the whitest white man to run for president in recent memory.

Breton Fisher--June, of Santa Barbara, CA.,died unexpectedly last weekend. She was the wife of the late J. Robert Breton and Maurice L. Fisher. Born in New York City on March 27, 1927, she was the daughter of the late Henry Goldman Jr. and Adrienne (Straus) Goldman. A graduate of the Brearley School, she attended Bryn Mawr. After college, she worked for a fashion copywriter, then as a lyricist and in public relations. After her first marriage to Mr. Breton, a Broadway actor who went on to become a television producer and director, she moved to Mamaroneck, NY, and then to Greenwich, Conn. After Mr. Breton died, she and Mr. Fisher formed Ridgewater Partners, and for many years, they designed and escorted luxury golf trips around the world. Mrs. Fisher was an inveterate traveler, avid golfer and bridge player. But her greatest accomplishment was achieved while she was in her 80s. What started out as a story for family turned into the book, "When Money Was In Fashion: Henry Goldman, Goldman Sachs and the Founding of Wall Street," published in 2010. The book was a biography of her grandfather, Henry Goldman, the son of the founder of Goldman Sachs. She is survived by three daughters, Tracy Breton, of Cranston, RI, Brooke Breton, of Pacific Palisades, CA, and Cynthia Breton of Burlington, VT; a son, Taylor Breton, of Florida; a grandson, Devon Breton Pakozdi; and a brother, Henry Goldman of Colorado Springs, CO.

KAMENETZKI--Myra, 90, devoted Italian teacher and bridge player, died after a brief illness. Born in Riga in 1921, Lally, (as she was always known) spent her childhood in Italy, leaving in 1941 because of fascist racial laws. She helped support her parents, ran the New York office of the Italian pharmaceutical company, Carlo Erba and pursued graduate work in Italian literature. She taught Italian at Hunter College and ran an Italian poetry recitation competition with tireless enthusiasm for more than thirty years. She taught privately for many years after her retirement, while doggedly pursuing the elusive goal of bridge Life Master. She was predeceased by her brother, Michael Ugo Stille and leaves behind generations of loyal students and niece, Lucy Stille, literary agent, and nephew, Alexander Stille, journalist and writer, who was also one of her students. We will miss Lally's fabulous memory, family stories and her ferocious spirit when playing Scopa.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Sculptured by Weights and a Strict Vegan Diet,'' Jan. 5: As a vegan art student, I am interested in the cultural dialogue surrounding personal choice and its physical embodiment, like abstaining from meat while seeking to shape the body and engage in social communities. Too often such engagement remains unknown or becomes misunderstood through poor representation, so your timely report is another step toward true discussion and provides a valuable resource for those unfamiliar with the possibilities of a plant-based diet.

''We are making our money here in the U.S., and we're going to have to keep doing it.'' Mark L. Reuss, president of General Motors' North American division. After turning out new small cars and mainstream sport utility vehicles last year, G.M. is focusing on its higher-profit luxury models for its Buick and Cadillac divisions. ''We're just riding that 'Downton Abbey' wave.'' Stephen Morrison, the editor in chief and associate publisher of Penguin Books. The British melodrama ''Downton Abbey,'' already the darling of American public television, has become a marketing tool for booksellers and publishers, who are rushing to print books that take readers back to Edwardian and wartime England.

A town house on Central Park West that comes with its own 60-foot lap pool and that sold for $22.375 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city public records. Although it is not unusual for town houses on the East Side to sell for $20 million or more, the sale of 247 Central Park West was a record price for a single-family town house on the Upper West Side. It is one of just a handful of single-family homes that face the park. The previous record was $19.39 million in 2010 for 26 West 76th Street, according to Gregory J. Heym, the chief economist at Terra Holdings.

An article in some editions last Sunday about catcher Jorge Posada's plans to retire after 17 years with the Yankees misidentified the site of the baseball game against the Red Sox on May 14 when he asked not to be in the lineup after learning he had been dropped to ninth in the batting order. The game was in New York, not in Boston.

CHASIN--Stephen Lee, Died on January 12, 2012 Beloved husband, devoted father of Philip, Rebecca and Brian and Grandfather to Vincent. He was a highly successful entrepreneur and the co-founder of one of the most successful demolition and environmental remediation firms in the country. He was an avid skier, fishermen, yachtsman, scuba diver and Golfer. His magnificent spirit, generous heart and friendship filled the lives of us all. He will live in our hearts forever. Funeral service on Tuesday 11:30am at Schwartz Brothers Forest Hills, NY.

KANTOR--Norman. 1927 2012. Born and raised in Plainfield, NJ to Abraham and Rose Kantor. He graduated from Plainfield High School in 43 and Cornell University in '47. He also played football (QB) at Georgia Tech for a year during ROTC in 45 (not the Bulldogs best year). He was a long-time resident of Westfield, NJ and New York City. He is predeceased by his wife Margaretha of 42 years and his brother, Marvin and two sisters, Miriam and Leonore. He is survived by his two children, Steven Kantor (who resides with his wife Jane in New York City) and Clarissa Taylor (who resides with her husband BJ in Westfield). He also is survived by his four grandchildren who he adored Chloe, Caroline, Ben and Jack as well as his devoted friend of recent years Andrea Berger. In 1960, Norm took over United Supply Co. from his father and grew it into the largest family-owned HVAC and plumbing supply house in NJ. Known nationally throughout the industry as a great innovator, Norm introduced the first retail plumbing showrooms, Kitchen & BathWorks, in 1982. The company is celebrating 100 years of success and continues to be owned and run by the family an accomplishment in which he took great pride. But his priorities were never financial success, they were much richer goals and, by example, he taught us all. He saw everyone as a friend and treated everyone with dignity, respect and empathy. Each person he met was important to him and if they had time to listen, he had a story for them sometimes even if they didn't have time to listen. Optimism was his religion. He taught us life was a wonderful gift and each day was another chance to do good and enjoy it. He put family and friends first and as everyone he met quickly became his friend, his life was busy and full until his last months. Norm also was gifted with many passions and talents. A jack-of-all-trades, he was an accomplished fine artist and sculptor, a film producer (Pretty Boy Floyd, Black Like Me), and a great writer who never published. He had a great love for and knowledge of tennis and Shakespeare. He was a memorable dancer (crazy legs) but not a great singer although that never stopped him. He was truly one of those rare people who lived his life the way we all hope to, but rarely do with unstoppable optimism, an undeniably warm smile and happy laughter through thick and thin. This was his gift to us all. We love you Dad

His back, a chronic but manageable concern for years, has been troubling him again, but Roger Federer is in Melbourne with every intent of returning to the court and playing in his 49th consecutive Grand Slam tournament. The record, held by the former South African player Wayne Ferreira, stands at 56. But Federer is a serial record breaker and, now third on this all-time list, just might break another one.

FRISCHER--Sylvia, 97, of New York City, passed away following a wonderful life marked by adoring husbands, Martin Asnin and Murray Frischer, rewarding careers, worldwide travel, feistiness and stunning beauty. Those who hold her dear include her daughter Karen Asnin Whitby, of whom she was forever proud, her cherished son-in-law Paul Whitby, and her loving niece Nancy Fisher. Until her last days, when asked if she enjoyed life, her response was "absolutely."

Gallagher and Sons, 31 Arch Street, Greenwhich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent in his honor to your local hospice charities.

''I MAY be their most passionate member,'' the snow-white-haired designer Natalie Chanin said of the Southern Foodways Alliance, a nonprofit group dedicated to preserving the culinary heritage of the American South. For years, it has been Ms. Chanin's calling to preserve the textile traditions of Florence, Ala., with her clothing line, Alabama Chanin. So, when the organization's director, John T. Edge, who writes the United Tastes column for The Times, approached her about doing a collaborative project, hand-sewn quilts seemed an obvious departure. Auctioned off at the Taste of the South event at bucolic Blackberry Farm in Tennessee, this particular blanket features the words of Roosevelt Scott of Scott's Bar-B-Que in Hemingway, S.C.: ''Cut. Chop. Cook. It's all right here. In the wood.'' But it's just one of many. ''Sign me up for a baker's dozen,'' Ms. Chanin said when she joined up. More at southernfoodways.blogspot.com. STEPHANIE LACAVA

BUMSTED--William Joseph, died peacefully at his home in John's Island, Vero Beach, Florida on January 5, 2012. Deeply loved by his family, he is survived by his wife Gloria, his children from his late wife, Nancy: David Wentz Bumsted (Heather), Martha B. Zipp (Brian), two step-children Alexandra and Lloyd Nimetz, and five grandchildren: Phoebe and David Bumsted, Jr; William Bumsted O'Hearn, Elena and Jack Zipp. A 1940 graduate of Dartmouth College and a member of "the greatest generation," Mr. Bumsted served in the Pacific in the Army. He was born May 25, 1919 and started work at the international insurance brokerage firm Johnson and Higgins the day after Pearl Harbor. He became President of the Venezuelan office and later a Partner of the firm in New York, leading the International and Marine Cargo departments. An avid golfer, Mr. Bumsted was a member of Baltusrol and Pine Valley as well as the John's Island Club, and for many years the Lake Placid Club. He was President of the Lake Placid Educational Foundation and was active in the community of Lake Placid, NY, his spiritual home. An astute businessman with a keen wit and love for people, he captured the hearts of all whom he encountered. Filled with joy and goodness he has left each of us a better person. Memorials may be made to the VNA of Vero Beach, Florida or the SOA of Lake Placid, New York. The family invites you to share your fond memories in the guestbook on www.legacy.com.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the New Orleans Saints' 45-28 victory over the Detroit Lions in the N.F.L. playoffs, which helped erase the memory of the Saints' playoff loss at Seattle last season, misidentified the position of Matt Hasselbeck, who played for the Seahawks in last year's game. He is a quarterback, not a cornerback.

BERTELE--Edward A.,a decorated federal investigator and a World War II hero, died on Wednesday, December 28, 2011 of cerebrovascular disease. He was 91. He was a Veteran of World War II and received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star for leading a squad against enemy troops in the Battle of Hagenau, France in December 1944. He was a retired Special Investigator for both the U.S. Department of Treasury and Department of Justice. He started working as a federal agent in the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Internal Revenue Service, the forerunner of the BATFE, in 1953. He worked under cover for several months eventually smashing an illicit cartel with roots in New York City and North Carolina in 1962. He received a special award for bravery from the New York City Police Department for saving the lives of two city police officers in a civil unrest in Bedford-Stuyvesant in 1960. Mr. Bertele transferred to the Special Investigations Unit of the Immigration & Naturalization Service in 1963. Edward Anton Bertele was born in Jersey City, NJ on July 6, 1920. He was a graduate of Fordham University where he received a BA and of St. Johns University from where he earned a law degree. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Dorothy, and three children, Donna Distasio of Oceanview, DE, Dr. Terence Bertele of Washington, DC and Edward Bertele of Charleston, SC; five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
Proceedings against the chief justice, Renato C. Corona, have been criticized as politically motivated.
Film Neil Genzlinger

FOX--Everett (Ed) Allen, 77, of Manhattan, died Friday, December 30. Passionately engaged in his urban community and rigorously principled, Ed was a proud New York City social worker, activist and member of the Community Church of New York Unitarian Universalist. His wife, Suzanne Jones Fox, died in 1987, and Ed is survived by his two children, Cora Fox and Everett Fox; one granddaughter, Lily Fox; two sisters, Sarah Fox and Bobbe Gray; and his long-time friend, Claire Booss. We will miss his spirited love of beauty and his generous regard for all human beings. A memorial service will be held at the Community Church (40 E. 35th St., New York, NY 10016) on Sunday, January 22 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Community Church of New York or the Jane Addams-Hull House Museum (800 S. Halsted, Chicago, IL 60607).

The Look photo feature on Jan. 1, about Richard and Mildred Loving, an interracial married couple who sued to have miscegenation laws struck down,misstated the number of states in which interracial marriage was illegal in 1958, the year they married. It was 24 -- not 16, which was the number of states in which interracial marriage was illegal in 1967, the year the Supreme Court ruled on their case. The error also appeared in Mrs. Loving's obituary on May 6, 2008.

An article last Sunday on Gotham West, a planned residential development between 10th and 11th Avenues on the West Side of Manhattan, misstated the amount of retail space in the project. There will be 15,000 square feet of retail, not 1,700 square feet.

GRUNTHER--Dr. Howard. We mourn the loss of our dear friend, Dr. Howard Grunther. We have known him as a close friend to our family for more than 45 years. His absence will be felt deeply by all of the Unger family. Beth and Allen Unger
Pop Nate Chinen

AT Vail Mountain Ski Resort, the snow-making machines have been busy as Colorado contends with a below-normal snowpack. Keeping the snow ample is important to the ski industry, which generates revenue from lift tickets, ski instruction, equipment rental, food, lodging, retail outlets and activities like tubing. The Vail resort has invested millions in snow-making equipment, and employees have been working to keep as many trails open as possible. The most intense work occurs from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m., when temperatures are most favorable and guests are least inconvenienced. Employees were grateful when Mother Nature lent a hand just recently, dropping more than a foot of snow on the area -- at no charge.

TUBY--Evelyn (Menken), formerly of Great Neck, New York, suddenly on January 13, 2012, at 94. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Robert Tuby and loving sister of seven girls and two boys. Adoring mother of the late Joan Tuby Weinsier and of Suellen Tuby Globus. Cherished grandmother of Michael Weinsier, Wendy Segal, Tracy Nathanson, Daryl Eisenberg and Allison Wallach and dearly loved great-grandmother of Matthew, Jacqueline, Jake, Nicky, Jillian, Amanda, Charlie and Annie. Her natural exquisite internal and external beauty, proper lady like demeanor, articulate and always well read, glamorous Evelyn will be missed forever. She loved her family and we loved her! Sharp as a whip till the end, leaving us with such dignity, as she wished. She will be forever in our hearts. Funeral services private.

In this new column, T takes a series of snapshots from the art scene in Marfa, Tex. THE Foundation for Jammable Resources is an artist-collective-cum-band whose shows blend installation, punk and performance art. Its members -- many of whom hail from California or Texas and earn paychecks in restaurants -- have all been in Marfa, Tex., for about five years. John Rayburn, above left, and Carlos Lujan, second from left, have played together for 12 years and met Anthony DeSimone, above right, four years ago in the local scene. They started jamming together at parties, realized they had a lot in common and ultimately settled any remaining differences in a drum war in front of the Ballroom, a local cultural arts space, late one night during an open-house weekend hosted by Chinati, the foundation created by the artist Donald Judd. They started playing and experimenting with Mr. Rayburn and decided they liked what they were doing and, along with their ''mascot,'' John C., second from right, are now a Marfa fixture. A selection of tracks is at soundcloud.com/ffjr.

8 P.M. (NBC) THE 69TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Ricky Gervais, above, returns for his third stint as host of these awards -- considered predictors of the Oscars -- sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live from the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles. In the motion picture drama division, nominees include ''The Descendants,'' ''The Help,'' ''Hugo,'' ''The Ides of March,'' ''Moneyball'' and ''War Horse'' for best picture; Glenn Close, Viola Davis, Rooney Mara, Meryl Streep and Tilda Swinton for best actress; and George Clooney, Leonardo DiCaprio, Michael Fassbender, Ryan Gosling and Brad Pitt for best actor. In the comedy or musical division, the nominees are ''50/50,'' ''The Artist,'' ''Bridesmaids,'' ''Midnight in Paris'' and ''My Week With Marilyn'' for best picture; Jodie Foster, Charlize Theron, Kristen Wiig, Michelle Williams and Kate Winslet for best actress; and Jean Dujardin, Brendan Gleeson, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ryan Gosling and Owen Wilson for best actor. Morgan Freeman will receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award. Awards will also be handed out for television work. Coverage from the red carpet begins at 5 on E! and at 7 on NBC; E! will visit after-parties at 11. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley speaks with the Republican presidential candidate Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'' at 10 on ABC. The comedian Stephen Colbert is also a guest.

GRUBER--Murray, 94, died on January 10, 2012. Trained as a pharmaceutical chemist, he was the founder of Dermik Labs and developed innovative products for the treatment of intractable skin problems. He was honored by the American Academy of Dermatology for his many contributions to the field. Murray was very philanthropic, endowing programs in cancer research and supporting many medical and Jewish causes. Beloved husband of Helen Gruber and the late Lila Gruber. Devoted father of Barry Gruber, Daryl Kulok, Sharon Draghi and the late Neil Molberger. Cherished grandfather of Charlie and Georgia Kulok and Benjamin and Nicolas Draghi. He will be sorely missed.

An article in some editions last Sunday about President Obama's decision to use his recess appointment power, despite the Senate's pro forma session, misidentified the federal court to which he nominated Caitlin J. Halligan, whose confirmation was filibustered. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, not the Federal District Court in Washington.

CAREY--William Polk. The Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York records with great sadness the passing of William Polk Carey. A former Governor of our Society, Bill was known for his generous support and valued leadership. He was instrumental in helping to establish our Educational Endowment Fund which will have a lasting effect on future generations. A proud 11th generation descendant of Samuel Fuller, Bill wears our Mayflower tie in his press photo. He will be greatly missed.
SAUTTER--Lois. I mourn the death of my trusted personal assistant for 25 years and a friend to all our family for almost 40. She was a wise and caring person. I will miss her. Harry Petchesky

COHEN--Richard G.,80, on January 12, 2012. Born in Brooklyn, graduate of Bronx High School of Science, Univ. of Pennsylvania and Columbia Law. Longtime tax attorney at the I.R.S. and in private practice. Served honorably in the U.S. Army Audit Agency. Lifelong Yankee fan. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Streit), devoted father of Frances, Emilie, Sarah Jane Grosbard, and the late Andrew, dear father-in-law of Alan Green, Bridget Murphy, Michael Grosbard and John Williams, adored grandfather of Isobel and Henry Green, Oliver and Benjamin Cohen, Lily and Lucy Grosbard and Summer and Lincoln Williams. Service Monday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to Bronx High School of Science, University of Pennsylvania or Columbia Law School.

PEOPLE don't just live in Dunbar Spring, they nest. In the Tucson neighborhood just north of downtown, yards bristle with salvaged scrap metal, along with solar panels and water harvesting tubes. Many houses resemble art installations. Dunbar Spring was Tucson's first black neighborhood; it is named after two prominent citizens: the African-American poet Paul Laurence Dunbar and the Swiss-born John Spring, who became Arizona's first bilingual public-school teacher in 1872. Today, it is a haven for artists, environmentalists and local foods activists. Despite all this activity, the neighborhood is serene: mesquite trees -- the product of regular community plantings -- droop over narrow sidewalks, which wind past painted murals; sometimes the only sound is the crackle of lizards darting over the trees' dry pods. ANDREW SIMMONS

TOOSHIE, the Parisian swimwear line devoted to making derrières beautiful, has now partnered with A.P.C., the Francophile favorite, to create an 11-piece capsule collection. Included in the offering are powder-blue trunks for men and this psychedelic one-piece for women. ''I like the idea of an eccentric print on a very simple bathing suit,'' said Jean Touitou, A.P.C.'s founder and designer. ''Often you see prints like this on terrible shiny materials. The idea was to find a nice matte one.'' As for the fit, Tooshie's designer, Natascha Sayn Wittgenstein, took care of that: ''It's not about focusing on shapes -- cover this, reveal that -- but keeping it elegant with these small pieces of fabric,'' she said. Jump in! CHELSEA ZALOPANY

The cover article on Dec. 25 about Brussels and its chocolate industry misstated part of the history of chocolate in Belgium. King Leopold II colonized the African Congo from 1885 to 1908, not just in 1885, and it was partly for the cocoa crops, not largely for cocoa. (He also secured the territory for its diamonds, minerals, ivory and rubber.)

BASS--Richard, 86, died on January 12, 2012 in Scottsdale, Arizona. Beloved husband of Elizabeth; loving father to Andrew, Dani, Peter, Robin and Steven, and devoted grandfather to Jordan, James, Isabel, Jacob, Sophie, Oliver and Annie. Dad was a gifted pediatrician in New York for over 40 years and adored by generations of parents and children. An avid and skilled photographer, enthusiastic tennis player and world traveler. An adventurous spirit who embraced all life had to offer, proud of his Jewish roots in Flatbush, and blessed with a wry sense of humor and the gentlest of souls. He will live in our hearts forever. Charitable contributions may be made in his memory to: Banner Alzheimer Institute, 901 E. Willetta Street, Phoenix, AZ 85005; or Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Sportswriter's Tribute at Hall of Fame Upsets Some Visitors,'' Jan. 6: The Baseball Hall of Fame's tribute to the Philadelphia columnist Bill Conlin is another discomforting example of how the sports world doesn't get it when it comes to child sexual abuse.

Le Conversazioni, a literary festival on the Island of Capri, was inaugurated in 2006, with guests that included David Foster Wallace, Zadie Smith, Jonathan Franzen and Jeffrey Eugenides. They were interviewed on subjects from failure to inspiration. What follows are excerpts from their comments. Jonathan Franzen: ''What's hard to convey to European readers is how deeply irrelevant American writers are to American culture. People are accustomed in Germany to caring about what Günter Grass thinks about this or that. No one outside of a very small circle in New York could care less about what Philip Roth thinks about the Iraq war.''

Murray's philanthropy will continue to impact the lives of many through his generous endowment. We extend our condolences to Helen, to their children, to their grandchildren, and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

PATIN--Margot, 98, died January 11 in Manhattan. A gifted soprano, she fled her native Hannover, Germany, for Mandate Palestine and helped bring opera to Israel, singing in cabarets, on radio and in Pagliacci and Fledermaus as Miriam Feinzak. Coming here with her late husband, Morton, she loved the Met, especially Placido Domingo. Nephew Fred and his wife Nancy will greatly miss her musical passion.

MARSHALL--Norma Jean (nee Tonkin), passed away peacefully at her home in Park Slope, Brooklyn, on January 10, 2012. Greatly loved by all who knew her, Norma is survived by her husband James, and son Andrew; grandchildren Nick, Jamie, and Isabelle; daughter-in-law Mary Jane DeWeese; and sisters-in-law Linda Marshall and Margaret Ashton. Born to Gordon and Maude Tonkin in Australia, Norma was a practicing nurse in the early years of her career. She came to New York City in 1960 shortly after her marriage to James in Montreal. James and Norma moved in 1967 to Park Slope in Brooklyn. Most of Norma's middle and later years were spent as an active volunteer for cultural organizations, most especially the Long Island Historical Society (managing its antiques and gift shop) and then for many years at the Brooklyn Museum. She served on the Museum's Community Committee for over a decade in capacities including cultural tours, fund raising for the annual Museum Ball, and originating the Women in the Arts Program. An avid traveler, she explored many countries on five continents, and transmitted her love of travel to her husband and son. With an extremely generous heart and a genuine love of people, she made friends everywhere and captured the hearts of all whom she encountered. She filled her family and friends with joy and kindness, and so while her loss is deeply felt, she has left the world a sweeter place. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, February 4 from 2-3pm in the chapel at Green-Wood Cemetery, 500 25th St., Brooklyn, NY.
COHEN--Eileen S. Missing you even more on your birthday. We are grateful for your constant and unconditional love and support.
DUNDES--Lester. Would be 98. Fun, exciting, generous and really missed. He was a man to love.

A picture caption on Dec. 25 with the Comings Attraction entry on the Week Ahead page misidentified the location at the Metropolitan Museum of Art where Kayhan Kalhor will play the Persian spike fiddle on Jan. 28. The concert will be in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, not in the museum's Islamic Galleries.

Las Vegas has diversified in the past decade, becoming a destination for tourists interested in culture and dining as well as gambling. A new resort is hoping to tap into an even broader tourist market: gun enthusiasts. Machine Guns Vegas, a 10,000-square-foot lounge and shooting range (machinegunsvegas.com), opens this month. It will include 16 shooting lanes and stock weaponry from handguns to machine guns. Two lanes will be part of a V.I.P. area, offering groups the use of a lounge furnished with plush sofas and plasma TVs.

Most artists find the teachers they need, whether consciously or by accident. Such was the case with Degas (self-portrait, above), who was inspired by Rembrandt (self-portrait, top) upon seeing his etchings in Rome. ''Rembrandt and Degas: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man'' opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Feb. 23 and explores that influence.

REITER--Howard L.,66, of Coventry, CT, died of complications of cancer at home on January 10th. Son of the late Harry and Sally (Hayden) Reiter, he leaves his beloved wife of thirty-nine years, Laura; brothers Martin Reiter (Susan) and Gary Reiter (Marie); sister-in-law Jane Berenbeim (Ronald); nieces Jessica and Sarah Berenbeim and Alice Reiter; and nephew Benjamin Reiter. Scholar and teacher of American politics, recognized internationally for his studies of American political parties, Howard was Professor and Chair Emeritus, Department of Political Science, University of Connecticut. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Gifts in Howard's memory may be made to the Reiter Fund for Political Science of the UConn Foundation; the American Civil Liberties Union; or the Grey Cancer Center, Hartford Hospital.

The wide-brimmed felt or velour hat has finally given the sportswear look a definitive silhouette. The floppy brims, worn rakishly, create a frame for the face. The simplicity of the hat, with a ribbon band around the crown, speaks volumes. For some wearers, the hats have taken on a masculine fedora shape. A young man, seen on Fifth Avenue sporting a wide brim with five others in a hatbox slung over his shoulder, emphasized the nonchalant attitude of this popular style.

JONES--Breckinridge. Died peacefully at home on January 7 at age 90. Formerly of Montclair and Spring Lake, Breck was a member of the Medford Leas community, Medford, NJ. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Marie and is survived by daughters Deborah and Melissa, grandchildren Samuel and Dakota, sister Nancy and their families. He graduated from Princeton, class of 1944, was an Army Air Force veteran of World War II, and spent 45 years at The New York Times, where he was Deputy Editor of The Index. A man of great dignity, conviction, compassion and humor, he will be dearly missed by his companion Jean, his family, friends and colleagues.

R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, climbed Mount Kilimanjaro to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts have appeared occasionally in Bats. It was 10 p.m. when Timo, one of the porters on our climb of Mount Kilimanjaro, tapped on my zipped tent flap to make sure I was awake. Little did he know that I had been awake for at least an hour because of the gale-force glacial winds that were pounding the exterior of the tent, a noise that assured me that something unpleasant awaited. The wind, coupled with my fears and excitement about what lay ahead, allowed for about three hours of partly uninterrupted sleep.
After the crash, everything was up in the air. People, chairs, glasses, food. ALESSANDRA GRASSO, a passenger on the cruise ship that ran aground in a fatal accident off Italy. [10]
The Denver Nuggets have rebuilt since trading the All-Star Carmelo Anthony to the Knicks, and now boast a fluid team that can contend in the Western Conference.

THE 2012 professional bull-riding season began on Jan. 6 at Madison Square Garden in a Cheyenne-meets-Seventh Avenue display of five rounds, 40 riders and 80,000 pounds of bucking livestock. From Friday night, when the world's top riders came out of the chutes, to Sunday afternoon, when Cody Nance of Paris, Tenn., took first place on Sticker Shock, the dirt-flinging, cowboy-tossing spectacle -- born, it is said, in 16th-century Mexico -- lived up to its trademarked name as the Toughest Sport on Earth. For those unfamiliar with such things, the Professional Bull Riders -- also known as P.B.R. -- have been around since 1992 and, each year since, have held events at locations around the country, from Cowboys Stadium in Arlington, Tex., to the Pit in Albuquerque, N.M. It was the sixth straight year that the league kicked off its season in Manhattan, and this year's celebration included New York touches: there were business deals announced with Lucas Oil and Pabst Blue Ribbon beer, interviews with VH1 and Telemundo, and a ringing of the closing bell on Wall Street.

In the days of the Original Six, the N.H.L. conducted two votes annually on major awards for individual players. The end-of-season winner was awarded the trophy and a bonus, and the midseason winner received a bonus, albeit a smaller one. No trophies or bonuses are offered here, but these top performers deserve recognition at the N.H.L. season's halfway point, which passed last week. (All statistics are through Friday.)

HALPER--Lorna Blaine, died at her home in Pawling, New York on Friday, January 6, 2012. Lorna was born December 12, 1924 to Katherine Tweed and Graham Burt Blaine in Boston. She studied at Barnard College and Black Mountain College, an institution celebrated as a refuge for major European artists fleeing fascism, and later lived in New York and Pawling. She is preceded in death by her husbands, Tasker Howard, a renowned jewelry designer, and Albert Halper, a distinguished novelist and playwright, as well as by her parents, her brothers Harrison Tweed Blaine and Graham Burt Blaine, Jr., and by her sisters Katherine Winthrop Blaine Swan and Charlotte Blaine Vaughn. Lorna is survived by her stepson Thomas Halper and her step granddaughter Pauline Halper and by several nieces and nephews. Lorna's paintings, drawings, and sculptures have been exhibited nationally and internationally, and are housed in many private and public collections, perhaps most prominently at the Black Mountain College Museum and Art Center. Her work is characterized by a technical virtuosity that never called attention to itself, a sensitive appreciation of the past that fed a bold insistence on trying new things, and a matchless integrity that left her impervious to the appeals of passing ephemera. She was always and in all things very much her own person, and yet she was entirely without arrogance or self-righteousness and known for her extraordinary generosity. Her friends and family regard her as unique and therefore unforgettable and irreplaceable.

PRABAL GURUNG'S first prefall collection featured pieces that ranged from classic sheaths (in emerald green) to prim pleated skirts and fishtail shirtdresses (with contrasting colors on front and back, as shown here). What makes Mr. Gurung the next generation's red carpet go-to for the avant-garde (Rooney Mara, Jessica Chastain) is his ability to imprint himself on traditional fabrics and textures. For example, a treated metallic tweed T-shirt revived a mainstay staple, while an entrancing kaleidoscopic print (evident on everything from dresses to shorts, in muted hues of browns and blush inspired by the muddied, grittier side of India) demonstrates the progress Mr. Gurung has made evolving beyond his pretty confections for the party set. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

An article last Sunday about Windows Phone software misstated the timing of aspects of its introduction. The software started to appear in phones in the fall of 2010, not 2011, and the cut-and-paste function was released in spring 2011, not the fall.

The 36 Hours column last Sunday, about Vienna, misspelled the name of the Ferris wheel in the Prater and also misspelled, at one point, the German for ''Vienna'' in a reference to a concert hall. The Ferris wheel is the Riesenrad, not Reisenrad, and the concert hall is Wiener Konzerthaus, not Weiner (an accompanying map repeated the error).

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Interpreters Help to Tell the Story Behind the Fight,'' Jan. 9: Accurate interpretation is also what medical interpreters need to strive for during encounters between health-care providers and patients who do not share a common language. Unfortunately many rely on untrained bilingual individuals who often distort or miss the message. We need to have the same interpreting standards in both the boxing and the health-care arenas.

Texans (11-6) at Ravens (12-4) Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Ravens by 7.5 There are some N.F.L. games that captivate the imaginations of both die-hard and casual fans, matchups between thrilling teams led by compelling superstars who play a fast-paced, innovative style of football. And then there is this game.

The ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday about an increase in home automation features in new midrange developments misstated the number of properties sold at Stone Hill, a gated community in Muttontown. Out of 80 planned, 50 lots -- not 6 -- have sold. (On 35 of those, houses have been built and are occupied.)

KRAUS--Philip C.,a percussionist who worked with musicians from Leonard Bernstein to Ella Fitzgerald to the Drifters died January 13 in Houston, TX. He was 93. Born in New York City, Mr. Kraus studied at Juilliard. After serving in the Army band during WWll, he worked in tv, concerts, records and movies. Among the many highlights of his career, Mr. Kraus recorded the famous marimba riff in "Spanish Harlem" and played in the orchestra at Madison Square Garden the night Marilyn Monroe sang "Happy Birthday Mr. President" to JFK. In 1978 Mr. Kraus moved to Houston. He worked for the Houston Symphony, taught at Rice University and played in the Houston Pops. Preceding him in death was his wife of 65 years, Janet Hoenig Kraus. Mr. Kraus leaves his daughters, Beth Johnstone (Edwin), Suzanne May (Donald), his grandchildren Andy Turboff (Amy), Jeffrey Turboff, Alexa May Rushing (Eric) and Chloe May (Daniel Rowen) as well as great-grandsons, Will Turboff and Jack Rushing. Funeral will be on Sunday, January 15 in Houston. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Juilliard School.

On Jan. 1, Rajon Rondo of the Celtics had 18 points, 14 rebounds and 11 assists in a win over the Wizards. Of the 158 games this season, that is the only triple-double recorded so far. There are a host of reasons that could explain the aberration (since 1999-00 the league has averaged one every 36 games), from short training camps to frequent back-to-back games to simple statistical variation. But for Jason Kidd, the modern master of the triple-double, missing time to a back injury can't help.

A dance entry in the Week Ahead column on Jan. 1 misstated the surname of the composer-performer involved with the American Realness festival at the Abrons Center. He is Ryan Tracy -- not Ryan Kelly, a former New York City Ballet dancer who is a co-founder of the Moving Theater dance company.

GINSBERG--Saul, of Sun Lakes, Arizona (formerly of East Greenwich, RI) passed away January 13, 2012 in Phoenix. He is survived by his wife, Rita, children Arthur (Janice) Ginsberg, Martin (Nadine) Ginsberg, and Sue (Neil) Figler as well as grandchildren Adrienne, Mitchell, Jessica and Kimberly Ginsberg, Gary and Daniel Figler. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Gail. Saul will be remembered as a loving husband and brother, devoted father and grandfather and will be missed by all who knew and respected him. It's hard to believe that anyone but scholars of modern literature or paid critics have read W. H. Auden's dramatic poem ''The Age of Anxiety'' all the way through, even though it won a Pulitzer Prize in 1948, the year after it was published. It is a difficult work -- allusive, allegorical, at times surreal. But more to the point, it's boring. The characters meet, drink, talk and walk around; then they drink, talk and walk around some more. They do this for 138 pages; then they go home. Auden's title, though: that people know. From the moment it appeared, the phrase has been used to characterize the consciousness of our era, the awareness of everything perilous about the modern world: the degradation of the environment, nuclear energy, religious fundamentalism, threats to privacy and the family, drugs, pornography, violence, terrorism. Since 1990, it has appeared in the title or subtitle of at least two dozen books on subjects ranging from science to politics to parenting to sex (''Mindblowing Sex in the Real World: Hot Tips for Doing It in the Age of Anxiety''). As a sticker on the bumper of the Western world, ''the age of anxiety'' has been ubiquitous for more than six decades now.

While the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints bans coffee and tea based on an original prohibition against hot drinks in a book of scripture called the Doctrine and Covenants, it does not ban caffeine. The year began in inspiriting fashion, with the Green Mountain Project's superb annual presentation of Vespers music by Monteverdi, sponsored by Trinity Church at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste. Then, days later, a bleak midwinter seemed to settle in, when Trinity declared a hiatus in its own music program, suspending the activities of its excellent Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at least until March. Now, on Tuesday, the Juilliard School is announcing a $20 million gift to endow its graduate-level program in historical performance. The sheer size of the gift is enough to make heads snap in the early-music world, whose practitioners typically struggle to stay a step ahead of poverty.

In a year in which nine of the top 10 movies at the box office have been sequels, perhaps it was appropriate that Ricky Gervais served up a slightly less compelling version of last year's Golden Globe Awards. NBC said on Monday that its live Globes telecast on Sunday night drew 16.8 million viewers, down a whisker from last year's 17 million. About 4 percent fewer people in the target demographic, adults age 18 to 49, tuned in, as measured by raw ratings points. (A 5.0 this year compared to a 5.2 last year.) NBC had heavily promoted Mr. Gervais's acerbic comedic style as a reason to watch. As promised, he delivered a crude monologue - a repeat performance of 2011, when his remarks drew gasps - but shocking people twice with the same shtick is hard to pull off. Other factors possibly affecting interest in the show: NBC has limited ability to promote itself (the network's overall schedule remains in the ratings basement), and the Globes also celebrated a batch of smaller films like "The Artist" that have produced limited box-office results. Still, the telecast was a win for NBC, delivering the network's biggest audience, excluding sporting events, since last year's Globes.

Just how popular is Adele becoming? A new survey by a market research group in Britain has found that two songs recorded by the singer accounted for more than a third of all karaoke performances there in 2011. Leading the list, not surprisingly, was "Someone Like You," a hit single from the CD "21," which was chosen by one in four karaoke singers and is also up for a Grammy next month in the best pop performance category. In second place, with 10 percent of the three million total performances tabulated, was her cover version of Bob Dylan's "Make You Feel My Love," a track from her debut CD, "19." The top non-Adele karaoke song was "Heroes," a track written by David Bowie and Brian Eno in the 1970s that enjoyed a resurgence of popularity after it was featured on the television program "The X Factor."

Jon Huntsman had a more impressive resume, a better policy shop, better odds in November and stronger conservative bona fides than many of the candidates vying for the Republican nomination. But several of them are still running while he's dropped out, and that almost all of them enjoyed temporary surges in the polls while he always languished at the bottom of the pack. For this, there's plenty of blame to go around: Huntsman can blame the mainstream media, for constantly depicting him as the "sane Republican" tragically doomed to irrelevance by the folly of his party's base; he can blame his own advisers, for embracing that self-defeating image and trying to re-run John McCain's 2000 campaign in a very different climate; he can blame Republican voters for dismissing him because of symbolism and identity politics rather than judging him on his record; he can blame conservative machers and opinion-makers for doing the same. (He can even blame his father, who declined - or wasn't asked, or both - to play Sheldon Adelson to his son's cash-poor campaign.)

MOSCOW - As of last Friday, I am an undocumented person in my own country. I cannot open or close a bank account, receive medical care at a state clinic, buy a cellphone, return a purchase to a store or enter into a contract, which my job requires me to do several times a day. All of these operations and many more require a valid internal passport, a peculiar document that may be the most significant vestige of the U.S.S.R. in modern Russian society.Back when we lived behind the Iron Curtain, these passports entitled us to travel only within the confines of the Soviet Union. Anyone lucky enough to be allowed to travel abroad was issued a special foreign-travel passport just for the occasion and had to surrender it upon returning home. When Russians acquired the right to travel freely, they got to keep their foreign-travel passports. But the internal passport refused to die. So now each adult Russian citizen has two passports. The documents look alike, except that the one for internal use is printed on lighter paper stock, making it feel less substantial.
