Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team - a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen - traveled to Lambeau Field for Sunday's showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It was a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. They were joined by two pals in Milwaukee.

An article on Friday about Green Bay Packers fans who gather at the Kettle of Fish bar in Greenwich Village for the team's games rendered incorrectly the name of the street where the original iteration of the bar opened in 1950. It is Macdougal Street, not MacDougal Street.

I see by the calendar that Congress is due back in session Tuesday, whatever that means. They've actually been in session - sorta, kinda, why not? - a parliamentary trick to prevent President Obama from naming people to keep the government running. But even that is in dispute. Thus far, the Worst Congress Ever has done nothing but show that the United States can be a nonfunctioning democracy when it wants to, like Italy but with all-you-can-eat buffets. In a single demi-term, it nearly shut down the government, fouled a fledgling economic recovery with a pointless fight over the debt ceiling, and then threatened to withhold spending money for 160 million working Americans by raising the payroll tax. Brinkmanship is its only game.

LEDER--Suzanne R. (nee Willner), died peacefully at her home on January 13, 2012. Beloved mother of Stacy Stolz, mother-in-law to Richard and adoring grandmother to Joshua Picker. Her spunky spirit and energy will be missed by her family

The headquarters of the start-up Square would be the absolute worst place to play hide-and-seek. There are no offices. Executives sit in open cubicles. All of the conference rooms, large and small, are surrounded by walls of clear glass. The only real place to hide, thankfully, would be the toilet. This openness might seem odd given what Square does. It manages more than $2 billion a year in credit card transactions made through mobile phones. But the company is set up this way by Jack Dorsey, Square's chief executive and co-founder, for a reason: to promote trust and transparency in its employees, which it hopes will translate to its customers. Design, he believes, has the power to determine a distinct mind-set, something he needs if Square is to succeed as a mobile payment system.

LEVY--Ellen, 94, of Manhattan, on January 14th. A talented sculptress, painter and jewelry designer, her work was featured in the windows of Bergdorf Goodman. She volunteered at Doing Art Together, the parent-child workshops at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and at The Hospital for Special Surgery. She was predeceased by her loving family: parents Nathan and Bernice Levine; husband of 31 years Charles Joseph Levy; sister Bobbie Cutler and daughter Susan Hirshfield. She is survived by her cherished and adoring family: son Charles Joseph Levy, Jr.; daughter-in-law Lorie Cowen Levy; son-in-law Peter Hirshfield; granddaughters Lauren Hirshfield Belden, Victoria Hirshfield, Claire and Margo Levy. Burial is private. The family will receive visitors Tuesday, January 17th from 5 to 8pm at the home of her son in Westchester. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the charity of your choice.

(OWN) OPRAH AND THE LEGENDARY CAST OF 'ROOTS' 35 YEARS LATER Oprah Winfrey welcomes Cicely Tyson, LeVar Burton, John Amos, Leslie Uggams, Louis Gossett Jr. and Ben Vereen into her home in Montecito, Calif., as she, above with several cast members, pays tribute to the 35th anniversary of the mini-series adapted from Alex Haley's Pulitzer Prize-winning autobiographical novel of his family's descent from an African slave, Kunta Kinte. (HBO2) THE TIME TRAVELER'S WIFE (2009) In this adaptation of the Audrey Niffenegger best seller, Eric Bana plays Henry, a Chicago librarian and unwilling time traveler who flits -- naked -- in and out of the life of his true love, Clare (Rachel McAdams), only to return each time with increasingly disconcerting information about her future. ''The director Robert Schwentke lays a heavy hand on every nuance and has made a dirge about love instead of an ode,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

BASS--Richard, 86, died on January 12, 2012 in Scottsdale, Arizona. Beloved husband of Elizabeth; loving father to Andrew, Dani, Peter, Robin and Steven, and devoted grandfather to Jordan, James, Isabel, Jacob, Sophie, Oliver and Annie. Dad was a gifted pediatrician in New York for over 40 years and adored by generations of parents and children. An avid and skilled photographer, enthusiastic tennis player and world traveler. An adventurous spirit who embraced all life had to offer, proud of his Jewish roots in Flatbush, and blessed with a wry sense of humor and the gentlest of souls. He will live in our hearts forever. Charitable contributions may be made in his memory to: Banner Alzheimer Institute, 901 E. Willetta Street, Phoenix, AZ 85005; or Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014.

CHARLESTON, S.C. - Jon M. Huntsman Jr. will announce Monday that he is ending his bid for the Republican presidential nomination and endorsing Mitt Romney, narrowing the field and erasing a challenge to Mr. Romney from the moderate wing of his party. Mr. Huntsman, who had hoped to use the South Carolina primary this week to revive his flagging candidacy, informed his advisers on Sunday that he was bowing to political reality and would back Mr. Romney, whom he accused a week ago of putting party ahead of country.

NEW YORK GIANTS (11-7) at SAN FRANCISCO 49ERS (14-3) Quarterback Alex Smith's coming-of-age performance Saturday, leading two touchdown drives in the final two minutes to beat the New Orleans Saints, changes the calculus for San Francisco's opponents. Now they have to worry about an offense that can win a shootout with one of the game's most productive teams? Uh-oh. Until the divisional round, the 49ers were generally thought of as an outstanding defensive team - Justin Smith is the terrorizing pass rusher who dominated the Saints' offensive line - with an offense that too often settled for field goals. So much for that. Now San Francisco has a balanced offense and a shutdown defense.

LEDER--Suzanne. Grandma you were the best grandma a grandson could ever ask for. I am who I am today because of you. Your spirit will always remain within my heart. I miss and love you more than you will ever know. Love, your grandson Josh.

An article on Friday about a warning from the Obama administration to Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that closing the Strait of Hormuz would be a ''red line'' that would provoke an American response misstated, in some editions, part of the name of the naval service in Iran that controls the operations in the Persian Gulf, including the strait. CHERIN--Richard E. January 9 in Hanover, NH, age 82. Long-time Montclair resident; partner at Gibbons (New York/New Jersey bars). A broad selection of new movies -- a druggy thriller, a 3-D cartoon and a religion-tinged musical comedy -- delivered sturdy results at North American theaters over the weekend, with overall ticket sales on par with the same period last year. ''Contraband,'' starring Mark Wahlberg as an ex-smuggler forced to fix a botched drug deal, was No. 1 and took in about $24 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Universal Pictures and Relativity Media spent about $25 million to make the film. Disney's ''Beauty and the Beast 3-D'' was second; the gussied-up version of this 22-year-old film sold about $18.5 million in tickets. ''Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol'' (Paramount Pictures) showed continued life in third place, selling about $11.5 million in tickets for a five-week total of $187 million. Dolly Parton and Queen Latifah placed fourth with the musical ''Joyful Noise,'' which took in about $11.3 million -- slightly less than pre-release surveys had indicated -- and cost Alcon Entertainment about $25 million to make.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about new products on display at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, misstated the name of one line of ultra-thin notebooks from Samsung. The company produces Series 9 ultrabooks, not Series 8.

Jon Hamm has been a bad boy, and not just in his scenes in ''Bridesmaids.'' A few days ago Mr. Hamm let it slip in a podcast interview that the long-awaited season premiere of ''Mad Men,'' the AMC period drama on which he plays the advertising executive Don Draper, would be shown on March 25. Though a few days of radio silence from the network followed Mr. Hamm can now wipe those beads of sweat from his Brylcreemed brow: AMC has confirmed the news, announcing over the weekend that Season 5 of ''Mad Men'' would begin on that date, with a two-hour episode written by the series' creator, Matthew Weiner, and directed by Jennifer Getzinger, who directed the episode ''The Suitcase'' last season. For fans of ''Mad Men'' this premiere has been a long time coming. The previous season concluded more than a year ago, on Oct. 17, 2010, and while new episodes typically start in the summer, production on Season 5 was delayed by a lengthy contract renegotiation involving Mr. Weiner, AMC and Lionsgate, the studio that produces the series. At the end of that process AMC announced that it had renewed ''Mad Men'' through Season 7, which Mr. Weiner said would be the show's last.

An article on Friday about the creation of a magnetic storage unit consisting of just 12 iron atoms described incorrectly in some editions the surface upon which researchers arranged the atoms. It was copper nitride molecules, not atoms.

The new gadgetry at the International Consumer Electronics Show this week owes a lot to the crisp articulation of ever-increasing computer performance known as Moore's Law. First proclaimed in 1965 by Intel's co-founder Gordon Moore, it says that the number of transistors that can be put on a microchip doubles about every two years. But a new descriptive formulation that focuses on energy use seems especially apt these days. So much of the excitement and product innovation today centers on battery-powered, mobile computing -- smartphones, tablets, and a host of devices based on digital sensors, like -personal health monitors that track vital signs and calorie-burn rates. And the impact of low-power sensor-based computing is evident well beyond the consumer market.

PALO ALTO, Calif. - Sam Odio expected a few congratulatory e-mails when he sold Divvyshot, his online photo-sharing service, to Facebook last April for millions of dollars. Instead, his in-box was flooded with pitches from Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and other Wall Street firms looking to manage his newfound wealth. Goldman has the inside track, having courted him with an exclusive factory tour of Tesla, the electric sports-car maker, and tickets to a screening of the final Harry Potter film.

Mary Raftery, a journalist whose television documentaries exposed decades of abuse of needy children in state-sponsored, church-run schools in Ireland, prompting an apology by the prime minister and a government investigation, died on Tuesday in Dublin. She was 54. The cause was cancer, her niece Isolde Raftery said.

PATTERSON--Robert P. III of Brooklyn, NY died on January 12, 2012 after suffering a cardiac arrest. He was born on April 3, 1958 to Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr. and the late Bevin D. Patterson. Bob attended St. David's and Millbrook Schools and graduated from Middlesex School. He received a BA from Hartwick College and his CSW from NYU School of Social Research. He also studied for a postgraduate degree in Gestalt Psychotherapy. He worked as a social worker in Manhattan where he had a clinical psychotherapy practice until he was forced to stop as a result of a neurological illness, which he faced with much dignity. He is survived by his loving wife Cristina C. Patterson (adjunct professor at CUNY, NYU and The New School University), his father and siblings Anne P. Finn, Margaret, Paul, and Katherine. A funeral service will be held at 11:30am, Thursday, January 19, at Our Lady of Loretto Church, 24 Fair St., Cold Spring on Hudson, NY 10516. Following the burial, there will be a reception at the family home.

-Lil Wayne, the New Orleans rapper, has turned his experience at Rikers Island into a memoir that will be published in November, two years after his release, Grand Central Publishing announced on Thursday. The book, ''Gone Till November,'' is described as an internal monologue based on journals Lil Wayne kept during his eight-month stint at the New York City jail on a gun possession charge. ''He kept detailed journals of his inner and outer life while he was on Rikers Island and they certainly tell as story,'' Ben Greenberg, the executive editor at Grand Central, said in the announcement.

Foursquare, the app that lets people share their locations with select friends, is moving beyond the check-in. Early last year, the service introduced a feature called Explore, which used algorithms to suggest nearby restaurants and other places to visit, based on the check-in history of a user and that user's friends.

The Republican battle for South Carolina was supposed to have been a time for the state's socially conservative voters to weed out the candidates they found unfit. Instead, the primary has been dominated by a loud and unruly argument over whether Bain Capital, the private equity firm that was led by Mitt Romney, drove companies out of business and put people out of work while enriching itself with billions of dollars. That has pushed aside issues like abortion, gun rights and same-sex marriage, and, so far, has muddied the effort for conservatives to coalesce around a single candidate with credentials they might find acceptable.

YARDE--Richard. We mourn the death of Richard Yarde, a dear friend and one of America's greatest artists. His spirit will live on his great works of art, particularly his celebration of the dancers of Harlem's Savoy Ballroom. Larry Schulz & Sandra Cameron

MARLIN--Edith, passed away January 14, 2012 at age 84. Edith was a History Teacher for New York City Public Schools. She is survived by her beloved husband Stanley, cherished children John and Elizabeth (Alan) Legatt, five adoring grandchildren and three loving great-grandchildren. Edith is predeceased by siblings Julius, Charlotte, Lillian and Frances. For information: Zion Memorial Chapel. 914-381-1809.

A pair of bills that would strengthen antipiracy laws - and that could essentially censor the Internet, according to heavyweights like Google - have received scant coverage from the major television networks. The parent companies of the TV networks are among the chief supporters of the bills, having lobbied Congress to write them in the first place. Those two facts, taken together, have caused conspiracy theories to flourish online about corporate interference in news coverage.

While their children slept, the group of friends played Uno late into the night. Sometime after 1 a.m. on Sunday, the first-floor apartment on Decatur Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, began to fill with smoke. The adults gathered up three children and fled. It was only then that one of them, Mia Smith, realized her 7-year-old son was still in the apartment.

Norman Siegel and Herbert Teitelbaum were classmates at New York University law school. Mr. Siegel is married to Saralee Evans, a former acting State Supreme Court justice. Their wedding ceremony was performed by Emily Jane Goodman, a Supreme Court justice. They all come from Brooklyn. Collectively, they have 161 years of legal experience and a record of impact in and out of court. And now, when most of their contemporaries are contemplating retirement or have already quit, the four of them are starting a new law firm. ''I know lots of lawyers of my generation who've been put in a situation where they have to retire,'' Mr. Siegel said. ''I'm as energetic as ever, and I'm much more experienced. I know which issues are viable and which are policy issues. Herb is a better negotiator than I am. The two judges give us credibility.''

KOORY--Valentine was born May 30, 1944 in Bridgeport, CT. He died after a sudden illness January 7, 2012 in Chattanooga, TN. A viewing will take place Thursday, January 19 from 3-7pm at Leo P. Gallagher and Sons, 31 Arch Street, Greenwhich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent in his honor to your local hospice charities.

Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team - a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen - traveled to Lambeau Field for Sunday's showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It was a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. They were joined by two pals in Milwaukee. We left Milwaukee at 10:30 a.m. with the eight of us eagerly anticipating the finale of our long week of planning and looking forward to the Giants and the Packers playing at Lambeau. The drive to Green Bay is about two hours from Milwaukee, and we piled into two cars from our hotel with a ton of energy and a little trash talking between the Giants and Packers fans among us.

While women's service magazines have long relied on readers to contribute content, from first-person accounts to recipes, Ladies' Home Journal is taking that strategy to new lengths: beginning with the March issue, it will allow readers to produce the majority of its articles. The 128-year-old magazine, with an average paid circulation of 3.2 million, would be the first major mass-market magazine to draw on user-generated content for most of its pages. It has proved to be a winning formula for other specialty magazines, including Taste of Home, where readers share recipes and food preparation tips. Ladies' Home Journal will also introduce a new look.

GRABOW--Connie, January 13, 2012, age 71, of Westchester County, passed away peacefully in the presence of her children on Friday, January 13 at 8:00pm in New York City. With her radiant smile and joyous spirit, Connie was the light of many, many lives, especially to her two surviving children who know the blessings of having had a perfect mother. Her generosity, unerring sense of right and wrong, and her dedication to her family and friends not to mention her magical powers in the kitchen made her a deeply beloved figure. Though she will be sorely missed, the example of her life will be a continuous source of inspiration to all who knew her. Connie Grabow was born to Anthony and Stephanie Schifini in the Bronx, New York on November 18, 1940. She is survived by her daughter, Suzanne Gerla, and her husband Michael Gerla, and their beautiful children - "Mooma's" beloved Julia and Caroline; her son Albert Imperato and his partner Brian; her sister Rose and brother-in-law Joe Gilberti, and their children and grandchildren; her stepson Mitchell Grabow and his wife Patti and their sons Harry and Jack; and her stepdaughter Lisa and her husband Tommy Karach, along with their children Rachel and Nicholas; aswell as many other nieces, nephews and friends. We all rejoice in the knowledge of Connie's reunion in Heaven with her beloved parents, brother John, son Frank, and husband, "Papa" Steve. The family will receive friends on Tuesday, January 17 from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm and Wednesday, January 18 from 2 to 5pm, with a service Wednesday, 7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street; Private funeral on Thursday, January 19 at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

We extend our sympathies to her children, Barbara and Barry, Anise and Phil Parnes, Harwin and Liz Goldman, and Michael and Rena Goldman; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Jerry W. Olympia Dukakis will play a female version of the magician Prospero in a production of ''The Tempest'' this summer at Shakespeare & Company, based in Lenox, Mass., the theater announced on Tuesday. She will be joined on stage by her brother, Apollo Dukakis, who will play Gonzalo, and Rocco Sisto as Caliban. Tony Simotes, who is in his third year as Shakespeare & Company's artistic director, said in a phone interview that he first met Ms. Dukakis when she taught theater at New York University in the early 70s and that they have remained friends and colleagues ever since. He said he had wanted to cast and direct Ms. Dukakis for many years, recalling her portrayal of a female King Lear at Shakespeare & Company in 1998.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about a family that left Haiti after the earthquake in 2010 and settled in Queens, where they discovered that a son had leukemia and later received financial assistance from Catholic Charities Brooklyn and Queens, one of the seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, referred imprecisely to the family's immigration status. While the federal government did give the family the temporary protected status offered to Haitians after the earthquake, it did so only after the family arrived in the United States and applied for the status. The family did not immigrate ''under'' that program.

At the next Republican presidential primary debate on Monday night, Fox News will be measuring viewers' reactions to each answer on Twitter, the social Web site that acts as an online water cooler during big television events. Died peacefully on January 14, 2012, Beloved husband of the late Myra Fox, devoted father of Debbie, Mitchell, Nina and Evan, father-in-law of Gary and Nina and Grandfather to Mollie, Emma, Rachel, Elizabeth and Mia. A successful businessman in the printing industry from Manhattan, was also known for his philanthropy to organizations and individuals alike and had a knack for getting "it" done when others couldn't. His idiosyncratic style and his potent, engaging personality made for memorable friendships, his love filling the lives of so many. The news that Hostess filed for bankruptcy last week was met with nostalgic dismay by millions of baby boomers who lamented what they thought was the imminent demise of the Twinkie. Hostess, which emerged from bankruptcy just three years ago, has maybe 100,000 creditors, mostly labor unions and pension funds (one of which is reportedly owed $944 million) that represent the company's employees. Its debt approaches a billion dollars, a lot by most standards.

The stock has risen sharply on the double-breasted suit, that vestige of the all mighty power-suit era. Though the linebacker-like shoulders have had the air let out of them and the jacket shape is significantly softer, that signature button stance remains the same. Corneliani started off the Milan season with a group of guys hitting the runway en masse in gray flannel double-breasted suits with tonal shirts and ties; Brioni, newly part of France's PPR family of luxury fashion houses, showed a boardroom-appropriate light gray version with a faint windowpane during its presentation in, fittingly, an ersatz boardroom; and Massimiliano Giornetti featured a sexy, low-slung four-button navy take in his show for Salvatore Ferragamo. Meanwhile, Canali favored a higher, more dandified 6-button model in mourning stripes with a contrasting velvet collar. Paul Surridge's first collection at Z Zegna also preferred this higher button stance - a crisp white shirt and dark tie peeked out just the slightest from underneath the jacket. The sharp lapels of the graphic Prince of Wales plaid suit in Sarah Burton's Alexander McQueen collection looked positively lethal. And Giorgio Armani, always seeking perfection, showed off his model's gym-toned body with a lower cut and softer shoulder. Definitely a powerful suit.

An editing award is considered a must for a best-picture win at the Oscars - no film has received that top prize without at least an editing nomination since 1981 - and the editors' group has a lot of overlap with the Academy voters in its membership, so its choices are usually an above-average predictor.

The 66th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be held on Sunday, June 10, at the Beacon Theater in New York and broadcast live on CBS, organizers of the ceremony announced on Tuesday. The Tonys are the best-known awards for Broadway musicals and plays, voted on by hundreds of producers, tour presenters, directors and others in the theater industry. The organizers also set April 26 as the cutoff date for Broadway shows to open and be eligible for Tony nominations and awards; the nominations are expected to be announced the week of April 30.

Hearing loss, a disability currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, may be the nation's most damaging and costly sensory handicap. It is a hidden disability, often not obvious to others or even to those who have it. Its onset is usually insidious, gradually worsening over years and thus easily ignored.

As one of the many outgrowths of the sweeping federal health care law, health insurers and employers must now pay the cost of screening children for obesity and providing them with appropriate counseling. With about one in three children in the United States obese or overweight, according to government statistics, the need for such programs is clear. But, experts say, creating them will be challenging. Other than intensive hospital-based programs, few proven models exist for helping children and adolescents achieve and maintain a healthier weight, and researchers do not even fully understand the factors that contributed to the rapid rise in childhood obesity in recent years. ''If this were easy, if there were clear outcomes for success, we would be investing in these,'' said Dr. Samuel R. Nussbaum, the chief medical officer for WellPoint, one of the nation's largest health insurers.

Mitt Romney was wrong in stating at the debate Monday night that President Obama wants to cut $1 trillion from military spending. The administration is committed to reductions of less than half that amount over 10 years -- about $450 billion, or roughly 8 percent of the Pentagon budget over a decade. Moreover, Congressional Republicans as well as Democrats support the level of cuts that Mr. Obama is seeking. The cuts were mandated as part of the bipartisan deficit-reduction agreement with the president in August.

INTERNATIONAL Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with a Memo From Britain article, about efforts to duplicate a tunnel used in the mass escape of Allied prisoners from a Nazi camp, described incorrectly items shown with Hugh Hunt, a Cambridge University engineering professor who was a consultant on the project. They were items experts believed the prisoners would have used creating the tunnel, chronicled in the 1963 movie ''The Great Escape.'' They were not artifacts unearthed during an exploration of the remains of the original tunnel.

CHASIN--Stephen L.,beloved and devoted son of Beatrice and deceased father Milton. Caring brother of Gerold, Robert, sister Jane and sister-in-law Gayle. Loving nephew to Charlotte, Esther, Estelle and Louis. His generosity and love will stay with us forever.

ZIEBARTH--Jack. Jack Ziebarth died January 13, 2012. Born on February 8, 1926 in Chicago, Illinois. Graduated from Amherst College. Served in the US Navy during WWII. Founder of Ziebarth Geary Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange. Survived by loving wife, Jean Miles, children Jody, Michael, Susie and Amy and proud grandfather to nine. Avid sportsman, hunting and fishing around the world. Onetime race horse owner and recently an owner of the Green Bay Packers. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the charity of your choice.

ALBANY - A majority of New York State voters oppose Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's plan for building the country's largest convention center at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, according to a poll released on Monday. Voters remain highly contented with Mr. Cuomo's job performance, the poll, conducted by Siena College, found. But their disdain for his convention center proposal - 38 percent supported it, and 57 percent opposed it - represents the first time since he took office that one of his major proposals has landed with a thud.

NEW YORK An article last Tuesday about opposition by the West 69th Street Block Association to the renaming of a portion of that street after a mayoral aide misspelled the middle name of a famous writer who had part of West 84th Street named after him in 1980. He was Edgar Allan Poe, not Allen. (The same misspelling appeared on the street sign erected by the city to honor Poe, a former resident of West 84th. Though the city spelled his name correctly on its second try, the same cannot be said of The Times, which has corrected Poe's middle name at least 10 times -- though dozens of misspellings of Allan, dating to the 1870s, were never corrected.)

NEW YORK An article on Friday about the halting of a New York Philharmonic performance after a cellphone interrupted Mahler's Symphony No. 9 misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a composer who sent a humorous Twitter message about the incident. He is Daniel Dorff, not Dorf.

PARIS -- As the world was transfixed by the Titanic-like imagery of the partly submerged Costa Concordia and the frantic efforts to save the fuel-laden vessel in rough seas off the Tuscany coast, questions swirled on Monday about the enormous cruise line industry, which operates without much regulation. The ship's detained captain, Francesco Schettino, was accused by his bosses of deviating from a fixed, computerized course to show off his beautiful $450 million boat, carrying more than 4,200 passengers and crew members, to the people of Giglio Island on a still Friday night, crashing it on a reef.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street; Private funeral on Thursday, January 19 at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

David Henry Hwang's Broadway comedy ''Chinglish,'' about the misadventures and cultural misunderstanding of an American businessman as he is trying to close a deal in China, will end its run on Jan. 29, after 128 performances. The bilingual play, which features Gary Wilmes as the businessman and Jennifer Lim as a Chinese official who becomes his unlikely ally and lover, opened at the Longacre Theater in October to generally favorable reviews, and was named by Time magazine as the No. 1 new American play of 2011. Despite those accolades, and the strong reputation of Mr. Hwang, a Tony Award winner whose previous work includes ''M. Butterfly,'' box office sales remained modest. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Devotees of early music in New York may be experiencing whiplash. The year began in inspiriting fashion, with the Green Mountain Project's superb annual presentation of Vespers music by Monteverdi, sponsored by Trinity Church at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste. Then, days later, a bleak midwinter seemed to settle in, when Trinity declared a hiatus in its own music program, suspending the activities of its excellent Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at least until March. Now, on Tuesday, the Juilliard School is announcing a $20 million gift to endow its graduate-level program in historical performance. The sheer size of the gift is enough to make heads snap in the early-music world, whose practitioners typically struggle to stay a step ahead of poverty. The donor is Bruce Kovner, the chairman of the school's board, who recently retired as chairman of the $10 billion hedge fund Caxton Associates. Mr. Kovner, 66, has already financed the curriculum in period performance, which began in 2009, through its development and several academic years costing, he said in a telephone interview, $500,000 to $1 million each. The program, which is directed by the English violinist Monica Huggett and has attracted guest luminaries like the conductor-instrumentalists William Christie and Jordi Savall, has had a significant impact on the New York scene by presenting its own public concerts and furnishing performers for groups like Trinity's.

Donations in lieu of flowers: Institute for Family Health, 16 E. 16th St, New York, NY 10003, Attention Dorothy Gottfried Memorial Fund.

In a year in which nine of the top 10 movies at the box office have been sequels, perhaps it was appropriate that Ricky Gervais served up a slightly less compelling version of last year's Golden Globe Awards. NBC said on Monday that its live Globes telecast on Sunday night drew 16.8 million viewers, down a whisker from last year's 17 million. About 4 percent fewer people in the target demographic, adults age 18 to 49, tuned in, as measured by raw ratings points. (A 5.0 this year compared to a 5.2 last year.) NBC had heavily promoted Mr. Gervais's acerbic comedic style as a reason to watch. As promised, he delivered a crude monologue - a repeat performance of 2011, when his remarks drew gasps - but shocking people twice with the same shtick is hard to pull off. Other factors possibly affecting interest in the show: NBC has limited ability to promote itself (the network's overall schedule remains in the ratings basement), and the Globes also celebrated a batch of smaller films like ''The Artist'' that have produced limited box-office results. Still, the telecast was a win for NBC, delivering the network's biggest audience, excluding sporting events, since last year's Globes. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KAUFMAN--Shirley Schaffer, M.D. Died peacefully on January 10, 2012 after a long and fulfilled life. She was predeceased by her husband of 61 years, Dr. Paul Kaufman on December 3, 2011. She is survived by her children Eric Kaufman, Julie Bagnasco, and Lydia Ahern (Bill) and six grandchildren. She was born October 13, 1921 in New York. Shirley graduated from the University of Wisconsin, then Washington University Medical School in 1947. Early in her career as a psychiatrist she worked at New York Hospital/Paine Whitney and Mount Sinai Hospital. Later, in the 1960's at Maimonides Hospital, she was a pioneer in the field of community based mental health at one of the first clinics of its kind. In 1970's she was the first director of two community mental health clinics in Westchester County. She retired in 1980 to enjoy a second 30 year career of living life on her own terms. She was a voracious reader. Until the end of her life, her interests in world politics, the arts, and people never waned. Shirley was a fiercely loyal person and was highly esteemed by all who knew her.

LONDON -- Britain plans to turn London into a major foreign exchange trading center for the Chinese renminbi to benefit from faster growth in Asia while strengthening the city's position as a financial center in the wake of the banking crisis. George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, said during a visit to Hong Kong on Monday that he was working with Chinese and British banks to establish London as a new hub for the renminbi market.

The account information for millions of customers at Zappos.com, an online shoe and clothing company, may have been compromised by a hacking attack, the company's chief executive, Tony Hsieh, wrote on Sunday in an e-mail to employees. In the message, posted on the Zappos Web site, Mr. Hsieh said a criminal ''gained access to parts of our internal network and systems'' through one of the company's servers in Kentucky.

THE FACTS There are many reasons to stay properly hydrated, but only recently have scientists begun to consider diabetes prevention one of them. The amount of water you drink can play a role in how your body regulates blood sugar, researchers have found.

It did not even take the full 140-characters to start the great Twitter war Monday afternoon. In fact, it started innocently enough, just after noon, with a Twitter posting from @MittRomney, the Mitt Romney Twitter account.

3:02 p.m. | Updated The online video service Hulu, most of whose programming consists of material licensed from television and film companies, has commissioned its first original script-based program, which is scheduled to be available on Hulu's free web service, rather than its premium pay Hulu Plus site, as of the middle of next month. Called ''Battleground,'' the new series is described as a faux documentary-style political drama-comedy set in Wisconsin-- which in real life has emerged as a frontline in combat between liberals and conservatives since Republican governor Scott Walker took office a year ago. The new show, which is to have 13 episodes, will be directed by J.D. Walsh, a Wisconsin native known from acting appearances in ''Two and a Half Men,'' and will be produced by Marc Webb (''The Amazing Spider-Man'') and Hagai Shaham (''The Details''). Hulu is said to be aiming ''Battleground'' at the same kind of audience that watches popular programs like ''The Office'' and ''The Colbert Report.''

SONNENSCHEIN--Marty R.,owner of SunRay Textile, passed away on January 15, 2012 after a three year struggle with Parkinson's. Funeral Services are graveside at the Westchester Hills Cemetery at noon on January 17. The family will sit shiva after the ceremony. Marty is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Marilyn, daughters Max and Helaine, grandchildren, David, Jake, Rachel and Maxwell, and cherished friend Jimmy Little. Marty, a New York City native was a diehard Yankee fan. He and his wife recently moved to Boynton Beach, Florida. Marty was 79. The family is asking in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to the Parkinson's Foundation.

At the gym last week I saw a guy lifting weights, working out his shoulders while two friends urged him on. He alternated two similar exercises with heavy weights, repeating one exercise 10 times and then the other one 10 times, never resting between sets. ''We want to burn out his shoulders,'' one of the man's friends explained to me.

SPORTS An article on Jan. 6 about the rarity of goalies scoring goals in sports like soccer, hockey and lacrosse misstated the number of goals credited to goalies in N.H.L. history. It is 12, not 11. The article also misstated the number of times an N.H.L. goalie had scored by shooting the puck all the way down the ice into the net. It is six times, not five.

Patients want to know they are getting treatment based on medical evidence, not a lunch or a financial relationship. ALLAN J. COUKELL, a consumer advocate at the Pew Charitable Trusts, on a rule that would require drug companies to disclose payments they make to doctors. [A3]

HEARST--Hope Chandler, passed away peacefully at her home in Honolulu on January 11, 2012. She was 90. Born Hope Chandler in 1921 in New York City, Hearst was a child actress and model, and famously graced a 1937 cover of LIFE Magazine as the "Prettiest Girl in Paradise." In 1938, in New York's Grace Church, she married the late David Whitmire Hearst, son of William Randolph Hearst and a vice president and director of Hearst Corporation. The young couple moved to Beverly Hills, Calif., where Hearst's husband began his career with the Los Angeles Evening Herald-Express. Hearst gave birth to two children, Millicent Hearst Boudjakdji and David Whitmire Hearst, Jr. "Together, David and Hope Hearst exhibited the highest level of support as Hearst Corporation grew and changed," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. "And long after her husband's death, Hope regularly assumed the role of cheerleader, encouraging Hearst management in every way." After her husband's death in 1986, Hearst moved permanently to Hawaii, a place the Hearsts first visited as a newly married couple. She loved Hawaii and her many friends and family members there. Hearst was happiest surrounded by her family and adored pets in the living room of her Honolulu home. "She was a remarkable, loving, and joyful woman," said her granddaughter Anissa B. Balson, a director of Hearst Corporation and a trustee of the trust established under the will of William Randolph Hearst. "We will all miss her very, very much." Hearst is survived by her brother, Warren Coley of Hawaii; her son, David W. Hearst, Jr., of California and Hawaii; her grandchildren, Balson, Cherif Boudjakdji and Samia Staehle; and her four great-grandchildren. In addition to her husband, she is predeceased by her daughter Boudjakdji, who was president of the William Randolph Hearst Foundation, a director of Hearst Corporation and trustee of the trust established under the will of William Randolph Hearst. Final services will be conducted in private.

Meet Paul S. Levy. He is a low-key private equity executive and former lawyer who helped co-found a midsize firm, JLL Partners, in 1988. It manages about $4 billion on behalf of pension funds and endowments like the New York State Teachers' Retirement System and Harvard University.

Too much vitamin D may be just as bad as too little, a recent study suggests. Vitamin D supplements reduce blood levels of C-reactive protein, or CRP, an indicator of inflammation that is linked to cardiovascular disease. But supplements help only up to a point.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Thursday about Dr. Mary Ellen Avery, a medical researcher who made a discovery that helped save hundreds of thousands of premature infants, misstated the surname of the chief of newborn medicine at Children's Hospital Boston, where Dr. Avery was the first woman to be appointed physician in chief. She is Dr. Stella Kourembanas, not Kourembana.

A City Room post recently about a town house on the Upper East Side that blew up in 2006 brought to mind another town house, another era and another explosion - the town house in Greenwich Village that became a bomb factory for the radical group the Weathermen. Unlike with the physician on the Upper East Side who apparently intended to destroy his town house, the explosion on West 11th Street in Greenwich Village, in 1970, was an accident.

Can a presidential candidate erase his campaign? And how fast can that happen? Literally within minutes of the news breaking Sunday night that Jon M. Huntsman Jr. had decided to abandon his White House bid and endorse Mitt Romney, his campaign went into overdrive to begin wiping the record clean.

The wave of online protests against two Congressional bills that aim to curtail copyright violations on the Internet is gathering momentum. Wikipedia is the latest Web site to decide to shut on Wednesday in protest against the two Congressional bills, the Stop Online Piracy Act, often called SOPA, and the Protect IP Act, which is often called PIPA. The bills have attracted fierce opposition from many corners of the technology industry. Opponents say several of the provisions in the legislation, including those that may force search engines and Internet service providers to block access to Web sites that offer or link to copyrighted material, would stifle innovation, enable censorship and tamper with the livelihood of businesses on the Internet.

10 P.M. (13) NUCLEAR AFTERSHOCKS In the 10 months since an earthquake and tsunami crippled the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex in Japan (above, a woman who lived near the plant being checked for radiation), that country has closed all but a handful of its 54 reactors. Germany has decided to phase out its 17 nuclear power plants by 2022. Should the United States follow suit? In this ''Frontline'' episode, Miles O'Brien examines the future of nuclear energy around the world and asks whether any of the 104 reactors in the United States could suffer a Fukushima-type accident. He also investigates a controversial decision facing nuclear regulators: whether to relicense the nearly 40-year-old Indian Point plant, 38 miles north of Manhattan. Critics, like Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, insist that the risks are too great. But proponents, including former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, argue that the plant should remain open because it provides about a quarter of New York City and Westchester County's power while producing few greenhouse gas emissions. 2 P.M. (HBO) TEMPLE GRANDIN (2010) Claire Danes earned an Emmy for her role as Ms. Grandin, the autistic animal behaviorist who helps design slaughterhouses. The director, Mick Jackson, who also won an Emmy, used snapshot images that track Ms. Grandin's self-perceptions from her condition's early diagnosis through her turbulent school years and the unwavering support of her mother (Julia Ormond), aunt (Catherine O'Hara) and science teacher (David Strathairn). ''Hers is a tale that could be easily played up for drama, intrigue and weepy reconciliations, but this narrative is loyal to Ms. Grandin's credo: emotions are secondary to tangible results,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. ''And the result is a movie that is funny, instructive and also intangibly charming.''

Just how popular is Adele becoming? A new survey by a market research group in Britain has found that two songs recorded by the singer accounted for more than a third of all karaoke performances there in 2011. Leading the list, not surprisingly, was ''Someone Like You,'' a hit single from the CD ''21,'' which was chosen by one in four karaoke singers and is also up for a Grammy next month in the best pop performance category. In second place, with 10 percent of the three million total performances tabulated, was her cover version of Bob Dylan's ''Make You Feel My Love,'' a track from her debut CD, ''19.'' The top non-Adele karaoke song was ''Heroes,'' a track written by David Bowie and Brian Eno in the 1970s that enjoyed a resurgence of popularity after it was featured on the television program ''The X Factor.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Nearly a third of middle-aged Americans regularly take a baby aspirin in the hope of preventing a heart attack or a stroke or lowering their cancer risk. But new research shows that aspirin is not for everyone, and that in some patients this so-called wonder drug is doing more harm than good. ''I stop a lot more aspirin than I start,'' said Dr. Alison Bailey, director of the cardiac rehabilitation program at the Gill Heart Institute at the University of Kentucky. ''People don't even consider aspirin a medicine, or consider that you can have side effects from it. That's the most challenging part of aspirin therapy.''

Many renewable energy supporters see the creation of an energy supergrid as an indispensable part of Europe decreasing its reliance on fossil fuels. The supergrid would take renewable energy from where it is produced - say, on wind farms in Scotland or in solar arrays in Spain or North Africa - and deliver it to Europe's faraway population centers. In addition to the environmental argument, there is also an economic one. In this Business of Green special report, Beth Gardiner writes:

As a philosophy professor, I spend much of my time thinking about the arguments put forward by professional philosophers. As a citizen (and an occasional columnist for The Stone), I also spend lots of time thinking about the arguments put forward by Democrats and Republicans on currently disputed political issues. Of course, there are differences in logical sophistication and complexity between the philosophical and the political arguments. But, allowing that popular political arguments require shortcuts from full academic rigor, there is not, I think, that much difference between the logical acumen of politicians and philosophers.

After a monthlong holiday hiatus, "Glee" and "New Girl" returned with new episodes to give Fox a lift in the broadcast television ratings on an otherwise sluggish Tuesday night. How sluggish? According to Nielsen data, CBS was still the No. 1 network in total viewers despite a full slate of repeats on the schedule. Fox was first in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic, as "New Girl" was the highest-rated program of the night in that category. The show also had a total audience of 6.9 million viewers. "Glee" finished with more viewers (7.5 million) but was second among adults 18 to 49.

At this point, Adele's run at the top of the Billboard chart is titanic. Literally: This week Adele's "21" (XL/Columbia) notches its 16th No. 1, the first time since the "Titanic" soundtrack in 1998 that a release has topped the list as many times. As Billboard notes, only three albums in the last 20 years have had more weeks at No. 1: Billy Ray Cyrus's "Some Gave All," which had 17 in 1992; Garth Brooks's "Ropin' the Wind," with 18 in 1991 and 1992; and the soundtrack to "The Bodyguard," with 20 in 1992 and 1993.)

The average age of light vehicles on American roads continues to increase, reaching a new high of 10.8 years, according to a study by Polk, the automotive forecasting service. The firm noted that the average was pushed upward by an  increase in average light-truck life from 10.1 years in 2010 to 10.4 years through June 2011. The average age of passenger cars only increased from 11 to 11.1 years during that period. The trend is expected to slow, however, because of the recent rebound in sales of new vehicles. Read more »

Last year in Mexico, just a couple of days into my vacation, I fractured my kneecap. In the emergency room, through pain so severe I found myself yelling at all helpful parties around me, particularly my wife, the doctors noted that they did not have painkillers to send home with me. "WHAT!?" I screamed. "No oxycodone, hydrocodone, nothing?" They explained that Mexico's drug laws had grown so strict due to the actions of the narcotraficantes that pain meds were tough to come by (and only provided to patients who had been admitted to the hospital).

At Salvatore Ferragamo, a black nylon double-breasted trench, buttoned to the top with black gloves and briefcase, was also meant for serious business. Canali's gray trench with epaulettes achieved a cool monochromatic look with a tonal shirt and tie. Prada's regal procession contained a lot of winning clothes but the subtly striped coat worn with a leather floral pen/boutonnière on the chest pocket was a standout. The unmistakable sound of a tattoo gun could be heard coming from backstage while we waited for the start of Umit Benan's fall show. Curiosity overtaking decorum, I popped behind the curtain to see an already inked model getting another actual tattoo, with a pretty raw arm to show for it. He was one of a group of real guys taking part in a barracks tableau, jubilantly postwar, that included a naked "soldier" showering (eventually he got dressed for his trip down the runway), a bruiser boxing and other assorted military types. It was a fine line to walk for a presentation, but it steered clear of cliché by committing wholeheartedly (and bodily) to the enactment. Though at times a bit too literal an interpretation, the clothing featured a lot of clever riffs on the theme, with the actual tattoo artist's rig being the most clever. He wore a high-buttoned vest with oversize envelope pockets over a striped shirt and tie with cropped cargo pocket pants, and carried a military style jacket with leather sleeves. It was a vivid, memorable show.

The "For Your Consideration" ad, paid for by studios and directed at Academy voters, started appearing in Hollywood trade publications sometime in the 1950s and are often quite elaborate, even for movies that don't have a shot at winning an Oscar. (Michael Jordan, best actor in "Space Jam," anyone?) As with everything Oscars related, they have their own artistry and market-tested logic. But though they are designed to promote an actor's performance or a film's good reception, they are not always entirely accurate. We know, you're shocked, shocked!

This year's Sundance Film Festival, which starts Thursday, is heavy on films that reflect an American dream turned nightmare. There are stories of financial fraud, corporate greed, the damaged health-care system and a looming hunger crisis. "Independent film has always had a bleak streak: a desire to tell complicated stories that don't end with everyone smiling is part of what sparked the indie movement," writes our colleague Brooks Barnes, but he adds that advances in digital technology have made it possible to tell those stories while they still resonate in the culture. Robert Redford, the festival's founder, tells him, "If ever there was a crucial time for a hard, honest look at our country, it's now - it's no secret that we're at the bottom of a very dark barrel - and the speed with which films can now be made is greatly helping artists to do just that." Nahalat Binyamin Street, which crosses lower Rothschild Boulevard - Tel Aviv's chief axis of white Bauhaus beauties - is emerging as the microhood of the moment. By day this thin strip is all garment-district shuffle and cheeky graffiti art, but at night the street takes on a moody but electric air. You might find Bar Refaeli, or at least plenty of women who look like models, at the street's hottest spot, Mizlala (No. 57). Here the city's star chef, Meir Adoni, whips up dishes like fish kebabs, garlic-sage linguine with white asparagus and something called Palestinian tartar - ground beef, raw tahini paste, pine nuts, charred eggplant puree, cumin and parsley.

LEVANDER--Ellenore B.,90, of Pelham, New York, beloved wife of Seymour, devoted mother of Victoria and Andrew and their spouses, Richard (deceased) and Carol, and adoring grandmother of Adam (and Reva), David (and Leah), Sam and Ben and great-grandchild, Riley. She enjoyed her work as an interior designer and loved to travel, read and attend plays and the Philharmonic. Most of all she was fiercely proud of her family and friends. Funeral at the Pelham Jewish Center, Pelham New York, noon on Wednesday.

Diane Paulus is moving from Catfish Row to a mysterious island. The producers of Cirque du Soleil announced this week that Ms. Paulus, the director of ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess,'' which just opened on Broadway, is set to direct ''Amaluna,'' the company's latest touring spectacle, which will open in Montreal on April 19 before moving to Quebec City and Toronto. The show is inspired by ''The Tempest,'' and like Julie Taymor's recent film version, it turns Prospero, Shakespeare's hero, into Prospera. In ''Amaluna,'' Propera is the queen of goddesses who presides over an island ''guided by the cycles of the moon,'' according to Cirque's announcement of the show.
7:46 p.m. | Updated Wells Fargo is somewhat unusual among big banks - it continues to produce profit gains.

Shares of the Carnival Corporation, the world's largest cruise ship operator, fell 14 percent on Tuesday as analysts and investors sought to gauge the effect of the grounding of Carnival's Costa Concordia after days of continual images and videos of the listing ship. The death toll from the accident on Friday was 11, though at least 24 people were still missing after the ship, carrying 4,200 passengers and crew members, hit rocks and capsized hundreds of feet off Giglio Island, in Italy.

The Yankees avoided arbitration with relievers Joba Chamberlain and Dave Robertson by agreeing to one-year contracts with both, the team announced Tuesday. Robertson emerged last season as perhaps the best setup man in baseball, with a 1.08 earned run average in a team-high 70 relief appearances. He received $1.6 million, tripling his salary of 2011, which was $460,450.

KRITZ--Madeline. A beloved faculty member for over 47 years at The Dalton School, Maddie was a teacher and later a reading specialist who opened up the world of literacy for generations of Dalton students. The entire Dalton community will miss her tremendously and we extend our condolences to her family. Ellen Stein, Head of School

The year 2011 is over, and soon we'll be hearing again about billion-dollar paydays for select hedge fund wizards. If it makes you feel any better, not everyone is sharing in these riches. The people who operate the most successful hedge fund around are receiving a relative pittance.

A bottle of reasonably priced red to enjoy with dinner is stock-in-trade at most wine shops, including Vintry Fine Wines in Battery Park City. But this sleek, well-lighted new store, with eye-level displays of about 2,500 bottles, including 85 Champagnes and 24 kosher wines, goes well beyond the everyday. Its well-curated selection includes more than 75 large bottles, magnums and up. Among the highlights are a double magnum of 1991 Dominus and a five-liter bottle of 1990 Mayacaymus cabernet sauvignon (third and fourth from left), a double magnum of 1970 Chateau Mouton-Rothschild (center), and a magnum of 1978 Chateau Petrus and one of 1989 Chateau Rayas Chateauneuf-du-Pape (far right). Also, a rare magnum of 1981 Chateau d'Yquem (bottom center). These bottles range from about $1,000 to $7,500.

The Mets avoided hearings with four players eligible for salary arbitration after reaching one-year agreements with starter Mike Pelfrey, relievers Ramon Ramirez and Manny Acosta, and center fielder Andres Torres, the team announced Tuesday. The agreement with Pelfrey, who finished the 2011 season with a 7-13 record and a 4.74 earned run average, was worth $5,687,500. Pelfrey made $3.9 million last season.

In Monday night's Republican debate in South Carolina, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas described the leaders of Turkey as ''Islamic terrorists,'' an inaccurate characterization that drew a swift rebuke from the Turkish government. Asked whether Turkey, a predominantly Muslim democracy of nearly 79 million people and an American ally in the region, belonged in NATO, Mr. Perry said it did not.

10 P.M. (BBC America) MISTRESSES This soap opera about four women in Bristol, England, balancing friendship and extramarital intrigue, left American viewers dangling when Season 2 wrapped in May 2009. Now it returns for a four-episode finale. When last we saw the girlfriends, Katie (Sarah Parish), the doctor who helped her terminally ill married lover commit suicide in Season 1 (and then went on to have an affair with his son and then with an old, also-married flame), was about to find out if her latest beau would sweep her off to Australia in an act of forgiveness. Trudi (Sharon Small), who thought her husband had died in the terror attacks of Sept. 11 and discovered that he was in fact still alive, had gotten married to a man who also wasn't what he seemed. Jessica (Shelley Conn, above), a pregnant event planner in an open marriage, learned that her spouse had decided to be monogamous. Or so he said. And Siobhan (Orla Brady) was relegated to single-mother status after struggling with infertility in her marriage, then getting pregnant by a colleague -- which sent her husband packing. In this Season 3 premiere the women are summoned to Katie's house, where their icy demeanor suggests that they are friends no more. Joanna Lumley joins the cast as Vivienne, Katie's imperious mother. 1 P.M. (HBO Signature) SOMETHING'S GOTTA GIVE (2003) In this double bill from the director Nancy Meyers, a music executive in his 60s (Jack Nicholson) with a fondness for young women finds the rug pulled out from under him when he falls for the mother (Diane Keaton, above) of a woman he's dating (Amanda Peet). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Mr. Nicholson and Ms. Keaton sparred ''with the freedom of professionals with nothing left to prove, and Mr. Nicholson has the gentlemanly grace to step aside and let Ms. Keaton claim the movie.'' He added, ''She in turn brings out the best in everyone around her.'' At 3:15, in ''It's Complicated,'' Meryl Streep plays Jane Adler, a successful California restaurateur who is about to settle into life as an empty nester when she is blindsided by advances from her ex-husband (Alec Baldwin), who had left her a decade earlier for a pretty young thing (Lake Bell). Steve Martin is thrown into the mix as the architect overseeing the renovation of Jane's house, and he is not without his own charms. The truth, Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times, is ''that everyone needs a little coddling, which could be the key to Ms. Meyers's peculiar talent: She pampers her audience shamelessly.''

Though it has been some years since their owner left this plane of existence, the guitars of George Harrison need not weep for loneliness or lack of use: they are about to be shown off and shared in a new iPad app planned for release next month. On Tuesday the George Harrison estate said that it was working with Bandwdth Publishing, which makes applications for mobile devices, to create a virtual showroom of that singer-songwriter's trove of guitars that will make use of many of his personal recordings. The iPad app, called ''The Guitar Collection: George Harrison,'' will offer pictures of the guitars that display ''the scratches, dings and worn threads'' in the instruments, a news release for the project said. Users can see 360-degree images of the guitars, created by the photographer and filmmaker Steven Sebring; read about their detailed history and the modifications Harrison made to them; and listen to tracks he played on them. The app also includes videos of the guitars being played by Ben Harper, Josh Homme, Mike Campbell and Harrison's son, Dhani, as well as a conversation between Dhani Harrison and Conan O'Brien, the late-night television host and guitar enthusiast, about Harrison's collection.

Because of an editing error, an essay in some editions on Monday about Giants fans who traveled to Green Bay for the team's playoff against the Packers carried an incorrect byline. The essay was written by Doug Chase, not by Stephen Costello.

LAWSUIT DISMISSED A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Credit Suisse and its former star investment banker, Frank P. Quattrone, left, ending a decade-old shareholder action brought by investors in AOL Time Warner stock. The dismissal removes the last of 11 civil lawsuits brought against Mr. Quattrone related to his conduct during the dot-com boom. PETER LATTMAN

With donations to Occupy Wall Street falling significantly and money starting to run low, the movement has imposed a partial spending freeze to make sure enough money is available for crucial functions like bailing protesters out of jail. ''We need to stop all new nonessential spending until we get our budgetary committee together,'' Haywood Carey of Occupy Wall Street's accounting working group said Tuesday.

PRICE--Charles. The Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies is profoundly saddened to learn of the death of Charles Price. Charles and his wife, Carol, a Founder of FAPE, have been an integral part of our organization since 1986. Their many contributions constitute a great legacy. Chiefly among them is Winfield House, the U.S. Ambassador's Residence in London, where Charles served as Ambassador from 1983 to 1989. They have watched over this historic property, providing endless resources to ensure that it is maintained in its original splendor. We send our deepest sympathy to our beloved founder and Board member, Carol, and to all their family. Jo Carole Lauder, Chairman Eden Rafshoon, President Darren Walker, Vice President Wendy W. Luers, Founder and President Emerita Ann L. Gund, President Emerita Jennifer A. Duncan, Director
A review in the Dining Briefs column last Wednesday about Corkbuzz Wine Studio misidentified a dish. It is brandade with fried potatoes, not with fried cassava.

DEANS--John. Family and friends mourn the passing of John Deans. A graduate of PRATT and Columbia Universities, he was a professor emeritus at City University of New York and taught and practiced architecture for over 45 years. We will always remember him for his independent spirit, sharp wit, intelligence, love of the outdoors and as an admirer of the arts. He is survived by his dear friend Doris; two daughters Alison and Jennifer; his son-in-law Ken and grandchildren Isabelle and Gavin.

A little liquid nitrogen with your manhattan? Warm up that drink with a foot-tall flame? Booker & Dax, a new bar that places technology squarely in the service of mixology, has you covered.

Ronald O. Perelman's marital breakups - divorces from the actress Ellen Barkin and Patricia Duff among them - have been rich fodder for the gossip pages. Now a split with a longtime business associate promises to be almost as acrimonious. The former associate, Donald G. Drapkin, and Mr. Perelman are headed to a federal courtroom in Manhattan next week in a dispute over roughly $20 million. The court battle provides a rare window on the pay, perks and behind-the-scenes politics in the world of deal-making.

Having served on several cultural boards, the literary agent Morton L. Janklow found that many arts leaders lacked basic business skills necessary to manage their institutions. So he has spearheaded a new master's of arts degree program at Syracuse University, which is to be announced Tuesday. ''Sometimes they don't have the tools with which to confront the growth of their organizations,'' Mr. Janklow said of current arts executives in an interview. ''We've got to be prepared to run these things in a more serious way.''

For years, detectives trying to distinguish gun-carrying New Yorkers from others have had to rely on observations, street smarts and luck. A man with a gun on his hip might grab the front of his sport coat to keep it from flapping open and revealing the pistol. Someone getting out of a cab might hold tight to his side, to keep a weapon secure. But science is now promising to assist such human efforts.

CONE--Eric Roger. 1924-2012. 87, passed away quietly on Thursday, January 12th, 2012, at his home in Dorset, Vermont. He is survived by Carol, his wife of 55 years, his son Alexander of New York City, and his second son Jeffrey of Taos, New Mexico. No services are planned at this time.

Alison Schneider, a food-loving, stay-at-home Manhattan mother of five, conducted some Greenmarket tours and taught informal cooking classes here and there. Then she wanted more. So she started pursuing a master's degree in food studies at New York University. And now she is opening Haven's Kitchen, an elegantly designed shop, cooking school, catering kitchen and party rooms on two floors of a 19th-century carriage house in Chelsea. In the airy street-level space, she has shelves stocked with food products, cooking and tabletop items for sale. At a coffee counter, granola, breakfast pastries and cookies made in-house will be sold and served. Beyond a small reception area is a spacious teaching kitchen with marble counters and professional equipment, run by Julia Sullivan, a Culinary Institute of America graduate from Nashville who worked at Blue Hill at Stone Barns. A full schedule of hands-on classes will be available next week on the business's Web site.

The N.F.L. conference championship games on Sunday feature nearly everything a fan could want: great offenses, tough defenses, exciting new stars, respected future Hall of Famers with perhaps their final chance at a title. Only Rex Ryan and the Jets are missing.

The series premiere of ''Alcatraz'' -- which features a crack investigative team tracking former inmates of the infamous prison -- managed to capture a large portion of the broadcast audience for Fox on Monday night. The new drama averaged 10 million viewers and outperformed the premiere of the previous time slot occupant, ''Terra Nova,'' in the 18-to-49 demographic, according to Nielsen data. The numbers also remained consistent throughout the two-hour period, suggesting viewers liked what they saw. But no show could hold a candle to the overall audience numbers for NBC's ''Betty White's 90th Birthday: A Tribute to America's Golden Girl.'' An average of 13.9 million people tuned in to the 90-minute special, although the audience skewed older. The season premiere of ''Betty White's Off Their Rockers'' followed, with another 12.2 million viewers.

Princeton, N.J. IN recent weeks Mitt Romney has become the poster child for unchecked capitalism, a role he seems to embrace with relish. Concerns about economic equality, he told Matt Lauer of NBC, were really about class warfare.

When word got out in the fall that Public School 277 in the Bronx had landed on a list of schools that could be closed by the Education Department because it had received an F on its progress report, students, parents and teachers went on a campaign to convince officials that their school had been working hard to raise achievement. In December, when they learned that school officials had decided to keep the school open, ''you could hear the resounding cheer throughout the school,'' the principal, Cheryl Tyler, said. Deputy Chancellor Marc Sternberg said, ''We saw the school has a motivated principal and energized staff with a vision for improving student achievement.''

ASCHKENASY--Herbert. Herbert (Herb) Aschkenasy passed away on January 12, 2012, while at home with his family by his side. Herb was a beloved longtime president and, most recently, chairman and CEO of Oregon Freeze Dry Inc., based in Albany, Oregon. Born in Vienna, Austria, Herb was nine years old when the Aschkenasy family came to New York in 1941. He grew up in the Bronx and attended the Bronx High School of Science, graduated from the City University of New York (now City College of New York) with a Bachelor of Science, received a Ph.D. in chemistry from the Polytechnic Institute of New York, and did postdoctoral research at Cambridge University. He served in the U.S. Army during the Korean conflict. Herb married Ruth Kurland on July 11, 1954 in The Bronx, New York. Ruth and their three children survive, Leah Reid of New York City, David Aschkenasy of San Diego, and Dr. Miriam Aschkenasy of Massachusetts, as well as four grandchildren. Herb's parents preceded him in death. Herb and Ruth lived in Philadelphia, Kentucky, and Wisconsin while Herb held technical, sales, and management positions with Celanese Corporation and Rohm & Haas. Herb transferred to Oregon Freeze Dry in 1981 from the Chemical Group of Philip Morris Industrial, where he served as president. Oregon Freeze Dry Foods (as it was then called) had fallen on hard times. After a period of rebuilding the company, in 1986 he led a management team in the purchase of Oregon Freeze Dry (OFD) from Philip Morris Incorporated. Herb remained president until he was appointed chairman in January of 2011. Under his leadership the company grew by adding facilities in Albany and acquiring companies with manufacturing facilities in England and Denmark, and establishing a sales office in Japan. Herb was especially proud of the growth of the company's Mountain House brand and when the OFD logo was added to packaging for General Mills Berry Burst Cheerios, Lipton cup-a-noodle soup, and most recently Costco's Kirkland Signature brand of real sliced fruit. Herb received a gubernatorial appointment to the board of the State-owned workers' compensation company (SAIF) and was elected chairman from 1988 through 1993. He was subsequently appointed to the Oregon State Board of Higher Education in September 1993 and served until September 2001, including a term as president. He was also on the board of Associated Oregon Industries, was a past chairman of the Northwest Food Processors Association, and served on other religious and charitable boards. In November of 2011 his alma mater, City College of New York, awarded Herb the Townsend Harris Medal for outstanding entrepreneurship. Herb was also a pillar of the Salem Jewish Congregation (Temple Beth Sholom), serving as president and trustee for many years. His contributions to Jewish Life and presence in Salem were exemplary. His commitment to the community was unconditional and honored his family heritage honorably. Herb was a respected and trusted sage to rabbis, leaders and staff. Memorial contributions may be made to OHSU Knight Cancer Institute or to Temple Beth Sholom.

After two decades of steady increases, obesity rates in adults and children in the United States have remained largely unchanged during the past 12 years, a finding that suggests national efforts at promoting healthful eating and exercise are having little effect on the overweight. Over all, 35.7 percent of the adult population and 16.9 percent of children qualify as obese, according to data gathered by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and published online Tuesday by The Journal of the American Medical Association. While it is good news that the ranks of the obese in America are not growing, the data also point to the intractable nature of weight gain and signal that the country will be dealing with the health consequences of obesity for years to come.

An obituary on Friday about Bill Janklow, the former congressman and governor of South Dakota whose political career ended when he was convicted of manslaughter for killing a motorcyclist while speeding, misstated part of the name of the newspaper in Mitchell, S.D., that reported on his later citations for speeding. It is The Daily Republic, not The Daily Record.

TORRES--Joan D.,died peacefully at home on January 13 after a sustained illness. Born in Wilson, AR, she grew up in southern Missouri and attended Murray State University in Kentucky, where she fell in love with the theatre. She came to New York to fulfill her dreams and became an accomplished actress, appearing in many productions around the country. She is survived by her husband, cartoonist Angelo Torres, and her two sons John and Andrew, to whom she devoted her life. Loved for her warmth and kindness, she will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched.

An article in some editions on Monday about China Telecom's plans to start a branded mobile service in Britain misattributed a quotation regarding a similar service operated by Turkcell, a Turkish company, in Germany. It was Lale Saral Develioglu, the chief international business officer at Turkcell, not Banu Uzgur, a spokeswoman for the company, who said: ''We believe in the future of serving the sizable Turkish population in Germany and Europe. The operation is at the start-up stage. However, its contribution to Turkcell Group's financials is expected to grow.''

Giuseppe Quintarelli, a wine producer from the Veneto region of northeastern Italy whose Valpolicellas, reciotos and Amarones were revered by devoted followers all over the world, died Sunday at his home in Negrar, Italy. He was 84. His death was confirmed by a grandson, Francesco Grigoli, who said he had Parkinson's disease.

First thing Saturday, Pierette Domenica Simpson's boyfriend called and said, ''Go online. You'll be interested.'' She checked the headlines. Something about an Italian ocean liner in trouble. The way the ship was listing, the report that it was taking on water, the light from the cabins reflecting in the water, the passengers' struggle to clamber into lifeboats - everything seemed so familiar. ''I thought, 'How can this be? It's 56 years later,' '' Ms. Simpson said.

The Your Money column on Jan. 7, about financial strategies for those laid off shortly before retirement, referred incompletely to the possibility of taking money out of a company plan, like a 401(k), to pay health insurance premiums. While such a transfer is technically possible, the rules governing it are more onerous than those that apply to withdrawals from an I.R.A.

An arms race seems to have sprung up among the new breed of beer stores that specialize in imports and craft labels. If one offers 250 different brews, the next stockpiles 400. Now, Ted Kenny, a former beer salesman, is raising the ante with at least 700, including 20 on tap, at Top Hops Beer Shop, the new store he plans to open Saturday on the Lower East Side. Mr. Kenny also sells what he calls ''the majors'' - Bud Light, anyone? All beers are available cold. And like most new beer emporiums in New York, the store has a bar where customers can order food, too, like the cheeses from Consider Bardwell Farm in Vermont, which is owned by Mr. Kenny's architect, Russell Glover.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the documentary-style film ''When Mitt Romney Came to Town,'' omitted part of the title of the financial firm for which Mr. Romney worked and referred imprecisely to its main business. It is Bain Capital, not Bain, and it is primarily a private equity firm, not a venture capital firm.

An article in some editions on Sunday about the San Francisco 49ers' 36-32 playoff victory over the New Orleans Saints misstated the number of interceptions 49ers quarterback Alex Smith threw during the regular season. It was five, not 10. (The 49ers had a total of 10 turnovers during the season.)

An art review on Dec. 30 about favorite three-dimensional objects on long-term display in New York City museums referred incorrectly to the figure of Erasmus in ''Saints Christopher, Eustace and Erasmus (Three Helper Saints),'' attributed to Tilman Riemenschneider, at The Cloisters. He is wearing a bishop's vestments, not ''papal regalia.''

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in some editions on Friday about Penn State alumni who expressed dissatisfaction with the university at town hall-style events with the new president Rodney Erickson misstated the given name of Erickson's predecessor, who was fired in the wake of a sexual abuse scandal. He is Graham B. Spanier, not Gordon.
