''Magic/Bird,'' Eric Simonson's play about the rivalry and friendship between Larry Bird, the former Boston Celtics forward, and Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers point guard, has a Broadway theater and a complete cast. The play, to be directed by Thomas Kail, will open on April 11 at the Longacre Theater, the show's producers announced Tuesday. Previews begin March 21. Additional casting was also announced. Kevin Daniels and Tug Coker, already cast in the roles of Johnson and Bird, will be joined by Deirdre O'Connell, Peter Scolari, Rob Ray Manning, Jr. and Francois Battiste, all of whom will play several roles in the six-person cast.

It seems like a classic case of closing the barn door after the horses have gotten out. The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to declare a row of 26 19th-century town houses and tenements on the north side of Tompkins Square Park in the East Village a historic district. But there was just one problem: A building project that the designation was intended to prevent received a permit from a different New York City agency just hours before and now, essentially, cannot be stopped.

The 66th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be held on Sunday, June 10, at the Beacon Theater in New York and broadcast live on CBS, organizers of the ceremony announced on Tuesday. The Tonys are the best-known awards for Broadway musicals and plays, voted on by hundreds of producers, tour presenters, directors and others in the theater industry. (Off Broadway and regional shows are not eligible.) The organizers also set April 26 as the cutoff date for Broadway shows to open and be eligible for Tony nominations and awards; the nominations are expected to be announced the week of April 30. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Saturday's primary in South Carolina - with evangelicals expected to make up sixty percent of the electorate - provides what seems like a perfect testing ground for disrupting any claims about Romney's inevitable nomination.

Since the turn of the millennium, the world has made stunning progress toward the goal of universal primary education.  In sub-Saharan Africa, enrollment in primary school has risen by 18 percentage points; in Asia and Latin America there has been more limited progress. While globally, 69 million school-age children do not attend school now, in 1999 that figure was 106 million. This is a huge achievement.

Despite being in the geographic center of the Civil War, battles in Appalachia were few and far between. There are a few conventional explanations. The area's topography made it a near-impenetrable borderland for an army of any size. And there was little there for a large occupying force to conquer in any case.

In filing for bankruptcy protection early Thursday morning, Eastman Kodak executives say they are seeking to follow the path of American corporations that have reinvented themselves after a court-supervised reorganization, like United Airlines and Chrysler.

There is sad news about Gary Carter, the Hall of Fame catcher and a hero of the 1986 World Series for the Mets. Carter's daughter wrote on the family's Web site Thursday that her father's doctors had discovered "several new spots/tumors on his brain." New York City Opera's orchestra ratified a three-year contract on Thursday that provides for deep cuts but also a new labor-management committee to deal with fund-raising, planning and artistic matters. The financially pressed company has moved out of its home at Lincoln Center to present a sharply reduced season in several theaters around New York.

Sloane Stephens's close loss to the veteran Svetlana Kuznetsova in the second round of the Australian Open Thursday was filled with subtle lessons. She had chances to win the first set, but Kuznetsova prevailed, 8-6, in the tiebreaker. The set took 69 minutes and Stephens came away with nothing. It is perhaps the harshest aspect of the tennis scoring system: sets and games - no matter how close - are winner take all. Other sports (football and basketball come to mind) stop at halftime and each team still has a chance to win. In other words, the losing team's points are not erased.

I travel to Iowa for the caucuses every four years, like all political journalists, but I've never quite understood the point. Yes, I know Iowa is commonly referred to as the first delegate selection contest in the nation. But it's not. No delegates are actually selected at the caucuses. It's supposed to be a bellwether for the nation, but it's not. The Iowa caucuses, especially the Republican ones, have a mixed record at predicting the next nominee, and a fairly bad one at predicting the next president.

The founder of one of ancient Rome's most illustrious clans, consul Lucius Cornelius Scipio Barbato, began building monumental tombs for his relatives in the third century B.C., and the family continued to use the site as a place of rest until the first century A.D. The site was forgotten, then made into a public park in 1929 and shuttered for restorations in 1992. This week, for the first time in two decades, the tomb of the Scipios has been reopened to the public (Via di Porta Sebastiano 9, www.060608.it).Among the Scipios entombed there were two of the Punic War's greatest Roman heroes: Scipio Africanus Major, the general who defeated Hannibal and ended the Second Punic War, and Scipio Africanus Minor, who destroyed Carthage and ended the Third Punic War.

In the dispute over New York City's policy of digitally fingerprinting applicants for food stamps, an interesting footnote was provided by Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. Mr. Berg reminded us that one elected official among Mr. Spitzer's fellow Democrats vigorously attacked the governor for this action.

The Academy released on Wednesday what we'll call the semifinalists for the Oscar for best foreign-language film. You can see the field of nine here. The letter, signed by Mr. Gingrich's two daughters from his first marriage, Kathy Lubbers and Jackie Cushman, faulted the network for engaging in "talk about the past, just days before an important primary election," Trip Gabriel and Brian Stelter reported. The number of low-income veterans receiving government assistance for their heating and cooling bills hit a new high last year, according to a survey by a federal energy-assistance program.Over the last four years, the survey found, the number of low-income households with at least one military veteran receiving federal energy assistance rose by about 1.1 million households, to 1.78 million.

Recency bias is when we overemphasize the importance of recent events, just as many observers are doing this week with the most recent Ravens and Patriots games. Baltimore eked out a win over the Texans with a lackluster performance on offense, while New England dominated the Broncos on both sides of the ball. Don't put too much stock in those two games. In Baltimore's case, keep in mind that Houston owned one of the very best defenses this season, allowing only 5.2 yards per pass attempt and yielding only a 39 percent run success rate, good for second and seventh in the league. And regarding New England, remember that Denver was overmatched in several departments and had backed into the playoffs with a mediocre record.

FITZGERALD--Anthony W. The Partners of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle LLP, mourn the passing of their colleague and former partner, Anthony W. Fitzgerald. Tony was a 1962 graduate of Fordham University School of Law and he began his 48 year career at Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle LLP on January 6, 1964. He became a Partner of the Firm on April 1, 1971. He was Chairman of Office Operations from 1980 through 1984 during which time he oversaw the relocation of the Firm from Wall Street to 101 Park Avenue in midtown Manhattan. He was Managing Partner of the Firm from 1984 through 1988 and thereafter he became Chairman of the Real Estate Department. He became Of Counsel on January 1, 2009 and then, together with Marion, his wife of 52 years, they explored their love of traveling. Tony was a devoted father of six children and grandfather to thirteen grandchildren, avid golfer, hockey, field hockey and football fan and dedicated football and hockey coach. In addition to being a fine lawyer, he was a good friend and partner, and a loving family man. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The wake will be held in the chapel at Church of the Nativity, 180 Ridge Road, Fair Haven NJ 07704, on Thursday, January 19, 2012 from 5pm to 8pm and the funeral will be held at 10am on Friday, January 20, 2012 at Church of the Nativity.

An article on Tuesday about the Koobface gang, a Russian group believed to be responsible for spreading a notorious computer worm on social networks, misspelled the surname of one man identified by investigators as a member of the group. He is Alexander Koltyshev, not Koltysehv.
8:47 p.m. | Updated Goldman Sachs's chief financial officer told analysts on Wednesday that his firm could not cut its way to prosperity.

LAS VEGAS -- At the International Consumer Electronics Show, the helmet camera makers GoPro and Contour have both demonstrated products that can put all of your plummeting, hurtling and rocketing adventures on the air live through a Wi-Fi connection. GoPro demonstrated the Wi-Fi BacPack, which snaps on the back of a $300 GoPro HD Hero2 camera to connect it to a Wi-Fi network. Once on the network, a wrist-worn remote control can toggle between and turn on and off up to 50 cameras, making it possible to watch, record or photograph different views of a live event on a remote computer. Or the Wi-Fi can connect to a phone to stream the video live to the Internet. The Wi-Fi BacPack and Wi-Fi Remote should be in stores in March. The BacPack and Remote are sold in a combo kit for $100.

A critically acclaimed production of ''Clybourne Park,'' the 2011 Pulitzer Prize winner for drama by Bruce Norris, will open on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater on April 12, a spokesman for the show said on Wednesday. ''Clybourne Park,'' a satire about race and gentrification that is set in 1959 and 2009 in a fictional Chicago neighborhood that was discussed longingly in Lorraine Hansberry's ''Raisin in the Sun,'' had its premiere in Feb. 2010 at the Off Broadway theater company Playwrights Horizons. Despite strong reviews and significant buzz, the production was not able to secure a commercial transfer to Broadway in time to be eligible for the Tony Awards that spring. Instead, the production closed in New York in mid-March that year.

An article on Tuesday about insurance companies' efforts to address the problem of childhood obesity referred incorrectly to the number of children who completed a UnitedHealth pilot program. It was 84 percent, or about 130 participants -- not 155 participants. (That was the total number of children and teenagers who started the program.)

A picture caption in some editions on Sunday with an article about the men's race at the United States Olympics marathon trials reversed the identities of two of the three runners shown. Meb Keflezighi was at the right and Abdi Abdirahman was at the left. (As the caption correctly noted, Ryan Hall was in the center.)

KRITZ--Madeline J.,suddenly, January 16, 2012. Born March 4, 1942. Teacher and Reading Specialist at Dalton School-47 years. BS Tufts-1963; MA Columbia. Beloved sister of Karen Kritz Demetriou, brother-in-law Thomas J. Demetriou, devoted aunt to Adam, Kimberly and Abby Demetriou.; Michael, Katie, Sloane and Leo Demetriou. Predeceased by parents Leonore Cohen Kritz and Allan Kritz. Funeral service January 20, 11am, Plaza Jewish Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam. Memorials Technion Society.

Last week we published a case study about William Burris, one of 10 franchisees who learned that their Australia-based franchiser, Rent Your Boxes, had gone bankrupt. Mr. Burris, who had invested more than $100,000 to purchase three territories in the Washington area, rallied by creating a new company, Rent Our Boxes, for himself and his nine fellow franchisees. But getting the franchisees to agree on how to run the new company proved problematic, and Mr. Burris started thinking about going it alone. There seemed to be safety in numbers, especially if the jilted franchisees wanted to continue pursuing legal action against their original franchiser, but relations among the franchisees continued to go from bad to worse. ''You had 10 franchisees who had paid money to follow someone else's system and who expected someone else, me in this case, to do the work for them,'' said Mr. Burris, a former director of advertising and media sales at the International Franchise Association. ''In my time at the I.F.A., I learned that the No. 1 reason franchises fail is because their owners fail to market their own business.''

WALTERS--Sylvia (KAPLAN), of Poughkeepsie, New York, born in Philadelphia and formerly a long time resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, New York passed away following a wonderful life on January 18, 2012 at the age of 91. Predeceased by her husband Sidney, loved mother of Jonathan (Terry Fromson), Rebecca (Eric Gidseg) and David (Elizabeth), and grandmother of Robin and Dana Walters, Tovah Gidseg, Janna Walters-Gidseg and Joshua Walters. Devoted to her family but also as a founding member of the Women's Strike for Peace, committed to the causes of peace, civil rights and social justice. Memorial donations may be made to Planned Parenthood, the ACLU or the Women's Law Project of Philadelphia.

On Thursday, the world will go to battle over a second. In Geneva, 700 delegates from about 70 nations attending a meeting of a United Nations telecommunications agency will decide whether to abolish the leap second.

LAS VEGAS --Toshiba unveiled a tablet it claimed to be the lightest and thinnest in its class, the 10-inch Excite X10. Made of a magnesium alloy, the tablet weighs 1.18 pounds and is a third of an inch thick. It's strength and rigidity is enhanced by a Corning Gorilla Glass 10-finger multi-touch screen. (The iPad 2, by comparison, is 0.34 inches thick and weighs 1.33 pounds.) The screen is treated with a smudge resistant coating, which was showing wear from thousands of hands at the International Consumer Electronics Show here.

How can you tell people, 'Learn the trade, get involved, there is a future here.' Is there? STEVE ROONEY,leader of a machinists union in Wichita, Kan., on the Boeing company's plans to shut down its manufacturing operations there. [A10]

LIMITED RIGHTS It is quite possible that the Carlyle Group, the private equity firm that is preparing to go public, is proposing the most shareholder-unfriendly corporate governance structure in modern history. It starts with the fact that Carlyle is providing its soon-to-be public shareholders with no power over the company. Carlyle has also deliberately limited other rights of shareholders that are typically present in public companies. The question, the Deal Professor says, is whether prospective shareholders protest and refuse to participate in Carlyle's public offering. STEVEN M. DAVIDOFF
To the Editor: Reading '' 'Can I Help You?' Irks the Web-Savvy Customer,'' by Taffy Brodesser-Akner (Thursday Styles, Jan. 12) gave me an idea.

As kids, when we used to wrestle and play around, we had an expression for when someone had you pinned, and you were in enough pain that you wanted to concede -- you would yell, ''calf rope!'' The rodeo term is not one I have used in running my business. At least not until recently. When I started my advertising business 17 years ago in Austin, Tex., I knew I needed to learn some things about running the business. A steady diet of self-help, business and motivational books taught me just enough, and my instincts took over from there. And then luck kicked in. We eventually grew to more than $8 million a year in annual revenue. But the lingering effects of the recession left me scrambling a bit late last year when many of our clients cut their ad budgets for the second year in a row.

New York City does not lack for exotic and specialty food shops, but perhaps the most diverse display of ever-changing imported produce can be found in what is called the grinding room in the customs area of John F. Kennedy International Airport's Terminal 4, the major gateway for international arrivals. -On Thursday afternoon, there was a cornucopia of hard-to-identify foodstuffs on a large metal table in the inspection area. There was sugar cane, dusty yams, dragon fruit and a panoply of herbs. There were strange tubers and a variety of homemade sausages and rodent meat. There was a load of red prickly fruit, small citrus fruits and of course plenty of mangoes.
An entry in the Scouting Report last Thursday about a men's clothing sale at the store Project No. 8 misstated the store's street address. It is at 38 Orchard Street, not 36.

CARDOZO--Peter Stirling, on January 17, at age 95 at home in Williamsburg, VA. Survived by his wife Susan Strong Cardozo. Father of Peter Jr, Pamela, Christopher and Jonathan. Author, Director of Marketing for Bantam Books, Dartmouth '39, sailor and beloved family man.

An obituary on Wednesday about the harpsichordist, organist and conductor Gustav Leonhardt misspelled several names. One of the musicians who, like Mr. Leonhardt, made influential recordings on period instruments in the 1950s and 1960s was August Wenzinger, not Wenziger. The man with whom he studied organ and harpsichord at the Schola Cantorum in Basel, Switzerland, was Eduard Müller, not Miiller. And one of the churches in Amsterdam where Mr. Leonhardt has been organist is Waalse Kerk, not Waasle Kerk.

THE Hawaiian shirts that are showing up in stores this season are far hipper than their forebears. Stella McCartney did a classic bowling shirt in a digitally manipulated island print. J. Crew has a boy-cut floral shirt in the hues of luau leis. And the print-savvy Suno designers used a splashy tropical print for several pieces in its vacation-ready collection, including the aloha shirt here. ''We were exploring the quirky world of the uniformed tourist,'' said Erin Beatty, who designs Suno with Max Osterweis. ''It's a new take on the Hawaiian shirt: slightly exaggerated, a bit humorous, but still completely wearable.'' Clockwise from above: Hawaiian-print silk shirt, $1,055 at Stella McCartney, 112 Greene Street;(212) 255-1556; stellamccartney.com.Chambray button-down, $426 at sunony.com. Floral cotton-silk shirt, $88 at J. Crew,

Not long ago, I received a call from a furniture-store owner who was checking the references of one of my former employees. He introduced himself, and got right to the point: ''I'm calling for a reference for ...'' He named a former saleswoman. I immediately said, ''She's very nice!'' Which she is. He went on to explain that he was excited to hire her because of all of her contacts. I didn't say a word. He thanked me and we finished the call. He never asked if she really had contacts. He never asked how her sales compared to those of our other salespeople. He never asked why she left. He never asked if I would consider rehiring her.
To the Editor: Re ''Two People, One Identity,'' by Austin Considine (Sunday Styles, Jan. 15). As a twin, I found the relationship of Nate and Kirk Mueller to be quite peculiar.

The Sunday Observer on Charles Dickens, which included an anecdote about Dostoyevsky meeting Dickens, failed to note that scholars are divided about such a meeting. While some have written of it and of a letter in which Dostoyevsky was said to have described it, others have questioned the letter's authenticity and whether the meeting occurred.

HUGO GUINNESS, the London-born artist who makes Brooklyn his home, is known for his black-and-white lino-cut prints of commonplace objects. At John Derian, they cover the walls, done up in vintage frames. Now Mr. Guinness has collaborated with Coach on a limited-edition collection of small leather goods with illustrations inspired by the hustle and bustle of New York. ''New York is Maximum City,'' Mr. Guinness said. ''Everybody's in a hurry.'' His images -- sunglasses, a coffee mug, keys, handcuffs -- on reversible tote bags, wallets and an iPad cover read as a sendup of the sights we encounter on our daily rounds. Hugo Guinness for Coach collection, $68 to $398 at Coach stores; coach.com.

WEISS--Marcia, of New York, 80 years old, passed away peacefully in her home on January 18, 2012 after a long hard fought courageous battle with cancer. She faced her illness as she lived her life, without self-pity and with elegance. She was the beloved and adored wife for 60 years to Leonard J. Weiss. Devoted and loving mother of Frederica and Harvey Kadden and Jonathan and Elisabeth Weiss. Cherished grandmother of Zachary, Joshua, Daniel, Jared and Aaron. Marcia's unconditional love for each of her grandsons was legendary. Loving daughter of the late Lillian Berman-Perlin. Marcia was a wonderful and special friend to many. Marcia was kindhearted, generous, smart, witty and loving to all those around her. Her beautiful spirit will forever soar in the hearts of her family. She will be deeply missed, but never forgotten by all those who knew and loved her. Services: Friday, 11:30am January 20, 2012 at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In Marcia's memory donations may be made to North Shore-LIJ System Foundation, Breast Cancer Research.

LL Cool J will host the Grammy Awards next month, marking the first time in seven years that the show's producers have decided to go with a single master of ceremonies, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Wednesday. Since 2008, the rapper and actor has been the host for the televised nominations concert the Grammys produces in the fall. This is the first time, however, he will be asked to keep the main ceremony moving along. The awards will be announced on Feb. 12 at the Staples Center in Los Angeles. CBS will broadcast the show, which will feature performances by Nicki Minaj, Foo Fighters, Taylor Swift, Kelly Clarkson, Jason Aldean and Bruno Mars. The last time the awards program had a single host was in 2005, when Queen Latifah, another rapper turned actress, played that role. In the past, the producers have relied on comedians as hosts, among them Jon Stewart, Billy Crystal, Ellen DeGeneres and Rosie O'Donnell.

Imagine how Mitt Romney would campaign if he actually ran as a private equity executive, dangerous though that may be in this era of the Tea Party and Occupy Wall Street. Aggressively attacked by a super PAC supporting Newt Gingrich, Mr. Romney stands accused of being a rapacious capitalist intent on destroying jobs for personal gain. Mr. Romney has responded: Au contraire! He argues that his work at Bain Capital, one of the earliest and most successful private equity firms, created jobs by making companies more efficient and successful.

EASLEY, S.C. -- Even before polls confirmed the tightening race in South Carolina, Newt Gingrich bounded from event to event on Wednesday as if he were having a flashback to, oh, about six weeks ago, when ''surge'' appeared in every line written about him. He fed off enthusiastic crowds, strong reviews of his debate performance on Monday and incoming fire from Mitt Romney, whose attacks seemed to confirm that Mr. Gingrich mattered again.

9 A.M. (MoreMax) GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING (2003) This feature directorial debut from Peter Webber, based on the novel by Tracy Chevalier, imagines the life of Griet (Scarlett Johansson, right), a teenage maid in the Netherlands in the 1660s who becomes the muse for Johannes Vermeer (Colin Firth) and is immortalized in one of his most famous paintings. ''Ms. Johansson is photographed so that her skin is as opalescent as her earring, but the movie is opaque,'' Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. ''It is an earnest, obvious melodrama with no soul, filled with the longing silences that come after a sigh.'' Yet, he added, the film is ''a dexterous and absorbing visual re-creation of the lighting and the look that Vermeer achieved in his work.'' The movie received Oscar nominations for art direction, set decoration, cinematography and costume design. 9:15 A.M. (HBO2) CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS (1989) When the mistress (Anjelica Huston) of Judah Rosenthal (Martin Landau, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a Manhattan ophthalmologist, threatens to go public with their affair and his unethical financial dealings, he hires his mobster brother (Jerry Orbach) to kill her in this movie from Woody Allen, who received best director and best screenplay nominations. Mr. Allen also plays Cliff Stern, a married documentarian infatuated by another woman (Mia Farrow). Sam Waterston is Judah's best friend, a rabbi; Alan Alda is a successful television producer and Cliff's brother-in-law. ''The wonder of 'Crimes and Misdemeanors' is the facility with which Mr. Allen deals with so many interlocking stories of so many differing tones and voices,'' Vincent Canby wrote in The Times. ''The film cuts back and forth between parallel incidents and between present and past with the effortlessness of a hip, contemporary Aesop.''

KARLIE KLOSS, model. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW The jacket is a Christian Dior that John Galliano gave me after shooting a campaign. It's a classic Dior silhouette: ultrasophisticated and chic. The Prada dress, I bought in Paris. The boots are Kurt Geiger, which I bought when I was shopping with my best friend, Jourdan Dunn, in London. I always go on a shopping spree and spend too much when Jourdan and I are together.

Bi-Rite Market is something of an institution in San Francisco. A grocery store with a huge and faithful following, it doesn't see itself as just a grocery store. People actually line up on the street to get inside. The reviews for the store on Yelp are overwhelmingly positive. The homepage on the store's Web site proclaims, ''Bi-Rite is a neighborhood market, feeding our community with love, passion & integrity.'' Sam Mogannam, who owns both the market and a nearby creamery, wanted his Web sites to capture the spirit of his stores. ''We wanted the experience of logging on to biritemarket.com and biritecreamery.com to be as similar to the experience of walking through the door of our market and creamery as we could,'' Mr. Mogannam said. ''This meant showing the bounty of the produce, prepared foods, and delicious grocery products we offer, for that wow feeling of surprise our guests have each time they come to the market.''

GRUNSCHLAG--Rosi, on January 15, 2012. Predeceased by her sister Toni and brother David. She was the daughter of the late Morris and Cecilia Grunschlag. Rosi and Toni were preeminent duo pianists and Steinway artists, who gave concerts all over the world.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Wednesday about a building project in the East Village that received a permit to proceed just before the Landmarks Preservation Commission voted to declare the area a historic district misstated, at one point, the surname of the executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, who supported preservation. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, he is Andrew Berman, not Sherman.

LAS VEGAS -- If you have ever wished you could drive a dance club and have a DJ in your dashboard -- and really, who hasn't? -- Pioneer has your car stereo. The company has put a virtual DJ in three of its in-dash music systems by adding a feature called Mixtrax that links the owner's music into a non-stop track for a club-style sound. It gave the first public showing of the system this week at the International Consumer Electronics Show.

Do you have a bunch of programs open on a PC or Mac and want to switch around between them without fumbling for the mouse? On a Windows system, just hold down the Alt key while pressing the Tab key to see a box showing your open windows and applications. Keep holding down the Alt key while pressing the Tab key to cycle through the icons and let go when you get to the program or window you want to use. Microsoft has a list of shortcuts. An Easter egg hidden in Windows 7 lets users see the vintage Windows XP version of the box: just hold down the Alt key on one side of the keyboard, quickly press and let go of the other Alt key on the keyboard's opposite side, then press the Tab key while still holding down that first Alt key.

Two tough sentries guarded Santigold at all times on Monday night. Everywhere she went during her performance at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, there they were: a pair of limber, stoical dancers, faces impassive behind sunglasses but with every other body part in constant and impeccable motion. At one point they wore tuxedo dresses; at another, Victorian tops with sharp shoulders paired with ruffled shorts that fluttered beautifully when they shimmied.

6:25 p.m. | Updated Ryan Seacrest, his talent agency CAA and the events promoter A.E.G. have been talking for three years about making a cable channel for concerts, live events and other entertainment. Now they have found the channel space for it at HDNet, the pioneering but poorly distributed channel owned by the billionaire sports and media mogul Mark Cuban. This summer, HDNet will become AXS TV, a joint venture of Mr. Cuban, Mr. Seacrest's media holding company, CAA and A.E.G.

New York City Opera cleared a major obstacle in its effort to forge ahead in reduced form and without its Lincoln Center home, saying on Wednesday that it had reached agreements with both of its major unions. Rehearsals were to begin immediately. The company and the unions have been trying to come up with a deal for almost a year in negotiations that grew bitter after the company announced it was leaving the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center for various spots across the city. A strike, or even failure to reach an agreement before the Feb. 12 season start, could have put the fragile company under.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. - The frosty exchange over race and social welfare between Juan Williams and Newt Gingrich during Monday night's Fox News debate has become a breakout moment of the South Carolina primary. For many conservatives, it demonstrates how liberals defend a broken entitlement system. And for many liberals, it shows how minorities are often unfairly caricatured as addicted to government aid. As a team from Fox News prepared for this point in the debate, they knew they had a provocative issue on their hands. And they worked to massage Mr. Williams's question, refining it from something that started out in much blunter fashion.

A day after Mitt Romney conceded that he paid a lower tax rate than many Americans, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg - another politician who made his fortune in the financial industry - said on Wednesday that he personally paid ''the highest personal income tax rate.'' Mr. Bloomberg, a billionaire who is usually reluctant to discuss his finances, said the bulk of his earnings stemmed from holdings in his media company, which he said was taxed as ordinary income at the highest city, state and federal rates, before he took deductions for charitable giving.

At this point, Adele's run at the top of the Billboard chart is titanic. Literally: This week Adele's ''21'' (XL/Columbia) notches its 16th No. 1, the first time since the ''Titanic'' soundtrack in 1998 that a release has topped the list as many times. As Billboard notes, only three albums in the last 20 years have had more weeks at No. 1: Billy Ray Cyrus's ''Some Gave All,'' which had 17 in 1992; Garth Brooks's ''Ropin' the Wind,'' with 18 in 1991 and 1992; and the soundtrack to ''The Bodyguard,'' with 20 in 1992 and 1993.) Adele's ''21,'' out since last February and a safe bet to sweep the Grammy Awards next month, sold 104,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing the album's total to just over six million. Its weekly sales have not dipped below 100,000 since August. It was also only a matter of time before an Adele song also reclaimed No. 1 on Billboard's digital songs chart. This week ''Set Fire to the Rain,'' the third single from ''21,'' rose two spots to the top with 193,000 downloads, while last week's No. 1 download, Jason Mraz's ''I Won't Give Up,'' fell to No. 9 with 127,000 sales, a 44 percent drop.

Joining its hometown industry and betting on the success of YouTube's new initiative to promote original content, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announced that it would start an online video channel in July featuring news and talk-show programming, among other art-focused shows. MOCA TV, as the channel will be known, will be the first contemporary-art channel to be included as part of YouTube's plan, announced last October, to move more aggressively onto the turf of network and cable television by creating dozens of channels featuring comedy, sports, music and other kinds of entertainment. YouTube, a unit of Google, has already announced programming partnerships with the likes of The Wall Street Journal, Thomson Reuters, and WWE, the wrestling producer, as well as the production companies of celebrities like Madonna, Rainn Wilson, and Shaquille O'Neal.

But poetry, it is now clear, can be tantamount to treason in China, just as it was in Czechoslovakia (Václav Havel), the Soviet Union (Joseph Brodsky and many others) and other authoritarian regimes of yesteryear.

Blog Responds in Grooveshark Case: Digital Music News, an industry blog that has found itself in the middle of a copyright infringement suit against the streaming service Grooveshark, has responded to a subpoena it received in the case. A pair of anonymous comments on the blog, purportedly written by Grooveshark employees, have become central pieces of evidence in the major record labels' case against the service, and last weekend Grooveshark served Digital Music News with a subpoena for information about those comments. Paul Resnikoff, the blog's publisher, explained in a detailed post on Friday addressed to Grooveshark's lawyers why he would not comply with the subpoena. He noted that to protect the identity of anonymous commenters, the site "flushes" relevant data after 24 hours and that he is entitled to the protection of state shield laws for journalists. He wrote:

The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the giant public employees' union, will begin airing a 30-second video ad in Florida on Saturday attacking Mitt Romney for making what it said was a $473,000 profit from his firm's investments in a medical company that admitted engaging in Medicare fraud.

Since the start of the presidential campaign, independent groups have spent at least $29.5 million asking voters to elect or defeat candidates through television advertisements and other means. The most active groups have been "super PACs," which can raise unlimited money from individuals, corporations and labor unions. Although these groups cannot legally be tied to a candidate, several of the most-active ones are run or advised by former associates or campaign staff. Track the spending of each of these independent groups here.

Michael Anthony, chef and partner at Gramercy Tavern, returned to the kitchen last week after recovering from surgery to repair a tear in his aorta, Papermag reports. Mr. Anthony, 44, had surgery in the fall for a rare condition.

In this week's column, I roast a whole fish. If it sounds familiar it's because we posted a video of the process last winter. Here it is again, and it may help flesh out the recipe if you have any questions about the techniques.

The Detroit Pistons have one of the worst offenses in the N.B.A. The ball never seems to get to the players it should, the shots seem to go up before a quality opening is actually created and the team as a whole stumbles into an alarming number of miscues. It's no trick of scheduling that lost Detroit 12 of its first 15 games, as the inability to score in any kind of efficient or consistent manner has been a big problem - and sadly, a big problem among many - for the Pistons thus far.

Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about force-placed insurance -- something that most homeowners don't know about until their mortgage lender sends them a letter telling them they need it. If the homeowners don't act quickly, the lender will buy the insurance for them, almost always at a price that's a lot higher than the market rate.

JPMorgan Chase has hired Marc Granetz, until last month a senior banking executive at Credit Suisse, to spearhead an internal push to improve the firm's own financial strength and strategy, the bank announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

Wikipedia has been a household name for years. But when the site announced that it would black out its English-language site earlier this week in support of a Webwide protest against two antipiracy bills, it became a hot topic of conversation.

In the New York Times Book Review, Charles Isherwood reviews Ian Donaldson's "Ben Jonson: A Life." Jonson, a playwright and "Britain's first literary celebrity," was a contemporary of Shakespeare. In his book, Mr. Donaldson makes the case that Jonson was as central as Shakespeare to the development of the British theater. Honda kicked off the 2012 New York motorcycle show early, revealing a new model on Thursday night intended for the American market. The NC700X was first introduced at the EICMA industry show in Milan in November, but was described then as a Europe-only model.
As my colleagues Vikas Bajaj and Sruthi Gottipati report, the Indian-born author Salman Rushdie canceled a planned appearance at a literary festival in India on Friday, citing recent death threats.
